<item>
<title>Runner Suffers Heart Attack, Finishes Race Later</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/runner-suffers-heart-attack-finishes-race-later
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/heart-health/041917_aharunner_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Bill Hughes and his daughter, Bethany Gordon, had just made the turn for the halfway point in last April’s Monument 10K in Virginia when Hughes grabbed his daughter’s arm.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Oh my gosh!” he cried before collapsing.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Gordon flipped her father over with the help of other racers. His face was bloodied from the fall and he wasn’t responsive.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Someone said, ‘His chest isn’t moving,’ so I started chest compressions immediately because I knew it was important to do it right away,” Gordon said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After getting about a dozen compressions in, another racer took over. Three bystanders – two of whom were race participants and all medical professionals – alternated giving CPR.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A police officer quickly arrived with an automated external defibrillator, or AED, a portable device that can shock the heart back to a normal rhythm.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hughes was in an ambulance on his way to the hospital within about 10 minutes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Testing at the hospital revealed Hughes needed a triple bypass, which he had a few days later. After the surgery, he began cardiac rehabilitation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Fifty days after his cardiac arrest, he was strong enough to return to the race course and complete the second half.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He crossed the finish line with his family and some of his rescuers. He called the experience “humbling.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s overwhelming to think about how many people helped save me and all the support I’ve gotten,” said Hughes, a retired Army officer who works at the Pentagon.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Warning signs ignored&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Even before his cardiac arrest, Hughes was working with a cardiologist to manage his risks for heart disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hughes, 61, had high blood pressure and managed it for more than a decade with medication.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He also had a family history of cardiovascular diseases.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;His grandfather had a stroke in his 60s and died two years later. His father had two heart attacks, one of which occurred in his 30s. Then his brother suffered a fatal heart at age 54.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This really opened my eyes to the importance of your family history,” Hughes said. “I had all those warning signs from my family, but I didn’t really take them seriously.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hughes has overhauled his diet to add more fruits, vegetables, whole grains and lean meats. He &amp;nbsp;has also sharply reduced fatty foods and salt.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hughes has urged his two daughters and two sons to talk with their doctors about their risks.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He also shared his experience with 300 co-workers at a health-focused “town hall” at the Pentagon. He encouraged them to check with their doctors about their risks and learn what they can about their family health history.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Importance of CPR training&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The experience also gave Hughes a greater appreciation for&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href=&quot;http://cpr.heart.org/AHAECC/CPRAndECC/UCM_473161_CPR-and-ECC.jsp&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;CPR training&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He underwent training last July.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Each year in the United States, more than 350,000 cardiac arrests occur outside a hospital. Only about 11 percent of those treated by emergency medical services survive, according to &lt;a href=&quot;http://cpr.heart.org/AHAECC/CPRAndECC/AboutCPRFirstAid/CPRFactsAndStats/UCM_475748_CPR-Facts-and-Stats.jsp&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;statistics&lt;/a&gt; from the American Heart Association.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;CPR can double or triple a person’s chance of survival, especially if performed within the first few minutes of cardiac arrest.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Gordon, 32, is a teacher and underwent CPR training a few years ago as a workplace requirement.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I always figured someone else would be around that was better prepared,” she said. “The fact that I was able to use it on my dad really made the importance of knowing CPR more real.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Gordon has become a strong advocate for CPR training, sharing her story on social media and with her coworkers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We’ve heard from so many people that said they got certified after hearing our story,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hughes has been exercising regularly, logging at least 11,500 steps every day. He’s careful to listen to his body and take things at a slower pace so he doesn’t get overtired.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On April 1, he returned to the Monument 10K. Although initially apprehensive, he completed the race in 81 minutes, mixing walking and jogging.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He raced alongside Gordon, as well as his other daughter, Emily Clayton, and son-in-law, Brandon Clayton.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I was tired, but didn’t overdo it,” he said, adding that in the past he would have pushed himself to jog the entire race. “The race could not have been better.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/runner-crosses-finish-line-50-days-after-heart-stops-during-race/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;original story&lt;/a&gt; was published on &lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;American Heart Association News&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/em&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<updateddate>2017-04-19T15:00:00</updateddate>

<dc:creator>American Heart Association News</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-19T22:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>
‘Boot Camp’ Teaches Caregivers How to Deal with Alzheimer’s Patients
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/boot-camp-teaches-caregivers-with-alzheimers-patients
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/aging/041917_alzheimersbootcamp_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&
]]>
<![CDATA[
lt;p&gt;Caring for someone with dementia often goes on for years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;First the person you love has trouble remembering simple words. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Then, she puts her phone in the refrigerator. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Before you turn around, she wanders out the door into the street and can’t find her way home. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It isn’t easy to know what to do, even for nurses and doctors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Family members usually learn as they go along. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But expert advice can make the lives of caregivers and their loved ones easier.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Attending a free one-day “boot camp” for caregivers, organized by the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA), made all the difference to Hugo Schmidt. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Schmidt, a retired middle school teacher in Los Angeles, has been caring for his 72-year-old wife, Alice, since 2012.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For some time, Alice has been using a walker. When they were outdoors, Schmidt held her arm.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At the UCLA education program, he learned that she could pull him off balance or he could twist her arm. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Instead, he learned to support her by holding the back of her pants or a belt. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I asked her if it made her feel secure and she said it was better,” he told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A growing need for education&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;About &lt;a href=&quot;http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamainternalmedicine/article-abstract/2587084&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;9&lt;/a&gt; percent of Americans age 65 and over suffer from dementia, when loss of memory and reasoning abilities interfere with daily life.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They may live as long as 26 years with the condition, needing personal care. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They might have &lt;a href=&quot;/health/alzheimers-disease/life-expectancy&quot;&gt;Alzheimer’s disease&lt;/a&gt;, caused by a buildup of plaques in the brain, or &lt;a href=&quot;/health/dementia/vascular-dementia&quot;&gt;vascular dementia&lt;/a&gt;, which comes after stroke.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;More than &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.alz.org/documents_custom/facts-and-figures-2017-news-release.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;15 million&lt;/a&gt; Americans are caring for loved ones with dementia. A third say that this responsibility has hurt their own health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Like Schmidt, attending one of the many education programs around the country could make their lives easier. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Everyone needs training, observed Dr. Zaldy S. Tan, medical director of UCLA’s Alzheimer’s and Dementia Care Program.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It doesn’t matter how smart, well educated, or sophisticated you are, even if you’re a physician or nurse,” he told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Coping with caregiving&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;At the UCLA program, 20 to 30 caregivers receive training from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The day includes expert reports on the medical side of dementia. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A physical therapist demonstrates how to use different types of walkers and canes. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Participants can talk with other caregivers, exchanging stories and tips, and learn about ongoing support groups they can join. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They also play out scenes with actors who play the part of the person with dementia.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Each person might have 5 or 10 minutes with an actor. Other caregivers then give feedback. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the scene, the caregiver might play out how they would prevent the person with dementia from leaving the house. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another scene might be about encouraging someone to take medicine. The caregiver might choose from sample food that would be best for someone with a swallowing problem. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So far, 84 percent of the participants have rated the program “excellent.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They also report in a survey by UCLA that their sense of knowing what to do six months after their sessions remained higher than it had been before the training. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Tan told Healthline that caregivers may not want to be told what to do. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They may take pride in their ways and not want to change. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“They need to be prepared for the long haul,” he said, and the fact their loved one will change over time. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One common mistake is to stick to low-fat or low-calorie diets even though people with dementia tend to stop eating and may lose weight. Tan recommends loosening up the diet so your loved one gets nourishment. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ruth Drew, director of family and information services for the Alzheimer’s Association, a national nonprofit, encourages caregivers to look for education that allows them to participate with questions, or in support groups.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s important to learn to see the world through your loved one’s eyes and play along, she told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She gave the example of a husband who rigged a latch at the top of the front door too high for his wife to reach. When she’d try to open it, he’d say, “Are you having trouble with that door? There’s something wrong with it. I have to fix it.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Getting into an argument, ordering them around, or treating them like children doesn’t work,” she said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;You also can’t force someone with dementia to learn.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Drew encountered two adult daughters who were troubled when their mother kept asking, “When is Dad coming home?” after he had died. They would explain that he had died, and their mother would cry. They even took her to their father’s gravesite.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But people with dementia have lost the ability to absorb new information, no matter how patient you are. The better move, Drew said, is to say, “Dad’s not coming home tonight. He’ll be back later in the week.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The UCLA team is looking for funding to support future boot camps. More programs are needed, said Drew.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There are so many people dealing with Alzheimer’s in their families, my hope is to see more education programs of every sort, with a variety of options,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Alzheimer’s Association offers &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.alz.org/care/alzheimers-dementia-care-training-certification.asp&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;resources&lt;/a&gt; like online training, local workshops, DVDs, and books. Its Savvy Caregiver program is a free five-session program.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;One caregiver’s growth&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Schmidt’s relationship with his wife has changed since he attended the UCLA boot camp two years ago.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For years, he had been teasing Alice, intentionally making her angry. For him it was a way to have fun and he thought she might like the chance to express anger.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I kind of liked it. You don’t get much attention from someone with dementia,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He didn’t think it was unkind because, he said, “She wouldn’t remember it a half-hour later.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But at boot camp, he got the message that he should stop.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another lesson: Give Alice information slowly. Instead of saying, “We’re going to the bathroom to put on your makeup,” he’ll say, “We’re going to the bathroom … and I’ll tell you everything else when you get there.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In restaurants, Schmidt now orders for her. At boot camp, he told Healthline, he learned to make her choices simple: two choices at most.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Both he and Alice resisted suggestions that she go to a day care program. The UCLA experts recommended one, and she now goes every Thursday from 10 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. Schmidt gets a day off and has noticed that Alice is “sharper” for days afterward. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There’s a lot you have to know,” he said. “You learn some by trial and error, but it’s far more effective to go to boot camp to have experts and other people with the same problem give you information and leave with practical knowledge and people you can turn to.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Schmidt’s adult daughter also attended a UCLA boot camp. And he’d like to return for a refresher course to help train his 5-year-old granddaughter on how to respond to Alice. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The most important thing I learned is that I’m really lucky,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He and Alice can still talk, after 40 years together. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

</guid>
<dc:creator>Temma Ehrenfeld</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-19T21:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>How Dangerous is Rat Lungworm Disease?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/how-dangerous-is-rat-lungworm-disease
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/041917_ratlungworm_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;Photo: Centers of Diseases Control and Prevention&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Photo: Centers of Diseases Control and Prevention&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A holiday in Hawaii conjures up images of beautiful beaches and ocean views — a tropical paradise. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;What is less likely to come to mind is a brain-invading parasite known as a rat lungworm. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But that was the reality for &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cbsnews.com/news/couple-contracts-rat-lungworm-disease-on-hawaii-honeymoon/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;newlyweds&lt;/a&gt; from California, who contracted the disease while vacationing on Maui. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The couple are two of at least nine reported cases of the disease in Hawaii so far in 2017.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Experts say the rising number of cases is worrying. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s concerning for everyone. People's health is at risk and produce growers’ livelihood is at risk,” Robert Cowie, PhD, a professor at the Pacific Biosciences Research Center at the University of Hawaii, told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What is rat lungworm disease?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Rat lungworm (&lt;em&gt;Angiostrongylus cantonensis&lt;/em&gt;) is a form of parasitic worm.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/parasites/angiostrongylus/gen_info/faqs.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)&lt;/a&gt;, the adult parasite is found in rats, which pass the larvae of the parasite in their feces.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Snails and slugs then get infected by ingesting the larvae from the feces.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Humans can become infected with the disease by ingesting raw or undercooked snails or slugs that have been infected by the parasite.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It is also possible to come into contact with the disease by eating raw produce like lettuce that hasn’t been properly washed and may have been contaminated by snails or slugs. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The effects vary and can include cold and flu-like symptoms, paralysis, coma, and in rare cases, death. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;James Creecy, PhD, assistant professor at the University of Central Oklahoma’s Forensic Science Institute, has done &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4480392/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;research&lt;/a&gt; into the expansion of rat lungworm in the United States.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He says the disease can in some cases lead to serious complications, like &lt;a href=&quot;/health/meningitis&quot;&gt;meningitis&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Eosinophilic meningitis is better described as white blood cells in the cerebrospinal fluid. Other symptoms include cranial nerve abnormalities, ataxia [loss of full control of bodily movements], &lt;a href=&quot;/health/encephalitis&quot;&gt;encephalitis&lt;/a&gt;, coma, and rarely death,” he told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“While this all seems very bad,” he added, “the disease is rare and there is an effective treatment for human infections. Infected wildlife are not as fortunate.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The CDC says that common types of treatment are for symptoms of the infection, rather than rat lungworm itself. Even without treatment, they say, the parasite will die over time. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Why disease hits Hawaii&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Robert Hollingsworth, PhD, is an entomologist for the U.S. Pacific Basin Agricultural Research Center, based in Hilo, Hawaii.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He has done research on a species of semi-slug (&lt;em&gt;Parmarion martensi&lt;/em&gt;) that has been on the Hawaiian Islands since at least 2004. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Semi-slugs were new pests on Hawaii Island when I was asked to investigate an outbreak in 2004. The residents reporting the outbreak had all become sick from sharing a salad. That's why I sent off specimens to the CDC for testing. The specimens were highly infected,” he told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Semi-slugs are considered especially dangerous in the spread of rat lungworm disease. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This species is high risk because it likes to climb, is relatively fast moving, and quickly locates rich food sources, and because specimens are likely to be infected by rat lungworm. More so than many other slug/snail species, they avoid soil and favor plastic and building materials. They have a penchant for getting in harm’s way,” Hollingsworth said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think of them as a ‘trash’ species that does particularly well around residences due to hiding places and the types of materials found around residences. In fact, inside and under trash cans are a favorite hiding place,” he added. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cowie agrees the latest spate of incidences of the disease is most likely due to this species of semi-slug.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The current outbreak on Maui seems associated with a particular species of slug [&lt;em&gt;Parmarion martensi&lt;/em&gt;] that we know to be a very good carrier of the worms. So if the outbreak is related to this species, why is it only happening now? Maybe because it has become more abundant and widespread,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Son’s infection leads to research group&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kathleen Howe became interested in rat lungworm after her son was infected with the disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With Susan Jarvi, of the University of Hawaii, she formed the Hawaii Island Rat Lungworm Working Group. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“My son contracted rat lungworm disease … was in the hospital for four months and in a coma for three months. He suffered a lot of brain and nerve damage and was not expected to recover,” Howe told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I became interested in research and education because there was no apparent research or education happening,” she added. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Jarvi, PhD, a professor of pharmaceutical sciences at the University of Hawaii at Hilo, says it is important people understand the dangers of rat lungworm and take proper precautions against the disease. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Wash vegetables thoroughly … It's also important to be educated about it and implement proper vector control,” she told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Experts advise people to minimize the areas slugs and snails may like to hide (such as in mulch, under plant pots, and piles of wood) and to use approved baits. It’s also important to get rid of rats. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Jarvi agrees the spread of the disease is most likely due to semi-slugs, but she believes there may also be another factor. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The lack of action in control by the state also likely contributes,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Hawaii Department of Health did not respond to Healthline’s request for comment on this story.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-04-19T13:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-19T13:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/how-dangerous-is-rat-lungworm-disease
</guid>
<dc:creator>Elizabeth Pratt</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-19T20:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>What Makes Someone a ‘SuperAger’?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/what-makes-someone-a-superager
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/aging/041917_superager_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The good news is that social scientists at Northwestern University have identified a group of older adults they call “SuperAgers,” whose cerebral cortexes shrink at half the rate of most older people. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The bad news is that so far it isn’t clear just what it is that these SuperAgers — all 80 or older — have or do that keeps their level of cognitive decline so low.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers already knew SuperAgers’ brains tend to retain more brain volume and typically don’t show the same wear-and-tear as other older adults.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This research was an effort to determine why.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/article-abstract/2614177&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;findings&lt;/a&gt; were published in the April 4 edition of the Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Unlocking the SuperAger mystery&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The team used &lt;a href=&quot;/health/head-mri&quot;&gt;MRI&lt;/a&gt; to measure the thickness of the cortex in 24 SuperAgers and 12 cognitively average peers who were the same age and had the same level of education.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Over 18 months, the annual decline in thickness between the first and second visits for the SuperAgers was 1.06 percent and 2.24 percent for the control group.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We’re trying to understand what it is about them and eventually replicate it,” Amanda Cook, a clinical neuropsychology doctoral student in the laboratory of Emily Rogalski and Sandra Weintraub at Northwestern, told Healthline. “It’s not like all the people in that group eat blueberries every morning.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To confound the picture further, some participants say they never touch alcohol, while others swear by their daily cocktail.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The normal aging process involves shrinking of the brain.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“But what’s unique about these people? There’s not much research on cognitive decline” in this population, Cook said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We tried to control outside factors,” Cook said. “Both groups of people had no difference in pre-morbidity. They had the same IQs, the same amount of education.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nor was there a difference in their rates of smoking, obesity, and diabetes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We don’t have MRIs of their brains when they were 50 or 60, so we can’t tell if they always had bigger brains,” Cook said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Studying the brain&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Heather Snyder, senior director of medical and scientific operations for the Alzheimer's Association, called the study interesting.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We want to know how they are different, and how we can replicate that for other people,” she told Healthline.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Alzheimer’s is the sixth leading cause of death in the country and the only one in the top 10 for which we have essentially no treatment,” Snyder said. “Of people over 85, 1 in 3 will develop dementia.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;What’s known is complicated and not fully explained. Snyder cited blood pressure as an example.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“High blood pressure in middle age is bad. It’s linked to cardiovascular disease. But in old age, high blood pressure is good because it feeds the brain,” she explained.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Behind the scientific discoveries is the willingness to pursue them.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Continued federal funding for studies is crucial,” Snyder said. “We are making progress and the need will only grow,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Focus of future research&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers in the field are also encouraged.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;William E. Sonntag, PhD, professor and director of Reynolds Oklahoma Center on Aging at the University of Oklahoma Health Sciences Center, discussed the issue with Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“What do these people have that the rest of us don’t? That’s the key question. And this will undoubtedly be the focus of studies over the next several years,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sonntag listed some possibilities: &lt;/p&gt; &lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Are there are factors in the blood that help to maintain brain volume? &lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Is there a particular diet (less likely although still possible)? &lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Are there specific genes that contribute to this effect? This is likely, although difficult to pull all the genetic effects out since it’s probably an interaction among several genes.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Do these SuperAgers have better vasculature (more blood vessels) in the brain (cerebrovasculature) that are critical for maintaining brain volume and function? If the blood vessels deteriorate, so does the brain. This may be why exercise appears to have a beneficial effect.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sonntag thought the study offered intriguing possibilities.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Any time that there can be a clear marker or predictor of cognitive dysfunction, the field moves forward. We can then use this marker as a way to test interventions,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sonntag said the key to scientific research and the development of pharmaceutical agents that may result in maintained function is to find the specific cellular mechanisms that make this happen. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Once the cellular mechanisms for this effect are identified, drugs can be developed to intervene,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.bumc.bu.edu/centenarian/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;New England Centenarian Study&lt;/a&gt;, Dr. Thomas Perls, a geriatrician at Boston University, suggested another way to look at this field of study.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a &lt;a href=&quot;http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,994967-1,00.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;story&lt;/a&gt; in Time magazine in 2004, he was quoted as saying, “It's not ‘the older you get, the sicker you get,’ but ‘the older you get, the healthier you've been.’ The advantage of living to 100 is not so much how you are at 100, but how you got there.”&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Senior Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-19T11:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-19T11:00:00</updateddate>

http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/what-makes-someone-a-superager
</guid>
<dc:creator>Roberta Alexander</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-19T18:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>
Marijuana-Based Medicine Can Reduce Epilepsy Seizures, Researchers Say
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/marijuana-based-med-may-reduce-epilepsy-seizures
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/041817_cannabisepilepsy_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Are marijuana-based products the antidote for epileptic seizures?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A study released today is joining a growing chorus of research material that concludes cannabis oil can help reduce seizures for people with certain kinds of epilepsy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers say &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.projectcbd.org/what-cbd&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;cannabidiol&lt;/a&gt; cut the number of seizures in half for a sizable number of children and adults with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS), a severe form of epilepsy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The results of the clinical study were presented today at the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.aan.com/conferences/2017-annual-meeting/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;American Academy of Neurology 2017 Annual Meeting&lt;/a&gt; in Boston. The research was sponsored by GW Pharmaceuticals, a developer of cannabidiol.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our study found that cannabidiol shows great promise in that it may reduce seizures that are otherwise difficult to control,” said study author Dr. Anup Patel, of Nationwide Children’s Hospital and The Ohio State University College of Medicine in Columbus and a member of the American Academy of Neurology, in a press release.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What the research showed&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;For their double-blind, placebo-controlled study, researchers followed 225 people for 14 weeks.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The LGS participants had an average age of 16 and had an average of 85 “drop seizures” a month. They had also tried an average of six epilepsy drugs that didn’t work for them and were taking an average of three epilepsy drugs during the study.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some of the participants were given a dose of 20 milligrams per kilogram (mg/kg) of cannabidiol daily. Others received a lower dose of 10 mg/kg daily or were given a placebo.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers said those taking the higher dose had an overall decrease of 42 percent in drop seizures. In addition, 40 percent of this group had their seizures reduced by half or more.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The participants taking the lower dose had an average decrease of 37 percent in seizures. About 36 percent of this group experienced a decline in seizures by half or more.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The placebo group saw an overall decrease of 17 percent in seizures. About 15 percent had their seizures decline by half or more.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers added that those in the high-dose group were 2.6 times more likely to say their overall condition had improved than the those taking the placebo.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There were side effects for 94 percent of those taking the higher dose and 84 percent of those taking the lower dose. About 72 percent of the placebo group reported side effects.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, the side effects were mild to moderate symptoms such as loss of appetite and sleepiness according to the researchers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers said there are plans to submit a new drug application for cannabidiol to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our results suggest that cannabidiol may be effective for those with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome in treating drop seizures,” said Patel. “This is important because this kind of epilepsy is incredibly difficult to treat. While there were more side effects for those taking cannabidiol, they were mostly well tolerated. I believe that it may become an important new treatment option for these patients.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A growing body of evidence&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;This research is the latest in a number of studies that have concluded marijuana-based products can help people with epilepsy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws (NORML) has &lt;a href=&quot;http://norml.org/library/item/epilepsy&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;listed&lt;/a&gt; a number of these studies on its website.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They also tout a &lt;a href=&quot;http://norml.org/news/2017/03/09/study-cbd-dominant-cannabis-extracts-reduce-seizure-frequency&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; published last month that concluded cannabis oil can reduce seizure frequency in people with refractory epilepsy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On its website, the Epilepsy Foundation &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.epilepsy.com/learn/treating-seizures-and-epilepsy/other-treatment-approaches/medical-marijuana-and-epilepsy&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;states&lt;/a&gt; that evidence from past research indicates cannabidiol can potentially be helpful to people with epilepsy. The organization does note that marijuana-based products have side effects. The group does support removing barriers to more cannabis research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In January, Consumer Reports published &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.consumerreports.org/seizures/cannabis-oil-cbd-treat-seizures/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;an article&lt;/a&gt; stating that research on marijuana extracts’ ability to control seizures has been promising.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The publication, however, did urge some caution. It noted that cannabis products aren’t regulated by the FDA and that for some people taking epilepsy drugs is more effective than using marijuana-based medicine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For officials at NORML, though, the case is clear.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“[The study] findings are encouraging, but not altogether surprising,” Paul Armentano, deputy director of NORML, told Healthline. “They confirm the testimonials of thousands of patients who have obtained seizure relief from cannabis-derived medicine when conventional treatment regimens have failed.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The parents of Charlotte Figi are also convinced.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2013, the 7-year-old girl with Dravet syndrome was experiencing an average of 50 seizures a day.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Her parents, along with a Colorado-based medical marijuana group, obtained a high-concentration cannabidiol and started administering it to the young girl.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The parents told &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cnn.com/2013/08/07/health/charlotte-child-medical-marijuana/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;CNN&lt;/a&gt; the medication significantly reduced their daughter’s seizures.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/epi.12610/full&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2014 report&lt;/a&gt; published in the journal Epilepsia stated the girl’s seizures had been reduced to two to three nocturnal convulsions a month.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers said the reduction had been constant for 20 months.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Armentano said it’s time for the United States to stop hampering cannabis-based research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“One can only wonder how much sooner these alternative treatments would have been available and embraced by the medical community were it not for America’s longstanding stigmatization and criminalization of both cannabis and those who consume it,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>

<updateddate>2017-04-18T14:00:00</updateddate>

<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-18T21:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Can You Tax People into Quitting Smoking?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/can-you-tax-people-into-quitting-smoking
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/041817_cigarettetax_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt
]]>
<![CDATA[
;&lt;p&gt;On April 1, smoking in California became much more painful — to people’s wallets, that is.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The harmful health effects of cigarette smoking are still there — things like an increased risk of coronary heart disease, stroke, and lung cancer. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And cigarette smoking still causes more than 480,000 deaths each year in the United States, according to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/tobacco/data_statistics/fact_sheets/health_effects/effects_cig_smoking/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But thanks to a statewide &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sacbee.com/news/local/health-and-medicine/article142084974.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;ballot measure&lt;/a&gt; approved last year, California’s cigarette tax is now $2.87 — two dollars more per pack than its long-time low.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The tobacco industry spent &lt;a href=&quot;https://theconversation.com/californians-backing-cigarette-tax-boost-even-though-big-tobacco-spending-millions-67884&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;$71 million&lt;/a&gt; to try to defeat this measure.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With the increase, California has the ninth highest cigarette tax in the country. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This is well below &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.tobaccofreekids.org/research/factsheets/pdf/0097.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;New York’s&lt;/a&gt; $4.35 per pack state tax and &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.tobaccofreekids.org/research/factsheets/pdf/0267.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Chicago’s&lt;/a&gt; $6.16 per pack, which includes both state and local taxes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But it’s much higher than Missouri’s almost invisible 17 cents per pack.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Cigarette taxes reduce smoking&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The goal of the California tax is to increase the price of cigarettes high enough so that people quit smoking or never start.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But will it work?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The simple answer is “Yes.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The bottom line is that significant tax increases are the single most effective way to reduce tobacco use,” Frank Chaloupka, PhD, an economist and research professor of health policy at the University of Illinois at Chicago School of Public Health, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A “significant” tax means large enough for people to feel the pinch in their wallet — at least 10 percent of the current price per pack.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If you raise the price enough that companies can’t absorb it, or can’t offset it with their marketing practices,” said Chaloupka, “then you start to see real public health impact.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;https://cancercontrol.cancer.gov/brp/tcrb/monographs/21/index.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;monograph&lt;/a&gt; by the National Cancer Institute, The Economics of Tobacco and Tobacco Control, found that in the United States a 10 percent increase in the price of cigarettes can reduce consumption by 4 percent.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Research at the University of California, San Francisco (UCSF), suggests that the state’s new cigarette tax will reduce its smoking rate even more. It’s currently around &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/statesystem/cigaretteuseadult.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;12 percent&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We estimated that just the price effect will cut smoking prevalence over the next five years to around 7 percent,” Stanton Glantz, PhD, professor of medicine and director of the UCSF Center for Tobacco Control Research and Education, told Healthline. “And that doesn’t even account for the effect of the reinvigorated anti-smoking program.”&lt;strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;States sometimes use cigarette tax revenue to also prop up the state’s budget. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But some states reinvest a portion of the money into other anti-tobacco measures, which can boost the health effects of the tax.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When you reinvest some of the tax revenues back into comprehensive tobacco control programs,” said Chaloupka, “you get bigger reductions in adults smoking, bigger effects on youth smoking, and larger overall reductions in cigarette sales.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;California’s tobacco control program will receive an estimated $120 million each year from the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.kmir.com/story/35044990/tobacco-users-trying-to-quit-ahead-of-april-1-2-tax-increase&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;new tax&lt;/a&gt;, according to a report on KMIR television.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This anti-tobacco program, started 28 years ago, has been credited with preventing more than a million early deaths due to cigarette smoking, and saving more than $138 billion in healthcare costs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think with the combined effect of the big price increase and the reinvigorated anti-smoking program,” said Glantz, “we can very well wipe out tobacco as a public health problem in five years in California.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Tax impacts some groups more&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;All smokers will be impacted by California’s new tax, but some groups will feel it more.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the CDC, &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/tobacco/campaign/tips/resources/data/cigarette-smoking-in-united-states.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;people with low incomes&lt;/a&gt;, adults with &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/media/dpk/tobacco/vs-adult-smoking/dpk-vs-adult-smoking-mental-illness.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;mental illness&lt;/a&gt;, and the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/tobacco/campaign/tips/groups/lgbt.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;LGBTQ community&lt;/a&gt; all have higher rates of smoking.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And in California, the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdph.ca.gov/programs/tobacco/Documents/CDPH%20CTCP%20Refresh/Research%20and%20Evaluation/Facts%20and%20Figures/FactsFigures2016PrePrintEditionV2.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;smoking rate&lt;/a&gt; is higher among African-Americans and Native Americans.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“They are, by far, carrying a much higher burden of tobacco-induced disease than the general public,” said Glantz.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;People with low incomes, especially, will be affected because they have less disposable income.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But they will also benefit the most.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“They’re the ones who are smoking, so they’re the ones who are going to pay the tax,” said Glantz. “But with the increase in price, they’re the ones who are going to quit smoking.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The cigarette tax will also head off smoking among young people.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We find that youth uptake of tobacco is two to three times more sensitive to price than overall tobacco users,” said Chaloupka.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The high cost of cigarettes can have a big impact on the “transition period” — when teens are moving from smoking cigarettes bummed from their friends to buying their own.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Glantz also expects a boost to California’s economy, as he described in a post on &lt;a href=&quot;https://theconversation.com/big-tobacco-aims-its-guns-to-kill-california-tobacco-tax-63750&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;The Conversation&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For every dollar spent on cigarettes — excluding taxes — 80 cents leaves the state, flowing mainly to tobacco-producing states.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When people quit smoking, they spend their money on other things, such as dinner at local restaurants or going to the movies. More of this money enters the local economy, where it supports jobs and economic activity.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Not only is the tax going to reduce smoking, reduce healthcare costs, and improve health,” said Glantz, “it’s also going to be a huge job creator in California and a huge stimulus to economic activity.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Public Policy</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-18T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-18T12:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/can-you-tax-people-into-quitting-smoking
</guid>
<dc:creator>Shawn Radcliffe</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-18T19:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Soda Tax Appears to Be Working in Berkeley</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/soda-tax-works-in-berkeley
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/041817_sodatax_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Telling people sugar is bad for them may not get them to cut down on the sweet substance.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, making them pay more for it just might.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s the overall thrust of a new study published today in the journal PLOS Medicine on a new soda tax that’s been in effect in Berkeley, Calif., for more than two years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers say sales of sugar-sweetened beverages appeared to have dropped while the sales of water have risen dramatically.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We were pleasantly surprised to see how much things have changed,” Dr. Lynn Silver, a senior advisor at the Public Health Institute in Oakland, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What researchers found&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.berkeleyvsbigsoda.com/faq&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;soda tax&lt;/a&gt; was approved by Berkeley voters in November 2014.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It took effect on Jan. 1, 2015.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The measure charges distributors of sugar-sweetened beverages one cent per ounce on their products.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In many stores, that extra fee is passed on to consumers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A panel of health experts advises Berkeley city officials on what local programs should receive money from the tax.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study authors report that as of the beginning of this year, the city had collected $2.5 million from the soda tax.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Public Health Institute and the Carolina Population Center at the University of North Carolina oversaw the study.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers studied sales of beverages in Berkeley and surrounding communities from Mar. 1, 2015 to Feb. 29, 2016.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They looked at the prices of beverages at 26 stores in Berkeley as well as the point-of-sale scanner data on more than 15 million beverage items at two supermarket chains from three Berkeley stores and six stores in adjacent cities.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers also conducted a phone survey of 957 Berkeley residents.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers said their data showed sales of sugar-sweetened beverages in Berkeley dropped more than 9 percent during the year that was studied.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They added the sale of water increased by more than 15 percent in that same time period. Sales of juices, teas, and other substitute beverages also went up.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They noted that the sale of sugar-sweetened beverages in nearby communities rose almost 7 percent.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What does the study prove?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Silver said the overall impression researchers got from the study was that the soda tax is working in Berkeley.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think Berkeley will be seen as a turning point,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other experts were also encouraged by the findings, but they did throw up some caution flags.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“These are positive findings and they’re encouraging,” Dr. Bruce Lee, executive director of the Global Obesity Prevention Center at Johns Hopkins, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, Lee noted that sales of sodas did increase in neighborhoods near Berkeley, indicating perhaps people were slipping over the city boundary to buy their sugar-sweetened beverages.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There may be some bleeding out into the edges,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He was encouraged by the increase in water sales in Berkeley, but he was curious to see if products such as fruit juices would continue to rise.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If the tax changes behavior, we want to know what it’s changing to,” Lee said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Donald Marron, PhD, director of economic policy initiatives at the Urban Institute, had a similar reaction.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Marron also wondered how much of Berkeley’s soda decline was due to people driving to other towns.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, he noted that tax hikes do tend to discourage consumers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If you raise the price of something, people will generally buy less of it,” Marron told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Marron did say there isn’t evidence yet of direct health benefits, but that’s because the soda tax hasn’t been in place long enough.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lee said he expects the Berkeley tax will eventually produce health benefits.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It can have some downstream effects,” he said.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Officials at the American Beverage Association said the story in fact acknowledges that soda taxes &quot;do not demonstrate a meaningful reduction in obesity rates.&quot;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Silver said she is hopeful the tax will have an impact on conditions such as &lt;a href=&quot;/health/obesity&quot;&gt;obesity&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;/health/diabetes&quot;&gt;diabetes&lt;/a&gt;, and &lt;a href=&quot;/health/heart-disease&quot;&gt;heart disease&lt;/a&gt; brought on by sugar-laden products.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Decreasing sugar consumption will definitely have health benefits,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Could the tax work in other places?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Is Berkeley a model for other communities?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Both Marron and Lee pointed out that Berkeley, with its population of about 115,000, is smaller than larger metropolitan areas, but larger than many suburban and rural communities.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In larger towns, they said, consumers would probably be less likely to travel across city lines to avoid a soda tax.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Silver doesn’t think people in Berkeley are doing that now.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She said researchers asked people during the phone survey if they were driving to other communities and most of them said they weren’t.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Silver also pointed out that Berkeley’s sugar consumption is about one-third of typical communities in the United States.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She believes a tax would have an even bigger impact in towns where soda sales are higher.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Officials at the American Beverage Association said Berkeley's relatively small size and higher income and low consumption rate make it &quot;a challenging place to determine the true impact of a beverage tax.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;They noted that the increase in soda sales in nearby communities indicates people are driving outside Berkeley to buy beverages. They said the same thing happened when a soda tax was imposed in Philadelphia.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The officials added that their association is taking &quot;aggressive action&quot; to help people reduce their sugar consumption. One way they said they are accomplishing this is by offering alternative beverages. They said they are also launching a nationwide campaign with specific emphasis in places with high obesity rates such as rural Alabama.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Silver did have some tips for other communities contemplating soda surcharges.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She said the tax should be big enough to have an impact on consumers’ wallets.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;An education on the health effects of sugar should accompany the tax.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And, Silver said, the money collected from the tax should be spent wisely.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<item>
<title>Do You Know what Chemicals Are in Your Bath Bomb?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/chemicals-in-bath-bombs
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/041817_bathbombs_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It’s been a long day.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;All you want is to pour yourself a glass of wine and curl up in a nice hot tub.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Better yet, you want to drop a bath bomb in that warm water and immerse yourself in luxury.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Bath bombs have been growing in popularity in recent years, promising everything from aromatherapy benefits to skin-soothing properties in a burst of fizz and color.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But, there’s a catch.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some of those bath bombs you’ve come to adore may be releasing a lot more than just colored fizz into that soothing water. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.consumersafety.org/about-us/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;ConsumerSafety.org&lt;/a&gt;, a consumer advocacy group that keeps the public aware of recalls and health and safety concerns, recently launched an investigation into the components of those bath bombs you’ve come to love.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And what they found might surprise you. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“People are using these toxic products on a daily basis, unknowingly exposing themselves and loved ones to harmful ingredients,” Sydney Ziverts, a health and nutrition investigator who initially compiled the bath bomb research for ConsumerSafety, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What’s in a bath bomb?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;To begin with, many bath bombs have the term “fragrance” listed as an ingredient.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) doesn’t require companies to further break down what chemicals they use to add “fragrance” to their products.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The Food and Drug Administration gives companies a labeling loophole for fragrances to protect a company’s proprietary perfume blend,” said Ziverts. “Therefore, companies don't legally have to disclose any toxic ingredients lingering in their fragrance blends.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some popular fragrance additives are chemicals that have actually made the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.epa.gov/hw/defining-hazardous-waste-listed-characteristic-and-mixed-radiological-wastes&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;hazardous waste list&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/1780852&quot;&gt;Benzene derivatives&lt;/a&gt;, for instance, are a human carcinogen linked to hormone disruption and reproductive malformation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://cfpub.epa.gov/ncer_abstracts/index.cfm/fuseaction/display.highlight/abstract/2313&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Aldehydes&lt;/a&gt; present an increased risk of respiratory allergies, liver disease, and embryo toxicity. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/biomonitoring/phthalates_factsheet.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;phthalates&lt;/a&gt; have been found to decrease hormone levels and sperm quality as well as being linked to obesity, ovarian aging, and some forms of cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Then there’s talc, which has been associated with an &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.consumersafety.org/products/talcum-powder/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;elevated risk of ovarian cancer&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.livestrong.com/article/150690-what-are-the-dangers-of-parabens-in-skin-care/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Parabens&lt;/a&gt; are known to disrupt the endocrine system.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.forbes.com/forbes/welcome/?toURL=https://www.forbes.com/sites/rachelhennessey/2012/08/27/living-in-color-the-potential-dangers-of-artificial-dyes/&amp;amp;refURL=https://www.google.com/&amp;amp;referrer=https://www.google.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;artificial dyes&lt;/a&gt; (specifically D&amp;amp;C Red 33) have been linked to attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in children as well as neuron damage and brain cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The debate over safety&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Officials at Lush Cosmetics, one of the more popular distributors of bath bombs, insist their products are safe.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Meghan Campbell, Lush’s brand and product trainer, went over safety issues ingredient by ingredient.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The bright array of eye-catching colors are all derived from vegetarian food, drug, and cosmetics safe colors [FD&amp;amp;C], or drug and cosmetics safe colors [D&amp;amp;C],” she told Healthline. “The glitter is plastic-free, and even the safe synthetic that provides the famous fizz [baking soda] can be found in most kitchens. Beyond that, Lush adds lovely effective ingredients like sea salt, cocoa butter, and essential oil-based fragrance blends, bespoke to each and every hand-pressed bath bomb.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She said customer safety and satisfaction is their top priority.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Lush would never put an ingredient in a bath bomb that we’d want people to steer clear of,” Campbell said. “We want you in the tub, not running from it.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, Ziverts found Lush’s explanation somewhat lacking. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Very interesting given the ingredients listed on their page(s),” she said in an email to Healthline. “Specifically related to Lush, I wanted to show you &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.lushusa.com/bath/fun/pink/9999903769.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;this&lt;/a&gt;. Although it’s a bubble ‘mold’ and not a bath bomb, you’ll notice the first ingredient listed is talc, which has a direct correlation to ovarian cancer.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are alternatives to bath bombs, such as the ones here listed on the blog &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.abeautifulwhim.com/ingredients-bath-bombs-dangerous/beauty/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;a beautiful whim&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For a fragrance fix use scented candles or incense. You’ll still get that calming aroma without steeping yourself in unknown chemicals — and the soft light will set the mood for relaxing.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If bubbles are your thing, and you don’t want to spring for a jacuzzi, you can find natural recipes &amp;nbsp;for making bubble bath all over the internet. Here’s one from &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.diynatural.com/homemade-bubble-bath/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;DIY Natural&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Is it the eye-popping color that you crave? There are much safer options to consider than dipping yourself in dyes. Look for &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.superbrightleds.com/moreinfo/novelty-lighting/submersible-rgb-led-tea-lights-led-candle-lights-floralytes/1416/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;submersible LED lights&lt;/a&gt; that can illuminate your bath from below.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If you don’t want to relinquish your bath bombs, at least seek out talc-free options, and products scented with recognizable ingredients rather than “fragrances.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, there’s always the option of making &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.popsci.com/how-to-make-your-own-bath-bombs&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;your own bath bombs&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That way you control the ingredients list, and you know exactly what you’re soaking in. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-04-18T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-18T10:00:00</updateddate>

<dc:creator>Leah Campbell</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-18T17:00:00</dc:date>
