<item>
<title>Is There Anything New Blood Tests Can’t Diagnose?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/new-blood-tests
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/100416_bloodtest_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The rig
]]>
<![CDATA[
ht diagnosis means everything.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In some cases, it can be a matter of life and death.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/jep.12747/full&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;recent study&lt;/a&gt; in the Journal of Evaluation in Clinical Practice found that more than 20 percent of patients who went for a second opinion at the Mayo Clinic had, in fact, been misdiagnosed by their primary care doctors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Doctors are human and ailments are complex, so misdiagnoses are nothing new.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;What can prevent patients from being inaccurately diagnosed?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Accuracy of new blood tests&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;One tool is a blood test.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There’s not always been a test for everything out there.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, there are a few new pathology exams (and more on the horizon) that can help doctors better detect diseases and conditions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Here are three recent developments:&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Viral vs. bacterial infections&lt;/strong&gt;: Wouldn’t it be great to know if you really need an antibiotic or if you should just let a cold run its course?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A Duke University team is looking into the efficacy of a test that could distinguish viral from bacterial infections.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Geoffrey S. Ginsburg previously &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/tech-new-blood-test-sorts-out-viral-and-bacterial-infections-091813#2&quot;&gt;told Healthline&lt;/a&gt; that he would love to have the “pregnancy test equivalent to viral infections.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Heart attack&lt;/strong&gt;: Researchers at King's College London created a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.kcl.ac.uk/newsevents/news/newsrecords/2017/04-April/Heart-attacks-diagnosed-quicker-by-new-blood-test.aspx&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;blood test&lt;/a&gt; that better detects heart muscle damage due to a heart attack.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When a doctor suspects that a patient has had an attack, only some incidents show changes on a heart trace or ECG. Those exams test levels of cardiac troponin, which is a protein released by the heart that is common after heart attacks or inflammation. When doctors can’t find cardiac troponin in the blood, patients are labeled as low-risk and typically discharged.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers, however, looked at 4,000 patients and found that 47 percent of those actually had an intermediate risk and required more tests. Their test for myosin-binding protein C is a better indicator of how much heart muscle has been damaged. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Tom Kaier, a cardiologist with Kings College London, told Healthline that the myosin-binding protein C is present in greater abundance and may rise quicker than troponin after a heart attack. That could change the way heart attacks are diagnosed. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Troponin is an excellent test, but it has its limitations. It takes over three hours to appear in adequate levels in the bloodstream to be measured reliably,” Kaier noted.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Considering that only 14 to 17 percent of patients that go to emergency rooms with chest pain have a heart attack, the other 80 percent want reassurance as soon as possible. A quicker diagnosis may also improve patient outcomes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The detection of myosin-binding protein C “appears in the circulation quicker, and thus could rule out heart attacks in more patients at an earlier time point than currently possible,” Kaier added. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Concussions/traumatic brain injuries: &lt;/strong&gt;Accurately diagnosing a concussion or traumatic brain injury can be a bit of a guessing game when it comes to specifying the severity of the impairment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But Dr. Linda Papa, an emergency medicine physician and researcher at Orlando Health released a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2016/03/160328114638.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; in JAMA Neurology&lt;em&gt; &lt;/em&gt;detailing a blood test that measures a protein released by brain cells upon an injury.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;More of the protein indicates a higher severity of brain injury, she explained.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Symptoms of a brain injury can be subtle and may not come on for several days. She told Healthline that diagnosing a concussion can be “very subjective” and is “often based on the experience of the clinician.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If a person doesn’t see a brain expert, they may not be accurately diagnosed, so having a concrete test to confirm injury would be a big step. A CAT scan can give an assessment of a brain injury, but it only detects lesions and cannot detect all of them.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Having a definitive blood test could help doctors make better treatment decisions sooner —hopefully leading to better patient outcomes, Papa said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), Papa’s test would be the first of its kind. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We’re just a couple of years from it being available,” she added. “We’re hoping the blood test will find injury where it couldn’t be seen before.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Papa noted that it was also tested in patients of all ages with severe traumatic brain injury and seems to “cover the spectrum” of brain injuries.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The future of precision pathology&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Michael J. Donovan, a pathologist and researcher at The Mount Sinai Hospital in New York, said there are many new innovations happening with blood tests.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are also developments in tests to evaluate urine, saliva, and cerebrospinal fluid.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the oncology field, for instance, researchers are looking at cell-free DNA, which is the deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) in blood that can be isolated and sequenced to identify cancer-related genes with mutations in them.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Doctors then can tell if a cancer drug will work on the patient. The blood acts as a companion diagnostic to gauge the efficacy of a drug before it’s even given. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“That’s one of the very practical ways in which the field has advanced,” Donovan told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other blood test innovations include evaluations that can predict how a kidney transplant patient will respond. This can replace an invasive biopsy. Researchers are also targeting urine tests in this area.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Donovan said that blood tests in the future may also be able to determine if a patient is building a response to human papillomavirus (HPV) in a lesion instead of having to biopsy it or conduct an intrusive cell scraping. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Blood tests are also a pathway to evaluate the possibility of neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We’re always looking for ways to detect the manifestation of Alzheimer’s prior to actual clinical manifestations,” Donovan said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other liquid biopsy options could evaluate a patient’s immune system via bloodwork so doctors can monitor an individual’s state via a simple blood draw. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Assessing DNA isn’t the only research pathway, either, as researchers are looking to evaluate peptide fragments in the blood. Peptides are amino acids that are linked via peptide bonds and in some ways are similar to DNA and ribonucleic acid (RNA).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;DNA gives a blueprint of genes, while RNA helps to execute the DNA’s guidelines.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Donovan said that the field of liquid biopsies will continue to evolve — again, not just via bloodwork but through spinal fluid, saliva, and urine. That will give doctors multiple tools to better diagnose patients and hopefully improve outcomes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“What we see in blood under a microscope, that will pull together a more comprehensive genotype of a person,” Donovan said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“That’s the future of precision pathology,” Donovan added. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Technology</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-17T14:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-17T14:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/new-blood-tests
</guid>
<dc:creator>Kristen Fischer</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-17T21:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Should Doctors Be Sued for ‘Wrongful Birth'?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/should-doctors-be-sued-for-wrongful-birth
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/041717_wrongfulbirth_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Currently, in 28 states you can sue a physician for malpractice if they don’t disclose a potential health issue that might affect the quality of life of a child after they are born.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But opponents of this legal option are attempting to get rid of so-called “wrongful birth” laws in several states.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We’re pushing back against the idea that there are certain children that shouldn’t be born, that something like a birth could be wrong,” Eric Scheidler, executive director of the Pro-Life Action League, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That push is gaining traction in Texas, where a proposal that would eliminate lawsuits involving wrongful birth legal action is working its way through the state legislature.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If successful, &lt;a href=&quot;https://legiscan.com/TX/text/SB25/id/1548615&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Texas Senate Bill 25&lt;/a&gt; would not only eliminate this type of malpractice suit, it would also send a message Scheidler and others who oppose abortion rights seek. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/laws-restrict-abortion-without-outlawing&quot;&gt;Read more: New laws restrict abortion without outlawing it &raquo;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What is wrongful birth?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Wrongful birth is its own separate type of malpractice.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In involves a rare situation where a doctor chooses not to tell a pregnant woman about a medical condition a fetus has or doesn’t order the typical diagnostic tests to determine the unborn child’s health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Abortion rights proponents say these instances deprive patients of the ability to make decisions about their future and their child’s future.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There are unintended consequences, like in situations where, had a woman known about a harmful condition earlier, she would have sought treatment earlier,” Blake Rocap, legislative counsel for NARAL Pro-Choice Texas, told Healthline. “Taking people’s agency away from them is just bad medicine. It takes away opportunities to seek treatments that might not be abortion.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;How many cases it would affect is hard to say. Rocap said that’s in part because many such cases settle.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/why-abortion-rates-have-decreased&quot;&gt;Read more: Why the abortion rate is decreasing &raquo;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What is the definition of “wrong&quot;?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Texas was the first state to recognize wrongful birth legal actions, according to a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.senate.texas.gov/cmtes/84/c610/021816-AllianceForLife-c3.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;presentation &lt;/a&gt;the advocacy group Texas Alliance for Life made in support of the proposed law.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The current law has been challenged three times and upheld each time, group members told the state senate’s Health and Human Services Committee.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The group said 28 states recognize this law, but nine have since eliminated it through legislative action.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In Texas, the debate began after a &lt;a href=&quot;http://law.justia.com/cases/texas/supreme-court/1975/b-4583-0.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;1975 case&lt;/a&gt; in which a pregnant woman came down with &lt;a href=&quot;/health/rubella&quot;&gt;rubella&lt;/a&gt; during her first trimester and later gave birth to a child with defective major organs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She and her husband sued their doctor for not diagnosing the rubella or telling them about how it might affect the fetus. They won.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A modern risk could come from something like the Zika virus, which can cause microcephaly and developmental delays in babies of infected mothers. There have been &lt;a href=&quot;http://texaszika.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;330 cases&lt;/a&gt; of Zika in Texas in the past three years, according to the state’s health services department.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But saying that it’s “wrong” to give birth to a child who is born impaired is wrong, said Scheidler.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Children aren’t mistakes. That’s horrific that someone’s birth could be wrong,” he said. “We make such an effort to accommodate people with disabilities in this country, and this is a direct contradiction of that really excellent institution that the American people have set up. To say that there are people who shouldn’t be born sends a terrible message.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Scheidler speaks from experience. He has a niece who he says can’t walk or talk.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The idea that her life is a mistake?,” he asks.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/why-planned-parenthood-wont-accept-no-abortion-deal&quot;&gt;Read more: Why Planned Parenthood won’t accept President Trump’s ‘no abortion’ deal &raquo;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The case for “wrongful birth”&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Defenders of the legal avenue say they are focused on potential parents having all the necessary information to make a decision.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They add they want to ensure there aren’t situations in which a doctor who opposes abortion rights might impose their beliefs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Doctors have high ethics and are not in the practice of lying to their patients. But the question is, are there doctors out there who would do that if they could get away with it?” said Rocap. “If it’s so rare why take it off the books?”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Rocap says rolling back the wrongful birth legal option would only ban a specific and rare set of malpractice suits.&lt;strong&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Plaintiffs could still sue over other possible malpractice — like if the doctor were to do something harmful in the delivery of the child. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The bill passed the Texas Senate on March 20 and it is now moving through the House.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Public Policy</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-17T14:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-17T14:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/should-doctors-be-sued-for-wrongful-birth
</guid>
<dc:creator>Matthew Berger</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-17T21:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Services Lacking for People with Mental Health Issues
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/services-lacking-for-mental-health
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/mental-health/041717_mentalhealth_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;When it comes to mental illness in the United States, the healthcare system may come up short for those who need it most.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/study-paints-somber-picture-of-us-mental-health-status-and-access-to-care-300438169.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;new study&lt;/a&gt; published today from the New York University School of Medicine concludes that many people with mental health issues encounter significant barriers to proper medical treatments.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s despite new legislation, in particular the Affordable Care Act (ACA), approved in 2010.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers examined serious psychological distress (SPD) in adults between 2006 and 2014.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They wrote that they discovered that “compared with adults without SPD, adults with SPD had an increased risk of forgoing healthcare and prescription medications because of cost and were more likely to be uninsured.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;SPD is not a diagnosis for mental illness but rather a scale used to measure the mental health of a given community by gauging negative emotions such as sadness, hopelessness, and nervousness, Judith Weissman, PhD, JD, research manager at New York University, and lead author of the study, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“SPD strongly covaries with serious mental illness,” she said. “It is associated with reduced functioning, and an inability to work or attend school, and causes impairment with daily living based on the negative emotional states.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Comparing data&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers used data from the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nhis/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;National Health Interview Survey&lt;/a&gt;, an assessment conducted by the U.S. Census Bureau.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Weissman and her team were able to compare healthcare utilization of those with SPD with those without it. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Healthcare utilization was measured through a series of metrics including inability to buy prescription drugs because of money issues, delay in healthcare because of a lack of money, or having to change where they sought treatment due to insurance issues.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2006, the first year of the survey, 9 percent of Americans with SPD didn’t have health insurance.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2014 that number was slightly higher at 9.5 percent.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Similarly, in 2006, 9 percent experienced delays getting treatment due to lack of mental health coverage. By 2014 that number increased to 10 percent.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Based on our data, we estimate that millions of Americans have a level of emotional functioning that leads to lower quality of life and life expectancy,” Weissman said in a press release. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Furthermore, she told Healthline, adults with SPD “appear to have more chaotic and less effective use of healthcare compared to those without, hence they are in poorer health.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Multiple mental health problems&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Compounding the problem of accessibility, a &lt;a href=&quot;https://today.duke.edu/2017/04/wiring-%E2%80%98little-brain%E2%80%99-linked-multiple-forms-mental-illness&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;new study&lt;/a&gt; from Duke University also points out that those with mental illness may often suffer from more than just one disorder.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers examined the prevalence and potential reasons for “comorbidity” a term used to describe when an individual has multiple mental disorders at once. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Approximately half of individuals who meet the criteria for a single mental disorder will also meet the criteria for a second disorder, researchers say. That makes treatment even more difficult.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Clinically, comorbidity is associated with greater severity of impairment and complexity in treatment planning, compliance, and coordination of services,” the study authors wrote.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers examined the “p-factor,” a statistical way to measure the overlap of different kinds of mental illness, such as depression, anxiety, and substance abuse.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A person with many of these issues would have a higher p-factor score than someone with one mental health condition.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Practically, “the p-factor suggests that there may be a general factor of psychopathology” that can be accounted for. The study authors say that this could provide a new way to approach treatment of mental illness.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If we continue to find support for the link between the ‘p-factor’ and the cerebellum, our research raises interesting questions about when and how this link emerges and how we might use that information to intervene more effectively,” study authors Ahmad Hariri, PhD, and Adrienne Romer, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There may be more efficient ways of treating mental illnesses by targeting their shared characteristics,” they said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Mental Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-17T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-17T12:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/services-lacking-for-mental-health
</guid>
<dc:creator>Gigen Mammoser</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-17T19:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Pedometers May Be a Step in the Right Direction for RA Patients
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/pedometers-for-ra-patients
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/tech/041517_pedometer_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;When it comes to rheumatoid arthritis (RA), taking any steps can be painful.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But a &lt;a href=&quot;http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/acr.23230/full&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;new study&lt;/a&gt; shows that taking those steps while wearing a pedometer can be beneficial for symptom management. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In fact, fitness trackers can help people with RA, whether or not they choose to set specific goals or track the number of steps they take each day.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers in the study concluded that the act of simply wearing a pedometer can motivate people with RA to keep moving and stay active.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers said that perhaps the most telling result in their study was a reduction in patient fatigue.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This may prove to be of interest to RA patients and rheumatologists alike, as fatigue is one of the most difficult RA symptoms to treat. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.arthritis.org/living-with-arthritis/pain-management/fatigue/beat-fatigue.php&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Arthritis Foundation&lt;/a&gt;, up to 98 percent of people with RA report fatigue as a symptom.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;On the move&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The latest study followed 96 participants. All but eight finished the 21-week assessment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The findings were published in the Arthritis Care &amp;amp; Research medical journal.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It found that providing pedometers to people with RA, without providing step targets, successfully increased activity while also diminishing fatigue.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The notion of exercise as a way to mitigate RA pain and fatigue isn’t new. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In fact, the Arthritis Foundation has run campaigns with slogans like &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=illnWGwxNfg&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Let’s Move Together&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They also formerly partnered with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in a campaign called &lt;a href=&quot;http://oaaction.unc.edu/arthritis-foundation-joins-get-moving-america-campaign-for-osteoarthritis/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Get Moving America&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While rheumatologists used to dissuade patients from exercise, now they encourage light activity such as water aerobics, tai chi, chair yoga, resistance band training, and walking.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Pedometers may be the next step&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;But pedometers may be the next recommendation they make.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A 2011 &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3042669/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; found that activity — in the form of aerobic and resistance exercise training — was key in fatigue reduction and management. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The latest study encouraged the intervention of pedometers to encourage movement of any kind in any quantity. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A review of studies published in the Journal of the American Medical Association revealed that people — with or without a medical issue —&amp;nbsp; who wore a fitness tracker or pedometer to record their steps increased their step count by at least 27 percent per day. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This may be worth considering.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With heart disease and muscle cachexia being closely linked to RA, perhaps the next prescription someone with RA should fill is that of a pedometer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Because rheumatoid arthritis medications have only small effects on fatigue, it's important for patients to have other ways to manage their fatigue,” said Patricia Katz, PhD, who was the lead author of the recent Arthritis Care &amp;amp; Research study. “These results suggest that something as simple as increasing physical activity by walking can help.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This relatively simple intervention helped a very sedentary group of rheumatoid arthritis patients increase their activity at a level that is considered clinically significant,” Lucas Carr PhD, of the University of Iowa, who wasn’t involved in the study, told &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/health/pedometers-tied-to-less-fatigue-for-rheumatoid-arthritis-patient/3679290.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Channel News Asia&lt;/a&gt;. “The largest health benefits are realized when an individual changes from doing nothing to doing something.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Overall, this study further confirms the importance of physical activity for people with RA,” concluded Katz. “Not only does it help to reduce fatigue — as shown in this study — it may improve mood, help a patient maintain a healthy weight, improve cardiovascular risk factors, and improve overall functioning.”&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Technology</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-17T09:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-17T09:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/pedometers-for-ra-patients
</guid>
<dc:creator>Ashley Boynes-Shuck</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-17T16:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Stem Cell Research Advancing Rapidly</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/stem-cell-research-advancing-rapidly
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/tech/041617_stemcells_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Stem cells have been touted as treatments for everything from hair loss to heart disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But are those claims scientifically sound?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Research on the technology continues to look promising, but many of its human applications are still preliminary and their effectiveness anecdotal.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Samumed, a $12 billion biotech start-up based in San Diego, profiled this month in &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.businessinsider.com/samumed-wants-to-regenerate-hair-bone-cartilage-2017-3&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Business Insider&lt;/a&gt;, exemplifies both sides of the coin. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The company has promised a bevy of age-reversing cures, including regrowing hair, treating wrinkles, and regenerating cartilage in people with osteoarthritis&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, their research isn’t conclusive. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;None of their treatments have received government approval yet.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Science and secrecy&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s easy to get excited about all this research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Samumed Is Trying to Create the Fountain of Youth,” says one headline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Samumed Aims to Reverse Aging with Eternal Youth Treatments,” says another.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Combined with $300 million in investment funding, the company has more than just buzz going for it in the biotech industry.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Their treatment for &lt;a href=&quot;/symptom/hair-loss&quot;&gt;androgenetic alopecia&lt;/a&gt; (hair loss) is currently in phase II trials.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Its program to help people with &lt;a href=&quot;/health/osteoarthritis&quot;&gt;osteoarthritis&lt;/a&gt; regrow cartilage in their knees is in phase III.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In total, the company has seven drugs in phase II trials, with plans to expand into more areas of disease research this year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, Samumed has raised some eyebrows in the industry with its secrecy. Some skeptics have likened the company to &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2016/09/elizabeth-holmes-theranos-exclusive&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Theranos&lt;/a&gt;, a biotech start-up that was valued at $9 billion before an investigation by the Wall Street Journal led to a shutdown of the company’s labs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Samumed has been more open about presenting their data to the public — but not about the actual treatments.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We're basically telling everyone, here's proof that it works,” Samumed Chief Executive Officer, Osman Kibar, told Business Insider. “How it works — you just need to wait a little longer because we want to build as much of a head start as we can.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Other stem cell research&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Beyond the applications of stem cells at Samumed, the technology is also being used to treat some of the United States’ most widespread health issues.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;New &lt;a href=&quot;http://jaha.ahajournals.org/content/6/4/e003918&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;research&lt;/a&gt; from the American Heart Association this month demonstrated the effectiveness of implanted stem cells into the hearts of people with &lt;a href=&quot;/health/heart-disease/cardiomyopathy&quot;&gt;cardiomyopathy&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Although the sample size was small (only 27 people), scientists noted “function and symptomatic improvements” of heart functioning as well as less frequency of hospitalization and lower medical costs. They conclude that the stem cell procedure is “a feasible treatment for cardiomyopathy,” but they note that a larger clinical follow-up is needed for more conclusive results.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the past week, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.newsweek.com/2017/04/21/stem-cell-spray-skingun-renovacare-burns-582079.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Newsweek&lt;/a&gt; reported on “miracle” stem cell treatments for burn victims that will promote healing without scars.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.statnews.com/2017/04/10/parkinsons-disease-stem-cells/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Stat News&lt;/a&gt; wrote about research on stem cells in mice that could potentially help cure Parkinson’s disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Measured optimism&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some researchers in the industry are somewhat measured in their optimism of the technology’s human applications.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I want to make sure that we provide a real cautionary note, especially to those individuals and those institutions that tout stem cells as the panacea for any ill,” Dr. Cato Laurencin, director of the Institute for Regenerative Engineering at the University of Connecticut, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Laurencin, a medical practitioner at the forefront of stem cell technology, is a firm believer in the benefits of the treatment, but also remains skeptical of some of the claims associated with it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Much of the evidence is still preliminary or anecdotal, and when people operate on information that is preliminary or anecdotal, there is the possibility for harm,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;His work in regenerative engineering — a term he coined several years ago — looks at the healing properties of implanted stem cells in the human body. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In &lt;a href=&quot;http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0174789&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;research&lt;/a&gt; published this month, Laurencin and his team concluded that stem cells effectively improved healing to torn rotator cuff tendons in rats.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Rotator cuff tendon tears are a relatively common injury in humans and can be difficult to treat.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Unlike other tendons in the body, the rotator cuff tendon is unable to heal itself, said Laurencin.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Once it is torn, it is liable to be reinjured again and again.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, the research released this month is about more than just applying stem cells to a certain kind of injury, it’s about how the stem cells are applied.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Nanotechnology and other advances&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Laurencin describes his field as an evolution of earlier work from 30 years ago in tissue engineering: a convergence of “bringing together new technologies to create new science and new possibilities.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In this case, nanotechnology is at the heart of this stem cell operation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Currently there are a variety of ways that stem cells can be implanted into a subject, including injections and bone marrow transplants.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For his research, Laurencin and his team used “biomaterial based fiber matrices” — a nanomaterial conducive to growing and attaching stem cells — to implant into the wounded area.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The results are promising, but Laurencin and his team will have to continue working with animals for some time before the process can be applied to humans.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The key is in understanding that stem cells have the potential for more than just regrowing damaged parts of the body.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The way we commonly think about a stem cell is it becoming a new tissue. But we’re also understanding that the stem cell itself can secrete biological factors that help regeneration occur. That’s what we think is happening here,” said Laurencin.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;His research into stem cells as a medicinal element in the body could have far reaching implications for all kinds of wound therapy. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Despite his measured approach, Laurencin is still willing to hypothesize about the excitement that the future of the field undoubtedly holds — with proper time, funding, and research. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There are newts and salamanders that can regenerate a limb,” he told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“How do we harness the cues that are taking place in these types of animals, and can we utilize what we’ve learned from these types of animals in humans?”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Technology</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-16T06:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-16T06:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/stem-cell-research-advancing-rapidly
</guid>
<dc:creator>Gigen Mammoser</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-16T13:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Baseball Legend Gets New Life After Death of Pro Football Player
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/baseball-legend-gets-new-life-after-death-of-pro-football-player
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/heart-health/041717_AHArodcarew_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;Photo: American Heart Association News&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&
]]>
<![CDATA[
quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Photo: American Heart Association News&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Baseball Hall of Famer and recent transplant recipient Rod Carew now knows whose heart and kidney are keeping him alive.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Those organs are from Konrad Reuland, an National Football League (NFL) tight end who died following a ruptured brain aneurysm.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This is believed to be the first such transplant involving pro athletes. Yet that’s only one of many links the men shared.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another is that Reuland went to middle school with Carew’s children, so donor and recipient crossed paths before.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Figuring out the connection&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mutual friends immediately connected the dots between Reuland’s death and Carew’s new chance at life.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Working together, the families discovered it likely was true, then got it confirmed by the local organ procurement network.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On March 2, the families met at the Reuland home for a remarkable reunion – one family filled with joy, the other still grieving, both bonded by a young man’s selfless gift.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“You’re a part of our family now,” Mary Reuland, Konrad’s mom, told Carew and his wife, Rhonda.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Yes,” Carew said. “Forever.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ralf Reuland, Konrad’s father, is a physician.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Using one of his stethoscopes, he, Mary and their youngest son Austin each heard Konrad’s heart thumping inside Rod’s chest.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As Mary listened, the edges of her mouth widened and her eyebrows jumped.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There it is,” she said softly, breaking into a full smile and laying her head onto Rod’s shoulder.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Does it sound the same?” Rhonda said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mary lifted her head, nodded and said, “I’ve got it memorized.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When Ralf heard the beat, he pressed his eyes shut. He opened his mouth but didn’t speak. A moment later he said, “Welcome home Konrad.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Young heart goes to family hero&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Konrad died Dec. 12. He was 29.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Over the final hours Mary spent with her oldest child, she kept her right ear on his chest. Her final words to the representative of the organ procurement network were, “Make sure his heart goes to a really good person because Konrad was a really good person.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Upon learning Konrad’s heart might’ve gone to Carew, Mary could hardly breathe.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She remembered going to the Anaheim Angels’ stadium as a child with her dad and brothers to watch him play. Carew was her favorite player.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She then researched Carew. Reading about his character and charity work – and that he, too, had endured the pain of burying a child – she decided he was a worthy recipient. She told him so when they met.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Thank you,” Carew said. “I will take care of this heart. Because I’ve been given a second chance. God knows how I feel and what I’m going to do for Him.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Whenever organs are transplanted into famous people – and whenever those people are Carew’s age, 71 – questions arise about preferential treatment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Add in the pro sports connection and their shared past, and this case is sure to draw even more scrutiny. However, strict protocols ensured the donation process was anonymous. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Had the Reulands wanted Carew to have Konrad’s organs, they could’ve steered them his way. It’s called a “directed donation.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Also noteworthy is that Carew’s health placed him so high on the waiting list despite his age. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We are so thankful, so grateful, so … there aren’t adequate words,” Rhonda told the Reulands.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A young life taken&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The full story of this transplant seems like something conjured in nearby Hollywood. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The tale begins with Konrad attending St. John’s Episcopal School in Rancho Santa Margarita, California, from sixth through eighth grades.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Rhonda’s daughter Cheyenne was there all three years, and her son Devon also was there Konrad’s final year. Devon was later basketball teammates with Konrad’s younger brother Warren.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Future donor and recipient likely interacted several times. The first encounter left quite an impression on Konrad, who was around 11.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“All he talked about for the rest of that day was, `I met Rod Carew!’” Mary said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A basketball star in his early teens, Konrad began playing football and became the nation’s top tight end coming out of high school. He went to Notre Dame, then transferred to Stanford, spending three seasons as a teammate of his brother, Warren.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Konrad played several seasons in the NFL with the New York Jets and Baltimore Ravens. He also spent time with the San Francisco 49ers and Indianapolis Colts.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Colts released him last August, so he spent the fall working out at home with his youngest brother, Austin. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After years of being slowed by a torn knee ligament and foot surgery, Konrad was in the best shape of his life – a taut 6-foot-6, 270 pounds – while waiting for a team to call.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He also had begun preparing for life after football. He took part in an NFL Business Academy at the University of Michigan last spring, then began dabbling in commercial real estate by buying a four-unit apartment complex. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Two days after Thanksgiving, he was on a treadmill when he felt “a click” behind his left eye and a severe headache. That was the emergence of the aneurysm, a ballooning of an artery in his brain.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It burst a few days later. A 17-hour operation followed. He never woke from a coma, his brain activity ceasing about two weeks later.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A life saved&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Carew’s medical odyssey began in September 2015 when he suffered a near-fatal heart attack while playing golf.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He spent a year with a left ventricular assist device, or LVAD, in his chest handling the work of his damaged heart. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Last fall, blood thinners he took as part of his LVAD protocol led to bleeding in his brain, making it more urgent for him to get a new heart. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He went on the transplant waiting list the Friday before Thanksgiving and moved higher a few weeks later. He got the call that a match was found on Dec. 14. He received the heart and kidney two days later.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The scene that would forever bind Carew and Reuland occurred last April in the kitchen of Mary and Ralf’s home.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mary was cooking dinner while Konrad was renewing his driver’s license. He asked her whether he should become an organ donor. She called it a personal choice, so he asked what her choice was. She said she’d signed up to do it, so he did, too.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The families learned about their possible connection from their overlapping networks of friends. For instance, Devon Carew and Warren Reuland are Facebook friends. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Word began to spread in Orange County, then across the sports world among people who knew of both sagas.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The only details the Carews received prior to the transplant were that the donor was “male, late 20s, local, exceptionally healthy.” They later learned his exact age: 29.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Reulands were told the recipient was a 71-year-old man from Orange County who was treated at Cedars-Sinai.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While such a wide age discrepancy might seem odd, the key factor was Hepatitis B. Both were immune. Nobody ahead of Carew on the transplant list was.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Timing and blood type worked out, too. Ultimately, Rod happened to be the right guy in the right place when the wrong thing happened to Konrad.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Getting out the word&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Now both families aim to harness the power of this story to help more people.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They want to draw attention to heart disease and brain health, hopefully spurring people to step up their prevention efforts. Heart disease and stroke are the world’s leading causes of death. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Heart disease has touched the Reulands, too. Mary lost her father and a 31-year-old brother to heart attacks; Ralf’s father has received a stent and battles atrial fibrillation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Both families want to encourage more people to become organ donors. To understand the difference one donor can make, consider that Konrad’s organs and tissues could go to several hundred people.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The full extent won’t be known for about a year. Carew’s family has long been signed up as organ donors in memory of his daughter, Michelle, who died of leukemia when she was unable to get a match for a bone marrow transplant.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Reulands also are seeking donations for an endowment fund in Konrad’s name through Big Brothers Big Sisters.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.gofundme.com/in-celebration-of-konrad-reuland&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Another fund&lt;/a&gt; was established by the football coach at Mission Viejo High School for a plaque that will hang under the scoreboard at the stadium, with any leftover money going to a scholarship fund.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The families look forward to working together – especially on “Heart of 29,” the campaign Carew started last year with the American Heart Association.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The program’s name came from the jersey number that Carew wore throughout his career. Because Konrad died at 29, the name carries added meaning.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The whole thing is just unbelievable,” Rod said. “I’ve been given a second chance so I’m going to take advantage of it. And I’ve got another family. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This is going to be great.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/baseball-great-rod-carews-new-heart-kidney-came-from-nfl-player-konrad-reuland/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;original story&lt;/a&gt; was published on &lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;American Heart Association News.&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-04-15T06:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-15T06:00:00</updateddate>

http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/baseball-legend-gets-new-life-after-death-of-pro-football-player
</guid>
<dc:creator>American Heart Association News</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-15T13:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>Are You Related to the Person You Married?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/are-you-related-to-the-person-you-married
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/041617_spouserelated_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The joke that married couples can appear similar may in fact be due to the tendency for couples to marry someone from a similar ancestry — whether they are aware of it or not.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s according to a new study published recently in &lt;a href=&quot;http://journals.plos.org/plosgenetics/article?id=10.1371/journal.pgen.1006655#sec020&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;PLOS Genetics&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the first ever investigation into mating patterns across multiple generations in the United States, researchers examined genetic similarities between spouses in three generations of families. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The participants took part in the Framingham Heart Study, which has examined the heart health of residents in Framingham, Mass., since 1948. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers from the University of Pennsylvania, the Boston University School of Public Health, and the University of California San Francisco found that of the 879 spouse participants, those from Northern European, Southern European, and Ashkenazi backgrounds were more likely to choose a spouse from the same ancestry. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Seeking similar backgrounds&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers say choosing a partner from a similar background could be due to a number of reasons. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Mate choice reflects a large number of factors including local geodemographics, social class, nationality, ethnicity, religion, anthropometric traits such as height and weight, as well as behavioral characteristics,” the researchers &lt;a href=&quot;http://journals.plos.org/plosgenetics/article?id=10.1371/journal.pgen.1006655#sec020&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;wrote&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“These patterns may also have reflected neighborhood characteristics, and the tendency for unions to occur locally.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study found that those from later generations were less likely to choose a spouse from the same ancestry. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Intermixing between participants with Northwestern and Southern European ancestries was relatively uncommon in the original cohort but increased in subsequent generations,” they wrote.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This may be due to the tendency for younger generations to move around more frequently.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“While unions historically have been preferentially local, increased movements of the population over past decades are contributing to the decay of local endogamy, as seen in Framingham,” the researchers found. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Are there health concerns?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Genetic similarity within a population is of particular significance in the area of genomic studies as it can lead to false positives in identifying gene regions associated with disease. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It can also impact estimations of the degree to which a disease may be passed on genetically. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Over several generations, the tendency for people to pick a mate from a similar ancestry has resulted in a genetic structure that has potential to bias results of genetic studies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Professor Peter Ralph from the Institute of Ecology and Evolution at the University of Oregon, says that in small populations, genetic similarity can also have health consequences. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In very genetically similar populations there are often increased risks of some genetic diseases, because it is effectively more likely someone gets two broken copies of some particular gene.&amp;nbsp;In practice, this only shows up in very small populations, or ones that have been very small in the recent past,” he told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ralph emphasizes that the findings of this study shouldn’t be misinterpreted.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There is an implication in some of the news about this study that there's some genetic cause that makes people find more similar spouses but that's not supported by this study at all [or claimed by the authors],” he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Noah Rosenberg, PhD, is a professor of population genetics and society at Stanford University. He says the research could pave the way for improving genetic studies of disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Many research methods in human genetics rely on an assumption that people choose mates randomly within a population. Although this of course is not how people choose mates, real populations often are close enough to random mating for the research methods to work properly,” he told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This study disentangles the component of nonrandom mating that is due to assortative mating by ancestry, evaluating changing preferences that people have had over time in a New England town for mates from similar ancestral backgrounds. It finds a way to improve genetic studies of disease to account for the effects of assortative mating by ancestry.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<updateddate>2017-04-14T15:00:00</updateddate>

</guid>
<dc:creator>Elizabeth Pratt</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-14T22:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>
Can Companies Save Money with Workplace Wellness Programs?
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/companies-save-money-with-workplace-wellness
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/041417_companyfitness_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Seven years ago, many city employees of &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.plantation.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Plantation, Fla.&lt;/a&gt;, had high blood pressure, high cholesterol, and high blood sugar levels — all risk factors for chronic health problems like &lt;a href=&quot;/health/heart-disease&quot;&gt;heart disease&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;/health/type-2-diabetes&quot;&gt;type 2 diabetes&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These diseases can worsen a person’s quality of life and increase their chances of dying early.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But they also cost companies big money in missed workdays, higher medical costs, and lowered productivity.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2016, employee absenteeism — missing work because of sickness or injury — drained the U.S. economy of $2 billion, according to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/pcd/issues/2016/15_0503.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This was due to just five health conditions — high blood pressure, diabetes, smoking, physical inactivity, and obesity.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These are all too common in the American workforce.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The CDC report found that up to 56 percent of employees surveyed were physically inactive, 30 percent were obese, and 27 percent were smokers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Building a healthier workforce&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Faced with this kind of drain on its resources, Plantation did what many companies across the country are increasingly doing. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They set up a workplace wellness program to address employees’ existing chronic health conditions and head off future problems by helping people lead healthier lives.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2012, around half of all companies with at least 50 employees offered some kind of &lt;a href=&quot;http://ww2.cfo.com/health-benefits/2015/06/claims-wellness-cost-savings-overblown-rand/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;wellness program&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These vary from company to company. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Employees are often prodded to undergo screenings for risk factors of chronic diseases — and to take steps to reduce their risk.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Programs may include lifestyle management activities like gym memberships, yoga classes, weight loss programs, nutrition classes, smoking cessation programs, and nutrition classes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There’s also programs to help people manage existing chronic diseases like heart disease and diabetes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Plantation’s program is more comprehensive than many.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The city works with &lt;a href=&quot;https://www1.marathon-health.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Marathon Health&lt;/a&gt; to provide an onsite health center to employees. This includes primary care services provided by doctors, health coaching, and a pharmacy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This approach has helped.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Margie Moale, the city’s human resources director, told Healthline that 68 percent of Plantation’s employees are now making progress in improving health risk factors such as blood pressure and body mass index (BMI).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other companies have seen similar improvements.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Jodi McWilliams, benefit manager for &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ki.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;KI&lt;/a&gt;, a global furniture manufacturing firm based in Wisconsin, said that in recent years many of its almost 2,000 employees have lowered their health risk factors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This enables employees to move into a “healthier” category — and pay less for their health insurance. This can be a big incentive for them to take care of their health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For people whose risk scores are poor, KI offers programs like Weight Watchers, health coaching, or smoking cessation classes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If employees complete these programs — but not necessarily succeed at them — they earn points toward moving to a cheaper insurance premium.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“They’re not guaranteed to walk out of Weight Watchers and have lost 10 pounds,” said McWilliams. “It’s just that they went through it and now maybe they know how to eat healthier.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Healthier workers, lower costs&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Since Plantation opened its employee health center in 2010, it has saved close to $4 million in healthcare costs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Moale attributes this decrease in part to catching health problems earlier when they are cheaper to treat or manage.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Employees can also visit a doctor at the health center during the workday — on city time. This greater accessibility means employees don’t have to put off seeing a doctor.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When a Plantation employee went to the health center for a sinus infection, her doctor encouraged her to have a mammogram that day, something she had been putting off for three years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The result came back the next day — breast cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But doctors caught it early enough to treat.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If this total health management program wasn’t in place, that woman would have ended up probably losing her life,” said Moale. “As it was, it was caught early enough, she had her surgery, and she’s healthy now.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Michele McDermott, senior vice-president of human resources at &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.assuranceagency.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Assurance&lt;/a&gt;, an independent insurance brokerage, said that healthier employees are also good for the whole company.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Not only is it helping the company, because our costs for the medical plan on the employer’s side are staying the same or improving,” McDermott told Healthline, “but we’re passing that along to our employees by not increasing their cost for participating in the plan.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Healthier employees may also be more productive.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.endocrine.org/news-room/current-press-releases/participation-in-a-weight-management-program-reduces-job-absenteeism&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;recent study&lt;/a&gt;, University of Michigan researchers found that employees who completed six months of a two-year weight loss program showed up at work more regularly.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Before the program, people reported working, on average, 5.2 hours per month less than their employer expected. After half a year, they were working 6.4 hours more than expected.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Plantation experienced a similar improvement in employee attendance after its health center opened.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In the first four years of operation of the care center, my absenteeism rate was down by 50 percent,” said Moale.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The 92 participants in the University of Michigan study also lost, on average, 41 pounds.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0749379709004863#bib84&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2009 review&lt;/a&gt; of studies looking at workplace wellness programs, researchers estimated that losing 10 percent of your body weight — and keeping it off — would save $3,116 to $7,504 in lifetime medical costs. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Are wellness programs worth the cost?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the United States, workplace wellness is a &lt;a href=&quot;http://ww2.cfo.com/health-benefits/2015/06/claims-wellness-cost-savings-overblown-rand/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;$6 billion industry&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some of this expense goes to running wellness programs. The 2009 review found that weight loss competitions — along the lines of “The Biggest Loser” — cost employers between $1.60 and $4.16 per pound lost by employees. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Given that kind of upfront expense, many employers want to know if they are saving more than they are putting into wellness programs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.rand.org/pubs/external_publications/EP50433.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2014 study&lt;/a&gt;, RAND researchers looked at a large workplace wellness program offered by PepsiCo.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For every dollar that the company spent on helping employees manage chronic illnesses, the company saved $3.78 in healthcare costs and reduced absenteeism.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, the lifestyle program — focused on things like eating better, exercising more, and quitting smoking — cost more to run than the company saved.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Combined, the two programs saved the company $1.46 for every dollar invested.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Companies looking for a bigger return on their investment may want to focus on workers’ existing chronic conditions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, that’s not to say that wellness programs that lose money on paper aren’t worth the investment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Assurance’s McDermott has noticed an increase in employee engagement in recent years, something the company measures every six months with a five-question survey.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She thinks this is partly related to the company’s wellness program, as are other less tangible benefits.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We don’t have as high a turnover as some of our competitors,” said McDermott, “because our employees are happy, they’re engaged, and they like the programs we offer. And they enjoy the camaraderie that our wellness program creates.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Employees embracing healthy living can also spill out beyond the workplace.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;KI’s McWilliams said that more employees are taking advantage of monetary incentives for entering walk, run, or bike races. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Those types of things are the ones that we really like to see, because it’s getting not only the employee involved, but maybe their spouse and maybe their kids,” said McWilliams, “and they’re out there in the community promoting wellness.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>

<updateddate>2017-04-14T12:00:00</updateddate>

</guid>
<dc:creator>Shawn Radcliffe</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-14T19:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>New Theory on Why Fertility Declines with Age</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/why-fertility-declines-with-age
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/womens-health/041417_infertility_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Every woman in her 30s knows she has a biological clock ticking.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Everyone around her knows it too.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For some women, this is no big deal. Either they’ve already had children or they have made the decision not to have them.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But for women who still yearn to be mothers, that clock becomes louder and louder the further into their 30s they get.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As most women know, 35 seems to be the magic number when doctors start to get nervous about a woman’s fertility. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The reasons for that heightened sense of urgency are well documented.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are countless studies depicting the decline of female fertility with age, which is why the American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists released a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.acog.org/Resources-And-Publications/Committee-Opinions/Committee-on-Gynecologic-Practice/Female-Age-Related-Fertility-Decline&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;committee opinion&lt;/a&gt; reflecting that clinical and scientific data in 2014.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In that opinion, they cited research that found that over the course of 12 insemination cycles, 74 percent of women younger than 31 achieved pregnancy, 62 percent of women aged 31 to 35 had similar success, and only 54 percent of women over 35 were able to get pregnant. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, a consistent increase in miscarriage rates has been found as women progress through their 30s.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Investigating the reasons, the general rule of thumb is that women over the age of 35 trying to conceive should receive more aggressive treatment than those under 35.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;None of this is new information. But the problem is, the scientific and medical communities have yet to come up solid reasons for why this happens.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cell.com/current-biology/abstract/S0960-9822(10)01001-8?_returnURL=http%3A%2F%2Flinkinghub.elsevier.com%2Fretrieve%2Fpii%2FS0960982210010018%3Fshowall%3Dtrue&amp;amp;cc=y=&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Previous studies&lt;/a&gt; have hypothesized the “cohesion loss” theory as an explanation for why this decline occurs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That theory was predicated on the concept that older eggs suffered from a loss of cohesion as the “glue” that holds the chromosomes together ceased to work as well.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, a recent study involving mice points to another potential complication. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cell.com/current-biology/fulltext/S0960-9822(17)30162-8&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Research&lt;/a&gt; released early this month out of the University of Montreal Hospital Research Centre has found that older eggs in mice also appear to have instability at the microtubule level. That contributes to abnormal cell division.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While these microtubules typically assemble a “spindle in a controlled symmetrical fashion,” in older eggs, the microtubules instead assemble in all directions. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But how accurate are these mice studies in predicting what is responsible for the decline in female fertility among the human population?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Healthline reached out to Dr. Alan Copperman, director of the Division of Reproductive Endocrinology and Infertility at RMA of New York, with that very question. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The mouse model is often relied upon as the primary mammalian model for genetic research, since despite there being some differences with regard to ovarian senescence, or aging, mice ovaries express many genetic and physiological similarities to humans,” he explained.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How the research might help&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;So … we may now have a better idea of what causes the decline in fertility women begin to experience in their 30s.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But what good does knowing the reasons really do?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to Copperman, it could potentially do a lot of good.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Ovarian aging is the most common limiting factor to a woman/couple’s success of conceiving a healthy pregnancy,” he explained. “Understanding the mechanisms by which aging eggs acquire problems with their cellular machinery that lead to an imbalance of genetic material could one day help us to find a therapeutic target for treatments to address the problem of ovarian aging and its effects on embryo quality.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Which means that this latest research could actually help to contribute to a solution further down the line. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s certainly a goal the researchers have in mind.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We are currently exploring possible treatments for eggs that might one day make it possible to reverse this problem and rejuvenate the eggs,” Greg Fitzharris, a co-author of the Montreal study, and an associate professor at the university, said in a press release.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Could we really be heading toward a future where turning 35 doesn’t mean a woman will then be reminded of her ticking clock by ever person she meets?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The research is still many years off from getting to that point, but with a growing understanding of the mechanisms that contribute to female fertility decline comes a greater ability to address those issues.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<updateddate>2017-04-14T10:00:00</updateddate>

<dc:creator>Leah Campbell</dc:creator>

<item>
<title>
Hyland Agrees to FDA Demand to Recall Baby Teething Products
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/throw-out-homeopathic-teething-tablets-gels
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/100616_homeopathicteething_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Hyland Inc. has finally given in to pressure from the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and recalled two of its teething tablet products.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On its website, the company issued &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.hylands.com/media/news-press-release/hylands-teething-update&quot;&gt;a statement&lt;/a&gt;, saying it had made the &quot;very difficult decision&quot; to pull from store shelves its Baby Teething Tablets and its Nighttime Baby Teething Tablets.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Company officials said no other Hyland products are affected.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The company said it believes the two recalled products are safe, but Hyland is &quot;adhering&quot; to what the FDA has requested.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On April. 7, FDA officials issued a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.fda.gov/ucm/groups/fdagov-public/%40fdagov-afda-orgs/documents/document/ucm552166.pdf&quot;&gt;strongly worded letter&lt;/a&gt; tellling Hyland to issue an immediate recall of the two products.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In October, FDA officials released an &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.fda.gov/NewsEvents/Newsroom/PressAnnouncements/ucm523468.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;advisory&lt;/a&gt; recommending parents not give their children homeopathic teething tablets or gels.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The tablets and gels are sold online as well as in some stores.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hyland’s, which says it has the best-selling brand of teething tablets, told &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cnn.com/2016/10/05/health/fda-teething-tablets-warning/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;CNN&lt;/a&gt; at the timie that it stands by its product.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;CVS pharmacies, however, &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cvshealth.com/newsroom/press-releases/cvs-pharmacy-announces-voluntary-withdrawal-homeopathic-teething-products&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;announced&lt;/a&gt; they had pulled from its shelves the Hyland’s products as well as their own versions and those made by Baby Orajel Naturals. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The FDA recommended parents stop using these products and throw away any they have in their home.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Teething can be managed without prescription or over-the-counter remedies,” said Dr. Janet Woodcock, director of the FDA’s Center for Drug Evaluation and Research, in a press release.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The advisory was made after parents reported their children were experiencing seizures, having difficulty breathing, and displaying lethargy, among other symptoms, after taking the homeopathic products.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;FDA officials said they are investigating the incidents. They added the homeopathic tablets and gels have not been evaluated for safety or efficacy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This is not the first advisory the FDA has made against homeopathic teething tablets. In 2010, the FDA released another &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.fda.gov/NewsEvents/Newsroom/PressAnnouncements/ucm230761.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;advisory&lt;/a&gt;. This one specifically named the brand Hyland’s.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Teething tablets are meant to treat the symptoms that babies experience when their first sets of teeth come in.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Homeopathic tablets contain diluted versions of natural substances.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hyland’s teething tablets contain belladonna.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Belladonna concerns&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Belladonna is a nightshade plant. It’s been used to treat tremors and spasms — symptoms caused by conditions such as colitis and Parkinson’s disease. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, belladonna also has the potential to be dangerous.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. David Krol, the chair of the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) Section on Oral Health, says “There isn’t really a use for it in children and … it can have significant side effects.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3361210/#CIT0004&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Research&lt;/a&gt; shows that children can overdose on belladonna after ingesting the equivalent of only two or three of the berries. This makes it important that dosage is monitored carefully.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The 2010 FDA advisory stated that Hyland’s tablets did not have a consistent amount of belladonna in each tablet. This made it more likely that infants would overdose on the tablets.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The company issued a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.fda.gov/Safety/MedWatch/SafetyInformation/SafetyAlertsforHumanMedicalProducts/ucm230764.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;recall&lt;/a&gt; and a new tablet was introduced in 2011.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Teething symptoms&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The difficulty with soothing a baby’s symptoms while they’re teething is that there isn’t much research to support what does and doesn’t work.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In fact, Krol says that there aren’t typical symptoms associated with teething.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Many people will assume that if a child is drooling a lot, if they’re fussy, if they’re crying, if they have any array of symptoms that it can be attributed to teething,” he told Healthline. “But the literature tells us that it’s hard to tie any of those things directly to teething. They can be caused by a variety of other things.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These behaviors are also typical of 6-month-old infants, whether they’re teething or not.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, diarrhea, vomiting, and fever are never symptoms of teething. These symptoms can be caused by more serious conditions. And because they can quickly become very serious for infants, parents should call a doctor. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Managing teething&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Infants who are teething are old enough for other medications such as ibuprofen (Advil) and acetaminophen (Tylenol).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But Krol says parents should avoid using any type of medication if they think their child has teething symptoms.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When balancing both the science as well as the risk I err on not encouraging any medications for teething,” he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When parents give medications to infants, there’s always a risk that the infant absorbs too much. Instead, Krol recommends that parents be soothing and loving to a child that is having trouble with teething. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If a child has sore gums, parents can freeze teething rings. He also suggests parents freeze a wet washcloth, wrap it around their finger, and rub it on the child’s gums.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<dc:creator>Emily Gadd</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-14T07:00:00</dc:date>
