<item>
<title>How a Skin Disorder Can Help Fight Melanoma</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/skin-disorder-can-fight-melanoma
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/cancer/041417_melanoma_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;P
]]>
<![CDATA[
eople with melanoma who develop vitiligo – a condition characterized by white patches of skin – often have a better prognosis than those without vitiligo.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;New research finds that this may be due to a greater abundance of cancer-fighting memory T cells in their skin.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That discovery could lead to new treatments for melanoma.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mary Jo Turk, Ph.D., of the Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in New Hampshire and a study leader, and her colleagues &lt;a href=&quot;http://dx.doi.org/10.1126/sciimmunol.aam6346&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;published&lt;/a&gt; their findings today in the journal Science Immunology.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The characteristics of melanoma&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Melanoma is a cancer that begins in skin cells called melanocytes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These cells are responsible for producing melanin, the pigment that protects the deeper skin layers from the damaging effects of sun exposure.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While melanoma is not the most common skin cancer in the United States, it is one of the deadliest. This year, it is estimated that &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cancer.org/cancer/melanoma-skin-cancer/about/key-statistics.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;9,730 people&lt;/a&gt; in the U.S. will die from the disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3248219/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;studies&lt;/a&gt; have shown that people with metastatic melanoma – that is, melanoma that has spread to other areas of the body – may survive for longer if they also have vitiligo.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Vitiligo is a skin disorder that researchers believe is triggered by an immune system attack on melanocytes, which causes white patches to appear on the skin and particularly on the face, lips, arms, hands, and feet.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For their study, Turk and colleagues set out to determine why vitiligo seems to improve the prognosis of patients with melanoma.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Cancer-fighting T cell discovery&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers came to their findings by analyzing the skin of mouse models with vitiligo and melanoma.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The team found that skin affected by vitiligo consists of resident memory T cells, which are immune cells that provide an initial response against infection in tissue surfaces.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While resident memory T cells are known to prevent viral infections in skin, the researchers were surprised to find that they also have cancer-fighting abilities.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Turk and colleagues note that cancer-fighting T cells were thought to only be present in the blood, the spleen, lymph nodes, and other immune system organs, and that they launch an attack on foreign invaders by entering the bloodstream.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&quot;Our studies challenge this long-held belief by showing that tumor-killing T cells already reside in skin, where they can rapidly respond and kill melanoma cells,” says Turk.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Although this study was conducted in mouse models, the researchers believe that their findings may help to explain why vitiligo appears to extend the life of patients with melanoma.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The next step for Turk and colleagues is human studies. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&quot;While we have shown that these T cells can kill melanoma in skin, we still need to determine whether they exist in other organs such as lung, where metastatic melanoma grows,” says Turk.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The hope is that their findings will pave the way for new treatments for melanoma.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&quot;Since our study identifies that resident memory T cells are critical for protection against tumors, and that T cells in skin provide long-term immunity to melanoma, the generation of such cells should be the goal of future cancer therapies,” Turk adds.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<category>Skin Conditions</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-13T14:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-13T14:00:00</updateddate>

</guid>
<dc:creator>Honor Whiteman</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-13T21:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
The Effects of Kidney Disease on Cardiovascular Health
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/effects-of-kidney-disease-on-cardiovascular-health
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/heart-health/041317_kidneydamage_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Kidney disease affects a large number of people in the United States and the condition often goes undetected.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;New research examines the impact of kidney disease on cardiovascular health and highlights the importance of screening for kidney disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kidney disease is one of the leading causes of death in the U.S., with approximately &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.kidneyfund.org/assets/pdf/kidney-disease-statistics.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;31 million&lt;/a&gt; people living with chronic kidney disease. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Because kidney disease often does not present any symptoms at its onset, the ailment frequently goes unnoticed. That is why it is sometimes referred to as a “&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/health-statistics/Pages/kidney-disease-statistics-united-states.aspx&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;silent disease&lt;/a&gt;.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It is estimated that as many as &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.kidneyfund.org/assets/pdf/kidney-disease-statistics.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;9 out of 10&lt;/a&gt; people with moderately reduced kidney function do not know that they have kidney disease.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The impact of the disease is sizable, however.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK) estimates that chronic kidney disease occurs in &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/health-statistics/Pages/kidney-disease-statistics-united-states.aspx&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;14 percent&lt;/a&gt; of the U.S. population.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, more than 660,000 people in the country have kidney failure. In 2013, more than 47,000 people died of kidney disease in the United States. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It is known that people with chronic kidney disease are also at an increased risk of cardiovascular disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the NIDDK, almost 70 percent of people aged 66 and above who have chronic kidney disease also have cardiovascular disease. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In this context, an international team of researchers led by Dr. Bernadette Thomas from the University of Washington in Seattle investigated the prevalence of kidney disease in relation to cardiovascular-related deaths at six points in time between 1990 and 2013.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.newswise.com/articles/kidney-disease-is-a-major-cause-of-cardiovascular-deaths&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;findings&lt;/a&gt; were published in the Journal of the American Society of Nephrology. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Cardiovascular vs. kidney failure deaths&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Specifically, Thomas and team looked at kidney disease stages 3, 4, and 5, examining their prevalence in 188 countries that were included in the Global Burden of Disease Study. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the NIDDK, there are &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/health-statistics/Pages/kidney-disease-statistics-united-states.aspx&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;five stages&lt;/a&gt; of chronic kidney disease, each corresponding to different degrees of kidney function.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They range from normal kidney function (at stage 1) to kidney failure, at which point either dialysis or a kidney transplant is often needed for survival. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The stages considered in the study correspond to a mild to severe loss of kidney function, severe loss of kidney function, and kidney failure.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Thomas and team estimate that worldwide, 2.2 million deaths in 2013 were linked to reduced kidney function. This amounts to 4 percent of the total number of deaths in that year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;More than half of these deaths (around 1.2 million) were cardiovascular and 960,000 deaths were caused by kidney failure.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers also looked at how reduced kidney function ranked in comparison with metabolic risk factors for cardiovascular disease during the time period studied.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They found that kidney disease fell behind high body mass index (BMI), high systolic blood pressure, and &lt;a href=&quot;https://medlineplus.gov/ency/article/003482-cr-1.htm?utm_expid=.xOQ8bDlsQeGQ6XTTmPo6yQ.1&amp;amp;utm_referrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com%2F&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;high fasting blood glucose&lt;/a&gt;, which is a marker of prediabetes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As a risk factor for premature death, disability, and poor health, reduced kidney function was on par with high total cholesterol levels.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This was calculated using disability-adjusted life years (DALY) as a metric, and the results were valid for both developed and developing countries throughout the world. One &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.who.int/healthinfo/global_burden_disease/metrics_daly/en/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;DALY&lt;/a&gt; refers to one year of life lost to poor health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Thomas highlights the importance of the study for understanding the real effect that kidney disease has on cardiovascular health in various countries around the world. She also stresses the necessity of kidney disease screening.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Understanding the true health impact of kidney disease on society necessitates considering cardiovascular as well as end-stage renal disease deaths and disability,” she said. “This is especially important within the developing world, where the death rate has increased since 1990.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Heart Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-13T14:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-13T14:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/effects-of-kidney-disease-on-cardiovascular-health
</guid>
<dc:creator>Ana Sandoiu</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-13T21:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Why More Women Are Choosing to Have Double Mastectomies
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/more-women-having-double-mastectomies
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/womens-health/041317_mastectomy_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;More women are opting to remove both breasts when cancer is found in only one.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The proportion of patients aged 45 and older who had contralateral prophylactic mastectomies rose from 3 percent in 2004 to 10 percent in 2012, according to a &lt;a href=&quot;http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamasurgery/article-abstract/2613702&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; published in JAMA Surgery.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Among women aged 20 to 44, it jumped from 10 percent to 33 percent.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Removing the unaffected breast does &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cancer.gov/types/breast/risk-reducing-surgery-fact-sheet&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;reduce the risk&lt;/a&gt; of cancer in that breast. However, for women at average risk, the chance of cancer developing in the other breast is small.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, the surgery &lt;a href=&quot;https://uihc.org/health-library/women-breast-cancer-considering-prophylactic-mastectomy&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;has not been shown&lt;/a&gt; to help those women live longer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So, why do they do it?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Genetic testing &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;As genetic testing becomes more common, we know more than ever about our health risks. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;BRCA1 and BRCA2 genetic mutations are associated with increased risk of breast and other cancers. Testing helps women understand the risks of developing specific types of cancer, as well as whether they can pass the mutations on to their children. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It also helps in choosing treatment options or taking preventive measures.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One of those preventive measures is prophylactic mastectomy. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For women who carry the BRCA mutations or have a strong family history of breast cancer, the surgery may reduce the risk of developing breast cancer by &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.breastcancer.org/treatment/surgery/prophylactic_mast&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;90 to 95 percent&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Testing is one thing. Interpreting the results is another.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A recent &lt;a href=&quot;http://ascopubs.org/doi/abs/10.1200/JCO.2016.71.6480&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;survey&lt;/a&gt; of more than 2,000 newly diagnosed women found that half who had a double mastectomy after genetic testing didn’t actually have mutations that increase the risk of additional cancers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They had variants of uncertain significance (VUS), which are often harmless.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;About half the women who had genetic testing never spoke to a genetic counselor about the results. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Between one-quarter and one-half of breast cancer surgeons surveyed said they treat women with VUS the same way they treat women with known cancer-associated mutations. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some women have the surgery before they ever get the results. Or before being tested at all.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Why they do it&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;At 45 years old, Charlotte Gajewski of Texas was diagnosed with stage 0 DCIS.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It sounded simple enough,” she wrote in an email to Healthline. “But after two lumpectomies, they continued to find more positive margins with cancer cells speckled throughout my breast in a shotgun pattern.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She tested negative for the BRCA genetic mutations and had no family history of breast cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;An &lt;a href=&quot;/health/breast-mri-scan&quot;&gt;MRI&lt;/a&gt; of the unaffected breast revealed a flat tumor. It was non-threatening but would need to be monitored. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“So I elected to have a mastectomy and, ultimately, a bilateral mastectomy,” said Gajewski. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Her doctor explained the pros and cons of the surgery. Her only hesitation was whether or not to spare the nipple on the unaffected breast.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She chose radical mastectomy on both so she wouldn’t have to live with doubts and fears of recurrence.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She’s happy with her decision but says she has no feeling or sensation across her entire chest, which is both annoying and a constant reminder of what she went through.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“What sounded like a simple and ‘dream’ diagnosis turned into quite a fiasco for me. But life is good now and I am healthy and joyful every day,” said Gajewski.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mari Gallion, 47, is an author living in Alaska. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Following the diagnosis of &lt;a href=&quot;/health/triple-negative-breast-cancer-outlook-survival-rates-stage&quot;&gt;triple-negative breast cancer&lt;/a&gt;, her doctor suggested breast-conserving surgery in the affected breast.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, the first lumpectomy failed to get clear margins. The second, third, and fourth lumpectomies were also unsuccessful. It no longer made sense to keep trying to save the breast, even though she tested negative for BRCA mutations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Together with her surgeon, she decided on a double mastectomy despite having cancer in only one breast.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The most important consideration was her health, she told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Early in the process, should mastectomy have become a reality, I was considering foregoing reconstruction when it was just one breast,” Gallion said. “My mom had a prosthetic, so I wasn't afraid of that, but if two were being removed, I wanted them both done.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Gallion feels fortunate that she was able to have the mastectomy and immediate reconstruction without the need for tissue expanders. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Not that it was easy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She called the first four weeks after mastectomy “horrifying.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There were moments that I wished I hadn't opted for reconstruction because of the pain and the time off work,” she said. “I had six surgeries all together, one of them three weeks after the mastectomy to remove the nipple, as there was a positive margin on my nipple. I understand it can be just as painful without the reconstruction. I was concerned about taking too many opioids, as I was literally watching the clock to see when I was allowed to take another pill. However, I am extremely happy with the result.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“They [my breasts] are kind of crazy looking in that one doesn't have a nipple, but I like that I can wear all my old clothes,” continued Gallion.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She’s considering getting a 3-D tattoo in place of the missing nipple.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Mastectomy despite not having breast cancer&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Comedian Caitlin Brodnick has never been diagnosed with breast cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But she had a double mastectomy anyway.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some of her reasoning was based on her childhood. Her father’s entire immediate family died of various cancers, including breast cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Growing up, I was convinced I would get cancer. I was really afraid,” Brodnick told Healthline. “I was born just nine months after my aunt died of cancer. It was completely devastating and my whole family was anxious about health and cancer as a direct result.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At 28 years old, she tested for BRCA mutations. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The result was positive. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To Brodnick, it felt like a cancer diagnosis. In fact, she refers to it as a diagnosis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The official diagnosis and knowing I had the genetic mutation was scary. I thought it would be easier to have something you clearly knew how to fight. The idea that you’re more likely to get cancer is very vague. You have to continually test and see doctors for screening. You’re on the defense and it’s maddening. You don’t know if cancer is lurking around the corner,” she explained.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Brodnick credits actress Angelina Jolie with jumpstarting the preventive mastectomy conversation. Jolie, who carries the BRCA1 genetic mutation, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/14/opinion/my-medical-choice.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;went public&lt;/a&gt; following her preventive double mastectomy in 2013.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Doctors are cautious because they don’t want patients to have a mastectomy as a gut emotional response without thinking it through,” said Brodnick. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Doctors didn’t push the decision on her.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She came to it on her own after discussing it with her husband and other family members.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She’d never had a major surgery before, so there was a lot of pre-op anxiety. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The minute I woke up after surgery I felt total relief,” she said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She also had implants. The size didn’t work out, so the procedure had to be repeated. Other than that, there haven’t been any post-surgical complications.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I had no idea I’d feel this great. Three years later, I’m strong and healthy.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As satisfied as she is with her own decisions, she knows it’s not for everyone. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“A close friend had breast cancer at a young age and had a mastectomy. It was traumatic for her. Reconstructed breasts won’t ever be like real breasts,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Brodnick’s story is documented in the &lt;a href=&quot;http://video.glamour.com/series/screw-you-cancer&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Screw You Cancer Series&lt;/a&gt; with Glamour magazine and her upcoming book, “&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.amazon.com/Dangerous-Boobies-Breaking-Time-Bomb-Breasts/dp/158005675X&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Dangerous Boobies: Breaking Up with My Time-Bomb Breasts&lt;/a&gt;.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A breast surgeon’s point of view&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Diane M. Radford is staff breast surgical oncologist at &lt;a href=&quot;https://my.clevelandclinic.org&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Cleveland Clinic&lt;/a&gt; and medical director of the breast program at Cleveland Clinic Hillcrest Hospital.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When counseling patients with cancer in one breast, she follows the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.breastsurgeons.org/docs/ASBrS_CPM_PositionStatement.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;consensus statement&lt;/a&gt; from the American Society of Breast Surgeons and the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.breastsurgeons.org/new_layout/programs/choosing_wisely.php&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Choosing Wisely&lt;/a&gt; guidelines. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I counsel women about the lack of survival benefit with CPM (contralateral prophylactic mastectomy) and increased risk of complications such as bleeding and infection,” she wrote in an email to Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In patients in high risk groups, such as BRCA gene carriers, the risk to the other breast is high enough to warrant CPM. My approach is evidence-based, and I review the pros and cons,” she said. “While CPM is the best risk reduction we can offer (about 95 percent risk reduction), the risk of cancer in the other breast is small in average risk women — 0.2 to 0.5 percent per year for those undergoing adjuvant therapies.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;No surgery is risk-free.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The risk of bleeding is about 1 percent and the risk of infection is also about 1 percent,” said Radford. “So if both breasts are removed those risks rise to 2 percent and 2 percent. There is debate on whether to routinely perform sentient node biopsy for CPM. I do not routinely perform sentient node biopsy for CPM, therefore there is theoretically no risk of &lt;a href=&quot;/health/lymphatic-obstruction#overview1&quot;&gt;lymphedema&lt;/a&gt; with CPM.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Medical decisions often involve more than statistics and probabilities. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There’s also a quality of life issue.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Radford explained that if, after counseling, a woman at average risk for contralateral cancer wishes CPM, she would agree to do it. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The consensus statement states that CPM also may be appropriate for women with other conditions such as dense breasts, recall fatigue, concern about reconstruction symmetry, and extreme disease-related anxiety,” she said. “If in my opinion the patient will be extremely anxious about risk to the other breast, then for quality of life, I would perform CPM.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-04-13T13:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-13T13:00:00</updateddate>

http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/more-women-having-double-mastectomies

<dc:creator>Ann Pietrangelo</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-13T20:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>
Breast Cancer in Men: More Common Than You Might Think
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/breast-cancer-in-men
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/mens-health/041317_menbreastcancer_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It’s rare for a man to be diagnosed with breast cancer, but it happens more than you might think.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While cases of male breast cancer only account for 1 percent of breast cancer diagnoses, close to &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cancer.org/cancer/breast-cancer-in-men/about/key-statistics.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2,500 new cases&lt;/a&gt; of male breast cancer are diagnosed in the United States every year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Each day that’s about seven new cases diagnosed and one death.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For the most part, the outcomes and treatments are the same for breast cancer, whether it occurs in a man or a woman.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But for men diagnosed with the disease, experts say the disease can present them with a real challenge to find support and treatment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Treatment geared toward women&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Male breast cancer made &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.foxnews.com/health/2017/04/03/dad-is-diagnosed-with-breast-cancer-for-third-time.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;headlines&lt;/a&gt; earlier this month when a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.foxnews.com/health/2017/04/03/dad-is-diagnosed-with-breast-cancer-for-third-time.htm.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;man in Brittan&lt;/a&gt;, who had been diagnosed with breast cancer twice, was diagnosed a third time.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Complicating things for Stuart Weaver was the fact that, after his initial diagnosis, his private insurer refused to pay for a drug to treat the disease because he’s a man.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While laws and insurers are different in Britain, many of the same problems plague men who are diagnosed with the disease in the United States, says a doctor who specializes in breast cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Many breast cancer trials often exclude men from getting into the study,” Dr. Bhuvaneswari Ramaswamy, director of the breast medical oncology division at The Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center, told Healthline. “This is changing, thankfully. The medical community is making efforts to include men in breast cancer studies unless there’s a biological or scientific reason to exclude them. But even if you do include them, you can imagine how few of them would be in the study.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Diagnosis, risk factors&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Genetics doesn’t play a big role in breast cancer in women, but it does in men.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In women, the risk factor for developing breast cancer is that you’re a woman and you’re getting older,” said Ramaswamy. “So age and being a woman are the most important risk factors for women. People often ask about family history and whether you carry the gene and things like that, and the risk factor of carrying an inheritable gene mutation is only between five to 10 percent in females.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For men, the risk factors are completely different, says Ramaswamy. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The most common reason for men to develop breast cancer is not aging, and it’s not because they’re men. It’s carrying the genetic mutation,” she said. “The risk factor difference is flipped because the most common reason for a man to develop breast cancer is because he carries the gene mutation.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ramaswamy also points out that more than 90 percent of breast cancers in men are of the estrogen receptor positive subtype, while that number falls to about 70 percent in women. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This means that more than 90 percent of breast cancers in men are dependent on estrogen.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Male breast cancer is largely a fluke, but are there any preventative measures men can take?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“You can’t modify a gene and you can’t modify your family history, obviously,” said Ramaswamy. “But you can modify your lifestyle. Men have an increased risk of developing breast cancer if they are overweight and if they drink. Because both obesity and alcohol consumption lead to higher estrogen in the body.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A lonely battle&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Breast cancer tends to be the most commonly diagnosed cancer among women in the United States, so there is no shortage of support options for women diagnosed with the disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But for men, finding support can be difficult.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The emotional aspect is so different between the two groups and I think this is something that’s important to highlight,” said Ramaswamy. “If a man is diagnosed, he’ll often feel very isolated. Almost all of my male breast cancer patients have verbalized that they feel isolated.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There is also a stigma many of the men feel.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Some of them also feel a little bit, kind of shameful, to share with their friends that they have breast cancer,” Ramaswamy added. “It’s not as masculine as saying that they have prostate cancer. There are also lots of concerns about taking medications like estrogen pills and how that will affect the idea of being a man.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Men also can have problems finding information.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The interesting, or ironic, part of this is that there is so much information, so much constantly being said about breast cancer on the web and everywhere else — but it isn’t about their specific problem,” Ramaswamy added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Outcomes largely the same&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Despite the unique challenges that breast cancer presents in men, treatment of the disease is pretty much the same for men and women.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Stage for stage, the outcomes are no different for male and female breast cancer,” said Ramaswamy. “So if you compare them at the same stages and types and subtypes, the outcomes are pretty much the same.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This is relatively good news for men who are diagnosed as they can utilize the same treatment methods as women — and, increasingly, the same medications as well.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But because the disease is so rare in men, detection can be difficult. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There is some data that male breast cancers are diagnosed a little bit late because men are not doing self-exams or getting mammograms, so there is some data on delayed diagnosis of male breast cancer,” said Ramaswamy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She added that since 99 percent of breast cancers occur in women, treatment and support services will always necessarily be geared toward women.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s definitely a very unique situation for men with breast cancer,” said Ramaswamy. “It’s not that there’s an agenda on this. It’s just that women are far more likely to develop breast cancer.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<category>Men's Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-13T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-13T12:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/breast-cancer-in-men
</guid>
<dc:creator>Dan Gray</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-13T19:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
How Working Class White Americans Are Killing Themselves
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/how-working-americans-are-killing-themselves
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/041317_whitedeath_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Death
]]>
<![CDATA[
rates among middle-aged white Americans have risen dramatically since 1999, especially for those with low levels of education.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Two Princeton University economists say this is driven mainly by deaths due to drug overdoses, suicide, and liver diseases related to alcohol — what they call “deaths of despair.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In particular, this group of Americans has been hit hard by the opioid epidemic — both from prescription and illegal opioids.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This has led to midlife mortality rates for working class Americans overtaking those of minority groups for the first time.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.brookings.edu/bpea-articles/mortality-and-morbidity-in-the-21st-century/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;new paper&lt;/a&gt;, Princeton University’s Angus Deaton and Anne Case suggest that a “cumulative disadvantage” has kept middle-aged whites in a downward spiral since the late 1990s.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Ultimately, we see our story as about the collapse of the white, high school educated, working class after its heyday in the early 1970s, and the pathologies that accompany that decline,” they write in the report.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Rising mortality rates&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Rising mortality rates among middle-aged whites are unusual in that they follow a century of declining rates.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The trend is also unique to this segment of the population. Since 1999, Americans in other groups — based on age, race, or ethnicity — have all experienced improvements in mortality.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Deaths rates among middle-aged whites with less than a high school degree are rising the quickest and much faster than middle-aged whites with at least a four-year college degree.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.npr.org/2016/12/17/505965420/study-communities-most-affected-by-opioid-epidemic-also-voted-for-trump&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Recent news reports&lt;/a&gt; sometimes focus on the impact of “deaths of despair” in rural areas.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But Case and Deaton found that these conditions are now much more widespread.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2000, the “deaths of despair” epidemic among whites was centered in the Southwest. By the mid-2000s, it had spread to Appalachia, Florida, and the West Coast.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Now it pervades all areas of the country, both rural and urban.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Middle-aged whites have also lost ground against heart disease, with declines in mortality slowing over the past decade and even stopping recently.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some blame the slowing progress against heart disease on the obesity epidemic. But it is not that simple.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Case and Deaton write that obesity is rising faster among African-Americans than whites. In spite of that, African-Americans made more progress against heart disease between 1999 and 2015.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers suggest that some deaths attributed to heart disease may actually be due to type 2 diabetes, which is also associated with obesity.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Cumulative disadvantages in life&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;While the researchers focused on mortality rates since the late 1990s, they also pointed out longer trends for whites.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The rate of “deaths of despair” for whites born in 1975 is rising faster than for those born in 1935.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Unemployment has also increased with each successive age group of whites since that time, while marriage rates have gone down. Self-reported physical pain and poor physical and mental health have gone up.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers write that others have suggested that “slowly growing, stagnant, and even declining incomes” have contributed to the high mortality rates of middle-aged whites.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, middle-aged African-Americans and Hispanics have fared little better in terms of income while their mortality has been falling over the past decade.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The “cumulative disadvantage” in life faced by whites fits with some theories suggesting that a rise in “deaths of despair” is driven by an erosion of this group’s social and economic well-being over the past two decades.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s quite possible that some of the social adversities that middle-aged white men have been facing in the country over the last 20 years are having an impact on their health outcomes, including their use of substances and their vulnerability to poor outcomes,” Dr. Itai Danovitch, chair and associate professor of the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Neurosciences at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Growing deaths of despair&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Given the circumstances faced by this group, “deaths of despair” may be an especially apt phrase for these preventable conditions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There’s probably an element of both alcohol and opioids that involves self-medicating,” said Danovitch. “And when you think about what self-medication is about, it’s often about trying to fill a hole or treat an emotional pain, or deal with despair.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These conditions also overlap, with each fueling and feeding on the others.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Alcohol use is associated with increased suicides. And suicides are also associated with alcohol use. And mental health problems are common to all three of those conditions,” said Danovitch.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Related mental health problems can happen not only when people are in the depths of a substance use disorder, but also when they are trying to “go straight.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Opioids and alcohol are really profound addictions that come with very difficult withdrawal symptoms — the kind of despair that is often associated with suicide,” Kevin Doyle, EdD, LPC, LSATP, a professor in the counselor education program at Longwood University in Virginia, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Complicating the matter, people also vary in how they end up with a substance abuse disorder.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Some people are depressed, and drugs and alcohol start out as a way to help them cope,” Deni Carise, PhD, chief clinical officer for Recovery Centers of America, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other people, she said, start using drugs and alcohol to have fun. And it becomes “such a problem that they’ve now either altered their brain chemistry so that they are depressed, or they are depressed situationally.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The effects of substance abuse can also spill over into other areas of a person’s life, feeding the sense of “despair.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With substance abuse, “there’s lots of family and financial ruin, involvement in the criminal justice system, etc.,” said Doyle, “the kinds of things that might cause someone to lose hope and get to that point of taking their own life.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Opioid epidemic still growing&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The opioid epidemic, in particular, is a strong push behind rising “deaths of despair” mortality rates for middle-aged whites.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), more than &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/drugoverdose/epidemic/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;six out of 10&lt;/a&gt; drug overdose deaths in the United States are due to opioids. Nearly &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/drugoverdose/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;half of these&lt;/a&gt; involve a prescription opioid, such as methadone, OxyContin, and Vicodin.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This includes both intentional and unintentional overdoses. Not everyone who dies of an overdose is addicted.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Among people who died from a prescription opioid overdose between 1999 and 2014, &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/drugoverdose/data/overdose.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;overdose rates&lt;/a&gt; were higher among whites, American Indians and Alaskan Natives, compared to African-Americans and Hispanics.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamapsychiatry/article-abstract/2612444&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;recent study&lt;/a&gt; in JAMA Psychiatry also found that between 2001 and 2013, heroin use increased more in whites than in other racial and ethnic groups.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, the proportion of people reporting that they started using prescription opioids for recreational purposes before moving onto heroin increased more for whites.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As a “gateway drug,” prescription opioids have been frighteningly effective.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It used to be that by the time somebody comes into treatment for heroin problems, they have what we would call a 10- or 20-year drug use history or career,” said Carise.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But now, people who try a prescription opioid pill at a party or lift one from a friend’s medicine cabinet, can quickly move onto heroin, methadone, or fentanyl, a synthetic opioid.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We have this very short trajectory now, that I’ve never seen in 30 years,” said Carise. “Sometimes in three, six, nine months easy, they’re using heroin because it’s easier to get, it’s stronger, and it’s less expensive.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Given the complex factors behind the rise in “deaths of despair” among whites, Case and Deaton write that it “will take many years to reverse the mortality and morbidity increase.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This may not bode well for whites who are in midlife right now — they are “likely to do much worse in old age than those currently older than 65,” write the researchers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Counteracting this epidemic will take a comprehensive public health approach, one that addresses both the economic and social factors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It will also mean helping people before they reach middle age — maybe even as early as public school.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;We need to “empower people’s ability to recover when they hit adversity,” said Danovitch, “to be resilient, and to be healthy, and to have lives that have well-being and quality.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<item>
<title>How Music Affects Our Moods</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/mental-listening-to-music-lifts-or-reinforces-mood-051713
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/mental-health/082515_musictherapy_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;From the drumbeats of our ancient ancestors to today’s unlimited streaming services, music is an integral part of the human experience. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers have pondered the possible therapeutic and mood boosting benefits of music for &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.musictherapy.org/about/history/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;centuries&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Even sad music brings most listeners pleasure and comfort, according to recent research from Durham University in the United Kingdom and the University of Jyvaskyla in Finland, published in &lt;a href=&quot;http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0157444&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;PLOS ONE&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Conversely, the study found that for some people, sad music can cause negative feelings of profound grief. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The research involved three surveys of more than 2,400 people in the United Kingdom and Finland, focusing on the emotions and memorable experiences associated with listening to sad songs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The majority of experiences reported by participants were positive. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The results help us to pinpoint the ways people regulate their mood with the help of music, as well as how music rehabilitation and music therapy might tap into these processes of comfort, relief, and enjoyment,” said lead author, Tuomas Eerola, Ph.D., a professor of music cognition at Durham University, in a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.dur.ac.uk/news/newsitem/?itemno=28329&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;press release&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He also said the study may help find reasons for both listening to and avoiding sad music. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;An earlier study, published in the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.1086/670609?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Journal of Consumer Research&lt;/a&gt;, found that people tend to prefer sad music when they are experiencing a deep interpersonal loss, like the end of a relationship. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The authors of that study &lt;a href=&quot;http://press.uchicago.edu/pressReleases/2013/May/0515Lee.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;suggested&lt;/a&gt; that sad music provides a substitute for the lost relationship. They compared it to the preference most people have for an empathic friend — someone who truly understands what you’re going through. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other research has focused on the joy upbeat music can bring. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A 2013 study in the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/17439760.2012.747000&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Journal of Positive Psychology&lt;/a&gt; found that people who listened to upbeat music could improve their moods and boost their happiness in just two weeks. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the study, participants were instructed to try to improve their mood, but they only succeeded when they listened to the upbeat music of Copland as opposed to the sadder tunes of Stravinsky. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And a happier mood brings benefits beyond feeling good. In a &lt;a href=&quot;http://munews.missouri.edu/news-releases/2013/0514-trying-to-be-happier-works-when-listening-to-upbeat-music-according-to-mu-research/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;press release&lt;/a&gt;, lead study author, Yuna Ferguson, noted that happiness has been linked to better physical health, higher income, and greater relationship satisfaction.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Music as therapy&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;This music research aligns with the larger arena of music therapy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.musictherapy.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;American Music Therapy Association (AMTA)&lt;/a&gt; reports that music therapy programs can be designed to achieve goals such as managing stress, enhancing memory, and alleviating pain.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It might seem surprising that music can help people cope with physical pain, but research has shown a clear link. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A 2015 review in &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(15)60169-6/abstract&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;The Lancet&lt;/a&gt;&lt;em&gt; &lt;/em&gt;found that people who listened to music before, during, or after surgery experienced less pain and anxiety, compared to patients who did not listen to music. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The music listeners didn’t even need as much pain medication. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To conduct the study, researchers looked at data from 73 different trials, involving more than 7,000 patients. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The people who experienced a slightly greater, but nonsignificant, reduction in pain, and needed the least pain medication, were the ones who got to pick their own music. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Music is a non-invasive, safe, cheap intervention that should be available to everyone undergoing surgery,” lead study author Catherine Meads, Ph.D., of Brunel University in the United Kingdom, recommended in a&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2015-08/tl-tll081115.php&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt; press release&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When it comes to treating chronic conditions, music therapy can also play a powerful role. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A recent review in the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4369551/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;World Journal of Psychiatry&lt;/a&gt; found that music therapy can be an effective treatment for mood disorders related to neurological conditions, including Parkinson’s disease, dementia, stroke, and multiple sclerosis. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After reviewing 25 trials, the researchers concluded that music is a valid therapy to potentially reduce depression and anxiety, as well as to improve mood, self-esteem, and quality of life. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They also noted that no negative side effects were reported in any of the trials, making music a low-risk treatment.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Barry Goldstein, a recording artist who has studied the vibrational effects of music for more than 25 years, says music has a profound impact on the brain.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.consciouslifestylemag.com/music-and-the-brain-affects-mood/&quot;&gt;a column&lt;/a&gt; for Conscious Lifestyle magazine, Goldstein wrote that music can actually enhance brain functions.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;He said music can evoke emotion, help regain memories, stimulate new neural connections, and active attention.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Boosting moods&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;While listening to music may bring greater health benefits, creating it can be an effective therapy, too. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A unique orchestra for people with dementia helped improve their mood and boost their self-confidence, according to researchers at the Bournemouth University Dementia Institute (BUDI) in Dorset, U.K.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The orchestra is one of several BUDI research projects that aims to demonstrate how people with dementia can still learn new skills and have fun. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Eight people with dementia and seven caregivers participated in the project, along with students and professional musicians. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Music touches everyone in some way, either by listening or playing,” said Anthea Innes, Ph.D., head of BUDI, in a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.esrc.ac.uk/news-events-and-publications/news/news-items/orchestra-helps-boost-confidence-and-mood-for-those-with-dementia/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;press release&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She said that the orchestra has been a life-enhancing project for everyone involved, and that the project challenges the negative public perceptions of people diagnosed with dementia. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Working together to produce a collaborative output is a powerful way to bring out the best in people — not just in terms of their musical skills, but their communication skills, friendships, care, and support for one another,” she added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Editor’s Note: This story was originally published on May 17, 2013. It was updated by Jenna Flannigan on August 3, 2016, and again by David Mills on April 13, 2017.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Mental Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-13T00:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-13T00:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/mental-listening-to-music-lifts-or-reinforces-mood-051713
</guid>
<dc:creator>Suzanne Boothby</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-13T07:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Why You Have to Wait Longer to Get a Doctor’s Appointment
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/why-you-have-to-wait-longer-to-get-a-doctors-appointment
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/041217_doctorwait_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Getting an appointment with a doctor shouldn’t be a problem.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As long as you can wait three weeks or even a little longer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.merritthawkins.com/uploadedFiles/MerrittHawkins/Pdf/mha2017waittimerelease.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;new survey&lt;/a&gt; concluded that the wait time to get into see a physician has been slowly ticking upward the past decade, reaching an all-time high of 24 days this year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Experts interviewed by Healthline said there are a number of reasons for the increase.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Among them are a shortage of physicians, an increase in the number of people with health insurance, and the extra time burden on doctors to deal with electronic medical records.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The ramifications are also varied.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The experts said these include people skipping preventative medicine appointments and an increase in the number of patients at urgent care centers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Crunching the numbers&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The 2017 Survey of Physician Appointment Wait Times was conducted by Merritt Hawkins, a healthcare consulting company.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Merritt Hawkins researchers received responses from 1,414 physicians in 15 metropolitan areas in the United States.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The doctors were from five medical specialties: family medicine, cardiology, dermatology, obstetrics/gynecology, and orthopedic surgery.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers said the survey showed that the wait time for a new patient-physician appointment has risen to an average of 24 days.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That compares with 18 days in 2014, 20 days in 2009, and 21 days in 2004.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Merritt Hawkins also did a similar survey in 15 midsize regions with populations from 90,000 to 140,000, and found wait times a little longer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The average wait time in those more rural areas was 32 days. That’s 33 percent higher than metro regions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Finding a physician who can see you today, or three weeks from today, can be a challenge, even in large urban areas where there is a relatively robust supply of doctors,” Mark Smith, president of Merritt Hawkins, said in a press release. “The challenge becomes even more difficult in smaller communities that have fewer physicians per population.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers also queried doctors on Medicare and Medicaid.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In metro areas, they found that 85 percent accept Medicare patients and 53 percent accept patients covered by Medicaid.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In midsize regions, 81 percent of doctors accept Medicare patients, while 60 percent accept Medicaid patients.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Why wait times are increasing&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;One of the main reasons for the increase in wait times is the simple law of supply and demand.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kurt Mosley, vice president of strategic alliances for Merritt Hawkins, said the current and pending shortage of doctors is a prime cause of the increase.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He noted this is particularly true in Boston, which had the highest average wait time with 52 days.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The fact of the matter is we simply don’t have enough doctors,” Mosley told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Mott Blair, a family physician in North Carolina, and a member of the board of directors of the American Academy of Family Physicians, said the increase in the number of patients is also exacerbating the problem.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He told Healthline that more people have health insurance because of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) and the uptick in the economy the past few years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That is creating higher demand at doctors’ offices.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“As the economy has turned around, we have been seeing a lot more people who want care,” Blair said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mosley added that the growth in the number of people over the age of 55 is also increasing demand.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Both experts agreed that the introduction of electronic health records is also limiting the time doctors can spend with patients.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.physiciansfoundation.org/uploads/default/Biennial_Physician_Survey_2016.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;another survey&lt;/a&gt; done last year by Merritt Hawkins, researchers discovered that 33 percent of doctors felt electronic records reduced the quality of care they give to patients.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, 55 percent said the electronic records reduced efficiency, and 59 percent said they reduced patient interaction.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The American Medical Association (AMA) found similar percentages in &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ama-assn.org/study-technological-admin-demands-cut-face-time-patients&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;a survey&lt;/a&gt; it did last fall.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The results prompted the AMA to issue &lt;a href=&quot;http://annals.org/aim/article/2546704/allocation-physician-time-ambulatory-practice-time-motion-study-4-specialties&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;a statement&lt;/a&gt; in the Annals of Internal Medicine noting that for every hour physicians were spending with patients, they were spending two hours on electronic records and other administrative tasks.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Blair said all of these factors are producing a simple result.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The number of patients I see during the day is decreasing,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The ramifications of longer waits&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The fallout from longer wait times is also varied.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The experts said people who have to wait several weeks to see a doctor might just skip routine or preventative medicine appointments.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That can lead to consequences down the road.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;People can develop more serious ailments from ignoring symptoms or postponing healthcare.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Healthcare delayed is healthcare denied,” said Mosley.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The other thing people do is make an appointment at an urgent care center or other medical facility when they can’t see their own doctor.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Blair said that’s fine if the patient is in pain or has a serious health issue. But, he said, if a person is going to a facility and seeing a different doctor each time for routine appointments they can miss out on the expertise a family doctor might contribute over a series of visits.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think this is a real danger,” he said. “It breaks down the continuity of care.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>General Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-12T15:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-12T15:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/why-you-have-to-wait-longer-to-get-a-doctors-appointment
</guid>
<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-12T22:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Brain Bypass Technology Provides Hope for People with Paralysis
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/brain-bypass-technology
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/041017_brainbypass_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Scien
]]>
<![CDATA[
tific breakthroughs in brain-computer interface technology may offer new hope for overcoming paralysis. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the latest advance, a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cbsnews.com/news/groundbreaking-technology-restores-movement-in-paralyzed-man/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;man with quadriplegia&lt;/a&gt; who was paralyzed eight years ago, regained functional movement of his arm.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He fed himself with his hand using this technology, a first in medical history.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers at Case Western Reserve University in Ohio announced their findings on Mar. 28 in the British medical journal The Lancet.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Case Western announcement was made the day after entrepreneur Elon Musk (of the Tesla electric car and rocket company SpaceX) revealed plans to develop a similar technology.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Musk’s “neural lace,” according to &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.wsj.com/articles/elon-musk-launches-neuralink-to-connect-brains-with-computers-1490642652&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;a report&lt;/a&gt; in The Wall Street Journal, would link a person’s brain directly with a computer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Meanwhile, scientists at The Ohio State University (OSU) are working with a patient with paralysis and have developed a technology similar to the one at Case Western.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The OSU team is &lt;a href=&quot;http://osuwmc.multimedia-newsroom.com/index.php/2016/04/13/man-uses-his-own-brainwaves-to-retrain-his-paralyzed-hand/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;developing the technology&lt;/a&gt; with scientists at Battelle Memorial Institute, a nonprofit organization in Ohio that creates medical devices.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Decoding brain signals&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Case Western scientists have been working with Bill Kochevar, a 53-year-old with quadriplegia who was injured in a bicycle accident.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers implanted a neuroprosthesis that decoded his brain signals and transmitted them to sensors in his arm, which helped him to regain movement in his hand and arm.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Robert Kirsch, PhD, chair of the Case Western Department of Biomedical Engineering, executive director of the university’s Functional Electrical Stimulation (FES) Center, is senior author of the research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He called the breakthrough a major step.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We’ve shown the feasibility of recording someone’s movement intentions and then making their own arm make those movements,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kirsch’s colleague Bolu Ajiboye, PhD, an assistant professor of biomedical engineering at Case Western, and research associate at the Louis Stokes Cleveland Veterans Administration Medical Center, explained how the technology works.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Normal movement in unimpaired persons occurs because the motor cortex generates a movement command, represented as electrical signals, that is passed through the spinal cord, and then activates the appropriate muscles,” Ajiboye told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A spinal cord injury prevents those electrical impulses from reaching the muscles, he explained, but the original movement command is still properly coded in the brain's patterns of electrical activity. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our system records the pattern of electrical activity through the brain implant and uses mathematical&amp;nbsp;algorithms to decode it into a movement command that is intended by the person with paralysis.&amp;nbsp;That command is converted into an electrical stimulation pattern that is applied to the right group of muscles to produce the movement. To Mr. Kochevar, the process is seamless and invisible. In his words, he says he just thinks about moving his arm and the arm moves as he intends.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ajiboye also pointed out what this new technology isn’t.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Science has attempted many times to “fix” a damaged spine through tissue engineering and regrowth without success, he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We would love for scientists to find a way to regrow and reconnect the spinal cord using cell therapies,” Ajiboye said. “However, our current approach uses technology to circumvent the spinal injury to get the movement signals from the brain to the right set of muscles to produce the movement.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other technologies that help people with paralysis to regain function are typically limited to devices they can control using their voices and eye movements, or by moving their heads.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, none of these devices allow for control of one’s own limb.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our device allows a user to move his own limb just by thinking,” Ajiboye explained. “I want to make it clear that our system is circumventing spinal injury, rather than reversing paralysis. Without the system, the user would still be paralyzed, and there is no evidence to suggest that use of this system would eventually result in the spinal regrowth, or would reintroduce the ability to move without the system.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How the technology works&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Why is the Case Western technology unique?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The system is the first to use both a brain-implant computer interface with an FES system to electrically activate paralyzed muscles.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Prior to this, scientists have treated a number of people with paralysis but with only one approach or the other. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kochevar is the first person to experience this combined technology.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ajiboye said many research groups have used the brain interface system with humans and with nonhuman primates. Both test groups were able to perform tasks such as moving cursors on a computer screen or moving robotic arms. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our FES Center for the last 25 to 30 years has implanted FES systems in people with spinal cord injuries to restore a number of functions, including standing, walking, breathing, and hand and arm movements,” he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kochevar joined the Case Western research project in 2014. He received his brain implants in December of that year. In 2015, Kirsch, Ajiboye, and their colleagues implanted electrodes in the muscles of his arm and hand.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kochevar learned to activate his brain signals to control different devices.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We first had him watch a virtual arm move on a computer screen, while he simultaneously imagined making the same movements with his own arm,” Ajiboye said. “This generated patterns of neural activity. We then developed a neural decoder, a mathematical algorithm that related the generated patterns of neural activity with aspects of the virtual arm movements.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Next, they had Kochevar control the virtual arm by generating patterns of brain signals that were then interpreted by the neural decoder, Ajiboye said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kochevar trained to move the virtual arm with precision to specified targets in the workspace. The scientists quantified his brain control of the virtual arm, and discovered that he was able to control it almost immediately, Ajiboye said. In addition, Kochevar relatively quickly achieved a success rate of 95 to 100 percent of target accuracy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Finally, the scientists had Kochevar attempt to move his arm through FES stimulation in a two-step process. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We manually moved his arm (via electrical stimulation) and instructed him to imagine that he was in control of his arm movements,” Ajiboye said. “Again, this helped generate the desired patterns of neural activity, which we used to build and refine our neural decoder. We had him use the final neural decoder to command the movements of his own arm, reanimated through electrical stimulation. He was able to instantly move his arm as desired, and has progressively gotten better with increased use.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a video released by Case Western, Kochevar said, “It was amazing because I thought about moving my arm and it did. I could move it in and out, up and down.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Since Kochevar had long-term paralysis, his muscles were initially weak and easily fatigued. Ajiboye said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To build his muscle strength and resistance to fatigue, the team “exercised” his muscles for several hours a day using electrical stimulation without the brain interface system.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Over time, this electrically stimulated exercise increased his muscle strength and his ability to use the system longer without fatigue.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Brain-computer interfaces&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Like the Case Western innovations, the &lt;a href=&quot;http://osuwmc.multimedia-newsroom.com/index.php/2016/04/13/man-uses-his-own-brainwaves-to-retrain-his-paralyzed-hand/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Ohio State innovation&lt;/a&gt; helped a man with quadriplegia to use his hand after years of paralysis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The research team was led by Dr. Ali Rezai, a professor of neurosurgery and neuroscience, and director of the Center for Neuromodulation at the university’s Wexner Medical Center.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The patient, Ian Burkhart, sustained a severe spinal cord injury at age 19 during a diving accident. It left him with little function and movement in his shoulders and biceps, and no movement from his elbows to his hands.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our team has developed a brain-computer interface technology that bypasses the damaged spinal cord, allowing a patient such as Ian with spinal cord injury and quadriplegia and no function of his hands for five years to simply use his thoughts to move his lifeless hand to come alive and under his volitional control,” Rezai told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In April 2014, Rezai implanted a microchip the size of the head of a pencil eraser on the surface of the motor cortex of Burkhart’s brain. The chip’s 96 microelectrodes recorded the firing of his individual neurons.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Rezai and his colleagues developed the neural bypass system, which records and analyzes the brain activity that occurs when Burkhart&lt;strong&gt; &lt;/strong&gt;intends to move his hand.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After bypassing the damaged spinal cord and damaged connection from the brain to the muscle nerves, the system links Burkhart’s brain signal with an external garment sleeve, Rezai said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This enables Burkhart to move his hand. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The brain implant records and interprets brain signals linked to thoughts, and links them to an external wearable sleeve garment to control his muscles,” Rezai explained. “It’s a neuromuscular stimulation system. The thoughts associated with an intention to move — for example opening the hand — are linked and connected within milliseconds to actual functional hand movement.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The first generation of the external wearable sleeve garment and stimulation system, he said, has up to 160 stimulating electrodes “made up of super flexible hydrogel — a high-definition, high-resolution array of electrodes that conform to different shapes and contours such as the forearm.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The garment can be shaped into a sleeve, a glove, a sock, pants, belt, head-band, and other form factors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Significant complexity and coordination is needed to allow movements in a smooth fashion to pick up a stirrer to stir the coffee, use a toothbrush, or play a video game,” he said. “This machine learning algorithm is improving and refining the movements from rough and choppy movements, to more smooth and fluid movements.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Optimism for the future&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Neuroscientists observing the recent breakthroughs are impressed and optimistic.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Joseph O’Doherty, PhD, a senior postdoctoral fellow at the Philip Sabes Lab at the University of California, San Francisco, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cin.ucsf.edu/index.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Center for Integrative Neuroscience&lt;/a&gt;, calls these recent advances in brain-computer interface technology “groundbreaking.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This research shows that paralyzed limbs can be reanimated — by thought alone — for restoring the coordinated, multi-joint movements important for daily life: reaching, grasping, eating, and drinking,” he told Healthline. “It is a proof-of-principle demonstration that raises the possibility that similar therapies could soon find adoption outside of the clinic.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Scientists have been working on brain-computer interfaces, in some form or another, since the late 1960s, he said. The field has progressed from the control of computer cursors, to moving wheelchairs and robotic arms, to, now, reestablishing voluntary control over the limbs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Spinal cord injury often impairs the sense of touch as well as the ability to move,” O’Doherty said. “Restoring limb sensations will be a crucial element of neuroprostheses that permit fluid and natural movements.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There are still many challenges to overcome,” he added, “but this new result, combined with many related advances in wireless technology, battery technology, materials science, and more, makes me very optimistic about neuroprosthetic devices for restoring movement and sensation becoming widely available.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Rezai said &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.fscip.org/facts.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;12,000 individuals&lt;/a&gt; in the United States each year sustain a spinal cord injury, and 300,000 live with such injuries from motor vehicle accidents, trauma, sports injuries, and falls.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Less than 1 percent achieve full recovery, and most have deficits that rely on various assistive and adaptive technologies to provide a limited degree of independence.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“These innovations offer hope and the potential for movement restoration and increased independence to many patients living with paralysis or other physical disabilities,” Rezai said. “In addition to motor improvements, this technology has potential implications for those with sensory deficits, chronic pain, speech, stroke, cognitive, anxiety, and behavioral implications.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Rezai said he is hopeful that soon those with physical, sensory, cognitive, and other disabilities will have the opportunity to be more functional, to have more independence, and a better quality of life.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our goal is to make this technology less invasive, reduce the size of the device, miniaturize the sensors, make the system wireless, and provide the system at home instead of in the laboratory,” he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Case Western team is also working to advance its system technologically.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We need to develop a wireless brain interface to replace the cable that connects the user to a set of recording computers,” Ajiboye said. “We need to enhance the brain implant for longevity, to increase the number of neurons we can record from, and to develop a fully implanted brain interface and functional electrical stimulation system.”&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
