<item>
<title>Get The Lead Out … of Men’s Hair Dye</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/get-the-lead-out-of-mens-hair-dye
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/mens-health/041217_menhairdye_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In the name of looking younger, men may be exposing themselves to dangerous amounts of lead.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In response, a group of consumer advocacy organizations is taking legal action to help prevent that.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The ingredient at the center of the group’s concern is a compound called lead acetate.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lead acetate is a component in some “progressive” hair dyes, cosmetic products that are designed to gradually darken gray.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In February, several leading consumer groups, including the Environmental Defense Fund, Earthjustice, and the Environmental Working Group, filed a &lt;a href=&quot;http://blogs.edf.org/health/files/2017/02/Lead-Acetate-Color-Additive-Petition-02-04-17.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;petition&lt;/a&gt; with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) requesting the agency ban the use of lead acetate.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The compound, which is found in Youthair and Grecian Formula products, is considered a neurotoxin.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Neurotoxins can damage organ systems, but they are particularly destructive to the nervous system.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Prolonged exposure to lead can result in brain damage, nerve damage, and neurological disorders, among other problems.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Unborn babies, children, and pregnant women are particularly vulnerable to the effects of lead.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) also &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/substances/toxsubstance.asp?toxid=22&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;labels lead acetate&lt;/a&gt; as a likely carcinogen.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Banned in Europe, allowed in America&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The FDA &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.fda.gov/cosmetics/productsingredients/products/ucm143075.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;approved&lt;/a&gt; lead acetate for cosmetic use in 1980.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To be approved as an additive, companies had to prove that lead acetate was safe under proper use circumstances.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;During the study phase, blood samples were drawn from people using the product and tested to monitor lead levels.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the FDA’s review of these findings, “no significant increase in blood levels of lead was seen in the trial subjects and the lead was not shown to be absorbed into the body through such use.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, in Canada and the European Union, the additive has been prohibited for almost a decade.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In its decision to ban lead acetate, Health Canada wrote, “The results showed that relatively small incremental exposures, such as those which would occur with regular use of hair dyes containing lead acetate, could result in the accumulation of potentially harmful body burdens of lead.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For now, the compound remains legal in the United States, but hair products must print this warning to customers on the products’ boxes:&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&quot;Caution: Contains lead acetate. For external use only. Keep this product out of children's reach. Do not use on cut or abraded scalp. If skin irritation develops, discontinue use. Do not use to color mustaches, eyelashes, eyebrows, or hair on parts of the body other than the scalp. Do not get in eyes. Follow instructions carefully and wash hands thoroughly after use.&quot;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The problem with “proper use”&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Progressive hair dyes need to be reapplied for proper maintenance of color.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That leads to continued exposure to the compound.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Plus, people don’t always follow the directions. Product packages advise people not to use these dye products on anything but their scalp, but not everyone heeds the warning. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A 2014 case study listed in the recent legal filing detailed the account of a man who had applied hair dye that contained lead acetate to his head and beard for seven months. He experienced tingling and numbness in his feet and hands, and his blood tests revealed the lead levels were 14 times higher than average blood lead levels.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;His doctor recognized the neurotoxin in his hair dye and instructed him to stop using it. Once he ceased using the lead-containing product, levels of lead in his blood returned to normal within six months. His neurological symptoms were also gone within a year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s not just the men coloring their hair who are at risk of lead exposure.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 1997, researchers from Xavier University of Louisiana concluded that lead contamination extends to common surfaces. Men can transfer lead to faucets, handles, bottles, hair dryers, and more. Family members can easily pick up the traces of lead throughout the home.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For example, the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.japha.org/article/S0003-0465(15)32422-8/pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; states that the progressive hair dye products coat hands with 150 to 700 micrograms of lead per hand. And there were up to 100 micrograms of lead on the surfaces men touched.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Washing hands with soap and water does not completely remove the lead.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, running hands through the hair can also spread lead to the hands. Hand-to-mouth or hand-to-surface contamination is possible and likely quite common.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Regulators taking another look&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;To put those numbers into context, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.epa.gov/lead/hazard-standards-lead-paint-dust-and-soil-tsca-section-403&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;states&lt;/a&gt; that 40 micrograms of lead per square foot on the floor is considered hazardous to children.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In countries where lead acetate is banned, brands like Grecian Formula and Youthair have created products that are lead-free. Some of those products are available in the United States, but the lead-containing products remain.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In December, the FDA &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.fda.gov/Cosmetics/GuidanceRegulation/GuidanceDocuments/ucm517327.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;proposed&lt;/a&gt; limiting the amount of lead in certain cosmetic products, including lipstick, eye shadow, lotions, and more. Hair dyes, however, were not part of that list.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The FDA is now &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2017/04/04/2017-06581/environmental-defense-fund-earthjustice-environmental-working-group-center-for-environmental-health&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;seeking comment&lt;/a&gt; from the public on the petition to ban lead acetate or allow it to remain an approved additive.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If the FDA were to ban the use of lead acetate in hair dyes and companies had lead-free alternatives available, the shift likely wouldn’t be a big market disruption. Still, manufacturers believe the ban would be an unnecessary restriction.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Combe, the company that manufactures Grecian Formula, told CBS in a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cbsnews.com/news/lead-acetate-hair-dye-mens-us-consumer-groups-file-petition-to-fda/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;statement&lt;/a&gt; that research on hand-to-mouth transmission of lead is “insufficient” and “lead acetate has been used safely as a color additive in ‘progressive’ hair dye products for decades based on extensive scientific studies.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Men's Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-12T11:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-12T11:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/get-the-lead-out-of-mens-hair-dye
</guid>
<dc:creator>Kimberly Holland</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-12T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
New Laws Restrict Abortion Without Actually Outlawing It
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/laws-restrict-abortion-without-outlawing
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/041217_antiabortion_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt
]]>
<![CDATA[
;&lt;p&gt;A law signed last month by Utah Governor, Gary Herbert, requires doctors to tell women seeking medical abortions that the procedure can be stopped midway through the process.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Health professionals say there are no medical grounds to make this claim.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Women’s rights advocates say it’s just the latest effort by lawmakers to police women’s bodies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They also say it’s part of a larger trend.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Abortion opponents haven’t been able to completely outlaw abortions, advocates say, so instead they are supporting laws across the country that make the medical procedure more difficult to obtain. Or they’re attempting to put in place requirements that interfere with the doctor-patient relationship.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I would tie this Utah law to a trend of abortion restrictions, a broader trend, that really seek to interfere directly in the exam room without necessarily banning abortion completely, but in even more nefarious ways,” Hayley Smith, a member of the Advocacy and Policy Counsel at the ACLU, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The law in Utah&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Utah &lt;a href=&quot;https://le.utah.gov/~2017/bills/static/HB0141.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;bill&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://le.utah.gov/~2017/bills/static/HB0141.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;H.B. 141&lt;/a&gt;, is based on the premise that if a woman decided not to take a second &lt;a href=&quot;/drugs/mifepristone/oral-tablet#Interactions3&quot;&gt;mifepristone&lt;/a&gt; pill — the drug that triggers a medical abortion — she could continue her pregnancy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Advocates for the bill say the legislation is backed by medical evidence, while doctors say it’s based on bunk science.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I’m very much in favor of the Utah measure to inform women that medical abortions can be reversed,” Eric Scheidler, executive director of the Pro-Life Action League, told Healthline in an email. “And it’s simply not true that there is no medical evidence backing this up. I have personally spoken with physicians who have successfully halted medical abortions. They report that this treatment is successful 65 to 70 percent of the time it is employed, and no birth defects have been associated with it.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Medical professionals, meanwhile, are sounding a different tune.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.acog.org/~/media/departments/state%20legislative%20activities/2015AZFactSheetMedicationAbortionReversalfinal.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;said&lt;/a&gt; in a statement, “Claims of medication abortion reversal are not supported by the body of scientific evidence, and this approach is not recommended in ACOG’s clinical guidance on medication abortion. There are no ACOG guidelines that support this course of action.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The statement also noted that &lt;a href=&quot;/progesterone/oral-capsule#Highlights1&quot;&gt;progesterone&lt;/a&gt;, which is used in an effort to reverse the abortion, is “generally well tolerated” but can carry a host of adverse side effects.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While the bill has raised many concerns, it could have been worse, says Marina Lowe, a member of the Legislative and Policy Counsel of the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) of Utah.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We saw this pop up pretty early in the session and we were obviously concerned,” she told Healthline. “The ACLU had experience with this same legislation when it was passed in Arizona a couple of years ago. There were some real concerns of the language, both from the perspective of mandating doctors to tell patients information which potentially is not medically accurate, but also some First Amendment issues.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lowe said her group sat down with the sponsor of the legislation and raised their concerns. The group ultimately provided the legislator with additional language that the ACLU thought would be better than the language that was in the bill originally. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“While we still don’t support the bill and think it doesn’t make sense for legislators to be telling doctors what they need to tell their patients, this language is much more flexible in terms of giving doctors the space to tell patients what they believe is in their best interest,” Lowe said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Similar laws nationwide&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;While the Supreme Court’s landmark &lt;a href=&quot;http://landmarkcases.org/en/landmark/cases/roe_v_wade&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Roe v. Wade ruling&lt;/a&gt; of 1973 guaranteed a woman’s right to seek abortion services, lawmakers around the country have found ways to make access to abortion difficult while not technically violating the ruling.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Smith noted that in the first week of its legislative session, Kentucky legislators “sped through” a law that requires medical providers to perform an ultrasound prior to an abortion.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The provider is required to show the image to the woman and describe it to her, even if she says she doesn’t want to hear that information.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It really turns it into a coercive situation,” Smith said. “This is part of a broader trend: Commandeering the doctor-patient relationship and putting the state and politicians right into that relationship.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In Oklahoma, the House Public Health Committee has &lt;a href=&quot;http://motto.time.com/4664160/oklahoma-abortion-written-consent/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;advanced&lt;/a&gt; a bill that would require women to get &lt;a href=&quot;http://thehill.com/homenews/state-watch/319635-oklahoma-house-advances-bill-to-require-mens-permission-for-abortions&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;written consent&lt;/a&gt; from their partner before getting an abortion.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In Arizona, Governor Doug Ducey, in late March, signed a bill into law that &lt;a href=&quot;https://mic.com/articles/172899/arizona-passes-extreme-abortion-restrictions-on-fetuses-that-are-delivered-alive#.3zKNSwqNn&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;requires&lt;/a&gt; doctors to attempt to resuscitate aborted fetuses that are “&lt;a href=&quot;http://nymag.com/thecut/2017/04/arizona-governor-signs-restrictive-born-alive-abortion-law.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;born alive&lt;/a&gt;” — ambiguous language that’s up for interpretation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Meanwhile, multiple states require a mandatory “waiting period” for women seeking an abortion.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lowe detailed some of the ways these laws limit a woman’s right to get an abortion.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Here in Utah, we have a 72-hour waiting requirement, whereby women who are seeking an abortion must wait 72 hours after being counseled and expressing their desire to get an abortion. They then must wait this 72-hour period to, quote, ‘think about their decision,’” Lowe said. “This may not sound like a big problem for some people, but if you live in a corner of the state of Utah, that 72-hour requirement means two separate trips to drive up to the part of the state where abortion clinics are located. If you have a family and a job and children, those two trips make it really quite difficult to access services you have a constitutional right to make use of.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Tough for doctors&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Laws that compel doctors to say things that they don’t necessarily believe has the potential to raise ethical issues.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s really concerning,” Terry O’Neill, president of the National Organization for Women (NOW), told Healthline. “Medical doctors are first introduced to do no harm. Informed consent is incredibly important. Any patient, male or female, is entitled to having the informed, medically accurate medical science told to them about their condition, their prognosis, and their recommended treatments.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With abortion services, O’Neill said, that bond is being broken.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Only in the case of women have we repeatedly seen ideological politicians inserting themselves into that informed consent process,” she said. “The law in Utah is a classic example. It actually requires doctors to lie to their patients. It is the antithesis of the informed consent that consumer groups have worked very, very hard to establish as the norm in medicine.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lowe points out that laws like these could dissuade top doctors from practicing in a given state.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This has an effect not only on women seeking abortions, but also physicians who are deciding whether or not to go into this field,” she said. “When your practice has made you feel shameful, when there are more requirements placed on you in terms or what you need to do in order to be licensed, in order to practice, when we see legislatures like the Utah legislature pushing these requirements that are essentially telling you to give your patients information that you don’t feel is accurate or safe or in the best interest of your patients, it has an effect.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Tougher for women&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Scheidler defends the new laws on moral grounds.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The Pro-Life Action League opposes abortion because it takes the life of an innocent unborn child, a child who is a member of the human family with an inalienable right to life, regardless of the circumstances surrounding the conception of that child,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Advocates for women, meanwhile, say that this position tramples on a woman’s right to make decisions about her body.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think you’ll hear anti-abortion politicians say that they’re passing these bills to make sure that a woman has fully thought through her decision, which is demeaning to women,” says Smith. “Because the truth is that women do truly think through their decision, and they speak with their healthcare provider, they speak with their family, they speak with a trusted religious adviser if they have one. And they make that personal decision on their own. For a politician to come in and presume to know better is just wrong.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Smith suggests the laws have other motivations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think their ultimate goal is to stigmatize abortion and shame women for the decision that they’ve already made,” she said. “It’s just another means of blocking women from getting the care that they need.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This sustained effort to sustain and stigmatize women for having an abortion, it actually doesn’t work,” said O’Neill. “There have been &lt;a href=&quot;http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0128832#sec013&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;studies&lt;/a&gt; done that show that 95 percent of women absolutely do not regret their abortion and report that they believe they made the right decision. That is notwithstanding a sustained effort by extremely well-funded, very powerful groups.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Sex ed. falls short&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;While lawmakers in some states take a hands-on approach to regulating abortion, sexual education is often lacking.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If you really want to prevent abortions, the best way is to make sure that people have access to education and information in order to make the appropriate, medically accurate decisions about their bodies,” said Lowe. “In Utah, we do a terrible job of equipping our young people with that information.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She said even some parents would prefer children be taught about sex education in the classroom.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“From what we can tell, there are lots and lots of parents who are uncomfortable having these sorts of conversations with their kids and would prefer to have this sort of information provided in our schools,” Lowe added. “And yet our schools are deciding, because of our lawmakers, to not touch these topics either.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On this topic, both sides are able to find a small amount of common ground.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The Pro-Life Action League does not support so-called ‘comprehensive’ sex education, which is often nothing more than training in condom use, along with the tacit message that we do not expect young people to be capable of exercising sexual self-control,” said Scheidler. “Truly comprehensive sex ed. would include training in understanding and recognizing the signs of a woman’s fertility cycle, and how to cooperate with that cycle to postpone pregnancy.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Abortion debate affects everyone&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Statistics show that &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.1in3campaign.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;1 in 3 American women&lt;/a&gt; will have an abortion by the age of 45, meaning that statistically, most people know someone who has undergone an abortion.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Regardless of a person’s personal beliefs about abortion, everyone has friends who are women, colleagues who are women, and women in their family,” said Smith. “The fact is that one in three women will have an abortion, so we all probably know someone who’s had one. It’s us. It’s our colleagues, our friends, our family members. And we can’t make that decision for somebody else, so I think the greatest thing is to think about these women, and think about what this means for their lives.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s extremely important that we stop demonizing women who have had abortions,” added O’Neill. “If we can reverse that, then politicians would no longer find it profitable to promote policies that end up harming women.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To gain a better understanding of the issue, O’Neill says it’s best to listen to women who have had abortions and are willing to share their experiences.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“As a practical matter, what I have seen in my experience is that women who talk about their abortion, to other men and women who are open minded, it does change the conversation,” she said. “It can change the opinion of the people who thought somehow that being anti-abortion was the same thing as being pro-life. They say, ‘Wait a minute, I can be pro-life and still support my friend who had an abortion. I can be there for her.’”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-04-12T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-12T10:00:00</updateddate>

</guid>
<dc:creator>Dan Gray</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-12T17:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Artificial Sweeteners May Encourage Fat Production</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/sweeteners-encourage-fat-production
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/food-fads/041117_sweetner_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As more Americans turn to artificial sweeteners to reduce their sugar consumption, scientists are beginning to explore how the substitutes react in the body.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.newswise.com/articles/view/672280/?sc=dwhr&amp;amp;xy=10020406&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; unveiled last week concluded that some artificial sweeteners may hinder our metabolism, rather than ramp it up.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This is particularly true in people who are already obese. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the new study, researchers tested how sucralose reacted in human stem cells that can change into fat, muscle, bone, or cartilage cells.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Scientists placed sucralose-saturated cells in petri dishes with substances that promote fat production.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After 12 days, the cells — which held the amount of artificial sweetener equal to about four cans of soda — showed an increase in fat production from these genes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What researchers discovered&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study’s principal author is Dr. Sabyasachi Sen, an associate professor of medicine and endocrinology at George Washington University in Washington, D.C.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Once the results from the petri dish were tallied, Sen and his researchers conducted further assessments.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They analyzed samples of abdominal fat from eight people who said they consumed artificial sweeteners, mostly sucralose, traces of aspartame, or acesulfame potassium. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Half of the samples came from people who were at a healthy weight while the other half came from people considered obese.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to Sen, researchers saw evidence of increased glucose in abdomen fat cells and ramped up fat-producing genes in those who were obese.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other people who didn’t consume artificial sweeteners didn’t produce the same results.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The report also revealed that people who consumed low-calorie sweeteners — which can be seven times sweeter than regular sugar — showed an “overexpression” of sweet taste receptors in their fat cells.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That rate was almost three times higher in people with a history of artificial sweetener consumption than compared with people who didn’t consume the sugar substitute.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Many health-conscious individuals like to consume low-calorie sweeteners as an alternative to sugar. However, there is increasing scientific evidence that these sweeteners promote metabolic dysfunction,” Sen said in a press release.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The findings appear to run contrary to what many Americans believe, according to Dana Hunnes, PhD, MPH, RD, senior dietitian and adjunct assistant professor in the Fielding School of Public Health at the Ronald Reagan University of California Los Angeles (UCLA) Medical Center.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Consuming artificial sweeteners in place of real sugar can help some people lose weight, but it may have a hidden downside.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I don’t think we really yet know the extent of what artificial sweeteners are doing to our bodies,” Hunnes told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Popularity of artificial sweeteners&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;More Americans are using artificial sweeteners than ever before.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A study published earlier this year revealed that artificial sugar consumption among adults is up by &lt;a href=&quot;http://thatsugarfilm.com/blog/2017/01/29/artificial-sweetener-consumption-is-on-the-rise/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;54 percent&lt;/a&gt;. In children, it’s up by &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/children-consuming-more-artificial-sweeteners#1&quot;&gt;200 percent&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Health experts say the reason is because artificial sweeteners can be found in products that line grocery store aisles — from beverages, to popcorn, and even English muffins.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Food labels that use the words “light” or “reduced sugar” often carry some type of artificial sweeteners.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s everywhere,” Hunnes said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are currently about seven types of artificial sweeteners on the market.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sucralose is considered one of the most popular. When the product was first introduced, it was marketed as a safe alternative, according to Hunnes, because it’s made from sugar. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In recent years, food companies have added artificial sweeteners to their products as a way to provide low-calorie foods without sacrificing taste. And people are gobbling it up, according to Hunnes, because “people think it’s safe.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What latest research indicates&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sen’s research, although utilizing a small sample size, is telling, according to Hunnes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It supports the hypothesis that increased consumption of artificial sweeteners may lead to weight gain and diabetes, as other studies have pointed out.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23364017&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2013 study&lt;/a&gt; showed an increased risk in type 2 diabetes in people who consume diet beverages that had artificial sweeteners in their ingredients’ lists.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, further experiments are needed, Hunnes added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Specifically, she’d like to see a randomized controlled trial, that’s also longitudinal, be conducted. Only then will scientists — and ultimately consumers — know the true facts about artificial sweeteners.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There’s a disconnect between what people believe vs. what science may actually be discovering,” she said. “They are replacing all this sugar with false sweetness and not doing themselves any favors.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Until that happens, it’s still too soon to tell if artificial sweeteners will follow the same trajectory as margarine, she said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For years, consumers were told that margarine was a safe and healthy alternative to butter because it didn’t contain saturated fats.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But then &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.health.harvard.edu/nutrition/butter-vs-margarine&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;scientists discovered&lt;/a&gt; that the types of trans fats found in margarine were worse than saturated fats in terms of causing heart disease.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-04-11T15:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-11T15:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/sweeteners-encourage-fat-production
</guid>
<dc:creator>Carolyn Abate</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-11T22:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Fresh Fruit Beneficial for People with Diabetes, Researchers Say
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/fresh-fruit-beneficial-for-diabetes
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/Diabetes/041117_fruitdiabetes_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Does an apple a day keep the doctor away — even for people with diabetes?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A new &lt;a href=&quot;http://journals.plos.org/plosmedicine/article?id=10.1371/journal.pmed.1002279&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; published today in PLOS Medicine concludes that not only does fresh fruit help prevent diabetes, it also lowers risk of death and vascular complications for those already living with the disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This is the first large prospective study demonstrating similar inverse associations of fruit consumption with both incident diabetes and diabetic complications,” the study authors wrote.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Half-million people studied&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Between June 2004 and July 2008, researchers recruited half a million adults aged 30 to 79 throughout different regions of China to take part.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Participants answered questionnaires and had their health monitored over the four-year period, allowing researchers to investigate links between diet and health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Among individuals who were free of diabetes at the start of the study,” the researchers wrote, “daily consumption of fresh fruit was associated with a 12 percent lower relative risk of developing diabetes.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For those diagnosed with diabetes before the start of the study, eating fresh fruit more than three days a week produced a 17 percent lower risk of death from any cause.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The diet also produced a 13 to 28 percent decrease in risk of developing major complications from the disease such as heart disease and stroke, compared with individuals who didn’t consume as much fresh fruit.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The sugar content in fruit&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sugar content in fruit can be high.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For example, a cup of figs can have up to &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.womenshealthmag.com/food/high-low-sugar-fruits/slide/4&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;27 grams of sugar&lt;/a&gt;, while a cup of grapes can have 16 grams.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Therefore, medical opinion on fruit and diabetes has been mixed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study authors point out that previous medical literature shows contradictory conclusions. One study concluded that “higher fruit consumption was significantly associated with diabetes incidence.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A separate European study concluded that there was no association between the two.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Finally, a recent meta-analysis of the issue said that higher fruit consumption was actually associated with a lower risk of diabetes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Different definitions of fruit&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;It can be perplexing, but there are reasons for the confusion.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Diets vary across the globe. That means the role — and even the definition — of fruit can change from place to place.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The authors note that many earlier studies were primarily conducted with Western populations, where fresh fruit consumption was often combined with processed fruit (think canned peaches).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Processed fruit can also include fruit juices, which have been shown to be a risk factor for diabetes. In fact, because of its sugar content — which is comparable to soda pop — even “100 percent” fruit juice is linked to &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cnn.com/2017/03/23/health/fruit-juice-weight-gain-kids-study/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;weight gain and obesity&lt;/a&gt;, especially in children.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another study, &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.theguardian.com/science/2013/aug/29/whole-fruit-juice-diabetes-risk&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;reported by The Guardian&lt;/a&gt; in 2013, said that individuals who replaced fruit juice with fresh fruit were able to significantly lower their risk of diabetes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Current &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.choosemyplate.gov/fruit&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;USDA guidelines&lt;/a&gt; recommend 1.5 to 2 cups of fruit per day for adult men and women in the United States. However, the recommendations do not specifically say “fresh fruit” — fruit juices, dried fruit, and processed fruits can also be included.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Important distinction&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nutritionist Kristin Kirkpatrick told Healthline that the difference between fresh fruit and refined sugars comes down to one important thing: fiber.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When eating fresh fruit, sugar is attached to fiber and, “that makes a big difference in how aggressive the body responds to the carbohydrate.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Under USDA guidelines, a cup of juice is equivalent to a cup of fresh fruit.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In healthy individuals that may be OK, but for people at risk for diabetes and obesity, comparing the two is like comparing apples and oranges.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The American Diabetes Association (ADA) has its own guidelines for fruit consumption, separate from the USDA. When contacted by Healthline, ADA officials pointed to the &lt;a href=&quot;http://professional.diabetes.org/sites/professional.diabetes.org/files/media/dc_40_s1_final.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2017 version&lt;/a&gt; of their publication Standards of Medical Care In Diabetes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“As for all Americans, individuals with diabetes should be encouraged to replace refined carbohydrates and added sugars with whole grains, legumes, vegetables, and fruits,” the association wrote.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, the ADA also does not make a significant distinction between the consumption of fresh and processed fruit as long as the final product doesn’t contain too much extra sugar.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On its &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.diabetes.org/food-and-fitness/food/what-can-i-eat/making-healthy-food-choices/fruits.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;website&lt;/a&gt;, fresh, frozen, and canned fruit are in the same category, and even fruits in “light syrup,” are included.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Diabetes</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-11T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-11T12:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/fresh-fruit-beneficial-for-diabetes
</guid>
<dc:creator>Gigen Mammoser</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-11T19:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Why Doesn’t the United States Have Universal Healthcare?
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/why-doesnt-the-us-have-universal-healthcare
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/041017_universalhealth_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p
]]>
<![CDATA[
&gt;&lt;p&gt;When you pay top dollar for a good or a service, it’s reasonable to expect the best. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The United States spends more per capita on healthcare than any other country in the world, amounting to more than &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cms.gov/research-statistics-data-and-systems/statistics-trends-and-reports/nationalhealthexpenddata/nhe-fact-sheet.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;$3 trillion&lt;/a&gt;, or about one-sixth of the country’s economy.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But despite the high price tag, the United States is still the only wealthy, developed nation without universal health coverage. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Now, as congressional Republicans &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/conservatives-outside-congress-say-latest-health-care-reform-push-has-foundered/2017/04/05/01435d36-1a11-11e7-855e-4824bbb5d748_story.html?utm_term=.8e23dd618f79&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;remain divided&lt;/a&gt; over healthcare reform, the issue of universal health coverage is getting renewed attention on both sides of the political spectrum.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., has repeated calls for a &lt;a href=&quot;https://berniesanders.com/medicareforall/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Medicare for All&lt;/a&gt; program that would provide health coverage for people of all ages, while gradually replacing the for-profit insurance industry. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If every major country on Earth guarantees healthcare to all people, and costs a fraction per capita of what we spend, don’t tell me that in the United States of America, we cannot do that,” Sanders said at a Boston rally in March.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sanders has put forward similar proposals before, in the Senate and as a nominee for Democratic Party leadership. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;More surprising are the prominent conservative voices advocating for some form of universal coverage.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In an &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.newsmax.com/ChristopherRuddy/trump-healthcare-health-paul-ryan/2017/03/14/id/778568/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;op-ed&lt;/a&gt; last month, Christopher Ruddy, chief executive officer of the conservative site Newsmax, and an ally of President Donald Trump, called for “an upgraded Medicaid system to become the country’s blanket insurer for the uninsured.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A few days later, conservative writer Ross Douthat devoted his New York Times&lt;em&gt; &lt;/em&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/18/opinion/sunday/make-america-singapore.html?rref=collection%2Fcolumn%2Fross-douthat&amp;amp;action=click&amp;amp;contentCollection=opinion&amp;amp;region=stream&amp;amp;module=stream_unit&amp;amp;version=latest&amp;amp;contentPlacement=1&amp;amp;pgtype=collection&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;column&lt;/a&gt; to pondering how to make U.S. healthcare more like Singapore’s low-cost universal system, though he thinks it’s implausible.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While Republicans continue to disagree over plans for health reform, discussion about the possibility of a universal system for the United States may grow. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The political divide&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Since the Affordable Care Act (ACA) — commonly known as Obamacare — was enacted, Republicans have vowed to repeal it, but last month the party was too divided to move forward with a House vote on their replacement bill.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That bill, the American Health Care Act (AHCA) — sometimes called Ryancare or Trumpcare —would have repealed major parts of the ACA, including the individual mandate that requires people who don’t buy insurance to pay a fine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It also would have phased out the ACA’s expansion of Medicaid and allowed insurers to charge older adults higher premiums than younger people.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cbo.gov/publication/52486&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;report&lt;/a&gt; from the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, the bill would have left 24 million Americans uninsured within the next decade. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The main disagreement that stalled the bill was between the GOP’s far-right conservatives, who want to get rid of as much of the ACA as possible, and moderate Republicans, who want to ensure their constituents don’t lose health insurance.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I believe this bill, in its current form, will lead to the loss of coverage and make insurance unaffordable for too many Americans, particularly for low-to-moderate income and older individuals,” said Rep. Charlie Dent, R-Pa., co-chair of a moderate Republican caucus called the Tuesday Group, in a &lt;a href=&quot;http://dent.house.gov/index.cfm?p=PressReleases&amp;amp;ContentRecord_id=C5448A50-4F80-4998-9416-62D80686F256&amp;amp;ContentType_id=C6EC3657-DC1E-476F-8D55-369892A8B74D&amp;amp;Group_id=7a83093f-b0df-4c08-affb-9f5cf4ef7c2a&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;statement&lt;/a&gt;.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Political blog FiveThirtyEight’s &lt;a href=&quot;https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-gops-new-health-care-plan-is-doomed-without-moderate-republicans/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;analysis&lt;/a&gt; showed that it would be impossible for the Trump administration to get enough votes for the bill to pass the House without support from moderate Republicans. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Four Republican senators also sent a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.gardner.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/gop-senators-say-house-health-care-draft-lacks-key-protections-for-medicaid-expansion-population&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;letter&lt;/a&gt; to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., indicating they would not support the plan to phase out the ACA’s Medicaid expansion because “reform should not come at the cost of disruption in access to healthcare for our country’s most vulnerable and sickest individuals.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s those types of statements that fuel speculation — in &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/28/opinion/republicans-for-single-payer-health-care.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;The New York Times&lt;/a&gt;, for example —that the Trump administration might have more success in reforming healthcare by embracing a universal system that covers everyone. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What is universal healthcare? &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The terms “universal” and “single-payer” are sometimes confused when it comes to healthcare — but they are not the same thing. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Universal health coverage is a broad term meaning that everyone has “access to good quality health services without suffering financial hardship,” according to the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.oecd.org/els/health-systems/universal-health-coverage.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are at least two major types of universal health coverage, explained William Hsiao, PhD, a health economist at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health who has designed universal healthcare systems in Taiwan, Sweden, and Malaysia, among others.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One is the “National Health Service” model, used in the United Kingdom. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It is a single-payer system because it is tax-funded and most healthcare is provided by the government through public hospitals and clinics. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the United States, the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs operates in a similar way.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The other type is the “National Health Insurance” model, in which the government mandates that everyone have health insurance, but services are delivered by a mix of public, nonprofit, and for-profit providers. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Within this second model, a range of different systems exists worldwide — some are single-payer, but others are multi-payer. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Canada’s healthcare system and the U.S. Medicare system are single-payer. Everyone is required to pay into a government insurance plan, which in turn pays doctors and hospitals.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Multi-payer systems operate differently. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In Switzerland, for example, residents &lt;a href=&quot;http://international.commonwealthfund.org/countries/switzerland/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;must buy insurance&lt;/a&gt; from competing nonprofit insurers, and the government subsidizes premiums, while also subsidizing doctors and hospitals. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;France, often considered to have the best healthcare system in the world, &lt;a href=&quot;http://international.commonwealthfund.org/countries/france/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;requires residents&lt;/a&gt; to enroll in government-funded insurance, but allows for private complementary insurance, too. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Though different, the United Kingdom, Canadian, Swiss, and French systems are all considered universal.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And in each country, the government &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.commonwealthfund.org/publications/issue-briefs/2015/oct/us-health-care-from-a-global-perspective&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;spends less per capita&lt;/a&gt; on healthcare than the U.S. government spends. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In fact, the U.S. government spends more per capita on healthcare than any other government except Norway and the Netherlands. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But high spending doesn’t translate into better health outcomes in the United States. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Compared with other wealthy countries, the United States has lower life expectancy, a higher infant mortality rate, and significant rates of chronic disease, according to a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.commonwealthfund.org/publications/issue-briefs/2015/oct/us-health-care-from-a-global-perspective&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2015 report&lt;/a&gt; from the Commonwealth Fund.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Around the world, I tell other countries, you can learn from America’s health system by understanding what not to do,” Hsiao told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Why U.S. healthcare stands out&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In order for a universal system to work, Hsiao said the government must require that everyone participate. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The ACA’s individual mandate is meant to keep the health insurance market financially sound by pushing healthy people to buy insurance — but it is one of Republicans’ most disliked aspects of the law. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hsiao thinks the reason the United States doesn’t have a universal system is that Americans place such a high value on individual liberty. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If you believe individual liberty is most important, it means that everyone can make their own choice, to choose what insurance they have or not,” Hsiao said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s also a matter of history. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The United States developed an extensive private health system at a time when other countries lagged behind, according to Gerald Friedman, PhD, a health economist at University of Massachusetts at Amherst, who supports the single-payer movement. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After World War II, it was straightforward for other countries to move from minimal coverage to universal programs because they had few private interests to contend with. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Americans, on the other hand, had a vested interest in their private system. Employers and employees wanted to keep insurance as a tax-free job perk, while healthcare providers wanted to protect their income.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Those private interests are part of the reason U.S. healthcare is so expensive. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For years, Friedman tried to convince people that a single-payer system would save the country money.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Then I realized every dollar I talked about saving is a dollar of somebody’s income,” he told Healthline. “It may be a health insurer, it may be a drug company, it may be a hospital.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In countries where health insurance is government-run or nonprofit-run, there is no profit factor to drive up prices. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A Commonwealth Fund &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.commonwealthfund.org/publications/press-releases/2015/oct/us-spends-more-on-health-care-than-other-nations&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;report&lt;/a&gt; found that high healthcare spending in the United States was mostly driven by greater use of technology and higher healthcare prices.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For example, a typical bypass surgery in the Netherlands costs about $15,000 while in the United States it costs about $75,000. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Prescription drugs are also pricier in the United States — sometimes &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2015-drug-prices/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;more than double&lt;/a&gt; what other countries pay.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s at least in part because other governments evaluate drugs for cost-effectiveness and &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.businessinsider.com/why-the-us-pays-more-for-prescription-drugs-2016-8&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;set prices&lt;/a&gt;, but the U.S. government doesn’t. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The government agency that runs Medicare is actually &lt;a href=&quot;http://kff.org/medicare/issue-brief/searching-for-savings-in-medicare-drug-price-negotiations/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;prohibited&lt;/a&gt; from negotiating drug prices. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another factor driving up U.S. healthcare costs are administrative expenses, since a system with many different insurance companies creates complex billing arrangements. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://content.healthaffairs.org/content/33/9/1586.abstract&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; in the journal Health Affairs&lt;em&gt; &lt;/em&gt;found that those types of expenses made up more than 25 percent of total U.S. hospital expenditures. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s about double the rate of administrative expenses in Canada and Scotland, which both have universal, single-payer systems. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If the United States reduced those expenses, the study authors estimate it would save more than $150 billion per year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Conservative approaches &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The conservatives who have spoken in favor of universal healthcare — still a minority among right-wing thinkers — tend to prefer multi-payer systems.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ruddy’s plan, for example, would include private insurance markets, in addition to bolstering Medicaid and Medicare. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another multi-payer model discussed by conservatives is Singapore’s healthcare system. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The country has a unique &lt;a href=&quot;http://international.commonwealthfund.org/countries/singapore/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;program&lt;/a&gt; that requires citizens to pay into personal accounts — with matching employer contributions — that are used to cover care as part of a subsidized national health insurance scheme. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Avik Roy, Forbes opinion editor and founder of conservative think tank FREOPP, based his &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/368772/conservative-case-universal-coverage-avik-roy&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;ACA replacement plan&lt;/a&gt; on the Singapore and Swiss models.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a Washington Examiner &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/a-conservative-case-for-universal-health-care-coverage/article/2542091&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;op-ed&lt;/a&gt;, Roy wrote, “Singapore and Switzerland spend far less on healthcare than we do and yet achieve all of the things that Americans value about their own system: choice, technology, and physician access.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Critics &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.slate.com/blogs/moneybox/2013/10/23/singapore_health_care_what_do_conservatives_like_about_it.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;point out&lt;/a&gt; that both systems are heavily regulated and government subsidized — aspects that traditional conservatives would resist. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Roy said he’s been arguing for at least five years that conservatives should embrace the cause of universal coverage. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The perception on the right is that universal coverage costs too much and it would require more government intervention in the healthcare system,” Roy told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He disagrees.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Because the cost of our system is so high, if you have a lower cost system, you could actually cover everyone and spend less money,” Roy said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Roy generally opposes single-payer models, but that’s not true of all conservatives. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;F.H. Buckley, a professor at Antonin Scalia Law School at George Mason University, and a Trump supporter, recently called on the president to support a single-payer system, noting that he promised his plan would leave no one uninsured. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The simplest way to do this is universal healthcare, on the Canadian model, with a right of individuals to purchase a Cadillac plan on top of this out-of-pocket,” Buckley &lt;a href=&quot;http://nypost.com/2017/03/30/why-trump-should-embrace-single-payer-health-care/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;wrote&lt;/a&gt; in the New York Post&lt;em&gt;.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Medicare for all &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Though it’s highly unlikely, if Trump did want to support a single-payer plan, there is one in the works. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sanders said he would introduce a bill to create a single-payer system within weeks. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Several progressive groups, including the Working Families Party, Social Security Works, and National Nurses United have endorsed the move. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our job is not just to prevent the repeal of the Affordable Care Act,” Sanders told crowds at the Boston rally. “Our job is to join the rest of the industrialized world, [and] guarantee healthcare to all people as a right.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;An estimated &lt;a href=&quot;http://kff.org/uninsured/fact-sheet/key-facts-about-the-uninsured-population/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;28 million&lt;/a&gt; people in America still don’t have health insurance, despite the ACA. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Supporters say the Medicare for All plan would cut U.S. healthcare costs dramatically and provide universal coverage. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“A single-payer system would provide enormous efficiencies in administrative costs and in drug savings. Those savings could be used to provide healthcare for everyone without breaking the bank,” said Dr. Adam Gaffney, a board member of the advocacy group Physicians for a National Health Program (PNHP).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Friedman estimates the Medicare for All plan would save the U.S. economy about $200 billion per year, while expanding access to healthcare services. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If we paid prices for drugs like Europeans and Canadians do, then we would save $100 billion right away,” he added. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Critics of the plan argue that it would lead to higher taxes and increase federal spending, with no guarantee it would rein in costs. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But single-payer advocates insist there would be overall savings.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“For many people, you will see good benefit in paying for healthcare through a tax instead of a premium,” Gaffney said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hsiao and Friedman told Healthline that people generally don’t understand the true costs they already pay for health coverage.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Your employer gives you a total compensation package,” Hsiao explained. “The health insurance premium paid by the employer squeezes down our cash compensation.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Friedman said that a single-payer system would benefit business because the current burden of health insurance raises U.S. labor costs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s one factor leading companies to leave the country or to import stuff from other countries, rather than hiring Americans to do it,” he added. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-bill/676/cosponsors&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Medicare for All&lt;/a&gt; bill was already put forward by Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., in the House, in January.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The bill has virtually no chance of passing and hasn’t even received support from a majority of House Democrats, though Conyers &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/RepJohnConyers/status/850088162386993152?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Etweet&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;tweeted&lt;/a&gt; that it has “record-breaking” support compared to previous versions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Rep. Steve Cohen, D-Tenn., one of the bill’s co-sponsors, told Healthline he supports the legislation because he represents a low-income constituency in Memphis that would benefit from it. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said that under the AHCA, Memphis would have been among the hardest hit cities for loss of benefits. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If an idea has merit, it’s worth supporting,” Cohen said. “Most new ideas and good ideas take a while to percolate. And if you believe it’s a good idea, you should support it regardless of the political climate.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The high stakes of health reform &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Vicki Tosher, a 64-year-old editor from Colorado, told Healthline she’s “been counting down the days” until her 65th birthday, when she will qualify for Medicare. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A three-time breast cancer survivor, she knows too well the financial stress that can accompany a serious illness. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2003, after her second breast cancer diagnosis, Tosher said her medical expenses hit an all-time high, at more than $20,000 for the year. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Then in 2009, she lost her job, followed by her employer-backed health insurance, and learned that none of the private health insurers in Colorado would cover her because of her previous breast cancer diagnoses.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The risk of recurrence was just too high,” she told Healthline. “I was uninsurable.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Tosher eventually found high-risk coverage through a state program and switched to a cheaper ACA plan when Colorado’s insurance marketplace opened. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Last year, Tosher faced another breast cancer diagnosis, and even with an ACA subsidy, she said the financial hardship is significant. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I plan my budget around making sure I have enough money to pay my medical bills,” she said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But she knows others who face greater difficulties.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Tosher helped found the Colorado nonprofit &lt;a href=&quot;http://senseofsecurity.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Sense of Security&lt;/a&gt;, which provides grants to people with breast cancer who are struggling financially.&lt;strong&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We try to allow them to focus on treatment and healing rather than worrying about whether or not they’re going to be able to feed their families or lose their homes,” she said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s people like Tosher and those she’s helped who are at the heart of why health reform causes contentious and emotional debate. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;No politician wants to be responsible for someone with cancer losing their health insurance or home.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Tosher was relieved when Republicans withdrew their ACA replacement bill because she felt the fringes on both sides of the issue would not cooperate to create a workable plan.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The biggest sense of relief I have is that people are going to have to start talking to one another,” she added.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<dc:creator>Jenna Flannigan</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-11T17:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>Gene Therapy May Help Those with Hearing Loss</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/gene-therapy-may-help-with-hearing-loss
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/tech/041017_hearingrestoration_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Researchers may have brought us one step closer to gene therapy for the treatment of hearing loss, after discovering a way to regenerate auditory hair cells in mice.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It is estimated that about &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nidcd.nih.gov/health/statistics/quick-statistics-hearing&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;15 percent&lt;/a&gt; of adults in the United States have some form of hearing loss, with men being twice as likely to develop the condition than women.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Damage to the auditory hair cells is one of the leading causes of hearing loss.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Aging is a common risk factor for such damage, although the ailment can also arise through prolonged exposure to loud noise, injury (such as head trauma), ear infections, and other illnesses and diseases.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Auditory hair cells are the tiny sensory cells of the cochlea – the inner part of the ear – that enable us to hear.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These cells consist of hair-like projections, called stereocilia, that are responsible for transforming sound vibrations into electrical signals that are sent to the brain.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In humans, auditory hair cells are unable to regenerate in order to replace damaged ones. In fish and birds, however, these cells can regenerate. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The process involves down-regulating expression of the protein p27 and up-regulating the expression of the protein ATOH1,” notes study co-author Jian Zuo, Ph.D., of the Department of Developmental Neurobiology at St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital in San Francisco.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For their study – &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cell.com/cell-reports/fulltext/S2211-1247(17)30390-X&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;published&lt;/a&gt; today in the journal Cell Reports – Zuo and team set out to determine whether they could trigger the same process in mice.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Using genetic manipulation&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Using genetic manipulation, the researchers deleted the p27 protein and increased ATOH1 expression in mice.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When the mice experienced auditory hair cell damage as a result of exposure to loud noise, the researchers found that the cells supporting the auditory hair cells began to transform into auditory hair cells themselves.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Further investigation revealed that a number of proteins work together in order to regenerate auditory hair cells. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers found that the deletion of p27 increased levels of a protein called GATA3 and boosted the expression of the POU4F3 protein. This increased ATOH1 expression, leading to auditory hair cell regeneration in the rodents.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers explain that ATOH1 is a transcription factor required for the development of auditory hair cells. In humans, the production of ATOH1 stops in the womb.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to Zuo and colleagues, however, their findings suggest that it may be possible to reactivate ATOH1 production in humans by genetically manipulating the p27, GATA3, and POU4F3 proteins.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Work in other organs has shown that reprogramming cells is rarely accomplished by manipulating a single factor,&quot; said Zuo. &quot;This study suggests that supporting cells in the cochlea are no exception and may benefit from therapies that target the proteins identified in this study.&quot;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers said the findings have implications for a phase I clinical trial that is already under way elsewhere using gene therapy to reinstate ATOH1 production in humans. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The aim is to determine whether such a strategy can trigger auditory hair cell regeneration in humans, and whether this might be an effective treatment for hearing loss.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&quot;Work continues to identify the other factors, including small molecules, necessary to not only promote the maturation and survival of the newly generated hair cells, but also increase their number,&quot; said Zuo.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Technology</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-11T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-11T10:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/gene-therapy-may-help-with-hearing-loss
</guid>
<dc:creator>Honor Whiteman</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-11T17:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Is Too Much Homework Bad for Kids' Health?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/children-more-homework-means-more-stress-031114
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/childrens-health/081216_homework_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;From kindergarten to the final years of high school, recent research suggests that some students are getting excessive amounts of homework.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In turn, when students are pushed to handle a workload that’s out of sync with their development level, it can lead to significant stress — for children and their parents.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Both the National Education Association (NEA) and the National PTA (NPTA) support a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nea.org/tools/16938.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;standard&lt;/a&gt; of “10 minutes of homework per grade level” and setting a general limit on after-school studying.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For kids in first grade, that means 10 minutes a night, while high school seniors could get two hours of work per night.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But the most recent study to examine the issue found that kids in early elementary school received about three times the amount of recommended homework. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Published in The American Journal of Family Therapy, the 2015 &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01926187.2015.1061407&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; surveyed more than 1,100 parents in Rhode Island with school-age children. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers found that first and second graders received 28 and 29 minutes of homework per night. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kindergarteners received 25 minutes of homework per night, on average. But according to the standards set by the NEA and NPTA, they shouldn’t receive any at all.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A contributing editor of the study, Stephanie Donaldson-Pressman, told &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cnn.com/2015/08/12/health/homework-elementary-school-study/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;CNN&lt;/a&gt; that she found it “absolutely shocking” to learn that kindergarteners had that much homework. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And all those extra assignments may lead to family stress, especially when parents with limited education aren’t confident in their ability to help kids with the work. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers reported that family fights about homework were 200 percent more likely when parents didn’t have a college degree.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Some parents, in fact, have decided to opt out of the whole thing. The Washington Post &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/parenting/wp/2016/08/26/too-much-homework-some-parents-are-just-saying-no/?utm_term=.942c843a12dc&quot;&gt;reported&lt;/a&gt; in 2016 that some parents have just instructed their younger children not to do their homework assignments.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;They report the no-homework policy has taken the stress out of their afternoons and evenings. In addition, it's been easier for their children to participate in after-school activities.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This new parental directive may be healthier for children, too.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Experts say there may be real downsides for young kids who are pushed to do more homework than the “10 minutes per grade” standard. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The data shows that homework over this level is not only not beneficial to children’s grades or GPA, but there’s really a plethora of evidence that it’s detrimental to their attitude about school, their grades, their self-confidence, their social skills, and their quality of life,” Donaldson-Pressman told &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cnn.com/2015/08/12/health/homework-elementary-school-study/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;CNN&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Consequences for high school students &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other studies have found that high school students may also be overburdened with homework — so much that it’s taking a toll on their health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2013, research conducted at Stanford University found that students in high-achieving communities who spend too much time on homework experience more stress, physical health problems, a lack of balance in their lives, and alienation from society.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That study, published in &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/00220973.2012.745469&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;The Journal of Experimental Education&lt;/a&gt;, suggested that any more than two hours of homework per night is counterproductive.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, students who participated in the study reported doing slightly more than three hours of homework each night, on average. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To conduct the study, researchers surveyed more than 4,300 students at 10 high-performing high schools in upper middle-class California communities. They also interviewed students about their views on homework.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When it came to stress, more than 70 percent of students said they were “often or always stressed over schoolwork,” with 56 percent listing homework as a primary stressor. Less than 1 percent of the students said homework was not a stressor.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers asked students whether they experienced physical symptoms of stress, such as headaches, exhaustion, sleep deprivation, weight loss, and stomach problems.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;More than 80 percent of students reported having at least one stress-related symptom in the past month, and 44 percent said they had experienced three or more symptoms. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers also found that spending too much time on homework meant that students were not meeting their developmental needs or cultivating other critical life skills. Students were more likely to forgo activities, stop seeing friends or family, and not participate in hobbies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Many students felt forced or obligated to choose homework over developing other talents or skills.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&quot;Our findings on the effects of homework challenge the traditional assumption that homework is inherently good,&quot; said Denise Pope, Ph.D., a senior lecturer at the Stanford University School of Education, and a co-author of a study. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Working as hard as adults &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;A smaller New York University &lt;a href=&quot;http://journal.frontiersin.org/article/10.3389/fpsyg.2015.01028/full&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; published last year noted similar findings.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It focused more broadly on how students at elite private high schools cope with the combined pressures of school work, college applications, extracurricular activities, and parents’ expectations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That study, which appeared in Frontiers in Psychology, noted serious health effects for high schoolers, such as chronic stress, emotional exhaustion, and alcohol and drug use.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The research involved a series of interviews with students, teachers, and administrators, as well as a survey of a total of 128 juniors from two private high schools.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;About half of the students said they received at least three hours of homework per night. They also faced pressure to take college-level classes and excel in activities outside of school. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Many students felt they were being asked to work as hard as adults, and noted that their workload seemed inappropriate for their development level. They reported having little time for relaxing or creative activities.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;More than two-thirds of students said they used alcohol and drugs, primarily marijuana, to cope with stress.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers expressed concern that students at high-pressure high schools can get burned out before they even get to college. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“School, homework, extracurricular activities, sleep, repeat — that’s what it can be for some of these students,” said Noelle Leonard, Ph.D., a senior research scientist at the New York University College of Nursing, and lead study author, in a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nyu.edu/about/news-publications/news/2015/08/11/nyu-study-examines-top-high-school-students-stress-and-coping-mechanisms.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;press release&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What can be done? &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Experts continue to debate the benefits and drawbacks of homework.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But according to an article published this year in &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.apa.org/monitor/2016/03/homework.aspx&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Monitor on Psychology&lt;/a&gt;, there’s one thing they agree on: the quality of homework assignments matters. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the Stanford study, many students said that they often did homework they saw as &quot;pointless&quot; or &quot;mindless.&quot; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Pope, who co-authored that study, argued that homework assignments should have a purpose and benefit, and should be designed to cultivate learning and development.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s also important for schools and teachers to stick to the 10-minutes per grade standard. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In an interview with Monitor on Psychology, Pope pointed out that students can learn challenging skills even when less homework is assigned. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Pope described one teacher she worked with who taught advanced placement biology, and experimented by dramatically cutting down homework assignments. First the teacher cut homework by a third, and then cut the assignments in half. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The students’ test scores didn’t change.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“You can have a rigorous course and not have a crazy homework load,” Pope said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Editor’s Note: The story was originally published on March 11, 2014. It was updated by Jenna Flannigan on August 11, 2016 and then updated again on April 11, 2017 by David Mills.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<category>Mental Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-11T00:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-11T00:00:00</updateddate>

<dc:creator>Sandra Levy</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-11T07:00:00</dc:date>
