<item>
<title>
Most Doctors in Survey Recommend Mammograms at Age 40
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/doctors-recommend-mammograms-at-40
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/041017_mammogram_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;If a woman seeks out advice on mammograms from various health organizations, she’ll get a variety of recommendations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, if she asks her doctor, she’s more than likely to be told to begin annual screenings for breast cancer at the age of 40.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s what a &lt;a href=&quot;http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamainternalmedicine/article-abstract/2617273&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;survey&lt;/a&gt; of physicians from across the nation reveals.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It was published today in the Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;More than 80 percent of doctors who participated said they feel women should start getting regular mammograms when they turn 40.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The results provide an important benchmark as guidelines continue evolving and underscore the need to delineate barriers and facilitators to implementing guidelines in clinical practical,” the study authors wrote.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Differing opinions&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The new survey is the latest salvo in the argument over how early women should start getting mammograms.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2015, the American Cancer Society changed its &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cancer.org/healthy/find-cancer-early/cancer-screening-guidelines/american-cancer-society-guidelines-for-the-early-detection-of-cancer.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;guidelines&lt;/a&gt;, saying women between the ages of 40 and 44 should consult with their doctors about the screenings. From ages 45 to 54, the organization recommends annual mammograms and then exams every two years for women 55 and up.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2016, the U.S. Preventative Services Task Force revised its &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.uspreventiveservicestaskforce.org/Page/Document/RecommendationStatementFinal/breast-cancer-screening1&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;guidelines&lt;/a&gt;. The group now recommends that women under age 50 consult with their doctor. They say women ages 50 to 74 should get screenings every two years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists &lt;a href=&quot;http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/1945498-overview&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;recommends&lt;/a&gt; women over 40 get an annual mammogram.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These guidelines are for women with an average risk of breast cancer. Most organizations don’t recommend mammograms for most women after age 75.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the survey released today, researchers sent out queries to 1,665 physicians. They got responses from 871 of them. About 44 percent were family medicine or general practitioners. Almost 30 percent worked in internal medicine and another 26 percent were gynecologists.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Overall, 81 percent of those responding said they recommended mammograms for women ages 40 to 44. About 88 percent advise women to get the screenings from ages 45 to 49. About 67 percent still recommend them for women 75 years and up.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers said the gynecologists were more likely to recommend annual screenings than those in the internal medicine and general practice fields.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Why the disagreement?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;It may puzzle people why these medical organizations would have differing opinions on mammograms.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Mitva Patel, a breast radiologist at The Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center, says she agrees with annual mammograms beginning at age 40.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The reason is simple.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think the most important aspect is how we can save lives,” Patel told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She said some organizations may take into account the legitimate issues of cost, over-diagnosis, and the anxiety of getting a mammogram or a follow-up test.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But she looks at just what will help detect breast cancer in a woman at an early age. She notes that 1 in 6 breast cancer cases occur in women ages 40 to 49.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She adds the level of radiation in mammograms is minimal and certainly worth the chance breast cancer can be caught at an early stage.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Patel is 42 years old, and says she has had a mammogram each of the past three years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s what I tell my mom to do and it’s what I do,” she said.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<category>Women's Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-10T16:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-10T16:00:00</updateddate>

<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-10T23:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Beauty of Cosmetics: Combining Anti-Aging and Natural Ingredients
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/anti-aging-cosmetics
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/womens-health/041017_antiaging_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&l
]]>
<![CDATA[
t;p&gt;Skin care and makeup used to be two separate entities.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, technology and nature are working in sync to create beauty products that creators say make skin look better and protect it from aging elements. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Barbara Green, who heads up specialty beauty research and development, as well as clinical research for NeoStrata (the company also makes Exuviance products), told Healthline that anti-aging makeup is formulated to deliver cosmetic anti-aging benefits and pigment coverage.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It often includes SPF protection as well.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Anti-aging makeup commonly targets a specific type of benefit such as pigment evening, reduced appearance of fine lines, smoother texture and/or reduced appearance of pore size,” Green noted.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Superpower ingredients&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Polyhydroxy and bionic acids are “proven powerhouses in anti-aging” that her company is using, Green said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Retinol, peptides, antioxidants, botanical brighteners, stem cell extracts, collagen, and other surface modifiers give the skin instant radiance and smoothing. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other ingredients trending in skin care provide targeted benefits based on a novel mechanism of action, including specific peptides or amino acid compounds.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another area emerging in anti-aging makeup aims to influence the natural microbiome, which is the natural occurrence of bacterial flora that normally populates the skin.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Shoppers will see more products with prebiotics and probiotic lysates entering the market.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There is an increase in customization of skin care and makeup to meet individual needs of consumers by building regimens or enhancing products with boosters,” Green added. “Expect color to become more customizable and to offer extended benefits beyond traditional protection from UV sunlight and anti-aging effects.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Back to nature&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Leah Kirpalani, a certified holistic health coach, clean beauty expert, and founder of the online beauty hub &lt;a href=&quot;http://good-life.co/about/&quot;&gt;Good Life&lt;/a&gt;, said there are more products that use plant-based ingredients in anti-aging skin care and makeup products. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;“&lt;/strong&gt;This is positive since many of the chemicals found in our beauty products are what’s actually causing the drying and wear-and-tear of our skin in the first place,” she told Healthline. “Many formulas are turning to plants as a potent form of skin replenishment and age-prevention.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Green tea and arnica are ingredients known to decrease skin inflammation, fight free radicals, and rejuvenate cells. Coconut oil, for instance, is showing up in lipsticks and foundations because it provides better hydration while lessening the occurrence of fine lines and wrinkles.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Using products for function to cover fine lines, wrinkles, and blemishes can oftentimes be the culprit of the skin damage in the first place due to its chemical-based ingredients,” Kirpalani said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Skin can be inundated with toxic fragrances, allergens, and synthetic preservatives when people use coverage products. That causes clogged pores and long-term exposure to chemicals in the body. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Luckily, innovative beauty companies are entering the market with a mindfulness about what ingredients they include — focusing on healing vs. drying and harming,” Kirpalani added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;More people are also embracing clean eating, which supports healthy skin and eliminates the need for heavy coverage products.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Christina Daigneault and Amy Galper, who wrote “Plant-Powered Beauty” coming out next year, agreed that nut and seed oils are gaining traction. Tomato seed, pomegranate seed oil, prickly pear seed oil, sea buckthorn oil, red raspberry seed oil, and butters from Brazil like cupuacu and murumuru are emerging ingredients in skin care and makeup.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Vegetable-based butters and oils that are rich in naturally occurring antioxidants are also emerging as more popular ingredients. These include cocoa butter, mango butter, shea butter, and nutrient-rich oils like avocado, pumpkin seed, and black cumin seed, chia, and hemp seed.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Daigneault and Galper say these ingredients are naturally rich in essential fatty acids to support cellular health and strength, and nourish skin so it stays supple and protected.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Essential oils — frankincense, carrot seed, lavender, rose, sandalwood, and helichrysum — promote tissue regeneration and combat inflammation, and consumers may see more of that when combing beauty product labels.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Challenges of beauty and function&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Green said that developing coloring products can be challenging because the anti-aging ingredients have to be able to work with the pigments.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some benefit ingredients have pH or other limitations that complicate the formulation approach for color products, she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While “multi-tasking makeup” or “makeup as skin care” products are becoming staples, Kirpalani said there is a catch to ensuring these products are actually improving skin health.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Watch out for packaging and marketing that claims to be healing or anti-aging,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kirpalani encourages consumers to look for ingredients they can pronounce and plant-derived sources. Avocado oil, grapeseed oil, vitamin E, and neem are skin healers that can also do double duty within lotion and foundation formulas — both healing the skin and providing results-oriented functionality.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“One of the biggest challenges of making functional products is that you don’t want to overload a formula or make an unstable formula,” Helen Knaggs, PhD, vice president of research and development for Nu Skin, told Healthline. “When formulating, you have to find ingredients that work well together and that happily coexist. Also, loading a formula with a lot of key ingredients is not always a good thing and could be too much for an individual’s skin.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As for what’s next in the industry, it will be products that combine antipollution and anti-aging ingredients for long-term benefits and instant aesthetics.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Knaggs predicts more focus on skin care regimens and systems to accentuate the benefits of the makeup. This can include cleansers, cleaning devices, and products that offer multiple advantages.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Expect more long-wear cosmetics to emerge as well, she noted.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It would be wonderful to have products that were easy to apply, looked great right after application, offered protection from pollution, as well as longer term anti-aging benefits. Double duty is already out there. In the future we will see more of a demand for triple duty,” she added.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Women's Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-10T13:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-10T13:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/anti-aging-cosmetics
</guid>
<dc:creator>Kristen Fischer</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-10T20:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Government Officials Taking Action on US Opioid Epidemic
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/government-taking-action-on-us-opioid-epidemic
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/041017_opioidepidemic_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&
]]>
<![CDATA[
gt;&lt;p&gt;In recent weeks, government officials from federal and state levels have once again called for renewed efforts aimed at tackling America’s opioid epidemic.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These measures range from limiting opioid prescriptions to getting more people into addiction treatment programs to investigating the role of pharmaceutical companies in fueling the crisis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2015, opioids caused more than &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/drugoverdose/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;33,000 deaths&lt;/a&gt; in the United States — a new record — according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Prescription opioids — such as &lt;a href=&quot;/drugs/methadone/oral-tablet#Highlights1&quot;&gt;methadone&lt;/a&gt;, OxyContin, and Vicodin — accounted for almost half of opioid overdose deaths. The rest were due to other opioids such as heroin and synthetic fentanyl.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Will government efforts be enough to prevent more people from becoming addicted and help those who already have an opioid use disorder?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Industry’s role in epidemic&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Last month, Sen. Claire McCaskill (D-Missouri) requested internal documents from five top opioid manufacturers about their marketing tactics and what they knew about the possible risks of addiction and abuse related to opioid painkillers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She is also seeking information on whether companies donated to groups that may have been working to block increased regulation of opioids.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s time to look at the manufacturers and find out what they knew about addiction … [and] what marketing practices did they use to push these drugs,” McCaskill said in a conference call on Tuesday, as reported by &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2017/03/28/sen-claire-mccaskill-opens-probe-opioid-drugmakers/99702506/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;USA Today&lt;/a&gt;. “We want to get to the bottom of why all of a sudden opioids have been handed out like candy in this country.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The investigation currently focuses on five companies with the largest sales of opioids: Purdue Pharma, Janssen Pharmaceuticals, Insys Therapeutics, Mylan, and Depomed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the past, Chicago and other localities have sued manufacturers over “&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/ct-pfizer-opioid-marketing-20160705-story.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;deceptive marketing&lt;/a&gt;” of prescription drugs involved in the opioid epidemic — alleging these practices began as far back as the late 1990s.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lawsuits accuse manufacturers of downplaying the addictive nature of opioids, leading to overprescribing of opioid pain medications. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sen. Rob Portman (R-Ohio) also recently pushed for President Donald Trump to discuss with Chinese President, Xi Jinping, China’s role in manufacturing synthetic opioids like &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/rob-portman-trump-china-fentanyl_us_58e53a20e4b0fe4ce087a7da&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;fentanyl&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These drugs are sometimes smuggled into the United States from Canada or Mexico, but they are increasingly shipped directly from China by mail.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Fentanyl is more potent than prescription pain medications and heroin. Over the past year, many states have seen a spike in &lt;a href=&quot;http://abcnews.go.com/US/fentanyl-deaths-spiked-us-sign-slowing/story?id=44554601&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;fentanyl overdose deaths&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Tackling opioid overprescribing&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some states are trying to limit the availability of prescription opioids by enacting new opioid prescribing regulations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In Ohio, a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.dispatch.com/news/20170330/new-rule-limits-narcotic-painkiller-prescriptions-to-seven-days&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;new rule&lt;/a&gt; limits acute pain prescriptions to no more than seven days of opioid pain medications — or five for minors. Currently, doctors can prescribe 30 to 90 days of opioids. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These types of restrictions straddle a line between preventing opioid abuse and tying a doctor’s hands when it comes to treating patients’ pain.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I have a lot of concerns about inappropriate or overprescribing of opioids. However, I also have a lot of concerns about regulating medical practice, particularly at the level of how you manage the pain of a patient,” Dr. Itai Danovitch, chairman and associate professor in the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Neurosciences at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The new Ohio rule will not apply to patients with cancer or those in palliative or hospice care or medication-assisted addiction treatment programs. These exemptions earned the approval of the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2017/03/pain_prescription_limits_set.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Ohio State Medical Association&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;States also use &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.virginia.gov/services/virginia-prescription-monitoring-program/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;prescription monitoring programs&lt;/a&gt; to prevent patients from obtaining opioid pills from multiple doctors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In Virginia, “physicians are required to log into a database to assess whether a patient has previously been prescribed opioids, to minimize the chances of so-called ‘doctor shopping,’” Kevin Doyle, EdD, LPC, LSATP, a professor in the Counselor Education program at Longwood University in Virginia, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These kinds of efforts “may help prevent the problem down the road, but there’s the issue of the people who are currently addicted and need treatment,” said Doyle.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Trump commission to address opioids&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;President Trump is expected to sign an &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.statnews.com/2017/03/28/trump-opioids-executive-order/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;executive order&lt;/a&gt; setting up a commission to address the nation’s growing opioid epidemic.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The panel would identify federal funding that could be used to help people with opioid use disorder. Programs would include long-term support services and medical treatments. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some have hailed the additional focus on the crisis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Trump’s commission is a good thing. It’s never a bad thing to really investigate an issue,” Deni Carise, PhD, chief clinical officer for Recovery Centers of America, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She also pointed out that U.S. Surgeon General, Dr. Vivek Murthy, released a &lt;a href=&quot;https://addiction.surgeongeneral.gov/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;report&lt;/a&gt; in November highlighting the country’s addiction crisis and steps to address it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There’s a lot of guidance that I think we can get from that document that’s already been made by a full commission of experts,” said Carise.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The American Medical Association, which focuses on raising awareness of the opioid crisis among physicians, applauded the creation of the new commission.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some worry that &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/trump-opioid-commission-budget_us_58dc4fd5e4b05eae031d0d10&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;budget cuts proposed by Trump&lt;/a&gt; to the Department of Health and Human Services and the National Institutes of Health (NIH) — along with a reorganization of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) — may work against the commission’s goals. These agencies fund treatment programs and research into improved treatments.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, the Republican’s Affordable Care Act (ACA) replacement — had it passed — would have eliminated addiction treatment coverage for &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2017/03/09/gop-health-care-bill-would-drop-mental-health-coverage-mandate-covering-1-3-million-americans/?utm_term=.b616ffab45d6&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;1.3 million Americans on Medicaid&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This type of coverage was not always available.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The ACA, the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/the-truth-about-exercise-addiction/201703/how-would-trumpcare-affect-mental-health-care&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act&lt;/a&gt;, and other recent legislation required insurance companies to provide mental health coverage — including substance misuse treatment — similar to medical and surgical benefits.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Those are really vital achievements that are absolutely critical to safeguard in the event that there are any changes to our healthcare system,” said Danovitch.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In spite of the improvements in mental health coverage, &lt;a href=&quot;http://archive.samhsa.gov/data/2k14/NSDUH200/sr200-findings-overview-2014.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;89 percent&lt;/a&gt; of Americans who needed treatment for an illegal drug or alcohol problem did not receive treatment in the past year, according to 2013 federal data.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://medcitynews.com/2017/04/insurance-policies-substance-use-disorder-benefits/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;recent study&lt;/a&gt; published by Danovitch and colleagues in the Journal of Psychoactive Drugs also found big differences in the quality of substance abuse benefits offered by California health insurance plans.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Getting more people into treatment means addressing many issues, including access to quality programs, affordability, and insurance coverage. This is especially true for certain segments of the population.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“What’s really been the tough area is your average American with basic health insurance being able to find a place that will take them and be able to bill their insurance for the majority of costs,” said Carise. “That’s the area where we really need to focus as a country.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Addiction</category>
<category>Public Policy</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-10T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-10T12:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/government-taking-action-on-us-opioid-epidemic
</guid>
<dc:creator>Shawn Radcliffe</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-10T19:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>China, US Companies Forming Healthcare Alliances</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/china-us-forming-healthcare-alliances
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/041017_chinahealth_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Three years ago, oncologist and cancer researcher Steven Rosen took a leadership role at City of Hope, the cancer hospital and research institution near Los Angeles.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One of the first things he did was gather his new colleagues together to discuss where the hospital should focus its burgeoning international health focus.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It didn’t take long for everyone to agree where they should concentrate.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s not about excluding others, but we decided to put our energy into a relationship with China,” Rosen told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Since that consensus, Rosen said, the hospital’s 10-person Center for International Medicine has established alliances with several prominent cancer hospitals in China.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These partnerships enable City of Hope to share its quality care practices and training with China.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In return, City of Hope benefits from the breadth of knowledge of Chinese physicians.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The alliances also create jobs and establish friendships between two of the most powerful nations on Earth.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I’ve been to China twice as part of this endeavor, and I have been so impressed with the quality of people I’ve met,” Rosen said. “The people we have recruited in this alliance are humble, bright, and talented. The friendships have evolved quickly.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Second opinions halfway around the world&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The two primary goals of the hospital’s alignment with China, Rosen explained, are to advance global cancer research, therapy, and diagnostics, as well as to make sure individuals in China have access to the best cancer care available in China and the United States.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Among the programs being launched is a “remote second opinion” program for people with blood cancers at Tongji Hospital in Wuhan, the most populous city in the central China province of Hubei. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In this scenario, City of Hope doctors will review diagnoses and provide second opinions to the Tongji Hospital’s doctors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They won’t, however, communicate directly with the patients because the U.S. doctors are not allowed to practice medicine in China.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;City of Hope is also working with a private company in China to oversee cancer care at a new hospital being built in Shenzhen, one of China’s largest cities. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Shenzhen is a relatively young and affluent city,” Ed McCarthy, the City of Hope vice president who runs the Center for International Medicine, told Healthline. “It’s an innovation and knowledge hub, but it doesn’t have strong healthcare institutions. If you’re a patient with cancer in that city, there’s a good chance you will drive somewhere else to be seen. There’s a gap in care there.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Number one goal: Save lives&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;One of the most fruitful endeavors of the initiative so far, City of Hope executives tell Healthline, is the partnership with the Second Affiliated Hospital of Zhejiang University (SAHZU) in Zhejiang, a province in eastern China. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;City of Hope doctors and scientists participate in educational exchanges with SAHZU physicians and scientists.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They also provide additional consultation on the treatment plans of people with cancer being treated at SAHZU.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When Dr. Yuman Fong, City of Hope's chair of surgery, and one of the world's most respected cancer surgeons, &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.prnasia.com/story/137235-0.shtml&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;announced&lt;/a&gt; the partnership with SAHZU, he said the shared knowledge and training between the two hospitals “help save lives.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Rosen added that the decision to reach out to China made sense for many reasons, including the demographics of the hospital’s surrounding neighborhood.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A quarter of the patient population at City of Hope, he said, is of Asian ancestry, mostly from greater China.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A new age in healthcare cooperation?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;While political relations between the two nations may be strained, it’s a different story on the healthcare front, where relations are positive and collaborative.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Rosen said these international partnerships benefit both nations as well as the entire world.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When China and the U.S. are aligned, the planet is safer,” he said. “If China and the U.S. are not aligned, then you have to pray. God knows what will happen. The people of both countries have a spirit that you can embrace, both are clearly focused on benefitting all of humanity in different ways.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Cancer drug companies join forces&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In China, a nation of about &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.worldometers.info/world-population/china-population/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;1.4 billion&lt;/a&gt; people, cancer is the number one cause of death. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;People in China have profoundly unmet needs in healthcare, including lack of access to quality treatments — especially among its poorest citizens. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The government, while pro-science and pro-research, can still sometimes apply excessive restrictions on foreign entry into China’s marketplace.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Drug companies from the United States have found it difficult to get their products into China.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But that’s changing quickly.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Several U.S. biopharmaceutical companies with treatments on the market or in clinical trials have established partnerships in the past few years with Chinese companies to co-develop and sell cancer treatments in China and globally.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And it’s already been a productive and collaborative 2017.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In January, Kite Pharma, the California-based biopharmaceutical company, &lt;a href=&quot;http://ir.kitepharma.com/releasedetail.cfm?releaseid=1007279&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;announced&lt;/a&gt; a joint venture with Shanghai Fosun Pharmaceutical to develop and commercialize Kite’s CAR-T cell immunotherapies for blood cancers in China.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The venture, Fosun Pharma Kite Biotechnology Co., is expected to be a world leader in advancing the CAR-T technology, which harnesses the power of the body’s immune system (T cells) to recognize and kill cancer tumor cells.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In clinical trials, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nature.com/cr/journal/v27/n1/full/cr2016154a.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;CAR-T&lt;/a&gt; is generating headlines for the high percentage of complete responses and durable remissions the treatment is producing in people with lymphoma and leukemia.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Helen Kim, Kite’s executive vice president of business development, told Healthline that for Kite, China represents a “significant future market, given the population and high incidences of certain cancers. Kite is committed to bringing its transformational therapies to patients worldwide.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She added that China is embracing innovative technologies for healthcare, including therapies for unmet needs like cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The Chinese regulators have demonstrated flexibility in requirements to get innovative therapies to market,” Kim said. “Large regional pharmaceutical companies such as Fosun Pharma are actively seeking collaborations to bring technologies to China.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kim cited another recent U.S.-China venture between Fosun and Intuitive Surgical, the Northern California-based global leader in robotic-assisted, minimally invasive surgery.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The collaboration will help the companies develop and sell innovative, robotic-assisted, catheter-based medical devices.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We are pleased to expand our partnership and advance the development of medical tools to enhance the wellbeing of global populations, including those in China that suffer from increased rates of lung cancer,” Chen Qiyu, chairman of Fosun Pharma, said in a &lt;a href=&quot;http://investor.intuitivesurgical.com/mobile.view?c=122359&amp;amp;v=203&amp;amp;d=1&amp;amp;id=2206833&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;statement&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Meeting healthcare needs &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;CASI Pharmaceuticals, the Maryland-based biopharmaceutical company, has adopted China’s unmet medical needs as its primary focus. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The company, which plans to bring several drugs to the Chinese market, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.casipharmaceuticals.com/investor-relations/news/casi-pharmaceuticals-announces-availabilty-of-anti-cancer-drug-zevalin&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;announced&lt;/a&gt; in July 2015 that it had licensed Zevalin, an FDA-approved, radio-immunotherapy for non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, and plans to commercialize it in Hong Kong and, eventually, greater China.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Zevalin, which is owned and sold in the United States by Nevada-based Spectrum Pharmaceuticals, will be available at hospitals such as Hong Kong Sanatorium and Hospital.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In China, it will be supplied by CASI and its local partner, Global Medical Solutions Hong Kong Limited.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We are very excited to work with Hong Kong Sanatorium and Hospital to make Zevalin available to patients,” Ken K. Ren, CASI’s chief executive officer, said in a statement. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He added that while Hong Kong is a relatively small market, it provides the company with clinical knowledge and experience for Zevalin in a Chinese patient population, “which we believe will have a positive impact in market penetration when Zevalin is approved and becomes available in our greater China markets.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Clinical trials in both countries&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In February, Denovo Biopharma, a precision medicine company with offices in San Diego and Hangzhou, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.crossroadstoday.com/story/34519426/denovo-biopharma-plans-to-launch-a-global-phase-3-trial-of-db102-enzastaurin-in-diffuse-large-b-cell-lymphoma&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;announced&lt;/a&gt; it will launch a phase III clinical trial in China and the United States for its lead drug for diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“China will play a very important role in the biomarker-driven DB102 trial, and we have successfully submitted the Investigational New Drug application to the China FDA,” Isabel Han, head of Denovo's clinical operations in Beijing, said in a statement. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;FierceBiotech &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.fiercebiotech.com/biotech/lilly-chi-med-cancer-med-hits-phase-3-goals-eyes-china-nda&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;reported&lt;/a&gt; last month that Hong Kong-based Hutchison China MediTech and U.S. pharmaceutical partner Eli Lilly have seen positive results in trials of the drug they’re co-developing for people with certain colorectal cancers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In phase III trials of more than 4,500 patients in China, the treatment showed a significant increase in survival rates. The partnership is expected to file for approval with China Food and Drug Administration (CFDA) within a few months. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Spending billions for U.S. companies&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;China’s pharmaceutical industry is still far behind the United States, but China healthcare companies and investors are spending billions of dollars to acquire U.S. healthcare companies. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to PitchBook, there have been 214 deals made in the past five years between Chinese investors and healthcare companies based in the United States.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Bloomberg &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-07-05/china-inc-goes-on-a-buying-spree-for-global-health-care-assets&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;reported&lt;/a&gt; that last year China’s Humanwell Healthcare Group, which makes anesthetics and contraceptive drugs, spent more than a half a billion dollars to purchase New York-based generic drug maker Epic Pharma last year. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;OncoImmune, a Maryland-based biopharmaceutical company, is &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.finsmes.com/2017/01/oncoimmune-closes-15-0m-series-a-funding-round.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;working&lt;/a&gt; with China investors to develop new immunotherapies for cancer, inflammation, and autoimmune diseases.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;OncoImmune’s recent funding round of $15 million was led by 3E Bioventures Capital, a healthcare-focused investor in China.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Nonprofits’ link to China&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Children’s Treehouse Foundation, a Colorado-based nonprofit whose sole mission is to assist children who have a mother or father with cancer, is already in 77 cancer hospitals in the United States. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And it is now in Hong Kong and hopes to increase its presence in greater China. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The foundation’s &lt;a href=&quot;https://childrenstreehousefdn.org/climb-programs&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;CLIMB Program&lt;/a&gt;, which in scientific studies has been shown to greatly improve kids’ ability to cope with a parent’s illness, is installed at the Hong Kong Cancer Fund, a patient advocacy organization.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Denis Murray, executive director of the foundation, said there is great need for patient support in China, where cancer has grown at alarming rates in the past 30 years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It is telling that countries like China have to go halfway across the world to find models for psychosocial support,” Murray told Healthline. “Because of the internet, international organizations can find us, learn about CLIMB, and get trained so they can use it with their cancer patients.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the long run, Murray said, mutual benefits should result from this exchange.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Other countries can benefit from models developed in the U.S., and we can learn how to make our programs more culturally appropriate for cancer patients here and across the globe,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cognoa, the California-based consumer healthcare company, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.mobihealthnews.com/content/cognoa-raises-116m-continue-validation-fda-submission-child-development-assessment-app&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;announced&lt;/a&gt; last month that it raised $11 million in its latest round of funding to design apps that assess child development and behavioral health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Most of that money came from Morningside, the Hong Kong-based venture capital and social responsibility firm.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Nonprofit brings companies together&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The US China Innovation Alliance (UCIA), a Texas-based nonprofit, is immersed in this global trend.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The organization works to bring innovative U.S. and Chinese companies together. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At its upcoming summit next month, the organization expects to host about 200 companies from China. More than half are either in the healthcare field or interested in investing in it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Xinxin Li, director of development of the nonprofit, said that among the drivers of this growing trend are hospital reforms in China and the needs of China’s aging population.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“China focusing on healthcare innovation and reforms have contributed to this trend,” she told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hospital systems in China can go private now, Li noted, “compared to before, when they were only managed by the government. Most hospitals are still public, the change is slow, but this reform has created opportunity.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another driver for these new U.S.-China healthcare alliances, Li said, is China’s changing demographics.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Not unlike America’s baby boom generation, Li noted, “China’s aging population is creating emerging needs for healthcare and the U.S. is the largest [research and development] and innovation generator.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Li said that people in China who are her parents’ age don’t just want good medicine, they want well-being.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“My parent’s generation, who are of retirement age, are living longer after retiring, and they need better care, and they can afford that kind of care,” she said. “This demand is driving the market. Hospitals in China are seeking more information about overseas health care experiences.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>

</guid>
<dc:creator>Jamie Reno</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-10T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Can Drinking Tea Really Improve Your Memory?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/can-drinking-tea-improve-memory
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/aging/040917_teamemory_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;T
]]>
<![CDATA[
ea is generally considered good for you, but there hasn’t been a lot of science behind that claim.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Now a team of scientists at National University of Singapore Yong Loo Lin School of Medicine has put a bit of muscle into the discussion.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, experts interviewed by Healthline say there are still a lot of unanswered questions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the Singapore &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27925140&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; published in the Journal of Nutrition, Health and Aging, the research team concluded that drinking tea regularly lowered the risk for cognitive impairment in older adults by 50 percent.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Furthermore, this rate of reduced cognitive decline increased by as much as 86 percent for people who carry the APOE e4 gene (apolipoprotein E), which puts them genetically at higher risk of developing &lt;a href=&quot;/health/alzheimers-disease-overview&quot;&gt;Alzheimer’s disease&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Feng Lei, an assistant professor in the department of psychological medicine at the Singapore school, pointed out that the bioactive compounds in tea leaves, including catechins, theaflavins, thearubigins, and &lt;a href=&quot;/health/l-theanine&quot;&gt;L-theanine&lt;/a&gt;, have anti-inflammatory and antioxidant potential that create this long-term benefit.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These and other bioactive properties also protect the brain from vascular damage and neurodegeneration, according to Lei.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our findings have important implications for dementia prevention,” Lei said in a press release. “Despite high-quality drug trials, effective pharmacological therapy for neurocognitive disorders, such as dementia, remains elusive and current prevention strategies are far from satisfactory.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This discovery, he said, might provide an easy, inexpensive health benefit.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Tea is one of the most widely consumed beverages in the world. The data from our study suggest that a simple and inexpensive lifestyle measure, such as daily tea drinking, can reduce a person’s risk for developing neurocognitive disorders in late life,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Conclusions and questions&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In order to determine the association between tea consumption habits and the incidence of neurocognitive disorders, the investigative team collected tea consumption data for 957 community-living Chinese adults aged 55 years or older from 2003 to 2005.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They also gathered information on cases of neurocognitive disorders from 2006 to 2010, noting that all the participants were cognitively intact at baseline when the study began.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lei and colleagues identified 72 incident cases of neurocognitive disorders within the group. Independent of other risk factors, consumption of both green tea and black/oolong tea reduced the risk of incidents linked to neurocognitive disorders.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The tea study has been met with mild interest and a lot of questions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to James A. Hendrix, PhD, director of global science initiatives at the Alzheimer’s Association, a lot more work needs to be done on the subject. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I’m always a little skeptical of associative studies,” he told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Because two things occur at the same time does not prove one caused the other, he noted.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We need independent research on this subject. If they find a similar link, maybe we should investigate,” he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hendrix recalled the results from tests of other dietary supplements, notably vitamins “that were touted as a treatment. That was disappointing.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another issue with the study, Hendrix said, is that it was conducted on a homogeneous population. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lei acknowledged this in a press release: “While the study was conducted on Chinese elderly, the results could apply to other races as well.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Furthermore, the data was gathered based on self-reports, which Hendrix noted was a weakness. “People were asked how much tea they drank. They weren’t monitored by a third party,” he said. “That creates issues.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;More questions&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study also raised other questions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;How long does a person have to drink tea to get the potential benefits?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;What happens if you are not a lifetime tea drinker, but start at age 50? Or 60?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And how much tea is enough? One cup? Five?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s important to recognize how long one has been doing this,” Hendrix said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He cited a Finnish study of people with dementia who showed a slowing of symptoms when they engaged in regular exercise.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He suggested the same issue around food and drink. If you don’t start early, do you have a higher risk? &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The Mediterranean diet is beneficial to the cardiovascular system,” Hendrix said. “And what’s good for the heart is good for the brain.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We don’t know if it works if you’ve eaten a bad Western diet until you’re 75 and then switch to a healthier one,” he said. “But it can’t hurt.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What can you do?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;A recent poll showed that for the first time more people worry about getting dementia than cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And that leads to Hendrix’s best advice: Develop a healthy lifestyle. Eat a balanced diet. Exercise. Quit smoking.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s unlikely the solution will be a single substance,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Susan Weiner doesn’t think that tea is a magic pill either.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The nutritionist and registered dietician called the study interesting, but she’d like to see more study.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“More research is needed,” she told Healthline, “but it's promising due to the antioxidant properties, which may have a very positive impact on cognitive function.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On a more mundane level, she said, “tea can be a delicious addition to your diet. Also … when no sweeteners are added they are calorie-free.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<category>Senior Health</category>

<dc:creator>Roberta Alexander</dc:creator>

<item>
<title>New Blood Test Could Diagnose MS in One Week</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/blood-test-could-diagnose-ms-in-1-week
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/MS/040817_msbloodtest_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Imagine a blood test that could allow a medical professional to diagnose &lt;a href=&quot;/health/multiple-sclerosis/basics&quot;&gt;multiple sclerosis (MS)&lt;/a&gt; within just seven days. Today, a diagnosis can take months or even years to confirm.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://iquity.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;IQuity&lt;/a&gt;, a start-up company based in Tennessee, plans to launch such a test in May. They claim it has a &lt;a href=&quot;https://iquity-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/App/Models/Article/files/000/000/020/original/multiplesclerosisnewstoday.com-IQuity%20to%20Release%207-Day%20Blood%20Diagnostics%20Test%20for%20Multiple%20Sclerosis%20in%20May.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;90 percent&lt;/a&gt; success rate in detecting MS.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To date, no one test can guarantee a diagnosis of MS.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Currently, diagnosing MS is accomplished taking a detailed medical history and through &lt;a href=&quot;/health/multiple-sclerosis/tests-diagnose&quot;&gt;tests&lt;/a&gt; such as a magnetic resonance image (MRI) of the brain and/or spinal cord and the process of elimination for other illnesses.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Due to the disease’s ability to mimic symptoms of other illnesses, and because no two people present MS symptoms exactly the same, the diagnosis process can sometimes be a guessing game.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The quicker, the better&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Bruce Bebo, executive vice president of research at the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, leads the organization’s team, whose goal is to invest the agency’s resources in the most impactful way.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There is an unmet need for speedier and more accurate ways to diagnose MS,” Bebo told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The current process requires a process of elimination that can take time. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Having a blood-based test could simplify or speed up the process, both of which would be advancement in treating MS.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He noted that the earlier MS is treated, the better the outcome. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While the test did well in trials with MS patients, the real crux is how will it perform in the broader population.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In order for the test to be truly effective, Bebo said it will need to help neurologists speed up the diagnosis process. He added this test is not likely to &quot;stand on its own&quot; but would be used in conjunction with other diagnostic tools.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The blood test works by detecting patterns in RNA.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23748426&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;RNA-based research&lt;/a&gt; in 2013 successfully identified profiles in people with MS.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Once the profile was identified, an algorithm was created to find a pattern of molecules specific to diseases like MS.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s this proprietary algorithm that lead to $4 million in funding from the National Institutes of Health (NIH) as well as significant private investment for IQuity’s blood test.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Optimism for the future&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;While the new IsolateMS test will have much to prove after hitting the market, those connected with MS are generally excited about where things are now vs. 20 years ago.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are currently 15 disease modifying drugs (DMDs) for MS, all developed in the past two decades.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Last month, the first drug for &lt;a href=&quot;/health/multiple-sclerosis/what-is-primary-progressive&quot;&gt;primary-progressive MS (PPMS)&lt;/a&gt; was &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/new-multiple-sclerosis-drug-awaits-approval&quot;&gt;approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA)&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The landscape continues to change for those with the disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Chase Spurlock, founder and chief executive officer of IQuity and co-inventor of the new test, is hopeful about the future of MS medicine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Spurlock started work on his project during his time at Vanderbilt University, hitting critical mass in 2013. IQuity formed in 2015.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While the test does not differentiate between &lt;a href=&quot;/health/multiple-sclerosis/types-of-ms#YourType1&quot;&gt;relapsing-remitting MS&lt;/a&gt; and PPMS, it is designed to find general patterns for diagnostic purposes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Currently the clinical criteria to differentiate between types of MS has not been 100 percent codified, Spurlock said, but the ability to accomplish this is in the future.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The future holds many opportunities,” Spurlock told Healthline. “RNA patterns change in response to stimuli, such as a possible viral response.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He added that figuring out the first event that leads to an illness would be significant in preventing and stopping progression.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This test could eventually help doctors decide the best treatment for a person with MS.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Spurlock suggested in the future doctors will be able to “look at an RNA profile or molecular picture and decide on the first day what’s happening, and would they be better on one therapy vs. another.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Both Bebo and Spurlock shared the importance of early diagnoses and treatment as supported in the international consensus recommendations of 2016: &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27640924&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Brain health: Time matters in multiple sclerosis&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;IsolateMS does not need approval from the FDA because it is marketed and sold as a laboratory-developed test under The Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments (CLIA) law.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Spurlock says the NIH funding “allows us to throw a foot on the gas in moving forward.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Editor’s Note: Caroline Craven is a patient expert living with MS. Her award winning blog is GirlwithMS.com, and she can be found @thegirlwithms.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<updateddate>2017-04-07T13:00:00</updateddate>

</guid>
<dc:creator>Caroline Craven</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-07T20:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>Trying to Build a Better Sunscreen</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/build-better-sunscreen
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/040717_sunscreen_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;How often do you apply sunscreen? &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In an ideal world, everyone would adhere to the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.skincancer.org/prevention/sun-protection/sunscreen&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Skin Cancer Foundation recommendations&lt;/a&gt; and reapply sunscreen every two hours or immediately after swimming or sweating.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But the reality is often quite different. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sunscreen loses its effectiveness over time, making reapplication vital in avoiding damage to the skin. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But now, researchers in the United Kingdom are examining the ingredients in sunscreen in the hope of developing a longer-lasting product. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Sunscreens have been around for decades, so you'd think we know all there is to know about them, but we really don't,” Vasilios Stavros, PhD, associate professor of physical chemistry at the University of Warwick, said in a press release. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If we better understand how the molecules in sunscreen absorb light, then we can manipulate the molecules to absorb more energy, and we can protect the molecules from degradation. If the molecule doesn't break down, there's no need to reapply,” he explained.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The findings from Stavros and his team were reported earlier this month at a meeting of the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.skincancer.org/prevention/sun-protection/sunscreen&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;American Chemical Society (ACS)&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Chemical reactions in sunscreen&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers examined the chemical filters in sunscreen that absorb energy from the sun. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“UV filter molecules in sunscreens absorb radiation and convert highly toxic ‘electronic’ energy into ‘vibrational motion’ or ‘heat.’ Once the UV filter molecule has diffused this energy as heat, it is ready to reabsorb another photon of UV radiation and repeat the cycle,” Stavros told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In some cases, the chemical filters can fail by breaking into pieces or getting stuck in the excited state.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Stavros’ team sought to determine what was causing this chemical filter dysfunction.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They used lasers to replicate the sun’s energy. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In one instance, Stavros’ team found that 10 percent of the molecules in the common sunscreen ingredient oxybenzone get stuck in the excited state when under a laser.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Stavros suggests that this finding could pave the way for chemical manipulations that would allow for a longer-lasting sunscreen. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Many sunscreens on the market are made of both chemical and physical ingredients.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Chemical ingredients work by absorbing UV radiation and preventing penetration into the skin.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Physical ingredients work by deflecting UV radiation off the skin.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The dangers of sun exposure&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, dermatologists say many people struggle to keep to the guidelines of reapplying sunscreen.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Compliance with sunscreen application is one of the toughest challenges — it’s easy to say ‘reapply sunscreen to exposed areas every two hours,’ not always so easy to practice,” Dr. Adam Friedman, an associate professor of dermatology at the George Washington University School of Medicine and Health Sciences, told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Creating sunscreens that stay active longer will no doubt improve consumer/patient compliance and allow for better protective strategies.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.skincancer.org/prevention/sun-protection/swimming&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Skin Cancer Foundation&lt;/a&gt; recommends applying one ounce of sunscreen (about the size of a golf ball) to your entire body 30 minutes before going outside.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“About 90 percent of nonmelanoma skin cancers are associated with exposure to UV radiation from the sun, and if you have a visible sign of sun exposure, like a tan or sunburn, this means you’ve sustained skin cell damage,” a spokesperson for the Skin Cancer Foundation told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the United States, more than 5 million cases of nonmelanoma skin cancer are treated in more than 3 million people each year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Annually, there are more new cases of skin cancer than prostate, breast, lung, and colon cancers combined. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Skin Cancer Foundation estimates 87,110 new cases of invasive melanoma will be diagnosed in the United States in 2017. An estimated 9,730 people will die of the disease this year. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How to protect yourself&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;It may be a long way to go before a longer-lasting sunscreen is developed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the meantime, Friedman says when selecting a sunscreen, consumers should look for a product that has an SPF rating of 30 or higher, is broad spectrum, and is water resistant for up to 80 minutes. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The best sunscreen is one you will use again and again. The kind of sunscreen selected is a matter of personal choice and may vary depending on the area of the body to be protected,” Friedman said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He suggests creams are best for dry skin and the face, gels are good for hairy areas like the scalp or male chest, and sticks are good for around the eyes. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s also important to realize sunscreen is not enough. Seek shade when appropriate, remembering that the sun’s rays are strongest between&amp;nbsp;10 a.m. and 2 p.m.&amp;nbsp;If your shadow is shorter than you are, seek shade.&amp;nbsp;Wear protective clothing, such as a long-sleeved shirt, pants, a wide brim hat, and sunglasses, when possible,” Friedman said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Stavros’ research is ongoing, and he is confident the resulting data will shed more light on how sunscreens work. But he believes the future of longer-lasting sunscreens will be the result of collaborative work. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There are a number of teams around the world working in highly complementary areas like theory, industry, research and development and getting some truly beautiful results,” he said. “I believe through collaborative efforts we can really make huge steps toward making next-generation sunscreens.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-04-07T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-07T12:00:00</updateddate>

http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/build-better-sunscreen
</guid>
<dc:creator>Elizabeth Pratt</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-07T19:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Clothing That Makes Life Easier for People with Cancer
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/clothing-makes-life-easier-for-people-with-cancer
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/cancer/040717_cancerclothes_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p
]]>
<![CDATA[
&gt;Cancer treatment can go on for months or even years. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s a long time to wear awkward hospital gowns or struggle with clothing during chemotherapy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When it comes to appearance, there are hats, bandanas, and wigs available, but people with cancer have other needs, too.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s about comfort and practicality, but it’s also about feeling like you’re still you.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A small army of entrepreneurs is changing the way people with cancer dress.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For many of them, the idea stems from personal experience. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Dignity and empowerment&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;When cancer upended the lives of sisters Peg, Patty, and Claire, they realized just how important clothing choices could be.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When there was any choice at all.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The trio co-founded &lt;a href=&quot;https://healingthreads.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Healing Threads&lt;/a&gt; to address the issues they experienced firsthand.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Claire lost her life in 2006 to metastatic colon cancer after 35 months of treatment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Peg was treated for stage 3 melanoma, and has been cancer-free since 2002.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Patty has not had cancer, but she provided support for her two sisters. She remains a part of Healing Threads.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Peg Feodoroff, also known as “spirited sister #1,” is president of the Massachusetts company. She said the clothing was originally designed for people with cancer but has morphed into much more. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She told Healthline that the clothing line is helpful for men and women going back and forth for any type of medical treatments, including kidney dialysis. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The line features breakaway pants to provide easy access to the legs or hips.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When I designed those, my experience with cancer was melanoma,” said Feodoroff. “For anyone with melanoma on their leg, I thought they would prefer to wear these pants and expose only what has to be exposed when it has to be exposed, rather than take their pants off for the radiation table.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Feodoroff said a doctor once told her that he looks at people differently when they’re wearing a hospital gown rather than street clothes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It strips a person down to the lowest common denominator so you all look alike and all you are is a name on a bracelet. There’s nothing to distinguish you from anybody else,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One goal of Healing Threads is to help people maintain dignity and modesty while undergoing cancer treatment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another goal is empowerment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Being a baby boomer, and in the throes of the feminist movement many times, I want women in particular to take charge, demand answers, and be part of the decision-making process or even get a second opinion because they’re wearing a Healing Thread. That’s who we are and what we wanted to do,” said Feodoroff.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The versatile tops are particularly popular with women who’ve had mastectomies. You can wear the clothing in the hospital after surgery, but it’s ideal for those first weeks at home. Built-in provisions for drainage bags provide comfort and privacy. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The clothing is meant to go from treatment to public to home without a hitch.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And all that helps you feel more like yourself and less like a cancer patient.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Feodoroff laughed as she recalled her sister’s “horror” at having to wear a fanny pack to carry her chemo pump. She wouldn’t have had to use that option if she’d had a Healing Thread top.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So, how do doctors and nurses feel about nonhospital-issue clothing?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to Feodoroff, feedback from the medical community has been complimentary. Nurses note that the clothes are not just better looking than a hospital gown, they’re also quite functional.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A customer wrote Feodoroff to say, “Mom lost her battle but she did not lose her dignity during the treatments. Her love will remain in our hearts forever and always.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The sisters’ compassionate touch shines through in their clothing designs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We really love the human race and want to help women especially get through this horrible disease they’re facing,” said Feodoroff.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Fashion and fun for children&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Jessica Kidd, founder of &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.graciesgowns.org&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Gracie's Gowns&lt;/a&gt;, is a virtual one-woman show.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She’s president, chief executive officer, and primary seamstress of the Virginia-based nonprofit. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Gracie’s Gowns provides clothing for children with cancer and other illnesses. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This is important to these children and their parents because they're able to feel like they're not in the hospital setting,” Kidd wrote in an email to Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The children feel more at home, but they also have an increased self-worth that they are more than a room number or diagnosis and can be seen for the child they truly are. It inspires hope for families to continue each difficult day, regardless of the outcome,” she continued.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The gowns are custom-made for each child. The fabric colors and patterns are chosen to match their interests. Careful attention is paid to getting the size right.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The design itself is completely different from the traditional hospital gown. Ultimately, the part that sets us above from any other organization is that each gown is personalized with the first name of the child it is made for, and the family is not charged a penny to receive it,” said Kidd.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Gracie’s Gowns has created 3,511 unique gowns in five years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kidd previously worked in emergency services, medical transports, and pediatric critical care. She observed the problems children had with awkward, ill-fitting hospital gowns that were often made from irritating fabrics. The problem really hit home when her own child needed hospital care for a few days. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The idea for custom-made gowns for children came to her as she worked on a hospital gown for a friend. The organization was named in honor of her friend’s child, Grace, who passed away due to &lt;a href=&quot;/health/neuroblastoma&quot;&gt;neuroblastoma&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I wanted to show each child they truly mattered to someone and in some way help them smile in the darkest of times. I wanted them to know they weren't just room 2034 bed B, the kid with cancer. They weren't just a statistic, or even just one of those kids that spend most of their time in the hospital,” Kidd wrote on her website.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The organization also donates gowns directly to hospitals.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A growing number of options&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ingawellbeing.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;INGA Wellbeing&lt;/a&gt; makes stylish clothing for men and women in treatment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nikla Lancksweert co-founded the company after watching her mother go through ovarian cancer treatment. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In an interview with &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.npr.org/2017/03/26/521271203/trendy-hospital-clothing-to-make-cancer-patients-dress-well-even-when-unwell&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;NPR&lt;/a&gt;, Lancksweert spoke of the company’s back-opening dress for women, which is designed to take the place of a hospital gown.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“But you would never guess it. I've worn it in the playground. I've worn it to the supermarket, often meetings — not having had a chance to change — but it has all that sort of ease of opening in that it opens at the back and it also has openings down the arms and a very discreet opening to the stomach,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://ronwear.com&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;RonWear&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.chemocozy.com&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Chemo Cozy&lt;/a&gt; clothing lines feature colorful items with strategically placed zippers. The pieces are meant to feel cozy and help you get through treatment without having to disrobe or bare too much skin.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The clothes are designed to look as natural in public as your regular clothes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some people need an intravenous line called a PICC that remains in place between tests and treatments. Patients generally wear a dressing to cover and protect it. It’s a constant reminder of treatment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.careandwear.com&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Care + Wear&lt;/a&gt; sells a range PICC line covers in a variety of sizes and colors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One of the potential side effects of mastectomy is &lt;a href=&quot;/health/lymphatic-obstruction&quot;&gt;lymphedema&lt;/a&gt;, due to lymph node removal. One way to combat this is by wearing compression sleeves. &lt;a href=&quot;http://lymphedivas.com&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Lymphedivas&lt;/a&gt; offers compression sleeves and gloves that do the job, but with designs that are bold, sassy, or elegant to suit any occasion.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sometimes, a simple pair of socks can make all the difference in the world.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Jake Teitelbaum was no fan of the poorly made, unattractive, nonslip socks hospitals give to patients.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In treatment for refractory Hodgkin lymphoma, he started bringing his own colorful socks to the hospital. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It made him feel so much better that he founded the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.resilience.gives&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Resilience Project&lt;/a&gt;, an organization that sells fun socks online. Half of the proceeds help provide financial assistance to people with chronic illnesses.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It helped,” he wrote on his website. “It may seem ridiculous, but that little change reminded me that ultimately, I was in control of my experience. Whatever the circumstances, no matter how little I wanted to be isolated in the hospital, I could choose to use this as an opportunity to learn and grow as a person.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<dc:creator>Ann Pietrangelo</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-07T18:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>
Brain Stimulation May Reduce Tourette Syndrome Tics
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/brain-stimulation-may-reduce-tourette-tics
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/040717_tourette_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A new study may have brought deep brain stimulation one step closer for the treatment of Tourette syndrome.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers reveal that the technique significantly reduced the severity of “tics” in a small group of young adults with the disorder.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Tourette syndrome (TS) is a neurological condition characterized by repetitive, involuntary movements or uncontrollable vocal outbursts, known as tics.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Eye blinking, facial grimacing, jerking of the head or shoulders, and repetitive throat-clearing or grunting are some of the most common tics.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In more severe cases, people with TS may experience “complex” tics. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Complex motor tics are synchronized patterns of movement that involve more than one muscle group. For example, a facial grimace combined with a shoulder jerk and a head twist.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Complex vocal tics may include coprolalia – a term used to describe the vocalization of inappropriate words or phrases.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke, it is estimated that around &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ninds.nih.gov/Disorders/Patient-Caregiver-Education/Fact-Sheets/Tourette-Syndrome-Fact-Sheet&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;200,000 people&lt;/a&gt; in the United States have severe TS.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Onset of TS is most common in childhood. While symptoms usually improve by late adolescence, around 10 to 15 percent experience debilitating symptoms into adulthood.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How deep brain stimulation works&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are medications available to help reduce the severity of tics, but they do not work for all people with TS. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The new research, however, suggests that deep brain stimulation (DBS) could be an alternative treatment option for people with TS who do not respond to current therapies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Alon Mogilner, a study co-author who works in the departments of neurosurgery and anesthesiology at NYU Langone Medical Center in New York – and his colleagues &lt;a href=&quot;http://dx.doi.org/10.3171/2016.10.JNS161573&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;published&lt;/a&gt; their results today in the Journal of Neurosurgery. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To reach their findings, the researchers enrolled 13 young adults aged between 16 and 33 years who had severe TS.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;All adults underwent DBS, which involved the surgical insertion of two electrodes into the medial thalamus – a brain region that functions abnormally in people with TS.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Over the next few days, participants underwent a second surgery that involved attaching a neurostimulator to the electrodes – a pacemaker-like device that delivers electrical impulses to the medial thalamus.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Tic severity reduced&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Before and after DBS, the team assessed the subjects’ tic severity using the Yale Global Tic Severity Scale (YGTSS).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Participants were followed-up for at least six months and they underwent a number of assessments during this time.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At the first assessment after DBS, the researchers found that participants’ tic severity had been reduced by around 37 percent. By the final assessment, the severity of tics had decreased by 50 percent. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Furthermore, in a survey conducted six months after DBS, participants reported that the severity of their TS symptoms had improved “much” or “very much.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Additionally, all patients – even those who experienced some complications – said that they would undergo the procedure again.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&quot;The survey represents an important aspect of the study because the YGTSS, though a validated scale, may not fully capture the impact of DBS on quality of life for a person with Tourette syndrome,” said Dr. Michael Pourfar, another study co-author who works in the departments of neurosurgery and anesthesiology at NYU Langone.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At present, DBS is considered an “investigational” treatment for TS, as it has yet to receive approval from the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for this purpose.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, Mogilner and colleagues believe that their findings could change this. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&quot;Our study shows that deep brain stimulation is a safe, effective treatment for young adults with severe Tourette syndrome that cannot be managed with current therapies,&quot; said Mogilner. &quot;This treatment has the potential to improve the quality of life for patients who are debilitated through their teenage years and young adulthood.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-04-07T07:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-07T07:00:00</updateddate>
