<dc:creator>Honor Whiteman</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-07T14:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Skiing Again After a Stroke</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/skiing-again-after-stroke
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/040717_ahaskier_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For an extreme skier who jumps out of helicopters and prefers the Alps, a snowy hill in Pennsylvania wouldn’t seem to present much of a challenge.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But that was before Mark French suffered a debilitating stroke in 2015.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So getting back on his skis for the first time in February, even to descend a modest slope, was the greatest “schuss” of all.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It was a very satisfying milestone,” he said. “My goal is 100 percent recovery and I believe in time I’ll get there.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;French’s goals, however, extend far beyond just his own recovery.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Blindsided by an ailment he knew little about, the 62-year-old executive now wants to use his personal and professional resources to make a difference in stroke awareness and research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In business you need to be able to tell a story,” he said. “All I’m trying to do is share my story in a way that will cause people to think about stroke and what can and should be done.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;French is the founder and chief executive officer of Leading Authorities, a speakers bureau based in Washington, D.C.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It has a talent list ranging from political strategist Donna Brazille and former CIA Director Michael Hayden to basketball legend Magic Johnson and Saturday Night Live’s Darrell Hammond.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;An unexpected event&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;At 60, French was leading an enviable life.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He was running a successful business, traveling the world, rising early every morning for a strenuous cardio workout.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“From all outward signs, I was in great condition,” he said. “Never smoked, good blood pressure, didn’t have high cholesterol.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;French did have atrial fibrillation, an irregular heartbeat, but it didn’t seem serious enough to him or his doctor to warrant medication.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But AFib, as it is commonly known, can increase risk of blood clots, stroke and heart problems.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I couldn’t believe how little I knew about stroke,” he said. “I consider myself a pretty savvy well-read person, but I had no idea what the risk indicators were.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He found out on April 29, 2015.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After hosting a dinner for clients in downtown Washington, French got into his car to drive home.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“As I put my hands on the steering wheel, I felt what seemed to be an electric current in my left arm,” he said. “Nothing looked familiar. It’s almost miraculous I found my way home.&amp;nbsp; When I got there, my family recognized not everything was right.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;French had an ischemic stroke, a clot blocking blood flow to the brain, then a brain hemorrhage.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He was taken to a local hospital, and airlifted a day later to George Washington University Hospital – ironically, across the street from the site of his dinner the previous night.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A long road to recovery&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Doctors saved French’s life, but they weren’t optimistic.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I had paralysis on my left side,” he said. “They told my wife and daughters I had about 1 percent chance of ever walking again. It was just a cataclysmic change in my life.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Four weeks in the hospital were followed by six weeks at a rehabilitation hospital.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With determination, hard work “and a very good support network,” French returned to work that fall and has made steady progress since as he continues physical therapy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Defying the doctors’ predictions, French walks normally and has resumed traveling. He never had the speech problems that affect some stroke victims, but has difficulty typing (“thank goodness for voice-activated software”).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nonetheless, he’s trying to tackle the piano.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“What could have been a lethal event turned out to be recoverable,” he said.&amp;nbsp; “Stroke isn’t something you recover from the way you recover from a broken bone. You need patience and you need determination. I still have significant deficits, but I have as normal a life as one could hope for under the circumstances.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Spreading the word&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;But that’s not enough. French has spent a career building public awareness, and the battle against stroke needs plenty of that. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I believe that my stroke could have been prevented had I recognized the signs,” he said. “I never ever expected that I would be disabled. Few people do. But this is something that can happen to any more. People need to understand the magnitude of stroke as a leading cause of death and disability.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Once he understood that, “What has surprised me is the lack or resources being dedicated to stroke education, rehabilitation and research. It’s a very big deal, and I don’t think it’s being treated like a very big deal. Even in very good medical centers, there’s just not enough in the toolbox.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;His group, Leading Authorities, also produces videos and live events.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;French is determined to use his expertise to spread that message. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We’re in the communication business,” he said. “We’re going to get our message to opinion leaders and decision makers who have some influence. You hear a lot about marvelous breakthroughs in cancer research and that’s great. But we need to hear these things about stroke as well and I want to help.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As the two-year anniversary of his stroke nears, French considers himself “extraordinarily lucky” and is grateful for family and friends who were so crucial in his recovery. And as much as he appreciates the Pennsylvania slopes, that’s not the end of the story.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I’d like to ski the Alps again,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/back-on-the-slopes-after-stroke/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;original story&lt;/a&gt; was published on &lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;American Heart Association News&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<category>General Health</category>
<category>Outdoor Health</category>

<updateddate>2017-04-07T06:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/skiing-again-after-stroke
</guid>
<dc:creator>American Heart Association News</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-07T13:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Better Labeling for Drugs That Can Cause Erectile Dysfunction
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/drugs-that-can-cause-erectile-dysfunction
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/mens-health/040617_edlabeling_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt
]]>
<![CDATA[
;p&gt;What would you rather lose?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Your hair or your ability to perform sexually?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It may seem like an obvious choice, but some men may be making that decision without even knowing it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.newswise.com/articles/view/670909/?sc=dwhr&amp;amp;xy=10020406&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;recent study&lt;/a&gt; from Northwestern University has highlighted the need for more information about certain popular drugs targeted at male consumers that inadvertently cause erectile dysfunction and other side effects. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers investigated 5α-reductase inhibitors, a class of drug primarily used to treat two conditions in men: androgenetic alopecia (male pattern hair loss) and benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), otherwise known as an enlarged prostate.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Neither of these conditions is considered life-threatening.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hair loss is purely a social status issue while BPH can lead to problems such as frequent urination and bladder control problems.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Finasteride, otherwise known by its trade name, Propecia, and dutasteride (Avodart) are two popular examples of 5α-reductase inhibitors that are commonly prescribed for these conditions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;More serious than reported&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers in the Northwestern study say the sexual dysfunction effects of both finasteride and dutasteride are considerably worse than some medical literature suggests.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The current Full Prescribing Information (FPI) for finasteride says that, “(t)here is no evidence of increased sexual adverse experiences with increased duration of treatment,” and that “resolution (of sexual adverse experiences) occurred in men who discontinued therapy.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers disagree, saying that reporting of adverse sexual issues during clinical trials “was of poor quality” and “systematically biased.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Even before any human clinical trials were done, severe sexual dysfunction was a foreseeable consequence of taking finasteride or dutasteride,” Dr. Steven Belknap, research assistant professor of dermatology and medicine at Northwestern and lead author of the study, told Healthline. “If there was meaningful assessment of persistent sexual dysfunction in humans during the clinical development of the these drugs, this does not appear to have been reported in the medical literature, the FPI, or other publicly accessible sources.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Belknap and his colleagues concluded that 5α-reductase inhibitors are not only linked with erectile dysfunction while patients are using the drug, but that these symptoms persist even after stopping usage—a condition referred to as Persistent Erectile Dysfunction (PED).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a pool of almost 12,000 men, 167 (1.4 percent) of them developed PED. The median length of time that the symptom persisted was 1,348 days — almost four years — after they&lt;strong&gt; &lt;/strong&gt;stopped use of the drug.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers also concluded that 5α-reductase inhibitor usage was a more accurate indicator of PED in men than many other well-known predictors of the condition, including smoking, alcohol-usage, high blood pressure, and diabetes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Merck, the developer of Propecia, issued the following statement to Healthline:&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Nothing is more important to Merck than the safety of our medicines and the people who use them. Merck stands behind the demonstrated safety and efficacy profile of PROPECIA (finasteride), which has been prescribed to millions of men since its FDA approval in the U.S. in 1997. Merck conducted well-designed clinical trials on the product and stands behind the results, which were reported to the FDA and regulatory agencies around the world.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A representative from GlaxoSmithKline, the makers of Avodart, did not respond to a Healthline request for an interview.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A common side effect&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Erectile dysfunction is not an unusual side effect for many commonly prescribed drugs today.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Everything from anti-depressants, blood pressure medications, and even non-steroidal anti-inflammatory (NSAIDs) like aspirin can cause some sexual dysfunction.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At this point, no one is asking for 5α-reductase inhibitors to be removed from the marketplace. They are effective at their given purpose.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers say what is important is that those interested in taking these drugs are getting all the facts about them.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For a drug like finasteride, which has existed for over two decades and is estimated to be prescribed to 2.6 million men annually, researchers say that clear and accurate information about its relationship to sexual dysfunction should be more available.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2011, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.menshealth.com/health/hair-raising-effect&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Men’s Health&lt;/a&gt; reached a similar conclusion in their investigation into finasteride and so-called “post-finasteride syndrome” (PFS). They quoted Dr. Michael Irwig, an endocrinologist at George Washington University as saying “What we do want is for patients and doctors alike to understand the potential risk of persistent problems that may not, in fact, be reversible when you stop this drug.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Since that article was published, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) updated their labeling for finasteride in 2012 to expand on sexual adverse effects of the drug, including erectile dysfunction.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Men's Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-06T06:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-06T06:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/drugs-that-can-cause-erectile-dysfunction
</guid>
<dc:creator>Gigen Mammoser</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-06T13:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
How Easily Could the Measles Outbreak in Europe Spread to the US?
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/how-easily-could-the-measles-outbreak-in-europe-spread-to-the-us
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/Vaccination/040517_measles_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Should the United States prepare for another British invasion?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A major outbreak of &lt;a href=&quot;/health/measles&quot;&gt;measles&lt;/a&gt; in Europe raises questions about the disease’s ability to spread locally, or even internationally.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Last week the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.bbc.com/news/health-39419976&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;BBC reported&lt;/a&gt; on the rise of measles in countries throughout the European Union, including France, Germany, Poland, and Ukraine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, the largest outbreaks were seen in Italy and Romania — the latter reporting more than 3,400 cases of the disease, as well as 17 deaths since January 2016.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These incidents have members of the international health community wondering how such a thing could happen with a disease largely &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/measles/about/faqs.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;considered controlled&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How can it spread?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Since the introduction of a vaccine in 1963, cases of measles have dropped to historically low levels.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) announced that in the year 2000, the disease was eliminated from the country — meaning that over a year passed without continuous transmission of the disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Furthermore, the World Health Organization (WHO) has committed to “&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.searo.who.int/mediacentre/releases/2013/pr1565/en/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;eradicating&lt;/a&gt;” the disease from the globe by 2020.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, without proper vaccination practices, that may not happen.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the CDC, &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/measles/cases-outbreaks.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;cases of measles&lt;/a&gt; in the United States have steadily risen from a low of 37 people in 2004 to a high of 667 in 2014.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The disease targets young children who have never been exposed to it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As Healthline &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/measles-whooping-cough-rise-driven-by-unvaccinated-people#1&quot;&gt;reported last year&lt;/a&gt;, research published in JAMA stated, “greater emphasis needs to be placed on the association between vaccine refusal and the increase in [measles].”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In fact, the rise of contagious diseases largely considered neutralized by the CDC and WHO, such as measles and &lt;a href=&quot;/health/pertussis&quot;&gt;pertussis (whooping cough)&lt;/a&gt;, is largely attributed to the &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/children-anti-vaccination-movement-leads-to-disease-outbreaks-120312&quot;&gt;anti-vaccination movement&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2015, California reported 59 cases of measles, with 42 of them linked to &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/measles-spreads-in-california-due-to-unvaccinated-kids-012315#1&quot;&gt;groups of unvaccinated children at Disneyland&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Stephen Lauer, vice chair of pediatrics at the University of Kansas Health System, tells Healthline,&lt;em&gt; &lt;/em&gt;“The decrease in vaccination rates due in large part to the misinformation spread by the ‘anti-vax’ movement, is responsible for the spread of vaccine-preventable diseases.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Traveling across the oceans&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Measles is highly contagious and, according to Lauer, without addressing proper vaccination procedures, there is a possibility for the current outbreak in Europe to make its way to the United States.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The basic reason for the European outbreak is a decline in protective vaccination rates. If we follow the same path in the U.S., we can expect the same result,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Because of U.S. efforts to protect against the disease domestically, most cases of measles are brought into the country by &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/measles/about/faqs.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;unvaccinated travelers&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With the speed of global travel, unvaccinated, infected individuals can easily travel from country to country spreading disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Airplanes facilitate the process.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“A susceptible person could be exposed to a case of measles,” said Lauer, “travel for up to 24 hours, get off the plane, clear security, and not become ill for three to 10 days.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To protect against highly contagious diseases, humans depend on a phenomenon called “herd immunity.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The greater the number of vaccinated individuals in a group, the chance a disease is able to spread within that group decreases.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The infected unvaccinated person either gets better or dies, and if he doesn't come in contact with another unvaccinated person the virus can't spread,” explained Lauer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the case of a particularly communicable disease like measles, the recommended vaccination rate for a population is 95 percent to achieve herd immunity.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The recent outbreak in Europe has largely cropped up in areas where immunization levels have dipped beneath this threshold.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;An easy solution&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The answer to the problem remains the same as it’s been for the past 50 years: Vaccination.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to WHO, measles vaccinations have &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/measles-vaccine-has-saved-17-million-lives-since-the-year-2000-111215&quot;&gt;saved over 17 million lives&lt;/a&gt; since the year 2000. In order to completely eradicate the disease, countries across the globe will have to focus their efforts on vaccination.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When it comes to measles, Lauer is blunt: “Prevention is always safer, more effective, and less expensive than treating infection.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“As vaccination rates decline and infection rates rise,” he added, “we can expect to see deaths and serious morbidity from measles in the U.S. despite our outstanding care for those who become ill.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

</guid>
<dc:creator>Gigen Mammoser</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-05T22:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>Why You Sleep Well … Or Not</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/why-you-sleep-well
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/040517_sleepwell_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Do you toss and turn in bed, awaking every few hours, while your partner slumbers soundly and peacefully?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Do you find it impossible to go to sleep before midnight while others you know stumble off to bed and fall deep into dreamland at 10 p.m.?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There may be a biological reason for all this.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In two studies released this week, researchers say they have discovered variations in genes that may explain why some people have trouble sleeping and other people are so-called “night owls.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Still, the researchers say, a lot of questions remain unanswered.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Discovery of the “sleep gene”&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://advances.sciencemag.org/content/3/4/e1602663.full&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;first study&lt;/a&gt; was published Wednesday in the journal Science Advances.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In it, researchers focused on genes that change expression in the sleep-wake cycle.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers studied mice and discovered the expression of the gene FABP7 changed during the day in the brains of small rodents.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They noticed mice with a “knocked out” FABP7 gene slept more fitfully. The researchers concluded that particular gene is necessary for normal sleep in mammals.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers also checked the FABP7 gene in humans.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They combed through the data from nearly 300 Japanese men who participated in a sleep study that included DNA analysis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 29 of the men, the FABP7 gene did not appear to function properly and those men slept fitfully. The researchers said the men got as much sleep as other participants, but they experienced more waking moments and they didn’t sleep as soundly.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Finally, the researchers made transgenic fruit flies, inserting mutated and normal human FABP7 genes into the insects.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers said they noticed fitful sleep in the flies that had the mutated gene.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Sleep must be serving some important function,” Jason Gerstner, PhD, research assistant professor at Washington State University's College of Medicine, and lead author of the paper, said in a press release. “But as scientists we still don't understand what that is. One way to get closer to that is by understanding how it is regulated or what processes exist that are shared across species.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Gerstner said other genes are almost certainly involved in the sleep process. He and his team hope to find those biological links, too.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Why people are “night owls”&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The second study was published today in the journal Cell.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In it, researchers say they have discovered a variant in the gene CRY1 that slows a person’s biological clock.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This so-called “circadian clock” dictates when a person feels sleepy each night and when it’s time to wake up.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;People with the “night owl variant” have a longer circadian cycle, causing them to stay awake later, the researchers said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For their study, Michael W. Young, PhD, head of The Rockefeller University Laboratory of Genetics, and research associate Alina Patke, collaborated with sleep researchers at Weill Cornell Medical College.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They observed volunteer participants for two weeks in a laboratory apartment that was isolated from any clues as to what time of day it was. Participants were allowed to eat and sleep whenever they wanted.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Young said most people followed a typical 24-hour sleep/wake cycle. However, one person with &lt;a href=&quot;/health/circadian-rhythm-sleep-disorder&quot;&gt;delayed sleep phase disorder (DSPD)&lt;/a&gt; did not follow this pattern.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Among other things, the researchers noticed this person’s release of melatonin was delayed. That chemical helps bring on sleep.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Melatonin levels start to rise around 9 or 10 at night in most people,” Young said in a press release. “In this DSPD patient that doesn't happen until 2 or 3 in the morning.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When researchers checked the DNA of the DSPD participant, they said the mutation in the CRY1 gene stood out.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They said this gene mutation made the CRY1 protein more active, keeping other clock genes switched off for a longer period of time.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This is a fairly impactful genetic change,” said Young.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;No small matter&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers said sleep abnormalities are nothing to shrug off.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Someone with a “night owl” variant can go to bed later but needs to get up before their body is ready to return to waking status.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) estimates that at least &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/features/dssleep/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;50 million Americans&lt;/a&gt; have a sleep disorder.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They characterize insufficient sleep as a public health problem.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Young and his team plan further research. Part of that endeavor will be looking for solutions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Just finding the cause doesn't immediately fix the problem,” Patke said in a press release. “But it's not inconceivable that one might develop drugs in the future based on this mechanism.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For now, people with sleep disorders can help ease the problem by adhering to strict schedules.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Young added they can also get strong light exposure during the day.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-04-05T13:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-05T13:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/why-you-sleep-well
</guid>
<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-05T20:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Are People Being Misdiagnosed with High Blood Pressure?
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/misdiagnosed-with-high-blood-pressure
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/heart-health/040517_bloodpressure_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;If your doctor still uses a manual device to check your blood pressure, you risk being misdiagnosed, experts say.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This could lead to unnecessary treatment with medication for high blood pressure, not to mention dealing with the side effects and expense of those drugs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a new study published in the journal &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cfp.ca/content/63/3/e193.abstract&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Canadian Family Physician&lt;/a&gt;, researchers estimated that about 20 percent of Canadians being treated for high blood pressure, or hypertension, don’t actually need medication because their blood pressure was measured incorrectly.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers say this is due to more than half of family doctors in Canada still using manual devices to measure blood pressure.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Automated is the way to go&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Measuring someone’s blood pressure manually seems like a fairly straightforward procedure — put on the cuff, inflate it, and read the dial as the cuff deflates.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A lot can go wrong, though.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It seems like blood pressure is easy to measure, but almost no one does it correctly,” said Dr. Sarah Woolsey, a family physician, and medical director with HealthInsight Utah.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Using the wrong size cuff can throw off the numbers. It can also happen if a person is fidgeting while having their blood pressure checked, or checking someone’s blood pressure right after they come into the office.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Even just being in the doctor’s office can cause a person’s blood pressure to increase. This kind of “white-coat hypertension” is &lt;a href=&quot;http://hyper.ahajournals.org/content/62/6/982&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;surprisingly common&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The big message for us is that ‘white-coat hypertension’ is prevalent, and over-treatment may be prevalent and may lead to side effects of medication,” Woolsey told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To avoid these types of errors, the &lt;a href=&quot;http://guidelines.hypertension.ca/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Canadian Hypertension Education Program Guidelines&lt;/a&gt; recommend that doctors use automated blood pressure monitoring in the office.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Clinicians should use automatic devices. They are more expensive but more precise because they take several measurements,” Janusz Kaczorowski, PhD, a professor in the Department of Family and Emergency Medicine at Universite de Montreal, and lead author of the Canadian study, said in a press release.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Automated blood pressure monitoring can also be done while the person is alone, which reduces some of the white-coat hypertension. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Does that mean manual measurements are always wrong? No, but their accuracy depends on how they’re done.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Manual measurement is acceptable if it’s properly done, but that’s often not the case,” said Kaczorowski. “To take blood pressure the right way, a 12- to 15-minute period is required.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This may not work with the typical 10-minute visit to a family doctor.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Screening vs. diagnosis&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.uspreventiveservicestaskforce.org/Page/Document/RecommendationStatementFinal/high-blood-pressure-in-adults-screening&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF)&lt;/a&gt; offers similar guidelines for blood pressure screening.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The blood pressure measurement that happens at a routine doctor’s visit is an initial screening.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If someone’s blood pressure is elevated, then a more thorough check is needed to properly diagnose high blood pressure.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This can be done in several ways.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The gold standard is the 24-hour ambulatory monitor,” Woolsey told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If that isn't available, Woolsey said the guidelines “suggest multiple measurements of blood pressure — and they give you the option of an automated office blood pressure, or out-of-office monitoring, or multiple in-office monitoring.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ambulatory blood pressure monitoring devices are small, portable machines that measure a person’s blood pressure at regular intervals over 12 to 24 hours. This gives a more accurate picture of a person’s “real” blood pressure level.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, these devices may be hard to come by, especially in rural areas.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A recent paper published by Woolsey and her colleagues in the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.jabfm.org/content/30/2/170.full&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Journal of the American Board of Family Medicine (JABFM)&lt;/a&gt; found that only a quarter of 123 primary care clinics in Utah that responded to a survey had access to ambulatory monitoring. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers also discovered that clinics were not following all of the USPSTF guidelines.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At the high end, 93 percent of the clinics reported using an appropriately sized arm cuff. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But only 57 percent of clinics waited at least five minutes after the patient arrived at the office before checking blood pressure.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Woolsey thinks the situation may be similar in clinics throughout the United States.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Because of the lack of ambulatory devices in many areas and the challenges with manual blood pressure monitoring, automated devices may have an even bigger role to play in clinics.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We think the automated office blood pressure will be a good solution, especially for our smaller cities and smaller towns,” said Woolsey.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Empowering patients&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;People with high blood pressure often don’t feel sick until their pressure is really high or they develop another problem such as kidney disease, heart attack, or stroke.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s why high blood pressure is known as a “silent killer.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.heart.org/HEARTORG/Conditions/HighBloodPressure/KnowYourNumbers/Monitoring-Your-Blood-Pressure-at-Home_UCM_301874_Article.jsp#.WOTx6hLyt68&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Home blood pressure monitoring&lt;/a&gt; can help people track their condition in between doctor visits.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This can be done using standard manual blood pressure cuffs or automated home devices.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For this to work well, though, people need to be properly trained — another area of improvement identified by Woolsey and her colleagues. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Slightly more than a third of the Utah clinics provided instructions to people on how to measure blood pressure accurately at home.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But once people know how to check their own blood pressure correctly, home monitoring can help them in more ways than one.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I personally aspire to a day where we have diabetes without doctors, and hypertension treatment without doctors, because patients are so enabled in self-care,” said Woolsey. “Self-monitoring programs are good for patient engagement and patient self-awareness of their own conditions.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-04-05T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-05T12:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/misdiagnosed-with-high-blood-pressure
</guid>
<dc:creator>Shawn Radcliffe</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-05T19:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Most Americans Are Afraid to Perform CPR</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/most-americans-afraid-to-perform-cpr
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/heart-health/040517_CPR_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Only half of Americans can be counted on to perform CPR in an emergency, a new survey finds.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Even more – 61 percent – worry they could unintentionally injure the victim.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s a concern highest among minorities. About 70 percent of African-Americans, 67 percent of Asians and 64 percent of Hispanics think they could injure the person they are trying to help, compared with 59 percent of Caucasians.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hispanics are also more likely than Caucasians to believe special training and certification are required to perform Hands-Only CPR.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Report-2016-HOCPR-Tracking-Study.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2016 online survey&lt;/a&gt; of nearly 1,200 adults was commissioned by the American Heart Association (AHA).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Hands-Only CPR survey has been conducted since 2009.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A risk worth taking&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Longtime CPR instructor Dr. Gustavo E. Flores, said the findings didn’t surprise him because he’s heard the same concerns and comments from students.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But he wants people to know the benefits of CPR greatly outweigh the risk of injury.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Your patient in front of you is going through the worst thing that somebody could endure – no signs of life,” said Flores, director and chief instructor at Emergency &amp;amp; Amp; Critical Care Trainings in San Juan, Puerto Rico. “If your patient is in … sudden cardiac arrest, there’s nothing you can do that can make him worse.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Each year in the United States, more than 350,000 cardiac arrests occur outside a hospital. Only&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;about 11 percent of those treated by emergency medical services survive, according to AHA statistics.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;CPR can double or triple a person’s chance of survival, especially if performed within the first few minutes of cardiac arrest.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;No extensive training needed&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Flores’ father also taught CPR. As a child, Flores would often accompany his father to classes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Two decades ago, the hurdle was coming up with safe and effective techniques to pass on to the general public, Flores said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But despite today’s simple technique of pushing hard and fast in the center of the chest, the&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;misconception remains that specialized training is needed, he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It is safe to do Hands-Only CPR,” Flores said. “All you need is two hands.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Emergency medical services training coordinator Sean Culliney teaches CPR in Tucson, Arizona.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Far more damage comes from doing nothing,” said the paramedic from the Northwest Fire District.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Culliney said the survey shows the CPR community needs to do a better job of spreading the message in minority communities in urban areas.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;You could be needed&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The survey also showed 13 percent of respondents said they had recently been in a situation where they could have performed CPR but didn’t.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s up from 4 percent in the 2014 survey.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, 90 percent of respondents support making CPR training mandatory for high school students.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another 89 percent know to first call 911 if someone is in cardiac arrest, up from 86 percent in the 2014 survey.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Through the AHA’s Hands-Only CPR campaign supported by the Anthem Foundation, nearly 6.4 million people have been trained in Hands-Only CPR since 2015 through video education, events, and training kiosks.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;The &lt;/em&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/many-americans-afraid-to-perform-cpr/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;original story&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;em&gt; was published on &lt;/em&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;American Heart Association News&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;em&gt;.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Heart Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-05T06:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-05T06:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/most-americans-afraid-to-perform-cpr
</guid>
<dc:creator>American Heart Association News</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-05T13:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Researchers Looking at One-Shot Vaccination for Infants
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/one-shot-vaccination-for-infants
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/Vaccination/032917_newbornvaccine_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The concept is a simple one.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A vaccine given to a newborn baby can protect it from illness and disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Such a vaccination could also reduce the number of booster shots children get in their first few years of life.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The problem has always been creating a vaccine that is both effective and safe for the vulnerable immune system of infants.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers at Boston Children’s Hospital think they may be on the right track.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.jacionline.org/article/S0091-6749(17)30242-7/abstract&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;paper&lt;/a&gt; published late last month, the researchers detailed the one-shot vaccination they have been researching for the past decade.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The vaccine still needs to undergo human clinical trials.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, if it passes the test, researchers say the inoculation could protect babies when they are most susceptible.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It would also be given right after birth when children are already at the hospital.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The protective antibody response we saw was so strong that it's conceivable that you could get protection with one shot,” Dr. Ofer Levy, a specialist in infectious diseases at Boston Children’s Hospital, said in a press release. “This is critical because in many parts of the world, birth is the most reliable point of healthcare contact. After birth, it becomes challenging to bring children in for repeated clinic visits.&quot;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Vaccine worked in animals&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Newborns are vulnerable to diseases and usually don’t respond well to vaccines because their young immune systems usually mount weak antibody responses.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To help solve this problem, the researchers added compounds known as adjuvants that boost the immune system for their experimental vaccine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The scientists used a pneumococcal vaccine because it can cause &lt;a href=&quot;/health/pneumonia&quot;&gt;pneumonia&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;/health/meningitis&quot;&gt;meningitis&lt;/a&gt;, and &lt;a href=&quot;/health/sepsis&quot;&gt;sepsis&lt;/a&gt; that can be fatal to infants.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the study, the researchers gave the vaccine to half of a group of rhesus monkeys. The other half was inoculated with an existing pneumococcal vaccine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;By day 28, researchers said, the monkeys with the new vaccine had antibody levels from 10 to 100 times higher than the other group. They also were quicker to develop antibody responses.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers said the experimental vaccine works by stimulating a set of receptors on white blood cells. In particular, they noticed that stimulation of two specific receptors produced the strongest antibody response.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They added that the adjuvant was configured chemically with a lipid “tail” that mixes poorly with water.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That keeps it from entering the bloodstream where it can cause inflammation or flu-like symptoms.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Instead, the adjuvant stays in the muscle and activates the immune response from there.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The importance of the vaccine&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Currently, only the Bacillus Calmette Guerin (BCG), polio, and hepatitis B vaccines are given at birth in most parts of the world.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The polio and hepatitis vaccines also need multiple doses to be effective.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Boston researchers said a one-shot vaccine given at birth could greatly reduce infant mortality around the globe.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Two experts interviewed by Healthline agree.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Chris Nyquist, the medical director of infection prevention and control at Children’s Hospital in Colorado, said a “one and done” vaccine would be beneficial on several levels.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;First, she said, the vaccination would be given when a newborn is most vulnerable to illness. The child and their parents also are usually in a medical setting at that juncture.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s important to prevent infections as soon as we can,” said Nyquist.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cynthia Leifer, PhD, associate professor of microbiology and immunology at Cornell University, concurs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The most reliable interaction with medical care is at birth,” she said. “If the findings that they found in nonhuman primates is also true in humans, many more children could be protected by vaccines reducing the global burden of preventable infectious diseases.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Both Leifer and Nyquist said the possibility of reducing the number of booster shots is important. If the need for a follow-up visit is eliminated, then more children will be protected from disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They added a reduction in the number of shots could soothe fears of some parents about the effects of multiple inoculations on their children.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Reducing the number of shots may allay parent fears thereby increasing vaccine coverage and protecting more children,” said Leifer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Moms Against Mercury and the World Mercury Project did not provide a representative to comment for this story.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nyquist did suggest that human trials first test the experimental vaccine on adults to judge its safety before trying it out on children.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The vulnerability of young children&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Two studies released this week highlight the effectiveness of childhood vaccines.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the &lt;a href=&quot;http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/early/2017/03/30/peds.2016-4244?sso=1&amp;amp;sso_redirect_count=1&amp;amp;nfstatus=401&amp;amp;nftoken=00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000&amp;amp;nfstatusdescription=ERROR%3a+No+local+token&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;first study&lt;/a&gt;, researchers from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) concluded that a flu vaccination significantly reduces a child’s risk of dying from influenza.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The scientists used data from four flu seasons from 2010 to 2014.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They said flu vaccines reduced the risk of flu-associated death by 65 percent in healthy children and by 51 percent among children with underlying high-risk medical conditions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So far this flu season, the CDC has received 61 reports of children dying from flu-related complications.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.aap.org/en-us/about-the-aap/aap-press-room/Pages/Maternal-Tdap-Vaccine-Highly-Effective-in-Protecting-Infants-from-Pertussis-Study-Shows.aspx&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;second study&lt;/a&gt;, researchers concluded that vaccinating pregnant women against &lt;a href=&quot;/health/pertussis&quot;&gt;pertussis&lt;/a&gt; was highly effective in preventing newborns from contracting the life-threatening respiratory illness also known as whooping cough.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The scientists analyzed the records of almost 150,000 infants born at Kaiser Permanente Northern California from 2010 to 2015.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They said maternal &lt;a href=&quot;/health/new-baby-vaccination-guide/tdap-vaccine&quot;&gt;Tdap&lt;/a&gt; vaccination was 91 percent effective during an infant’s first two months of life and 69 percent effective during a child’s first year.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Children's Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-04T14:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-04T14:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/one-shot-vaccination-for-infants
</guid>
<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-04T21:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Celiac Disease Might Be Caused by Common Virus</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/celiac-might-be-caused-by-common-virus
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/040617_celiacvirus_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Celiac disease is an autoimmune condition characterized by an intolerance to gluten.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Precisely what causes such an intolerance, however, remains unclear.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a new study, researchers have found that infection with reoviruses might play a role, a finding that might bring us closer to a vaccination against celiac disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, as many as &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/digestive-diseases/celiac-disease/definition-facts&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;1 in 141 people&lt;/a&gt; in the United States have celiac disease, although the majority of these are unaware that they are affected.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The condition is triggered by an abnormal immune response upon consumption of foods containing gluten – a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When a person with celiac disease eats gluten, their immune system responds by attacking the lining of the small intestine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This can cause digestive symptoms – such as stomach pain and diarrhea – as well as long-term symptoms including fatigue, iron-deficiency anemia, bone or joint pain, migraines, and arthritis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At present, the only way to manage celiac disease is to avoid foods containing gluten.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, the researchers of the new study – including Dr. Terence Dermody, chair of the Department of Pediatrics at the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine in Pennsylvania - say their findings indicate that vaccination against certain viruses could help to prevent the disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers published their results today in the journal Science.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The link to reoviruses&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dermody and colleagues have long investigated the health implications of reoviruses.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They are a group of RNA viruses that are associated with gastrointestinal infections but which present no symptoms for most people.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For the new study, the team set out to determine whether there might be a link between reovirus infection and celiac disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To reach their findings, the researchers assessed the effects of two genetically different strains of human reoviruses on immune responses to gluten in mice.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The team found that one of the strains not only prompted an inflammatory immune response in the rodents, but it also led to the loss of oral tolerance to gluten. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On assessing the immune responses of those with and without celiac disease, the researchers found that those with celiac disease had significantly higher levels of antibodies to reoviruses.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Additionally, the analysis revealed that a higher level of reovirus antibodies was associated with increased expression of the IRF1 gene, which is a key player in the loss of oral tolerance to gluten.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This study clearly shows that a virus that is not clinically symptomatic can still do bad things to the immune system and set the stage for an autoimmune disorder, and for celiac disease in particular,&quot; said senior study author Dr. Bana Jabri of the Department of Medicine and Pediatrics at the University of Chicago Celiac Disease Center.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;‘Long-term consequences’ for children&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dermody and team said their findings indicate that an initial reovirus infection may leave a “permanent mark” on the immune system that later triggers an autoimmune response to gluten.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This could have significant implications for children who are genetically predisposed to celiac disease, the researchers note.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the United States, solid foods are normally introduced to babies at around 6 months of age, and these foods often contain gluten.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Young children have greater susceptibility to viral infections such as reoviruses. Combined with a high genetic risk of celiac disease, early gluten exposure may fuel its development.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&quot;During the first year of life, the immune system is still maturing, so for a child with a particular genetic background, getting a particular virus at that time can leave a kind of scar that then has long-term consequences,&quot; explained Jabri.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&quot;That's why we believe that once we have more studies, we may want to think about whether children at high risk of developing celiac disease should be vaccinated,” she added.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Allergies</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-04T13:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-04T13:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/celiac-might-be-caused-by-common-virus
</guid>
<dc:creator>Honor Whiteman</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-04T20:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>
Norway-Italy-Canada Combo: How to Put Together a Healthy, Happy Society
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/put-together-a-healthy-happy-society
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/040417_norwitalia_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;What does it take to make a healthy, happy society?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;How about a dose of Norway.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A smattering of Italy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And a dash of Canada.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to recent reports, all three of these countries have strengths that make them great places to live.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And good examples for other countries searching for health as well as happiness.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Norway is happiest country&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;This year Norway topped the United Nations’ World Happiness Report — although it was in a statistical dead heat with Denmark, Iceland and Switzerland. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;All four countries ranked high for factors known to support happiness: caring, freedom, generosity, honesty, health, income and good governance.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They, and the other top 10 countries, also scored well for longevity, strong social networks and trust. The last one refers to an absence of corruption in business and government.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Norway does have an advantage over some less-happy countries — steady income from oil production and one of the largest &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.reuters.com/article/us-life-happiness-scandinavia-idUSKBN16R27B&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;sovereign wealth funds in the world&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This allows the government to fund programs that help keep Norwegians happy — like its cradle-to-grave assistance programs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But it may be how Norway handles its wealth that matters most.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Even when oil prices sag, Norway is still able to ride it out “by choosing to produce its oil slowly, and investing the proceeds for the future rather than spending them in the present,” says the report.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The United States, in spite of being known as an economic powerhouse, has dropped in recent years. It landed in the 14th spot this year. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The U.N. report cites declining social support and an increase in corruption as eroding America’s happiness.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The report also offers the United States as “a vivid portrait of a country that is looking for happiness ‘in all the wrong places.’”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The country’s focus on raising the rate of economic growth — through tax cuts and deregulation — “will increase inequality, social tensions, and the social and economic divide between those with a college degree and those without,” write the authors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Mental health drives happiness&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;There’s a stark contrast between the top 10 countries and those at the bottom — which includes places like war-torn Syria and the Central African Republic.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In spite of that, the report points out that happiness also varies greatly within many countries.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Unemployment and income inequality account for some of these differences, especially in poorer countries.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But in all countries mental health is a stronger factor than physical health for why some citizens are happy and others are not.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In Western countries like the United States, “diagnosed mental illness emerges as more important than income, employment or physical illness,” write the authors of the report.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Max Strom, yoga health and wellbeing teacher and author of the book “&lt;a href=&quot;http://maxstrom.com/store/books/app-happiness-avoid-near-life-experience/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;There is No App for Happiness&lt;/a&gt;,” might agree.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The way to really find out if someone is happy is not to ask them on the street with a camera in their face because most likely they’ll not tell you the truth,” said Strom. “The real way is to ask what medications are they are taking.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Strom points to the high use of antidepressants and anti-anxiety medications by Americans — the United States outranks all other countries on this, according to a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.businessinsider.com/countries-largest-antidepressant-drug-users-2016-2&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;report by Business Insider&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In his book, Strom talks about how technology gets in the way of real happiness, which he defines as finding meaning in our lives.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In particular, studies have shown that using &lt;a href=&quot;http://online.liebertpub.com/doi/abs/10.1089/cyber.2016.0259?journalCode=cyber&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;social media can make you unhappy&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Instead of being social in person with people, we will go online,” said Strom, “whether it’s on our phone or on some other device.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But these relationships lack the non-verbal communication that comes in a face-to-face interaction. Which leaves us wanting more.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We’re starving for intimacy, even though we’re constantly in contact with people,” said Strom.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Health spending doesn’t equal health&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Research is finding &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/news/magazine/happiness-stress-heart-disease/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;links between happiness and health&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But living in an unhappy country doesn’t always mean being unhealthy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Take Italy, for example.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It ranked 48th on the U.N.’s World Happiness Report, but it is number one for health on the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-03-20/italy-s-struggling-economy-has-world-s-healthiest-people&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Bloomberg Global Health Index&lt;/a&gt; of 163 countries.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This report looks at variables that include life expectancy, causes of death and health risks such as smoking, obesity and pollution.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Part of Italy’s health success stems from a Mediterranean diet rich in fresh vegetables and fruit, and healthy fats like extra virgin olive oil.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Diet may even trump healthcare spending.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Italy spends only 9 percent of its &lt;a href=&quot;http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SH.XPD.TOTL.ZS&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;gross domestic product (GDP)&lt;/a&gt; on healthcare. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The United States spends 17 percent of its GDP but ranked 34th on Bloomberg’s list. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This is due in part to more than &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/fastats/obesity-overweight.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;two-thirds&lt;/a&gt; of the adult Americans being overweight or obese, a risk factor for heart disease, stroke and diabetes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;America’s fragmented healthcare system may also be depressing the country’s health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://annals.org/aim/article/2609289/survival-comparison-patients-cystic-fibrosis-canada-united-states-population-based&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;recent study published in Annals of Internal Medicine&lt;/a&gt; found that Canadians with cystic fibrosis can expect to live into their 50s. In the United States, they may only reach their 40s.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This inherited disorder affects the lungs, intestines, pancreas and other organs. It has no cure.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/20/upshot/why-cystic-fibrosis-patients-in-canada-outlive-those-in-the-us.html?&amp;amp;_r=0&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;According to the New York Times&lt;/a&gt;, Canadians with cystic fibrosis had a similar risk of early death as Americans with private insurance coverage.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But compared to people with cystic fibrosis in the United States who had Medicaid, patients in Canada had a 44 percent lower risk of early death.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other socioeconomic factors may be involved, but insurance coverage remains a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cff.org/News/News-Archive/2014/Insurance-Coverage-Remains-a-Top-Concern-for-People-with-Cystic-Fibrosis/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;top concern for Americans with cystic fibrosis&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Access to care and life-saving medications — things that people in countries like Canada take for granted — can have a big impact on health, especially with serious and chronic medical conditions.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Mental Health</category>
<category>Public Policy</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-04T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-04T12:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/put-together-a-healthy-happy-society
</guid>
<dc:creator>Shawn Radcliffe</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-04T19:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
The Challenge of Taking Someone with Dementia to the Emergency Room
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/the-challenge-of-taking-someone-with-dementia-to-the-emergency-room
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/040317_dementiapatients_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Trips to the emergency room aren’t usually due to joyous circumstances.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Yet most people find ways to cope with the anxiety of such a visit.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But for people with Alzheimer’s or dementia, a visit to the emergency room often devolves into a bout of delirium.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The inability to logically process what’s going on creates an additional layer of concern for the doctors, nurses, and technicians who are caring for these people. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I saw this firsthand when my father visited the emergency room with severe stomach pain. It turned out he had pancreatitis due to gallstones. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He also has Lewy body dementia, which means he has Parkinson’s-like symptoms well as memory loss. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He was admitted to the hospital and from the get-go, it was clear his stay was going to be a challenge for him and for the people who would care for him.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He couldn’t answer questions about his pain and within hours of being admitted he was convinced he’d been kidnapped. This lasted for almost his entire stay.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The challenge with people with dementia&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;My father’s reaction was textbook, according to Margaret Dean, RN, CS-BC, NP-C, MSN, FAANP, Texas Tech Health Sciences Center, Geriatric Division, and a member of the Alzheimer's Foundation of America's Memory Screening Advisory Board.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;What’s more, she said, it showed the challenges that healthcare providers face when caring for people with dementia. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Even simple procedures like taking blood pressure or administering a shot can be confusing or scary to someone with dementia.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“They tend to get confused when things are happening so fast,” she told Healthline.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;More than 5 million people living in the United States have Alzheimer’s disease. By 2050 that number is expected rise to 16 million.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As modern medicine continues to make advancements and humans live longer, Dean noted that hospitals can expect to see more patients with memory loss disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She said in a few years, experts say that by the age of 85 at least 1 in 2 people will have some type of dementia, mainly Alzheimer’s.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dean believes that the healthcare industry needs to play catch up if wants to properly care for people with these conditions when they come to the emergency room.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She said it’s not uncommon for these healthcare workers to have little experience with people with dementia or Alzheimer’s. Her mission is to educate the masses on caring for geriatric patients in general.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Healthcare workers need to learn how to deal with these people, how to talk to them,” she said. “It’s like with pediatrics. You’re not just dealing with the patient; you’re dealing with all of the other people around them.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What medical workers should do&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;One of the most glaring issues is that dementia or Alzheimer’s doesn’t reveal itself in blood work.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nor does it show up on the patient’s face.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The two diseases also don’t follow a structured path of symptoms.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One person may not be able to remember names while another may not remember how to complete simple tasks such as tying their shoes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dean said by nature the emergency room is chaotic.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At any given time, patients have multiple people completing different tasks. But that environment can only exacerbate the anxiety someone with dementia is experiencing.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“They do that because they are in a hurry,” she said. “I get that, but they have to limit the amount of things that are going on at once.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Healthcare providers should also take a moment to reassess their bedside manner when assessing dementia and Alzheimer’s patients.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When you talk to them, speak very simply,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What family members should do&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The best advocates for a person with Alzheimer’s or dementia are family members, according to Ruth Drew, MS, LPC, director of Family and Information Services at the Alzheimer’s Association.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Family members need a game plan for when or if a hospital stay in required. First and foremost, all important documents must be copied and readily available. &lt;strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Advanced directive, power of attorney,” she said. “Like an emergency kit that’s ready to go.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Secondly, she says that family members need to take a proactive approach, particularly in the early stages of an emergency room visit.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think we expect that everyone knows more than we do,” she said. “But not everybody who works in the healthcare field understands the impact of the disease.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s true. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On the first night my father was admitted, I had to remind every single person who entered his room that he had dementia.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;His Alzheimer’s diagnosis was buried in his electronic file and didn’t pop up as soon as they entered his name into their system.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Drew said it’s important to be specific.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Let the nurses, doctors, and technicians know what your family member likes and doesn’t like.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Maybe loud noises are too distracting. Maybe they respond better when the nurse speaks close and with constant eye contact.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The subtle differences can make a world of difference.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Be a spokesperson, ask a lot of questions about the medicine, procedures,” she said. “Ask, ‘how can we get this in the chart?’”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Training medical personnel&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dean said many of the issues that I faced with my father’s hospital stay could be resolved if geriatrics, including dementia and Alzheimer’s care, were considered mandatory rotations for all healthcare providers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It needs to be a required track, at the baccalaureate level, grad level, medical school, residency, PT, OT, pharmacy,” she said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A rotation would provide proper training in “what to say, what not to say, how to understand where they are at,” she said. “What is their reality, because often their reality isn’t present day.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She mentioned a time she was talking to a someone with Alzheimer’s who was at the nurse’s station, and asked him what year was it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“He said 1936. And I asked him, ‘Where are you?’” she said. “He told me ‘I’m on my farm … and I have these mules and these people owe me money.’”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Welcome to the world of Alzheimer’s,” she said.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-04-03T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-03T12:00:00</updateddate>

<dc:creator>Carolyn Abate</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-03T19:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>The Effects of Penicillin on Young Children</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/penicillin-for-young-children
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/childrens-health/040317_penicillin_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&g
]]>
<![CDATA[
t;&lt;p&gt;Antibiotics have been helping us to ward off infections for nearly a century, since the invention of penicillin in 1928.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;An increasing number of studies, however, point to the adverse effects of administering penicillin to children early in life.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nonetheless, a new study has examined the effect of a low dose of penicillin in late pregnancy and early life on the offspring of mice.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When Sir Alexander Fleming &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/the-real-story-behind-the-worlds-first-antibiotic/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;discovered&lt;/a&gt; penicillin - the world’s first antibiotic - in 1928, he revolutionized medicine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Since then, penicillin has saved countless lives as the bacteria-killer has been used to fight a wide range of infectious diseases that, until then, were incurable and deadly.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Today, penicillin-based antibiotics are still widely prescribed. In fact, a 2010 &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22711728&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; reported that amoxicillin was the most commonly dispensed drug among children around the world. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Recent studies, however, have been expressing concern over the long-term, negative effects of early-life exposure to penicillin.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Maternal intake of antibiotics has been &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nature.com/articles/doi:10.1038/ncomms15062&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;linked&lt;/a&gt; with a risk of asthma in children. Early-life exposure in offspring has been associated with allergies, obesity, and neurocognitive impairment in late adulthood.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers at St. Joseph’s Healthcare Hamilton and McMaster University - both in Ontario, Canada - set out to investigate the long-term effects of early-life exposure to penicillin in the offspring of mice.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study was &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nature.com/articles/doi:10.1038/ncomms15062&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;published&lt;/a&gt; in the journal Nature Communications.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Behavior, gut bacteria, and brain chemistry&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers found that penicillin had long-lasting effects on offspring.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Specifically, the mice treated with antibiotics showed a lower level of anxiety-like behavior as well as higher levels of social aggression.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The antibiotics seemed to affect both sexes equally, altering the gut bacteria and increasing the expression of cytokines in the mice’s frontal cortex. Cytokines help to control the body’s immune response. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Additionally, the antibiotic was found to alter the integrity of the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.brainfacts.org/brain-basics/neuroanatomy/articles/2014/blood-brain-barrier&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;blood-brain barrier&lt;/a&gt; - a semipermeable membrane barrier that separates the blood circulating in our body from the brain fluid and tissue. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. John Bienenstock, director of the Brain-Body Institute at St. Joseph’s Healthcare Hamilton and Distinguished Professor at McMaster University, explains the findings: &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In this paper, we report that low-dose penicillin taken late in pregnancy and in early life of mice offspring, changes behavior and the balance of microbes in the gut. While these studies have been performed in mice, they point to popular increasing concerns about the long-term effects of antibiotics. Furthermore, our results suggest that a probiotic might be effective in preventing the detrimental effects of the penicillin.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The scientists discovered that a probiotic supplementation protects against some of these modifications. The &lt;em&gt;Lactobacillus rhamnosus JB-1&lt;/em&gt; was found to partially counteract the antibiotics’ effect.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, the researchers concede that the sample size of the analyses for this was quite small, so the positive effects of the probiotic should be validated by further research. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Widespread exposure to antibiotics&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Bienenstock expressed concern over the widespread pediatric use of antibiotics.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There are almost no babies in North America that have not received a course of antibiotics in their first year of life,” he told Healthline. “Antibiotics are not only prescribed, but they are also found in meat and dairy products. If mothers are passing along the effects of these drugs to their as yet unborn children or children after birth, this raises further questions about the long-term effects of our society’s consumption of antibiotics.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the near future, the researchers plan to investigate the effects of penicillin on offspring when administered only to pregnant mothers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Additionally, the scientists hope to counter the negative behavioral effects of antibiotics with the help of beneficial bacteria, so they will test the efficacy of various bacteria in the offspring of mice.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
