</guid>
<dc:creator>Ana Sandoiu</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-03T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Immune System Research Could Bring New Treatments for MS, Diabetes
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/new-treatments-for-ms-and-diabetes
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/tech/040317_paralysisresearch_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In autoimmune disorders, malfunctioning immune cells turn against the body.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These cells attack the protective sheaths that surround neurons in the brain, which can eventually lead to a host of symptoms and conditions like paralysis, and in some cases be fatal. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Now, imagine if these wayward cells could be influenced to control the disease, rather than fuel it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Research presented today at a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.acs.org/content/acs/en/meetings/spring-2017.html?cid=home_meetings&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;meeting&lt;/a&gt; of the American Chemical Society (ACS) shows that it’s possible — and could be a game-changer — when it comes to treating autoimmune diseases like multiple sclerosis (MS) and type 1 diabetes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Current methods imprecise&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;While current immunotherapies can yield positive results, they tend to deal in broad strokes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This approach can affect and potentially compromise the entire immune system, rather than dealing with just the cells that are causing problems.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Christopher Jewell, PhD, associate professor in the bioengineering department at the University of Maryland, and lead researcher on the study released today, told Healthline that his team set out to develop a form of immunotherapy that specifically targeted the problematic cells, leaving the rest of the immune system alone.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We are working on autoimmune disease, where the body’s immune system mistakenly recognizes and attacks its own cells or tissues,” Jewell wrote in an email. “In multiple sclerosis, myelin — the matrix that insulates neurons — gets attacked by malfunctioning immune cells entering the brain. Existing therapies have been beneficial for patients, but are broadly acting, often leaving patients immunocompromised. So the drawbacks are that the therapies are not specific enough. They also require lifelong treatment and don’t cure disease or permanently stop progression.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;When good cells go bad&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;With autoimmune diseases, an immune cell can falsely recognize a beneficial antigen as a foreign invader. It’s then brought to the lymph nodes, where an immune cell known as a T cell attacks it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the case of MS patients, T cells attack the myelin sheath — the protective shield that surrounds neurons in the brain.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Because of the role the lymph node plays in this process, researchers targeted this area.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s in the lymph node that these myelin-specific cells decide how to respond to myelin once they leave the lymph node,” said Jewell. “Our idea was to inject degradable polymer particles directly into lymph nodes that slowly degrade in these tissues to release signals that tell the myelin-specific cells to become regulatory T cells that can control disease, instead of inflammatory T cells that drive disease.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Jewell says these polymer particles are loaded with myelin fragments along with low doses of regulatory drugs in order to change the way the cells respond to myelin.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;From there, these regulatory, beneficial T cells leave the lymph node and migrate to the brain to control the inflammatory T cells that are attacking the myelin sheath.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The particles are also just large enough to stop them from draining out of the lymph node, meaning the signals are able to not just influence existing cells but also the cells that are developing in the local tissue. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We want to try to locally program the function of lymph nodes, but still achieve a selective and system-wide therapeutic effect,” said Jewell. “This is different from other particle-based approaches being tested that involve systemic administration, such as IV, that exposes the entire host to the immunosuppresants and regulatory signals.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Other potential applications&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The research team found success with their methods.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The particle injections were able to return the power of movement to paralyzed mice.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The next steps for the researchers include testing their methods on other mice, such as those who have had transplants or type 1 diabetes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Later this year, they plan to collaborate with clinicians from the University of Maryland School of Medicine to perform tests on nonhuman primates.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This next round of testing will provide further insights, says Jewell.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Mouse models of MS recreate some features of human disease, but they also lack some of the important characteristics,” he said. “So testing in a setting that is closer to humans is important to understand the benefits and limitations of our idea.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If testing goes well, the plan is to eventually use this form of therapy for humans with autoimmune diseases like MS and type 1 diabetes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“One of our goals is to use this unique platform to study lymph node function and how best to promote tolerance, so we’re excited about the new insight we are contributing using intra-lymph node delivery of particles as a tool,” wrote Jewell. “Of course, we also hope to contribute to better options for patients and we are currently working in pre-clinical models of both MS and diabetes.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When asked where this technology could be 10 years from now, Jewell said that he hopes it not only leads to improved forms of immunotherapy but also a better understanding of how the lymph node functions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I hope that we’ve been able to use the unique control we have over the lymph node environment to give the field new information about how immune tolerance works,” he wrote. “The more knowledge we have in the field, the better chance we have for scientists and engineers to create more effective and selective treatments to stop autoimmune disease. We will also keep pushing forward on the therapeutic aspects to see if it might be translatable to humans.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Diabetes</category>
<category>Multiple Sclerosis</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-03T11:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-03T11:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/new-treatments-for-ms-and-diabetes
</guid>
<dc:creator>Dan Gray</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-03T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Is America Ready for Lab-Grown Meat?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/lab-grown-meat
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/food-fads/033017_labmeat_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Your next burger or chicken taco may soon come from a lab, not a farm.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lab-grown meat, or cultured meat, is gaining popularity and shelf space in American grocery stores.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And more brands are on their way.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In March, San Francisco-based &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.memphismeats.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Memphis Meats&lt;/a&gt; announced it had developed the first lab-grown chicken strips in the country. The chicken strips join the brand’s lab-grown meatballs, which they announced in February 2016.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Similarly, brands such as &lt;a href=&quot;http://beyondmeat.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Beyond Meat&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.impossiblefoods.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Impossible Foods&lt;/a&gt; have their meat-free, plant-based products in grocery stores and restaurants across the country.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How is meat grown?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Like the meatballs, the chicken strips are made with harvested animal cells.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Memphis Meats must use fetal serum, which is extracted from unborn calves and chicks. Proteins are added to the cells to promote tissue growth.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A structural support, much like a scaffold, is used to support the growth of the meat.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In many cases, the structural support is edible so the company doesn’t have to remove it before a consumer can eat it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Skeptical carnivores might be surprised to find that the product is quite similar to animal meat.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We are developing a new way to produce the delicious meat we’ve always enjoyed, without the need to feed, breed, and slaughter actual animals,” says Memphis Meats’ co-founder and chief executive officer, Dr. Uma Valeti. “We think this is an incredible business opportunity to transform a global industry that is nearing a trillion dollars, and at the same time improve the world.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And even though Memphis Meats’ products aren’t entirely animal-free, in the future, Valeti says the company hopes that will change.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our goal is to entirely remove the animal from the meat production process,” he says. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For now, the cost of production is prohibitive for the mainstream consumer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2016, Memphis Meats &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.wsj.com/articles/startup-to-serve-up-chicken-strips-cultivated-from-cells-in-lab-1489570202&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;told&lt;/a&gt; The Wall Street Journal it estimates one pound of chicken costs about $9,000 to produce.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Compare that to the national average for a pound of conventionally raised chicken, which is slightly more than &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.bls.gov/regions/mid-atlantic/data/AverageRetailFoodAndEnergyPrices_USandMidwest_Table.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;$3 per pound&lt;/a&gt;, so Memphis Meats has a lot of work to do if they want their lab-grown product to compete dollar for dollar. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We will be working over the next few years to lower the cost of production,” Valeti says. “We’re on a cost curve that is decreasing faster than we had imagined.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The company is targeting a 2021 launch date for consumer products.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Plant-based meat alternatives&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lab-grown meats aren’t the only new beefy game on the scene.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The rise of “bloody” vegetable burgers is giving traditional veggie burgers a run for their money.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Instead of patties of mushed-up beans, grains, and vegetables, companies are developing plant-based burgers that are virtually indistinguishable from their cow counterparts in look, aroma, and taste.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The first one of these meat-like veggie burgers is available now.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Beyond Burger from Beyond Meat is made from 100 percent plant proteins and it packs in 20 grams of protein per 4-ounce serving. That’s one gram more than a traditional beef patty of the same size.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The patties are also GMO-free, soy-free, and gluten-free, and have almost half the saturated fat of traditional beef.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Many grocery stores will even place the new plant-based patties right alongside traditional patties to persuade consumers to pick up the new product.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“An animal is doing the same thing,” Ethan Brown, chief executive officer of Beyond Meat, explained. “They’re taking an enormous amount of plant matter, they’re running it through the digestive system, they’re converting that into muscle or meat. We’re taking plant matter as well, we’re picking the amino acids, fats, minerals, and of course the water, and we’re assembling those in the same architecture to the extent that we can that’s present in meat. My argument is that this really is meat. It’s just meat that’s coming directly from plants, instead of being run through an animal.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Brown said it’s just a different route along the same path.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The demand for alternative proteins&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Americans aren’t giving up their meat anytime soon.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Last year, the average American ate 90 pounds of chicken and 55 pounds of beef.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The meat industry in the United States brings in more than &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.meatinstitute.org/index.php?ht=d/sp/i/47465/pid/47465&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;$864 billion a year&lt;/a&gt; and employs 6.2 million people. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Demand for alternative proteins, however, may still shake up the industry.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to Lux Research, the demand for alternative proteins will double by 2024.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That means the global supply chain will need to keep up with the growing demand, and the current animal options may be unable to outpace the animal-free alternatives.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Consumers are also becoming more aware of the global impact traditional animal meats can have. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Limited resources like water and land may become tapped out as supply grows. Products that don’t need as much water or land may gain the upper hand in the protein fight.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;But are Americans ready?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The answer is absolutely “Yes,” if you ask Ethan Brown. “The uptick in consumer interest is unreal. When I started the business in 2009, it was much more of a push where we had to do a lot of convincing to consumers,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It may be a matter of education.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;div class=&quot;hl-poll&quot; style=&quot;float: right; margin: 10px;&quot;&gt; &lt;script type=&quot;text/javascript&quot; charset=&quot;utf-8&quot; src=&quot;http://static.polldaddy.com/p/9712961.js&quot;&gt;&lt;/script&gt; &lt;noscript&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://polldaddy.com/poll/9712961/&quot;&gt;Would you try a burger with lab-grown meat?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/noscript&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think what’s happening is there’s just a large number of Americans that are hearing from multiple sources the benefits of consuming plant-based proteins,” Brown said. “All of these studies are continually coming at people, and then you have an increasing awareness of the role of animal protein in global warming, climate change, and that public psyche continues to occur. We benefit from that.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Valeti says the time for his company’s cultured meat is now.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In recent polls, a majority of consumers say that they will eat clean meat. We’ve also seen some clear early adopter segments that are ready to buy our products as soon as possible, even at a price premium,” he said. “This is all before we’ve had a meaningful chance to educate consumers on the benefits of clean meat. So, we are certain that the winds are blowing in our favor.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Food and Nutrition</category>
<pubdate>2017-04-03T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-04-03T10:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/lab-grown-meat
</guid>
<dc:creator>Kim Holland</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-03T17:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Will Technology Replace Good, Old-Fashioned Exercise?
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/will-technology-replace-exercise
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/040217_exercisetech_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;With smart appliances, cameras, phones, and even social robots making it into our high-tech world, it seems plausible that we'll also turn to tech solutions to perform exercise for us.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At least that’s what a new &lt;a href=&quot;https://academic.oup.com/endo/article-abstract/doi/10.1210/en.2016-1250/3070534/Whole-body-vibration-mimics-the-metabolic-effects?redirectedFrom=fulltext&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; published in the journal Endocrinology suggests. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study conducted on obese mice reports that whole body vibration (WBV) may be as effective as regular exercise when it comes to benefiting muscles and bone health, and combatting some of the negative effects of obesity and diabetes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;During WBV, you sit, stand, or lie on a machine that has a vibrating platform. When the machine vibrates, it transmits energy to the body causing the muscles to contract and relax multiple times during each second.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The science on WBV is sound. When you vibrate on a platform, the platform causes your muscles to contract almost like you're moving but you’re not,” Pete McCall, adjunct faculty of exercise science at Mesa College in San Diego, Calif., told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For people who are overweight and have difficulty moving, McCall said WBV is a good start. “But like any other form of exercise you’re going to have a finite wall. There will be a point where your body adapts to it and another unit of that exercise isn’t going to provide your body significant benefits,” he added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Still a need for movement&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;No matter how much technology makes its way into fitness, the body still needs to move, said McCall. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Think of your heart and your circulatory system like the engine in a car, he said. If you leave your car in the backyard for 30 years, it’s going to fall apart, but if you turn it on a few times a month, it will remain drivable.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The body is the same way,” McCall explained. “You can't just leave your body sitting in the backyard, so to speak. It will deteriorate. Your heart is like the engine, so when you move, your heart pumps blood around the working muscles. By moving, you’re making your heart more effective at getting blood, oxygen, and nutrients to your muscles.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Karen Lawson, IEEE senior member and senior director of design technology, agreed, pointing to data tracking technology that is widely used to track miles run, steps taken, calories eaten, and more. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Think Fitbit, Apple Watch, MyFitnessPal, and beyond.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While technology helps to quantify fitness goals and motivate people to refine their workouts and diet, Lawson said moving is essential. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Being a passive participant will still not result in achieving health-related or physique goals without moving the body. Also, it can be discouraging to see the slow pace of results for someone constantly checking in. It confirms there is still no ‘quick fix’ to years of sedentary behavior or poor diet,” she told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The future of fitness&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;If fitness technology isn't going to exercise for us, what will it do? McCall and Lawson see the future of technology making an impact on fitness in several ways. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Fit equals cheaper health insurance&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt; While McCall and Lawson believe the number of wearable fitness trackers and tracking apps will continue to increase, McCall sees them taking on a different role in health. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“These are useful for tracking data, but until health insurance companies start giving you a discount based on how active you are on a daily basis, the data we collect on our activity is irrelevant,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He pointed out that some organizations are starting to give employees extra bonuses, credits, or money toward health insurance premiums if the employee achieves a minimal amount of activity per quarter.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For instance, the insurance provider UnitedHealthcare has teamed up with the technology company Qualcomm to develop trackers. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s already happening. I can see it being common that in order to get the best rates from your health provider you’ll have to upload your tracker information once a month or quarter to show how much you are exercising,” McCall said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Smart fabrics will get smarter&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt; Over the next decade, Lawson thinks smart fabrics will include sensing capabilities that allow users to augment the monitoring and performance of their activity.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“While such fabrics exist today and are making their way into commercialized products, the cost and durability will only continue to improve and therefore these will be driven into the apparel and accessory market globally,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;In-home advancements&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt; Our fast-paced lives will drive in-home fitness technology, including the ability to stream workouts from your home, said McCall. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Daily Burn does this with Daily 365. You can be in Chicago and do a live class with an instructor in Manhattan. That type of in-home technology will be big,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The last five years, we had boutique studios like Cross Fit, Orangetheory, and SoulCycle really infringe on traditional health club space, but the next five years, I can see people saying why pay $25 per class at a boutique studio when I can pay that per month for a say, Daily Burn membership and do it at home?”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Human interaction trumps technology&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;With a lot of technology in our lives, McCall believes most people like their exercise as low tech as possible. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There is kind of saturation point where we just want to go to the gym and work out and forget the downloading and uploading of this and that. It gives us a chance to step away from the screen for an hour or so and maybe connect with friends and those we work out with in the meantime,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Going back to the basics of movement is always a sure thing, he added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Let's face it, Cross Fit got huge, but it has you run around the block. They've gone to the basics. Instead of buying an $8,000 treadmill, they have you flipping over 300-pound car tires, or instead of being on an expensive elliptical runner, you're doing jump ropes in your garage,” McCall said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Still, there’s no denying people will continue to seek out tech solutions for exercise, noted Lawson. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“But … the trend of changing how fitness is achieved, having more fun, and developing new behaviors around ‘gamification’ of exercise is hopefully resulting in more positive results beyond the body image,” she said. “The holistic benefit of human movement, e.g., experiencing the beauty of a hike, coupled with the technology support to quantify your improved behaviors promises more sustainable health improvements.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<updateddate>2017-04-02T06:00:00</updateddate>

<dc:creator>Cathy Cassata</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-04-02T13:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>
Antibody May Help Deliver Better Prognosis, Treatments for Rheumatoid Arthritis
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/antibody-helps-prognosis-treatments-for-rheumatoid-arthritis
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/arthritis/040117_RAtherapies_THUMB_LARGE.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&g
]]>
<![CDATA[
t;&lt;p&gt;Rheumatoid arthritis is a painful, debilitating autoimmune disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That makes it a difficult condition to treat.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But now, researchers have found that &lt;a href=&quot;http://ard.bmj.com/content/early/2017/03/22/annrheumdis-2016-210873&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;specific antibodies&lt;/a&gt; in certain people with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) may provide more treatment options and a better outlook for people with the disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In some — but not all — people with RA, there are antibodies formed that target a protein in joint cartilage called collagen II. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These antibodies often play a role in increasing inflammation in the earlier stages of RA.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Potentially better outcomes&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the past, researchers have concluded that the highest amounts of collagen antibodies are usually detected at the time of an RA diagnosis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These levels most often decrease during the first year of RA disease activity.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But a recent study out of Uppsala University in Sweden concluded that antibodies against the cartilage protein collagen II are associated with a good outlook.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers said people with RA who have more of these antibodies often do better when it comes to treatments, the management of symptoms, and how disabling their symptoms become.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This study followed a group of people with RA over the course of five years to look at the suspected correlation between collagen antibodies and disease advancement.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;What they found could prove vital as a prognostic tool and help to further individualize and implement targeted treatments. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Analyzing these antibodies, in combination with other relevant antibodies, could be used for predicting prognosis and choosing therapy for rheumatoid arthritis patients,” Dr. Johan Ronnelid, lead researcher on the study, said in a press release.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Vivek Anand Manivel, a PhD student at the Department of Immunology, Genetics and Pathology, and a lead author of the study, also offered a public statement to the press: “We found that patients with collagen antibodies showed increased signs of inflammation during the first six months after diagnosis, after this there was no difference compared to patients without any collagen antibodies. We also discovered that the presence of collagen antibodies at the time of diagnosis was associated with a better prognosis.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The significance of the research&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;What this means for people with RA is that treatments may become better-tailored to them moving forward, depending on the antibody presence and activity.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;RA is a complex disease that manifests itself differently from person to person.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Since disease activity is so unpredictable, any assistance in figuring out prognosis or a better therapeutic approach could be of importance to the rheumatology community. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In all, our findings suggest that a combined analysis of antibodies against collagen and antibodies against citrullinated peptides could be a new tool for predicting the disease course and perhaps also for choosing therapy in newly diagnosed RA patients,” said Ronnelid.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Currently, anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) is often used as an indicator for RA disease activity, alongside rheumatoid factors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Now, doctors can look at the collagen II antibodies as well when determining disease severity and thus, a more robust and detailed plan for treatment and disease management.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Arthritis</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-31T15:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-31T15:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/antibody-helps-prognosis-treatments-for-rheumatoid-arthritis
</guid>
<dc:creator>Ashley Boynes-Shuck</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-31T22:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
New Documentary Details ‘Largest Health Cover-up of Our Time’
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/documentary-details-largest-health-cover-up
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/033117_healthdocu_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&
]]>
<![CDATA[
lt;p&gt;The typical American diet is the number one cause of deadly and chronic illnesses in this country.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, the companies that produce some of the food products Americans eat aren’t likely to try to help reduce these serious problems.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And don’t look for assistance from government agencies and some of our best-known health-related organizations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They have conflicts of interest because they receive funding from the meat, dairy, and pharmaceutical industries.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s the main premise of a new documentary that premiered online last week.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“&lt;a href=&quot;https://vimeo.com/ondemand/whatthehealth/203617202&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;What The Health&lt;/a&gt;,” which is streaming now on Vimeo, seems to have garnered early attention.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The hour-and-a-half long documentary was the top trending video on Vimeo On Demand in the first few days after its release on Mar. 22.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Filmmaker Kip Andersen was not available this week for an interview, but in press materials he said the documentary “reveals possibly the largest health cover-up of our time.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Officials at some of the organizations criticized in Andersen’s film are not impressed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They accuse Andersen of cherry-picking studies and ignoring the importance of industry-funded research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There’s no doubt that poor diet and lack of exercise can lead to various health problems, including heart disease and type 2 diabetes,” Greg Miller, PhD, FACN, chief science officer for the National Dairy Council, told Healthline in an email. “People want to do their best when choosing a healthy diet, but so much information — and misinformation — makes it hard to know who and what to believe. That’s why it’s unfortunate when films such as ‘What the Health’ misrepresent sound nutrition science.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What the documentary entails&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Andersen begins his film by discussing how his family medical history got him interested in the topic.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Like a lot of Americans, I have a family history of diabetes, heart disease, and cancer, so it was important to me to learn more,” Andersen, who co-directed “What the Health” with Keegan Kuhn, said in a press statement.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Andersen proceeds to detail the health hazards of some of the favorite foods in the United States, citing numerous studies along the way.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He says meat, in particular processed meats, is a major cause of cancer and cardiovascular disease. This includes all meat products from beef to chicken to turkey to even fish. Chicken, he points out, is the top producer of cholesterol in Americans’ diets.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Andersen, who also made the film “&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cowspiracy.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Cowspiracy&lt;/a&gt;,” then goes after the dairy industry.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He says the health risks of products such as milk, cheese, and eggs have been underplayed. He states that eggs are pure fat and cholesterol.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Andersen then checks the websites of some of the country’s major organizations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He says the American Cancer Society has no warning about meat on its site and even has suggested &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cancer.org/healthy/eat-healthy-get-active/eat-healthy/find-healthy-recipes.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;recipes&lt;/a&gt; that include processed meat.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Andersen also finds &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.diabetes.org/mfa-recipes/recipes/?referrer=https://www.google.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;recipes&lt;/a&gt; for meat dishes on the American Diabetes Association website.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are also “heart healthy” &lt;a href=&quot;https://recipes.heart.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;recipes&lt;/a&gt; for beef dishes on the American Heart Association website.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Andersen also notes the &lt;a href=&quot;http://ww5.komen.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Susan G. Komen foundation&lt;/a&gt; has no warning about dairy products on its site even though he quotes research linking dairy products to breast cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Andersen calls each of the organizations for an explanation but does not get answers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He finally lines up an interview with an official at the American Diabetes Association. That interview ends with the official walking out of the room.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After feeling stonewalled, Andersen goes online and looks up the funding sources for these various organizations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He finds each of them has a long list of corporate sponsors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The American Diabetes Association receives support from &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.stopdiabetes.com/sponsors/dannon-light-fit-greek.html?loc=stopd-findoutmore?referrer=https://www.google.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Dannon&lt;/a&gt; yogurt, among others.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The American Cancer Society receives support from &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.tysonfoods.com/we-care/communities/community-projects/washington&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Tyson Foods&lt;/a&gt;, among others.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Susan G. Komen foundation receives support from &lt;a href=&quot;http://abcnews.go.com/Health/Wellness/kfc-fights-breast-cancer-fried-chicken/story?id=10458830&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Kentucky Fried Chicken&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.generalmills.com/2014/10/a-new-way-to-help-women-battling-breast-cancer/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Yoplait&lt;/a&gt;, among others.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And the American Heart Association receives support from the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.progressivecattle.com/news/industry-news/5515-beef-and-heart-health-a-healthy-partnership&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Texas Beef Council&lt;/a&gt;, among others.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He adds that the organizations also receive funding from the pharmaceutical industry.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Andersen points out the federal commission that formulates &lt;a href=&quot;https://health.gov/dietaryguidelines/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;U.S. dietary guidelines&lt;/a&gt; every five years is filled with members who have received corporate support.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;During the course of the film, Andersen interviews a dozen people in health-related fields including physicians and dietitians.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He also profiles three people with chronic illnesses near the end of the documentary who are faring better after two weeks of cutting out medications and eating a more plant-based diet.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The start of a healthy debate?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kurt Mosley, the vice president of strategic alliances for Merritt Hawkins health consultants, said the documentary brings up several important points.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The first is the unhealthy aspects of the average American diet.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think that is key,” Mosley told Healthline. “It’s our fast food diet.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He does disagree with the filmmaker’s contention that eating well is cheaper than eating poorly.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I try to eat healthy and it’s expensive,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mosley said the potential conflicts between the health organizations and industry are interesting, but he’d like to know exactly what support they’re getting, what percentage of their budget comes from those sources, and who else provides backing.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I’d like to see what sponsorship is across the board,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mosley said one of the big “takeaways” from the film is the point that many organizations try to help people cope with a disease, as opposed to preventing it either through lifestyle or medical advances.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We need to cure diseases rather than live with them,” he said. “We need to advise people on how to take better care of themselves.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mosley said this is a prime topic when he discusses poverty’s effect on healthcare with various groups.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Overall, he said the documentary could serve as an impetus for discussion of all these important issues.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This is really good as a start,” he said. “We have to start the conversation.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Criticism, concerns&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Representatives from some of the organizations highlighted in the film are criticizing Andersen’s film for a number of reasons.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Suzanne Grant, vice president of media relations and issues management at the American Heart Association, said her organization’s recommendations on diet have always followed a “rigorous, systematic review system of the best available scientific information.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She said the association’s most recent &lt;a href=&quot;http://circ.ahajournals.org/content/circulationaha/129/25_suppl_2/S76.full.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;lifestyle guidelines&lt;/a&gt;, for example, recommend that adults follow a diet that emphasizes vegetables, fruits, and whole grains. It also includes low-fat dairy products, poultry, and fish, and suggests limiting red meat as well as products laden with sugar and salt.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As for the recipes on the association site, Grant said it’s part of the organization’s goal of “meeting people where they are.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“A vegan or vegetarian dining pattern is not the dominant one in the U.S. today,” Grant said. “While we recommend that adults who could benefit from lowering their LDL cholesterol or their blood pressure should limit their red meat intake, we also recognize that red meat is a common feature of the American diet, and we urge all Americans to make informed choices to follow the recommended overall heart-healthy dietary pattern noted above if they choose to eat meat.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She added that nearly 80 percent of the American Heart Association’s revenue comes from sources other than corporations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Grant noted that the association is transparent about the money it receives from industry.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Financial support from a wide variety of corporations from across the country helps us achieve our goals of improving the cardiovascular health of all Americans and saving more lives,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Officials at the American Cancer Society had a similar reaction.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They point out they have a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cancer.org/healthy/eat-healthy-get-active/acs-guidelines-nutrition-physical-activity-cancer-prevention/common-questions.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;detailed list&lt;/a&gt; of dietary and lifestyle guidelines on their site.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Included in those guidelines are warnings about potential cancer risks with processed meats.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Officials add the nonprofit organization has participated in &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15644544&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;studies&lt;/a&gt; that have shown a link between red meat and cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Critics also noted that Andersen uses only one study to link dairy to breast cancer when there is &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Alicja_Wolk/publication/11450806_Meat_and_dairy_food_consumption_and_breast_cancer_A_pooled_analysis_of_cohort_studies/links/02e7e526eb8b3dd3b6000000.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;other research&lt;/a&gt; concluding there is no link.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Miller, of the National Dairy Council, said the documentary’s statements about healthy eating and dairy foods “are not supported by the science community.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said there are numerous ways to build a healthy diet.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dairy foods, he added, “play an essential role due to their unique set of &lt;a href=&quot;https://dairygood.org/content/2017/is-milk-good-for-you&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;nine essential nutrients&lt;/a&gt;.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nationaldairycouncil.org/content/2016/science-brief-whole-and-reduced-fat-dairy-foods&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;emerging research&lt;/a&gt; shows that dairy foods like milk, cheese, and yogurt are associated with a reduced risk of type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Miller also dismissed the notion that any research funded by industry is biased.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The assumption that research sponsored by industry which shows a favorable outcome is biased is disappointing to say the least,” said Miller. “What people may not realize is that without funding from industry, high-caliber research may not be possible. By focusing on funding bias, we risk dismissing what are potentially important contributions to scientific literature.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said the dairy council sponsors research at national and international universities that adheres to scientific principles.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“That’s why it’s important to look beyond the funding acknowledgements and make sure the research is rigorous and not biased toward outcomes to determine how it fits in the totality of science,” Miller said.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Public Policy</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-31T11:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-31T11:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/documentary-details-largest-health-cover-up
</guid>
<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-31T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Health Effects From Light Exposure Can Be Passed on to Children
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/light-exposure-can-be-passed-to-children
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/topic_centers/033117_lightexposure_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Over recent years, it has become clear that exposure to light during the night can have a negative impact on health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Now, a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.newswise.com/articles/harms-of-nighttime-light-exposure-passed-to-offspring&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;new study&lt;/a&gt; released today finds that these negative consequences may even be passed on to our children.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Modern society is bathed in light; a far cry from our evolutionary beginnings in the darkness of the African night.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Today, we rarely move more than 1 or 2 meters from a glowing screen. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers are slowly untangling the effect that this might be having on our minds and bodies. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Studies have shown that dim light exposure during naturally dark hours is linked to various health problems, &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3002207/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;including some cancers&lt;/a&gt; and diabetes. So, should we ditch our computers, televisions, and cell phones after dark?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Building on past research&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The new study, published in Scientific Reports, concludes that exposure to light at nighttime might not just affect us – it might impact our future children’s health, too. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The new findings come from The Ohio State University.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers knew from earlier studies that stressors could cause hormone disruptions in adult mice, altering their physiology and behaviour.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They also knew from their own previous research that animals exposed to light during dark hours showed a &lt;a href=&quot;http://rsbl.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/early/2011/01/21/rsbl.2010.1108&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;reduction in their immune response&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Similarly, they also found that, by disrupting circadian rhythms – which are daily sleep/wake cycles – dim light at night &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23929553&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;increased the body weight&lt;/a&gt; of mice.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The scientists – led by Yasmine Cisse, a graduate student, and Randy Nelson, professor and chair of neuroscience at Ohio State’s Wexner Medical Center – set out to build on these earlier results.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They designed a study to investigate whether parents could pass these deficits on to their offspring via epigenetic changes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Epigenetics describe genetic changes other than alterations in the actual sequence of the DNA; they are changes in the way that genes are expressed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For instance, some lifestyle choices, such as smoking, can cause certain sections of DNA to be switched on or off. These changes can then be passed to offspring while maintaining the exact same genetic code.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The impact of nocturnal light&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Investigating how nocturnal light interferes with general health is a difficult task because disturbed sleep can have a negative impact on health, separate from the effects of light exposure at night.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It is necessary to tease apart the effects of nocturnal illumination and sleep disturbance.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To tackle this problem, the team chose to use Siberian hamsters, a naturally nocturnal animal. In this way, they could measure the impact of light exposure during the night without directly affecting their sleep quality.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The team exposed the hamsters (male and female) to two lighting regimes for nine weeks: either a standard light day and dark night cycle, or dim light during the night.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The hamsters were then allowed to mate before being returned to standard light conditions. The next generation of hamsters were all raised in standard light conditions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Upon examination, the researchers found that the offspring of parents exposed to a dim light at night did indeed have measurable immune and endocrine impairments.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The importance of light pollution&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;It appeared that both mothers and fathers independently passed these deficits on to their offspring. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This is important, as Nelson explains: “These weren’t problems that developed in utero. They came from the sperm and the egg. It’s much more common to see epigenetic effects from the mothers, but we saw changes passed on from the fathers as well.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cisse says: “This suggests that circadian disruptions can have long-ranging effects in offspring and that’s concerning.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Specifically, the hamsters whose parents had been exposed to light at night displayed a reduction in immune response when faced with a foreign substance.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They also noticed changes in the genetic activity of the spleen: hormone receptors for melatonin and glucocorticoids were reduced in number.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That such a simple intervention could cause a significant response was quite surprising to the researchers. As the authors note: “These data demonstrate that a seemingly innocuous stimulus – dim light exposure at night – is sufficient to induce transgenerational effects on physiology.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nelson believes that “people are beginning to accept that light pollution is serious pollution and it has health consequences that are pretty pronounced – an increase in cancers, depression, cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and anxiety disorders.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These findings will need to be replicated in humans, but the message is that the technology that we are surrounded by may be negatively impacting our body’s ability to fight disease.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Children's Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-31T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-31T10:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>

</guid>
<dc:creator>Tim Newman</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-31T17:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>Prince’s Former Drummer Keeps His Heart Healthy</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/princes-former-drummer-keeps-his-heart-healthy
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/heart-health/033117_princedrummer_THUMB_LARGE.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In September, Bobby Z. bid an emotional farewell to his former bandmate Prince.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;His tribute was delivered inside First Avenue, the legendary Minneapolis nightclub where the two musicians performed in the 1984 movie “Purple Rain.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Two months later, Bobby came all too close to becoming the subject of a memorial concert himself.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Six years after suffering his first heart attack, the veteran musician suffered another when a coronary stent in his artery became dislodged.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This time, I was lucky to recognize the [heart attack] symptoms,” said Bobby, who was drummer for Prince and The Revolution, which disbanded in 1986. “If I hadn’t been stabilized, it probably would have killed me. This could have been the big one.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Rhythms of the heart&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;For better and worse, Bobby has become almost as well versed in heart attack symptoms as he is in drum rhythms.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2010, after experiencing severe pain shooting though his elbows, he suffered his first heart attack, the result of severely blocked arteries. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After having three stents inserted and enduring a long recovery process, Bobby became an American Heart Association (AHA) volunteer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He also launched his own heart-health awareness charity, My Purple Heart, a twist on the title of the Prince song and the “Purple Rain” movie.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After his first heart attack, Bobby reformed Prince’s old band, The Revolution, to support My Purple Heart with &lt;a href=&quot;http://first-avenue.com/event/2013/03/heartbenefit&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;“Benefit 2 Celebrate Life” concerts&lt;/a&gt; in 2011, 2012 and 2013. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Although the Purple One didn’t perform at those shows, he was “supportive on every level,” Bobby said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Prince was the first one to call my wife when I was in the hospital. He was a great supporter of my recovery and encouraged me to do the My Purple Heart shows. He gave us the blessing to use The Revolution name and do the shows under the AHA flag,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Then suddenly last April, Prince was gone.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The 57-year-old musical pioneer died at his Minneapolis home of an accidental overdose of the opiod painkiller fentanyl.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It was an ironic ending since Prince was one of the few rock stars who publicly disavowed all drugs and alcohol.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“To see the words ‘Prince Dead’ on television was absolutely unfathomable,” Bobby said. “I thought he’d be 99 years old, sitting on a stool, ripping on guitar. I never, ever dreamed he would go at such a young age. It’s a profound loss to the world. He was a living human mystery who would literally perform musical magic in front of your face.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Recognizing the signs&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Last November – just two months after the Revolution reunited to pay tribute to their late bandleader – Bobby began experiencing mild acid reflux during a child’s birthday party at a friend’s house.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That night, the reflux worsened.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I instinctively took (nitroglycerin) and an aspirin and knew I had to get to the hospital,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;His instincts were spot-on: Nausea, vomiting and digestive conditions such as acid reflux can be warning signs of heart trouble.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Thanks to his instinctive actions, Bobby was already at the hospital when he suffered a heart attack. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Today, he credits cardiologist Dr. Steven Heifetz and the staff of Fairview Southdale Hospital in suburban Minneapolis for saving his life.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We thought everything was great, and then the heart attack came out of nowhere,” said Vicki Rivkin, Bobby’s wife. “Bobby takes his health very seriously and he got to that hospital very quickly. It’s important to be safe, don’t hesitate, and call 911 right away.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Today, after a surgery to insert a newer-model stent, Bobby is doing fine, and he monitors his cholesterol religiously.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In 2011, I thought I was good-to-go for life. But it’s an evolving culture in your heart. You’re never really out of the woods,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I have very stubborn cholesterol and it seems the plumbing can still get clogged. My message now is that cholesterol numbers that are normal for normal people have to be much lower for people with a heart attack history.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A healthy lifestyle&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Bobby maintains a heart-healthy diet, doesn’t drink alcohol, and exercises several times a week at his local gym. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The stubborn reality of motivating yourself to exercise is the key to survival, the key to having the drugs work and having everything flow the way it should,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“My other message is that if you miss your exercise for a week or a month, you shouldn’t punish yourself mentally. You just have to get back on it and not beat yourself up about it.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While he continues to get stronger, Bobby is slowly resuming his musical career.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He’s planning a series of April concerts by The Revolution at &lt;a href=&quot;https://officialpaisleypark.com/pages/celebration2017&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Celebration 2017&lt;/a&gt;, a four-day event in Minneapolis marking the first anniversary of Prince’s death.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He’s also plotting another AHA “Benefit 2 Celebrate Life” concert for early 2018 before Super Bowl LII, which will be played at U.S. Bank Stadium in Minneapolis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We’re taking it slow. We’re still grieving and we’re still in a very fragile, strange world without Prince,” Bobby said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“But as Prince said, music is like medicine to people. There’s this huge hole, but when you play ‘Purple Rain’ live, you see the look on people’s faces, and you see it really helps. They’ll never get over (his loss), but at least the music helps them deal with it.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;The &lt;/em&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/revolution-drummer-bobby-z-had-a-heart-attack-soon-after-bidding-farewell-to-prince/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;original story&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;em&gt; was published on &lt;/em&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;American Heart Association News&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/em&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-03-30T13:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-30T13:00:00</updateddate>

<dc:creator>American Heart Association News</dc:creator>

<item>
<title>
Venom from Fanged Fish Could Become New Pain Medication
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/fanged-fish-venom-for-pain-medication
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/032917_fishvenom_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The next time you are in pain, you might want to think of a “fanged fish” that lives in the Great Barrier Reef off Australia.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The venom from that fish might eventually become a new painkiller that is less addictive than some of the prescription opioids available.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The announcement of the fish’s heroin-like venom is the latest in a burgeoning new field of research in which natural toxins from fish and animals are being sought as alternatives on our list of pain medications.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There’s definitely a big need for medications like this,” said Dr. Kiran Rajneesh, a neurologist with a specialty in pain management at The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center, who was not involved in the current study.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The research findings were published today in the journal Current Biology.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The fish in question&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The research was led by Bryan Fry, PhD, an associate professor of evolutionary biology, genetics, and molecular biology at the University of Queensland in Australia.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Fry told Healthline he became interested in the topic because he’s had 24 broken bones during his lifetime.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said he’s taken numerous pain medications over the years, becoming addicted to both Vicodin and &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.healthline.com/drugs/hydromorphone/oral-tablet#Highlights1&quot;&gt;hydromorphone&lt;/a&gt; at different times.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;His current research focused on the fang blenny, an aggressive fish found in the Pacific Ocean, including Australia’s coral reefs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The fang blenny injects other fish with an opioid peptide that acts like heroin or morphine. It causes both predators and prey to slow down and become dizzy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The venom is absolutely unique,” Fry said. “We’ve never seen anything like it.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Injecting the pure venom into a person would cause similar adverse effects. However, Fry said, researchers can study the venom’s peptides further to see if it could be developed into a new type of pain medication.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This may reveal versions that are longer lasting, more potent, or with less side effects [than other opioids],” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;New field of research&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Rajneesh said the idea of using fish venom as a painkiller is quite plausible.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He told Healthline there is growing interest in his field in utilizing natural toxins as opposed to those that are chemically produced.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said toxins from plants and animals tend to be less addictive, last longer, and have fewer side effects than current pain medications.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said one of the drawbacks of the natural toxins is that the human body can react negatively to foreign proteins and other substances that enter their realm.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The field has had some successes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One of the best known is &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cancer.gov/publications/dictionaries/cancer-terms?cdrid=644300&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;botulinum toxin&lt;/a&gt;, a neurotoxin produced by a bacterium that by itself is the most poisonous known biological substance. However, a purified version of it is used to make Botox.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Rajneesh said he uses a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.uwmedicine.org/health-library/Pages/tissue-plasminogen-activator-tpa.aspx&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)&lt;/a&gt; to treat stroke victims. That medication was derived from a snake venom.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There’s also an experimental drug made from the venom of a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/health/snail-venom-explored-new-pain-medication-article-1.1724101&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;sea snail&lt;/a&gt; in Australia that has shown promise as a pain medication.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We’ve derived some great uses from these substances,” he said. “Nature is really the best designer.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Fry said these and other discoveries show the importance of preserving the environment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This is why we must urgently protect all of nature. It is impossible to predict where the next wonder drug will come from,” he said.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-03-30T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-30T10:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/fanged-fish-venom-for-pain-medication
</guid>
<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-30T17:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Older Women With Gum Disease Face Higher Risk of Death
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/older-women-with-gum-disease-risk-death
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/womens-health/032917_gumdisease_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Researchers have concluded that women who have a history of gum disease or who have lost all of their natural teeth are at a greater risk of death from all causes. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The scientists analysed data from more than 57,000 women aged 55 or older to reach their conclusions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Michael J. LaMonte, Ph.D., a study co-author and associate professor of epidemiology and environmental health at the University at Buffalo in New York, and his colleagues recently published their findings today in the Journal of the American Heart Association (JAMA).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), gum disease – also known as periodontal disease – affects &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/oralhealth/periodontal_disease/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;47 percent&lt;/a&gt; of adults aged 30 and above in the United States.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The risk of gum disease also rises with age. About 70 percent of adults aged 65 and older have the condition.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Bad breath, red, swollen, or bleeding gums, and sensitive teeth are common signs of gum disease. The condition is also a key cause of tooth loss.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Between 2011 and 2012, almost &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/products/databriefs/db197.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;19 percent&lt;/a&gt; of adults aged 65 and older in the U.S. had complete tooth loss, or edentulism, with many cases caused by gum disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Poor dental health and mortality&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Previous &lt;a href=&quot;http://iai.asm.org/content/early/2015/08/11/IAI.00498-15.abstract&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;studies&lt;/a&gt; have associated both gum disease and tooth loss with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, LaMonte and colleagues note that these studies have a number of limitations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Few studies have included older adults or specifically women, and in those that have, inconsistent results were reported,” they write.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With this in mind, the team set out to gain a better understanding of how gum disease and tooth loss might impact the risk of CVD and mortality among older women.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To reach their findings, the researchers analyzed the data of 57,001 women aged between 50 and 89 years who were enrolled in the Women’s Health Initiative Observational Study between 1993 and 1998.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;History of gum disease, tooth loss, and frequency of dental visits were assessed using a follow-up questionnaire, conducted between 1998 and 2003.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Over an average 6.7 years of follow-up, the researchers identified 3,589 CVD events and 3,816 deaths among the women.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Tooth loss may raise death risk&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Compared with women without a history of gum disease, those with a history of the condition were found to have a 12 percent increased risk of death from all causes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This greater risk remained even after accounting for the frequency of visits to the dentist, the team reported.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Furthermore, the researchers found that women with complete tooth loss had a 17 percent increased risk of all-cause death, compared with women without edentulism.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Edentulism was most common among women who were older, less educated, and who visited the dentist less frequently.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;No association was found between gum disease, tooth loss, and risk of CVD.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers note that their study is purely observational, so it is unable to establish cause and effect between poor dental health and increased risk of death.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Still, they believe that their results warrant further investigation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&quot;Our findings suggest that older women may be at higher risk for death because of their periodontal condition and may benefit from more intensive oral screening measures,&quot; said LaMonte. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&quot;However, studies of interventions aimed at improving periodontal health are needed to determine whether risk of death is lowered among those receiving the intervention compared to those who do not.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Senior Health</category>
<category>Women's Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-29T13:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-29T13:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/older-women-with-gum-disease-risk-death
</guid>
<dc:creator>Honor Whiteman</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-29T20:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>New Drug to Treat MS Gets FDA Approval</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/new-multiple-sclerosis-drug-awaits-approval
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/060116_msmutation_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Fo
]]>
<![CDATA[
od and Drug Administration (FDA) has given people with multiple sclerosis some hope.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On Wednesday, FDA officials &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.fda.gov/NewsEvents/Newsroom/PressAnnouncements/ucm549325.htm&quot;&gt;announced&lt;/a&gt; the agency has approved a new drug to treat adults who have the relapsing form of multiple sclerosis (MS) as well as primary progressive MS (PPMS).&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It's the first drug approved for treatment of PPMS.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The drug, Ocrevus&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: 13.6px;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;(ocrelizumab), is an intravenous infusion given by a medical professional.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The approval is especially good news for those with progressive types of MS who have not found a drug that has worked to reduce flares, improve symptoms, or slow disease progression.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nationalmssociety.org/What-is-MS/MS-FAQ-s&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;National Multiple Sclerosis Society&lt;/a&gt;, 2.3 million people worldwide are living with the disease. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Now, for the first time, people with PPMS may benefit from what officials at Roche Pharmaceuticals have called a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.roche.com/media/store/releases/med-cor-2016-12-20.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;medical breakthrough&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a large phase III trial, Ocrevus was shown to significantly slow the progression of physical disability in people with PPMS. It was also successful in two large studies at reducing attacks in people with relapsing MS (RMS), according to Roche.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In December 2016, the FDA delayed approval for Ocrevus until this spring due to &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.fiercebiotech.com/biotech/roche-s-ms-med-ocrevus-delayed-by-you-guessed-it-manufacturing-issues&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;manufacturing issues&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How the drug works&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;MS hits everyone differently, with an array of symptoms and possible progressions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Its unique characteristics make finding remedies a challenge.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some people with MS may respond to one of the injectable disease modifying drugs (DMD) on the market. For others, one of the new oral drugs might work better for limiting attacks, lessening symptoms, and slowing progression of the disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But there are those people who have tried everything approved by the FDA and still have not found a therapy that slows the progress of the disease and prevents their disabilities from getting worse.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While several drugs are touted as being effective for RRMS, there had been no approved drugs specifically for PPMS.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ocrevus is designed to target the B cells that are responsible for myelin sheath damage and repair.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These CD20-positive B cells are a type of immune cell thought to be a key contributor to myelin (nerve cell insulation and support) and axonal (nerve cell) damage, which can result in disability in people with MS.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;B cells are part of the immune system and so called because they develop in bone marrow and produce antibodies. T cells, the other white blood cells in the immune system, are developed in the thymus gland.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Myelin is damaged by certain activation of T cells, which may be affected by B cells.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I’ve spent nearly the last 25 years of my career in both research labs and clinical development trying to find a novel treatment for MS. Like nearly all other researchers I have been focused on broadly immunomodulatory treatments or T cell directed treatments,” Dr. Hideki Garren, Ph.D., group medical director and clinical science leader at Genentech, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Genentech, part of the Roche Group, developed Ocrevus.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“What’s new and exciting about Ocrevus is that it is directed to only one component of the immune system, the B cell, which should provide efficacy and safety advantages,” Garren said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Waiting and hoping&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Genentech has an ongoing study to test Ocrevus with various biomarkers that could determine the success of the drug on the patient prior to taking it. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The FDA extension was the result of the submission of additional data by Genentech regarding the commercial manufacturing process of Ocrevus. The extension is not related to the efficacy or safety of Ocrevus, Genentech said in a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.gene.com/media/press-releases/14648/2016-12-20/fda-extends-review-of-application-for-oc&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;statement&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Officials at the National Multiple Sclerosis Society are optimistic about the new drug.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It will be a breakthrough for people living with primary progressive MS, who have waited so long for an effective disease modifying therapy,” said Dr. Bruce Bebo, the organization’s executive vice president of research, in a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nationalmssociety.org/About-the-Society/News/Detailed-Clinical-Trial-Results-Published-On-Ocrel&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;statement&lt;/a&gt;. “We hope that this success will encourage others to focus more resources into the research and development of treatments for progressive forms of MS.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Many patients are also eagerly awaiting the medication.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Hope stays alive,” said MS patient and blogger, &lt;a href=&quot;http://erikasmsblog.com&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Erika Lopez&lt;/a&gt;, who has now tried every feasible option for her progressive MS.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Just make it stop. Make the progression stop,” she told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em style=&quot;font-size: 13.6px;&quot;&gt;Editor’s Note: Caroline Craven is a patient expert living with MS. Her award winning blog is GirlwithMS.com, and she can be found @thegirlwithms.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em style=&quot;font-size: 13.6px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<updateddate>2017-03-29T12:00:00</updateddate>

<dc:creator>Caroline Craven</dc:creator>
