<item>
<title>
Researchers May Have Antidote for Carbon Monoxide Poisoning
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/researchers-may-have-antidote-for-carbon-monoxide-poisoning
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/032917_carbonmonoxide_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Dr. Sage Wiener has taken care of dozens of people with carbon monoxide poisoning as an emergency medicine doctor in Brooklyn.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He’s relied on oxygen to alleviate the headaches, dizziness, vomiting and other symptoms – a strategy that hasn’t changed much in recent decades.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But Wiener is heartened by new research that shows a protein might help people expel the poison and recover faster, mitigating potential damage to the heart, kidneys and other organs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Carbon monoxide is an odorless, colorless gas produced when fuel isn’t burned completely in furnaces, boilers, engines and other heat-generating sources.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When ingested, it chokes off the oxygen supply in the blood. Even relatively low levels of the gas can be harmful for people with cardiovascular disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How the antidote works&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Mark T. Gladwin, a critical care doctor at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center and senior author of the &lt;a href=&quot;http://stm.sciencemag.org/content/8/368/368ra173&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;December study&lt;/a&gt;, has seen what severe carbon monoxide poisoning can do.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;His interest in finding an antidote led him to study neuroglobin, a compound belonging to a family of proteins that bind or transport oxygen in the body.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Neuroglobin was discovered 17 years ago, but Gladwin said scientists don’t know what it does.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We make mutations in it to try to understand its function by making it change its function to see what it does,” said Gladwin, chair of the university’s department of medicine and director of the Pittsburgh Heart, Lung, and Blood Vascular Medicine Institute. “And that’s how we stumbled into this idea” that it could help treat carbon monoxide poisoning.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He and his fellow investigators changed the protein’s molecular structure to make it powerfully latch on to carbon monoxide and injected it into mice with lethal levels of the gas.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Gladwin said the mutated neuroglobin worked like a magnet, pulling the toxic gas off oxygen-rich hemoglobin that helps keep our tissues and organs healthy. The mutated protein bound itself 500 times more tightly to carbon monoxide than hemoglobin.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Gladwin said it only took about 25 seconds for half of the carbon monoxide in the blood to bind to the neuroglobin.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;By comparison, it takes about 70 minutes for a person with mild poisoning given a breathing treatment of 100 percent oxygen to get rid of half of the noxious gas inhaled, he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Someone with high levels of poisoning treated with oxygen in a high-pressure chamber takes about 20 minutes to get rid of half the carbon monoxide.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Wiener said most poisons cannot be removed from the body, so being able to target carbon monoxide would be effective.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Will it work on humans?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2015, there were 393 deaths from accidental carbon monoxide poisoning, according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;About 50,000 Americans visit an emergency room each year due to accidental carbon monoxide poisoning, research shows.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Thorsten Burmester, Ph.D., is the researcher who discovered neuroglobin.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said the results of the study are important because “the authors developed the first true application” for the protein.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Burmester, a professor at the University of Hamburg in Germany, was surprised the compound could bind to carbon monoxide with such great strength. The findings open up a new field of research, he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But the verdict is still out on whether the treatment will work in humans, said longtime medical toxicologist Steven Aks, D.O., an emergency medicine physician at Cook County Health &amp;amp; Hospitals System’s Stroger Hospital in Chicago who wasn’t involved with the research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mice in the study were treated immediately after being exposed to carbon monoxide. Yet many people exposed to the gas may not get medical treatment until an hour or more after exposure, Aks said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Really, the next questions are, does it work on a delayed basis and can we get it into people without causing any harm?” Aks said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It will likely be two years before researchers start testing the neuroglobin solution in humans, Gladwin said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Until then, experts urge people to learn &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/co/default.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;how to prevent carbon monoxide exposure&lt;/a&gt;, such as never using a gas range or oven to heat the home, never leaving a car running in an enclosed space such as a garage, and installing carbon monoxide detectors in the home.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/lab-researchers-create-possible-antidote-for-carbon-monoxide-poisoning/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;original story&lt;/a&gt; was published on &lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;American Heart Association News&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>General Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-29T11:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-29T11:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/researchers-may-have-antidote-for-carbon-monoxide-poisoning
</guid>
<dc:creator>American Heart Association News</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-29T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Herpes May Have Been Transmitted from Chimps to Humans
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/herpes-may-have-been-transmitted-from-chimps-to-humans
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/032817_herpeschimps_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Blame prehistoric chimps.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Or perhaps our ancestors who hunted them.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers say it appears the modern version of the herpes virus was transmitted from chimpanzees to humans tens of thousands of years ago.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The scientists add that the current version of genital herpes may have evolved from a mixture of two strains of the virus.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They published their findings today in the journal Molecular Biology and Evolution.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Herpes’ evolutionary path&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are two main types of herpes virus around today.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) is transmitted mostly by mouth and is found most often in cold sores. This ailment affects about two-thirds of the world’s population.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The herpes simplex virus 2 (HSV-2) is the main source for genital herpes. It affects about 11 percent of people around the globe.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The HSV-2 strain has been used to help verify the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4844272/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;“Out of Africa” theory&lt;/a&gt; that humans began migrating from that continent more than 50,000 years ago.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In general, HSV-1 and HSV-2 are considered cousins and have been thought to have evolved separately.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, the researchers of the study took a closer look at the evolution of the herpes virus, building on the work done in a &lt;a href=&quot;https://academic.oup.com/mbe/article/31/9/2356/2925757/Evolutionary-Origins-of-Human-Herpes-Simplex&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2014 study&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The team, led by Sebastien Calvignac-Spencer, PhD, of the Robert Koch Institut in Germany, examined the whole genome sequencing data of 18 HSV-2 isolates.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers say they determined the two main lineages of HSV-2 began diversifying about 30,000 years ago. One strain was restricted to Sub-Saharan Africa, while the other spread globally.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Calvignac-Spencer told Healthline in an email that the HSV-2 strain eventually mixed its genome with the HSV-1 strain.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said this mixture did not occur in all HSV-2, but the HSV-2 lineage that spread around the world contains the presence of HSV-1 recombinant fragments.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We don't know whether there is a causal relationships and these HSV-1 fragments provided a selective advantage to this lineage, but that is clearly one intriguing possibility,” Calvignac-Spencer said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How was the virus spread?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Calvignac-Spencer said his team did not investigate how herpes spread from chimps to humans.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said it’s unclear how the virus moved from one species to another.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Part of the reason is that the transmission happened so long ago.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, he said, there are a number of possible routes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One is aggressive interaction between prehistoric humans and apes could have resulted in direct skin contact with blood.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Humans also hunted apes, so the virus could have been transmitted while chimp meat was being butchered.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Humans could have also consumed food such as fruit wedges contaminated with chimpanzee saliva.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The significance of the research&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Calvignac-Spencer said there are several important observations to come out of his team’s research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One is that scientists now know that coinfection with HSV-1 and HSV-2 could result in the mixing of genomes, something not considered possible before this study.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Since this may have important functional consequences and alter the properties of the virus[es], I think it is clearly a question that warrants some follow-up,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Calvignac-Spencer added that his team was able to identify an “ancestral” pre-recombination version of HSV-2.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It turns out it is quite divergent from the ordinary HSV-2. So it might well be that some clinical tests designed to detect the ordinary HSV-2 are not so good at detecting the African HSV-2,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Calvignac-Spencer said his team plans to explore these and other issues in the near future.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>General Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-28T13:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-28T13:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/herpes-may-have-been-transmitted-from-chimps-to-humans
</guid>
<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-28T20:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Is Gleevec a Wonder Drug for Cancer Treatment?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/can-gleevec-treat-other-cancers
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/cancer/032717_gleevac_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It’s a drug that’s keeping people with chronic myelogenous leukemia alive.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers are now only scratching the surface of the potential of Gleevec and other drugs like it. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Before 2001, fewer than &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cancer.gov/research/progress/discovery/gleevec&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;1 in 3 people&lt;/a&gt; with chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) survived more than five years after diagnosis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Then, along came Gleevec.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Gleevec is a brand name for imatinib mesylate. It’s a tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI). &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved the drug as a targeted treatment for CML in 2001.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Treatment for CML hasn’t been the same since. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;https://news.ohsu.edu/2017/03/08/new-england-journal-of-medicine-publishes-long-term-results-of-gleevecR-for-patients-with-chronic-myeloid-leukemia&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;10-year follow-up study&lt;/a&gt; showed that 83 percent of people using the drug survived 10 years, some well beyond the decade mark. They did so without unacceptable toxic effects.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When Bharat Shah of Atlanta, Ga., was diagnosed with CML, his life expectancy was between six months and three years. So, he enrolled in a clinical trial for Gleevec. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Now, 17 years later, he’s still going strong. He told &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nbcnews.com/health/cancer/cancer-pill-gleevec-keeps-patients-alive-well-decade-n730951&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;NBC News&lt;/a&gt; that he continues to take the daily pill. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Aside from a little puffiness around the eyes, he doesn’t have any other side effects.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When compared with harsher chemotherapy drugs, Gleevec has been shown to produce fewer, milder side effects.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Swallowing a pill is also easier on patients than injections or lengthy infusions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It may well turn out to be a transformative treatment for other cancers and other types of diseases.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How Gleevec takes on CML&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Sean Fischer is a medical oncologist and hematologist at &lt;a href=&quot;http://california.providence.org/saint-johns/find-a-doctor/f/fischer-sean-a/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Providence Saint John's Health Center&lt;/a&gt; in California. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He calls Gleevec a revolutionary breakthrough for the treatment of CML.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Fischer explained that tyrosine kinases are proteins that send signals from the surface of a cell to its nucleus. This is necessary for normal cell function and division. But certain tyrosine kinases are a problem.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In the case of CML, a tyrosine kinase called the ABL tyrosine kinase, generated by a specific chromosomal abnormality characteristic of CML called the Philadelphia chromosome, is constitutively active, producing the disease,” he told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Gleevec, and other drugs like it, inhibit this tyrosine kinase. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“These medications have the potential to lead to remission of what was formerly a deadly form of leukemia,” said Fischer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. David S. Snyder, FACP, associate director of the Department of Hematology and Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation at &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cityofhope.org/homepage&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;City of Hope&lt;/a&gt; in California, specializes in CML.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He’s been involved in clinical research of Gleevec and other TKIs for many years. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He told Healthline that the recent report published in The New England Journal of Medicine confirms the successful response to Gleevec in the majority of patients with CML. Most achieve a functional cure of CML.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Snyder said there are two points of note.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Not all patients respond adequately and may need to be salvaged with more potent second or third generation TKIs [e.g. &lt;a href=&quot;/drugs/nilotinib/oral-capsule&quot;&gt;nilotinib&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;/drugs/dasatinib/oral-tablet&quot;&gt;dasatinib&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;/drugs/bosutinib/oral-tablet&quot;&gt;bosutinib&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;/drugs/ponatinib/oral-tablet&quot;&gt;ponatinib&lt;/a&gt;],” he explained.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Secondly, there have, fortunately, not been any serious, unexpected late adverse effects observed in patients treated with Gleevec. That contrasts to the experience with other TKIs, which have been associated with serious thromboembolic events, especially ponatinib, but also nilotinib and dasatinib, pleural effusions, and other cardiac effects,” Snyder continued.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Potential in treating other cancers&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Research indicates that imatinib is also effective in treating other cancers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This includes some forms of &lt;a href=&quot;/health/acute-lymphocytic-leukemia-all&quot;&gt;acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL)&lt;/a&gt; in children.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to Snyder, Gleevec targets the pathogenic driver of CML. But that’s not all it does. It also inhibits other tyrosine kinases. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That makes it useful in treating other malignancies. These include chronic eosinophilic leukemia and &lt;a href=&quot;/health/gist&quot;&gt;gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST)&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Other tumors that are driven by targetable tyrosine kinases may also be treatable with Gleevec,” said Snyder. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He also noted there are many other TKIs in development, or already approved, to treat some of these diseases, including a subset of lung cancers. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There are over 90 known tyrosine kinases in humans,” Snyder explained.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Other diseases&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Snyder said there have been some other unexpected, potentially beneficial effects noted for Gleevec. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“For example, Gleevec &lt;a href=&quot;http://diabetes.diabetesjournals.org/content/65/4/829&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;may help improve&lt;/a&gt; control of type 2 diabetes in some patients, perhaps by decreasing insulin resistance,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to Fischer, there is a focus on using this type of drug to combat nonmalignant disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nilotinib, which is a TKI similar to Gleevec, is also used to treat CML. It was found to affect activity in Parkinson’s disease, a neurologic movement disorder. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This exciting discovery has prompted additional research to fully assess this medication’s potential impact in Parkinson’s disease. Alzheimer’s, another progressive neurologic condition producing dementia, has also been quite topical,” said Fischer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said that’s due to discovery of gene mutation in certain older adults. It may protect them from developing Alzheimer’s dementia.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In a recent &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.pnas.org/content/114/6/1389.full&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, Gleevec was noted to mimic the effects of the protective mutation. This observation has served as a model for further study and development of such drugs to fight Alzheimer’s dementia,” said Fischer. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The platform for targeted therapy to treat nonmalignant conditions continues to evolve. The potential for breakthroughs is extremely exciting,” he said.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Cancer</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-28T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-28T10:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/can-gleevec-treat-other-cancers
</guid>
<dc:creator>Ann Pietrangelo</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-28T17:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Marathon Running Could Do Damage to Your Kidneys</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/marathon-running-could-damage-kidneys
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/032817_kidneymarathon_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;There is no denying that exercise is good for the body.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Research has shown that it helps to stave off multiple illnesses including type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and some cancers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Above and beyond physical activity’s ability to reduce disease risk, it also strengthens muscles, improves lung function, and has a range of psychological benefits.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, as with most things in life, it may be possible to have too much of a good thing.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;More vigorous activities can have negative health consequences.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As exercise goes, running a marathon is a particularly intense pastime – running 26.2 miles is not something to be taken lightly.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Are marathons bad for you?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The number of people participating in marathons has risen rapidly over recent years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In fact, over the past 35 years, the number of people in the United States participating in marathons has increased &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3538475/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;20-fold&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Because of this surge in interest, research into the benefits and potential dangers has also seen a sharp rise. Previous studies looking at marathon running and its impact on health have uncovered a number of potential health risks associated with the heart.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For instance, &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22160404&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;a study&lt;/a&gt; published in 2012 concluded that endurance training, including marathons, caused dysfunction in the right ventricle of the heart. Similarly, marathon- runners have been shown to have a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3538475/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;fivefold&lt;/a&gt; increased risk of atrial fibrillation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some researchers theorize that running marathons might also damage the kidneys.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Earlier work has shown that particularly vigorous activities – including harvesting sugar cane, mining work, and military training – can damage the kidneys.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, until now, marathon running’s impact on kidney health has not been studied.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A recent study set out to specifically examine the impact of running marathons on kidney health. The &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ajkd.org/article/S0272-6386(17)30536-X/fulltext&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;findings&lt;/a&gt; were published today in the American Journal of Kidney Diseases.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Chirag Parikh, who is a professor of medicine, led a team of researchers from Yale University. Participants were all runners from the 2015 Hartford Marathon, which takes place in Connecticut.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Before and after the race, the scientists took blood and urine samples, which they analyzed for markers of kidney injury.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Specifically, they checked for protein in the urine and creatinine levels in blood serum - a marker of reduced kidney function. They also examined kidney cells under a microscope.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In all, 82 percent of the runners in the study showed stage 1 acute kidney injury.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The dangers of kidney injury&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Acute kidney injury, as described by the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.kidney.org/atoz/content/AcuteKidneyInjury&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;National Kidney Foundation&lt;/a&gt;, is a “sudden episode of kidney failure or kidney damage that happens within a few hours or a few days.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It causes waste products to build up in the blood, making it hard for kidneys to maintain the correct balance of fluids in the body.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Parikh explains the results: “The kidney responds to the physical stress of marathon running as if it's injured, in a way that's similar to what happens in hospitalized patients when the kidney is affected by medical and surgical complications.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Why does marathon running damage the kidneys in this way?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers believe that there could be a number of factors involved, including dehydration, a rise in core temperature, and a drop in blood flow to the kidneys.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Although the drop in kidney function was significant, they also found that within two days, the kidney injury had resolved. However, more work needs to be done to understand whether this type of strenuous activity could cause long-term damage over time.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In conclusion, Parikh said: “Research has shown there are also changes in heart function associated with marathon running. Our study adds to the story - even the kidney responds to marathon-related stress.&quot;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It is important to note that exercise, in general, is a healthy life choice. However, evidence is mounting that excessive, particularly strenuous activity should be undertaken with caution.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<updateddate>2017-03-28T09:00:00</updateddate>

<dc:date>2017-03-28T16:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>
Is Obamacare Going to ‘Explode’ as President Trump Predicted?
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/is-obamacare-going-to-explode-as-pres-trump-predicted
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/ACA/032717_obamacareexplode_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p
]]>
<![CDATA[
&gt;President Trump may turn out to be right on this one.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On Friday, the president said the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, was going to “explode.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He repeated that &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2017/03/25/do-not-worry-trump-tweets-obamacare-explode/99617506/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;prediction&lt;/a&gt; in a tweet on Saturday.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And on Monday, his press secretary, Sean Spicer, reiterated the expectation, saying Obamacare was “&lt;a href=&quot;http://dailycaller.com/2017/03/27/spicer-repeal-isnt-dead-obamacare-is-dying-on-its-own-video/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;dying on its own&lt;/a&gt;.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They made the statements in response to the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cnbc.com/2017/03/24/obamacare-replacement-vote-postponed-in-house-as-gop-fails-to-win-support.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;failure&lt;/a&gt; of Republican leaders in the House of Representatives last week to approve a plan to “replace and repeal” Obamacare.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Experts interviewed by Healthline said the ACA may indeed start to unravel later this year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In part, they said, because Obamacare was headed for trouble anyway.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And it’s also because the Trump administration might not do much to help the healthcare system and, in fact, can do things to help push it over the cliff even sooner.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So, what happens if the ACA does collapse?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s going to be chaos,” Kurt Mosley, vice president of strategic alliances at Merritt Hawkins health consultants, told Healthline. “There has to be some kind of life support for the current system until a new plan is passed.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Twila Brase, president of the Citizens’ Council for Health Freedom, had a similar but slightly less pessimistic view.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think Obamacare as we know it will implode,” Brase told Healthline. “However, that doesn’t mean the health system will implode.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Will they sabotage?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Obamacare was facing a number of obstacles already this year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The first was that several large insurance firms, among them &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/unitedhealthcare-bails-out-of-obamacare&quot;&gt;UnitedHealthcare&lt;/a&gt;, had already significantly cut back on their participation in the state marketplaces that sell health insurance under the auspices of the ACA.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That has left about one-third of the counties in the United States with only one insurer in these marketplaces, according to a &lt;a href=&quot;http://kff.org/health-reform/issue-brief/2017-premium-changes-and-insurer-participation-in-the-affordable-care-acts-health-insurance-marketplaces/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Kaiser Family Foundation report&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The ACA system is also having trouble getting younger, healthier people to sign up. The tax penalties imposed on people who don’t have health insurance haven’t been high enough to motivate those younger folks to enroll.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Despite these problems, Ron Pollack, the executive director of Families USA, said Obamacare will remain healthy if it is allowed to move forward unimpeded.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think [the implosion] is purely wishful thinking on the part of the president,” Pollack told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, he acknowledged there are a number of things the White House can do to sabotage Obamacare.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It really is a question of what is the intent of the administration,” said Pollack. “It’s hard not to take [the president’s comments] as a signal.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One thing the White House has already done is &lt;a href=&quot;http://fortune.com/2017/01/22/trump-health-insurance-mandate/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;relax enforcement&lt;/a&gt; of the tax penalties for people without insurance.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That is likely to encourage even fewer younger, healthier people to sign up. Without their participation, it’s difficult for insurance companies to balance the costs of insuring older participants and less healthy customers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Unless young people sign up for this, I don’t see how it works,” said Mosley.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The other thing the White House has already done is not promote the open enrollment periods.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In late January, the Trump administration &lt;a href=&quot;http://money.cnn.com/2017/01/27/news/economy/obamacare-ads-trump/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;pulled the ads&lt;/a&gt; for Obamacare a couple weeks before this year’s enrollment period ended.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the end, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cnbc.com/2017/02/03/more-than-9-million-people-signed-up-on-federal-obamacare-exchange-by-close-of-open-enrollment-government-says.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;9.2 million Americans&lt;/a&gt; signed up for insurance plans on healthcare.gov, which serves 39 states. If state-run exchanges are included, Obamacare enrollment rises to 12 million. That’s still about half a million fewer enrollees than last year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Trump administration could decide to forgo advertisements for the entire 2018 enrollment period, which begins on Nov. 1.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There won’t be as much pressure on people to sign up then,” Brase noted.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Other ways to sabotage&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are a number of other things the White House can do to help derail the ACA, if it chooses.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One is to cut the cost-sharing subsidies that help people pay the premiums on the insurance they purchase on the marketplaces.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That could be done in the upcoming budget process for the next fiscal year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mosley said that could send premiums to unaffordable levels, especially for people with chronic conditions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The cost would be out of reach for a lot of people,” Mosley said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“That would discourage a lot of people from staying in the marketplace,” added Pollack.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The White House could also decide not to defend the ACA against lawsuits filed against it, something the Obama administration steadfastly did.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There’s a new sheriff in town. They could decide they’re not going to do it,” said Mosley.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The experts said that would allow opponents to continue to chip away at the healthcare law.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There’s also the question of Medicaid expansion.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Since the ACA was enacted in 2010, 31 states and the District of Columbia have opted to expand Medicaid for low-income households and receive federal funds to help administer the program.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mosley said a number of states were considering joining that expansion this year when it appeared Democrat Hillary Clinton was going to win the presidency.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, with President Trump in the White House, he says that’s unlikely to happen.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think talk of anybody expanding is dead right now,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What to expect&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;If the worst case scenario arrives and Obamacare collapses at year’s end, what is the fallout?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The experts don’t paint a pretty picture.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“That could cause real problems,” said Pollack.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The experts see more people without insurance coverage and higher premiums for those who buy plans in the marketplace.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mosley said more insurance companies might decide to walk away from the marketplaces. Others will simply stand on the sidelines to see what happens.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“They’ll have their finger in the wind,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Pollack adds that the 155 million Americans who have health insurance through their employers might also be impacted.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said companies could decide to cut back on coverage or continue to offer plans with high deductibles and out-of-pocket expenses.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Brase, however, said there may be a silver lining in all this.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She said states may decide to take more control over their health insurance plans. They are being given more leeway on how they implement the ACA under the act’s &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cms.gov/cciio/programs-and-initiatives/state-innovation-waivers/section_1332_state_innovation_waivers-.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Section 1332&lt;/a&gt;, which takes effect this year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“They should be doing this anyway,” she said. “This could be the beginning of things heading in the right direction.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Whatever happens, the experts agree that what the Trump administration does or doesn’t do will probably make or break Obamacare during the next year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I don’t believe Congress can do anything to prevent the implosion,” said Brase. “Whatever the administration does — that will be the difference.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>

<item>
<title>New Drugs That Could Help Us Live Longer</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/drugs-help-us-live-longer
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/032717_antiagingdrugs_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We
]]>
<![CDATA[
’re living longer these days, but that hasn’t stopped newer branches of medicine from trying to enhance and further extend our lifespans.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers in longevity medicine and biogerontology are studying drugs and compounds that can prevent and reverse aging on the cellular level.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Over the past few years, public interest in longevity issues has grown, but that interest is mostly in health-extending therapies, not simply life-extending therapies. Most people are interested in living longer, but only if they can also be healthier longer,” Sonia Arrison, author of “100 Plus: How the Coming Age of Longevity Will Change Everything, From Careers and Relationships to Family and Faith,” and founder of Singularity University in California, told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While many people are focused on lifestyle changes, the addition of drugs — rapamycin and &lt;a href=&quot;/drugs/metformin/oral-tablet#Highlights1&quot;&gt;metformin&lt;/a&gt; are two that Arrison mentioned — gives humans more options to extend their lives as well as the quality of their lives.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Compared with preventative drugs such as statins to avoid having a heart attack, anti-aging drugs fight multiple diseases at once instead of focusing on one ailment, Arrison added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A person who goes by the name Reason, a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.rationalargumentator.com/index/blog/tag/fight-aging/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;technologist&lt;/a&gt; and author on &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.fightaging.org/archives/2011/05/on-the-topic-of-my-name/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;FightAging.org&lt;/a&gt;, which highlights health- and longevity-enhancing medical technologies, told Healthline that the drugs are targeting a wide range of age-related ailments and diseases. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“All age-related diseases are age-related because they are caused by the processes of aging, which is to say an accumulation of damage in cells and tissues,” Reason wrote in an email.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Understanding longevity&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The field of &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3555024/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;geroprotection&lt;/a&gt; involves understanding cell senescence, which is when cells stop dividing.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When senescent cells no longer divide, they stop functioning, so organ health deteriorates. Cell senescence also causes the release of proinflammatory cytokines, which damage tissues. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This arena involves the use of geroprotectors, which are compounds that can stop or reverse cellular aging, and senolytics, which are compounds that can pinpoint and destroy senescent cells.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This is why researchers are looking into geroprotectors and senolytics, which requires long spans of time to understand.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In essence, today’s researchers may never see the outcomes of the research they’ve started because it can take decades to study. Nevertheless, scientists continue to try to understand these compounds and how they can alter our cells.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers are also looking into our cell’s telomeres, which are short segments of DNA in our chromosomes that protect cells from wear and tear that comes with aging. As cells divide, they can shorten and no longer protect the chromosome or cell.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lengthening them is the focus of recent research. Last year, a BGRF &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2016-04/brf-fgt042116.php&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; was able to lengthen &lt;a href=&quot;https://bioviva-science.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;human telomeres&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2017/03/molecule-kills-elderly-cells-reduces-signs-aging-mice&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;recent report&lt;/a&gt; in the journal &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cell.com/cell/abstract/S0092-8674(17)30246-5?_returnURL=http%3A%2F%2Flinkinghub.elsevier.com%2Fretrieve%2Fpii%2FS0092867417302465%3Fshowall%3Dtrue&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Cell&lt;/a&gt; detailed how peptides were able to boost the life span of mice. The study examined how cell therapy could reverse poor age-related kidney function, fur loss, and frailty in mice. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Scientists are looking into whether or not the approach can also prolong the life span of mice. Human safety studies are in the works. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Reason said there are two schools of thought when exploring extending life through genetic pathways.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One approach is to alter cellular metabolism and make cells age more slowly, but the work is difficult and expensive. The other is to fix old tissue because we understand how it compares with young tissue. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“No one yet fully understands everything these [older] cells do to us, but the fastest way to find out is to get rid of them, and we know that doing that in mice extends life and reverts aspects of aging,” Reason explained. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Either you slow down the damage, or you repair the damage. Aging is damage. It is in the ‘how’ of achieving one of those goals that all the complexity starts up,” Reason added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Documenting anti-aging compounds&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Human Aging Genomic Resources (HAGR) website recently released DrugAge, a database of lifespan-extending drugs and compounds.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It includes 418 compounds that were recorded from studies on 27 different model organisms.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;HAGR already operates the GenAge database of age and longevity-related genes in humans and model organisms. They also operate AnAge, which has aging and longevity records of more than 4,000 species, the GenDR database of genes associated with the life-extending effects of dietary restriction, and LongevityMap, which includes more than 2,000 human gene and genetic variations linked to longevity. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;DrugAge incorporates &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.aging-us.com/article/100799&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;earlier efforts&lt;/a&gt; by Biogerontology Research Foundation (BGRF) scientists, who produced &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.geroprotectors.org&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Geroprotectors.org&lt;/a&gt;. Right now, it’s the largest database of its kind.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the research teams from BGRF and the University of Liverpool, pharmaceuticals have not targeted most age-related pathways. The research is only focused on a small number of pathways that are currently known.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The goal behind the database is to pave the way for discovery of new life span-extending and health span-extending compounds.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I am confident that it [DrugAge] will gain widespread use in the aging research community, and represents a significant milestone along the way to the coming paradigm shift in modern healthcare away from single disease treatment and toward geroprotective multi-disease prevention,” Dmitry Kaminskiy, managing trustee of BGRF, said in a statement. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Franco Cortese, deputy director and trustee of BGRF, said in a statement the database will be “extremely valuable” for biogerontologists. The BGRF did not respond to Healthline’s request for comment. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Already, researchers are using the data to identify trends and develop a better understanding of the comparative effects of geroprotectors on organisms.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Arrison is excited when she sees people teaming up globally to battle human disease and decline — something that the DrugAge team is hoping to do with their database. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The more knowledge the health community can get, the better. The wonderful thing about the internet is that knowledge gets distributed faster, making the quest for cures that much quicker,” Arrison added. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Technology</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-27T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-27T12:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/drugs-help-us-live-longer
</guid>
<dc:creator>Kristen Fischer</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-27T19:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Can a 3-D Body Scanner Help You Lose Weight?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/can-3-d-body-scanner-help-you-lose-weight
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/tech/022417_3dbody_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For decades, people who wanted to be fit had only a few ways to track their progress.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Stand on a scale, measure their waist, and calculate their body mass index (BMI). &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the past few years, technology has expanded the number, complexity, and precision of those measurements.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The latest way to gauge the effectiveness of your fitness regimen is to stand in front of, or step inside of, a 3-D body scanner. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Two scanners with growing popularity are the mPod, housed in a secure, automated booth, and the Fit3D ProScanner, which uses a portable scanner tower with connected turntable.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;It’s like being at the airport&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The technology is familiar to anyone who's raised their arms overhead inside an airport security scanner.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Scanners benefit from the innovations found in the motion-sensing technology of Microsoft's Kinect, part of the Xbox One introduced in 2011. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The mPod was designed by Dipra Ray, Melody Shiue, and Andy Wu, who met as university friends in Australia. Ray and Wu majored in business and finance, Shiue in industrial design.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The company they founded, mPort, has partnered with LA Fitness to install 670 units in its clubs in the United States. Following the initial rollout in Orange County, Calif., the company is now installing mPods in other cities.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The mPod user steps into a photo booth-sized pod and stands still in one place while several sensors capture highly accurate body data without the user having to move. In a few minutes, the scanner produces a 3-D image that shows real-time changes achieved through different diets and fitness regimens.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The mPod is 100 percent automated,” Mehul Dave, mPort’s chief marketing officer, told Healthline. “The user does not require another person to help them. You interact only with the machine. The mPod has an audio, visual, and touch interface. It talks to you and you talk back with your hands.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The mPod uses noninvasive infrared technology, equivalent to what comes out of a television remote control, and is safe to use for everyone including pregnant women, he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The unit maps more than 200,000 data points to measure your individual body shape,” Dave added. “Then it sends the information to the mPod mobile app, creates a 3-D image, or avatar, with data on all body and health measurements, and what they mean. It also describes the levels of risk you face.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The mPod records height, weight, biceps, chest, narrow waist, hips, mid-thigh, knees, calves, shoulders, and neck. It also measures BMI, body fat percentage, fat-free mass and percentage, waist-hip ratio, waist-height ratio, basal metabolic rate, ideal weight range, and target heart rate for exercise. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dave and his colleagues finished their prototype in May 2013, and attracted investors four months later. By June 2016, they had signed the contract with LA Fitness clubs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Seeing the changes&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The mPort focus is direct use by the customer in a shopping center or a club.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The mPod design offers security and comfort in a public place, Dave said. The app extends the usefulness of the scan by allowing users to access and use their data anytime to pursue health and fitness goals.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While mPort’s founders first conceived of their scanner as a way for users to measure themselves before buying clothing online, Greg Moore — the founder and chief executive officer of Fit3D in Redwood City, Calif., and creator of the ProScanner — was inspired by his mother, Lynne.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In an interview with Healthline, Moore said, “After trying for several years to shed some unwanted pounds, my mother hired a trainer and a nutritionist and started on a very healthy lifestyle. She mixed healthy eating with high-intensity interval training and cardio exercises. She was building muscle while shedding fat. So when I'd see her every few months, I could see that she fit inside of her old body.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lynne became increasingly demotivated because her weight seemed to change so minutely, he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With a background in fitness, he knew her body was getting more lean and dense, but she didn't have a way to evaluate her progress. She finally gave up. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A computer engineer, Moore was a member of the invention team at Sportvision, which provides data and analytics for MLB teams. He drew on that experience, beginning in 2010, “to solve my mom’s problem with motivation.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Fit3D ProScanner user stands on a raised circular platform that makes one 360-degree rotation while an infrared camera on a nearby aluminum stand records information and relays it to a connected laptop.&lt;p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The ProScanner captures about 1,200 “depth” images on a body and combines them to create a full 3-D avatar of a human body, Moore said. The unit extracts more than 350 of those measurements to produce proprietary and university research-backed wellness metrics. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The data is finally presented to users and their coaches through the cloud-based Fit3D web platform,” Moore said. “Users can see scans and stats, compare them to past scans, and see a crazy amount of data about their bodies.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Fit3D sells, leases, or rents ProScanners to a spectrum of businesses to enhance their customer experience, Moore said. Clients include health insurance companies, hospitals, health clubs, weight loss centers, fashion brand shops, and custom-made men’s suit shops. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Moore said user feedback has helped to improve the ProScanner.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Do 3-D images help someone lose weight?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;James Shapiro, a certified personal trainer and president of New York City-based Primal Power Fitness, has watched the tech boom in fitness over the past decade.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I've seen how impactful wearable tech has been for data tracking,” he told Healthline. “But this turn into 3-D body scanning is incredible.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When I try to create a blueprint for someone, I want to know every possible detail,” he added. “This boils down to nutrition, sleep habits, hydration levels, stress levels, and more. These small variables matter because it can be the difference of a couple points of body fat, or levels of performance.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Clients benefit from the wealth of recorded scan data.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Having these small details in a physical representation offers a picture the client can believe in and understand when it comes to body composition,” Shapiro said. “A scan removes the margin of error that bio-electric impedance tests [which measure body fat in relation to lean body mass] have, and that has significant reliability. On a larger commercial scale, scans can be the best thing that can happen to personal training.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Although Shapiro and his colleagues have no experience yet with 3-D scanning, he has a keen interest in the technology.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When you want to deliver a quality service, you want to provide the best information to back up your statements or claims,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;div class=&quot;hl-poll&quot; style=&quot;float: right; margin: 10px;&quot;&gt; &lt;script type=&quot;text/javascript&quot; charset=&quot;utf-8&quot; src=&quot;http://static.polldaddy.com/p/9704800.js&quot;&gt;&lt;/script&gt; &lt;noscript&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://polldaddy.com/poll/9704800/&quot;&gt;Would a 3-D body scanner help you lose weight?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/noscript&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;p&gt;This would be more important for his clients who wish to considerably improve body composition and would benefit from the detailed 3-D images, he added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“A scan would offer a significant physiological boost to clients, who would be able to see that their sweat and tears were showing concrete results,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Shapiro said the only real drawback to 3-D scanning would be that either the trainer or the client could misinterpret the information and believe they could achieve “spot” reduction. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Spot reduction is the belief that you can reduce a specific area of the body through extensively training only that part,” he said. “This might lead to unclear expectations and loss of motivation due to a lack of results.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<updateddate>2017-03-26T06:00:00</updateddate>

<dc:creator>Patrick Keeffe</dc:creator>

<item>
<title>
Adopting a Child After Finding Out You’re Infertile
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/adopting-after-finding-out-youre-infertile
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/032717_adoption_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;“Just adopt.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Those same two words were thrown at me relentlessly after my infertility diagnosis at the age of 26.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I was young and single, and from an outsider’s perspective I’m sure it made sense.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Why worry about this now? Wait until you settle down. Then … just adopt.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The words came from a place of caring. But every time I heard them, it stung a little bit more. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The truth was, I wasn’t ready to accept adoption as my path in life.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I had always wanted to be a mother, but I’d always pictured that coming to me in the same way it did for everyone else.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I believed I would fall in love, get married, get pregnant, and be able to care for my child from the moment of conception.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Once I felt those choices being ripped away from me, adoption began to feel like the scraps I was left with.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And the more people offered it up to me as the seemingly easy solution, the more I resented the idea that I should just accept this second-rate path to parenthood.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Because yes, at the height of my infertility grief, that was how I began to view adoption. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I’m not proud. But I was so angry. And sad. And hurt.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Why did everyone around me get to just snap their fingers and be pregnant, while I was essentially being told to simply take what I could get and be grateful for it?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A change of heart&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;It took years for me to get past that feeling.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I pursued fertility treatments on my own, determined to at least give my body a chance at carrying a baby.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When it didn’t work, I took a step back and told myself I would wait.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Wait until I fell in love. Wait until I had my partner. Wait until something else felt like the right step to take.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I didn’t move closer to adoption. I just moved further away from the tight grip I was holding on what parenthood should look like for me.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And in the years that followed, I worked on healing both my body and my heart. I gave myself permission to not have all the answers. I took the pressure off.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Then, something happened.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;About five months’ shy of my 30th birthday, a friend sent me a link to a profile of a little girl on a foster to adopt website.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I don’t know why,” she said, “But I saw her and just thought of you.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I hadn’t thought any further about adoption at all in the years prior. And I certainly hadn’t thought about fostering or adopting an older child.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But something clicked as I looked not only at this little girl’s profile, but also at the profiles of other children like her looking for homes. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It no longer felt like second best. Suddenly, it felt like everything I’d been waiting for.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A sudden change in plans&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;My heart opened to adoption almost overnight.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I began to believe adopting an older child through foster care was something I was meant to do.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I started classes for my foster care certification almost immediately, and I was getting truly excited about the prospect of skipping those sleepless baby years and instead bringing a child into my life who might otherwise never find a place of their own to call home.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A child who might really, truly need me. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Life had other plans.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Just three months after that first profile was sent to me, and on the day of my last foster care certification class, I found myself in a delivery room holding the newborn who would become my daughter.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I’d met her other mother by chance just the week before, as she had been frantically looking for someone to take the baby she was still carrying. The details of our adoption story are incredibly unique, but four years later I can say with certainty … it was all very much so meant to be. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;We have an extremely open adoption, and I am routinely thankful for the connections we have been able to maintain with my daughter’s other family.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I am also so in love with this little girl, to the point that I can’t believe I ever thought, even for a second, that adopting might be a lesser way of becoming a parent.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A long, emotional road&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;But hindsight is always 20/20.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One thing you will never hear me telling a woman who is struggling with infertility to do is to “just adopt.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I firmly believe that adoption has to be a calling for it to work. You have to want it, not because you can’t have anything else, but because it’s where your heart is actually leading you. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I also know from experience that just because you’re not there now, doesn’t mean you never will be. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Healthline spoke to Lori Holden, author of “The Open-Hearted Way to Open Adoption,” and she shared a similar sentiment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Adoption is too big a deal to enter into with anything but full intentionality,” she explained. “There are just too many issues that can come up along the way that can be too difficult to deal with if it’s not something your heart is in.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Which is why it can be important to come to a place of peace with infertility first.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Filling the crib isn’t the same thing as resolving infertility.” Holden said. “Becoming a mom or dad through adoption resolves the parenthood issue, but still, we remain incapable of conceiving and bearing a child with our and our beloved’s DNA. This can show up over the years when we realize on occasion that we have a child with an unfamiliar-to-us temperament or interest or skill set. We may notice it when our child’s expression reminds us of a birth parent.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These flashes can trigger feelings of jealousy or sadness or insecurity. “She looks too much like her and nothing like me.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In those moments, we may feel left out, resentful, diminished. Will we allow these emotions to cause us to react from a hurt place? Or will we take a moment to understand what is going on inside us and choose how we respond to our emotions?” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I am personally of the belief that until you are at a place of peace with infertility, dealing with those emotions that go hand in hand with adoption in a healthy way is nearly impossible.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How long should you wait?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.acf.hhs.gov/hlcmsresource/cb/afcarsreport23.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;federal government statistics&lt;/a&gt;, there are about 427,000 children in foster care with an average age of 8.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are also about 111,000 children waiting to be adopted.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So, clearly the need is there.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But how long should a person still grieving infertility wait before pursuing adoption?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Holden told Healthline, “I’ve found that grief tends to come in a spiral rather than a linear fashion. It may be unrealistic to wait until all grief is resolved — does that ever even happen? But there is a sense of acceptance that eventually comes if we allow our feelings to be felt and maybe even released. The spiral does tend to lessen in intensity over time. With the help of a good therapist, and with the intention to deal with feelings of grief when they do spiral around each time, we can get to a place of acceptance of infertility and excitement about adoption as a path toward parenthood.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Reaching that point is different for everyone, and some may never fully get there. That’s OK, too. Adoption isn’t for everyone. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Of the several adoptive parents Healthline spoke to, there were a lot of different responses regarding when to move on to adoption.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sarah Allen of Australia, and Amber Mary of Alaska, both said they wished they hadn’t wasted so many years (and so much money) on fertility treatments and had instead moved on to adoption sooner.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Meanwhile, Kim Freitas echoed some of my own sentiments, saying, “I don’t think I could have closed the infertility chapter of my life without trying IVF. That was my closure, so to speak.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I personally needed to try. I needed to check those boxes and to be able to walk away from the dream of pregnancy knowing I had at least given it a shot.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I honestly don’t think I ever would have been able to move on to adoption had I not first answered that lingering “what if.” And while I don’t have happy feelings regarding the two rounds of IVF I pursued, I do tend to feel like things happen the way they are supposed to. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If I had come around to adoption sooner, I wouldn’t have my little girl … and I can’t imagine my life turning out any other way.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<updateddate>2017-03-24T13:00:00</updateddate>

http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/adopting-after-finding-out-youre-infertile
</guid>
<dc:creator>Leah Campbell</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-24T20:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>Video Games Can Help Ease Pain for People with MS</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/video-games-can-help-ease-pain-for-people-with-ms
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/tech/032517_liberation_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Can logging a few minutes here and there on “Candy Crush” or “Pokemon Go” actually help those with multiple sclerosis (MS)?&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Over recent years there have been a variety of clinical studies and research that promote the benefits of video games and computers for patients with this disease of the central nervous system.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;From vision to balance to depression, people are finding relief from their MS symptoms in the comfort of their own homes. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Cog-fog&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nationalmssociety.org/Symptoms-Diagnosis/MS-Symptoms/Cognitive-Changes&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;National Multiple Sclerosis Society&lt;/a&gt;, approximately 50 percent of those with MS experience brain fog, or “cog-fog” as it’s commonly called.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cog-fog is the description used when the synapses in the brain do not fire correctly and thought processes are interrupted.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Using computers and video games to rehabilitate this cognitive dysfunction is now proving successful.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A recent &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.neurology.org/content/86/16_Supplement/P2.170.short&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; concluded that adaptive, computer-based rehabilitation can lead to improved cognitive functioning in people with MS.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another &lt;a href=&quot;https://press.rsna.org/timssnet/media/pressreleases/14_pr_target.cfm?ID=1879&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; was based on research done by the Japanese neuroscientist Dr. Ryuta Kawashima. It used video games that included puzzles, word memory, and other mental challenges to help those with MS.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The popular online games from &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.lumosity.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Lumosity&lt;/a&gt; supposedly help improve memory.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While there is &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.consumer.ftc.gov/blog/brain-training-lumosity-does-it-really-work&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;no clinical proof&lt;/a&gt; to support those claims, testimonials remain strong that users have quicker recall and better decision-making skills after playing the games.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Users can track their cognitive skills by watching their performance records and comparing them with the general population.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some companies have created games specific to MS symptoms. &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.multiplesclerosis.com/us/living_with_ms.php&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;MyBrainGames&lt;/a&gt; was designed by Bayer pharmaceutical company. The user may access one of several games or customize it based on their own cognitive issues.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cognifit.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;CogniFit&lt;/a&gt; is a healthcare company providing activities for people with MS that offer customization, tracking, and more than 50 brain games. This program is available for computers and also offers tablet and phone apps for a monthly subscription.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another game called &lt;a href=&quot;http://brainage.nintendo.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Brain Age&lt;/a&gt; is available for Nintendo DS and Wii consoles. It’s designed to “train a brain in 10 minutes.”&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sometimes &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nationalmssociety.org/Symptoms-Diagnosis/MS-Symptoms/Cognitive-Changes&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;cog-fog&lt;/a&gt; may indicate a possible relapse. By playing games on a regular basis one begins to know their scores and how they usually perform. When a user shows lower than usual scores, this could be an indication that the person’s MS is aggravated. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Balance&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The use of video games has also proven successful with physical therapy for balance.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In one &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.mdpi.com/1660-4601/10/11/5697/htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; using an Xbox 360, people with MS were able to improve their balance with video games.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In another &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3882950/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt;, both patients and physical therapists said that exercising with Wii Fit games was fun, and that it challenged the patients’ physical and cognitive capacities.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition to balance the Wii Fit has been helpful in motivating folks to get up and move. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Get physical&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Yoga, strength, balance, and aerobic training have been found to &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17881393&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;reduce fatigue, increase fitness levels&lt;/a&gt;, and improve quality of life in people with MS.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The most recent craze, “&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.pokemongo.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Pokemon Go&lt;/a&gt;,” where the users chase Pokemon around their neighborhoods and throw Poke balls, seems to be a good enough reason for some people to increase physical activity.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Former skateboarder and carpenter &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.msunites.com/blog/2016/07/17/pokemon-go-mobile-game-as-a-therapy-for-ms/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Trevor Nurse&lt;/a&gt; is inspired by “Pokemon Go” and uses it as a distraction from the pain associated with walking.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He says it makes him more active and improves his attitude.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Mindfulness&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Video games that incorporate meditation can calm and soothe anxiety in people with MS.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Used to calm the mind and body in people with MS, &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3882962/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;meditation&lt;/a&gt; can also help to ease pain and improve quality of life. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to Professor George Jelinek, author of the book “&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.amazon.com/Overcoming-Multiple-Sclerosis-Evidence-Based-Recovery/dp/1742371795&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Overcoming Multiple Sclerosis: An Evidence-Based Guide to Recovery&lt;/a&gt;,”&lt;em&gt; &lt;/em&gt;a 7-step recovery program, meditation is one of the central elements to finding wellness, and is a “key part of healing from any disease.”&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One app called &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.stopbreathethink.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Stop, Breathe &amp;amp; Think&lt;/a&gt; also offers meditative guidance and suggestions for making the process simple and easy for beginners. Meditations range from “engaging your senses” to “commonality of suffering.”&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em style=&quot;font-variant-numeric: inherit; font-stretch: inherit; font-size: 13.6px; line-height: inherit; font-family: &amp;quot;Open Sans&amp;quot;, sans-serif; color: #333333;&quot;&gt;Editor’s Note: Caroline Craven is a patient expert living with MS. Her award winning blog is GirlwithMS.com, and she can be found @thegirlwithms.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em style=&quot;font-variant-numeric: inherit; font-stretch: inherit; font-size: 13.6px; line-height: inherit; font-family: &amp;quot;Open Sans&amp;quot;, sans-serif; color: #333333;&quot;&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
