<category>Technology</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-24T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-24T12:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/video-games-can-help-ease-pain-for-people-with-ms
</guid>
<dc:creator>Caroline Craven</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-24T19:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Have a Child … Live Longer</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/have-a-child-live-longer
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/032217_livelongchildren_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt
]]>
<![CDATA[
;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Parents know that those little bundles of joy bring them plenty of fun and satisfaction.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Now it turns out having children has an unanticipated benefit: longer life. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to a &lt;a href=&quot;http://jech.bmj.com/content/early/2017/01/30/jech-2016-207857&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;new study&lt;/a&gt; out of Sweden, older parents live longer than their neighbors who don’t have children.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Parenthood is associated with a longer life, particularly in older age, when health and abilities may have declined, according to research published in the Journal of Epidemiology &amp;amp; Community Health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The difference is apparent by age 60, the researchers say, and may be as much as two years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The gender of the child or children does not seem to matter.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For instance, the one-year risk of death for an 80-year-old man with a child was 7.4 percent, compared with 8.3 percent for a man of the same age who didn’t have a child.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To investigate whether parenthood might prolong life in older adults, the researchers tracked the lifespan of 704,481 men and 725,290 women from the age of 60 and on. The participants, who all lived in Sweden, had been born between 1911 and 1925. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study concluded at the end of 2014, as the researchers also gathered registry data on the participants’ marital status and the number and sex of any children they had.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Why children lengthen your life&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers’ findings come as no surprise to Donna Butts, executive director of Generations United, an organization based in Washington, D.C., that promotes three-generation solutions to personal and societal problems.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She has a solution for those older adults missing out on the benefits of children.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If you don’t have a child in your life, find one,” she said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There is no evidence that becoming a surrogate grandparent at age 60 comes with a longevity benefit, but Butts sees it as positive all around.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Everyone needs some purpose,” Butts said. “Intergenerational activities are positive on all fronts.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It makes sense,” she said. “Research shows how much good comes from older adults being with young people.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For one thing, the older people reported having a greater social network.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“They are more engaged, have more reason to get up in the morning,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One of the easiest ways to interact with a child, according to Butts, is through reading. Many literacy programs count on older volunteers reading to children who need to hear stories or improve their reading skills or even share quiet time. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Sometimes you just need to listen to a child,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;An &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.aarp.org/about-aarp/press-center/info-02-2017/aarp-bulletin-march-issue-features-50-great-ways-live-longer-exclusive-investigation-medicare-fraud-new-face.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;article&lt;/a&gt; in the March issue of the AARP Bulletin lists 50 ways to live longer, and one of them is to take care of grandchildren.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Swedish research team also found a similar link between longevity and providing care to grandchildren.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Men, unmarried get biggest benefits&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The newest data suggest you don’t even need to wait for a grandchild or babysit the ones who’ve arrived.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;You get the bonus by the mere fact of having procreated.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lead author on the study is Karin Modig, PhD, who teaches epidemiology at the Institute of Environmental Medicine, Karolinska Institutet, in Stockholm.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The research protocol required taking account of influential factors, such as educational attainment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It turned out the risk of death was lower among those who had had at least one child than those who did not have a child — and more so among men than among women. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers said the lower risks were evident among those who were married and unmarried, but seemed to be stronger among those who weren’t married, at least among the men.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The difference in death risk was 1.2 percent among unmarried men and 0.6 percent among those who were married.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Unmarried men might be relying more heavily on their children in the absence of a partner, the researchers suggest. They are also likely to be less educated, whereas the opposite tends to be true of women.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The research team wondered if the child’s gender would be significant as suggested by a previous study. Perhaps that research had focused on the traditional social benefits of having a daughter. Other types of support, including advocacy and navigating the health system, could be provided by sons as well, they said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The team concluded, “Our finding that the association grew stronger when parents became older is further in agreement with research suggesting that childless people face support deficits only toward the end of life.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In fact, that two factors (having a child and longevity) coexist does not prove a causal relationship between them.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the meantime, until further evidence is revealed, speculation about what this finding means continues both inside and outside the scientific community. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>General Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-24T07:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-24T07:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/have-a-child-live-longer
</guid>
<dc:creator>Roberta Alexander</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-24T14:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Fat, Face, and Facebook: The Latest Trends in Plastic Surgery
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/latest-trends-in-plastic-surgery
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/031717_plastictrend_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&g
]]>
<![CDATA[
t;&lt;p&gt;Plastic surgery doesn’t seem to be losing in popularity.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;New data from the American Society of Plastic Surgeons (ASPS) reveals that Americans are seeking out cosmetic surgeries and augmentations at a growing rate.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2016, the ASPS reports plastic surgeons performed 17 million surgical operations and minimally invasive procedures, such as laser hair removal and chemical peels.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With more than 290,000 procedures, breast augmentation claimed the top spot for the second year in a row.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The newly released information also reveals the number of cosmetic surgeries that focus on the face is growing.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, a new type of plastic surgery popped up on the popular list for the first time.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A new focus on fat&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Though the phrase “plastic surgery” may stir up connotations of chemical fillers, silicone breast implants, and injectable artificial ingredients, the ASPS research suggests that patients prefer a more “natural” ingredient in their “plastic” surgery: fat.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Minimally invasive cosmetic fat injections increased 13 percent in 2016.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, fat grafts in the buttocks also became more popular last year with a 26 percent increase.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But it was breast augmentations that used fat injections that saw the biggest increase, with a 72 percent jump in one year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Plastic surgeons harvest a patient’s unwanted fat from their abdomen using liposuction and then inject it to lift and rejuvenate other areas such as the face, buttock, and even the breast,” said Dr. Debra Johnson, president of ASPS, and a private practice plastic surgeon at The Plastic Surgery Center in Sacramento, Calif., in a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.plasticsurgery.org/news/press-releases/new-plastic-surgery-statistics-reveal-focus-on-face-and-fat&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;statement&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Newer procedures focus on removing fat in less invasive ways, and many of these are more affordable. That may account for the increased popularity in 2016.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Fat “freezing” increased 5 percent. Noninvasive skin tightening procedures that target fat pockets and seek to tighten sagging skin increased 5 percent, too.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Fat-targeting injections, which are usually used to reduce pockets of fats in areas like the chin, increased 18 percent.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While some people may be looking to move fat from one part of their body to another, others are just looking to remove fat altogether.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Liposuction took the second spot on the list of most common plastic surgeries in 2016 with 235,237 procedures.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A renewed focus on the face&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Spots three, four, and five on the list of most popular cosmetic surgical procedures in 2016 have a common theme: changes to the face.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nose reshaping and eyelid surgery were both up 2 percent year over year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Face-lifts, which had fallen off the list in recent years, climbed back onto the list at the fifth spot with a 4 percent increase since 2015.&lt;strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Likewise, many of the top noninvasive or minimally invasive procedures followed the same theme.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The number of these procedures topped 15 million in 2016.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Botulinum toxin type A (Botox) injections earned the top spot with 7 million procedures. That’s up 4 percent from 2015.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Rounding out the list were soft tissue fillers (2.6 million procedures), chemical peels (1.36 million procedures), laser hair removal (1.1 million procedures), and microdermabrasion (775,000 procedures).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;What do these minimally invasive procedures have in common?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Fast results with little downtime.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Johnson also thinks it points to people being more proactive about their skin’s appearance.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think this represents both a younger demographic trying to take better care of their skin early on, and older patients who are not interested in surgery but want to do something to help them tread water longer,” she told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The role of social media&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The return of the face-lift, as well as the increased emphasis on face procedures in general, points to a suspected common source point: social media.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If the popularity of selfies and disappearing photo apps like Snapchat reveal anything, it’s that Americans are becoming more obsessed with how they look — and how people respond to their looks.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Filters and apps offer airbrushed effects that were once reserved for high-dollar photo editing software, so if a filter can make a person feel proud of their appearance for a short period of time, plastic surgery may offer that boost for a longer time.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s the reasoning for Johnson, who said in the same ASPS statement, “Patients are captivated by instant improvements to the face. It’s evident in the popularity of apps and filters that change how we shape and shade our faces. While there are more options than ever to rejuvenate the face, a face-lift done by a board-certified plastic surgeon can have a dramatic, longer-lasting result which is why I am not surprised to see face-lifts back in the top five most popular cosmetic surgical procedures.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In an interview with Healthline, she added, “I think social media is playing a huge role in increasing awareness of these issues and provides personal experiences with various treatments and surgeries. I think it’s positive that patients can see that others share their same concerns, which can be very validating.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s not quite how Elaine Ducharme, PhD, a licensed clinical psychologist in independent practice in Glastonbury, Conn., sees the social media influence.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Social media plays a huge role in impacting self-esteem and drive to alter our bodies. Everyone is so connected to the ‘perfect’ images of celebrities on their phones, iPads, computers, etc. Mixed in with all the friend information on websites such as Facebook, are all kinds of images and ads on how to look more beautiful,” she told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If social media and the pressure to match or meet a self-imposed expectation is the impetus for some of these surgical procedures, Johnson said people aren’t necessarily trying to replicate someone else’s looks for themselves.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It is rare that patients come wanting to look like someone else, a celebrity or some beautiful person. Instead they will say, ‘I’d like full cheekbones like Kim Kardashian,’ or ‘I’d like lips like Angelina Jolie.’”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While others may be quick to blame the Instafamous or the celebrities who use their social media to promote themselves in ways stars never did, celebs may not bear the real blame.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“A lot of people have become truly preoccupied with themselves,” Ducharme said. “People judge each other by how they look and then put pressure on themselves to look perfect. People constantly are posting pictures of themselves and watching for comments and compliments. I see teens becoming more preoccupied with their looks and wanting to make changes with Botox.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Labiaplasty grows in popularity&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;While the top procedures focus on the face and the highly visible parts of the body, another less obvious cosmetic procedure is gaining popularity.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The ASPS started tracking the number of labiaplasty procedures in 2015 and 2016. Doctors performed more than 12,000 of those procedures. That’s a 39 percent increase in one year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This procedure reshapes the labia by lifting skin or filling out areas of the vagina and labia with injectable fillers. Here, too, Ducharme points to the influence of social media.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When social media, sexting, and especially pornography began to show female genitalia, women suddenly start comparing, and often feel that if they are different in any way, they must be abnormal,” she said. “There is actually quite a bit of variation in size and shape of labia and the vagina. Social media has just given women one more thing to worry about and feel insecure about.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Johnson, however, sees another way social media is influencing and accounting for the increase in vaginal cosmetic changes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The fashion of removing pubic hair with waxing, laser hair removal, or shaving has made the labia more ‘visible,’ and women thus see themselves more critically. Social media has made labiaplasty less scary to many women,” she said, “Knowing that other women share the same concerns has allowed women to seek consultation with issues they might have otherwise been embarrassed about.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As with any type of invasive surgical procedure, cosmetic or otherwise, labiaplasty carries with it risks and possible side effects. These include bleeding, infection, and loss of sensation in the genitalia.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Men and plastic surgery&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;It might seem, based on outdated stereotypes, that the plastic surgery clientele is almost entirely female, but that’s changing quickly as plastic surgery among men is becoming more common each year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Between 1997 and 2015, the number of plastic surgeries for men increased more than &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.surgery.org/hlcmsresource/ASAPS-Stats2015.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;325 percent&lt;/a&gt;. In 2015, men accounted for more than 1.2 million plastic surgery procedures.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The top five surgical procedures were:&lt;/p&gt; &lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;liposuction&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;nose surgery&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;eyelid surgery&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;male breast reduction&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;face-lift&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Men are becoming more open to plastic surgery. The ‘metrosexual’ movement has made caring about your appearance more acceptable to men,” Johnson said. “Men often seek less invasive procedures, including Botox, fillers, laser treatments. They have minimal downtime and no scars.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Here again, Ducharme sees the increase in plastic surgery for men in a different light.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Overall, I think social media has had a greater impact on women, since they have traditionally struggled more with body image. On the other hand, I have seen more young men becoming more preoccupied with their bodies and spending inordinate amounts of time at the gym,” she said. “Instead of starving themselves, as do women with eating disorders, they work out in a very unhealthy way. They use nutritional supplements and sometimes drugs to get that perfect body.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Body positivity campaign&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;If social media is to blame for the increase in cosmetic procedures, it’s social media that may turn the boat in the other direction.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Social media campaigns like Project HEAL’s &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.newsnation.in/article/118363-what-makes-beautiful-these-women-asnwer.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;#WhatMakesMeBeautiful&lt;/a&gt; encourage people of all shapes and sizes to embrace their bodies and be openly proud.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The United Kingdom’s Body Gossip uses art and creativity to encourage self-esteem and self-acceptance.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sport England’s This Girl Can campaign aims to encourage women of all shapes and sizes to get moving to make themselves healthier.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And it’s in England where the powerful self-love movement may be gaining some traction. Last year, the number of surgical procedures done there fell &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2017/feb/13/number-cosmetic-surgery-procedures-uk-fell-2016&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;40 percent&lt;/a&gt;. That’s a near-decade low after hitting their highest numbers in 2015.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“So many seek plastic surgery to fix imperfections, thinking that somehow their lives will miraculously change for the better. If they don’t really like or accept who they are, the surgery will do nothing to increase their happiness,” Ducharme said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How to find a plastic surgeon&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;If you’re considering plastic surgery, Johnson reminds you to be careful with your choice of doctor.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Plastic surgery is one of the only specialties in which nonplastic surgeons seek to provide care. It is important for patients to do their homework and assure that the surgeon they choose to perform their cosmetic procedure is truly a ‘plastic surgeon,’” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;You can start by visiting the ASPS’s website where they maintain a list of board-certified plastic surgeons who are ASPS members.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When you make an appointment, be sure to ask questions of the doctor and staff. Find out how long they’ve been in practice, what certifications and licenses they have, and what their specialty is, if they have one.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Don’t be afraid to seek second and third opinions to find a doctor that is both licensed and makes you comfortable with your choices and options.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>

<pubdate>2017-03-23T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-23T12:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/latest-trends-in-plastic-surgery
</guid>
<dc:creator>Kimberly Holland</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-23T19:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Cardiologist Who Gets to the Heart of the Issue</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/cardiologist-gets-to-heart-of-issue
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/heart-health/032317_AHAcardiologist_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Two life-changing events helped mold Dr. Arie Szatkowski, an ebullient, shaggy-haired New Yorker, into a Cardiac Crusader of the Mid-South.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When he was 23, his father, who was a doctor, died suddenly of a heart attack. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“He was my role model, and I was already applying to medical school,” Szatkowski said. “After he died, I knew I was going to go into cardiology.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A few years later, in the first week of a fellowship at Columbia, it was time for the young doctors to practice administering echocardiograms, an ultrasound test that maps the heart’s structure and function.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He volunteered to be the subject.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I get on the gurney and the professor starts looking and looking more carefully, and he says, ‘Do you know you have atrial septal defect?’” Szatkowski recalled.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The doctor was referring to a hole in the wall between the heart’s two upper chambers, a congenital condition often not discovered until it causes serious problems.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It was a stroke of luck I went into the right field,” Szatkowski said. “Had I not found it, I would have found out later with a stroke or irreversible arrhythmia or heart failure.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A cardiac catheterization procedure fixed the defect.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It also allowed Szatkowski to embark on a career with two added benefits: personal insight into a heart patient’s perspective and a passion to make a difference.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“A lot of things I went through are things I take my patients through,” he said. “You can actually empathize with them and express to them you know what they’re going through. You’ve been through it and you can talk about just how it feels.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Moving to heart disease ‘ground zero’&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;But beyond the doctor’s office, there’s a bigger picture.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The native New Yorker headed to Memphis in 2003 to join Stern Cardiology Foundation, a 38-doctor group practicing in Tennessee, Arkansas and Mississippi. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This is really the ground zero of heart disease in our country,” Szatkowski said. “To try to help one person at a time is great. But to actually impact a community and a region is so much more. I thought if I could come here and start to inspire people just beyond the patient visit and use all the resources that we have here to actually change the course of the disease, that would something be great to do.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That has meant years of outreach: speaking to church groups, civic organizations and news media as well as preaching nutrition, exercise and other heart-healthy themes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Szatkowski has also set up community health screenings, lobbiied politicians to build more parks, and promoted good health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There’s no set plan,” he said. “You just get involved.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The ‘go-to’ cardiologist&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ron Childers, chief meteorologist at WMC-TV in Memphis, calls Szatkowski the station’s “go-to guy for heart-related issues.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When Childers recently chaired the city’s Heart Walk, a fundraiser for the American Heart Association, “I told him I want you to be on our executive leadership team. I knew he has no time, but he still agreed to carve some out. He really cares about the health of the community.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The weatherman also calls Szatkowski his cardiologist. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There’s something about his presence that’s just so inspiring,” said Childers, who adds that the doctor has helped him improve his diet, lower stress and lose weight. “You just don’t want to disappoint him. He wants you to succeed in being healthy and he just has this way of conveying things that makes you want to do it.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Szatkowski is equally focused on making his profession better.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A few years ago the Stern group dispatched him to its offices across the state line in Mississippi, where he is now director of cardiac services at Baptist Memorial Hospital-DeSoto in Southaven.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“He has helped them so much with accreditation, standards and just a total transformation in their cardiac care,” says Debbie Eddlestone, Stern’s chief executive. “I really don’t know how he gets everything done that he does, but he has great time management skills.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The hospital recently won several awards in the AHA’s Get With the Guidelines program to improve response to and treatment of heart issues and strokes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Szatkowski is also busy with initiatives to improve quality standards in his physician group and across Baptist Memorial’s 15-hospital system. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We need to do our part as well as we can, as part of achieving change in the community,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Childers, a Memphis native, jokes that promoting heart health in a region where “we live off fried chicken, fried catfish and barbecue, and most everything starts with bacon grease” is no simple task.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In Arie’s exam room he has a map showing the rates of heart disease, and we’re like the reddest area on the map,” he says. “He’s out there battling that, and we’re lucky to have him.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s a challenge, Szatkowski acknowledges, but that also makes it an opportunity.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This is the leading region for a lot of bad things, like smoking, obesity, diabetes,” he says. “If you can make a difference here, you can have the biggest impact on the death rate in the whole country. It’s a process that takes time, but a lot of people and a lot of organizations here have the same vision, and I think things are getting better.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/fateful-days-changed-the-destiny-of-cardiology-doctor/&quot;&gt;original story&lt;/a&gt; was published on &lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/&quot;&gt;American Heart Association News&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<item>
<title>Gene Variants May Help Diagnose MS Early</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/gene-variants-diagnose-ms-early
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/032317_msresearch_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic disease where the immune system attacks the myelin sheath – the fatty substance that protects nerve fibers in the central nervous system.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As a result, the nerve fibers can become damaged, which interrupts signaling between the brain and spinal cord.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This can lead to movement problems, as well as muscle weakness and numbness or tingling in face, body, and extremities.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nationalmssociety.org/What-is-MS/Who-Gets-MS&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2.3 million people&lt;/a&gt; across the globe are affected by MS, with onset of the condition being most common between the ages of 20 and 50.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At present, there are no laboratory tests that can detect MS, meaning that it can take years to reach a definitive diagnosis. In the meantime, damage to the central nervous system worsens.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Following an MS diagnosis, there are medications available that can help slow disease progression by suppressing the immune system, but these can have severe side effects.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A new study has revealed the discovery of genetic variants associated with an increased risk of MS. Researchers suggest these variants could fuel the development of new ways to diagnose and treat the disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Co-lead study author Simon Gregory, director of genomics and epigenetics at the Duke Molecular Physiology Institute at Duke University Medical Center in North Carolina, and colleagues reported &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cell.com/cell/fulltext/S0092-8674(17)30286-6&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;their findings&lt;/a&gt; today in the journal Cell.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;DNA variants and the immune system&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Gregory and his team did a genetic analysis of individuals with and without MS.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They identified two DNA variants in two genes - DDX39B and IL7R – that increase a person’s risk of MS by threefold.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers found that the interaction of these variants leads to an overproduction of a protein called sIL7R. This protein communicates with the immune system, which the researchers believe plays a key role in the development of MS.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&quot;Our study identifies an interaction with a known MS risk gene to unlock a new MS candidate gene, and in doing so, open[s] up a novel mechanism that is associated with the risk of multiple sclerosis and other autoimmune diseases,&quot; said Gregory in a press statement.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the researchers, their findings may have important implications for patients, such as more accurate diagnostic techniques for MS and other immune-mediated conditions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&quot;One could envision how this type of knowledge will someday lead to [diagnosing] multiple sclerosis sooner and, now that we have promising therapies, a doctor could start the appropriate treatment more quickly,” said study co-leader Dr. Mariano Garcia-Blanco, of the Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology at the University of Texas Medical Branch.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It is not out [of] the realm of possibility to imagine a path for screening for other autoimmune diseases such as type 1 diabetes,&quot; he added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers note that their findings may also open the door to tests that can screen individuals with a family history of MS.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This early detection of DNA risk variants may help people to be more aware of MS symptoms.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<item>
<title>
Why Taxpayers Sometimes Fund Research for Expensive New Drugs
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/taxpayers-fund-research-for-drugs
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/032317_taxpayersdrugs_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A potential deal between the Trump administration and a pharmaceutical company was &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.businessinsider.com/bernie-sanders-lashed-out-at-sanofi-about-zika-vaccine-contract-2017-3&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;harshly criticized&lt;/a&gt; by Sen. Bernie Sanders earlier this month.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Vermont senator, concerned about potentially inflated drug prices, said President Trump was “on the brink of making a bad deal” that would give French pharmaceutical company Sanofi exclusive patents for a Zika vaccine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The controversy reignited a long-running debate over U.S. taxpayers helping fund pharmaceutical research — only to see pharmaceutical companies jacking up the price once a drug hits the market.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While concerns about unaffordable drugs are warranted, there’s far more to the issue than meets the eye, according to experts who spoke to Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Sky high prices&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;A large part of Sanders’ concern over the proposed deal was that Sanofi would overcharge for the vaccine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Looking at headlines from the past few years, it’s easy to see why he’s concerned.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/new-hepatitis-c-drug-stirs-controversy-041114&quot;&gt;Sovaldi&lt;/a&gt;, a hepatitis C drug developed by Gilead that initially sold for $1,000 per pill, is a prime example of private companies overcharging for a drug that’s research was funded in part by taxpayer dollars, said Will Holley, spokesperson for the Campaign for Sustainable Rx Pricing (CSRxP).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The R&amp;amp;D for Sovaldi was largely conducted by a small biotech company, later acquired by the current manufacturer, that received the majority of its funding from the National Institutes of Health (NIH),” Holley told Healthline in an email. “Gilead purchased this biotech, and then fully recouped the cost of acquiring the company in just one year of sales of the $1,000-per-pill drug.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another high-priced medication that has attracted considerable attention is the &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/cost-of-epipens-forcing-allergy-sufferers-to-syringes&quot;&gt;EpiPen&lt;/a&gt;, an auto-injector that provides epinephrine to people with serious allergies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Before costs cooled, the price for the device — one that can mean the difference between life and death — more than quadrupled over a 10-year period.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Who’s funding what?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;When examining this issue, it’s important to make the distinction between basic and applied research in the field of pharmaceuticals.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Basic research is typically funded through government grants and is conducted by academics.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Applied research is usually paid for by private interests and builds off of the initial basic research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“With basic research, there are no clear commercial objectives, and the people who do it are driven to publish their results and make them as widely known as possible,” Stuart Schweitzer, PhD, professor of health policy and management at the UCLA Fielding School of Public Health, told Healthline. “On the other hand, there is applied research, where organizations say, ‘Hey, there’s a finding out there. I think that we can make a bundle of money if we pursue that. Let’s see if we can turn it into a commercial product.’”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In effect, it means that while public money can lead to discoveries that are further built on by private companies, most of the money that brings a drug to market is paid for by drug companies rather than taxpayers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“While government funding supports basic research, America’s biopharmaceutical companies conduct the critical R&amp;amp;D needed to bring new medicines to patients and bear the associated costs and risks,” Holly Campbell, director of communications for the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America (PhRMA), told Healthline in an email. “In fact, the biopharmaceutical sectors spend more on R&amp;amp;D than the entire National Institutes of Health operating budget, with all biopharmaceutical companies investing more than $70 billion in R&amp;amp;D.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Campbell also points to a &lt;a href=&quot;http://csdd.tufts.edu/files/uploads/PubPrivPaper2015.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2015 white paper&lt;/a&gt; from the Tufts University School of Medicine that concluded that 67-97 percent of drug development is conducted by the private sector.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While public dollars rarely fund the direct development of pharmaceuticals, there are exceptions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some come under the Orphan Drug Act of 1983, which allows the government to fund pharmaceutical firms to develop drugs for conditions that affect a small percentage of the population while limiting the amount of potential profit by private companies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Schweitzer cites Epogen, a drug for people on dialysis, developed by Amgen, as a success story of the Orphan Drug Act.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When Amgen started its work, the number of patients on kidney dialysis was very small,” he said. “But as soon as it was realized that the number of dialysis patients was growing beyond 200,000 patients, then Amgen had to give up its money to the government. I’ve read stories that there are some exceptions to that, where the money hasn’t been given back, and that’s clearly an oversight, with Congress not enforcing the law as tightly as they should. But the principle is there: If it’s a very small market, even though it’s a commercial product, government will come in because nobody else is going to invest in such a small market.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Even when large amounts of money are poured into research and development, there’s no guarantee that the research will actually lead anywhere.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I see the pharmaceutical industry as extraordinarily vulnerable to failure,” said Schweitzer. “It’s a very high-risk business. Something like 10 percent of all drugs that are developed get FDA approval. Merck, a couple of years ago, had a drug for inhaled insulin that cost about $2 billion. It was even approved by the FDA, and nobody bought it. It was a failure. They closed it down and sold their patent rights.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Tweaking the system&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Part of what makes this such a contentious issue is a lack of transparency, creating a system where virtually no public data exists to show the link between prices and development costs, said Holley.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Manufacturers should be required to disclose R&amp;amp;D costs for drugs, including how much of the research is funded by the NIH, other academic entities, or another pharmaceutical company later acquired by the current manufacturer,” he said. “A market cannot function when purchasers have limited information and, in the case of prescription drugs, pricing is a black box. Prices for drugs are clearly rising at rates that far exceed inflation and the level of any rebates or discounts offered by manufacturers.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Holley says CSRxP would like the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to provide an annual report that includes the top 50 increases over the past year by both branded and generic drugs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That report would also have the top 50 drugs by annual spending and how much the government pays in total for these drugs, and historical price increases for common drugs, including Medicare Part B drugs, over the most recent 10-year period.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Schweitzer said the long FDA approval process can hinder competition, allowing the first company to develop a drug or technology to have a virtual monopoly while other companies go through the approval process.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“An example of that is the EpiPen,” Schweitzer says. “How did they get away with raising their price, and nobody came in and underbid them? You’ve got to look at the FDA’s devices section. The drug in the EpiPen, epinephrine, is a generic drug. There’s no secret to it. The secret is in the delivery system itself. How is it that Mylan developed a really good medical device and nobody else could do that? The FDA devices section takes three years to approve a device, and that really hurt a lot of people. So now there is competition in the market for the EpiPen, but it shouldn’t have taken that long.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I’d like to see legislation that would have the FDA lighten up on the approval regulations,” said Schweitzer. “So when a drug price has increased by more than, say, 50 percent in a year, the FDA could scare manufacturers away from doing this by ensuring that there’s going to be [a competing product] in the marketplace quite soon. So my answer lies on the supply side, and definitely not price controls, because I don’t believe that we’re going to get as much drug discovery if we take away the motive of making money with a few of our successful drugs.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Holley agrees that encouraging competition is crucial.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The keys to any real solution are increased transparency, removing barriers to competition, especially from generics, and ensuring that prices are correlated with the value that a drug brings to the patients who need them,” he said.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<updateddate>2017-03-23T10:00:00</updateddate>

</guid>
<dc:creator>Dan Gray</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-23T17:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Should Ibuprofen Be a Prescription Drug?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/should-ibuprofen-be-prescription-drug
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/heart-health/032217_ibuprofen_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After a new study in Denmark linked ibuprofen and another common pain medication to an increased risk of cardiac arrest, one of the study authors called for restrictions on over-the-counter sales of these drugs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Concerns about nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are not new.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Previous studies have linked NSAIDs to increased risk of &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.bmj.com/content/354/bmj.i4857&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;heart failure&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.fda.gov/Safety/MedWatch/SafetyInformation/SafetyAlertsforHumanMedicalProducts/ucm454141.htm?source=govdelivery&amp;amp;utm_medium=email&amp;amp;utm_source=govdelivery&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;heart attack or stroke&lt;/a&gt;, and &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.bmj.com/content/343/bmj.d3450&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;irregular heart rhythm&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Mary Norine Walsh, medical director of heart failure and cardiac transplantation at St. Vincent Heart Center in Indianapolis, and president of the American College of Cardiology, said the new study expands on past research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It elucidates that sudden cardiac arrest is the mechanism of death, at least in [Denmark],” Walsh told Healthline. “And it adds to the data that we already have showing that this class of drug is bad with regard to mortality.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Walsh was not involved in the &lt;a href=&quot;https://academic.oup.com/ehjcvp/article/3/2/100/2739709/Non-steroidal-anti-inflammatory-drug-use-is&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;new study&lt;/a&gt;, which was published Mar. 15 in the European Heart Journal - Cardiovascular Pharmacotherapy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Cardiac risks&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the study, researchers reviewed the medical records of 28,947 people who had a cardiac arrest outside of the hospital in Denmark between 2001 and 2010.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They also collected data on all prescriptions for NSAIDs filled in the country during that time.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;More than 3,000 people who had cardiac arrest — sudden loss of heart function — had taken an NSAID within 30 days before the event.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Use of any NSAID raised the risk of cardiac arrest by 31 percent, compared to a previous 30-day period without heart problems.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;/health/drugs/diclofenac/oral-tablet&quot;&gt;Diclofenac&lt;/a&gt; — which is available in the United States only as a prescription — was linked to a 50 percent increased risk of cardiac risk and prescription-strength ibuprofen with a 31 percent greater risk.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;/drugs/naproxen/oral-tablet&quot;&gt;Naproxen&lt;/a&gt;, rofecoxib, and &lt;a href=&quot;/drugs/celecoxib/oral-capsule&quot;&gt;celecoxib&lt;/a&gt; were not associated with cardiac arrest. The researchers say that this could be because these drugs are seldom prescribed in Denmark and were not represented equally in the study.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The results serve as a reminder that NSAIDs are not harmless, even though some are available over-the-counter without a prescription.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“NSAIDs should be used with caution and for a valid indication. They should probably be avoided in patients with cardiovascular disease or many cardiovascular risk factors,” study author Gunnar H. Gislason, professor of cardiology at Copenhagen University Hospital Gentofte in Denmark, said in a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.escardio.org/The-ESC/Press-Office/Press-releases/harmless-painkillers-associated-with-increased-risk-of-cardiac-arrest&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;press release&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Restricting NSAIDs&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Given the cardiac risks, Gislason also suggested that restrictions be placed on the over-the-counter sale of these drugs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I don't think these drugs should be sold in supermarkets or petrol stations where there is no professional advice on how to use them,” said Gislason. “Over-the-counter NSAIDs should only be available at pharmacies, in limited quantities, and in low doses.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the United States, ibuprofen (such as Advil and Motrin) and naproxen (such as Aleve) are both available over-the-counter, but in lower doses than prescription NSAIDs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the &lt;a href=&quot;http://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/articles/non-steroidal-anti-inflammatory-medicines-nsaids&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Cleveland Clinic&lt;/a&gt;, heart problems caused by NSAIDs can happen within a few weeks of use, and are more likely to occur with larger doses and long-term use.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The new study, though, looked only at prescription NSAIDs, so not everyone agrees with the need for restricting the sale of these drugs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Their data doesn’t address ibuprofen at lower doses because they couldn’t track it,” said Walsh. “So I’m not sure that’s the best recommendation.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;People also have other non-NSAID options for pain relief.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Acetaminophen is a very good pain medication for mild pain,” said Walsh. “It is not an anti-inflammatory. It doesn’t have a longer half-life that some of the over-the-counter NSAIDs have. But acetaminophen is a very good pain medication.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Talal Attar, an interventional cardiologist and an assistant professor of clinical internal medicine at The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center, said that over-the-counter NSAIDs can be used safely.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“With a young and healthy individual who just sprained an ankle and has to take something for three or four days,” Attar told Healthline, “I think the risk of causing a cardiovascular event — although not zero — is low enough that it’s probably reasonable to have access to those drugs over-the-counter.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Cleveland Clinic recommends that people use over-the-counter NSAIDs for no more than three days for fever and 10 days for pain.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Any longer than that — of if you have a history of, or risk factors for, cardiovascular disease — and you should talk to your doctor first.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Attar also suggests that people taking regular prescription medications for high blood pressure, heart disease, diabetes, or other conditions be careful when using over-the-counter NSAIDs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think it’s prudent to speak to your pharmacist or your physician any time you take something over-the-counter — whether it is an NSAID or anything in general — because of the risk of interfering with that medication,” Attar said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;People with chronic pain — who often use pain medications long-term — can work with their doctor to balance the risks and benefits of NSAIDs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s a shared decision between the patient and the doctor,” said Walsh. “If your pain is severe enough and one of these agents has been beneficial for your condition — such as a bad arthritis — it may be something that you want to consider.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Heart Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-23T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-23T10:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/should-ibuprofen-be-prescription-drug
</guid>
<dc:creator>Shawn Radcliffe</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-23T17:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>A Sperm Test You Can Do at Home With a Smartphone</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/a-sperm-test-you-can-do-at-home-with-a-smartphone
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/mens-health/032217_spermtest_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It is currently estimated that worldwide infertility affects &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.eurekalert.org/emb_releases/2017-03/aaft-ara032017.php&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;45 million&lt;/a&gt; couples.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;About 40 percent of these cases are attributable to the male partner. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the United States, approximately &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.resolve.org/about/fast-facts-about-fertility.html?referrer=https://www.google.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;1 in 8 &lt;/a&gt;couples cannot conceive and a third of these cases are attributed to male infertility. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Current infertility diagnosing practices are expensive and can only be carried out in a clinic or hospital.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, a team of researchers at Brigham and Women's Hospital (BWH) in collaboration with Massachusetts General Hospital (MGH) - both in Boston - have designed a new, inexpensive, and simple tool for diagnosing male infertility. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The new device, which hasn't been named yet, is smartphone-operated and can be used from home.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Using motility and sperm concentration criteria, researchers said the new device analyzes and measures semen quality, ultimately identifying infertility with a degree of 98 percent accuracy.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Manoj Kanakasabapathy led the research team that designed and tested the device. The findings were &lt;a href=&quot;http://dx.doi.org/10.1126/scitranslmed.aai7863&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;published&lt;/a&gt; in the journal Science Translational Medicine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How the device works&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The sperm analyzer is made of an optical attachment that connects to both a smartphone and a device onto which users can load a sample of their semen. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The semen sample device is disposable and uses a microchip with a capillary tip. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Users are guided by the app through each stage of the testing process. Additionally, a weight microscale - connected wirelessly to the smartphone - measures the total sperm count. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hadi Shafiee, Ph.D., a principal investigator in the Division of Engineering in Medicine and Renal Division of Medicine at BWH and co-author on the study, explained the team’s motivation:&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&quot;We wanted to come up with a solution to make male infertility testing as simple and affordable as home pregnancy tests,” he said. “Men have to provide semen samples in these rooms at a hospital, a situation in which they often experience stress, embarrassment, pessimism, and disappointment. Current clinical tests are lab-based, time-consuming, and subjective. This test is low-cost, quantitative, highly accurate and can analyze a video of an undiluted, unwashed semen sample in less than five seconds.&quot;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Accurate, user-friendly&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;To test the accuracy of the device, Kanakasabapathy and team collected and analyzed 350 clinical semen samples from the MGH Fertility Center.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The World Health Organization (WHO) &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cnrha.msssi.gob.es/bioetica/pdf/Valores_semen_humano.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;define&lt;/a&gt; normal sperm concentration as higher than 15 million sperm per milliliter, and normal &lt;a href=&quot;https://medlineplus.gov/ency/article/003627.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;motility&lt;/a&gt; - or the ability of the sperm to move - as more than 40 percent. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Based on these criteria, researchers said the device detected infertility with 98 percent accuracy. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers also wanted to test how user-friendly the device is, so they assessed its use by both trained and untrained volunteers. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A total of 10 users with no training correctly categorized more than 100 sperm samples as fertile or infertile.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Applications of the new device&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers think that the new tool will benefit a variety of people.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Men who have undergone a vasectomy can use the home-based device to monitor their sperm several months after surgery. At the moment, vasectomy patients are required to check in regularly with a urologist to make sure the surgery was successful, but the new device could make this practice obsolete. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Additionally, the new device could serve as a &lt;a href=&quot;https://report.nih.gov/NIHfactsheets/ViewFactSheet.aspx?csid=112&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;point-of-care&lt;/a&gt; testing tool, which could be used not only at the patient’s home but also in the hospital or other locations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Finally, the authors suggest the device could also be used to test fertility in animals. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&quot;The ability to bring point-of-care sperm testing to the consumer, or health facilities with limited resources, is a true game changer,&quot; says Dr. John Petrozza, study co-author and director of the MGH Fertility Center. &quot;More than 40 percent of infertile couples have difficulty conceiving due to sperm abnormalities and this development will provide faster and improved access to fertility care. [...] We have really been able to create a product that will benefit a lot of people.&quot;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The new device is currently only a prototype, but as soon as the researchers carry out further tests, they will apply for approval from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Men's Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-22T11:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-22T11:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/a-sperm-test-you-can-do-at-home-with-a-smartphone
</guid>
<dc:creator>Ana Sandoiu</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-22T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Opioids vs. Marijuana: Which Is More Dangerous?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/opioids-vs-marijuana
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/031317_weedopioid_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;What would you rather have your kid hooked on?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Prescription pills or marijuana?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A lot of parents might lean toward those prescription painkillers that they themselves use.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But are medications such as &lt;a href=&quot;/drugs/oxycodone/oral-tablet#Highlights1&quot;&gt;oxycodone&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;/drugs/hydrocodone/oral-tablet#Highlights1&quot;&gt;hydrocodone&lt;/a&gt; really the lesser of two evils?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Both marijuana and prescription opioids have been targeted by the White House.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Trump administration has made it clear there will be renewed scrutiny of marijuana laws.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In particular, recreational marijuana laws are being targeted for “&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.marketwatch.com/story/expect-greater-enforcement-of-marijuana-laws-under-trump-spicer-says-2017-02-23&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;greater enforcement&lt;/a&gt;,” according to White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Attorney General Jeff Sessions also &lt;a href=&quot;http://fortune.com/2017/01/10/jeff-sessions-marijuana-confirmation-hearing/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;opposes recreational marijuana&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;President Trump has also promised to do something about the opioid epidemic sweeping across the country.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, the Republican &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cnn.com/2017/03/11/politics/donald-trump-medicaid-cuts-opioids/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;health plan&lt;/a&gt; he supports reduces funding for a lot of addiction recovery programs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With the debate over the health effects of both marijuana and prescription painkillers, you might wonder which is actually doing more harm to the United States?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Healthline decided to take an in-depth look.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Officially, marijuana is more dangerous&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Although &lt;a href=&quot;http://norml.org/news/2016/11/10/voters-in-eight-states-approve-marijuana-law-reform-in-unprecedented-election-victories&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;eight states&lt;/a&gt; have passed laws legalizing recreational marijuana use, and 29 states have legalized medical marijuana, federal law still labels marijuana as an illegal substance.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The DEA classifies marijuana as a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.dea.gov/druginfo/ds.shtml&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Schedule 1 drug&lt;/a&gt;, defined as having no accepted medical use and a high potential for abuse. Other Schedule 1 drugs include LSD and heroin.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On the other hand, Schedule 2 drugs, which include crystal methamphetamine and cocaine, have been accepted as medical treatments in the United States.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Prescription opioids, which include &lt;a href=&quot;/drugs/morphine/oral-tablet#Highlights1&quot;&gt;morphine&lt;/a&gt;, fall into this category of drugs — legal when prescribed by medical personnel.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Thomas Strouse, medical director of the Stewart and Lynda Resnick Neuropsychiatric Hospital at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA), thinks the classifications are a bit ridiculous.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Although marijuana can cause health problems if used in excess, he said, there are &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/marijuana-deaths-2014_us_56816417e4b06fa68880a217&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;no known cases&lt;/a&gt; of somebody dying from a marijuana overdose. The same cannot be said for opioids.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The CDC reports that overdose deaths from opioids have quadrupled since 1999. In 2015, more than &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/drugoverdose/data/overdose.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;15,000 Americans&lt;/a&gt; died from overdoses involving prescription opioids. Those prescription pills now account for nearly half of all U.S. overdoses from opioids.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, an average of 1,000 Americans are treated in emergency rooms every day for misusing prescription pills.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Overall, the use of prescription medication far outdistances the use of marijuana.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the CDC, doctors in the United States write &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/65/rr/rr6501e1.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;259 million&lt;/a&gt; opioid prescriptions a year. The sales of these drugs have more than quadrupled since 1999.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As for treatment, Strouse says withdrawal from a marijuana addiction is significantly less severe than withdrawal from an opioid addiction.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Strouse said marijuana’s designation as a Schedule 1 drug has more to do with historical and political reasons than any hard data.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I believe [the drug classifications] should be based on science,” he told Healthline. “It does not make sense to me that cannabis is a Schedule 1 drug.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Marijuana health effects&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Marijuana won’t kill you. Not from an overdose anyway.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But is it healthy for you?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nap.edu/catalog/24625/the-health-effects-of-cannabis-and-cannabinoids-the-current-state&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;recent study&lt;/a&gt; sought to qualify the purported harms as well as benefits of marijuana.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Marie McCormick, professor of maternal and child health in the Department of Social and Behavioral Sciences at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, professor of pediatrics at the Harvard Medical School, and chair of the study, says the widely cited negative side effects of cannabis are hard to substantiate.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The classification of cannabis as a Schedule 1 drug makes it very difficult to acquire research-grade samples,” McCormick told Healthline. “There are a lot of questions about the quality of the existing data. Existing studies are variable, even in terms of the concentrations of the cannabis. It’s hard to sort out the data.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Still, the recent report did determine relationships between smoking marijuana and health problems. According to McCormick, “What appears is that smoking does lead to bronchitis, smoking during pregnancy does lead to lower birth rates, and initiating cannabis use at an early age is a risk factor for problematic use.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She said there is testing in the workplace, but there’s no data associated with workplace injuries as a consequence of cannabis use.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Even the widespread concern that marijuana causes poor academic performance among young marijuana users isn’t necessarily correct.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Early use of cannabis leads to academic failure is the assumption,” McCormick says. “But the questions around cannabis use are asked of students retroactively. We don’t know how the student was doing before the cannabis use.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The literature is mixed on whether marijuana use leads to abuse of other, more harmful drugs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Usually they’re talking to someone who has another drug problem and asking what they did before,” McCormick says. “What they don’t know about are the people who start cannabis and don’t go any further. There’s no evidence of it being a gateway drug.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The report investigated cannabis use and 11 types of health issues, including heart attack and schizophrenia, but could not find strong evidence of a relationship between them.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.acc.org/about-acc/press-releases/2017/03/09/14/05/marijuana-use-associated-with-increased-risk-of-stroke-heart-failure?w_nav=S&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;report&lt;/a&gt; released over the weekend at the American College of Cardiology said marijuana use is associated with an increased risk of heart disease and stroke.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Strouse said that heavy use of marijuana can lead to psychological disorders in some people.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He added that marijuana also can do damage to the developing brains of people under the age of 25.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The impact of heavy marijuana use on a developing brain is no small matter,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On the other hand, McCormick’s report did identify several therapeutic uses for cannabis, including treating chronic pain and treating chemotherapy-related nausea and vomiting in cancer patients.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws (NORML) touts two recent studies involving marijuana and opioids.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://norml.org/news/2017/03/09/medical-marijuana-legalization-associated-with-fewer-opioid-related-hospitalizations&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;first study&lt;/a&gt;, released this month, reports that statewide legislation that permits medical marijuana use is associated with a reduction of opioid-related hospitalizations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://norml.org/news/2017/02/16/study-medical-cannabis-patients-reduce-their-use-of-opioids&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;second story&lt;/a&gt;, released last month, states that patients with legal access to medicinal marijuana reduce their use of opioids.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The data is clear. Cannabis is effective at treating pain, including hard-to-treat pain conditions like neuropathy, and arguably represents a safer alternative to opioids,” Paul Armentano, deputy director of NORML, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ultimately, the McCormick report recommends a lot more study, including the development of a standard set of questions to ask research participants so data can be consistent across studies, and a review of marijuana’s status as a Schedule 1 drug.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“As a Schedule 2 drug, cannabis would be treated like opioids like morphine and codeine,” McCormick said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The effects of opioids&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;As most opioids are legal, there is much more research about their efficacy and potential harms.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.teaterhs.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Dr. Don Teater&lt;/a&gt;, medical advisor at the National Safety Council from 2013 to 2016, authored the report &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.colorado.gov/pacific/hlcmsresource/Psycholigical%20and%20Physical%20Side%20Effects%20Teater%20NSC.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;The Psychological and Physical Side Effects of Pain Medications&lt;/a&gt;, which addresses the national epidemic of opioid abuse, addiction, and overdose.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Compared to marijuana, opioids are much riskier, much more dangerous,” Teater told Healthline. “Opioids cause more problems than they’re worth.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Opioids prescribed for pain bring fast relief and an accompanying sense of calm. Both effects quickly wear off, however, and a higher dose is necessary to regain the same effects due to increased tolerance to the drug.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“They’re not effective for ongoing improvement of chronic pain,” Teater said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“A lot of people are in pain,” Teater added. “And social and emotional factors affect pain and how we deal with it. The pain is made worse by poverty, stress at work, depression, and anxiety. People are looking for a killer medicine to fix it. Behavioral therapy is the best solution — get them exercising, improve mental health, reduce catastrophizing — but everyone is given pills.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Teater said quality of life goes down the longer you use prescription painkillers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Opioid receptors in our brains work to keep us motivated, confident about getting things done, and energized to do and finish projects,” he said. “Chronic use of opioids decreases the number of opioid receptors and our own opioids, as the brain quits producing these. We wind up with less motivation, less happiness, and less success. Opioid users have twice the rate of depression as nonusers. The longer you take them, the worse off you’re going to be.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It can be a downward spiral.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Life for a user revolves around opioids,” Teater said. “Thus begins a difficult relationship with the prescriber. Every visit focuses on pain and the opioids. Doctors have seven or eight minutes with each patient, a prescription is demanded, and it’s easier to give it to them than to explain why it’s not good for them.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Teater suggests there are only two appropriate uses for opioids, both short-term.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The first is acute trauma, as with soldiers with wartime injuries.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The sooner they get morphine — and its tremendous calming effect — the less likely they are to develop PTSD,” Teater said. “Opioids keep memories from searing into the consciousness.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The other time opioids may be called for is at the end of life.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The calming effect of opioids will help dying patients deal with the pain,” Teater said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Otherwise, he says, over-the-counter medications can be just as helpful as opioids for pain relief.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“One ibuprofen is as effective as two Percocet,” Teater says. “Opioids aren’t even as effective as Tylenol or acetaminophen. No one should be getting an opioid prescription for dental procedures, strains, or sprains. People think opioids are the strongest for pain relief but really it’s the calming effect that they want. It doesn’t have so much to do with the pain.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Drugs and children&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are also concerns about opioids in relation to children.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Two studies published Monday in the journal Pediatrics dealt with the topic.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/children-ingesting-prescription-pills&quot;&gt;first study&lt;/a&gt;, researchers reported that poison control centers average 32 calls a day connected to young children accidentally ingesting prescription pills.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.aappublications.org/news/2017/03/20/Opioids032017&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;second study&lt;/a&gt;, researchers said most teens abusing prescription opioids had been given them at a younger age for medical reasons.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Marijuana isn’t great for young children either.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/marijuana-popularity-increases-childrens-exposure-rises&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; published last year reported that accidental exposures of children to marijuana were rising in Colorado after that state legalized medicinal marijuana.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers said the exposures were mainly due to parents leaving marijuana in places where young children could find it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Most of those exposures involved food laced with cannabis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The children admitted to the hospital suffered from vomiting, dizziness, drowsiness, and respiratory problems. There were a few cases of seizures.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, no deaths were reported.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Editor’s note: Officials at the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America (PhRMA) did not respond to Healthline’s requests for an interview for this story.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<updateddate>2017-03-22T11:00:00</updateddate>
