<dc:creator>Matt Schneiderman and David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-22T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Gun Violence Draining Public Health Resources</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/gun-violence-draining-public-health-resources
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/032117_gunviolence_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Gun violence doesn’t just injure and kill people.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It also costs the public health system in the United States a lot of time and money.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And a significant portion of taxpayer funds are being used to pay for it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s the conclusion of a &lt;a href=&quot;http://med.stanford.edu/news/all-news/2017/03/initial-hospital-costs-from-gunshot-wounds-total-6-billion-over-nine-years.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;new study&lt;/a&gt; conducted by the Stanford University School of Medicine in California.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers published their findings today in the American Journal of Public Health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Billions of dollars spent&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers analyzed data from 267,000 patients who were admitted to medical facilities for gun-related injuries from 2006 to 2014.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They reported that the initial hospitalization costs for these patients during the nine-year period were more than $6.6 billion.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s an average of $735 million a year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers noted that these were just initial costs and did not include emergency room visits or hospital readmissions after the initial injury.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The injuries in the study included gunshot wounds that were self-inflicted, accidental, and those related to assaults.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers noted that 10 percent of trauma patients at Stanford’s medical facility suffered from gunshot or knife wounds.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There is a high cost for these injuries, especially because they are preventable,” Sarabeth Spitzer, a Stanford medical student and lead author of the study, said in a press statement.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The research team also noted that research on gun violence has been limited since 1996. That’s when Congress approved a law forbidding federal funds from being used on firearms research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/policy-gun-violence-research-ban-lifted-after-newtown-shooting-012114#2&quot;&gt;ban was lifted&lt;/a&gt; in January 2014.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Firearm injuries are tied to one of the most controversial political issues in the country, so it is important for all sides to have access to fact-based research,” Spitzer said. “Cost information can be especially helpful when making health policy decisions.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Who’s getting shot&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers also discovered that the gunshot victims were overwhelmingly male.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There was also a connection between their insurance status and how they were injured.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The shootings of younger individuals with those with lower incomes insured by Medicaid comprised two-thirds of the firearm injuries. These people were most often the victims of an assault.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Older people with Medicare coverage were more likely to have self-inflicted gunshot wounds.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers uncovered that 40 percent of the total healthcare costs related to gun injuries is paid for by the government.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s a very high financial burden,” Spitzer said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She also noted that these kinds of cases can be ongoing. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There’s a cost if you're readmitted. There's long-term rehab, and a lot of these patients end up needing long-term healthcare,&quot; she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Spitzer’s team next plans to analyze data on the costs of hospital readmissions in gun-related cases.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Public Policy</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-21T13:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-21T13:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/gun-violence-draining-public-health-resources
</guid>
<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-21T20:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Should Young Doctors Be Allowed to Work 24-Hour Shifts?
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/should-young-docs-work-24-hr-shifts
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/032117_24hrsdoctors_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&g
]]>
<![CDATA[
t;&lt;p&gt;Have you ever worked 24 hours straight?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some young, aspiring doctors will soon be doing just that.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;First-year medical residents will be allowed to work 24-hour shifts later this year, when a cap previously limiting shifts to 16 hours is lifted.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education (ACGME) issued a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.acgme.org/Portals/0/PDFs/Nasca-Community/Section-VI-Memo-3-10-17.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;statement&lt;/a&gt; saying the revisions would “return first-year residents to the same schedule as other residents and fellows” and will be implemented during the 2017-2018 academic year. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The number of clinical and educational hours for residents will remain the same with a maximum of 80 hours of work per week.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But under the new revisions first-year doctors will now be permitted to work a 24-hour shift, plus an additional four hours to help facilitate transitions between doctors. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Why the long hours?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The ACGME argues that raising the cap on hours will ensure a “seamless continuity of care.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, the move has sparked criticism. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The ACGME’s adoption of this dangerous proposal displays a reckless disregard for the lives and health of thousands of medical residents and their patients nationwide,” Dr. Michael Carome, director of the Public Citizen’s Health Research Group, said in a&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.citizen.org/pressroom/pressroomredirect.cfm?ID=10202&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt; statement&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Fourth-year medical students across the country are now bracing themselves for inhuman shifts that will require them, just after graduating from medical school, to make life-or-death medical decisions and to drive home while sleep deprived for 28 hours or longer.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2011, the ACGME capped the number of hours first-year residents could work in one shift at 16 hours.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Now, the ACGME says the hypothesized benefits of limiting first-year hours were not realized and “the disruption of team-based care and supervisory systems, has had a significant negative impact on the professional education of the first-year resident, and effectiveness of care delivery of the team as a whole.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But Dr. Kelly Thibert, president of the American Medical Student Association, says that shorter shifts don’t necessarily equate to diminished continuity of care for patients. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“One of the recurring critiques of resident work-hour restrictions is that shorter shift lengths would lead to an increase in number of handoffs and thus would lead to decreased continuity of care. This concern is valid, but the perception that shorter shifts must come at the expense of patient safety due to the increased number of handoffs is just that, a perception,” she told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It is not the number of transitions but rather the quality of transitions that is critical to ensuring patient safety. Even at the end of 28-hour shifts, transitions of care still occur and these come at a time when residents are more likely to leave out information they deem ‘unimportant’ as they have reached and surpassed the point of exhaustion.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Doctors facing burnout&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Eve Kellner, president of the Committee of Interns and Residents (CIR), says an 80-hour work week puts enormous pressure on residents. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Doctors are human and humans require time to attend to the needs of life,” she told Healthline. “When you’re working an 80-hour week, you don't see your children or significant other who, in moments of despair, might be the only thing that has been staving off feeling isolated or developing depression. Not to mention how impossible it is to go to the DMV, mail a package, get laundry done, make healthy food choices, and other simple things that a human intern needs to tend to.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kellner says physician burnout has reached epidemic levels.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a survey of CIR members, 62 percent felt so burned out that it had affected their work and 28 percent had fallen asleep when driving after work. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Despite the high risk of burnout, Thibert says young doctors feel obligated to keep up with the demanding schedule. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“You would be hard pressed to find an intern or resident physician who would not work these long hours for fear of retaliation. It is engrained in the profession that this is how medicine operates and should therefore continue to operate,” she told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;An exception, not the rule&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.acgme.org/Portals/0/PDFs/Nasca-Community/Section-VI-Memo-3-10-17.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;statement&lt;/a&gt;, Dr. Thomas Nasca, chief executive officer of the ACGME, notes that the subject of work hours is an emotional topic both within the medical community and among the general public.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But he emphasizes that not all residents will regularly be expected to work a 24-hour shift. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It is important to note that 24 hours is a ceiling, not a floor. Residents in many specialties may never experience a 24-hour clinical work period. Individual specialties have the flexibility to modify these requirements to make them more restrictive as appropriate, and in fact, some already do,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kellner says although in the past there has been a culture that encouraged doctors to work long hours, this doesn’t necessarily need to be the expectation going forward. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The pressure to work excessive hours is part of the history and culture of medicine, but it is slowly changing. Residents are called residents because they used to literally live in the hospital. The norms were set by a physician workforce that was largely middle and upper class men, but residency is becoming much more diverse and inclusive. We need to realize that our own health shouldn’t suffer while we are caring for patients.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>

<item>
<title>Genetic Score May Help Predict Alzheimer’s</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/genetic-score-may-help-predict-alzheimers
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/aging/032117_alzheimersgenes_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It’s estimated that &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.alz.org/facts/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;5.5 million&lt;/a&gt; U.S. adults are now living with Alzheimer’s disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The large majority of these people (5.3 million) are over the age of 65. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The costs of caring for people with Alzheimer’s are also significant. Almost $260 billion in healthcare costs are predicted for this year. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The medical &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.alz.org/research/funding/alzheimers_our_commitment.asp&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;research&lt;/a&gt; community is working to find ways of diagnosing Alzheimer’s as early as possible. In the near future, physicians hope to be able to treat the disease before irreversible damage occurs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A team of international researchers, led by scientists at University of California-San Diego (UCSD) School of Medicine and University of California-San Francisco (UCSF), are moving closer to this goal.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The team designed a genetic score that they say predicts the risk of dementia among aging individuals with a high degree of accuracy. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The findings were &lt;a href=&quot;http://dx.doi.org/10.1371/journal.pmed.1002258&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;published&lt;/a&gt; in the journal PLOS Medicine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Analyzing genetic variations&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers analyzed the genotype of more than 70,000 patients with Alzheimer’s enrolled in several studies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They collected genetic data from healthy individuals in a control group. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The scientists focused on single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) that are commonly associated with Alzheimer’s.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/primer/genomicresearch/snp&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;SNPs&lt;/a&gt; are the most widespread type of genetic variation in our DNA. These variations are sometimes associated with certain illnesses, so they serve as biomarkers that help scientists to identify the disease. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In this study, the scientists examined Alzheimer’s-related SNPs as well as the status of the APOE gene. The &lt;a href=&quot;https://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/gene/APOE&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;APOE gene&lt;/a&gt; is responsible for encoding apolipoprotein E - a protein that ultimately forms lipoproteins, which enclose and carry cholesterol and other fats through the bloodstream.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;People that have the E4 variation of the APOE gene are known to be more likely to develop age-induced Alzheimer’s. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Based on this information and the data collected, the researchers used a polygenic score to determine the risk of developing age-related Alzheimer’s. They then tested it on two separate samples of people.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A polygenic hazard score (&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3605113/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;PHS&lt;/a&gt;) is the weighted sum of gene variation used to predict individual genetic traits and assess disease risk. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Study co-first author Rahul S. Desikan, Ph.D., clinical instructor in the UCSF Department of Radiology and Biomedical Imaging, explained the study procedure.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We combined genetic data from large, independent cohorts of patients with AD with epidemiological estimates to create the scoring, then replicated our findings on an independent sample and validated them with known biomarkers of Alzheimer’s pathology,” Desikan said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Accurate genetic tool&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers found that people scoring in the top 25 percent of the PHS developed Alzheimer’s at a much younger age and had the highest incidence.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Those with a high PHS score developed Alzheimer’s 10 to 15 years earlier than those with a low PHS. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Using the PHS score, the scientists were also able to identify the people who ultimately developed Alzheimer’s, despite the fact that they were cognitively healthy at the start of the study.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The tool enabled researchers to identify the age of Alzheimer’s (AD) onset even among participants who did not have the APOE E4 gene variation. The calculated score correlated strongly with neuropathology and AD-specific neurodegeneration. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“For any given individual, for a given age and genetic information, we can calculate your ‘personalized’ annualized risk for developing AD. That is, if you do not already have dementia, what is your yearly risk for AD onset, based on your age and genetic information. We think these measures of polygenetic risk, of involving multiple genes, will be very informative for early AD diagnosis, both in determining prognosis and as an enrichment strategy in clinical trials,” said Deskian.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study’s senior author also commented on the significance of the findings.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“From a clinical perspective, the polygenic hazard score provides a novel way not just to assess an individual’s lifetime risk of developing AD, but also to predict the age of disease onset,” said Anders Dale, Ph.D., who is also a professor in neurosciences, radiology, psychiatry, and cognitive science at the University of California-San Diego School of Medicine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Equally important, continuous polygenic testing of AD genetic risk can better inform prevention and therapeutic trials and be useful in determining which individuals are most likely to respond to therapy,” Dale added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The authors also point out some of the study’s limitations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For instance, the genetic data they used mainly belonged to people of European descent, so the study offers no evidence as to how PHS works for people of other ethnicities.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<updateddate>2017-03-21T11:00:00</updateddate>

</guid>
<dc:creator>Ana Sandoiu</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-21T18:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>
How Much Should a Workplace Accommodate Breastfeeding Employees?
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/should-workplace-accommodate-breastfeeding-employees
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/childrens-health/032017_breastfeedwork_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Pumping in the bathroom. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In some workplaces, that’s the only option for breastfeeding moms.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In others, even that’s a problem.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Most health experts recommend breastfeeding for the first year when possible and desirable.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lack of support in the workplace may be one reason that &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/breastfeeding/pdf/2016breastfeedingreportcard.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;breastfeeding rates&lt;/a&gt; in the United States drop after six months. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Katy Tang, a San Francisco supervisor, recently introduced legislation that could potentially change that, at least in her city.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The ordinance would require private and public workplaces to provide a lactation space with a seat, a surface, an electrical outlet, and access to a sink. All new construction would have to include a lactation space. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sfchronicle.com/bayarea/article/SF-may-require-breastfeeding-friendly-workplaces-10981678.php&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;San Francisco Chronicle&lt;/a&gt; notes that Tang is open to hardship exemptions for some small businesses. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Under the Affordable Care Act (ACA), &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.dol.gov/whd/nursingmothers/Sec7rFLSA_btnm.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;federal law&lt;/a&gt; currently requires employers to allow break time to express milk, along with a private place to do so. It can’t be a bathroom. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This law applies only to companies with more than 50 employees, and there are hardship exemptions. There are no federal rules for electrical outlets or sinks, although some states have more requirements than the federal law. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With repeal of the ACA on the table, those federal requirements may disappear, leaving the matter to states or individual businesses. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Some concerns&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Antonia Townsend is the founder of TheEnclosed.com, which has four employees in San Francisco.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Townsend is also expecting her first child in a few months. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I plan to breastfeed and pump in the office as needed throughout my first few months. While we will not have a ‘lactation space,’ we are taking a conference room and making it more private with curtains,” she told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Townsend acknowledged her privileged situation as the boss. But she’d do the same for any of her employees.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In fact, she believes all employers should do everything possible to help mothers breastfeed or pump at work. She added that it’s a crucial part of keeping these women in the workforce.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Even so, she doesn’t embrace the idea of strict legal requirements for lactation spaces.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For her business, it would be “completely untenable,” she said. “Especially if the requirement didn’t specify the size of the business and other parameters.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;TheEnclosed.com rents space in an office building shared by other businesses.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Townsend’s lactation space will have access to electricity but no sink. This setup, she said, is the only way it’s feasible. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It [the sink] would require complete re-plumbing of rented space. Landlords wouldn’t pay. We’d have to move or shut down the business if it was really a requirement,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Townsend is part of Dogpatch Business Association, a group of local businesses including bars, restaurants, accounting services, and others. She said it likely wouldn’t be different for any of them.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It would be a straight-up deal breaker for the majority of small businesses, especially with rents in San Francisco,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I’m hyperaware because San Francisco is legislation-happy. As a result, small businesses are getting squeezed out of the city. We don’t want to squeeze women of childbearing age out of the workforce as less desirable hires,” she continued.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some of her concerns are informed by the past, she explained. She once worked for a company where, though it certainly wasn’t a written policy, the culture was not friendly toward hiring women of childbearing age. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“That is the implication of this type of legislation,” said Townsend. “It puts this perceived burden of ever hiring women of childbearing age which, to me, is a far more horrible concern. Don’t get me wrong, you have to be able to breastfeed or pump. But it’s the other side of this, that’s what we risk, and it’s a really frightening prospect. This sort of legislation could have a subtle, but material impact on hiring practices.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When it comes to business, size might matter.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Townsend suggested that any legislation on lactation spaces should at least differentiate between small, medium, and large businesses.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But there’s more to it than size.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“A large office with extra space might be able to handle it. But a large restaurant with a hundred employees on a high-trafficked street — think of the rent on that. Creating a lactation space would be totally prohibitive. They’d have to leave the area. You have to understand the physical setup of each business,” said Townsend.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“That’s why legislation like this is problematic. It comes down to a case-by-case basis.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A tale of two businesses&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Erica Perng, director of communications at Lumos Labs, Inc. (Lumosity) reports a positive breastfeeding-work relationship. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In addition to offering 12 weeks of paid leave, when I returned to work, I had access to a serene Mother's Room equipped with a comfortable chair, pillows, ottoman, hospital grade pump, drawers to store my pump parts, a refrigerator, sink, and extras like a bottle brush, dish soap specifically for removing breast milk residue, dish rack specifically for pump parts, nursing tea, parenting books, and a bulletin board for putting up baby photos.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s a good way to retain valuable employees. It’s a setup that enabled Perng to breastfeed her son beyond his first birthday.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As Perng points out, businesses in Silicon Valley tend to be supportive of working parents. But it’s probably more than many companies around the country could manage.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mark Aselstine, founder of Uncorked Ventures, does business just outside of San Francisco. He has a small, part-time staff, and breastfeeding hasn’t been an issue.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He thinks requiring new construction to include lactation space is a great concept. But he shares Townsend’s concerns about business size and older, established buildings. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The ability of a business when they hire their first employee is dramatically different than say Google, Facebook, or Apple,” he said. “Where I get concerned as a small business owner is that if size isn't taken into account, do I need to create this space, before I can even hire an employee?” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Aselstine told Healthline that his wife had to deal with less-than-ideal setups at work. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Some of the time, it was the best that an employer or site could do. Other times, it seemed they simply didn't care all that much. It always seems better to me to allow people to make the best accommodation that they can, given the space and monetary requirements at play. But I know that also leads to some percentage of people thinking that means there aren't any real requirements,” he explained.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It seems like those two are competing concepts, which is why our local ordinance for new construction is pretty important. If I moved into my own space, it would be great to have ordinances like this taken care of already,” said Aselstine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Lactation spaces don’t solve everything&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Blogger Mary Kathryn Tiller of Texas likes the ordinance.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She told Healthline it would go a long way to improving women’s experiences of pumping in the workplace.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Not that it would solve every problem.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Tiller has had access to a private room in the workplace. She called it a partial win.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When her first child was born, she used the company conference room and brought her laptop in so she could continue working while pumping. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The only thing between her and her co-workers was an “in use” sign on the door. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;By the time her second child came along, she had a new job and a private nursing room. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The downside was that her job involved a desktop computer. And she was paid by the hour. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I needed the mobility, like a laptop, to move my workspace into the private room,” said Tiller. “Otherwise, I would have to clock out and lose pay. Unless the company's culture is supportive of breastfeeding mothers and will not punish them, either socially or financially, it doesn't solve all the problems.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Tiller credits both employers with being family friendly and supportive of her desire to breastfeed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Unfortunately, neither was adequately equipped with the tools to help me blend work and breastfeeding in a way that didn’t detract from my work day. I think you need both, the moral support and the equipment to be successful as a breastfeeding mom in the workplace,” she explained.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Eventually, she and her husband decided things would work out better if she stopped working outside the home. It wasn’t the only reason, but not having to deal with pumping on the job was definitely a factor.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“My advice to mothers who cannot afford to leave their job is pump if you can. It's hard work and terribly inconvenient. But if it's what you desire to do for your child, it's worth it and it's just for a season. If pumping wears you out, or is just not feasible in your job, formula provides a fantastic alternative for your babies. You're working hard to provide for your kiddos, financially and nutritionally, whether you use breast milk or formula,” she said.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>

<category>Public Policy</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-20T15:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-20T15:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/should-workplace-accommodate-breastfeeding-employees
</guid>
<dc:creator>Ann Pietrangelo</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-20T22:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
How Deep Do the Medicaid Cuts Go in Republican Health Plan?
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/medicaid-cuts-in-republican-health-plan
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/ACA/032017_GOPmedicaid_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;L
]]>
<![CDATA[
ike millions of Americans, Rachel Phalen is grateful for the Medicaid expansion that accompanied the passage of the Affordable Care Act (ACA).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Phelan&lt;strong&gt;,&lt;/strong&gt; a substitute teacher from Kentucky, has an 11-year-old son, Vance, who suffered a stroke in utero that caused him to have seizures for the first year of his life. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As a result, he has autism, tic disorder, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Most of Vance’s needs, Phelan said, are insured only because of a Medicaid-covered waiver in her state. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Considering all the obstacles he faces, Vance has significantly improved in all areas of his life,” she told Healthline. “He requires constant speech and behavior therapy. He is growing into a functional person.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But if Medicaid funding is cut, Vance would likely lose many of his much-needed services.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It will set him back so far,” Phelan said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Medicaid cuts on horizon&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;If House Republican leaders and President Trump have their way, nearly &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.forbes.com/sites/anthonynitti/2017/03/13/gop-health-care-bill-will-result-in-a-huge-tax-cut-for-the-rich-24-million-without-insurance/#6ba2c1eb6a2&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;$880 billion&lt;/a&gt; in Medicaid funds will be cut over the next 10 years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Over the same period of time, wealthy Americans would receive a tax cut of just about the same amount.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Under the House GOP’s plan, Medicaid expansion will be killed, and payments to the states will be capped and paid out by block grants.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Instead of the feds paying a set percentage of the states’ Medicaid needs, they would only pay a fixed amount per beneficiary. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This cap does not account for the almost inevitable increases in healthcare costs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Under the GOP plan, recipients will be cut off if they lose eligibility for two or more months.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Critics say it is just a way to take more Americans in need off the program.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The majority of the recipients of the Medicaid expansion are typically on the program temporarily, or come in and out of it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Therefore, the proposed changes have struck fear into the hearts of millions of Americans, including families with low incomes, seniors, those with intellectual and developmental disabilities, pregnant women, people dealing substance abuse, and children.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Obamacare to become Trumpcare?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;When Obamacare was passed, Medicaid was expanded to include all Americans under age 65 who earn up to &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/federal-poverty-level-eligibility-medicare-medicaid-benefits.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;138 percent&lt;/a&gt; of the federal poverty level.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Since then, Kentucky and 30 other states and the District of Columbia have chosen to participate in the expansion, with 19 states abstaining.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;More than 11 million adults have enrolled since the expansion through March 2016, according to &lt;a href=&quot;http://kff.org/health-reform/state-indicator/medicaid-expansion-enrollment/?currentTimeframe=0&amp;amp;sortModel=%7B%22colId%22:%22Location%22,%22sort%22:%22asc%22%7D&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;a review&lt;/a&gt; by the Kaiser Family Foundation of data from the Centers for Medicare &amp;amp; Medicaid Services (CMS).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Beyond those 11 million, Medicaid, which has been available since the 1960s, covers an additional 57 million Americans, almost six times as many as those enrolled in the Obamacare marketplaces.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;President Trump promised on the campaign trail that he would not cut Medicaid. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, the House bill will lead to &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/13/us/politics/affordable-care-act-health-congressional-budget-office.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;14 million&lt;/a&gt; fewer individuals being covered by Medicaid by 2026, according to the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Debate in Ohio&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In Ohio alone, some 3 million residents with low incomes or disabilities are now receiving coverage because of the Medicaid expansion.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Officials at the Center for Community Solutions, a nonpartisan group based in Cleveland, said the plan could cost Ohio more than $25 billion by 2025.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The center concluded that the resulting payments wouldn't be enough in Ohio to keep covering the state’s recipients.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Columbus Dispatch reported that Ohio's proposed Medicaid budget for next year is projected at &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.dispatch.com/news/20170313/ohio-could-lose-26-billion-under-trumpcare&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;$28 billion&lt;/a&gt;, including federal funding.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ohio Gov. John Kasich, who enacted the Medicaid expansion in his state under Obamacare in 2013, opposes his fellow Republicans’ plan to cut Medicaid.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said Republicans need to reconsider their plan and come to a compromise with Democrats.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If all you focus on in life is what's in it for me, you're a loser. You are a big time loser,” Kasich said on “&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/john-kasich-trump-very-open-compromise-health-care-n732386&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Meet the Press&lt;/a&gt;” this month. “And this country better be careful we're not losing the soul of our country because we play politics and we forget people who are in need.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kasich also took issue with an interview Vice President Mike Pence did on an Ohio television station in which Pence said the new legislation would give Ohio the “resources and flexibility that they need to be able to meet those needs going forward.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Said Kasich, “No, he's not right. Look, the bill needs [to be] fixed. The current system doesn't work. That's why it's possible to get Democrats involved … Don't kill Medicaid expansion, and you've got to fix the exchange, but you have to have the ability to subsidize people at lower income levels.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Disdain for the poor&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The plans that Republicans and Trump have for Medicaid are actually not conservative enough for the &lt;a href=&quot;http://thehill.com/policy/healthcare/health-reform-implementation/324479-freedom-caucus-still-opposes-gop-health-plan&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Freedom Caucus&lt;/a&gt;, an ultraconservative group.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, a growing number of &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cnn.com/2017/03/14/politics/moderate-republicans-health-care/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;moderate GOP governors and Congress members&lt;/a&gt; say the plan reflects an uncaring side of the GOP toward people with low or no incomes. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;An example of this uncaring contingent is Kansas Republican Congressman Roger Marshall.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Just like Jesus said, ‘The poor will always be with us.’ There is a group of people that just don’t want healthcare and aren’t going to take care of themselves. I think just morally, spiritually, socially, [some people] just don’t want healthcare,” he told &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/what-happens-if-gop-health-plan-approved&quot;&gt;New York magazine&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Seema Verma, the woman Trump tapped as the new administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS), appears to share the same opinion.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Just hours after she was sworn in last week, Verma reportedly sent &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/on-first-day-in-office-new-medicaid-chief-urges-states-to-charge-premiums-prod-recipients-to-get-jobs/2017/03/15/8d36c480-0928-11e7-a15f-a58d4a988474_story.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;a letter&lt;/a&gt; to the nation’s governors, urging states to alter Medicaid by imposing insurance premiums, charging recipients for part of emergency room bills, and prodding them to get jobs, according to multiple news reports.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The letter also called the Medicaid expansion a “clear departure from the core, historical mission of the program.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Critics of Verma, who was approved virtually down party lines in the Senate, say that the Medicaid expansion is actually right in line with what Medicaid has always been about: assisting America’s less fortunate.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Verma had already &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.indystar.com/story/news/politics/2017/02/15/architect-indianas-medicaid-plan-faces-confirmation-hearing/97965042/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;riled critics&lt;/a&gt; when she worked for Pence when he was governor of Indiana. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Verma’s Medicaid model in Indiana threw a person out of the program for missing two payments — no matter what their life circumstances at the time. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;‘Remarkable level of cruelty’&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In December, Dr. Robert Zarr, president of Physicians for a National Health Program, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.pnhp.org/news/2016/december/doctors-group-calls-on-trump-to-rescind-nominations-of-price-verma-to-key-health-&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;said&lt;/a&gt; Verma’s actions in Indiana “signal that she will inflict cruel and unusual punishment on America's most vulnerable citizens.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Senator Maria Cantwell (D-Wash.) told the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/13/us/politics/seema-verma-medicaid-medicare-administrator.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;The New York Times&lt;/a&gt; that Verma made millions of dollars in consulting fees by kicking poor, working people off of Medicaid for failure to pay monthly contributions similar to premiums.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Michael Carome, director of the health research group at Public Citizen, the nonprofit consumer advocacy organization, told Healthline, “The House Republicans’ plan to cut nearly a trillion dollars from the Medicaid budget over the next 10 years, while simultaneously giving a huge tax break to wealthy individuals and corporations, demonstrates a remarkable level of cruelty and callousness.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Carome, whose organization spearheaded the Clean Budget Coalition, an alliance of hundreds of public interest groups that together are calling on Congress and the White House to pass a clean budget with no ideological riders, said that the Republican health plan, if enacted, “would deprive millions of our country’s poorest and most vulnerable people of the healthcare they deserve, resulting in preventable suffering and death.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Seniors affected, too&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The group that perhaps stands to lose the most if these controversial plans for Medicaid are approved is seniors, who voted for Trump by a wide margin.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Without Medicaid, millions of seniors and their families may simply not be able to pay for things like long-term care, nursing home services, and other services.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nancy LeaMond, executive vice president of The American Association of Retired Persons (AARP), the nation’s largest group for seniors with more than 37 million members, said in a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.aarp.org/politics-society/advocacy/info-2017/aarp-opposes-healthcare-bill.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;statement&lt;/a&gt; last week, that the Medicaid cuts would put the health and safety of 17 million Americans, including seniors as well as children and adults with disabilities, “in jeopardy” by eliminating services that allow individuals to live independently in their homes and communities. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This harmful legislation would make healthcare less secure and less affordable,” LeaMond said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Trump’s press secretary, &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2017/03/08/press-briefing-press-secretary-sean-spicer&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Sean Spicer&lt;/a&gt;, dismissed the AARP’s concerns about the bill, suggesting that AARP is a special interest group.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mick Mulvaney, the White House budget director, said on Thursday that &lt;a href=&quot;http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2017/03/white-house-says-cutting-meals-on-wheels-is-compassionate.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;deep cuts&lt;/a&gt; in Trump’s proposed budget to multiple programs for seniors and the poor is “one of the most compassionate things we can do.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;San Diego seniors fearful&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Beverly G., who’s in her 80s and still lives in her own home in San Diego, said Medi-Cal, which is California’s version of Medicaid, “means absolutely everything. End of story. There is no other answer. If I didn’t have it, I’d be really, deeply struggling.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Beverly is a member of ElderHelp, a community-based nonprofit organization in San Diego that provides personalized services and information that helps seniors remain independent and live with dignity in their own homes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Members of ElderHelp are worried and uncertain about what will happen to their Medicaid benefits, say the leadership at the organization.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our response to the GOP plan aligns closely with that of the National Council on Aging (NCOA), AARP, and other national leaders in the aging sector,” Anya Delacruz, associate executive director of ElderHelp, told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In the context of Medicaid, we are particularly concerned that proposed per capita caps will shift the burden of skyrocketing healthcare costs to the states,” she said. “We believe that resultant/imminent cuts will lead to a significant reduction in necessary services.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Delacruz added that more than one-third of ElderHelp members receive assistance through Medi-Cal. Many, she explained, are already struggling to meet their most basic needs including housing, transportation, food, and rising healthcare costs. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The drug crisis&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;During a time when America is dealing with a nationwide opioid drug abuse epidemic, the Republican healthcare plan would also eliminate the Obamacare requirement that Medicaid cover mental health and addiction services in states that expanded it. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In his speech last month before Congress, President Trump addressed the drug crisis and vowed, “We will expand treatment for those who have become so badly addicted.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, the rollback of Medicaid expansion would deeply affect many states where the opioid addiction crisis is the most severe, including Kentucky, Ohio, and West Virginia. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If you are drug addicted, if you are mentally ill, you have to consistently see the doctor,” Kasich said in his “Meet the Press” interview. “From what I see in this House bill, the resources are not there.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Joshua Sharfstein, associate dean at Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health, told &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2017/03/09/gop-health-care-bill-would-drop-mental-health-coverage-mandate-covering-1-3-million-americans/?utm_term=.14801884&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;The Washington Post&lt;/a&gt; that the Republicans healthcare plans represent “a major retreat from the effort to save lives in the opiate epidemic.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nearly 1.3 million Americans receive treatment for mental health and substance abuse disorders under the Medicaid expansion, healthcare economists Richard G. Frank of the Harvard Medical School, and Sherry Glied of New York University, recently told the Post.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Children affected, too&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Medicaid cuts in states like Virginia, where the budget is already tight, could mean far fewer children are covered, according to a Public News Service (PNS) report last week. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Vox reported that Virginia Medicaid covers about half a million children from low-income households. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Margaret Nimmo Holland, executive director at Voices for Virginia's Children, said there’s been bipartisan consensus in Virginia that children's health is worth the investment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She said 19 out of 20 children in Virginia now have healthcare coverage, and the care delivered through Medicaid was designed by doctors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She told Vox that shifting costs from the feds to an already strained Virginia budget would mean fewer children covered, less generous benefits, or lower payments to providers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It is very concerning that 50 years of progress in children's health could be undone so quickly,” Holland said. “The benefits are actually designed by pediatricians, so it means that lawmakers are not deciding what services kids need, pediatricians are. And so any time that you start cutting the benefits, you're really jeopardizing the health of children.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Recipients meet with congressman&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;On Mar. 3, Rachel Phelan and her son’s speech therapist, Leslie McColgin, along with several others with children who receive support from Medicaid, visited the office of Kentucky Rep. James Comer, the Congressman in their district.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Phelan said that while the meeting with Comer’s staff, which Comer himself did not attend, went well, their questions weren’t really answered. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I do not believe [Comer] will care or listen,” Phelan said. “I hope that somewhere out there these politicians can grow a heart, and realize the way they vote and run our country affects everyone. If you cannot stand up for our vulnerable, then what kind of person are you?”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If the federal government or states stop funding these programs, Phelan wonders what will happen to children with disabilities, like her son, nationwide who are in need.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Kids with disabilities become adults with disabilities,” she said. “How will we help this vulnerable group? We can’t simply institutionalize them. They are citizens and they have rights.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Phelan said that applying block grants to Medicaid will create a national “disaster” for Medicaid recipients. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There’s not enough funding now for our Medicaid system,” she said. “If we ration the funding, we will have to resort to further rationing care. Those who are disabled do not have other options for care. The will suffer greatly.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Editor’s note: Comer’s press office declined to respond to several requests for comment for this story.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-03-20T14:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-20T14:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/medicaid-cuts-in-republican-health-plan
</guid>
<dc:creator>Jamie Reno</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-20T21:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Poison Centers Inundated with Calls About Children Ingesting Prescription Pills
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/children-ingesting-prescription-pills
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/childrens-health/032017_childopioids_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Every 45 minutes, on average, a call is made to a poison control center in the United States about a child being exposed to prescription opioids.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s 32 calls every day from January 2000 through December 2015, according to a &lt;a href=&quot;http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/early/2017/03/16/peds.2016-3382&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;new study&lt;/a&gt; conducted by the Center for Injury Research and Policy, and the Central Ohio Poison Center at Nationwide Children's Hospital in Columbus, Ohio.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The research was published today in the journal Pediatrics.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers said the data show the current opioid crisis is affecting not just adult Americans but their children, through both accidental and intentional misuse.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We knew we would find something, but the numbers smacked me across the face,” Dr. Marcel Casavant, one of the study’s authors, told Healthline. “This is really a lot of kids.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What the numbers show&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;More than 188,000 calls came into U.S. poison control centers regarding pediatric exposure to opioids during the time period studied.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;About 60 percent of those were regarding children younger than age 5.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The second most common age group affected was teenagers. More than two-thirds of those incidents were intentional. That represented a 50 percent increase in suspected teenage opioid-related suicides over the 16 years covered by the study.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Since 2009, exposures have actually decreased, but researchers said that news comes with two caveats.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Incidents involving buprenorphine, a prescription drug used to help people addicted to opioids, have continued to climb. The study notes nearly half of those incidents have been serious enough to warrant admitting the patient to a healthcare facility.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And it’s possible the overall decrease could be partly due to people turning to nonprescription opioids, exposure to which wasn’t included in this study.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“So maybe it means good news, maybe it means legal and pharmaceutical and education actions are finally paying off and we’re getting control of this epidemic. But maybe it means people have just been driven to street drugs, like heroin,” said Casavant, who is medical director of the Central Ohio Poison Center and chief toxicologist at Nationwide Children's Hospital.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The heroin problem&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Deaths from heroin overdoses have increased sharply since 2010.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, that increase doesn’t necessarily mean children have an increased risk of exposure to drugs like heroin in the home.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Unlike a bottle of pills that might be lying on the bathroom counter, “people tend to be a lot more careful with heroin,” Casavant notes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Nicole Villapiano, a University of Michigan pediatrician who was not involved with the study, told Healthline the findings are consistent with what she sees in her own practice.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When you're working in the ER, it feels like a nearly daily occurrence” to see children or teenagers exposed to opioids, said Villapiano, who has conducted research on increasing numbers of babies born with drug withdrawal symptoms from opioids.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She called the new findings “yet another unintended consequence of prescription opioids.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How to reduce the problem&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Not all of the child exposure to opioids can be avoided, but using different packaging or administering the drugs differently could lower the numbers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the case of exposure to buprenorphine, Villapiano thinks those incidents could be cut by administering the drug via an implantable rod — rather than the more common pills or dissolvable strip — more frequently, removing the possibility of misuse by another individual.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;More broadly, adult Americans are allowed by law to request prescriptions in nonchild-resistant containers, letting the elderly or those with disabilities avoid hard-to-open bottles.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Casavant said that’s fine if you’re careful with those bottles, but if there are children in the house or you, say, carry them in your purse to a house with kids, it’s risky.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The story we hear all the time is, ‘I just turned around for a second, I turned back, and my kid ate 10 or 15 pills,’” he says.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Child-resistant containers are no guarantee, though, particularly in terms of a teenager who intends to deliberately ingest the pills.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But both accidental and intentional exposures might be reduced through the use of different packaging, such as blister packs that require each pill to be punched out individually.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Casavant says that around half the teenagers he sees in the ER and his clinic who have attempted suicide regret it immediately after the attempt, leading them to call the poison control hotline or run to tell their parents.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Punching out individual pills won’t prevent suicide by overdose, but it could give teenagers more time to change their minds before it’s too late.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He noted that situations like that are where calls to a poison control center are critical. The study found most of the cases called into the centers were able to be handled at home with the guidance of the call center staff.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Poison Control &lt;a href=&quot;1-800-222-1222&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;hotline&lt;/a&gt; in the United States is 1-800-222-1222. There are poison control specialists available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Children's Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-20T11:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-20T11:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/children-ingesting-prescription-pills
</guid>
<dc:creator>Matthew Berger</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-20T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Why Men in the United States Don’t Get Vasectomies</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/why-men-in-us-dont-get-vasectomies
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/mens-health/031917_vasectomies_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Getting a vasectomy isn’t something men usually think to do with some of their buddies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But that’s what three Southern California fathers did.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Paul Diaz, Basilio Santangelo, and John Lambrechts went to the same doctor on the same day to have &lt;a href=&quot;http://ucla.multimedia-newsroom.com/index.php/2017/03/06/starting-conversations-ending-stigmas-about-vasectomies/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;back-to-back-to-back vasectomies&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The men have two children each. They said part of the reason for their decision was to take responsibility for their family planning after their wives had done the giving birth part.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I didn't want my wife to have to go back on birth control because I know there's a lot of issues with it. So then I thought I would take one for the team and I decided I would do it,” Lambrechts told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“My wife, Sabrina, already went through a lot giving birth,” added Santangelo, “and so I figured it's an easier option for me to do this.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The trio also did the appointments together as a way to spotlight the low percentage of men in the United States who get vasectomies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It's not something to be ashamed of, and on the contrary, it's you being responsible,” Diaz told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Not part of U.S. culture&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.un.org/en/development/desa/population/publications/pdf/family/trendsContraceptiveUse2015Report.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2015 report&lt;/a&gt; by the United Nations showed that 1 in 10 men in the United States get vasectomies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s half the rate of men in Canada and the United Kingdom.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The low percentage comes despite the fact vasectomies are a significantly easier medical operation than tubal ligation or other procedures that women go through.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Vasectomies are an outpatient procedure and are performed at a doctor’s office under local anesthesia.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The operation generally takes less than 30 minutes and the recovery time is usually a few days.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Vasectomies also have a high success rate.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sterilization procedures for women, on the other hand, are usually performed at a hospital or surgical center.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They’re invasive surgery that’s done under general anesthesia.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The recovery is longer and usually requires an overnight stay after the operation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Jesse Mills, the urologist and director of the men’s clinic at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA), who did the procedure on the three fathers, said it makes senses for men to be the ones to undergo the surgery.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said part of the reason men don’t get vasectomies in the United States is that the practice is much more engrained in other industrialized nations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In other countries, it’s such a part of the norm,” Mills told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He noted that men in the United States don’t even go in for regular checkups.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This is part of a public health issue as well,” he said. “This is a huge part of how guys look at healthcare.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Not a problem in Alaska&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. John Cullen delivers babies in the coastal community of Valdez in eastern Alaska.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He also performs vasectomies. He’s done hundreds of them in the past 25 years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cullen told Healthline he wasn’t surprised by the low percentage of U.S. men getting vasectomies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But he said that’s not the case in the rugged town of Valdez.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s seems easier for men up here to do it,” said Cullen, who is a board member for the American Academy of Family Physicians. “They may not be as worried about their masculinity.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another reason, Cullen says, is he makes birth control part of the discussion when parents come in to see him in the initial weeks after a child is born.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s a good environment to have the discussion,” he said. “It’s a teachable moment.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cullen has also done outreach to the community to educate people about vasectomies. He even occasionally offers free vasectomies as part of events such as the Valentine’s Day Dance at Prince William Sound College.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He tells men it’s an easy and effective form of birth control.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There’s not a lot of long-term consequences,” Cullen said. “It’s an ideal form of contraception.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The long-time physician also emphasizes to men the importance of doing their part.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think it’s important for men to take responsibility for their own contraception. It’s part of being an adult,” Cullen said. “I don’t think it’s fair for women to have all the responsibility on this.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Especially considering how easy the procedure is for men compared with women.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“For men not to step up to the plate is really fairly wimpy,” Cullen said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Doing their part&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Diaz, Santangelo, and Lambrechts did not wimp out.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The three men, who call themselves the “vascateers,” had all decided they were only going to have two children.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lambrechts thought of the surgery first.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I heard the surgery was a quick recovery, and she had already been through childbirth, so that was my contribution,” he told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When they heard about Lambrechts’ plan, his two fellow fathers decided to join him.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We are a very close group of friends,” said Santangelo. “Our kids were born months apart. We've traveled together before kids, and now with kids, and we've shared some pretty awesome milestones together [but] we never thought we'd share this!”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;All three men said the outpatient surgery was easier than they’d thought it’d be.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The procedure was done on a Friday afternoon, and by Sunday I was OK, and went to brunch with my family,” said Santangelo.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The trio decided to get the operation done right before the holidays since there would be plenty of sports on television while they recovered.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They aren’t the first men to think of this strategy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Several studies have shown an &lt;a href=&quot;http://fortune.com/2017/03/16/vasectomies-%20during-march-madness/?xid=time_socialflow_%20twitter&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;uptick in vasectomies&lt;/a&gt; each year right before the NCAA basketball tournament in March.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The idea is you can recover while watching college basketball all day long.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Binging on sports, though, wasn’t the main motivation for the three friends.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I heard the surgery was a quick recovery and [my wife] had already been through childbirth, so that was my contribution,” said Lambrechts.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We feel very blessed with the two girls we have,” added Diaz. “We're getting up there in the years and we're very comfortable with the two girls we have, so we just decided we didn't want any surprises down the road.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Guys don't really talk about this kind of thing that much,” noted Santangelo. “For us, we're all friends and are open with each other.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-03-19T06:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-19T06:00:00</updateddate>

<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-19T13:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>
Regenerative Stem Cell Treatment Offers Hope for People with Rheumatoid Arthritis
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/stem-cell-treatment-hope-for-people-with-ra
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/arthritis/031817_regenerativeRA_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A phase II stem cell treatment is the talk of the rheumatology community. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Stem cell treatments have been a topic of conversation among many people with autoimmune and degenerative forms of arthritis. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Now, an Australian pharmaceutical company is trying to figure out if this type of regenerative medicine could play a key role in treating or managing rheumatic diseases like rheumatoid arthritis (RA).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.mesoblast.com&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Mesoblast&lt;/a&gt; has developed a stem cell therapy that is administered intravenously to people with RA who didn’t experience success taking anti-TNF drugs like Remicade, Enbrel, and Humira.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The study results&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;https://globenewswire.com/news-release/2017/02/15/917784/0/en/Durable-Responses-and-Sustained-Low-Disease-Activity-Over-Nine-Months-After-a-Single-Dose-of-Mesoblast-Cell-Therapy-in-Rheumatoid-Arthritis-Patients-Resistant-to-Anti-TNF-Agents.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;phase II study&lt;/a&gt; followed 48 patients who received one injection of the stem cell therapy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These patients received therapeutic benefits as long as nine months after the initial dosing, company officials reported.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While more studies will be conducted in a phase III trial in order to validate the results, the results could mean positive things for the many people with RA who don’t fare well on TNF-inhibitors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Anti-TNF drugs are a billion dollar industry as well as a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2621374/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;source of relief&lt;/a&gt; for many people with RA.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2669237/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;20 to 40 percent&lt;/a&gt; of people treated with these medications either have an adverse reaction, or find no relief.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Perhaps the best news for people with RA who are sensitive to medications or experience pharmacophobia is that unlike some other treatments, little toxicity or side effects were indicated in the studies of Mesoblast’s stem cell treatment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How the treatment works&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The treatment uses mesenchymal precursor cells (MCPs).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Because the immune system doesn’t recognize these MCPs as foreign or invaders, they don’t tend to produce a negative response.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The MCP cells are adult stem cells, not embryonic stem cells. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The cells work because they contain certain receptors targeting the RA response and altering the way the body’s immune system works — or, in the sense of RA, the way it malfunctions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to a published statement to the press from Mesoblast, “The way the cells work is, they have receptors on their surface that are activated by every major cytokine that is important in progressive rheumatoid arthritis, including TNF, IL-1, IL-6, IL-17. Those cytokines drive the disease and also bind to receptors on our cells. And when they bind to our cells they activate the cells to release other factors that switch off the very cells that made those cytokines.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There continues to be more research done on stem cell therapy as a way to treat immune, autoimmune, and inflammatory diseases.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the United States, a company called &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.regenexx.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Regenexx&lt;/a&gt; shares some stem cell success stories on their website, often pertaining to healing osteoarthritis or injury.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While in the past, stem cells were only used to treat orthopedic injuries and conditions, newer research — like the targeted regenerative stem cell therapy that is being created by Mesoblast — also aims to treat other forms of arthritis like RA.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
