<pubdate>2017-03-18T06:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-18T06:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/stem-cell-treatment-hope-for-people-with-ra
</guid>
<dc:creator>Ashley Boynes-Shuck</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-18T13:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>The Tribal Diet That Could Eliminate Heart Disease</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/the-tribal-diet-that-could-eliminate-heart-disease
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/heart-health/031717_tribaldiet_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&l
]]>
<![CDATA[
t;p&gt;You may not walk like an Egyptian, but you might want to eat like a Tsimane.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(17)30752-3/fulltext?elsca1=tlpr&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; published today in The Lancet says the forager-horticulturist tribe in South America has the lowest reported levels of vascular aging of any population on Earth.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Besides the healthy heart conditions, these indigenous people of the Bolivian Amazon region also have low blood pressure, low cholesterol, and low blood glucose.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers attributed these healthy qualities to the tribe’s high level of physical activity and its plant-based diet.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They concluded that the lack of this type of activity and diet in developed countries such as the United States should be added to the risks associated with heart problems.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The loss of subsistence diets and lifestyles could be classed as a new risk factor for vascular aging and we believe that components of this way of life could benefit contemporary sedentary populations,” said Hillard Kaplan, PhD, senior author and anthropology professor at the University of New Mexico, in a press statement.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Katie Ferraro, a registered dietitian and assistant clinical professor at the University of San Diego and University of California, agrees with the assessment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We could certainly move in their direction,” Ferraro told Healthline. “We could look to them as models.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What researchers discovered&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers visited 85 Tsimane villages in 2014 and 2015.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They took CT scans of the hearts of 705 village residents between the ages of 40 and 94.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They checked for hardening of the coronary arteries as well as the villagers’ height, weight, blood pressure, heart rate, cholesterol, blood glucose, and inflammation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They discovered that 85 percent of Tsimane people had no risk of heart disease. That included two-thirds of the villagers who were 75 years or older.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another 13 percent of the tribe members had a low risk, while 3 percent had moderate or high risk.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A similar study of 6,814 people in the United States ages 45 to 84 showed that only 14 percent had no risk of heart disease. About 50 percent had a moderate or high risk. Another third had a low risk.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Tsimane population also had low heart rates and healthy levels of blood pressure, glucose, and cholesterol.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This was despite the fact that about half of villagers did show elevated levels of inflammation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The inflammation common to the Tsimane was not associated with increased risk of heart disease and may instead be the result of high rates of infections,” said Dr. Randall Thompson, cardiologist at Saint Luke's Mid America Heart Institute.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers credited the villagers’ plant-based diet and physical activity level for their health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They noted that the Tsimane people spend only 10 percent of their waking hours being inactive. That compares with a 54 percent inactivity level in people in industrialized nations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers said hunting, fishing, gathering, and farming keep the men working six to seven hours a day, and the women working four to six hours a day.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They also noted the Tismane people’s plant-rich diet, which is 72 percent carbohydrates, includes nonprocessed foods such as rice, corn, nuts, and fruits. Their diet is about 14 percent protein, coming from animal meat.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Smoking is also rare in these villages.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How Americans can adapt&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ferraro said the activity level and the carbohydrate-rich diet were the two factors that stood out in the study.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She noted high-carb diets are generally considered unhealthy in the United States, but that’s because Americans tend to get their carbohydrates from processed foods.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The villagers are eating the right carbohydrates,” said Ferraro, who teaches a cultural foods class at San Diego State University. “They’re a prescription for heart disease prevention.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kristin Kirkpatrick, MS, RD, LD, a licensed, registered dietitian who is a wellness manager at the Cleveland Clinic Wellness Institute, agreed with that assessment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It shows that having a high-carb diet is not as bad as people think with the key point that their carbs were also loaded with fiber, something the body cannot digest,” Kirkpatrick told Healthline. “I've always recommended a ‘back to the basics’ approach to diet and this clearly shows the upside to that.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Both dietitians also pointed to the high activity level as another key.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think the physical activity factor here is huge,” said Kirkpatrick, “and for sure corresponds to the new studies showing that inactivity is as risky to health as obesity.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Both acknowledge that Americans aren’t going to move to a tent in a national park and try to hunt game.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, they said there are ways people in modern societies can incorporate parts of the Tsimane lifestyle.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One is to significantly reduce the amount of processed foods in the diet.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The mantra of fresh vegetables, fruits, and nuts is applicable here.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The other is to lead a more active lifestyle, even for people who have desk jobs where they are sitting most of the workday.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ferraro said it’s a good habit to get up every hour from your desk and be active for 5 to 7 minutes. You can even set a timer to remind you.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That practice will add 45 minutes to an hour of exercise to your day.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Make movement part of your daily routine,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Heart Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-17T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-17T12:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/the-tribal-diet-that-could-eliminate-heart-disease
</guid>
<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-17T19:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Americans Are Having Less Sex. Does It Matter?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/americans-having-less-sex-does-it-matter
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/031717_lesssex_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Americans are having less sex.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Should we care? Does it matter?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Experts who talked to Healthline say it does — from the ability to have a relationship to maintaining good mental health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A recent &lt;a href=&quot;http://newscenter.sdsu.edu/sdsu_newscenter/news_story.aspx?sid=76628&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; in &lt;a href=&quot;https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs10508-017-0953-1&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Archives of Sexual Behavior &lt;/a&gt;found that people in the United States who were living together or married had sex less often between 2010 and 2014 compared with those who were together from 2000 to 2004.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This includes millennials, too. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Jean M. Twenge, the 2017 study's lead author, and professor of psychology at San Diego State University, conducted research last year that found millennials had fewer sexual partners than Gen Xers. She is the author of “Generation Me: Why Today's Young Americans Are More Confident, Assertive, Entitled — and More Miserable Than Ever Before.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Despite their reputation for hooking up, millennials and the generation after them (known as iGen or Generation Z) are actually having sex less often than their parents and grandparents did when they were young,” Twenge said in a statement. “That's partially because fewer iGeners and millennials have steady partners.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Understanding millennials and sex&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Her &lt;a href=&quot;https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10508-016-0798-z&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2016 research&lt;/a&gt; found that 15 percent of 20- to 24-year-olds born in the 1990s had not had any sexual partners since age 18, compared to only 6 percent of Gen Xers when they were young adults.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Twenge says the numbers aren’t indicative of the stereotype of the generation that they have a lot of sex with multiple partners.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Online dating apps should, in theory, help millennials find sexual partners more easily,” Twenge said in a statement. “However, technology may have the opposite effect if young people are spending so much time online that they interact less in person, and thus don’t have sex.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Jenni Skyler, a certified sex therapist, sexologist, and a licensed marriage and family therapist with The Intimacy Institute in Colorado, said that electronic distractions are one reason why young people may have sex less.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are also other barriers. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“People lay in bed on their tablets or phones, isolated from one another in an electronic medium that can be almost addictive. At least when people were lying in bed before with just the TV as a barrier, they could cuddle and watch the same show, upping the odds for sensual contact,” she told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Tammy Nelson, a certified sex therapist and licensed couples’ counselor, who wrote&lt;em&gt; “&lt;/em&gt;The New Monogamy&lt;em&gt;,” &lt;/em&gt;told Healthline&lt;em&gt; &lt;/em&gt;that technology may play a factor in how millennials approach sex.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They may depend on pornography, social media, or cyber relationships for instant gratification and uncomplicated relationships. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Perhaps cyber relationships and even sex with themselves or virtual partners is easier, faster, and less complicated than with their real life committed partner or spouse,” Nelson explained.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If that is the case, it doesn’t necessarily mean that they are any less happy than other generations, she added. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The ramifications of less sex&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In her 2016 study, Twenge noted that 45 percent of millennials had slept with someone other than a partner or spouse when they were in their late teens or 20s. That’s up from 35 percent of Gen Xers at the same age. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It's hard to say if millennials’ rate of sexual frequency will increase once they get into relationships,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;People getting married at age 30 may have less sex than if they’d married at 22 like baby boomers did.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Millennials are more likely to spend their years of peak sexual frequency without a steady partner, which might cut down on their total lifetime sexual frequency,” Twenge said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While they may be having sex less often, more of them are sleeping with people they are not “in a relationship” with.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Does it put millennials more at risk for sexual health complications?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/nchhstp/newsroom/2016/std-surveillance-report-2015-press-release.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2016 CDC report&lt;/a&gt; noted a rise in sexually transmitted infections (STIs) such as chlamydia (up 6 percent since 2014), syphilis (up 19 percent), and gonorrhea (up nearly 13 percent).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nearly 20 million new STI cases happen each year, the CDC says, and more than half of those are in people ages 15 to 24.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some experts say that &lt;a href=&quot;http://nypost.com/2016/11/02/millennials-arent-wearing-condoms-anymore/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;social media and technology&lt;/a&gt; has fueled this phenomenon. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Ryne Sherman, an associate professor at Florida Atlantic University who co-authored the 2016 study, said sexual frequency is tied to mental and physical health, though it is tough to confirm that more sex causes greater health, or if greater health causes more sex.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He suspects that it goes both ways. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our results are very consistent with the view that mental health is a real problem for millennials [compared with previous generations],” Sherman told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Fran Walfish, a family and relationship psychotherapist based in California, said the less-sex trend could be problematic for marriages — assuming that millennials still have less sex if they do marry. She noted a trend of young people in their 20s and 40s are in sexless marriages. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Lack of sex has many causes, including ‘we just had a baby,’ to being worn out by the kids, financial strain, or career demands. No matter the cause, at the root is a common denominator. Lack of communication,” Walfish told Healthline. “And, when marital communication breaks down, sex falls apart. Divorce often ensues.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Millennials also aren’t as focused on marriage and children, and aren’t taking these steps as did the generations before them, she added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Those that do marry and try to have kids later on could face age-related pregnancy risks and infertility issues.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Safer sex?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Twenge has said that millennials are “very interested in safety, which also appears in their reduced use of alcohol and their interest in ‘safe spaces’ on campus.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This is a very risk-averse generation, and that attitude may be influencing their sexual choices,” Twenge noted.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Millennials do not have drastically fewer sex partners and drastically lower sexual frequency, just lower than other generations given their age and the time in which they live, Sherman added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Millennials could be one of the safest generations when it comes to sex, he contended. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The CDC reports in its Youth Risk Behavior Survey, that 41 percent of high school students had engaged in sex in 2015, down from 54 percent in 1991. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This generation appears to be waiting longer to have sex, with an increasing minority apparently waiting until their early 20s or later,” said Twenge. “It’s good news for sexual and emotional health if teens are waiting until they are ready. But if young adults forgo sex completely, they may be missing out on some of the advantages of an adult romantic relationship.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How much sex aren’t we having?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Americans also had sex about nine fewer times each year from 2010 through 2014 compared with 1995-1999, the 2017 report found.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Data was derived from the General Social Survey, which includes 26,000 adult participants who were asked about their sexual behaviors since 1989.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“These data show a major reversal from previous decades in terms of marriage and sex,” said Twenge in a statement. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It is true, older and married people do, in fact, have sex less often. This may or may not correlate to age, being tired, or boredom with a long-term partnership,” Nelson said. “But for the ‘older’ people today, sexual frequency declines, but sex also improves as we age.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We get better in bed as we get older,” Nelson added. “We don’t measure sexual performance by the notches on our belts, but with the level of intimacy, the quality of eroticism, the variety, the fantasies we share with a partner, our capacity for helping our partner to orgasm, the loss of body image insecurities, and the delight and pleasure we find in the act of sex itself.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nelson encourages young people not to be dissuaded by the report. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Sex is not going away. We are biologically created to seek pleasure, to be in partnerships of all kinds,” she explained.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;People are living longer, healthier lives and can still enjoy sex later in life. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Focus on sex, at any age, can bring intimacy and rewards for a lifetime,” she added.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Sexual Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-17T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-17T10:00:00</updateddate>

http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/americans-having-less-sex-does-it-matter
</guid>
<dc:creator>Kristen Fischer</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-17T17:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>Biomarkers in Blood May Help Detect Autism Earlier</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/biomarkers-in-blood-may-help-detect-autism-earlier
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/autism/031617_autismdiagnosis_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Researchers say they have uncovered a relatively easy and accurate way to tell early on whether a young child has autism.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers say metabolic biomarkers in the blood can help medical personnel assess whether a child is on the autism spectrum.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They say this early detection method could allow for earlier diagnosis of autism and perhaps better treatment of the condition.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Their &lt;a href=&quot;http://journals.plos.org/ploscompbiol/article?id=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1005385&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;findings&lt;/a&gt; were published today in the journal PLOS Computational Biology.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What biomarkers reveal&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In their study, scientists used blood sample data collected at Arkansas Children’s Hospital.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They looked at the samples from 83 children diagnosed with autism and 76 children classified as neurotypical.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;All were between the ages of 3 and 10.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers said they noticed concentrations of specific substances formed by metabolic processes in the blood of children with autism.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They said their method correctly classified 97 percent of the children with autism and 96 percent of the neurotypical children.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The method presented in this work is the only one of its kind that can classify an individual as being on the autism spectrum or as being neurotypical,” Juergen Hahn, PhD, a study author, and professor of biomedical engineering at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in New York, said in a press statement. “We are not aware of any other method, using any type of biomarker, that can do this, much less with the degree of accuracy that we see in our work.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Eugene Arnold, a professor emeritus in the department of psychiatry and behavioral health at the Wexner Medical Center at The Ohio State University, agreed the research findings are important.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said they could be used to help with diagnosis, treatment, and even prevention in autism.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s a good advancement in the field,” he told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Why the findings are important&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;About &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/ncbddd/autism/data.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;1 in 68 children&lt;/a&gt; in the United States (about 1.5 percent) have autism, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The exact cause of the condition is still unknown.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study authors said previous research has revealed certain differences in metabolic processes in children with autism.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, they said, medical professionals have struggled to transfer this knowledge into diagnostic tools.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hahn said further research is needed, but his team is hopeful the early biomarker diagnosis could lead to treatments that would alter the metabolic processes and reduce autism symptoms.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Arnold said if that research actually pans out, it could be an important development.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said there are theories that autism can be affected by both genes and a child’s environment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A child who is born with DNA that makes them more likely to develop autism can have those genes activated by outside sources, including their diet or their mother’s diet.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He noted that &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/features/folicacidbenefits/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;previous research&lt;/a&gt; has indicated that a healthy amount of folic acid, for example, can help reduce the possibility of birth defects involving the brain and the spine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Arnold said that it’s uncertain whether vaccines could fall into the category of an outside influence that can trigger autism-related genes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I’m not sure it’s completely relevant,” he said. “There’s not good evidence that vaccines cause autism in general.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Arnold noted if a child is diagnosed early with autism, then perhaps a change in diet or other factors could help alleviate symptoms.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He did caution that the 97 percent accuracy rate should be improved with this diagnostic method. He said that even a high accuracy rate when dealing with only 1.5 percent of a population can lead to a tripling of mistaken diagnoses.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We need to be careful that there isn’t a lot of false positives,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Early detection from friends, family&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The importance of detecting autism early is the center of another &lt;a href=&quot;http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/1362361316679632?journalCode=auta&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;recent study&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers say they discovered that family members and friends who have consistent contact with a child can alert parents to the possibility of autistic behavior.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In their study, the researchers conducted an online survey of 477 parents of children with autism. They also did a follow-up survey of 196 friends and family members referred by the parents.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the surveys, 25 percent of parents said that other individuals indicated their child might have a serious condition before they suspected it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, more than 50 percent of the friends and family members reported they suspected a child had a serious condition before parents noticed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Of those, half of the friends and family told parents of their concerns while the other half didn’t, or only hinted at their suspicions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers said the individuals who most frequently noticed the children’s condition were grandmothers and teachers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In those instances, children were diagnosed with autism as many as five months earlier than children whose parents weren’t notified by friends or family.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, children with older siblings were diagnosed as many as 10 months earlier than children without siblings.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers said an earlier diagnosis can help improve treatment for children with autism.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Many parents avoid seeking help to find a diagnosis for their child, even though they sense something might be wrong,” said Nachum Sicherman, a study co-author, and professor of business at Columbia Business School, in a press release. “They often ignore signs of a larger problem and look the other way, making the role of close family members and friends vital to accelerating diagnosis and helping a child’s condition.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Children's Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-16T13:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-16T13:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/biomarkers-in-blood-may-help-detect-autism-earlier
</guid>
<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-16T20:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>Do You Have to Be Antisocial to Lose Weight?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/do-you-have-to-be-antisocial-to-lose-weight
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/food-fads/031617_antisocialdiet_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Picture your last meal at a restaurant with friends. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Plates loaded with delicious food.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;People laughing and telling stories.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Wine glasses filled and refilled over the course of the meal.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A good time, right?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sure. But researchers say there’s a downside to all that social revelry, especially if you are trying to lose weight, or even just keep off the pounds.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;New research has found that the urge to overeat is strongest when you are dining with others in social situations, especially when out at a restaurant.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The biggest source of temptation is when people are in restaurants and they’re with other people. In particular, being with others who are eating is a huge trigger,” Lora Burke, PhD, MPH, the study’s lead author, and a professor of nursing at the University of Pittsburgh, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But it’s not just your friends who can lead your diet astray.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;People can feel food temptation “even if they’re alone but are in sight of people who are eating,” said Burke.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Increasing temptation&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the &lt;a href=&quot;http://time.com/4693702/diet-weight-loss-food-restaurant/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;year-long study&lt;/a&gt;, researchers used a smartphone app to follow 150 people enrolled in a weight loss program.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The app asked people to check in up to five times a day, reporting whether they were tempted to stray from their eating plan, or if they actually did.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At the same time, they reported where they were, who they were with, and their mood.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Throughout the day they also reported whenever they ate — or thought about eating — foods or portion sizes that didn’t fit their plan. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And they weighed themselves every day on a digital scale that sent data to the researchers automatically.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;div class=&quot;hl-poll&quot; style=&quot;float:right; margin:10px;&quot;&gt; &lt;script type=&quot;text/javascript&quot; charset=&quot;utf-8&quot; src=&quot;http://static.polldaddy.com/p/9696069.js&quot;&gt;&lt;/script&gt; &lt;noscript&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://polldaddy.com/poll/9696069/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Where are you most tempted to go off your diet?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/noscript&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;p&gt;This use of technology in the study allowed researchers to capture information in real time, rather than relying on people to remember details later.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We assessed them in the moment,” said Burke. “They’re in their natural environment — wherever they are — and they let us know what they’re doing, rather than relying on recall.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The amount of data provided some hints at how people react to food temptations in different situations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;People were more tempted when they were in the presence of other people eating, compared with eating alone — even if they were sitting near strangers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They also reported more food temptations when they were at a restaurant or bar, rather than at home or work.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And they were less likely to be tempted when eating in their car or at another person’s house.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Not every meal with friends at a restaurant leads down the path of temptation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But the study found out that when people were tempted at a restaurant and were around others who were eating, “at least 60 percent of the time they will go on and eat something that they really weren’t planning for,” Burke said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The chance of giving in to temptation at work or in the car was about 40 percent and 30 percent, respectively.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study was presented at a recent meeting of the &lt;a href=&quot;http://professional.heart.org/professional/EducationMeetings/MeetingsLiveCME/EPILifestyle/UCM_316904_EPI-Lifestyle-Scientific-Sessions.jsp&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;American Heart Association&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Mindful eating&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;So is locking yourself in your house with a bowl of salad and ignoring your friends’ text messages your best option?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Not quite.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Even though eating at a restaurant with friends can be a high-risk situation, friends can actually help you stick to your weight loss plan.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other research found that people who received &lt;a href=&quot;http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.849.558&amp;amp;rep=rep1&amp;amp;type=pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;more social support&lt;/a&gt; were better able to keep the weight off. As were people who enrolled in a &lt;a href=&quot;http://psycnet.apa.org/index.cfm?fa=buy.optionToBuy&amp;amp;id=1999-00242-015&amp;amp;_ga=1.18664253.546971615.1489603865&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;weight loss program with friends&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Plus, the new study found that even though people experienced fewer food temptations when they were at home, they still gave into them about half of the time. Even when they were alone.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So food temptation lies in wait in many places. As do distractions — which some think may be behind our overeating.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“People often overeat when they’re distracted — social situations can be distracting, of course,” Dan Zigmond, author of “&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.buddhasdiet.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Buddha’s Diet: The Ancient Art of Losing Weight Without Losing Your Mind&lt;/a&gt;,” told Healthline. “But sitting alone at your desk at work can be hugely distracting, as well. And there’s lots of evidence that people make bad choices in that situation, too.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;You can counteract the effect of these distractions by being more mindful while you eat.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This technique has been applied in successful &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1499404611002648&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;weight loss programs&lt;/a&gt;. But its roots extend even further back.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Part of the theme of our book is to carry forward the teachings that Buddha presented so many years ago. Those really all boil down to just paying attention,” said Zigmond. “To try to ensure that you’re always paying some attention to what you’re eating, no matter where you’re doing it, when you’re doing it, or with whom.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Zigmond said that this works even in groups, as seen with Buddhist monks who eat their meals communally, and mindfully.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mindful eating mind might mean something as simple as pausing for a moment before starting to eat. Or paying attention to each bite of food. Or talking about the food with your friends.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the end, this can improve the dining experience for everyone, without leaving you feeling guilty afterward for overeating.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I don’t think meals out with friends have to be bad for our health or our weight,” said Zigmond. “But we have to combine them with a certain amount of attention and mindfulness.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Food and Nutrition</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-16T11:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-16T11:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/do-you-have-to-be-antisocial-to-lose-weight
</guid>
<dc:creator>Shawn Radcliffe</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-16T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
The Debate Continues Over Whether Diets Can ‘Reverse’ Diabetes
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/the-debate-continues-over-whether-diets-can-reverse-diabetes
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/Diabetes/030617_diabetesdiet_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;
]]>
<![CDATA[
p&gt;Can simply eating less food periodically cure someone of diabetes?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Can such a diet cause cells that have been hampered from producing insulin to start producing it again?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At least one researcher seems to think so.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Healthy diets have long been promoted as a way of lowering your risk of diabetes, and a careful diet is necessary for avoiding blood sugar spikes for those who already have the disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Valter Longo, PhD, the director of the Longevity Institute at the University of Southern California (USC) Leonard Davis School of Gerontology, has long been a proponent of the fasting diet.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cell.com/fulltext/S0092-8674(17)30130-7&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; published late last month in the journal Cell, Longo and fellow researchers concluded a fasting diet promoted the growth of new pancreatic cells, which help produce insulin, in mice with type 1 and type 2 diabetes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Human cells exposed to the diet in a dish also produced increased insulin, suggesting it could alleviate diabetes in humans.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Longo hopes to begin human trials of the fasting diet later this year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Questions, potential conflicts&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are plenty of questions left to be answered.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One is whether only a portion of patients — perhaps those who recently developed diabetes and haven’t been insulin-deficient as long — respond to the diet.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We don’t know,” Longo told Healthline. “We’ll see if the only ones who respond are the more recent ones — or nobody.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Longo, who also partially owns a food company that sells meal plans to help people who want to follow a fast-mimicking diet. He’s conducted past research that has found this type of diet might reduce the risk for cancer, heart disease, and other age-related ailments.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Those ties also raise some questions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Any time it seems like something can fix everything, that’s always a worry. And then when there’s products involved,” says Deborah Greenwood, PhD, RN, president of Deborah Greenwood Consulting, specializing in diabetes and digital health, and past president of the American Association of Diabetes Educators. “But I wouldn’t want to say something is bad just because it’s unique. We just need long-term studies with a significant amount of people.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other recent research has also raised the possibility of reversing diabetes through diet.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another short-term study, &lt;a href=&quot;http://diabetes.jmir.org/2017/1/e5/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;published last week&lt;/a&gt;, found that 10 weeks of a personalized, ketogenic diet that was overseen remotely by medical professionals led to improved control over blood sugar levels and weight loss in people with type 2 diabetes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The ketogenic diet includes low amounts of carbohydrates, which have the most impact on blood sugar.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But that study, backed by a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.virtahealth.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;new start-up&lt;/a&gt; that calls itself an “online specialty medical clinic that reverses type 2 diabetes without medications or surgery,” has product ties, too.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I never liked the word ‘reversal’ in terms of diabetes,” Greenwood told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She says the only way to truly reverse it would be bariatric surgery, in which a portion of the stomach or intestines is removed. But she says she knows people with diabetes who have followed a ketogenic diet and love it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s just really hard to live in the world and engage in typical life when you’re so restricted, and there’s no long-term data to show if it’s sustainable or healthy,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Cells and behavior&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Greenwood said Longo’s study could be different because it suggests it could be possible to change a person’s cells not simply behavior, as in the ketogenic study.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But it would still likely require some behavior changes because of the careful monitoring required by the new diet.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Most people who are on insulin are highly engaged, and some aren’t,” she said. “My guess would be someone who would take on a rigid diet would be engaged. But maybe not. The mice didn’t have to do too much in their lives. They didn’t have to go to work. They had fairly easy routines.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Undertaking those sorts of diets on your own — particularly if you’re dependent on insulin medication — can be dangerous, although even before these studies there were a number of claims online of people using fasting or starvation diets to reduce the impacts of the disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As for his formula, Longo wouldn’t say what exactly the diet consists of.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We don’t talk about the diets because we don’t want people to improvise at home,” he told Healthline. “It’s quite dangerous the way it’s done right now for diabetic patients, especially those on insulin.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Human trials, he says, would be undertaken in a hospital setting with careful oversight and protocols.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But his goal is to one day have the diet approved for home use.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He describes a box with strict instructions that people could take home, although it still wouldn’t likely be available to those using insulin.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So, however the research advances, the best diet will still be the one that helps keep diabetes at bay in the first place. Experts say avoiding processed carbs, sugary drinks, and red meat as much as possible is a great start.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Diabetes</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-16T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-16T10:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/the-debate-continues-over-whether-diets-can-reverse-diabetes
</guid>
<dc:creator>Matthew Berger</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-16T17:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Why Do One Million Babies Per Year Die the Same Day They’re Born?
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/why-one-million-babies-per-year-die-same-day-theyre-born
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/childrens-health/031517_babydeaths_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Modern medicine has made significant advancements in the care and treatment available to humans.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cancer is no longer the death sentence it was once deemed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;AIDS and HIV are considered treatable diseases now.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Even the surgery required to clear clogged arteries is about two steps away from being an outpatient procedure.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But, despite these scientific breakthroughs, there is one health issue that remains a troubling trend across our planet: Infant deaths.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Each year approximately one million infants die on the day they are born, according to a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.savethechildren.org/site/apps/nlnet/content2.aspx?c=8rKLIXMGIpI4E&amp;amp;b=8943305&amp;amp;ct=13664839&amp;amp;notoc=1&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2014 report&lt;/a&gt;, Ending Newborn Deaths, from the Save the Children Foundation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The number was highlighted again this year when Bill and Melinda Gates mentioned the findings in their foundation’s &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.gatesnotes.com/2017-Annual-Letter?WT.mc_id=02_14_2017_00_AL2017_IN-YT_&amp;amp;WT.tsrc=INYT&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;annual letter&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A variety of reasons&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Experts say infant deaths occurs in both developing nations and industrialized nations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are a variety of causes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some infants who die on their first day of life succumb to birth defects, said Dr. Jose Cordero, MPH, of the University of Georgia.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But ultimately, most deaths can be traced back to the type of healthcare that pregnant women have access to. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“What we’re really talking about is what you have at the local level,” Cordero told Healthline. “It has to do with prenatal care, and it has to with delivery with an appropriately trained attendant.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In developing nations medical care for pregnant women is usually administered by midwives or healthcare attendants, compared with industrialized nations where doctors and nurses commonly provide care.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Save the Children report states, “half of first-day deaths around the world could be prevented if the mother and baby had access to free healthcare and a skilled midwife.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Infant deaths occur when these attendants haven’t received proper training in emergency life-saving procedures, according to Cordero. This can include resuscitation, if the baby is born not breathing.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the Save the Children report, “skilled care during labor could reduce the number of stillbirths during labor by 45 percent and prevent 43 percent of newborn deaths.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Adequate training can teach healthcare attendants how to identify high-risk pregnancies, Cordero noted. Conditions like placenta previa, a ruptured placenta, or preeclampsia can lead to complications for the baby and the mother.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A healthcare attendant that has the training to detect any early stage complications can “recognize that because of these complications [the mother] needs a higher level of care,” such as a hospital,” Cordero said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Aside from pregnant and delivery care, birth defects are also a major factor in infant death, he noted.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some of these birth defects, such as spina bifida, may be prevented if pregnant women ingest enough folic acid. For example, women could eat wheat products that are fortified with this important vitamin&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s a simple solution that isn’t standard practice throughout the world. And not just in developing nations, Cordero added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Only about one-third of the flour in the world is fortified, so a lot of progress can be made,” he said. “The U.K. still is not doing it.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;High infant death rate in the U.S.&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The United States does fortify its flour supply. However, the country still struggles to improve its infant death rate. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/nvsr/nvsr63/nvsr63_05.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2014 report&lt;/a&gt; by the National Center for Health Statistics compared the infant death rates of 22 industrialized countries. The United States came in last.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As in developing countries, infant death rates in the United States are also tied to access to healthcare.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s about economic and social conditions that women struggle with every day,” Alicia Leatherman, director of Infant Wellness at Nationwide Children’s Hospital (NCH), told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In Columbus, Ohio, where NCH is located, African-American babies are two times more likely than Caucasian babies to die in their first year. The county is working to reduce that number through a program called “Celebrate One,” which was rolled out in 2014.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our goal is to decrease infant mortality rates by 40 percent,” Leatherman said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The program takes into consideration a host of situations and scenarios that hinder access to prenatal care. They include neighborhood conditions, smoking, and even the spacing between pregnancies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2014, the county’s infant death rate was 8.4 percent. By 2015 that number dropped to 7.7 percent. However, Leatherman said preliminary numbers for 2016 show an uptick.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She said they suspect that some of these deaths are due to prematurity or sleep related issues caused by situations such as co-sleeping.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There are many different reasons,” Leatherman said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Even so, the county is pleased with the response that the program has received.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We’ve seen an increase in getting [pregnant women] into prenatal care, early,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While there is still much to be done when it comes to infant death rates, both Leatherman and Cordero say there has been significant improvement in access to prenatal care for women throughout the world. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Twenty years ago, our concern was there were a million babies in Africa alone that were dying of measles,” Cordero said. “So, a lot of progress has been made.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-03-15T14:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-15T14:00:00</updateddate>

</guid>
<dc:creator>Carolyn Abate</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-15T21:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Three Women Blinded in Unproven Stem Cell Treatment
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/three-women-blinded-in-unproven-stem-cell-treatment
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/031517_blindstemcell_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;If it sounds too good to be true, it probably is.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That may be especially true when it comes to experimental treatments involving stem cells.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s the warning out today from researchers who looked into a purported medical trial at a Florida clinic that left three older women blind.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers said there were plenty of warning signs about the experimental treatments.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These included the fact patients paid $5,000 to participate, and the trial had no control group or previous research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The findings will be published tomorrow in The New England Journal of Medicine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“[The paper is a] call to awareness for patients, physicians, and regulatory agencies of the risks of this kind of minimally regulated, patient-funded research,” said Dr. Jeffrey Goldberg, professor and chair of ophthalmology at the Stanford University School of Medicine, and co-author of the paper, in a press statement.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How women were blinded&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The stem cell treatments happened in 2015.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The treatment was listed on &lt;a href=&quot;https://clinicaltrials.gov/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;ClinicalTrials.gov&lt;/a&gt; as a “study to assess the safety and effects of cells injected intravitreal in dry macular degeneration.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That is a common, progressive disease of the retina that leads to loss of vision.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The clinical trials website is overseen by the U.S. National Library of Medicine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Officials at the National Institutes of Health (NIH), which oversees the medical library, did not respond to Healthline’s request for an interview.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study authors said people may have signed up thinking they were going to be part of a trial. However, the written material that accompanied the website listing did not mention a trial.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The three women who were blinded ranged in age from 72 to 88, and each suffered from macular degeneration.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Before the experimental surgery, their eyesight ranged from 20/30 to 20/200, uncorrected.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At the clinic, which was not named in the research paper, the patients had fat cells removed from their abdomens. The fat tissue was then processed with enzymes with the goal of obtaining stem cells.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Platelet-dense plasma was isolated from blood drawn from the patients. The cells were then mixed with the platelet-dense plasma and injected into the eyes. Patients reported that the entire process took less than an hour.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Soon after, the three female patients experienced side effects that included vision loss, detached retinas, and hemorrhages. They are now blind.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Thomas Albini, a study co-author, and an associate professor of clinical ophthalmology at the University of Miami, where two of the patients were subsequently treated, said the women will probably remain blind for the rest of their lives.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Although I can't say it's impossible, it's extremely unlikely they would regain vision,” he said in a press statement.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Albini said the blindness could have been caused by the injection of a contaminant or the cell wash solution into the eye. When injected into the eye, the stem cells also could have changed into myofibroblasts, a type of cell associated with scarring.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study authors said that even if the procedure have been properly done, there is no evidence the surgery would have improved the women’s vision.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There is a lot of very well-founded evidence for the positive potential of stem therapy for many human diseases, but there's no excuse for not designing a trial properly and basing it on preclinical research,” Goldberg said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Lots of warning signs&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study authors said there were plenty of “red flags” on this particular medical offering.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The first was the lack of information on the site about a clinical trial.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There was also no hypothesis based on laboratory experiments, assignment of a control group and treatment group, collection of data, masking of clinical and patient groups, and plans for follow-up.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&quot;There was a whole list of egregious things,&quot; said Albini.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The next warning sign was the request for patients to pay $5,000 for the treatment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&quot;I'm not aware of any legitimate research, at least in ophthalmology, that is patient-funded,&quot; Albini said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another tip-off was the fact the surgeons operated on both eyes at the same time. The study authors said professionals working in legitimate clinical trials would usually operate on one eye at a time to make sure the treatment is working properly.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There's a lot of hope for stem cells and these types of clinics appeal to patients desperate for care who hope that stem cells are going to be the answer, but in this case these women participated in a clinical enterprise that was off-the-charts dangerous,” Albini said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study authors noted that listings on ClinicalTrials.gov are not fully scrutinized for scientific soundness. This particular listing is still on the site, but now states: “&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/results/NCT02024269&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;This study has been withdrawn prior to enrollment.&lt;/a&gt;”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The clinic is also no longer performing these eye injections, although it is still seeing patients, Albini said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The procedure was also not subject to Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approval because the cells were not transferred between patients and were considered “minimally processed,” the study authors noted.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The authors recommended that people considering participation in a clinical trial check a website, such as &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.closerlookatstemcells.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;A Closer Look at Stem Cells&lt;/a&gt;, for more information.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They can also investigate whether a trial is affiliated with an academic medical center.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
