<pubdate>2017-03-15T14:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-15T14:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/three-women-blinded-in-unproven-stem-cell-treatment
</guid>
<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-15T21:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Helping Children Recover From Traumatic Brain Injuries
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/helping-children-recover-from-traumatic-brain-injuries
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/childrens-health/031517_childbraininjuries_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/traumaticbraininjury/get_the_facts.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;report&lt;/a&gt; that traumatic brain injury (TBI) is the number one cause of disability and death among children and adolescents in the United States.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This particularly true for children under 4 years of age and teens between 15 and 19.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.biausa.org/brain-injury-children.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Research&lt;/a&gt; has shown that TBIs are particularly traumatic for children, as they impact the child’s brain development and can cause serious cognitive impairment over time.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Negative effects include a decline in reasoning and trouble processing information.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some of these adverse effects are not obvious right away. They may come up later when the children advance in age and are faced with different cognitive challenges. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;New research - published in Neurology, the journal of the American Academy of Neurology (AAN) - suggests that &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.newswise.com/articles/which-kids-will-take-longer-to-recover-from-brain-injury&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;a new biomarker&lt;/a&gt; may help anticipate which children will have more trouble recovering from a TBI and consequently require more aggressive treatment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Emily L. Dennis, Ph.D., of the University of Southern California (USC) and one of the authors of the new study, explains the motivation behind the research:&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Traumatic brain injury is a leading cause of disability in children, but it is very difficult to predict long-term outcome and which kids might need more aggressive treatment,” she said. “While the severity of the injury certainly plays a role in this, there is still a lot of uncertainty - you frequently have two patients with similar injuries who have different recoveries.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Studying the impact&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study looked at 21 children aged between 8 and 18 who had been admitted to a pediatric intensive care unit in a Los Angeles County hospital as a result of a moderate to severe TBI.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Reasons for the brain injury included traffic accidents as well as falls from skateboards or bikes. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study also used a control group of 20 children who did not experience TBI.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers examined the patients’ brain by using a special type of imaging device called a diffusion-weighted MRI. They scanned the patients’ brain two to five months after the injury and then again 12 months later.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The scientists also administered reasoning and memory tests.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Additionally, they examined the patients’ brain using an electroencephalogram as they were completing a pattern-matching task that focused on the time it takes for their brain to transfer information from one hemisphere to another.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The team focused on this aspect of brain activity because previous studies had shown that both children and adults who had TBI exhibit slower transfer times immediately after the injury.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Slow transfer time&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers found that a few months after the injury, half of the children with TBI had slow transfer time while half had a normal transfer time – that is, within the same range as the healthy control group. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the slow-transfer half of the TBI group, the scans revealed disruptions in the white matter that connects the two hemispheres of the brain, called the corpus callosum.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These disruptions worsened between the first scan and the second one, which took place a year later. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;By contrast, the half of the TBI group that had normal transfer time did not reveal any differences from the control group in their brain scans. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In other words, as Dennis explains: “The TBI slow-transfer time group showed progressive decline during this period, while the other group showed signs of recovery.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Finally, the reasoning and memory tests also revealed poorer scores in the TBI slow-transfer group, compared with the normal-transfer TBI group and the control group. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Significance of the study &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Although the study sample was small and the findings need to be confirmed by larger studies, the current results point to the disruption in the white matter as a reliable biomarker for predicting the children who will have more trouble recovering from a TBI.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The finding in this study that there is degeneration of white matter in about half of the children with moderate to severe TBI during the first 16 months after an injury should stimulate attempts to understand why this is happening so that treatments may be developed to lessen this progressive decline in white matter,” said Dennis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Bradley L. Schlaggar, Ph.D., of the Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis, MO, and a member of the AAN, also commented on the significance of the study in an accompanying editorial:&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This study is an important step forward to identifying a functional biomarker that may predict the trajectory of TBI recovery,” he said.“Success in confirming these results would be transformative for the field. We need tools that will allow us to make individual predictions so we can make the best decisions about treatment and how to educate and counsel our patients and their families.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Children's Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-15T13:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-15T13:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/helping-children-recover-from-traumatic-brain-injuries
</guid>
<dc:creator>Ana Sandoiu</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-15T20:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
What is the Future of ‘Death with Dignity’ Laws in Trump Era?
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/death-with-dignity-laws-in-trump-era
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/031517_deathwithdignity_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;
]]>
<![CDATA[
p&gt;&lt;p&gt;These are the early days of the administration, but President Trump and the Republican-controlled Congress have already taken aim at the country’s healthcare legislation, immigration policy, and environmental regulation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Is “Death with Dignity” (DwD) in the crosshairs, too?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sometimes called medical aid-in-dying or physician-assisted suicide, these laws allow doctors to prescribe lethal medication to terminally ill patients.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The issue has mostly been decided at the state level, but the federal government has weighed in before and could do so again. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In fact, two clues suggest there is some opposition to aid-in-dying on the federal level. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In February, a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/dc-politics/2017/02/13/826001a2-f208-11e6-a9b0-ecee7ce475fc_story.html?utm_term=.4f1c05912921&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;House committee&lt;/a&gt; voted to block Washington D.C.’s Death with Dignity Act (DWDA), which the district's council had approved late last year. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Since the Constitution charges Congress with legislative jurisdiction over Washington D.C., Congress has a duty to carefully scrutinize this bill, its impact on medical patients, and its effects on our health-care system,” Reps. Phil Roe (R-Tenn.) and Brad Wenstrup (R-Ohio) &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nationalreview.com/article/444573/washington-dc-death-dignity-act-assisted-suicde-health-care-costs-compassion&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;wrote&lt;/a&gt; in the National Review. “We have weighed the legislation and found it wanting.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Arguing that the law opens up too many avenues for abuse, Wenstrup and others sponsored resolutions of dissent.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These resolutions fizzled out, but the law could be held up during budget proceedings.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Stepping on the states&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Congress does have jurisdiction over Washington, D.C., but in general it usually doesn't review laws passed by states and municipalities. However, there are other ways for the feds to step in.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2001, a few years after Oregon’s DWDA went into effect, Attorney General John Ashcroft &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.law.cornell.edu/supct/cert/04-623&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;announced&lt;/a&gt; that dispensing lethal medication to terminally ill patients was not a legitimate medical use of a drug. He said doctors who went along with the Oregon law were therefore in violation of the Controlled Substances Act (CSA). &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Ashcroft directive was ultimately overturned by the Supreme Court, not because the judges found his interpretation unreasonable, but because they ruled in a 6-3 decision the attorney general did not have the authority to make such a decision. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Arthur Svenson, a political science professor at the University of Redlands in California, thinks the CSA could be invoked again as a means of overturning DWDA laws.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Congress, if it wants to, could clarify [the CSA] in a single sentence, and here’s how it would read: [physician assisted suicide] is not a legitimate medical purpose. Period,” he told Healthline. “The effect of that clarification of the law by Congress would mean that if you were a doctor in those six states that legalized assisted suicide you’d go to jail” for prescribing lethal medication.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Would Republicans be willing to do that? Maybe. Would Trump be willing to sign that law? Maybe.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With clear instruction from Congress, any opposition to DwD laws from the Attorney General Jeff Sessions would be much easier to defend.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Secular vs. sectarian&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;On the flip side, Svenson can also envision a way — a “little crack in the door” — for aid-in-dying to become the law of the land. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There are five people on the [Supreme Court] currently who don’t accept religiously inspired justifications for existing laws. They need valid secular reasons, not valid sectarian reasons,” he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That aversion to enacting laws based on religious principles led to the court’s legalization of sodomy and same-sex marriage, he explained.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Is it possible that you could return to the court and argue that the reasons why state governments have banned Death with Dignity were fundamentally religious inspired?” he said. “If you remove your religious reasons for banning Death with Dignity, what secular reasons remain in the wake?”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Since the Oregon law was enacted in 1997, about 1,500 people have requested lethal prescriptions and two-thirds have chosen to take them.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The state has reported no abuses of the law so far, although its communication strategy — informing terminally ill patients of their right to access lethal drugs alongside the news that it was denying them further healthcare coverage — caused a major public relations dustup. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It dropped my chin to the floor,” Randy Stroup, who learned that the Oregon Health Plan would not pay for experimental cancer treatment but would pay for lethal drugs, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.foxnews.com/story/2008/07/28/oregon-offers-terminal-patients-doctor-assisted-suicide-instead-medical-care.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;told&lt;/a&gt; FOX News in 2008. “[How could they] not pay for medication that would help my life, and yet offer to pay to end my life?”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://nypost.com/2016/10/24/terminally-ill-mom-denied-treatment-coverage-but-gets-suicide-drugs-approved/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;similar case&lt;/a&gt; in California, which approved its own DwD law in 2016, drew national attention and outrage. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In these examples, opponents of the law found evidence for exactly what they had feared: Insurance companies were approving death as a cheaper option.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Supporters of the law argue that these patients would have been denied coverage with or without the law. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Keeping it at the state level&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Despite Svenson’s hope that Oregon’s clean record could encourage a victory for the movement, DwD proponents are unlikely to push the law at the federal level any time soon. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For one thing, President Trump’s Supreme Court pick Neil Gorsuch is known to oppose the practice. In 2006, he published “The Future of Assisted Suicide and Euthanasia,” an extension of his dissertation work at Oxford. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2017/02/01/neil-gorsuch-wrote-the-book-on-assisted-suicide-heres-what-he-said/?utm_term=.b0061843b1f2&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;book&lt;/a&gt;, he concludes that “[H]uman life is fundamentally and inherently valuable, and that the intentional taking of human life by private persons is always wrong.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The National Right to Life Committee, which advocates against abortion as well as aid-in-dying, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nrlc.org/communications/releases/2017/release013117/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;praised&lt;/a&gt; Gorsuch’s nomination.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Still, Barbara Coombs Lee, president of the aid-in-dying advocacy group Compassion &amp;amp; Choices, doesn’t think the addition of Gorsuch to the Supreme Court will change the composition of the court radically enough to sway its standing on DwD laws one way or the other. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Gorsuch is seen as an “&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.politico.com/story/2017/01/who-is-neil-gorsuch-bio-facts-background-political-views-234437&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;intellectual heir&lt;/a&gt;” to the late Antonin Scalia, whose seat he will fill if confirmed. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ultimately, pursuing federal approval is just not the strategy advocates are taking right now.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s full steam ahead for states,” Coombs Lee told Healthline. “The fact of the matter is that the U.S. Supreme Court has a harder time revoking what has come to be a cultural value in the United States.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The legalization of DwD laws in California could cause such a shift. That law made the option for terminally ill people to take lethal drugs newly available to 1 in 8 Americans, Svenson points out.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It will be telling, don’t you think, if no abuse is located in the state of California,” Svenson said.&amp;nbsp; “I think if enough states said yes then we will return to the Supreme Court and maybe make the argument again.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Laws and opposition&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Two 1997 Supreme Court decisions denied a constitutional right to aid-in-dying but kicked the issue back to the states for further debate.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Besides Oregon, California, and Washington D.C. — Colorado, Washington, and Vermont have all legalized DwD through voter referendum or legislative action. In Montana, the practical is also legal following a 2009 state Supreme Court &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/01/us/01suicide.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;case&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Most of these places follow the example set by Oregon. The option is only available to mentally competent adults with less than six months to live who are capable of taking the medication themselves.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;No state has sanctioned &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J_EKwSXOsVE&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;assisted suicide&lt;/a&gt;, a practice advocated by Dr. Jack Kevorkian, which requires a doctor to administer lethal doses of drugs via IV or injection.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But many disability, religious, and medical groups still oppose the law. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In a society that prizes physical ability and stigmatizes impairments, it’s no surprise that previously able-bodied people may tend to equate disability with loss of dignity,” writes the disability rights group Not Dead Yet. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This reflects the prevalent but insulting societal judgment that people who deal with incontinence and other losses in bodily function are lacking dignity. People with disabilities are concerned that these psycho-social disability-related factors have become widely accepted as sufficient justification for assisted suicide.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Providing care&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Although the debate centers on making this option legal and safe for physicians and their patients, many medical professionals remain uneasy about it. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Of doctors surveyed by &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.medscape.com/features/slideshow/ethics2016-part2#page=2&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Medscape&lt;/a&gt; in 2016, 29 percent were opposed to physician aid-in-dying, although that number had dropped from 41 percent in 2010. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Palliative care experts don’t want the debate to eclipse the larger issue of appropriate treatment and pain relief for terminally ill patients. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“[The International Association for Hospice and Palliative Care (IAHPC)] believes that no country or state should consider the legalization of euthanasia or PAS until it ensures universal access to palliative care services and to appropriate medications, including opioids for pain and dyspnea,” the group wrote in a statement published online late last year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a conversation with Healthline, Liliana De Lima, the group’s executive director, explained that access to appropriate care at the end of life is not guaranteed for many people in the world. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Actually there’s discussion in India right now about euthanasia, and the people in India that we work with have raised this concern,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It may be “easier and less expensive to say, ‘OK, let’s go for euthanasia or assisted suicide,’ and right now the vast majority of people in India don’t have access to palliative care,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the United States, access to such care is uneven. A &lt;a href=&quot;https://reportcard.capc.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;report&lt;/a&gt; generated by the Center to Advance Palliative Care found that people who die in the southern United States or in for-profit hospitals are less likely to receive adequate end-of-life care.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Like Not Dead Yet, IAHPC eschews the term “death with dignity.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We’ve seen a lot of people dying with good palliative care in a very dignified manner,” De Lima said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Vigilant groups&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;With Washington D.C. politics set to boil and members of Congress vowing to filibuster Gorsuch, groups concerned about aid-in-dying are setting their sights at the local level. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Here in Oregon we’re still really concerned about advocating for people at all points in life, from those in the womb to … adults in need of advocacy and specifically elder care and protecting patients’ rights,” Liberty Pike, communications director at Oregon Right to Life, told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The organization is particularly concerned with a &lt;a href=&quot;http://gov.oregonlive.com/bill/2017/SB494/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;bill&lt;/a&gt; in the state Senate that would change advance directives so patients could refuse spoon-feeding when mentally incompetent. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Compassion &amp;amp; Choices, too, remains vigilant. The group has weighed in on other issues, like contraception access, that it sees as a question of personal choice in medicine.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They also advocate for better communication between patients and their doctors with initiatives like &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.compassionandchoices.org/truth-in-treatment/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Truth in Treatment&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think the more we can detoxify conversations about dying, the better,” Coombs Lee said.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Public Policy</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-15T11:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-15T11:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/death-with-dignity-laws-in-trump-era
</guid>
<dc:creator>Rose Rimler</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-15T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Who Are They? 14 Million More People Won’t Have Health Insurance Next Year
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/more-people-wont-have-health-insurance-next-year
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/ACA/031417_gopplan_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;About
]]>
<![CDATA[
14 million people who have health insurance today won’t have it by the end of the next year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Many of them will be young, healthy people as well as members of families with low incomes and people over the age of 60.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s the conclusion of a report released Monday on the Republican healthcare bill to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (ACA).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The report authors predicted the GOP plan would lead to 14 million more people being uninsured in 2018.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;By 2026, 24 million more people would be uninsured than if the ACA, also known as Obamacare, remained in place.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Over the next decade the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.npr.org/2017/03/13/520031463/gop-health-care-bill-could-leave-24m-without-coverage-by-2026-cbo-says?sc=17&amp;amp;f=1001&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;uninsured rate&lt;/a&gt; would rise from its current 11 percent to 18 percent, wiping out the gains made under the ACA.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cbo.gov/hlcmsresource/115th-congress-2017-2018/costestimate/americanhealthcareact_0.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;analysis&lt;/a&gt; from the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO) provided fuel for opponents and raised &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.politico.com/story/2017/03/cbo-Republican-obamacare-repeal-plan-236007&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;concerns&lt;/a&gt; among moderate and conservative Republicans.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Who would lose insurance?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Much of the initial spike in the number of uninsured would result from the repeal of the individual mandate. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Without the threat of the ACA’s penalties for not having insurance, some people would opt out of buying coverage.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Others, though, would give up coverage when their premiums increase.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And some people would lose coverage when their employer stopped offering insurance to workers. The Republican plan repeals the employer mandate to provide insurance as well.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A large number of uninsured would also result from the plan’s reduced funding of Medicaid, which was expanded under the ACA.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;By 2026, 14 million fewer people would be enrolled in Medicaid under the Republican bill — accounting for more than half of the increase in uninsured people.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This includes people who are eligible now for Medicaid, and those who would have become eligible if more states expanded coverage under the ACA.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The CBO found that &lt;a href=&quot;http://khn.org/news/deciphering-the-cbo-estimates-on-the-gop-health-bill/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;95 percent of people&lt;/a&gt; who became eligible for Medicaid through the expansion would lose coverage by 2024, as federal funding to states decreases.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, 15 percent of people who received healthcare services at Planned Parenthood would “lose access to care.” Most federal funds to Planned Parenthood cover services for people enrolled in the states’ Medicaid program, often people with low incomes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, the Republican bill would &lt;a href=&quot;http://khn.org/news/Republican-vows-to-defund-planned-parenthood-reality-makes-that-hard/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;defund Planned Parenthood&lt;/a&gt; for a year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Premiums would eventually fall … for some&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Under the Republican plan, insurance premiums would rise in 2018 and 2019 as fewer healthy people — those with lower health costs — signed up.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Single people in the individual marketplace might see premium increases up to 20 percent.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Starting in 2020, the repeal of the individual mandate would be offset by other parts of the legislation, and premiums would drop. By 2026, they would be around 10 percent lower than under the ACA, according to the CBO report.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, premiums would vary widely by income and age.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Under the Republican bill, insurers would be able to charge older people five times more than they do younger people.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At the same time, tax credits for older people would only be twice the size of credits for younger people.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As a result, the plan would raise premiums “substantially” for older Americans, and lower them “substantially” for younger buyers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For example, a 64-year-old with an income of $26,500 in 2026 would pay $14,600 a year, compared to $1,700 under Obamacare.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But a 21-year-old earning $68,200 — 450 percent above the poverty line — in 2026 would pay $1,450 under the Republican bill, compared to $5,100 under the ACA.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lower premiums for younger people might encourage more of them to sign up for coverage, something that the ACA had difficulty convincing them to do.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Federal deficit would drop&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Over the next decade, the Republican bill would cut the federal deficit by $337 billion.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A large part of this would come from an $880 billion decrease in Medicaid spending over the next decade. This amounts to 25 percent less spending for the program by 2026 than projected under the ACA.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Repealing ACA subsidies would save $673 billion, although the Republican plan’s tax credits would cost $361 billion, according to the CBO report.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Defunding Planned Parenthood for a year would save about $157 million in 2017. But this would also lead to a $21 million increase in Medicaid spending for several thousand pregnancies, as women with low incomes lose access to family planning services.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Several Republicans have called the CBO’s estimates into question, saying future Republican legislation will affect these numbers. However, those plans have not been released yet. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2017/mar/12/mick-mulvaney/fact-checking-white-house-attack-nonpartisan-cbos-/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Experts&lt;/a&gt; who monitor the CBO say they have found that its predictions are unbiased and “largely sound.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-03-14T14:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-14T14:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/more-people-wont-have-health-insurance-next-year
</guid>
<dc:creator>Shawn Radcliffe</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-14T21:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Cutting Breast Cancer Treatment Costs by Reducing Radiation
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/cutting-breast-cancer-treatment-costs-by-reducing-radiation
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/cancer/031417_breastradiation_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In 2013, &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/cancer/breast/statistics/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;230,815 women&lt;/a&gt; and 2,109 men were diagnosed with breast cancer in the United States and 40,860 women and 464 men died from the disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;By 2020, annual breast cancer treatment costs are projected to reach $20 billion.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The primary focus of breast cancer care is providing these patients with the best, most effective treatment, said Dr. Rachel A. Greenup, MPH, assistant professor of surgery at the Duke University School Medicine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, there is a real need to reduce costs where possible, Greenup adds, as long as care is not compromised.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Greenup is the lead author of a study published today in the Journal of Oncology Practice.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Saving money in breast cancer care&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;To investigate whether cost savings could be made in the treatment of breast cancer, Greenup and her team from the Duke Cancer Institute in North Carolina, used data from the National Cancer Database taken in 2011.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In total, the analysis looked at 43,000 breast cancer patients aged 50 or older.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;All patients had small tumors that had not spread to the lymph nodes and had undergone a lumpectomy (surgical removal of the cancer without removing the breast).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.breastcancer.org/research-news/shorter-radiation-better-for-early-stage&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Earlier research&lt;/a&gt; has shown that this type of patient can do equally well when given a 4-week course of radiation, compared with the standard 6-week course.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another previous &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23690420&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; demonstrated that some patients aged 70 or over, who were receiving tamoxifen (a breast cancer drug), did not show any increased survival benefits when also treated with radiation therapy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In other words, certain breast cancer patients have been shown to do equally well on a reduced course of radiation therapy or no radiation therapy at all.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Despite this knowledge, the current study showed that 57 percent of the patients that could have safely reduced (or removed) radiation therapy were still given the full, longer regimens.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our study provides an example of a win-win situation, where patients can receive high-quality, evidence-based cancer care while also reducing the treatment burden for patients and the healthcare system,” Greenup said in a press statement.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Using Medicare reimbursement data, the researchers estimated that the cost of the lengthier radiation therapy was more than $13,000 per person, compared with around $8,000 for the shorter radiation regimen. Without any radiation treatment, the cost is zero.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Millions of dollars could be saved&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Scaling up the data, the researchers delved into Medicare data for all women with breast cancer over the age of 50 and who were eligible to receive a reduced radiation course.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They concluded that the overall cost of treatment in the U.S. was around $420 million in 2011. If these women had been treated using the alternative approaches that are backed by research, the cost could have been lowered to $256 million, a saving of &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.eurekalert.org/emb_releases/2017-03/dumc-rrc030917.php&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;$164 million&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Of course, high-quality care is the priority in cancer treatment, but our study suggests that utilization of evidence-based radiation treatment can translate into reductions in healthcare spending without sacrificing quality,” Greenup said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Aside from the reduction in cost, a shorter radiation course would be better for patients, the researchers concluded.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The women being treated would not be required to make as many hospital visits, and potentially lose out on work and family time, but they would still receive the best possible care. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study is guaranteed to spark debate. There are, however, shortfalls in the research, as the authors make clear.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For instance, Medicare data were used to assess costs, but insurance data would have been more accurate. Those figures were not available to the researchers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Also, the data did not explain why each individual patient subscribed to the longer treatment plan. The 6-week course may have been warranted for reasons not explained in the dataset. Alternatively, the patient may not have felt confident deciding to reduce or omit radiation therapy, making it a personal rather than clinical decision.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Despite these shortfalls, the research highlights an area where substantial savings could be made without jeopardizing levels of patient care, Greenup said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It's important to look for opportunities in cancer treatment where we can safely reduce healthcare costs without compromising excellent outcomes,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Cancer</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-14T13:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-14T13:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/cutting-breast-cancer-treatment-costs-by-reducing-radiation
</guid>
<dc:creator>Tim Newman</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-14T20:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Are We Closer to Curing the Common Cold?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/are-we-closer-to-curing-the-common-cold
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/030317_coldcure_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Imagine if the common cold, something that affects billions of people every year, could be cured.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Perhaps we are a step closer to that dream.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Scientists say they’ve made a breakthrough by analyzing a ribonucleic acid (RNA) genome of the human parechovirus (HPeV), a virus that causes the common cold and polio, along with hand, foot, and mouth disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Experts say the news is promising, but curing the common cold is nothing to sneeze at.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Cracking the code&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Scientists from the University of York, University of Leeds, and University of Helsinki, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-016-0011-z&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;announced&lt;/a&gt; their findings in the journal Nature Communications.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The common cold infects more than two billion people annually, making it one of the most successful viral pathogens, so we are excited to make this &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.york.ac.uk/news-and-events/news/2017/research/scientists-close-in-on-cracking-code-of-common-col/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;crucial step forward&lt;/a&gt;,” Professor Reidun Twarock, a mathematical biologist at the University of York’s Departments of Mathematics and Biology, and the York Centre for Complex Systems Analysis, said in a release.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The breakthrough stems from the discovery of a “hidden code” found within HPeV that is responsible for formation of the virus.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Now that the code has been found, the research team is trying to figure out what drugs to use to target and destroy it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The coding works like the cogwheels in a Swiss watch,” Professor Peter Stockley from the Astbury Centre for Structural Molecular Biology at the University of Leeds, said in a release. “We now need a drug that has the same effect as pouring sand into the watch. Every part of the viral mechanism could be disabled.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Andrew Nye, DO, of the Orlando Health Physicians Family Medicine Group, says the research is fascinating.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The common cold is actually not just one virus, but a whole host of many different viruses,” he told Healthline. “One of the largest groups is the coronavirus, and there’s a number of different subviruses that belong to that family. So the researchers have identified a structural weak point, if you will, in terms of how all of these viruses package and assemble the shield around themselves. It’s very promising because if a medication could be developed to attack those specific sites, you would ideally be able to attack that whole family of viruses — not just one species, but many different species.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nye said it appears the researchers have identified some valuable targets.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“A medication or class of medications that attack these sites would likely be effective for a good amount of time, so that’s pretty exciting,” he said. “The more basic level you can attack a virus on, its basic level of construction, the more success you’re going to have.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Being able to target the cold virus would be brilliant,” Dr. Hilary Hawkins, of the Orlando Health Physician Associates, told Healthline. “I’m not sure if it’s possible because there are so many variants of the cold virus. It’s exciting that they’re looking into this as a possibility, but it’s very early.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A persistent ailment&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The common cold certainly lives up to its name. It’s very common.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The average adult gets &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.aafp.org/afp/2007/0215/p515.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;two to four colds&lt;/a&gt; per year, while children typically get more. It’s the most frequent infectious disease in humans.&lt;strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s a challenging illness because it presents differently depending on the individual patient, says Hawkins. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s not just one discrete thing like strep throat or pneumonia,” she says. “A cold can manifest itself as coughing and sneezing, or congestion, or a sore throat. The duration is different in everybody. It seems to target the immune system differently, to the point where it’s difficult to tease out exactly whether it’s a cold or something else.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The common cold’s diversity is one of the factors that makes it difficult to find a cure. Nye says realistically it’s unlikely that the common cold will ever be fully eradicated.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The cold is not just one virus, it’s dozens and dozens of different viruses,” he says. “Even if this medication or class of medications was successful against the host family of coronaviruses, you’re still going to have other viruses that this will not be effective for. And at some point, likely, the coronaviruses will have some mutation that will benefit them to resist this medication or class of medications. Short-term, I think there’s a lot of benefit. In terms of elimination, no, that’s not really realistic, I don’t think, just because these viruses are so pervasive that you have to eliminate them on a global scale pretty much simultaneously, which is not going to happen.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Giving it the cold shoulder&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;While everybody catches a cold now and then, there are precautions that can be taken to avoid it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hawkins says that washing your hands with soap and water is key, pointing out that the virus lives on surfaces that people are likely to be touching.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I would say that most people seem to get sick when they travel,” she says. “Part of that is because you’re exposed to a whole new set of germs that you’re normally not exposed to. Also, people don’t realize the nastiness of planes. There have been studies done that show that the places where viruses — the cold virus especially — will stay is the tray tables. Wiping down your tray table, washing your hands before you eat if you can, and turning your body away from someone who’s coughing next to you are all key.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If you do catch a cold, it’s important to monitor your symptoms so you can not only get healthy again, but avoid infecting those close to you.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hawkins says that anyone who works with children or elderly people should exercise extra caution when it comes to returning to work.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Certainly, if anyone has a fever, they should not be at work — and they shouldn’t be at work for at least a 24-hour period, until their fever has broken,” says Hawkins. “If you’ve been sick for two or three days, make sure to get rest and get plenty of fluids, but if you can work, you’re not necessarily putting anyone at danger.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Cold and Flu</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-14T11:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-14T11:00:00</updateddate>

</guid>
<dc:creator>Dan Gray</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-14T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
New Drugs Alone Won’t Defeat Antibiotic Resistant Bacteria
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/new-drugs-alone-wont-defeat-antibiotic-resistant-bacteria
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/031417_bacteriadrugs_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The pronouncement was an urgent one.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The World Health Organization (WHO) last week put out a list of 12 “&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.who.int/medicines/publications/WHO-PPL-Short_Summary_25Feb-ET_NM_WHO.pdf?ua=1&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;priority pathogens&lt;/a&gt;” they said have become drug resistant and are threatening human health across the globe.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;WHO officials urged pharmaceutical companies worldwide to put new drugs to combat these deadly bacteria on a fast track.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Antibiotic resistance is growing and we are fast running out of treatment options. If we leave it to market forces alone, the new antibiotics we most urgently need are not going to be developed in time,” Marie-Paule Kieny, PhD, WHO's assistant director-general for Health Systems and Innovation, said in a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/releases/2017/bacteria-antibiotics-needed/en/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;press release&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Experts interviewed by Healthline agreed the new drugs are a necessary strategy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But they said other preventative measures need to be taken because these bacteria are likely to adapt and become resistant to whatever new drugs humans come up with.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Drug discovery is just a piece of a very big puzzle,” Dr. Lee Norman, chief medical officer of the University of Kansas Hospital, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The deadly dozen&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;WHO officials divided the dozen deadly bacteria into three categories.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At the top were three pathogens listed as “critical” dangers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These are bacteria that are resistant to multiple drugs. They are a particular threat in hospitals, nursing homes, and with patients who require devices such as ventilators and blood catheters.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These hospital-acquired infections are no small matter.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) estimates there are more than &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/hai/surveillance/index.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;700,000&lt;/a&gt; of these infections every year in acute care hospitals in the United States. About 75,000 people with these infections die during hospitalization every year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Six pathogens were listed on WHO’s second grouping of “high priority” bacteria.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The final three pathogens were on a “medium priority” list.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These second and third tiers are comprised of bacteria that are increasingly becoming drug resistant. They are the cause of a number of common diseases such as gonorrhea and salmonella.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“New antibiotics targeting this priority list of pathogens will help to reduce deaths due to resistant infections around the world,” Dr. Evelina Tacconelli, PhD, professor of infectious diseases and head of the Division of Infectious Diseases at the University of Tubingen, said in the press release. “Waiting any longer will cause further public health problems and dramatically impact patient care.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Norman told Healthline creating the list is a good way to draw attention to this growing problem.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s the right step to take,” he said. “It’s a call to action that’s been coming for a long time.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Arjun Srinivasan, the CDC’s associate director of Healthcare-Associated Infection Prevention Programs, agrees.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s helpful to look at data and look at the impact organisms have and then prioritize them,” Srinivasan told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Both Norman and Srinivasan concur that new drugs are something society just has to develop, even if there is an assumption that bacteria will simply become resistant to new drugs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Among other things, you can’t just stand by and allow someone to suffer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s hard to see people slip away and die,” said Norman.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Other steps to take&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Both Norman and Srinivasan, however, agree that new drugs alone won’t solve the problem.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Bacterium have been on Earth longer than humans and have shown an incredible ability to adapt to their surroundings, they said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We can’t count on drug development to keep us one step ahead,” said Norman. “We need to be humble about this.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Both experts say one of the chief ways to reduce the amount of bacterial infections is to make sure hospital rooms and other medical facilities are free of germs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That is easier said than done, especially in developing countries, the experts said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Norman said new types of catheters and other devices that are less likely to become contaminated need to be invented.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He added the simple act of people washing their hands frequently and thoroughly could do wonders.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We should never fall asleep at the switch on this one,” Norman said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He added more research into the causes of bacterial infections could provide other solutions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Srinivasan noted that clean water worldwide is another major way to reduce bacterial infections.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We need to take care of all the basic infrastructure needs,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Srinivasan added that vaccinations are important. Although most vaccines are for viruses, there are a few for bacteria such as certain types of pneumonia and diphtheria. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said regular inoculations are vital, too, because they make people healthier and less likely to succumb to a bacterial infection.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;All in all, the two experts agree that a multipronged approach to drug resistant bacteria is necessary.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We have to do all of these things,” said Srinivasan.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-03-14T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-14T10:00:00</updateddate>

<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-14T17:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Most People Don’t Need to Take Omega-3 Supplements</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/most-dont-need-omega-3-supplements
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/031317_fishoil_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/nutritionsource/omega-3-fats/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Omega-3s&lt;/a&gt; are a group of polyunsaturated fatty acids that perform key functions in the human body.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They are part of the body’s cell membranes and play a crucial role in the production of hormones, which later control blood clotting and the elasticity of artery walls.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These fats are particularly important because, unlike other types of fat, the body cannot produce them on its own.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Instead, the body needs to get them from food. Omega-3 can be found in fish, nuts, oil, and flax seeds, as well as green, leafy vegetables.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Because of their fundamental role in the good functioning of the human body, omega-3s are believed to have a variety of health benefits, particularly in regards to heart disease. The fats seem to prevent arrhythmias by keeping the heartbeat at a steady pace, lowering the blood pressure, and improving the functioning of blood vessels. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Do omega-3 supplements benefit the population at large and can they be used to prevent heart disease?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To answer this question, the American Heart Association (AHA) reviewed several studies that investigate the benefits of omega-3 dietary supplementation and published a science advisory to report on the findings.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The writing committee was chaired by Dr. David Siscovick and the recommendations were &lt;a href=&quot;http://dx.doi.org/10.1161/CIR.0000000000000482&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;published&lt;/a&gt; in the AHA’s journal Circulation. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Supplements may not be needed&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The advisory group analyzed several randomized controlled trials that assessed the preventive potential of omega-3s on cardiovascular disease, as well as the effect of fish oil supplements on heart attacks, stroke, coronary heart disease, atrial fibrillation, and other conditions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The reviewed studies were published since 2002. The advisory also analyzed two studies published before that year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The trials considered for the advisory focused on the use of supplements, but not on omega-3 intake directly from food. They investigated the benefits of taking around 1,000 milligrams of omega-3 daily.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The writing committee concluded that treatment with omega-3 supplements is “reasonable” for patients who have experienced a heart attack or heart failure.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, the review did not find sufficient evidence to support the use of omega-3 supplements as a preventive measure against heart disease in the general, healthy population. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We cannot make a recommendation to use omega-3 fish oil supplements for primary prevention of cardiovascular disease at this time,” said Siscovick, senior vice president for research at The New York Academy of Medicine. “People in the general population who are taking omega-3 fish oil supplements are taking them in the absence of scientific data that shows any benefit of the supplements in preventing heart attacks, stroke, heart failure, or death for people who do not have a diagnosis of cardiovascular disease.&quot;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Significance of the report&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The advisory’s recommendations are particularly significant given that more than 18 million adults in the United States said that they were taking omega-3 fish oil supplements in 2012, according to a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25671660&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; referenced by the authors. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The chair of the writing group explained that the new findings confirm previous recommendations made by the AHA in a scientific advisory they published in 2002.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&quot;Scientific findings from the past two decades that focused on the prevention of cardiovascular diseases continue to show that among people who are at risk of dying from heart disease, the potential benefit of omega-3 fish oil supplements is still useful for people who have had a recent heart attack, which is consistent with the 2002 statement,&quot; Siscovick said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The chair also commented on how the advisory affects healthcare professionals.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&quot;Physicians should use this advisory as a guide to make decisions on whether omega-3 fish oil supplements might be appropriate for some patients,” Siscovik added. “The advisory concludes that supplementation with omega-3 fish oil may benefit patients with specific, clinical, cardiovascular disease indications, including patients with a recent prior heart attack and heart failure.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Food and Nutrition</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-13T13:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-13T13:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/most-dont-need-omega-3-supplements
</guid>
<dc:creator>Ana Sandoiu</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-13T20:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Should Doctors Talk to Teen Girls About Sexual Assault?
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/should-doctors-talk-to-teen-girls-about-sexual-assault
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/031317_sexualassault_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Sar
]]>
<![CDATA[
ah Patterson was sexually assaulted as a sophomore in high school.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But she never really received the treatment she needed. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“My doctor didn’t know how to talk to a scared teen,” she explained.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Patterson isn’t the only young girl to have faced a similar experience.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Teens and young adults over the age of 12 experience the highest rate of sexual assault, according to &lt;a href=&quot;http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/139/3/e20164243&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;a report&lt;/a&gt; published in the March 2017 issue of Pediatrics.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Up to now, teen girls and women haven’t always received the care they’ve needed, or even been properly identified as victims of assault.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) wants to change that.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.aappublications.org/news/2017/02/27/assault022717&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;New guidelines&lt;/a&gt; recently released by the AAP reflect a growing effort to identify and help teens like Patterson as early as possible. Those guidelines include encouraging physicians to:&lt;/p&gt; &lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Routinely ask adolescents about any history of sexual violence, dating violence, and sexual assaults. &lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Screen for sexually transmitted infections (STIs).&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Offer emergency contraception to female adolescents who disclose sexual assault if reported within 120 hours of the assault.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Be prepared to offer emotional support and referrals for additional counseling. &lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt; &lt;p&gt;The goal is to help teens open up to their physicians and to ensure they get the support they need if an assault has taken place.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Debate over guidelines&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, not everyone is on board with the changes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some parents don’t feel comfortable with doctors talking to their teens about these subjects, and some past victims of abuse feel as though these new guidelines wouldn’t help anyway. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I know I wouldn’t have said anything if I’d been asked as a teen.” Chris B. of California told Healthline. “My abuser always threatened to kill my mother if I told. So I never did.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Andrea Duncan of Missouri agreed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I don’t think most teens would talk. I know I never would have talked in front of a parent,” she told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If a teen hasn’t already opened up to a parent, what are the chances they will open up to a doctor when their parent is present?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As part of these new guidelines, should doctors be requesting a few minutes alone with teen patients to ask these potentially uncomfortable questions? &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Robyn Boring, the mother of daughters, was adamant in her response.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Given the stories I know of pediatricians and doctors who have been complicit in child abuse and trafficking of pictures and persons, I would absolutely not allow a doctor to be alone with my daughters or son questioning them,” Boring told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Possible solutions&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;So what is the answer?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;How can doctors help their patients to open up, and how can they better provide the support those patients might need?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Jody Jordan, a family advocate in Texas, told Healthline she’s in favor of these new guidelines, believing they are a step in the right direction.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In my profession,” she explained, “we are encouraged [and required] to watch for signs of abuse. Stats vary, but most studies say that at least 1 in 5 girls and 1 in 20 boys will be sexually abused in childhood. And screening for that, in my opinion, is a good thing. These questions should be getting asked. And I would hope parents would look at this as another level of protection for the most vulnerable members of our society.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Heather Pickens, a mother in Arizona, agrees.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She told Healthline the story of a friend who was sexually abused as a young teen. That friend spoke to a D.A.R.E. officer in their middle school, which was what started the process of getting her the help she needed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In her case,” Pickens said, “she finally met an authority figure that she could trust and felt comfortable telling the truth to. So for me, I feel like more pediatricians and family doctors performing these screenings might help to make more teens feel comfortable opening up. It’s just one more potential authority figure who could make that connection.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-03-13T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-13T12:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/should-doctors-talk-to-teen-girls-about-sexual-assault
</guid>
<dc:creator>Leah Campbell</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-13T19:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Why Planned Parenthood Won’t Accept President Trump’s No Abortion Deal
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/why-planned-parenthood-wont-accept-no-abortion-deal
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/031317_plannedparenthood_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;President Trump likes to describe himself as a big-time deal maker.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, an offer the president made to Planned Parenthood has been flatly rejected by the nonprofit organization.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to The &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/06/us/politics/planned-parenthood.html?smid=tw-share&amp;amp;_r=0&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;New York Times,&lt;/a&gt; the White House has told Planned Parenthood it can keep the $500 million it receives annually in federal money if it stops providing abortion services.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That money accounts for about 40 percent of Planned Parenthood’s annual &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.plannedparenthood.org/files/2114/5089/0863/2014-2015_PPFA_Annual_Report_.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;$1.3 billion budget&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In comparison, abortion services only make up about &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2015/08/12/for-planned-parenthood-abortion-stats-3-percent-and-94-percent-are-both-misleading/?utm_term=.bcdf989c6192&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;3 percent&lt;/a&gt; of the more than 9 million medical services the organization provides every year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On paper, that might seem like a good deal. In reality, Planned Parenthood officials, say it is not.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The White House proposal that Planned Parenthood stop providing abortion is the same demand opponents of women’s health have been pushing for decades, as a part of their long-standing effort to end women’s access to safe, legal abortion,” Erica Sackin, the director of political communications for the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, told Healthline in an email. “Planned Parenthood has always stood strong against these attacks on our patients and their ability to access the full range of reproductive healthcare.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Abortion opponents see the rejection as the organization revealing its true priorities.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It helps to show how central abortion is to Planned Parenthood’s operations,” Eric Scheidler, executive director of the Pro-Life Action League, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The debate has galvanized both sides, with supporters of Planned Parenthood rallying to their cause.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“All women need Planned Parenthood reproductive health services,” Terry O’Neill, the president of the National Organization for Women (NOW), told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;It’s Medicaid money&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;So what is the $500 million at stake here?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s not a line item in the federal budget that is simply crossed out.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The vast majority of that money comes from &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.plannedparenthoodaction.org/issues/health-care-equity/medicaid-and-reproductive-health&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Medicaid&lt;/a&gt; when Planned Parenthood is reimbursed by that federal program for services provided for people receiving Medicaid.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other money comes from reimbursements under &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.plannedparenthoodaction.org/issues/health-care-equity/title-x/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Title X&lt;/a&gt;, a federal family planning program.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The defunding proposal is part of the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/06/us/politics/affordable-care-act-obamacare-health.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Republicans’ plan&lt;/a&gt;, unveiled a week ago, to replace the Affordable Care Act (ACA). It would take away those federal reimbursements for Planned Parenthood for one year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Medicaid is &lt;a href=&quot;https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/how-defunding-planned-parenthood-could-affect-health-care/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;funded jointly&lt;/a&gt; by the federal government and the states. Those states could decide to make up the difference.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, several states had already begun processes to defund Planned Parenthood, even before Donald Trump took over the White House.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In Texas, legislators took action in December to take away Medicaid funding for Planned Parenthood. That prohibition was &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/22/516631590/judge-rules-texas-cant-cut-off-medicaid-funds-to-planned-parenthood-for-now&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;temporarily halted&lt;/a&gt; last month by a federal judge.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In Iowa, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/news/politics/2017/02/02/amid-heated-rhetoric-iowa-senate-votes-halt-planned-parenthood-funding/97378012/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;state senators voted&lt;/a&gt; in early February to block Planned Parenthood from receiving federal funds. That bill is now making its way through the Iowa House.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In Mississippi, a federal judge last October &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.reuters.com/article/us-mississippi-plannedparenthood-idUSKCN12L0EB&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;struck down&lt;/a&gt; a state law that would have barred medical providers that perform abortions from participating in the state’s Medicaid program.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Planned Parenthood supporters point out that federal law prohibits federal money from being used for abortion services. They say the reimbursements go for other health programs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Opponents, like Scheidler, say the federal funds free up money for Planned Parenthood to provide those other services, so the reimbursements indirectly pay for abortions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They say it’s time for the federal government to put an end to this.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If Planned Parenthood gets out of the abortion business, it will be a net gain for America,” said Scheidler.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Supporters of the organization see across-the-board disaster if that happens.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Defunding Planned Parenthood would block millions of people in this country from accessing birth control, cancer screenings, and preventive care,” said Sackin.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What would be the effect?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to Planned Parenthood, about three-fourths of the organization’s patients have incomes at or below 150 percent of the poverty level.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;About &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.plannedparenthoodaction.org/blog/how-federal-funding-works-at-planned-parenthood&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;60 percent&lt;/a&gt; of the organization’s patients receive services for free through Medicaid or Title X, a federal family planning program.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If Planned Parenthood didn’t receive those federal reimbursements, that would mean it would either have to deny services to people with low incomes, or perform those services for free.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Either way, supporters say, the defunding would force the organization to close some of its 650 clinics across the country.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“For many patients, Planned Parenthood is the only healthcare provider they see,” said Sackin. “Blocking access to care at Planned Parenthood hurts communities that are struggling to get by the most, especially those with low incomes, those living in areas with no other quality health care providers, and communities of color who face systemic barriers to care.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Scheidler said Planned Parenthood’s position is “a form of extortion” because they are telling federal officials they will yank all services if they can’t perform abortions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sackin did not respond to Scheidler’s claim, but O’Neill did.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She said that organizations like Pro-Life Action League have engaged in their own form of extortion by threatening women seeking abortions as well as the facilities where they’re performed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She added that wanting to provide a full range of services is not extortion.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If Planned Parenthood clinics did close, abortion opponents say women could find those health services at other facilities that receive federal funding.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The goal is to preserve the health services that women get,” said Scheidler.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, Planned Parenthood supporters say it’s not that simple.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They say some women trust only Planned Parenthood to provide them with health services. This is especially true of teenage girls who might not want their parents to know they went to the doctor.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, in many underserved communities, Planned Parenthood is the only facility near enough for women to visit. This is particularly true in rural areas.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In a lot of these communities, women use Planned Parenthood as their primary care physician,” said O’Neill. “Places like rural areas would be badly hurt.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Even Scheidler admits the adjustment would take time.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It might take some effort to make up that gap,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There has been a preview of sorts of this ripple effect in Texas.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2011, state lawmakers introduced a series of budget cuts for family planning services. Those reductions caused the closure of 82 clinics, one-third of which were affiliated with Planned Parenthood, according to a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMsa1511902#t=article&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; in the New England Journal of Medicine. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Planned Parenthood supporters say this magnitude of closures would drastically reduce health services to women.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They note the birth control and family planning services they provide actually &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.plannedparenthoodaction.org/issues/health-care-equity/medicaid-and-reproductive-health&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;save taxpayers money.&lt;/a&gt; They say their programs help prevent 2 million unintended pregnancies a year. Overall, &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.plannedparenthood.org/about-us/who-we-are/planned-parenthood-at-a-glance&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;those programs&lt;/a&gt; along with cancer screenings and other services save taxpayers more than $13 billion a year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Therefore, they say, opponents should accept the fact Planned Parenthood performs abortions because of all the other services that it provides.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Scheidler can’t agree to that compromise.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I can’t accept that bargain,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Planned Parenthood officials say it’s a matter of weighing the benefits their organization provides.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“For the vast majority of people in this country, Planned Parenthood is the solution, not the problem,” said Sackin.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-03-13T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-13T10:00:00</updateddate>

<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-13T17:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>What You Should Do If You Faint</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/what-you-should-do-if-you-faint
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/031317_fainting_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Fainting could be a sign of a serious heart problem and should be evaluated by a doctor, say new guidelines from three leading heart organizations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://circ.ahajournals.org/lookup/doi/10.1161/CIR.0000000000000498&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;guidelines&lt;/a&gt;, issued Thursday by the American College of Cardiology, American Heart Association and Heart Rhythm Society, are the first such guidelines on the topic.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Fainting is fairly common. About 41 percent of Americans have fainted at some point.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This is very important because fainting impacts thousands of people every day,” said Dr. Win-Kuang Shen, a cardiologist at the Mayo Clinic in Phoenix and chair of the group that developed the guidelines. “Having these guidelines is not only good for the clinicians using them, but for everyone.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What causes fainting?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;When someone faints, they lose consciousness due to a drop in blood pressure, resulting in a lack of oxygen to the brain.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Fainting can be due to neurological, psychological or cardiac causes,” said Dr. Gerald Fletcher, a cardiologist at the Mayo Clinic in Jacksonville, Florida, who was not involved in writing the new guidelines.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Occasional fainting is not necessarily cause for concern, but if it’s repetitive, it needs to be addressed, he said. About 14 percent of people have recurrent fainting.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Extreme emotion, such as attending a funeral or in response to seeing blood, can trigger fainting, but it is not life-threatening, said Dr. Vincent Bufalino, M.D., a cardiologist and president of Advocate Medical Group in Naperville, Illinois, who was not involved in writing the new guidelines.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Heart-related causes are to blame for fainting more often in people over 60 compared to younger people, according to the guidelines.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This could be due to underlying heart disease or taking a higher dose of blood pressure-lowering medication, Bufalino said. Dehydration at any age can also contribute to fainting, he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Irregular heart rhythms and faulty heart valves are the most common heart triggers for fainting, Bufalino said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What to do after fainting&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The new guidelines say people who faint for any reason should get a physical exam and provide their doctor with a detailed medical history.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The office visit may include an electrocardiogram, a simple, inexpensive test of the heart’s electrical activity that can help spot heart-related causes of fainting.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Competitive athletes who faint should see a doctor before resuming sports, the guidelines say. Bufalino said athletes typically pass out from dehydration or overexertion, but testing can help identify or rule out hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, an enlarged heart that could require additional treatment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For most people who faint, additional tests, such as MRI or CT scans, are unnecessary unless the person has already been diagnosed with heart disease or a new heart issue is suspected, according to the guidelines.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Doing appropriate tests when needed and not “spending a fortune” on unnecessary tests is the best approach to fainting from a cardiovascular point of view, Fletcher said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Although it’s important to remember that most fainting episodes are not severe, Fletcher said, checking in with your doctor to ask if it’s something to worry about is a good idea.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/first-fainting-guidelines-issued-to-diagnose-life-threatening-heart-conditions/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;original story&lt;/a&gt; was published on &lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;American Heart Association News&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
