<pubdate>2017-03-13T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-13T10:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/what-you-should-do-if-you-faint
</guid>
<dc:creator>American Heart Association News</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-13T17:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Shorter, Quicker Exercises Might Be More Beneficial
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/shorter-quicker-exercises-more-beneficial
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/031017_shortexercise_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Do enough curls and you’ll start to see your biceps grow.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Walk up enough staircases and you’ll no longer get so out of breath.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Swim enough laps and you might start noticing you’re sleeping better.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But what about the less noticeable effects of exercise?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;How do you become healthier in other less visible but critical ways?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Exactly how exercise can affect your tiniest components — your cells — is still being uncovered.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cell.com/cell-metabolism/fulltext/S1550-4131(17)30099-2&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;recent study&lt;/a&gt; published in Cell Metabolism sheds some light on the mystery, finding that high-intensity interval training (HIIT) during exercises like biking and walking increased the capacity of the mitochondria.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p class=&quot;m-172881150373536250gmailmsg&quot;&gt;Those are the organelles that produce the energy in cells that keeps us going.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What researchers discovered&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;This energy generation capacity decreases as we get older, but the researchers found that, due to exercise, the cells in study participants made more mitochondrial proteins as well as the proteins responsible for muscle growth.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This, the researchers said, essentially reversed the effects of aging at the cellular level.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We always knew exercise could have an impact on cell function,” the study’s senior author, Dr. Sreekumaran Nair, of the Mayo Clinic, told Healthline. “Many age-related changes are related to lack of exercise. But if you deliberately do it, then you can really reverse most it.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Specifically, interval training — brief bursts of high-intensity cardio followed by longer period of lighter activity or rest — led to a 49 percent increase in mitochondrial capacity in the muscle cells of volunteers ages 18 to 30.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It also produced a 69 percent increase in participants ages 65 to 80.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Those were the two age groups included in the research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study divided volunteers — 36 men and 36 women — into a group that did high-intensity interval cycling, one that lifted weights, and another that did both. Researchers then took biopsies from the participants’ thigh muscles.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The benefits went beyond interval training causing mitochondrial improvements.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The quicker, more intense exercises also reduced insulin sensitivity and, thus, susceptibility to diabetes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nair said the study was intended to help uncover how exercise affects cell functioning, not necessarily to find the best exercises.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But he would recommend combining HIIT with strength training to maximize both the age-reversing cellular benefits and the muscle strength improvement.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said to stick with the interval training if you only have time for one.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Broader benefits&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The broader benefits to health and longevity from exercise have been well established for more than 70 years, said Jennifer Turgiss, Ph.D., vice president of behavioral science and advanced analytics at Johnson &amp;amp; Johnson Health and Wellness Solutions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She rattles off a list of ailments that exercise is known to decrease the likelihood of developing. These include stroke, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes, breast and colon cancers, depression, and anxiety. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But, she says, through new research methods we are starting to learn more about how physical activity affects us at the cellular level.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It is early days for this type of research, so there would be no changes in [exercise] recommendations yet,” Turgiss told Healthline. “But keep on the watch.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She notes that updates to the government’s &lt;a href=&quot;https://health.gov/paguidelines/second-edition/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Physical Activity Guidelines&lt;/a&gt; are currently in the works. Those &lt;a href=&quot;https://health.gov/paguidelines/guidelines/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;guidelines&lt;/a&gt; don’t currently mention cellular health or interval training.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Most athletes already use &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/what-exercises-are-best&quot;&gt;interval training&lt;/a&gt; in their exercise programs and the approach appears to be growing in popularity among non-athletes as well.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For some ideas on how to apply it in your own exercise routines, look to a &lt;a href=&quot;http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0154075&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; last year that put 27 sedentary men through 12 weeks of HIIT consisting of three 20-second sprints on a stationary bike, each followed by 2 minutes of easier riding.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The group, which biked for 10 minutes a day total, saw the same benefits in terms of aerobic fitness, regulation of blood sugar, and improved function of muscle cells as men who biked for 45 minutes at 70 percent of their maximal heart rate.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Fitness and Exercise</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-12T06:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-12T06:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/shorter-quicker-exercises-more-beneficial
</guid>
<dc:creator>Matthew Berger</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-12T13:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Predicting Who Will Get Progressive MS</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/predicting-who-will-get-progressive-ms
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/MS/031117_mspredictions_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;
]]>
<![CDATA[
Life with a progressive disease can be challenging for anyone, even the most prepared. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Not knowing what the future holds can make for unnecessary stress. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Add to that a lack of approved therapies, and someone with the disease could lose hope. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But doctors and researchers, in a range of studies, are beginning to find answers to these issues for people with progressive multiple sclerosis (MS). &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Understanding who will develop progression with the disease is a big part of MS treatment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Stopping the progression is key to slowing or stopping neurological damage, and &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3002639/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;early treatment&lt;/a&gt; leads to a better chance of living well with MS.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While there are no drugs approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for progressive MS, one medication is expected to get FDA approval late this month.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/new-multiple-sclerosis-drug-awaits-approval&quot;&gt;Ocrelizumab&lt;/a&gt; is considered a breakthrough in the treatment of progressive MS. Study participants showed lower rates of clinical progression — meaning their symptoms appeared improved after receiving the drug. Also, the number of lesions showing up on MRI were fewer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Predicting MS&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2017/03/170301224233.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;recent study&lt;/a&gt;, researchers report they found a way for early diagnosis of MS in the progressive category. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a group of 155 people ages 50 and older, 30 percent progressed to secondary progressive MS by the five-year mark of the study.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The two things in common with all those who progressed? Fatigue and weak or spasmodic legs.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Study participants with those symptoms were more likely to progress from relapsing-remitting MS to secondary progressive MS within five years,” said study author Dr. &lt;a href=&quot;http://medicine.buffalo.edu/content/medicine/faculty/profile.html?ubit=bw8&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Bianca Weinstock-Guttman&lt;/a&gt;, of the Jacobs School of Medicine and Biomedical Sciences at the University of Buffalo in New York, and a member of the American Academy of Neurology. “Better understanding who is at high risk of getting worse may eventually allow us to tailor more specific treatments to these people.”&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Both fatigue and leg issues can be common for people with MS. Excessive &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nationalmssociety.org/Symptoms-Diagnosis/MS-Symptoms/Fatigue&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;fatigue&lt;/a&gt; is considered the most disabling symptom. It occurs in &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nationalmssociety.org/Symptoms-Diagnosis/MS-Symptoms/Fatigue&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;80 percent&lt;/a&gt; of people with MS, according to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, fatigue can lead to &lt;a href=&quot;http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/1352458517695470&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;exacerbated symptoms&lt;/a&gt; such as poor cognitive function. Cog-fog, as it is often called, causes issues with information processing speed, attention, motor function, and memory. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are not a lot of effective treatments for fatigue, especially without strong side effects. However, researchers are not giving up.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a recent study, researchers looked at the efficacy of a personalized &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24854634&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;neuromodulation&lt;/a&gt; treatment, basically a form of &lt;a href=&quot;/health/electroconvulsive-therapy&quot;&gt;electroconvulsive therapy (ECT)&lt;/a&gt;. The study suggested that interventions could help relieve debilitating symptoms by targeting key areas of the brain.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, “[Fatigue] can significantly interfere with a person’s ability to function at home and work, and is one of the primary causes of early departure from the workforce.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Seeking the cause&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;While the industry has seen many improvements for relapsing MS there have been little for those with progressive MS. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This is changing as doctors and researchers find success in their studies of progression, what causes it, and how to stop it. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Along with fatigue and spasmodic legs, &lt;a href=&quot;http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s12035-015-9648-6&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;biomarkers&lt;/a&gt; continue to be tested for use in understanding progression.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The cause of progression is not known, but recent studies continue to unveil interesting conclusions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;North Africans in France progressed significantly &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.karger.com/Article/FullText/431042&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;faster&lt;/a&gt; than Caucasian people with MS.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In Ireland, the typical &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9576534&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;person with MS&lt;/a&gt; is age 54 and older. There was a preponderance of men and a greater number of people with motor onset compared with other subgroups of people with MS. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The increasing number of successful studies looking into progressive MS is hopeful, experts say. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“While more research needs to be done, this study brings us closer to understanding which older adults with MS may be at higher risk of getting worse,” said Weinstock-Guttman.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Editor’s Note: Caroline Craven is a patient expert living with MS. Her award winning blog is&lt;a href=&quot;http://girlwithms.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;GirlwithMS.com&lt;/a&gt;, and she can be found @thegirlwithms.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Multiple Sclerosis</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-11T06:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-11T06:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/predicting-who-will-get-progressive-ms
</guid>
<dc:creator>Caroline Craven</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-11T14:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>What? Hearing Loss Expected to Rise Dramatically</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/hearing-loss-expected-to-rise
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/031017_hearingloss_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;If you fear you’re going to spend your “golden years” with a hand cupped behind your ear, saying “Eh, what?” you may not be all that wrong.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And some younger people may be joining you.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to a &lt;a href=&quot;http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamaotolaryngology/article-abstract/2606784&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;new study&lt;/a&gt;, the number of adults in the United States 20 years of age or older with hearing loss is expected to nearly double in coming decades.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Put another way, that means the percentage of adults who have hearing loss will rise from 15 percent to 22 percent. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s a jump from 44 million in 2020 to 73 million in 2060. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Demand for hearing services&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Adele Goman, PhD, a postdoctoral research fellow at the Johns Hopkins Center on Aging and Health in Maryland, is one of several scientists who analyzed audiometric data from the latest National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s a biannual epidemiologic survey of a representative sample of the U.S. noninstitutionalized population.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Last year we estimated how common hearing loss is across different age groups and how many adults have hearing loss today,” Goman told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study was supported by grants from the National Institutes of Health and by the Eleanor Schwartz Charitable Foundation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We did not know the number of adults that are expected to have hearing loss in the coming decades,” Goman said. “This is important to know in order to appropriately plan for future hearing healthcare needs.”&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Since the number of adults with hearing loss is expected to increase in the coming years, demand for audiologic services will increase as well.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;More than two-thirds of adults 70 years or older in the United States will have clinically meaningful hearing loss.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Audiologic healthcare services encompass a range of options including aural rehabilitation, hearing aid fitting, hearing screenings and referrals, hearing aid testing, and novel approaches to hearing healthcare,” said Goman.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A public health issue&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study concludes that hearing loss is a major public health issue independently associated with higher healthcare costs, accelerated cognitive decline, and poorer physical functioning. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s not any surprise to Barbara Kelley, whose position as executive director of the Hearing Loss Association of America puts her on the front lines.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We’ve always known hearing loss is a primary health concern,” Kelley told Healthline. “When you have one health problem, you probably have others.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She noted that people with hearing loss have more falls than those not affected.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There may be a link to dementia as well,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It is thought that some aspects of hearing loss are due to aging, she said. “But we don’t know if that’s due to exposure to too much noise. It may be a co-morbidity factor.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Remember all those warnings about loud rock music that went in one ear and out the other, so to speak?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If you leave a concert with ringing in your ears, for example, that’s a sign that some cells in your ear have died, Kelley said. And they stay dead forever.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Changes are afoot&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Today, a hearing aid might cost $4,000 and it’s not covered by most insurance carriers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kelley said the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has suggested a new category of over-the-counter devices. It would be a first step into amplification devices.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One new device uses “smart buds” controlled by your smart phone. Kelly said the high-tech format might be popular with aging baby boomers who say, “I don’t need a hearing aid. That’s for old people.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The hearing aid market has a low volume, high cost model,” Kelley said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But that could change.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kelley cited a bill introduced in November by Senators Elizabeth Warren (D.-Mass.) and Chuck Grassley (R.-Iowa), the Over-the-Counter Hearing Aid Act of 2016.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The bipartisan legislation would make certain types of hearing aids available without prescription as well as remove some of the requirements that make it difficult for consumers to get the products they need.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We’d love to see Medicare cover hearing loss,” Kelley said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When Medicare was established in 1965 its intent was to focus on life-threatening issues. Hearing loss, vision, and dental care were specifically excluded and it would take an act of Congress to reverse that.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“That’s a hard nut to crack,” Kelley admitted.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Also in the works: On Apr. 18, the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) will host a daylong workshop to examine competition, innovation, and consumer protection issues raised by hearing health and technology, especially hearing aids.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Health and science authorities observe that many more consumers could benefit from hearing healthcare devices and related services, but cannot afford them.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For example, a &lt;a href=&quot;http://nationalacademies.org/hmd/reports/2016/Hearing-Health-Care-for-Adults.aspx&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2016 report&lt;/a&gt; by the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine estimates that “67 to 86 percent of adults who may benefit from hearing aids do not use them.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/press-releases/2017/01/ftc-announces-workshop-hearing-health-technology&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;FTC workshop&lt;/a&gt; will bring together researchers, healthcare providers, industry representatives, consumer representatives, policymakers, and others to examine ways in which enhanced competition and innovation might increase the availability and adoption of hearing aids by those consumers who need them. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The workshop will be free and open to the public. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So listen up.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>General Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-10T21:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-10T21:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/hearing-loss-expected-to-rise
</guid>
<dc:creator>Roberta Alexander</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-11T05:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Low-Gluten Diet May Be Linked to Diabetes Risk</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/low-gluten-diet-may-be-linked-to-diabetes-risk
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/Diabetes/0309i17_glutendiabetes_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Does a diet low in gluten increase the risk of type 2 diabetes?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers involved in a new, long-term study think it might, but some dietitians argue the link could actually be due to a low intake of fiber. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the observational study commencing in 1984, researchers estimated the daily gluten intake for almost 200,000 participants through food questionnaires completed every two to four years. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The findings were &lt;a href=&quot;http://professional.heart.org/professional/EducationMeetings/MeetingsLiveCME/EPILifestyle/UCM_316904_EPI-Lifestyle-Scientific-Sessions.jsp&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;presented today&lt;/a&gt; at the American Heart Association's Epidemiology and Prevention / Lifestyle and Cardiometabolic Health 2017 Scientific Sessions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What researchers discovered&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In their study, researchers found that those who ate the most gluten had a lower risk for developing type 2 diabetes in the 30 years of follow-up study. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Participants in the highest 20 percent of gluten consumption had a 13 percent lower risk of developing type 2 diabetes compared with those with the lowest daily gluten consumption (fewer than 4 grams).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We wanted to determine if gluten consumption will affect health in people with no apparent medical reasons to avoid gluten,” Geng Zong, PhD, a research fellow in the Department of Nutrition at Harvard University’s T.H. Chan School of Public Health, said in a press release. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Gluten-free foods often have less dietary fiber and other micronutrients, making them less nutritious, and they also tend to cost more. People without celiac disease may reconsider limiting their gluten intake for chronic disease prevention, especially for diabetes.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Janelle Smith, MS, dietitian for the &lt;a href=&quot;https://celiac.org/&quot;&gt;Celiac Disease Foundation&lt;/a&gt;, says those who are forced to be gluten-free due to celiac disease shouldn’t be concerned by the study. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Those with celiac disease might worry that they are at an increased risk of type 2 diabetes based on these results. As of now, research does not show that celiac disease is associated with an increased risk of type 2 diabetes, but it is associated with type 1 diabetes,” she told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It is quite possible that it is not reduced gluten, but overall reduced fiber intake that would result in this correlation.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The fiber connection&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Smith is not alone in suggesting a possible link between type 2 diabetes and a low-gluten diet could in fact be due to restricted fiber intake. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.susanweinernutrition.com&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Susan Weiner&lt;/a&gt;, a registered dietitian and nutritionist, holds a similar view on the research. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“My initial thought is that people who restricted gluten [also] restricted fiber from whole grains as well in their quest to limit their gluten intake,” Weiner told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Additionally, if they ate cake, crackers, and cookies which were gluten free without looking at carbohydrates or calories, that could have caused an increase in weight associated with an increased risk of type 2 diabetes. The cause is not conclusive, but this seems likely.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Of those who participated in the study, individuals who ate less gluten also tended to eat less cereal fiber, which is considered a protective factor against the development of type 2 diabetes. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Weiner says it is important those who follow a gluten-free diet ensure they are not eating too much processed food. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When folks go ‘gluten free’ for reasons other than a legitimate reason such as celiac disease or gluten sensitivity, they often purchase processed gluten-free foods such as cookies, crackers, and chips. These foods have low nutritional value, pack on calories, and are low in fiber,” she told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The health consequences of following a gluten-free diet composed primarily of processed foods can lead to weight gain and detrimental long-term consequences associated with low fiber intake,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Low-gluten diet popularity&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Gluten is a type of protein found in wheat and rye that gives bread and baked goods elasticity and a chewy texture.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Only a small percentage of the population cannot eat gluten. About &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3264942/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;1 percent&lt;/a&gt; must abstain due to celiac disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Despite a lack of evidence that reducing consumption of gluten provides long-term health benefits, gluten-free diets have been gaining popularity.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Experts say this isn’t necessarily a good thing. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The rise of popularity of the gluten-free diet is a double-edged sword for people with a medical necessity for it,” Alice Bast, chief executive officer of the patient advocacy group &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.beyondceliac.org/celiac-disease/facts-and-figures/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Beyond Celiac&lt;/a&gt;, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The gluten-free fad has driven the increase in the availability of packaged food options and to some extent raised awareness of celiac disease and gluten sensitivity,” she added. “However, we’ve also seen the gluten-free fad overshadow the fact that it’s the only current treatment for celiac disease … For those of us for whom the gluten-free diet is not an option, it has resulted in our not being taken seriously in situations in which we don’t have 100 percent control over our food and beverages.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Smith says the findings of the research may prompt those who abstain from gluten for reasons other than celiac disease and sensitivities to think carefully about doing so. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I hope that the public will begin to realize that ‘gluten-free’ does not equate with ‘healthy,’ and that a healthy gluten-free diet takes planning and consideration,” she said.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Diabetes</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-09T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-09T12:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/low-gluten-diet-may-be-linked-to-diabetes-risk
</guid>
<dc:creator>Elizabeth Pratt</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-09T20:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Erectile Dysfunction Drugs May Benefit Men Who’ve Had a Heart Attack
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/erectile-dysfunction-drugs
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/news/030917_edheart_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p class=&quot;Normal1&quot;&gt;Erectile dysfunction (ED), typically &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.bumc.bu.edu/sexualmedicine/physicianinformation/epidemiology-of-ed/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;defined&lt;/a&gt; as the inability to achieve or maintain an erection enough to achieve satisfactory sexual intercourse, affects a large number of aging U.S. men.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p class=&quot;Normal1&quot;&gt;Recent studies have reported that &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.bumc.bu.edu/sexualmedicine/physicianinformation/epidemiology-of-ed/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;10 percent&lt;/a&gt; of men between 40 and 70 live with severe or complete ED.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p class=&quot;Normal1&quot;&gt;Age plays a significant role in the onset and development of ED. Its prevalence increases from 22 percent around the age of 40 to almost 50 percent by the age of 70.&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: 13.6px;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p class=&quot;Normal1&quot;&gt;The most commonly prescribed form of ED medication is the so-called phosphodiesterase type 5 (&lt;a href=&quot;https://livertox.nih.gov/PDE5Inhibitors.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;PDE5&lt;/a&gt;) inhibitors, which cause vasodilation in the penis and lungs. On the market, they are sold as Viagra, Levitra, Cialis, and Stendra.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p class=&quot;Normal1&quot;&gt;New research&amp;nbsp; - presented today at the &lt;a href=&quot;https://accscientificsession.acc.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;American College of Cardiology's 66th Annual Scientific Session&lt;/a&gt; - examines the effect of PDE5 inhibitors on men who have had a heart attack.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p class=&quot;Normal1&quot;&gt;For men, the risk of heart disease rises considerably after the age of &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health/health-topics/topics/hdw/atrisk&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;45&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What researchers learned&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p class=&quot;Normal1&quot;&gt;The team - led by Dr. Daniel Peter Andersson, a postdoctoral researcher at Karolinska Institutet in Sweden - looked at the health records of men aged 80 and under who had been diagnosed and hospitalized with their first heart attack between 2007 and 2013.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p class=&quot;Normal1&quot;&gt;The health records were part of a Swedish national database that included every hospital in Sweden.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p class=&quot;Normal1&quot;&gt;The patients were followed for an average period of 3.3 years after their initial heart attack. Researchers compared the health outcomes of those who received a prescription for a PDE5 inhibitor or alprostadil - another kind of ED medication that is not a PDE5 inhibitor.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p class=&quot;Normal1&quot;&gt;Overall, slightly more than 7 percent of men received a prescription for an ED drug. Of these, 92 percent were prescribed a PDE5 inhibitor and 8 percent obtained a prescription for alprostadil.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p class=&quot;Normal1&quot;&gt;After adjusting for risk factors such as diabetes, stroke, and heart failure, the researchers found that men who were prescribed PDE5 inhibitors or alprostadil were 40 percent less likely to be hospitalized for heart failure than men who were not using ED medication.&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: 13.6px;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p class=&quot;Normal1&quot;&gt;Additionally, it appeared that taking PDE5 inhibitors also decreased the mortality risk for patients with a heart attack diagnosis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p class=&quot;Normal1&quot;&gt;The findings indicated a dose-response trend - as more prescriptions for PDE5 inhibitors correlated with a lower risk of premature death - but the authors caution that the study is too small to categorically indicate a dose-response benefit. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;ED medication and heart attacks&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p class=&quot;Normal1&quot;&gt;The lead author said the findings are significant.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p class=&quot;Normal1&quot;&gt;&quot;If you have an active sex life after a heart attack, it is probably safe to use PDE5 inhibitors,” said Andersson in a statement. “This type of erectile dysfunction treatment is beneficial in terms of prognosis, and having an active sex life seems to be a marker for a decreased risk of death [and] a healthy lifestyle, especially in the oldest quartile - those 70 to 80 years old. From the perspective of a doctor, if a patient asks about erectile dysfunction drugs after a heart attack and has no contraindications for PDE5 inhibitors, based on these results you can feel safe about prescribing it.&quot;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p class=&quot;Normal1&quot;&gt;As the study is observational, the researchers could not establish causality or uncover the mechanism by which ED medication may improve cardiovascular health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p class=&quot;Normal1&quot;&gt;Therefore, Andersson says, it is possible that ED drugs are a marker of an active sex life, which could be the reason why these patients went on to live a healthy, heart disease-free life.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p class=&quot;Normal1&quot;&gt;However, the authors note that PDE5 inhibitors were initially designed to treat &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.heart.org/HEARTORG/Conditions/HeartAttack/DiagnosingaHeartAttack/Angina-Chest-Pain_UCM_450308_Article.jsp#.WMFGohLyhR0&quot;&gt;angina&lt;/a&gt; - a type of chest pain that occurs when the heart does not receive enough oxygen-filled blood.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p class=&quot;Normal1&quot;&gt;Andersson and team also point out that previous research has linked PDE5 inhibitors with lower blood pressure in the heart’s left ventricle. This makes it easier for the heart to pump blood, and the authors speculate that this could explain why the ED medication is beneficial for people who have had a heart attack.&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: 13.6px;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p class=&quot;Normal1&quot;&gt;Despite this, Andersson deems the results of his research surprising, as ED is normally associated with a higher risk of heart disease in healthy men.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p class=&quot;Normal1&quot;&gt;Finally, the authors acknowledge the limitations of their study.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p class=&quot;Normal1&quot;&gt;The participants’ socioeconomic status was not accounted for and the research did not consider the impact of untreated ED - or the effect of having a healthy, active, medication-free sex life - on people who had had a heart attack.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p class=&quot;Normal1&quot;&gt;In the future, Andersson and colleagues plan to conduct a larger-scale study that includes more health records and more comprehensive data on the participants’ education, marital status, and level of income.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Men's Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-09T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-09T12:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/erectile-dysfunction-drugs
</guid>
<dc:creator>Ana Sandoiu</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-09T20:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Challenges of Starting a Family After 40</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/challenges-of-starting-a-family-after-40
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/aging/030917_olderparenting_HODA_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;
]]>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;Hoda Kotb of the “Today Show” adopted a child at age 52.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Actor George Clooney is anticipating fatherhood for the first time at age 55.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Celebrities may get the headlines, but they aren’t the only ones embracing parenthood at an older age.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/nvsr/nvsr64/nvsr64_12.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;National Vital Statistics Report&lt;/a&gt; from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), more women over age 40 are having children, with a 2 percent increase in births by women 40 to 44 during 2014. Women over 50 also had more babies in 2014 than 2013.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Illinois residents Maura Collins and her husband, Todd Beidler, were 40 and 43 when they had their first child.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We got married later in life, so starting a family in our 40s is just the way things went for us,” Collins told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Yet the couple does consider how their age could present challenges.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We both recognize that we are always going to be among the older parents at our children’s games or school events, but we’re very cognizant of staying healthy as much as we can control so we can keep up with the kids and enjoy them physically as much as possible,” said Collins. “My husband has done the math and when our youngest child graduates college, he’ll be 67. While that’s a little scary to think about since with age comes physical and health concerns, the math wasn’t going to prevent us from having children.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So was the case for California residents Matt and Jenny, who adopted their first child when they were 53 years old and their second child when they were 54.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After trying to conceive naturally and through IVF for nearly 12 years, they decided to adopt through the Los Angeles County foster care system. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Another couple we knew were going down that path. Their story inspired us,” Matt told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The couple, who didn’t want their full names revealed, fostered two children who ultimately were reunified with their biological parents. However, the next two children they fostered were placed with them permanently.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Older parents and adoption&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Adoptive parents like the Matt and Jenny are not uncommon, says Megan Lestino, vice president of public policy and education at the National Council for Adoption.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Older adults come to adoption through different routes. Sometimes they come to us through infertility and other times they have older children in the home and realize they have the time and finances to raise another child,” Lestino told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She notes that while not always the case, adoptive parents tend to be older. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Although the United States does not have a federal regulation regarding a maximum age at which a parent can adopt, Lestino says it’s up to the states to determine the age of parents for both infant and foster adoption.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Many states will require parents to be at least 18 to 21 years old and a certain amount of years older than the child they’re adopting.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Typically there’s no age limit on the other end,” Lestino says. “As long as parents are capable of parenting the child they’re being matched with, in most cases there aren’t rules around age. Adoption professionals can see that with age comes a certain level of resilience, responsibility, and experience that can be beneficial to parenting. As long as they’re physically capable of caring for the needs of a child, age is neutral.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Matt and Jenny can attest.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When they were screened by a private adoption agency, “they were more concerned with how stable we were as individuals and as a couple, what our motivations were to foster and eventually adopt. We were required to do health screenings and background checks. Point being, our age was not an issue,” said Matt. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, the couple thinks about how they’ll be in their 70s when their children are in their 20s.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I also considered, perhaps a little cynically, that our chances of being alive when our children are graduating college are at least as good or maybe better than that of bio-parents half our age who are hard drug users,” notes Matt.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When it comes to open adoption, in which the birth parents choose adoptive parents for their child, age may be more of an issue, explains Lestino.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Some birth parents may consider health and age while others may see age as experience, so it depends on their preferences. In most cases, age is a consideration birth parents are aware of, but it’s more about what comes with age than age itself,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Greg Eubanks, president and chief executive officer of the World Association for Children and Parents (WACAP), agrees with Lestino’s sentiment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, he says many adoption agencies have policies about age. For instance, WACAP requires that there is at most a 48-year difference between a child’s age and the youngest parent. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The main reason is that children from adoption have faced all kinds of losses so we want to set them up with the best family as possible. If we see a family who is well into their 50s, we do need to consider issues regarding health, ability to parent, and where the parents will be when the child is nearing the teenage years and becoming more active,” Eubanks told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He adds that older parents make ideal parents for older children.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Parents who are older tend to have more patience, they have more life experience, and are more tolerant. These are all great qualities for older children. And with older children, older parents may not have to deal with the exhaustion that comes with say, a toddler,” Eubanks said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For older parents who want to adopt from a country outside of the United States, age may or may not become a barrier.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Each country sets their own age requirements with some countries setting strict maximum age limits and others having more flexible standards.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For instance, in China, adoptive parents have to be at least 30, and married couples over 50 years of age can adopt, but the age difference between the child and younger spouse can’t be more than 50 years. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Parenting through surrogacy&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Adoption seemed far-fetched for Sparky Campanella, a 56-year-old man in California. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I considered it, but found it impossible for a single man to adopt a baby. I could find places that would allow me to adopt 2 years and up, but I wanted those two years since they are important in terms of a child’s development,” Campanella told Healthline. “Plus, the genetic tie initially wasn’t that important to me, but I found it more important as I went through the process.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After the death of his father five years ago, Campanella says the desire to become a parent became strong.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“My mom had died before that, and at some point after my dad’s death, being at the end of the line and seeing the importance of family at the end of life, something changed in me,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Campanella was married in his early 30s, but neither he nor his ex-wife seriously considered a family.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We were into our careers and we thought maybe someday, but things didn’t work out. Then we got divorced,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While Campanella dated women with children over the years, he says he often felt like a third wheel.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At 53 years old, he began looking into egg donors and surrogate mothers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When I found my egg donors profile it all crystalized. I saw someone who actually reminded me of my ex-wife in terms of looks and intelligence and background,” Campanella says.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He chose the egg donor and found a surrogate. In 2015, his son, Rhys, was born. Campanella was 54.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In terms of my age being a limitation on me being a good father, I don’t think it is. I’m good in health and have a lot of energy,” he says.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Challenges, benefits of older parents&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Campanella, Collins, Matt, and Jenny all agree that staying healthy is a concern for them, and therefore they take extra care of themselves.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They also agree that the physical demands of being an older parent can take a toll.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In fact, Susan Bartell, PhD, a New York-based psychologist and author who specializes in parenting, says many older parents she sees are tired.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s tough to take care of a baby when your body and brain aren’t quite prepared for the job,” Bartell told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Matt says he and his wife wake up most mornings sore.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I joke that despite playing football and having bad skiing accidents when I was younger, I was never as sore as I am now,” he said. “Nothing that some ibuprofen and hugs from the little ones won’t fix.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Collins admits that it would be physically easier to raise children if she were 10 years younger.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think the sleep deprivation would be easier if we were younger since we’d probably bounce back easier,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Campanella adds that parenting never ends.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This is relentless and there’s a mental and physical exhaustion to it, but there’s also an amazing experience and a privilege that I wouldn’t give up,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When it comes to how other, younger parents of their children’s peers might view them, none of the parents are concerned.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our perception is that families are becoming more and more diverse. Also, we see that starting a family in the ‘traditional’ way isn’t necessarily a guarantee of a happy, stable family. If it were, there wouldn’t be such a dire need for foster parents,” said Matt.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Collins agrees and believes she can relate to younger parents.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I can still hold a conversation with younger parents, and I do see some older parents of my generation, so it’s not a massive divide,” she said. “Today, kids are open minded to different types of families. Most importantly, they love you unconditionally, so being there for them and as present as possible is what’s most important.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Campanella sought out new friends once becoming a parent.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Making friends with single moms really helped. We are in the same situation. Especially since the only family and support I have left is my brother who lives out East,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Bartell notes that older parents like Campanella often face the challenge of finding support outside of family.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The new parents’ parents are much older, so there is likely less support from grandparents,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Being more established in their career and financially stable has allowed Campanella and Collins the opportunity to pay for support through childcare as well as the ability to work from home part-time.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Though Bartell says that’s not always the case.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“[Older parents] are more entrenched in a career and lifestyle and so it is more difficult to be as flexible in parenting as it often requires. This is stressful for new parents,” she says.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Finding balance with work, a social life, and personal time is a challenge for any parent, argues Matt.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I’d expect you would hear that from parents in their 20s,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Biggest benefit of being older&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Life experience is the greatest benefit of being an older parent, according to Campanella, Collins, and Matt. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I spent a lot of time on myself, therapists, workshops, journaling, and life experiences, so I do feel that maturity and perspective helps me parent,” Campanella said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Collins says she lived a fulfilling life during her 20s and 30s.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I have no regrets socially or professionally. I don’t look back and wish I could do more now, and I can share all those experiences with the kids,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Matt believes he and his wife are better parents today than they could have been in their younger days.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We have a lot to offer our girls in terms of life experience, values, creativity,” he said. “As I’ve gotten older, I’ve finally realized that the world doesn’t revolve around me, and that everything I do, say, or even think has some impact on the world. I think those are good things to pass on to children.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>

<item>
<title>What Would Happen If GOP Health Plan Is Approved?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/what-happens-if-gop-health-plan-approved
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/ACA/030817_gopplan_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On Mo
]]>
<![CDATA[
nday, Republican leadership in the House of Representatives moved forward with &lt;a href=&quot;http://healthaffairs.org/blog/2017/03/07/examining-the-house-republican-aca-repeal-and-replace-legislation/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;two bills&lt;/a&gt; to “repeal and replace” the Affordable Care Act (ACA).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The bills, though, are far from a full repeal, which may mean Republicans recognize that the ACA wasn’t all bad.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There are so many things about the ACA that did work well,” Kurt Mosley, vice president of strategic alliances at Merritt Hawkins, Staff Care, told Healthline. “And it’s a lot cheaper to remodel a house than it is to tear it down and rebuild it back up again.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The main effects of the legislation are on the ACA provisions for making health insurance more affordable as well as individual and employer mandates, taxes, and reforms to Medicaid. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The legislation would also defund &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/06/us/politics/planned-parenthood.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Planned Parenthood&lt;/a&gt; for a year, and cut funding for vaccine research and &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2017/3/7/14842090/republican-health-plan-public-health&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;public health&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, the bills keep in place several popular parts of the ACA, including requiring insurers to cover preexisting conditions, maternity care, and preventive services; allowing children to stay on their parents’ insurance until age 26; and prohibiting annual or lifetime coverage limits.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The bills still have to be voted on by the House and Senate. &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.democraticleader.gov/newsroom/372017-3/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Democratic opposition&lt;/a&gt; is already in place and even some &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/mar/08/healthcare-reform-trump-republican-opposition&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Republicans&lt;/a&gt; have concerns.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So the issue is far from over.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But here is a look at who could be affected by the legislation as it stands today.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Millions could lose coverage&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Since 2010 more than &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.latimes.com/politics/la-na-pol-obamacare-uninsured-rate-20170214-story.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;20 million people&lt;/a&gt; gained insurance coverage as a result of the ACA.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This resulted from subsidies to offset the cost of premiums, state health insurance exchanges offering insurance, and the individual mandate.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The last one required most people to obtain health insurance or face tax penalties. This was to help keep premiums affordable for older, sicker people.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But many young people still opted to pay the penalty and go without insurance.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The penalties just weren’t onerous enough for the individual mandate,” said Mosley. “There’s got to be a different incentive for younger people to sign up.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Republican legislation will try to entice people to keep continuous coverage by charging them a 30 percent surcharge if they let their coverage lapse and then sign up again.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The mandate requiring larger employers to provide affordable health insurance for their employees would also be &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cnbc.com/2017/03/07/small-business-groups-glad-to-see-mandates-go-in-gop-healthcare-plan.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;repealed&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Also gone are the ACA income-based subsidies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These would be replaced by tax credits ranging from $2,000 for young adults to $4,000 for older adults.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But it’s not necessarily an even swap.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The ACA offered subsidies at a higher rate than the proposed AHCA legislation, which uses a sliding scale of tax credits. This change would most impact poor, older adults,” Michael Topchik, national leader for the Chartis Center for Rural Health, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This change, say &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/07/health/risk-of-losing-health-insurance-in-republican-plan.html?&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;analysts&lt;/a&gt;, could result in millions of people losing coverage.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/08/health/american-medical-association-opposes-republican-health-plan.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;American Medical Association&lt;/a&gt; echoed concerns about the potential loss of coverage. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The group emphasized that tax credits need to “be sufficient to enable one to afford quality coverage” and tied to a person’s income to make better use of taxpayers’ money.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Coverage is important because it allows people to seek earlier treatment from primary care doctors rather than needing more expensive critical care later.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think we have to create a plan that makes coverage more affordable and expands the choice,” said Mosley, “but doesn’t drive Americans to the emergency room.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Older adults and those with low incomes impacted&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In particular, the loss of subsidies would impact people with low incomes, and Americans in their 50s and 60s, who could face higher premiums.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Republican plan would allow insurers to charge older Americans five times as much for premiums as they do their youngest customers. Under the ACA, this was capped at three times.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Before people even reach retirement age, big insurance companies could be allowed to charge them an age tax that adds up to thousands of dollars more per year,” Nancy LeaMond, AARP’s executive vice president, said in a &lt;a href=&quot;http://thehill.com/business-a-lobbying/business-a-lobbying/322861-aarp-rips-gops-harmful-healthcare-legislation&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;statement&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The lobbying group for older adults also blasted the legislation’s provisions for &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/06/upshot/gop-health-bill-would-cut-funding-for-poor-and-taxes-on-rich.html?_r=0&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;reducing federal funding for Medicaid&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;All of these changes would especially impact Americans in rural areas.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The repeal of the individual mandate may leave fewer rural patients — who represent some of the older, poorer, and sicker members of our population — without health coverage in the future,” said Topchik.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This could increase the strain on rural hospitals, which have been &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/rural-hospitals-closing&quot;&gt;closing&lt;/a&gt; at an alarming rate.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I have little doubt that this will mean fewer may be able to afford health coverage,” said Topchik, “which would ultimately increase the burden on rural providers.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Two key &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.npr.org/2017/03/07/519020153/trump-supports-gop-health-care-plan-but-it-isn-t-everything-he-wants?sc=17&amp;amp;f=1001http://www.npr.org/2017/03/07/519020153/trump-supports-gop-health-care-plan-but-it-isn-t-everything-he-wants?sc=17&amp;amp;f=1001&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;healthcare changes&lt;/a&gt; pushed by President Trump, though, are not included in the bills — reigning in rising costs of prescription medications and allowing people to purchase insurance across state lines.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Whatever the bills look like when they make it through the House and Senate, some experts are hoping that the changes are worth the effort.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If it doesn’t cut costs and it doesn’t improve healthcare coverage and make our patient population better, why change it?” said Mosley.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>

<pubdate>2017-03-08T13:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-08T13:00:00</updateddate>

<dc:creator>Shawn Radcliffe</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-08T21:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>Latest AI is Headed to Your Doctor's Office</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/artificial-intelligence-car-radiology
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/030817_radiologytech_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The same artificial intelligence that may soon drive your new car is being adapted to help drive interventional radiology care for patients.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA), have used advanced artificial intelligence, also called machine learning, to create a “chatbot” or Virtual Interventional Radiologist (VIR).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This device communicates automatically with a patient’s physicians and can quickly offer evidence-based answers to frequently asked questions. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The scientists will present their research today at the Society of Interventional Radiology’s 2017 &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.sirmeeting.org/index.cfm?&quot;&gt;annual scientific meeting&lt;/a&gt; in Washington, D.C.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This breakthrough will allow clinicians to give patients real-time information on interventional radiology procedures as well as planning the next step of their treatment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Edward W. Lee, assistant professor of radiology at UCLA’s David Geffen School of Medicine, and one of the authors of the study, said he and his colleagues theorized they could use artificial intelligence in low-cost, automated ways to improve patient care. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The fundamental technology that has made self-driving cars possible is deep learning, a type of artificial intelligence modeled after the connections in the human brain,” explained Dr. Kevin Seals, resident physician in diagnostic radiology at UCLA Health, and a study co-author, said in a Healthline interview. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Seals, who programmed the VIR, said advanced computers and the human brain have a number of similarities.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Using deep learning, computers are now essentially as good as humans at identifying particular objects, making it possible for self-driving cars to ‘see’ and appropriately navigate their environment,” he said.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This same technology can allow computers to understand complex text inputs such as medical questions from healthcare professionals,” he added. “By implementing deep learning using the IBM Watson cognitive technology and Natural Language Processing, we are able to make our ‘virtual interventional radiologist’ smart enough to understand questions from physicians and respond in a smart, useful way.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How does VIR work?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Think of it as an initial, superfast layer of information gathering that can be used prior to taking the time to contact an actual human diagnostic or interventional radiologist, Seals said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The user simply texts a question to the virtual radiologist, which in many cases provides an excellent, evidence-based response more or less&amp;nbsp;instantaneously,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He noted that if the patient doesn’t receive a helpful response, they are rapidly referred to a human radiologist.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Tools such as our chatbot are particularly important in the current clinical environment, which focuses on quality metrics and follows evidence-based clinical guidelines that are proven to help patients,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Seals said a team of academic radiologists curated the information provided in the application from the radiology literature, and it is rigorously scientific and evidence-based. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We hope that using the application will encourage cutting-edge patient management that results in improved patient care and significantly benefits our patients,” he added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It can be thought of as ‘texting’ with a virtual representation of a human radiologist that offers a significant chunk of the functionality of speaking with an actual human radiologist,” Seals said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When the non-radiologist clinician texts a question to the VIR, deep learning is used to understand that message and respond in an intelligent manner. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We get a lot of questions that are fairly readily automated,” Seals said. “Such as ‘I am worried that my patient has a blood clot in their lungs. What is the best type of imaging to perform to make the diagnosis?’ The chatbot can respond to questions like this in a supersmart, evidence-based way.”&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sample responses, he said, can include instructive images (for example, a flowchart that shows a clinical algorithm), response text messages, and subprograms within the application — such as a calculator to determine a patient’s ‘Wells’ score,’ a metric doctors use to guide clinical management.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The VIR application resembles an online customer service chat.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To create a crucial foundation of knowledge, the researchers fed the app more than 2,000 data points that simulated the common inquiries interventional radiologists receive when they meet with patients. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;VIR becomes smarter with each use&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;When a referring clinician asks a question, the extensive knowledge base of the app allows it to respond instantly with the best answer. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The various forms of responses can include websites, infographics, and custom programs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If the VIR determines that an answer requires a human response, the program will provide contact information for a human interventional radiologist.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The app learns as clinicians use it, and each scenario teaches the VIR to become increasingly smarter and more powerful, Seals said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The nature of chatbot communications should protect patient privacy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Confidentiality is “critically important in the world of modern technology and something we take very seriously,” Seals said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He added that the application was created and programmed by physicians with extensive HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996) training. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We are able to avoid these issues because users ask questions in a general and anonymous manner,” Seals said. “Protected health information is never needed to use the application, nor is it relevant to its function.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;All users — professional healthcare providers such as physicians and nurses — must agree to not include any specific protected patient information in their texts to the chatbot, he added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;None of the diverse functionality within the application requires specific patient information, Seals said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Improving speed and efficiency of care&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;This new technology represents the fastest and easiest way for clinicians to get the information they need in the hospital, starting with radiology and eventually expanding to other specialties such as neurosurgery and cardiology, Seals said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our technology can power any type of physician chatbot,” he explained. “Currently, there are information silos of sorts that exist between various specialists in the hospital, and there is no good tool for rapidly sharing information between these silos. It is often slow and difficult to get a busy radiologist on the phone, which inconveniences clinicians and delays patient care.”&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other clinicians at the UCLA David Geffen School of Medicine are testing the chatbot, and Seals and Lee say their technology is fully functional now.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We are refining it and perfecting it so it can thrive in a wide release,” Seals said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Seals’ engineering and software background allowed him to perform the necessary programming for the as-yet unfunded research project. He said he and his colleagues will seek funding as they expand.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This breakthrough technology will debut soon.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The VIR will be made available in about one month to all clinicians at the UCLA Ronald Reagan Medical Center. Further use at UCLA will help the team to refine the chatbot for wider release.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The VIR could also become a free app.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We are exploring potential models for releasing the application,” Seals said. “It may very well be a free tool we release to assist our clinician colleagues, as we are academic radiologists focused on sharing knowledge and improving clinical medicine. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers described the importance of the VIR in a summary of their findings: “Improved artificial intelligence through deep learning has the potential to fundamentally transform our society, from automated image analysis to the creation of self-driving cars.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Technology</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-08T11:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-08T11:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/artificial-intelligence-car-radiology
</guid>
<dc:creator>Patrick Keeffe</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-08T19:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>HRT Lowers Risk of Death for Women, Protects Heart</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/hrt-lowers-risk-of-death-protects-heart
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/womens-health/030817_hormonetherapy_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&
]]>
<![CDATA[
gt;&lt;p&gt;During menopause, women can experience a range of symptoms including hot flashes, night sweats, fatigue, and vaginal dryness.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hormone replacement therapy (HRT), also referred to as estrogen replacement therapy, is widely used to counter these side effects.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Because HRT is so commonly used, it has received a great deal of attention from researchers. Benefits have been weighed against concerns and scientific &lt;a href=&quot;http://annals.org/aim/article/1169676/menopausal-hormone-therapy-primary-prevention-chronic-conditions-systematic-review-update&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;opinion has shifted&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On the positive side, HRT has been found to lower the risk of osteoporosis and improve certain measures of heart health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Conversely, other studies have demonstrated a link between HRT and an increased risk of cancer and stroke.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Concerns surrounding these risks have created a sharp decline in the number of women using HRT over the past 15 years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Reopening the HRT debate&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;A new study, being presented on March 17 at the American College of Cardiology’s &lt;a href=&quot;https://accscientificsession.acc.org/Registration-and-Hotels?_ga=1.76225813.1695365780.1488999184&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;66th Annual Scientific Session &amp;amp; Expo&lt;/a&gt; in Washington, D.C., might nudge public opinion back the other way.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study is titled “Hormone replacement therapy is associated with less coronary atherosclerosis and lower mortality” and it’s guaranteed to spark discussion.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers looked retrospectively at the data of more than 4,200 women who received a coronary calcium scan at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles between 1998 and 2012. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A coronary calcium scan measures calcium buildup in coronary arteries. Higher calcium levels are a marker for plaque buildup and, consequently, signal an increased risk of heart attack or stroke.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Of the participants included, 41 percent were using HRT at the time of their scan.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;HRT use was at its highest between 1998 and 2002 and slowly declined across the study period, dropping from 60 percent in 1998 to 23 percent in 2012.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Around 6 percent of the women died during the study follow-up, which spanned an average of eight years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;During the analysis, the data were adjusted for coronary calcium score, age, and a range of cardiovascular risk factors, such as diabetes, high cholesterol, and high blood pressure.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Because those in the HRT group were older than those in the non-HRT group (64 versus 60, respectively), the researchers also adjusted for this discrepancy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Once all variables were accounted for, the team found that women using HRT were 30 percent less likely to die than those not taking the medication.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Similarly, women on HRT were 20 percent more likely to have a zero score on the coronary calcium scan - the lowest possible score, indicating minimal heart attack risk.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They were also 36 percent less likely to have a coronary calcium score above 399 - a score linked with severe atherosclerosis and high heart attack risk.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers’ conclusions are clear, but they also call for caution. Dr. Yoav Arnson, a visiting postdoctoral scientist at Cedars-Sinai and lead study author, says:&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Hormone replacement therapy resulted in lower atherosclerosis and improved survival for all age groups and for all levels of coronary calcium. From this, we do think it is beneficial, but we would need prospective or randomized studies to determine which groups might not benefit or even be harmed by this therapy.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The protective abilities of HRT&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;This large-scale study provides evidence that HRT exerts a protective effect on cardiovascular health, but how might this work?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Estrogen’s positive influence on heart health involves at least two pathways.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;First, estrogen &lt;a href=&quot;http://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/articles/estrogen-hormones-heart-health&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;reduces levels&lt;/a&gt;&lt;strong&gt; &lt;/strong&gt;of low-density lipoprotein, or “bad,” cholesterol, and increases high-density lipoprotein, or “good,” cholesterol. Secondly, estrogen increases flexibility in blood vessels and arteries, helping them to cope with changes in flow.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Before menopause, women have high levels of estrogen in their systems and, typically, have levels of cardiovascular health equivalent to that of men 10-20 years younger than them.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, after menopause, estrogen levels plummet and heart disease risk increases as a result.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;HRT replaces this lost estrogen, reinstating its protective abilities.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Although the current study is large and has a longer-than-average follow-up time, it does not reveal the specific groups of women that might benefit from the treatment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It also doesn’t add to the understanding of other risks associated with HRT, such as cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Though the current findings come down heavily in favor of HRT, a decision to begin treatment will still be a complex choice for an individual and their doctor to make. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-03-08T11:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-08T11:00:00</updateddate>

<dc:creator>Tim Newman</dc:creator>
