<item>
<title>A Universal Cancer Vaccine is Highly Unlikely</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/cancer-vaccine-unlikely-but-do-we-need-one
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/030817_cancervaccine_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;There’s a simple reason a universal cancer vaccine will probably never be developed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are too many types of cancers and they are quite different from each other.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;New research published in the journal &lt;a href=&quot;https://genomemedicine.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s13073-017-0408-2&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Genome Medicine&lt;/a&gt; provides insights into the challenges of developing such a comprehensive cancer vaccine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“A broad or semi-universal vaccine capable of targeting many different tumors would be seen by some as the ‘Holy Grail’ of cancer therapy, as it wouldn't involve the time or cost of individualizing treatment,” Dr. Ryan Hartmaier, lead author from &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.foundationmedicine.com&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Foundation Medicine&lt;/a&gt;, said in a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2017/02/170223202031.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;press release&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A successful cancer vaccine must recognize the biological molecule in a tumor that is foreign. Then it must turn the immune system against it. To do that, you have to identify the specific target.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The research team performed a comprehensive genetic analysis of more than 60,000 unique tumors. They were searching for sets of genetic alterations that could be targeted to develop a semi-universal cancer vaccine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Their findings show how unlikely that is. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Where the research stands&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This research reveals how powerful the molecular analysis of tumors has become,” Dr. Mark Faries told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Faries is a surgical oncologist. He’s also director of the Donald L. Morton, MD, Melanoma Research Program, and director of Therapeutic Immunology at the John Wayne Cancer Institute at &lt;a href=&quot;http://california.providence.org/saint-johns/find-a-doctor/f/faries-mark-b/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Providence Saint John's Health Center&lt;/a&gt; in California.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said vaccine development alternates between enthusiasm and disappointment. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hopes were high early on. Then researchers realized the complexity of the relationship between cancer and the immune system.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Now we have a much better understanding of how the immune system works and its interaction with cancers. There’s a lot of excitement again. Particularly with the development of immune-modulating therapies for cancers that work with the immune system,” said Faries.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“These drugs amplify the immune response. The goal of a vaccine is to create one of those responses,” he added. “There is reason to think a combination of new drugs and vaccines will be particularly effective. But they won’t work for all.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Faries, who has long been involved in cancer vaccine development trials, expressed doubt about the feasibility of a broad cancer vaccine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The new research shows that there’s too much variability from patient to patient and tumor to tumor to devise something that would work for everyone,” he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I’m not sure [a universal cancer vaccine] has ever been anyone’s realistic goal … We can’t even do that with the flu vaccine. I don’t think there will be a single vaccine or pill to treat all cancers. But that’s not a requirement for cancer treatment. We target therapies and vaccines for specific disease,” said Faries.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Don J. Diamond, PhD, told Healthline, “In actuality, this is a refinement of studies that have been published in numerous journals.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Diamond is chair and professor at the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cityofhope.org/research/beckman-research-institute/research-departments-and-divisions/experimental-therapeutics&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Department of Experimental Therapeutics&lt;/a&gt; at City of Hope in California. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Certainly, a wide variety of mutations can contribute to the development of cancer. Because those mutations are unique, the development of a generalized cancer vaccine to cover all those driver mutations is hard to envision with today’s technology,” Diamond said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Diamond added there are a few genes, such as TP53, that are associated with a lot of cancers. But there’s another problem in coming up with a vaccine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“What caused the mutation in the first place may have nothing do with the cancer itself, or the driving force for metastasis. At the time of therapy, the early event may no longer be responsible,” he explained.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Vaccines to treat certain types of cancer &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;A broad approach aside, vaccines can be used to treat specific types of cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Doctors are already treating some cancers with immune checkpoint modulators. By directing the immune system toward a specific target, a vaccine may prevent recurrence. It may also enhance the effects of other immunotherapies, according to Faries.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The HER2/neu, the mutant protein most commonly found in breast cancer, led to drugs like &lt;a href=&quot;/drugs/trastuzumab/injectable-solution&quot;&gt;trastuzumab&lt;/a&gt;,” said Faries.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Efforts are underway to develop vaccines against that same protein. Not only in breast cancer, but in gastric and other cancers as well. Possibly across a broader spectrum of cancers that express that particular abnormality.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Faries cautioned that some of the more advanced vaccine approaches would probably be too expensive to think about in a wide population.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Vaccines to prevent specific cancers&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Diamond said there are obstacles to preventive vaccines for specific cancers. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s very hard to predict what type of cancer someone would get, or when they would develop it. You’d have to balance the present with the future, and reward with unknown risks,” he said. “Will the side effect of trying to prevent one cancer be the acceleration of another? We don’t know enough to make those decisions ethically or morally.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Eliminating viral-based cancers is a much safer strategy, said Diamond. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Faries agrees. “The most successful preventive vaccines are generally those that protect from causative agents,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;An example of this is the hepatitis B vaccine. It helps prevent liver cancer caused by hepatitis. Another example is the HPV vaccine. It helps prevent HPV-related cancers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Where we go from here&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Study results like these can be disappointing.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That doesn’t mean cancer researchers will stop trying.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There’s a survival benefit to understanding cancer,” said Sandra Brown, MS, LCGC, cancer genetics program manager at the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sjo.org/Our-Services/The-Center-for-Cancer-Prevention-and-Treatment.aspx&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Center for Cancer Prevention and Treatment&lt;/a&gt; at St. Joseph Hospital in California.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Cancer is basically evolution on steroids,” she wrote in an email to Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We consciously create a healthy environment, although aging alone can lead to the accumulation of mutations necessary for tumorigenesis. Then we treat to create a hostile environment while the cancer may evolve multiple clonal pathways in an attempt to reproduce successfully within that environment.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She continued, “Perhaps often we win and the tumor dies. But there is always the possibility that lethally resistant random mutations will occur anytime in tumorigenesis, particularly during treatment. Genetically modified humans may someday be immune to tumorigenesis, or attenuated viruses may someday perfectly recognize tumor cells for targeted destruction.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Preventing cancer now&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Broad therapeutic or preventive cancer vaccines won’t happen anytime soon.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This makes other methods of cancer prevention that much more important. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The first step, according to Faries, is understanding the cause. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;We already know what causes some cancers. But prevention is still a problem, he explained. That’s because you have to apply this knowledge to a wide population who might not be intent on following through.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Smoking is a classic example. You can tell people until you’re blue in the face that smoking kills. But they continue to smoke,” said Faries.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;His suggestion is that people should consider their family history and other risk factors. If you’re more likely to get a certain type of cancer, learn the prevention measures. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Diamond has a few words of advice for anyone trying to lower their cancer risk.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Protect yourself from the sun, don’t smoke, manage your weight, and don’t eat charcoaled foods.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<dc:creator>Ann Pietrangelo</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-08T18:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>When Food Disrupts Family Harmony</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/when-food-disrupts-family-harmony
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/030917_ahafamily_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Arias family gatherings are about food.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The tamales, roast pork, rice, beans and other foods served at birthday celebrations, Mother’s Day and weddings are the dishes Javier Arias and his seven siblings grew up eating in rural northern Mexico.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Decades after moving to the United States, the 58-year-old construction project manager and his brothers continued their paternal grandfather’s tradition of killing the pigs and cows they barbecue.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“That’s what unites families,” said Javier. “Eating.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Javier and his siblings are a tight-knit bunch. Starting in the 1970s, they followed each other to northern Texas from their hometown of General Teran. But over the past nine years, food has been a source of conflict.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Back then, Aurelio Arias, the youngest of the clan, announced he was becoming a vegan, meaning he’d no longer eat meat or dairy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;His wife Lily and their eldest son, Aurelio Arias Jr., became vegan about three years later.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Aurelio’s sister Andrea Alaniz and their mother became vegetarian.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Javier stopped drinking soda and started eating mostly fruits, beans and vegetables.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It was about getting healthier and living longer for their families, they said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Family gatherings not the same&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;But their new food choices have come at the expense of family harmony.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Holidays and weekend barbecues have never been the same.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Relatives who still eat meat feel rejected when the siblings and their mother don’t eat the food they serve.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Aurelio and Lily often offend relatives when they bring vegan dishes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Aurelio and Javier have been left out of weddings and quinceaneras, the coming-of-age celebration when girls turn 15. Sometimes, they’ve chosen not to go.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Older brother Concepcion Arias said the separation hurts.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I’ve grumbled about it because they can’t share in the experience [with everyone else],” said the 61-year-old father of five.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Why food matters&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Arias’ conflict doesn’t surprise two longtime food and culture historians who say the foods we eat are more than nourishment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They are loaded with meaning about love of family, friends, classes and heritage, the academics said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“People do believe we pass along culture through food,” said Alice P. Julier, Ph.D., the director of the food studies program at Chatham University’s Falk School of Sustainability and the Environment. “Language often goes away. But food is something that people supposedly can maintain and celebrate.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And eating the same foods together is one way people strengthen their heritage and relationships with relatives, said Amy Bentley, Ph.D., a professor of food studies at New York University’s Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human Development. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Changing what we eat — even if it’s for health reasons — could be interpreted as making a break from family unity, she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Food ways, I think, is almost as prominent as religion in terms of how people create ethnic and religious identity,” said Bentley, whose research has focused on food and American culture and society for more than two decades.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Among the mostly Hispanic and Latino patients she sees at a San Antonio clinic, dietitian Dahlia Gomez has noticed a pattern among families of patients who change what they eat.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If the person has health problems, relatives give unconditional support, said Gomez. But, she said, if a family member makes a personal choice to stop eating foods the family has eaten for generations, they’re less accepting.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Health concerns drive changes in diet&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Aurelio was the first to change his diet, which had been heavy on beef and low on fruits and vegetables.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The 48-year-old restaurant owner quit eating meat and dairy after he was rushed to a hospital with chest pains. His blood pressure was dangerously high and he had to be hospitalized. He missed his father’s funeral as doctors monitored his heart.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Aurelio was no stranger to heart problems. His father had survived a heart attack, and his paternal grandfather’s stroke was linked to high blood pressure.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I love my family and I didn’t want to die,” Aurelio said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Back then, Javier also had health problems: high blood pressure, high cholesterol and diabetes. After seeing his younger brother’s health improve, Javier changed his eating habits.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Today, the brothers have each lost more than 60 pounds and their blood pressure and cholesterol are back to normal. Javier also no longer needs medication to control his diabetes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Their sister Andrea changed the way she ate after medical exams showed she had a fatty liver.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;“I was addicted to steaks,” said the 63-year-old mother of five. “That was one of my favorite vices.&quot;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Andrea has encouraged her meat-eating siblings to try the tacos and enchiladas Aurelio and Lily offer at their vegan Mexican restaurant. Some have come around.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But Concepcion still doesn’t support his family members’ meatless diet, despite having his own dietary restrictions to help manage his diabetes, high blood pressure and high cholesterol.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The construction company owner gets sentimental when he talks about the family’s festive gatherings back when everyone ate the childhood dishes they loved.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When people share in the same experience, it’s more fun, you have a more enjoyable time,” Concepcion said. “Life feels easier.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/food-family-and-the-health-scare-that-changed-it-all/&quot;&gt;original story&lt;/a&gt; was published on &lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/ &quot;&gt;American Heart Association News&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Food and Nutrition</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-08T00:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-08T00:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/when-food-disrupts-family-harmony
</guid>
<dc:creator>American Heart Association News</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-08T08:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
How Poor Diet Raises Your Risk of Dying from Heart Disease
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/how-poor-diet-raises-your-risk-of-dying-from-heart-disease
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/heart-health/030717_dietheart_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After years of public health messages promoting healthy eating, most people now know that a poor diet can increase their risk of heart disease, stroke, and type 2 diabetes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But how much of an effect does diet have on your risk of dying from one of these diseases?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A lot — a new study suggests.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We combed through studies and data to look at the cumulative effects of poor diet on what we call cardiometabolic diseases — heart disease, stroke, and diabetes — and determined that nearly half of all deaths are linked to poor diet,” Renata Micha, RD, PhD, study author, and research assistant professor at the Friedman School of Nutrition Science and Policy at Tufts University, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, another group of researchers says that fewer overweight and obese people are trying to lose weight, another factor leading to increased risk for heart disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Effect of 10 dietary factors&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers in the diet study used risk assessment models and national data on dietary habits to determine how many of the more than 700,000 deaths in 2012 from heart disease, stroke, or type 2 diabetes were due to poor diet.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They estimated that 45 percent of the deaths were associated with 10 dietary factors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Top on the list was excess intake of sodium, which researchers estimated accounted for almost 10 percent of the deaths.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But it’s not just about eating too many foods that are bad for our health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Americans are overconsuming salt, processed meats, and sugary-sweetened beverages,” said Micha. “We are underconsuming fruits, vegetables, nuts and seeds, whole grains, vegetable oils, or fish.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Vegetable oils like those found in soybeans, sunflower seeds, and walnuts are high in &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.heart.org/HEARTORG/HealthyLiving/HealthyEating/Nutrition/Polyunsaturated-Fats_UCM_301461_Article.jsp#.WL6uEhLyt68&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;polyunsaturated fats&lt;/a&gt;, which are known to reduce harmful cholesterol levels. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.heart.org/HEARTORG/HealthyLiving/HealthyEating/HealthyDietGoals/Fish-and-Omega-3-Fatty-Acids_UCM_303248_Article.jsp#.WL7dPxLyt68&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Fatty fish&lt;/a&gt; like salmon, mackerel, herring, and sardines are high in heart-healthy omega-3 fatty acids. Non-fish sources of omega-3s are also available — like flaxseeds, chia seeds, and microalgae — but were not looked at in this study.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the study, diet accounted for a greater fraction of deaths among African-Americans and Hispanics compared with whites, as well as among adults with low levels of education compared to those with high levels of education.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers also estimated a stronger effect of diet on risk of death in men, which they write is “primarily because of generally unhealthier dietary habits.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s a wake-up call and another opportunity,” said Micha. “We need to be reminded of this simple truth: eating healthy can and will prevent people from dying prematurely from heart disease, stroke, and diabetes.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/10.1001/jama.2017.0947&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; was published Mar. 7 in the Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Positive dietary changes&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a related &lt;a href=&quot;http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2608201&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;commentary&lt;/a&gt; in JAMA, Noel Mueller, PhD, MPH, and Dr. Lawrence Appel, MPH, caution that the results of the study are from observational research rather than stronger long-term randomized trials, which are difficult to do in nutritional research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So there is potential that other factors not included in the study may influence the risk of dying. This could include non-dietary factors like income and physical activity levels, or a person’s overall dietary pattern.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It is possible that processed meat consumption merely reflects a Westernized dietary pattern,” write Mueller and Appel.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They also question whether these 10 dietary factors are the best ones to monitor. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Saturated fat didn’t make the study’s list, but “randomized trials conducted decades ago demonstrated that replacement of saturated fat with polyunsaturated vegetable oil reduced cardiovascular disease events by 18 percent to 41 percent,” write Mueller and Appel.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.heart.org/HEARTORG/HealthyLiving/HealthyEating/Nutrition/Saturated-Fats_UCM_301110_Article.jsp#.WL7l2BIrJ68&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Saturated fats&lt;/a&gt; come mainly from meat and dairy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In spite of those concerns, Mueller and Appel write that the “likely benefits [of an improved diet] are substantial and justify policies designed to improve diet quality.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The new study identified a reduction in sodium intake as a prime target for public health policy, something that is already under way.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has recently announced voluntary sodium reduction targets for the food industry,” said Micha. “This is quite timely and we need to engage industry to gradually reduce salt content in processed foods.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She also points to &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/the-skinny-on-soda-taxes-010216&quot;&gt;taxes on sugary beverages&lt;/a&gt; passed by U.S. municipalities in recent years as a sign of progress.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, she highlighted promising initiatives like programs in the workplace and schools to promote healthier eating, and improvements in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program for people in the United States with low or no income.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But even without the government’s help, people can take charge of their own health — even if it is one small change at a time.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Eat more of the good and less of the bad,” said Micha. “Start by making one healthier choice each day and build on it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Fewer trying to lose weight&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another risk factor for heart disease, stroke, and type 2 diabetes not addressed by the new study is being overweight or obese.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/fastats/obesity-overweight.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)&lt;/a&gt;, more than two-thirds of American adults are overweight or obese. And one-fifth of adolescents are obese.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But as overweight and obesity have increased in the United States, fewer people are trying to lose weight, report the authors of a &lt;a href=&quot;http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/10.1001/jama.2016.20036&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;research letter&lt;/a&gt; published in the same issue of JAMA.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers used the responses of more than 27,000 adults from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) to determine shifts in weight loss over the past few decades.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Overweight and obesity among adults increased during that time — from 53 percent during the period from 1988 to 1994, to 66 percent during the period from 2009 to 2014.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;During the same period, the percentage of overweight or obese adults trying to lose weight declined — from 56 percent in 1988 to 1994 to 49 percent in 2009 to 2014.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Study author Dr. Jian Zhang, DrPH, an epidemiologist at Georgia Southern University, and colleagues, write that this “may be due to body weight misperception reducing motivation to engage in weight loss efforts or primary care clinicians not discussing weight issues with patients.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Heart Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-07T14:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-07T14:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/how-poor-diet-raises-your-risk-of-dying-from-heart-disease
</guid>
<dc:creator>Shawn Radcliffe</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-07T22:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>The Debate Over Vaccine Safety Is Far from Over</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/debate-over-vaccine-safety
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/Vaccination/022817_vaccineautism_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;
]]>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;If you think the debate over the safety of childhood vaccines is going to go away soon, think again.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If anything, it’s likely to get more heated.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After all, this is an issue that centers on the health and safety of children.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Those who are dubious of vaccines think children are being harmed to the extent that some of them develop autism.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Those who champion vaccines feel the antivaccination movement is putting public health at risk by lowering herd immunity and sending unvaccinated kids into schools and other community spaces.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The issues involved may not be as simple as one might think, and the reasons they get such public traction are varied.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Those who question the safety of vaccines blame greedy pharmaceutical companies, corrupt government officials, and biased scientific studies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Those who are adamant that vaccines are safe blame an out-of-control social media scene, nonexpert celebrities, and a growing antiscience mood.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This heated battle is starting to boil as a new, more conservative administration settles in at the White House — one that some feel &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/anti-vaccination-may-get-boost-in-trump-administration&quot;&gt;may encourage&lt;/a&gt; vaccine opponents.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s sad and scary. I’m worried about the direction we are going,” Cynthia Leifer, PhD, an associate professor of immunology at Cornell University, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How the vaccine safety issue grew&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The antivaccination movement got its first big booster shot in 1998 when Dr. Andrew Wakefield and 12 colleagues published research in The Lancet journal.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Wakefield said his case studies had shown the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine could be linked to a rise in autism cases in children.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3136032/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;number of faults&lt;/a&gt; were eventually uncovered in Wakefield’s research. Among them was the small sample size of 12 people as well as his ties to private companies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Lancet &lt;a href=&quot;https://sciencebasedmedicine.org/lancet-retracts-wakefield-article/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;retracted&lt;/a&gt; the study in 2010. That same year, the General Medical Council in the United Kingdom &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/25/health/policy/25autism.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;banned Wakefield&lt;/a&gt; from practicing medicine, citing a number of ethical lapses.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The antivaccination movement did get another boost from a more reputable source.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It came in the form of Dr. Bernadine Healy, a former director of the National Institutes of Health (NIH), professor of medicine at Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, and dean of Ohio State University Medical School.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=De7DCpcyQfY&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2008 interview&lt;/a&gt; with CBS News, Healy said government officials and scientists had been too quick to dismiss the concerns of families whose children became ill after receiving vaccinations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Healy &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/09/us/09healy.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;died in 2011&lt;/a&gt; of brain cancer, but her words are &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.thevaccinereaction.org/2016/11/bernadine-healy-the-question-of-a-link-between-vaccines-and-autism-is-unanswered/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;still quoted&lt;/a&gt; by a number of antivaccination groups.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some celebrities then attached themselves to the cause.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One of the first was &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.generationrescue.org/home/about/jenny-mccarthy/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Jenny McCarthy&lt;/a&gt;, the former Playboy Playmate, whose son was diagnosed with autism in 2005.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;McCarthy went public with concerns about childhood vaccines and eventually formed &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.generationrescue.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Generation Rescue&lt;/a&gt;, whose primary mission is to help families with autistic children.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There’s also &lt;a href=&quot;https://worldmercuryproject.org/mercury-vaccines-cdcs-worst-nightmare/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Robert F. Kennedy Jr.&lt;/a&gt;, the son of Sen. Bobby Kennedy who was assassinated in 1968 while running for president.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In an &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.healthline.com/health-news/kennedy-q-a-about-vaccine-safety&quot;&gt;in-depth half-hour interview&lt;/a&gt; with Healthline, Kennedy said he got involved in the issue while representing people who said they had been stricken with mercury poisoning by coal-fired power plants.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kennedy formed the &lt;a href=&quot;https://worldmercuryproject.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;World Mercury Project&lt;/a&gt;, whose primary goal is to raise awareness about the serious dangers of mercury.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When it comes to vaccines, the organization’s focus is on &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.fda.gov/downloads/BiologicsBloo%20dVaccines/SafetyAvailability/VaccineSafety%20/UCM298182.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;thimerosal&lt;/a&gt;, a mercury-based preservative that was taken out of childhood vaccines in 2003, but is still used in flu vaccines that are given to children and pregnant women.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Last month, Kennedy and actor Robert De Niro, whose son has autism spectrum disorder, held a press conference in which they announced they’d offer &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/de-niro-kennedy-offer-100g-proof-vaccines-safe-article-1.2973956&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;$100,000&lt;/a&gt; to anyone who can present them with a peer-reviewed study that proves thimerosal is safe.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Critics called the offer a publicity stunt, but the news conference received plenty of attention.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Vaccine supporters say the attention given to vaccine opponents is indicative of a new world of social media where a former Playboy model can become a leading expert on autism and vaccines.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Social media allows individuals with a high profile to keep rehashing the issue,” said Leifer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There’s also the internet in general.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Anybody can toss up a website, so for every &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.healthychildren.org/English/safety-prevention/immunizations/Pages/Vaccine-Studies-Examine-the-Evidence.aspx&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;page&lt;/a&gt; on healthchildren.org declaring that vaccines are safe there is a &lt;a href=&quot;http://ahrp.org/former-merck-scientists-sue-merck-alleging-mmr-vaccine-efficacy-fraud/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;page&lt;/a&gt; that details the lawsuit filed by former Merck scientists stating that the company intentionally skewed results from their MMR vaccine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition to the antiscience mood, there is also a growing disdain for pharmaceutical companies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s been fueled partly by stories of pharmaceutical firms charging what many in the public see as outrageous prices for products.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These high-profile stories include Mylan’s &lt;a href=&quot;http://fortune.com/2016/09/21/mylan-ceo-epipen-price-hike/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;price hike&lt;/a&gt; of its EpiPen for serious food allergy reactions, to the sudden &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.forbes.com/sites/dandiamond/2015/12/03/what-martin-shkreli-says-now-i-shouldve-raised-prices-higher/#6d47f41e1362&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;5,000 percent price increase&lt;/a&gt; for the lifesaving drug Daraprim by Turing Pharmaceuticals.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On its site, the World Mercury Project says the pharmaceutical industry is a trillion dollar industry with vaccines bringing in &lt;a href=&quot;https://worldmercuryproject.org/mercury-in-vaccines/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;$25 billion&lt;/a&gt; in annual sales.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They say the “insatiable pharmaceutical industry” has 271 new vaccines under development at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in the hope of raising annual vaccine sales to $100 billion.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With this kind of money and the health of children at stake, it’s probably no mystery why the arguments on both sides of the vaccine safety issue can get heated. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A look at the studies&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Vaccine proponents cite study after study for their support of inoculations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Among them are a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nationalacademies.org/hmd/~/media/Files/Report%20Files/2013/Childhood-Immunization-Schedule/ChildhoodImmunizationScheduleandSafety_RB.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2013 analysis&lt;/a&gt; by The National Academy of Sciences, a &lt;a href=&quot;http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/125/6/1134?sso=1&amp;amp;sso_redirect_count=1&amp;amp;nfstatus=401&amp;amp;nftoken=00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000&amp;amp;nfstatusdescription=ERROR%3a+No+local+token&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2010 study&lt;/a&gt; published in the journal Pediatrics, a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed?cmd=Search&amp;amp;doptcmdl=Citation&amp;amp;defaultField=Title+Word&amp;amp;term=Uchiyama%5Bauthor%5D+AND+MMR-vaccine+and+regression+in+autism+spectrum+disorders%3A+negative+results+presented+from+Japan&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2007 review&lt;/a&gt; of data on 900 children in Japan, and a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed?cmd=Search&amp;amp;doptcmdl=Citation&amp;amp;defaultField=Title+Word&amp;amp;term=Farrington%5Bauthor%5D+AND+MMR+and+autism%3A+further+evidence+against+a+causal+association.&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2001 study&lt;/a&gt; published in the journal Vaccine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, a special federal “vaccine court” &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/02/12/AR2009021201391.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;ruled in 2009&lt;/a&gt; that vaccines do not cause autism, and the families of autistic children are not entitled to compensation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nature.com/news/brain-scans-spot-early-signs-of-autism-in-high-risk-babies-1.21484&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study published last month&lt;/a&gt; reported that brain scans can sometimes spot signs of autism in babies with higher risk of developing the disease. Researchers say this counters the arguments that autism begins to show up in children at ages 3 and 4 after they have received vaccinations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Officials at the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/index.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;CDC&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.fda.gov/BiologicsBloodVaccines/Vaccines/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;FDA&lt;/a&gt; say studies and rulings such as these have convinced them that vaccines are safe.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Even the nonprofit organization Autism Speaks states on its &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.autismspeaks.org/what-autism/learn-more-autism/what-causes-autism&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;website&lt;/a&gt; that the “scientific evidence is clear” that vaccines do not cause autism. On their site, they have published a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.autismspeaks.org/science/science-news/no-mmr-autism-link-large-study-vaccinated-vs-unvaccinated-kids&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2015 study&lt;/a&gt; that concluded there was no link between the MMR vaccine and autism. That same year, the advocacy group issued a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2015/02/09/leading-autism-advocate-urges-vaccination/?utm_term=.5233862e139a&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;strong statement&lt;/a&gt; urging parents to have their children vaccinated.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, opponents of vaccines are still not swayed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They note that the federal court that dismissed links between vaccines and autism has also awarded numerous families compensation for brain damage caused to their children by vaccines. Those judgments include high-profile cases in &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.huffingtonpost.com/robert-f-kennedy-jr-and-david-kirby/vaccine-court-autism-deba_b_169673.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2009&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.huffingtonpost.com/david-kirby/post2468343_b_2468343.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2013&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The vaccine skeptics also list a series of allegations to back up their claims.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Many of these issues were first discussed by Healy a decade before her death and are outlined on a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.fourteenstudies.org/index.html&quot;&gt;14 Studies&lt;/a&gt; page on McCarthy’s website Generation Rescue.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The arguments, for and against&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;One of the chief assertions of vaccine opponents is what they see as a correlation between the rise in autism rates and the increase in vaccinations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They report that autism rates in the United States have risen from 1 in 10,000 children in the 1980s to 1 in 110 children. At the same time, the number of recommended vaccinations has increased from 10 to 36.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kennedy said the numbers are backed up by the stories from thousands of parents who talk about the seizures and autism symptoms their children developed after receiving vaccines.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“What are the chances they all made up the same story,” he told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Vaccine supporters, however, say two things happening at the same time doesn’t necessarily mean they’re connected.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Leifer said if you go outside after a rainstorm and worms are crawling on the ground that doesn’t mean it rained worms.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Kathryn Edwards, the chair of the pediatrics department at the Vanderbilt University School of Medicine, agrees.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Two things that happen at the same time are not necessarily related to one another,” she told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Not everything that goes together is causational,” added Leifer. “There are other things that should be considered.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Among them are environmental changes, diets, better diagnostic tools, and more awareness of diseases.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kennedy and others are also focused on mercury, a compound they say is the second deadliest toxin on Earth.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For vaccines, they’ve homed in on thimerosal, the mercury-based preservative still found in flu shots.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kennedy said his group has more than six dozen studies that establish a link between thimerosal and autism. He says there are no studies that exonerate the ingredient.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said that means our country is pumping high levels of mercury into children and pregnant women when they are given flu shots.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I don’t understand why everybody isn’t upset,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Vaccine opponents, however, say there are studies that have declared thimerosal safe, at least the amount used in vaccines.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health has printed &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.vaccinesafety.edu/cc-thim.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;a list of research&lt;/a&gt; that disputes a link between thimerosal in vaccines and autism.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The bottom line is that raising an issue about thimerosal is a purposeful attempt to sow seeds of doubt about the safety of vaccines that save the lives of children,” said Leifer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A lot of scientific research is disputed by vaccine opponents, though.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They say a lot of the studies are heavily influenced by the powerful pharmaceutical industry. They compare the situation to the tobacco companies’ involvement in &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ucdmc.ucdavis.edu/welcome/features/20071114_cardio-tobacco/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;lung cancer research&lt;/a&gt; and the sugar industry’s coercion in &lt;a&gt;tooth decay research&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The [vaccine] research has been designed and written by the industry,” Kennedy said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The opponents also say the studies on vaccines and autism have only been done on the MMR inoculations. They add there are also no studies comparing vaccinated children with unvaccinated children.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Jon Cohen, a staff writer for the journal Science, published by the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS), said vaccine skeptics are asking this question in reverse order.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“You can’t prove a negative. Flip these questions on their heads,” he told Healthline. “What evidence links vaccines to autism? What evidence links thimerosal doses used in vaccines to harm?”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Leifer and Edwards both said there has been some research done comparing vaccinated and unvaccinated children. However, those studies are difficult to set up because of the low number of children who haven’t received those vaccines.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Vaccine opponents also say there is corruption within government agencies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On the 14 Studies page, the opponents say “studies are rife with conflicts” between study authors as well as government officials and industry representatives.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kennedy said there are a “tiny handful of corrupt scientists and leaders” who are protected by the silence of many others who work with them at agencies like the CDC.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He compares it to the cover-up of priest pedophilia in the Catholic Church that was uncovered by the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/movies/spotlight-movie&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Boston Globe&lt;/a&gt; and detailed in the movie, “&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1895587/&quot;&gt;Spotlight&lt;/a&gt;.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, vaccine supporters see these accusations as nothing more than far-fetched conspiracy theories.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Vaccine safety is something we take very seriously,” said Edwards.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The impact of the debate&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Concerns over vaccines are nothing new.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cohen notes that there have been safety issues since Edward Jenner developed the smallpox vaccine, the world’s first inoculation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nor is vaccine safety confined to the United States.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2016/09/france-most-skeptical-country-about-vaccine-safety&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2016 survey&lt;/a&gt;, researchers said people in France showed the highest concern over vaccines of the 66 countries studied. In that European nation, 41 percent disagreed with the notion that vaccines are safe.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cohen said vaccines can cause harm. He noted the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1383764/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Cutter Incident&lt;/a&gt; in 1955 when a defective batch of vaccines actually caused 40,000 cases of polio in children. There was also the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2012/05/120507131953.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;STEP study&lt;/a&gt; in which some men who received a vaccine designed to protect against HIV ended up at higher risk of being infected by the virus.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Despite these cases, Cohen said, there is a reward vs. risk factor that needs to be considered. That is sometimes clouded by a relative lack of exposure to disease in modern society.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Unlike in the smallpox or polio era, parents typically have never seen the damage done by the diseases they are vaccinating against, and there’s little understanding of herd immunity — the idea that if a certain percent of a population is immune, a pathogen stops spreading,” Cohen said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Edwards agreed, saying some younger parents may not have had measles or mumps as a child.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“They’re not nice things to have,” she commented.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Leifer also asks people to look at the success rate of vaccines.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There have been no &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.who.int/csr/disease/smallpox/faq/en/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;smallpox cases&lt;/a&gt; anywhere in the world since 1978. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Polio used to cause 15,000 cases of paralysis a year in the United States before the vaccine was introduced in the 1950s. There has not been a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/polio/us/index.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;polio case&lt;/a&gt; that originated in the United States since 1979.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The rates of &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/measles/cases-outbreaks.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;measles&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/mumps/outbreaks.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;mumps&lt;/a&gt; in the United States have been significantly reduced.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I don’t think there’s any way you can argue against that,” said Leifer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Vaccine critics still see the decrease in certain diseases being offset by the rise in autism and other ailments.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, Leifer says the debate over vaccine safety is hurting efforts to win the battle against autism.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s slowing down the race to find out what exactly causes autism,” she said.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<updateddate>2017-03-07T10:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>

</guid>
<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-07T18:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>Robert F. Kennedy Jr.: Q&amp;A About Vaccine Safety</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/kennedy-q-a-about-vaccine-safety
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/Vaccination/030717_rkjr_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is the chairman of the &lt;a href=&quot;https://worldmercuryproject.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;World Mercury Project&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The nonprofit organization’s goal is to “ban all uses of mercury on a global level.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The group states that &lt;a href=&quot;https://worldmercuryproject.org/world-mercury-project-overview/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;mercury&lt;/a&gt; is the second most toxic element on Earth and can cause inflammation in brain tissue. That inflammation has been connected to autism, Alzheimer’s disease, multiple sclerosis, and other ailments.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The group says mercury is released into the air by coal-fired power plants and can be found in our food supply.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mercury is also in thimerosal, a preservative that in the past&amp;nbsp;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: 13.6px;&quot;&gt;was used in some but not all childhood vaccines. The ingredient was &lt;/span&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/vaccinesafety/concerns/thimerosal/timeline.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot; style=&quot;font-size: 13.6px;&quot;&gt;removed&lt;/a&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: 13.6px;&quot;&gt; as a safety precaution in 2003.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: 13.6px;&quot;&gt;Thimerosal is still used in flu and tetanus shots.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Officials at the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) say &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.fda.gov/downloads/BiologicsBloo%20dVaccines/SafetyAvailability/VaccineSafety%20/UCM298182.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;thimerosal is safe&lt;/a&gt; to use as a preservative in vaccines, but Kennedy and others aren’t convinced.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They point out that flu shots are given to pregnant women as well as children.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The group feels strongly enough about the issue that they held a press conference last month and offered a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/de-niro-kennedy-offer-100g-proof-vaccines-safe-article-1.2973956&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;$100,000 reward&lt;/a&gt; to anyone who can present a peer-reviewed study that proves that thimerosal is safe.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Healthline has taken a look at both sides of the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.healthline.com/health-news/debate-over-vaccine-safety&quot;&gt;vaccination debate&lt;/a&gt; in a detailed article.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As part of that research, Healthline talked with Kennedy about his concerns. Here are excerpts from that half-hour interview.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Healthline: &lt;/strong&gt;Why is this issue so important to you?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Kennedy:&lt;/strong&gt; I was litigating and managing around 30 cases against coal-fired power plants, principally focusing on mercury emissions. I had learned a lot about mercury toxicity. I was going around the country speaking on the issue and I began running into women who would tell me that if I was truly interested in mercury exposures to children that I needed to look at thimerosal in vaccines … As I began reading the science, I was struck by the huge delta between what the actual science said and how it was being presented by the press and the public health regulators … It made me angry that they were continuing the practice of injecting children with neurotoxins.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Healthline:&lt;/strong&gt; It seems that there is an element in here of fighting against big business. It seems that you could compare this to what the sugar and the tobacco industry did with science.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Kennedy: &lt;/strong&gt;Sugar, tobacco, the carbon industry. They all did this.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Healthline:&lt;/strong&gt; Do you see a similarity here?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Kennedy:&lt;/strong&gt; It’s very similar. This is really almost identical to the global warming debate because you have all the independent science … saying there is an effect. In other words, that carbon is warming the globe and with neurodevelopment disorders [that] mercury in vaccines are causing [them]. Then you have a small [amount] of industry-created science … that purportedly exonerates thimerosal and is really designed and written by industry scientists … and it appears on the CDC’s website. But the science is weak and fraudulent … We brought to our press conference 321 studies … 240 studies on neurological effects other than autism and 81 studies indicating a link to autism. We could not find a single study that says thimerosal was safe … What the CDC tells you is not science. What The New York Times reports is not science. And what your doctor tells you is not science … If you look at [studies] done by research scientists you will find a mountain of studies that support my position and very, very few studies that dispute me.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Healthline:&lt;/strong&gt; What about vaccines in general? Would you agree that the vast majority of science says vaccines in general are safe?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Kennedy:&lt;/strong&gt; It’s not my expertise. I don’t think there is any study you can do that would say that particular thing. I think you’d have to look vaccine by vaccine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Healthline:&lt;/strong&gt; It seems your main concern is the flu shot, which is given to children and pregnant woman. Is that your focus?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Kennedy:&lt;/strong&gt; It’s being given to children at 6 months and it’s being given to pregnant women. So, today the exposure a child suffers is probably the greatest in history. If you give a flu shot to a woman who is one or two months pregnant, that child could be getting thousands of times of exposure levels to mercury.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Healthline: &lt;/strong&gt;You’re talking about a pretty big cover-up or conspiracy here. Do you really think those agencies are in cahoots? That there’s all this corruption within the industry? Because that’s what it would take to pull this off?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Kennedy:&lt;/strong&gt; The CDC has systemically [within its vaccine branch] ordered its scientists to destroy data, to manipulate data, to massage it, to dump it in garbage cans [if it uncovers] links between development diseases and vaccines. Do I think everyone at the CDC is corrupt? Of course not. There is a tiny handful of corrupt scientists and leaders … The rest of the public health community is not part of any conspiracy, but it has [become part of] the orthodoxy. It’s the same as the pedophile scandal in the Catholic Church … There was a tiny handful of corrupt priests, but the entire church — the bishops, the cardinals, the Vatican, and the other priests — and the prosecutors and the press and the police … told themselves it was more important to protect the institution even though it was injuring the children it was supposed to be protecting. The scandal and silence went on for years before it was exposed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Healthline:&lt;/strong&gt; Why would this handful [of CDC employees] do this?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Kennedy: &lt;/strong&gt;[When information on thimerosal reached CDC officials]&lt;strong&gt; &lt;/strong&gt;they said that if we come clean about this, not only are we going to get sued, but the vaccine companies are going to get sued, and they won’t be able to make any vaccines. I think there was a worry ... that if they told the truth, that the American people would lose faith and the institution would be so badly injured that maybe it would create even bigger problems with public health … It’s not completely selfish … There was a genuine concern that this could destroy the whole program and they had to clean it up.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Healthline: &lt;/strong&gt;Are you worried at all that some of the antivaccination campaigns … could do just that? That they could harm the overall vaccine industry and cause harm to public health?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Kennedy:&lt;/strong&gt; I don’t see how they can do that because Congress has now passed a law that makes it virtually impossible to sue a vaccine company.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Healthline:&lt;/strong&gt; Taking this a little broader, do you worry at all that some of the vaccine safety concerns from people might feed into the antiscience mood that seems to be building in the country and that includes climate change?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Kennedy:&lt;/strong&gt; I’m trying to fight that trend and get people to pay attention to real science. There’s so much scientific illiteracy, especially in the press. The press doesn’t read science … They just parrot what the CDC tells them. Is there any other arena where the press thinks it’s OK to just parrot what a government official tells them?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Healthline:&lt;/strong&gt; There’s something folks on the other side have said … They think a lot of this is fueled by parents who understandably just want an answer, just something to blame, for their kids’ autism. What would be your response to that?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Kennedy:&lt;/strong&gt; They are dismissing the stories of tens of thousands that saw the same thing happen to their children … What are the chances they all made up the same story? ... If this is not caused by mercury, then find out what it is and get rid of it.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>

<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
