<item>
<title>Why are Drug Prices for Rare Diseases on the Rise?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/critics-orphan-drug-law-ripe-for-abuse
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/030617_orphandrugs_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For years Americans with Duchenne muscular dystrophy were able to import a drug, deflazacort, from outside the United States at a cost of about $1,200 per year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This price, though, could skyrocket to a list price of $89,000 a year now that a U.S. pharmaceutical company has received approval for the drug as a treatment for the rare, fatal disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In an interview with the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2017/02/10/an-old-drug-gets-a-new-price-to-fight-a-rare-disease-89000-a-year/?utm_term=.968d4aabea79&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Washington Post&lt;/a&gt;, the chief executive officer of Marathon Pharmaceuticals said the net price will be $54,000 after rebates and discounts.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Last month, the company received approval from the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for deflazacort as an “orphan drug.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This special designation comes under the Orphan Drug Act, which was intended to encourage companies to develop drugs to treat rare diseases, those affecting 200,000 or fewer Americans.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/diseases/pages/31/faqs-about-rare-diseases&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;National Institutes of Health (NIH)&lt;/a&gt;, there are around 7,000 rare diseases, which affect a total of 25 to 30 million Americans.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In exchange for investing in research and development of orphan drugs, companies receive a tax credit on research and development, access to federal grants, and exclusive rights to sell the drug for that disease in the United States, even if the patent expires before then.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Marathon Pharmaceuticals also received a special “priority review” voucher — basically an FDA fast-track review of a future drug. The company can use this voucher itself or sell it to another for hundreds of millions of dollars.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The program has had many successes — &lt;a href=&quot;http://khn.org/news/drugmakers-manipulate-orphan-drug-rules-to-create-prized-monopolies/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;450 orphan drugs&lt;/a&gt; have been brought to market since the act was signed into law by former President Ronald Reagan in 1983.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But critics are concerned the system is being abused to maximize profits, with companies using their near-monopoly on orphan drugs to charge exorbitant prices. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And, as with deflazacort, applying for orphan status — sometimes multiple times — for drugs that are already available on the market.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This, they say, is a burden on families who worry about covering the costs of these drugs if their health insurance lapses or copayments and deductibles go up.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Why are orphan drugs so expensive?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some orphan drugs can cost as much as $804,000 per year, according to a report by the &lt;a href=&quot;http://khn.org/news/sky-high-prices-for-orphan-drugs-slam-american-families-and-insurers/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Kaiser Health Network&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The average price for orphan drugs is lower, but even that outpaces non-orphan drugs. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to a &lt;a href=&quot;http://info.evaluategroup.com/rs/607-YGS-364/images/EPOD15.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;report&lt;/a&gt; on orphan drugs by EvaluatePharma, the average annual cost for orphan drugs was $111,820, compared with $23,331 for mainstream drugs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So why are orphan drugs so expensive?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There are no easy answers to the question why orphan drugs are relatively expensive,” Joshua Cohen, PhD, a research associate professor at Tufts Center for the Study of Drug Development, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“One reason is that they serve small populations,” he said. “Another reason is that they are often unique products with no competitors.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With seven years of exclusive rights for an orphan drug for a particular disease, a company can set whatever price it wants.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Companies say that the high prices are needed to recover the cost of research and development, which can be 20 to 30 years for a new drug.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to a &lt;a href=&quot;http://delauro.house.gov/sites/delauro.house.gov/files/Prescription-Drugs-Innovation-Spending-and-Patient-Access-12-07-16.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;report to Congress&lt;/a&gt; last year by the Department of Health and Human Services, though, average development costs for an orphan drug are about $1 billion, compared with $2.6 billion for a mass market drug.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And, as the Kaiser study points out, even with fewer patients taking them, orphan drugs can be big moneymakers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A $50,000 drug taken by 50,000 patients could bring in $2.5 billion per year for a company. A $300,000 orphan drug taken by only 5,000 people could net $1.5 billion a year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In spite of the smaller number of people affected by rare diseases, sales of orphan drugs are also expected to increase.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.statnews.com/pharmalot/2017/02/28/orphan-drugs-prices/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;StatNews&lt;/a&gt;, by 2022 orphan drugs will make up more than 21 percent of brand name prescription drug sales worldwide, an increase from 6 percent from 2000.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;EvaluatePharma also notes that seven of the 10 top-selling drugs in the world by sales are orphan drugs. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Double dipping on orphan drugs&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Critics say that drug companies have become increasingly savvy about utilizing the benefits of the Orphan Drug Act.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Of particular concern are orphan drug applications for existing mass market drugs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the Kaiser report, more than 70 orphan drugs were first approved by the FDA for mass market use. Many were approved for more than one disease, sometimes multiple ones.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This includes deflazacort. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;/drugs/tetrabenazine/oral-tablet&quot;&gt;Tetrabenazine&lt;/a&gt; was used for years to treat uncontrollable tremors in people with Huntington disease. According to the Washington Post, before its orphan drug status, a bottle of pills cost $42.28 from a European pharmacy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After orphan drug approval, the list price for a bottle of tetrabenazine in the United States was more than $6,000. The price was eventually increased to $21,243 a bottle.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a 2015 &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/news/media/releases/orphan_drug_loophole_needs_closing_johns_hopkins_researchers_say&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;commentary&lt;/a&gt; published in the American Journal of Clinical Oncology, Dr. Martin Makary at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, wrote that companies also exploit the law by focusing on just one of a drug’s uses — “one narrow enough to qualify for ‘orphan’ disease benefits.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After orphan drug approval, they then market the drug as off-label for other conditions, increasing their profits.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How high prices affect patients&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;One of the biggest concerns is that the high prices for orphan drugs will limit access to them — which would have the opposite effect of the original intent of the law.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Few people, if any, will pay the list price for an orphan drug. Drug companies have rebates and assistance programs to help offset the cost.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Insurance will also cover much of the cost for many people. But as insurance companies feel the price pressure of more people taking orphan drugs, they may ask people to pay more out of pocket or restrict access.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Insured U.S. patients face few outright denials of access to orphan drugs,” said Cohen, “but may incur high levels of patient cost-sharing and also certain conditions of reimbursement such as prior authorization.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For people on fixed incomes — such as those on Medicare or Medicaid — copayments of 20 percent of a drug’s cost can be a “considerable financial burden,” said Cohen.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In response to the Kaiser report in January, Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) and two other U.S. senators have &lt;a href=&quot;http://raps.org/Regulatory-Focus/News/2017/03/06/27032/Senators-Ask-GAO-to-Probe-Orphan-Drug-Act-as-Questions-Pile-up-Over-Marathon%E2%80%99s-Pricey-Steroid/#sthash.ZOK2nFFW.dpuf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;asked&lt;/a&gt; the U.S. Government Accountability Office (GAO) to look into abuse of the Orphan Drug Act.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Marathon Pharmaceuticals already &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/company-pauses-release-89-000-muscular-dystrophy-drug-n720731&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;announced&lt;/a&gt; last week that it would “pause” its launch of Emflaza — the brand name of deflazacort — because of pricing concerns raised by patients and advocacy groups.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other critics echoed the concerns about abuse of the Orphan Drug Act.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If we are serious about lowering drug costs, we have to make sure that incentives created to spur innovation are used for groundbreaking research instead of simply fleecing the American people,” William Holley, spokesperson for the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.csrxp.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Campaign for Sustainable Rx Pricing&lt;/a&gt;, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Public Policy</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-06T15:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-06T15:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/critics-orphan-drug-law-ripe-for-abuse
</guid>
<dc:creator>Shawn Radcliffe</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-06T23:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
What’s the Best Way to Treat People Addicted to Opioids?
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/best-way-to-treat-people-addicted-to-opioids
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/030617_coldturkey_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The op
]]>
<![CDATA[
ioid epidemic combined with the medical community’s inclination to prescribe drugs for pain management has created a perfect storm.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The crisis has heightened the debate over the best way to treat people addicted to prescription drugs with many professionals agreeing that going “cold turkey” is not a viable solution.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The dilemma comes as the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) releases its most &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/drugoverdose/data/analysis.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;recent statistics&lt;/a&gt; on the state of the opioid epidemic.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The agency reports that fatal drug overdoses have more than doubled since 1999. In 2015, 60 percent of all drug overdoses were from opioids, &lt;a href=&quot;http://abcnews.go.com/Health/fatal-drug-overdoses-doubled-1999-cdc-finds/story?id=45697327&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;ABC News reports&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The problem has become so widespread the past few years, that it’s no longer a fringe topic. It was even intertwined in the presidential election last fall, with several journalists addressing the fact that areas ravaged by the crisis tended to be strongholds for President Donald Trump. They dubbed them the “&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.businessinsider.com/trump-vote-results-drug-overdose-deaths-2016-11&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Oxy electorate&lt;/a&gt;.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It was hardly the only time the epidemic showed its face in politics.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;White House press secretary, Sean Spicer, offered a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.forbes.com/sites/debraborchardt/2017/02/23/sean-spicer-wrongly-links-recreational-marijuana-with-opioid-crisis/#4b3f04cc3ea9&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;commentary&lt;/a&gt; last month on the role of marijuana in fostering the problem.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Last week, Maryland’s Republican Governor, Larry Hogan, &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/md-politics/hogan-declares-opioid-state-of-emergency/2017/03/01/5c22fcfa-fe2f-11e6-99b4-9e613afeb09f_story.html?utm_term=.3b3b9e1be912&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;declared a state of emergency&lt;/a&gt; in response to the opioid crisis. The state is pledging an additional $50 million in an “all-hands-on-deck approach” that will include enforcement, prevention, and treatment services.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;No easy answers&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;A recent &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.jhsph.edu/news/news-releases/2017/many-patients-receive-prescription-opioids-during-medication-assisted-treatment-for-opioid-addiction.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; out of Johns Hopkins University concludes that part of the problem is that those who are dealing with opioid addiction have a high likelihood of being prescribed more narcotic drugs after addiction treatment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers looked at a cohort of 50 million people between 2006 and 2013 being prescribed buprenorphine, often referred to by its trade name Suboxone. The drug is widely used to treat opioid addiction by helping wean people with opioid addictions off of other drugs as well as softening the symptoms of withdrawal.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, the crux of the study is that, “Approximately two-fifths (43 percent) of buprenorphine recipients filled an opioid prescription during the treatment episode and two-thirds (67 percent) filled an opioid prescription following treatment.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The vast majority of patients that run into problems with opioids are using them exactly as prescribed, or at least are receiving these opioids from licensed prescribers,” said Dr. Caleb Alexander, the study’s co-author, and an associate professor of epidemiology and medicine at Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Alexander points to the very nature of our healthcare system as part of the culprit.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We live in a very fragmented healthcare system,” he told Healthline, “and all too often the left hand may not know what the right hand is doing. This is particularly worrisome when it comes to the use of a medicine as potentially dangerous as a prescription opioid.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;What this means in practical terms is that communication from one of a patient’s doctors to another isn’t necessarily all that great. If your dentist prescribes you something, your general practitioner likely won’t be aware of it (and vice versa) unless you bring it up. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This situation gets even more complex when dealing with substances such as buprenorphine and methadone because these require special licensing for distribution. It’s unlikely you can see your regular doctor and walk out with a prescription for them. Instead, opioid abusers must often travel to specialized clinics where they can obtain tightly controlled doses.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“For many patients who are being treated for opiate addiction, this component of their care is sort of walled off or pursued separately from their routine primary care,” said Alexander.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While the Obama administration did make some headway in making &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2016/07/06/484843560/obama-administration-eases-restrictions-on-doctors-who-treat-opioid-addiction&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;buprenorphine more accessible&lt;/a&gt; by easing restrictions on doctors’ ability to dispense it, the substance is still highly controlled.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Trying to slow prescriptions&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;What the current research suggests is that without more oversight, these drugs’ efficacy is questionable.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers note that the median length of a buprenorphine treatment was only 55 days, meaning the average user stuck with it for less than two months.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Within the current system, a patient dealing with opioid addiction could be prescribed buprenorphine and then several weeks or months into the treatment, the patient breaks their leg. In the emergency room, they are subsequently prescribed oxycodone for the pain.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But there are some stopgaps in place. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The rise of Prescription Drug Monitoring Programs (PDMPs) — statewide databases that allow physicians and pharmacies to see drug prescription records — are essential in helping to slow overprescription.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In terms of trying to get some sort of a flag going, pharmacists, when they see that people are on buprenorphine, have the ability to not fill an opiate prescription and in some cases, even a benzodiazepine prescription without notifying the prescribing physician,” Dr. Louis E. Baxter Sr., president of the Professional Assistance Program of New Jersey, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But these systems are still limited and almost always restricted by state.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Baxter notes that being in a tristate area, the medical community is attempting to coordinate interstate databases.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There are earnest efforts being taken to sort of make these more of a regional and ultimately a national database,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Dealing with pain&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;There is still a much larger issue at stake, of which PDMPs are only part of the solution.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The most crucial part of the opioid crisis narrative that research points to is that patients dealing with opioid dependence may also be dealing with legitimate pain issues. So, being prescribed buprenorphine and an additional opiate may in fact be “justified clinically.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, CDC Director, Dr. Tom Frieden, has &lt;a href=&quot;https://arstechnica.com/science/2016/03/cdc-just-says-no-to-opioid-prescriptions-for-chronic-pain/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;gone on record saying&lt;/a&gt;, “Plainly stated, the risks of opioids are addiction and death, and the benefits for chronic pain are often transient and generally unproven.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Some have characterized what I would argue is a false conflict between, on the one hand, quality of care for those in pain, and on the other, reducing our overreliance on opioids,” said Alexander. “These two are not fundamentally in conflict.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“For far too long, we’ve overrelied on prescription opioids at great cost to millions of Americans,” he added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Baxter agrees that pain management must be scrutinized, particularly for those who are not dealing with chronic issues. Sprains, breaks, and other short-term injuries may not need opioids at all. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Most acute pain only lasts four to five days,” he said, pointing to more mundane, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs as effective pain relievers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“People get good pain management with those non-opiate medications,” Baxter said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Additionally, there are plenty of other pain solutions available, including massage therapy and physical therapy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Drugs alone aren’t the answer&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Both Alexander and Baxter disagree with the notion that a drug like buprenorphine is effective on its own.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Anybody that is only being prescribed buprenorphine and is not having any counselling, they are all doomed, in my view, to return to use and abuse of opiates,” says Baxter.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“What should be done,” he continues, “is that when patients with opiate abuse issues present for treatment, they need to be evaluated to see if they have any significant pain issues, any chronic pain issues, and they also need to be evaluated to see if they have psychiatric issues.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;His recommendation for a more holistic approach to the problem, which includes drugs such as Suboxone, also incorporates counseling and rehabilitation. This “full treatment” approach, he says, has a 70 percent success rate.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In a situation in which individuals only use the buprenorphine and none of [the other treatments], that success rate is down there less than 20 percent,” he added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Baxter and Alexander both caution against the notion of going “cold turkey” because it is dangerous and ineffective.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In the past, it was thought that if you let somebody suffer through withdrawal that will help them never to use again because it’s such a terrible experience, but that has been shown to pretty much be folklore, and it’s not true,” said Baxter.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Instead, by including additional therapy and oversight for people dealing with pain and opioid addiction, there are viable alternatives.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Baxter and Alexander are both optimistic about the ways that our healthcare system is changing to deal with the opioid crisis and its intersection with pain management.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Alexander says that buprenorphine is “far from a panacea.” Instead, patients need to be engaged. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Frieden’s answer is even more straightforward.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The prescription overdose epidemic is doctor-driven. It can be reversed, in part, by doctors’ actions,” he said.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-03-06T14:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-06T14:00:00</updateddate>

<dc:creator>Gigen Mammoser</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-06T22:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>New Blood Test May Pinpoint Cancer Tumors</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/new-blood-test-may-pinpoint-cancer-tumors
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/cancer/030117_bloodchip_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;
]]>
<![CDATA[
New research shows promise for a blood test that not only identifies cancer but also pinpoints precisely where tumors are growing.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Published in the journal &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nature.com/ng/journal/vaop/ncurrent/full/ng.3805.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Nature Genetics&lt;/a&gt;, the study describes how a specific DNA signature called CpG methylation haplotypes can indicate both the presence and specific location of tumor cells.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Senior study author Kun Zhang of the Jacobs School of Engineering at the University of California-San Diego and colleagues say their findings could offer a noninvasive method for cancer diagnosis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the American Cancer Society, more than &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cancer.org/content/dam/cancer-org/research/cancer-facts-and-statistics/annual-cancer-facts-and-figures/2017/cancer-facts-and-figures-2017.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;1.6 million&lt;/a&gt; new cancer cases will be diagnosed in the United States this year and more than 600,000 people are expected to die from the disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In most cases, cancer diagnosis requires a biopsy, whereby a sample of tissue is removed and analyzed for the presence of cancer cells. This new test requires neither surgery, endoscopy, or the use of a needle.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Using DNA from healthy cells&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cancer blood tests are gaining momentum for cancer diagnosis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These tests work by identifying DNA traces of cancer cells that have broken away from tumors. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At present, however, such tests are unable to provide information on where in the body a tumor is located.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&quot;Knowing the tumor's location is critical for effective early detection,&quot;&amp;nbsp;noted Zhang.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For their study, the researchers created a technique that tests for DNA signature CpG methylation haplotypes. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In simple terms, this signature is an indicator of both tumor DNA and the DNA of healthy cells. The team explains that when healthy cells are destroyed by cancer cells, their DNA is released into the bloodstream. This DNA can be used to pinpoint the tissue affected by cancer cells.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&quot;We made this discovery by accident. Initially, we were taking the conventional approach and just looking for cancer cell signals and trying to find out where they were coming from,” said Zhang.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“But we were also seeing signals from other cells and realized that if we integrate both sets of signals together, we could actually determine the presence or absence of a tumor, and where the tumor is growing.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;‘A promising strategy’&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;To reach their findings, the researchers used samples from 10 different healthy tissues – including the liver, brain, lung, intestine, and colon – to produce a database of methylation patterns.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Additionally, the team used blood and tumor samples from cancer patients to create a database of genetic markers specific to cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Next, the researchers analyzed the blood samples of healthy patients and those with tumors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;By searching for cancer- and tissue-specific genetic markers in these blood samples, the team was able to identify the presence and location of tumors.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Zhang notes that further work is needed to “optimize and refine” this technique, but the researchers believe that their study provides proof of concept for a noninvasive diagnostic technique for cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In summary, methylation haplotyping in plasma is a promising strategy for the early detection of a tumor and its primary growth site, as well as for the continuous monitoring of tumor progression and metastasis to multiple organs,” say the authors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“With more plasma samples from patients at multiple clearly defined cancer stages and from healthy controls, it is possible to further improve the prediction sensitivity and specificity to a level adequate for clinical testing.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Cancer</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-06T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-06T10:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/new-blood-test-may-pinpoint-cancer-tumors
</guid>
<dc:creator>Honor Whiteman</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-06T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
What It's Like to Survive a Severe Food Allergy Attack
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/surviving-a-severe-food-allergy-attack
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/030517_severeallergyattack_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;If you knew that one bite of a muffin containing egg as an ingredient might kill you or your child ... how might you feel?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This is the day-to-day reality for many people in the United States living with severe food allergies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Research shows that an estimated &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.foodallergy.org/facts-and-stats&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;15 million Americans&lt;/a&gt; have food allergies that can be life-threatening. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Despite the increase in more allergy awareness circulating these days, there is still a misconception about the reality of life after surviving a severe allergy attack.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Simply injecting someone with an EpiPen or administering Benadryl does not remedy the aftershock of an attack.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The aftermath&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Allergic reactions vary from person to person.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In most cases, after an EpiPen or other treatment has been administered, it’s important to call 911 or local emergency services and request an ambulance, and alert medical services of the details of the allergy attack.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If the person having the attack becomes unconscious, administer CPR. It’s also crucial to head to the emergency room after a severe allergy attack even if symptoms are subsiding. There is always the potential for a follow-up allergic reaction.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And for many of the food allergy challenged it just doesn’t stop there.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Surviving the day-to-day aftermath of a severe allergic reaction is a scary ordeal,” Roz, the mother of a severely allergic child, told Healthline. “It’s ongoing. It affects everyone in our house. Every aspect of our lives is affected by planning on how to prevent or manage a severe allergic reaction. If my son has skin contact with nut oil or sesame oil — and doesn’t even ingest it — he ends up with hives all over his body that can potentially affect his breathing. This is too much pressure for a 9-year-old.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The physical and emotional state of surviving a severe anaphylactic allergy attack can be all-encompassing.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a recent Healthline online survey, participants had similar comments when speaking on the subject:&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I constantly have panic attacks after,” said Jenifer Lyn Owens. “Thinking everything I eat is going to cause my throat to swell, even if I know for sure it won’t. It’s not easy to deal with.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I feel complete exhaustion and extreme fatigue after finishing post and steroids [adrenal fatigue],” added Julie Stein Giesegh. “It can take six weeks or more to fully recover my strength.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our son is 11, and he has horrible anxiety over food,” said Megan Hunter. “Since he’s gotten older and is more aware of how he feels when he has a reaction he panics. Anytime he tried something new he worries. His reaction goes from mild to severe in no time. He usually takes a day or two to feel normal again.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Also, many within the food allergic community share one major concern after a severe allergy attack occurs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“You constantly worry about being exposed to the trigger again. I spent three days in the hospital because of an unknown allergy,” said Renee Baxter.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Taking charge of the situation&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Despite these worries many families are trying to take control where they can.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Food allergic reactions are not one-time events.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We constantly have to discuss hypothetical situations with my son so he is prepared,” Julie, the mother of a child with food allergies, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That training has come in handy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Recently, a friend at school told my son he could eat the candy that was offered and my son said, ‘No. There are no ingredients listed. I am not supposed to eat anything without asking my mom or dad,’” said Julie. “The reason he was able to say that was because just that morning we discussed a hypothetical situation like that occurring. This is part of our daily life.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Kristen Duncan Williams is the Founder of FAKS: Families of Allergic Kids in School. &lt;/em&gt;&lt;em&gt;FAKS is an organization devoted to spreading more food allergy awareness within school communities. For more information contact: faksbrooklyn@gmail.com&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<pubdate>2017-03-05T06:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-05T06:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/surviving-a-severe-food-allergy-attack
</guid>
<dc:creator>Kristen Duncan Williams</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-05T14:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Fashion for People with Arthritis and Other Painful Conditions
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/fashion-for-people-with-arthritis
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/030417_fashion_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Fashion design
]]>
<![CDATA[
er Michael Kuluva hasn’t let rheumatoid arthritis (RA) get in his way. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But he’s acknowledged a notable void in the fashion and beauty industries when it comes to adaptive options and more inclusive designs for people living with an illness or disability. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He isn’t alone. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are online initiatives in the form of hashtags, blogs, Twitter chats, and Instagram accounts that explore the relationship between fashion and chronic illness. It can be a pain for people in pain to dress themselves.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It can also be difficult to find fashionable, stylish options that are also adaptive and functional for anyone with a disability or aching body.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A fashion dream altered&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kuluva is the founder of the label Tumbler and Tipsy, which he debuted at New York Fashion Week. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, the former figure skater didn’t always dream of a career in fashion.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After he retired from his sport in his mid-20s, Kuluva realized that he had another interest and a talent that couldn’t be ignored.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He began working as an assistant for a designer despite having no formal training. He eventually secured a scholarship to the Fashion Institute of Design and Merchandising (FIDM). &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;During his time at FIDM, he found that he was performing well academically but couldn’t perform some basic tasks.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I noticed I could not even draw a straight line, and I had other little setbacks. I had trouble cutting fabric and I began comparing myself to other students,” Kuluva told Healthline. “My joints just weren't doing what they should be. I had pain. Then, one day, walking from class to my car, my back suddenly gave out.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kuluva first thought he had a kidney stone. He saw a urologist who told him the issue wasn’t urological and suggested that Kuluva see a rheumatologist.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After visiting three doctors and waiting months to be seen at the Mayo Clinic, Kuluva was eventually diagnosed with RA. Through trial and error, he found a combination of medications that worked pretty well for controlling his condition. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“No medication is ever 100 percent, but my regimen is going well,” he said. “If I miss a few weeks of treatment, because of travel or fashion shows for example, then I can definitely feel that. I didn’t really have issues while figure skating. … I had some bursitis, but I don’t think it had anything to do with my RA. So, my decision to retire from skating was not related to my rheumatoid arthritis, but I’m glad I retired when I did.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Bringing awareness to Fashion Week&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;After showing a collection that would eventually help to launch the career of model Kendall Jenner, Kuluva started to think about how he could use his art and his platform for good. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There’s been a lot of proud moments — a lot of great moments that are unforgettable. Kendall Jenner helped to launch my career and vice versa,” he said. “This gave me kind of a voice in society. So my CreakyJoints collection was a pivotal moment where I got to express myself within my fashion.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The collection is a collaboration with the arthritis-related nonprofit CreakyJoints, to promote RA awareness on the runway.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;CreakyJoints has worked with celebrities like actress &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/actress-megan-park-talks-about-life-with-rheumatoid-arthritis-072915&quot;&gt;Megan Park&lt;/a&gt; to promote RA awareness, but this fashion collection came about rather organically.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Real Housewife of New York Jill Zarin’s daughter was backstage in my dressing room, and we got to talking because she has a form of arthritis, too. It got me thinking, and after our conversation I figured I might contact CreakyJoints after that collection was done,” Kuluva recalled.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said he just wanted to lend his voice to a cause and be an advocate for something.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I like the nonprofit mindset of CreakyJoints, all for the patients. The president, Seth, has [spondyloarthritis], and so he really gets it,” Kuluva said. “So we all had lunch and brainstormed what we could do together. They pretty much left it up to me. I came up with putting starbursts on all the joints in my SS2017 show. The starbursts, while fashionable, represent the joint pain.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kuluva said the fashion industry still has a void to fill with adaptive and inclusive fashions for people who are sick or have disabilities. This is especially in terms of shoes and footwear.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kuluva did acknowledge that some current trends of more comfortable and functional styles may be ideal for people with chronic pain.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As for his own work, he continues to dream big and strives to do more. Kuluva has a history of incorporating charity and social change in his work as a fashion designer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I was hoping to inspire change with the collection that I did. I hope that it opens eyes and spreads awareness,” Kuluva said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In an interview for &lt;a href=&quot;https://themighty.com/2016/09/michael-kuluva-designs-activewear-line-inspired-by-arthritis/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;The Mighty&lt;/a&gt;, Kuluva explained his CreakyJoints collection by saying, “It really shows the joints affected by arthritis. It’s an explosion of colors on joints that would light up on tests for arthritis.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Being diagnosed with RA at age 28 could have destroyed his career or his vision for the future. But it didn’t.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kuluva advises other young people diagnosed with illnesses like RA to keep looking forward and not hiding their condition.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“As long as you're open and honest with your doctor and your family with what is going on with you and your health, you can get the help you need. An organization like CreakyJoints can help you understand that you may have restrictions, but you can still achieve great things,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Will fashion become more adaptive? &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kuluva is doing his part to spread awareness and other designers are, too. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Tommy Hilfiger has designed some &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-3681481/Tommy-Hilfiger-s-collection-adaptive-clothing-designed-children-special-needs-seller-fashion-brand.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;adaptive clothing&lt;/a&gt; for children with special needs and physical disabilities. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Fashion bloggers have fought back against &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.bustle.com/p/why-disability-is-the-latest-fashion-industry-frontier-30548&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;ableism in fashion shoots&lt;/a&gt;. (Like Kylie Jenner and Lady Gaga using gilded wheelchairs as “props.”)&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.instagram.com/madelinesmodelling_/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Madeline Stewart&lt;/a&gt; has made headlines as a model with Down syndrome.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;New York Fashion Week began to use &lt;a href=&quot;http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2016/2/25/the-disabled-models-of-new-york-fashion-week.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;models with disabilities&lt;/a&gt;, including amputee &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.instagram.com/shahol1/?hl=en&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Shaholly Ayers&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Beyonce cast disability activist &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.bustle.com/articles/149109-beyonce-casts-disabled-activist-jillian-mercado-for-an-awesomely-inclusive-campaign-photos&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Jillian Mercado&lt;/a&gt; as a model in one of her advertising campaigns. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.verywell.com/fashionable-adaptive-clothing-1094363&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;many more brands&lt;/a&gt; are coming out with adaptive clothing that is fashionable and chic, yet still provides necessary comfort and functionality. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Still, many fashions don’t have stylish, easy-to-wear or adaptive alternatives, or inclusive runway shows or advertising campaigns.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The beauty industry also lacks variety when it comes to ergonomic and adaptive options for hairstyling tools and makeup brushes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But designers like Kuluva think that these baby steps toward progress are working in favor of people with health problems or physical disabilities. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think the industry will get there,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For now, the Arthritis Foundation has a list of approved arthritis-friendly products with the “&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.arthritis.org/living-with-arthritis/tools-resources/ease-of-use/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Ease of Use&lt;/a&gt;” seal of approval, to help people with arthritis dress themselves more easily. They also have suggested footwear brands and options.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other websites, like the now-defunct Arthriving site from Aleve, have attempted to catalog the best products to help people with arthritis pain function better when it comes to daily activities like drying their hair, cooking, buttoning a blouse, fastening a bra, or tying their shoes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While that site is gone, there are many blogs that offer tips for &lt;a href=&quot;/health-slideshow/arthritis-products&quot;&gt;living well with chronic pain&lt;/a&gt; or limitations in terms of physical mobility and ability.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<updateddate>2017-03-04T06:00:00</updateddate>

</guid>
<dc:creator>Ashley Boynes-Shuck</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-04T14:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>Why Heart Disease is on the Rise in America</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/why-is-heart-disease-on-the-rise
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/heart-health/030317_heartdisease_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It seems that Americans aren’t getting the message about heart disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;New statistics predict that 45 percent of people in the United States will have at least one issue related to the disease by 2035.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s up from earlier predictions from the American Heart Association (AHA) of 40 percent by 2030. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The AHA predicts that costs related to the disease will double from $555 billion in 2016 to $1.1 trillion in 2035.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That “could bankrupt our nation’s economy and healthcare system,” according to AHA President Steven Houser, PhD.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He says heart disease and its complications are spreading quicker than originally thought.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The news comes as two celebrities made recent headlines for heart-related complications.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Actor &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cnn.com/2017/02/26/entertainment/bill-paxton-dead/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Bill Paxton&lt;/a&gt; died at age 61, reportedly from a stroke during heart surgery to fix a damaged valve, while fitness guru &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.today.com/news/bob-harper-updates-fans-condition-following-heart-attack-t108790&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Bob Harper&lt;/a&gt;, from “The Biggest Loser,” suffered a heart attack at age 51.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Why is heart disease getting worse, even though our society seems obsessed with healthy living?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other diseases like cancer and Alzheimer’s disease garner more attention, but the fact is cardiovascular disease (CVD) remains the nation’s most prevalent and costly killer, Houser told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Even though smoking is on the decline, Houser said that other risk factors — obesity, poor diet, high blood pressure, and type 2 diabetes — are on the rise.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, people may not realize how devastating heart disease is until they know someone who has it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Beating a preventable disease&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Michael Miller is a cardiology professor at the University of Maryland School of Medicine, and author of “Heal Your Heart: The Positive Emotions Prescription to Prevent and Reverse Heart Disease.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He told Healthline that the main factors driving the rise in heart disease are obesity and type 2 diabetes, but the real underlying culprits are moving less and stressing more. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“What we aren't doing enough is getting up and out, spending quality time with loved ones daily, and smelling the roses,” Miller said. &quot;We also need ‘me time’ to recharge, so I tell my patients to spend at least 15 minutes by themselves to collect their thoughts, whether by meditation or shutting off the radio while in the car.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I also suggest getting up every 15 minutes if you have a desk job and move around and stretch. &amp;nbsp;Same recommendations hold while watching TV,” he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Regina Druz, a cardiologist at the Integrative Cardiology Center of Long Island, told Healthline that stress is a factor along with obesity, diabetes, and pollution. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The epidemic is related to several factors, all converging in what amounts to a ‘perfect storm’ situation,” she said. “However, what fuels the rise of diabetes and obesity, and heart disease down the line, is inflammation, and the impact of inflammation and environment on our genetics.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A wake-up call?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Houser was surprised when he reviewed the recent AHA report due to the rising death rates and numbers that describe the financial toll CVD will have in the United States. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The report also finds that, by 2035, more than 123 million Americans will have high blood pressure, 24 million will have coronary heart disease, and more than 11 million will have experienced a stroke.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Houser said better investments in the National Institutes of Health (NIH) and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) would reduce the burden and costs associated with heart disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Policymakers must invest in research and ensure Americans have affordable, quality health care—especially preventive care. Then, schools and workplaces have to create healthy environments that promote healthy habits, he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The fact that CVD could singlehandedly bankrupt our nation’s healthcare system is disturbing,” Houser said. “But it’s a real possibility if we don’t act soon to do a better job of preventing what are largely preventable disorders.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<updateddate>2017-03-03T00:00:00</updateddate>

http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/why-is-heart-disease-on-the-rise
</guid>
<dc:creator>Kristen Fischer</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-03T08:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Can Acupuncture Cure Carpal Tunnel Pain?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/acupuncture-for-carpal-tunnel-syndrome
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/news/030217_acupuncture_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Acupuncture may be more effective in treating some chronic pain ailments than previously thought.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers in a study &lt;a href=&quot;https://academic.oup.com/brain/article-abstract/doi/10.1093/brain/awx015/3058778/Rewiring-the-primary-somatosensory-cortex-in&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;published today&lt;/a&gt; in the journal Brain concluded that acupuncture helped relieve pain for people with carpal tunnel syndrome.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers said the acupuncture helped reduce symptoms by “remapping” the brain.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They added the therapy also provided some healing effects at the source of the pain in the patients’ wrists.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Vitaly Napadow, PhD, director of the Center for Integrative Pain Neuroimaging, and senior author of the research paper, said his group hopes to do more research on acupuncture’s effectiveness on carpal tunnel and other chronic pain ailments.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“One of the benefits of acupuncture is it’s so minimally invasive and has such a low-risk profile,” Napadow told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What researchers discovered&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In this study, 80 people with an average age of 49 were tested.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The volunteers, 65 of whom were women, were divided into three groups.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One group was treated with verum electro-acupuncture at the wrist.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another group was given the acupuncture therapy in an ankle on the opposite side of their affected wrist.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The third group was given “sham acupuncture” treatments as a control.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They were each given 16 treatments over eight weeks. The participants were evaluated after the treatments and then reevaluated three months later.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Napadow said all three groups reported some relief from pain.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, he said the two groups that received acupuncture also showed some physiological changes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;High-tech imaging revealed the acupuncture had caused some mapping changes in the brain.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, there appeared to be some healing effects in participants’ wrists.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The group that received treatment in their wrists showed more benefits than the people who got acupuncture in their ankles.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Why acupuncture is effective&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;This study was not the first to show that acupuncture can be effective on carpal tunnel syndrome.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers conducted studies in &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3523426/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2012&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.healthcmi.com/Acupuncture-Continuing-Education-News/1611-acupuncture-reverses-carpal-tunnel-syndrome&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2016&lt;/a&gt; and reported that study participants experienced pain relief after receiving acupuncture.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, Napadow said his group’s study also measured the physical changes acupuncture produced.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said the signals the brain receives after an acupuncture needle is stuck into the skin may in essence “remap” the brain so it modifies pain signals from the wrist.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, he said, the needle punctures at the pain point may cause the body to send extra blood to that spot, much like what happens during bruising.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That additional blood may help damaged nerves to heal.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There seem to be some top down effects,” he noted.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Greater use of acupuncture&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Napadow said acupuncture is an alternative treatment that some people may want to consider before using drugs, or an invasive type of procedure such as surgery, for any kind of chronic pain ailment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He added that acupuncture is already recommended in a number of guidelines for various chronic pain conditions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said the biggest barrier right now is getting insurance companies to cover these alternative treatments.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For people who might be reluctant to try this ancient Chinese treatment, Napadow said they should consider the validity of the therapy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“People should focus not so much on the origin of the therapy but rather what it’s doing,” he said.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
