<pubdate>2017-03-02T14:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-02T14:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/acupuncture-for-carpal-tunnel-syndrome
</guid>
<dc:creator>David Mils</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-02T22:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Why There Hasn’t Been a New Alzheimer's Drug for 10 Years
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/why-there-hasnt-been-a-new-alzheimers-drug-for-10-years
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/aging/030217_alzheimersdrugs_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;
]]>
<![CDATA[
p&gt;There may be a long way to go before a new treatment for Alzheimer’s comes on the market. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Just three months after drug company &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/23/health/eli-lillys-experimental-alzheimers-drug-failed-in-large-trial.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Eli Lilly&lt;/a&gt; ended the clinical trial of its Alzheimer’s drug solanezumab, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2017/02/another-alzheimers-drug-flops-pivotal-clinical-trial&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Merck&lt;/a&gt; has stopped the trial of its Alzheimer’s drug verubecestat because an independent study found the drug had no chance of working. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s been a decade since a new drug was placed on pharmacy shelves to help treat the symptoms of Alzheimer’s disease, and there were high hopes for both the Eli Lilly and Merck drugs. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The more recent failures have certainly been disappointing, both from the patient advocacy point of view, but also from the perspective of the entire research field,” Bruce Lamb, PhD, Roberts Family Chair in Alzheimer’s Disease Research, and executive director of the Stark Neuroscience Research Institute at Indiana University, told Healthline.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“However, on the flip side, we now understand a great deal more about the disease processes than we did just a few years ago, and there is general consensus that we must redouble our efforts and work to speed these efforts as much as is possible,” he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A growing, expensive problem&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;More than 5 million people in the United States live with Alzheimer’s, a type of dementia that causes problems with memory, thinking, and behavior.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Alzheimer’s is the most common form of dementia, accounting for 60 to 80 percent of cases. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Of the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/chronicdisease/resources/publications/aag/alzheimers.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;5.4 million Americans&lt;/a&gt; with Alzheimer’s it is estimated 5.2 million are 65 years of age or older. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Every 66 seconds, someone in the United States develops Alzheimer’s, and this number is expected to increase significantly in the coming decades. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We know the numbers are going to triple by the middle of the century if we don’t find a way to stop, slow, or cure the disease,” James Hendrix, PhD, director of Global Science Initiatives at the Alzheimer’s Association, told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.alz.org/facts/overview.asp&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Research&lt;/a&gt; from the Alzheimer’s Association shows that by 2050, the number of people 65 years of age or older with Alzheimer’s disease is projected to hit almost 14 million. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Unless a medical breakthrough is discovered that can prevent or cure the disease, this will have a devastating effect on those living with the disease and the people who care for them. And it will likely have significant economic ramifications. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2016, care for those with Alzheimer’s and other dementias cost the United States &lt;a href=&quot;http://act.alz.org/site/DocServer/2012_Costs_Fact_Sheet_version_2.pdf?docID=7161&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;$236 billion&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If we don’t find a way to stop or slow the disease by the middle of the century, one third of the Medicare budget as it currently exists would go to one disease. … Alzheimer’s disease,” Hendrix said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And with &lt;a href=&quot;https://alz.org/global/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;47 million people&lt;/a&gt; worldwide affected by dementia, the economic impact will be felt on a global scale.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This disease has the potential to actually bankrupt whole health systems in some countries. It’s not just an issue of compassion for families and people who are dealing with Alzheimer’s and dementia, it’s also an urgent issue in terms of economics. … This is a very expensive disease,” he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.alz.org/alzheimers_disease_trajectory.asp#summary&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Alzheimer’s Association&lt;/a&gt; calculates that a successful treatment introduced in 2025 that could delay the onset of Alzheimer’s by just five years could reduce the number of people with the disease by 5.7 million by the middle of the century. This would save more than $220 billion within the first five years.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Tackling the unknown&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The potential market for a new Alzheimer’s therapy would be considerable.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, some experts worry that pharmaceutical companies will stop pursuing trials for Alzheimer’s drugs if their efforts continue to fail. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There is certainly a risk that some of the other big players in development of Alzheimer’s therapies may not continue to develop their drug pipelines if the risk is too high,” Lamb said.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“On the flip side, there is an extremely large market for Alzheimer’s therapies, so even a relatively modest success would be transformative and potentially quite lucrative,” he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Despite decades of research, experts say there is still so much that is unknown about Alzheimer’s that producing effective therapies remains challenging. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our understanding of this very complex disease is still rudimentary at best,” Lamb said. “We still understand very little about all of the changes occurring within the brain over the 20 to 30 years’ disease course. This makes it very difficult to both identify potential targets and also know when to target these therapies over the disease course.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hendrix says although the recent failures in clinical trials are disappointing, there are still other options to pursue. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“With every trial we learn something. … And there’s a vast amount of information and data that comes out. We need a better understanding of the disease and that will lead to better care,” he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lamb argues that more funding for Alzheimer’s research is crucial given the prevalence of Alzheimer’s disease. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Funding for Alzheimer’s research by the federal government is not appropriately scaled given the problem,” Lamb said.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He says it is estimated the federal government spends more than $200 billion a year on care for Alzheimer’s patients yet only spends $950 million on Alzheimer’s research. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The numbers don’t lie. We need better therapies for the millions who are dealing with the disease and the millions more who will get the disease in the coming decades,” Hendrix said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Senior Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-02T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-02T12:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/why-there-hasnt-been-a-new-alzheimers-drug-for-10-years
</guid>
<dc:creator>Elizabeth Pratt</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-02T20:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
The Multitude of Issues Surrounding Human Embryo Gene Editing
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/issues-surrounding-human-embryo-gene-editing
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/030217_geneediting_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Should scientists be allowed to dive deep into an embryo’s DNA and dig out an inheritable disease?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Should parents be allowed to tweak an unborn child’s genes to make their child tall or athletic or smart?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And what would be the consequences of all this on human evolution?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Those are some of the questions facing the medical community and society in general as limited experiments begin in the United States on human embryo gene editing.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;An advisory group formed by the National Academy of Sciences and National Academy of Medicine &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/14/health/human-gene-editing-panel.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;recommended last month&lt;/a&gt; that this kind of research should begin.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, the panel said it should only be done in rare cases where there is no alternative to preventing a baby from acquiring a serious disease or disability.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Ethical questions arise&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Research on editing the genes of human embryos is already underway in China and Sweden.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Clinical trials using gene editing to treat noninheritable conditions are already set to start in the United States.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, editing out inheritable ones like Huntington disease, cystic fibrosis, or Alzheimer’s disease from the genes of human embryos is a bigger undertaking, both scientifically and ethically.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Such editing could eliminate the risk of the disease for the embryos as well as eliminate these conditions for any offspring the embryos might produce as an adult.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But experts say that “germline” editing could cause unintended, permanent effects on human evolution.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It also could open up the ability to edit embryos for enhanced physical or mental characteristics, creating so-called “designer babies.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the past year, new, cheaper technologies — particularly the adoption of the more precise gene editing tool CRISPR-Cas9 — have made it more likely researchers will actually succeed at editing human embryos.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That makes the debate over these concerns no longer hypothetical.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The technology could save millions of lives.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Or it could lead to an ever-growing divide between those who can afford to pay for enhanced medical treatments and those who can’t.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How it could affect you &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Let’s say you and your partner both have cystic fibrosis with the same mutations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But you want to have a child who doesn’t have the disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Genetic editing could be the answer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Such embryonic manipulation would involve a small number of couples with specific conditions and preferences and lack of alternatives.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But, as University of Manchester Bioethicist John Harris told &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nationalgeographic.com/magazine/2016/08/human-gene-editing-pro-con-opinions/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;National Geographic&lt;/a&gt;, if suffering and death can be averted by this research “the decision to delay such research should not be made lightly. Just as justice delayed is justice denied, so, too, therapy delayed is therapy denied. That denial costs human lives, day after day.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For most couples, there would be other options available, points out Marcy Darnovsky, PhD, director of the Center for Genetics and Society in California.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some might be able to use an egg or sperm donor or screen embryos with preimplantation genetic diagnosis in a fertility clinic.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There is also the question of what this research will mean not just for our health but for our perceptions of society.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If we can do away with a disease like cystic fibrosis, for instance, how will that affect how we view and treat those who still have it?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;What will we be saying about who is “healthy” and who isn’t?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s a way of setting a bar about what kinds of people should be born,” Darnovsky told Healthline. “There are concerns about stigmatizing conditions and reducing the social supports of people who do live with those conditions.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;When it could affect you &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;All these implications are years or even decades away.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The research that will happen in the near term is more about improving the technology, not modifying embryos intended to be gestated and born.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That germline editing, in fact, is not allowed because of a prohibition on using federal funds to review “research in which a human embryo is intentionally created or modified to include a heritable genetic modification.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, the advisory panel’s report states that the technology is not ready for human trials.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But it also said using it to edit the precursors of humans — embryos, eggs, sperm — could soon be “a realistic possibility that deserves serious consideration.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For now, someone who is interested in one day benefiting from embryo editing should undergo carrier testing to see if and how much they are at risk of passing on a heritable disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Go through your [doctor], not one of those companies where you send off your spit in a vial,” said Darnovsky.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She said physicians have the time, training, and resources to make sure you’re fully informed about any conditions or decisions you’ll have to make.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, they can also keep you updated on new technologies and ethical quandaries as they emerge.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Public Policy</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-02T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-02T10:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/issues-surrounding-human-embryo-gene-editing
</guid>
<dc:creator>Matthew Berger</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-02T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>These Doctors Accept Only Cash</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/these-doctors-accept-only-cash
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/030117_cashdoctors_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;When Dr. Heather Bartlett was working as an outpatient doctor for a hospital system in Seattle — right out of residency — her idealism ran headlong into the reality of much primary care medicine in the United States.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Too many patients. Too little time.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It was a real eye-opening experience how many people you had to see,” said Bartlett, now a family medicine doctor at &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.theBartlettclinic.com&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;The Bartlett Medical Clinic &amp;amp; Wellness Center&lt;/a&gt;, a direct primary care practice in Ohio.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To make ends meet, many primary care practices squeeze more patient visits into their week. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As they do, the length of each visit shrinks, giving doctors barely enough time to assess a patient’s main concern, let alone connect with them.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Patients become herded through the cattle gates and physicians become hamsters in the wheel,” Bartlett told Healthline. “And it doesn’t make for a good relationship for anybody.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So Bartlett did what a small but increasing number of physicians are doing — ditching insurance companies altogether. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Instead they are setting up cash-only medical practices where doctors deal directly with patients on financial matters.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This immediately shifts the doctor-patient relationship.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The main benefit of not billing through insurance is that you no longer work for the insurance company. You work directly for the patient,” Dr. Carmela Mancini, an internal medicine doctor who has a &lt;a href=&quot;http://doctorMancini.com&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;direct primary care practice&lt;/a&gt; in Massachusetts told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What is ‘cash only?’&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The cash only model is known as direct care or direct primary care.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Patients pay an annual or monthly fee for access to their doctor. This covers most primary care procedures — things like physicals, tests for strep throat, EKGs, and stitches. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Patients also get 24/7 access to their doctors, longer office visits, and often same-day appointments.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Direct primary care differs from &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.medicaresearchinstitute.org/news-and-events/blog/2016/02/retainer-based-medicine-right-model-care-personalization/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;concierge medicine&lt;/a&gt;, which still bills insurance but uses the membership fees to provide patients with greater access and to pay for procedures not covered by insurance.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.johnlocke.org/app/uploads/2016/02/DPC-Spotlight.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;John Locke Foundation&lt;/a&gt;, the average monthly payment for direct primary care is $25 to $85. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some practices also offer different membership levels.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At Mancini’s practice, the fee ranges from $30 per month for 18- to 21-year olds, to $125 per month for people 65 years or older who often need more intensive care.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With only 800 to 1,000 patients — or fewer — direct primary care practices are smaller than typical primary care practices, which may have &lt;a href=&quot;http://californiahealthline.org/news/new-program-in-coachella-valley-seeks-affordability-in-personalized-primary-care/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2,000 to 3,000 patients&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This allows time during the day for longer office visits — and lets doctors maintain better work-life balance.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Typical primary care doctors may spend no more than 10 to 15 minutes with each patient.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A direct primary care doctor may spend at least 20 minutes with a patient. Or more.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A follow-up visit with Mancini is 30 minutes. For people with multiple chronic conditions, she’ll book one-and-a-half hours.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This hearkens back to your great-grandparents’ time.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This is how it used to be back in the day before you had back-to-back patients,” said Bartlett, “before insurance became the norm for outpatient care around the 1950s.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Doctors connecting with patients&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Longer visits help doctors see the big picture when it comes to their patients’ health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“To do good medicine, you need to know what’s going on with somebody,” said Bartlett. “If you tell somebody, ‘I only have time to hear your top two things,’ but their third thing was chest pain, you haven’t done your job.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Direct primary care doctors also have more control over how they interact with patients. Phone consultations, text messages, and Skype are common.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Most insurance companies will only reimburse a doctor when a patient comes into the office.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I don’t need to force people to come into my office for things that don’t need to be handled that way,” said Bartlett. “Telemedicine is booming. There’s a reason for that.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With telemedicine, patients can avoid unnecessary trips to the doctor — and hours away from work or having to pay for a babysitter — just to find out the results of a lab test or to ask a simple question about a rash or a cold.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And because doctors are accessible around-the-clock, patients may be less likely to put off seeking help.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After talking to a patient on the phone or getting a text, a doctor can write a prescription, refer a patient to the emergency room, or just ease their concerns.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There are so many patients that have so much anxiety,” said Bartlett. “A lot of anxiety is triggered by a concern that there’s something wrong with them.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Quicker care can also keep small problems from turning into larger ones — like a cat scratch becoming a major infection or symptoms of a heart attack or stroke going untreated.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;People get urgent care when it’s needed and avoid it when it’s not.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“With three of us in the office getting to know patients, we can save so many ER visits, so many unnecessary urgent care visits,” said Dr. Jeffrey Gold, a family practice doctor at &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.Golddirectcare.com&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Gold Direct Care&lt;/a&gt;, a direct primary care practice in Massachusetts.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Cutting out insurance companies&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Many advocates of direct primary care say these benefits result from no longer dealing with insurance companies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Part of this is that insurance companies don’t reimburse doctors enough to cover the cost of longer visits.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And there are many hoops for doctors to jump through to get reimbursed, including the use of electronic medical records for billing purposes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Most of us chose primary care to build relationships with people and take care of people,” said Gold. “How do you do that in an eight-minute visit, where 75 percent of it you’re standing at a computer checking boxes and typing stuff in?”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cutting out insurance billing also cuts costs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“[This model] definitely is sustainable, and what makes it sustainable is my overhead is really low,” said Mancini. “When you’re not billing through insurance, you don’t need 10 people doing coding and billing for you.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Although direct primary care physicians have fewer patients, the monthly membership fees plus lower overhead means that their practices can still be financially viable.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Direct primary care doctors can even do something else your great-grandparents might have been familiar with — the house call.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I have quite a few patients that can’t get out of the house because they’re homebound for a variety of reasons,” said Mancini. “In the insurance-based model, it’s really hard to do a home visit.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Putting consumers in charge&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;A big part of the direct primary care model is price transparency, which puts more control back in the hands of consumers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“How do you become a consumer if you don’t have the right tools?” said Gold. “The biggest thing we’re bringing to light is transparency in pricing, which does not exist.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Practices list membership fees on their website and clearly explain what patients get for their money — no surprise bills when an insurance company says a doctor’s visit wasn’t covered.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Direct primary care practices can also offer inexpensive medications to patients.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“You can have a small wholesale pharmacy in your office and dispense noncontrolled and noncompounded medications at amazing prices,” said Bartlett.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And doctors negotiate prices with private companies for better rates on lab tests, imaging, and other medical services — some of these are even &lt;a href=&quot;http://time.com/4649914/why-the-doctor-takes-only-cash/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;cash-only businesses&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These rates are sometimes lower than what an insurance company would pay for the same service.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Like their insurance-taking counterparts, direct primary care physicians can refer patients to a urologist, cardiologist, or other specialist.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But because direct primary care doctors spend more time getting to know patients’ medical histories and assessing their symptoms, they may be less likely to refer to a specialist just because they are in a hurry.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Many patients still carry some form of health insurance to cover these visits, hospital stays, and other nonprimary care services.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, even some people with insurance that covers primary care visits find it worthwhile to pay a membership fee for 24/7 access to their doctor, longer visits, and a shorter wait for an appointment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Not everyone is as enthusiastic about the promises made by direct primary care advocates, especially given the small amount of &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.medpagetoday.com/Blogs/CareerConsult/60762&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;research&lt;/a&gt; available on these practices.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2016, only 6 percent of physicians participated in a cash only practice, according to &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.medscape.com/features/slideshow/compensation/2016/public/overview#page=19&quot;&gt;Medscape's Physician Compensation Report&lt;/a&gt;. But interest is growing.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-four-legs-of-a-new-health-care-system-1480550930&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;The Wall Street Journal&lt;/a&gt; sees direct primary care as an important piece of any replacement for the Affordable Care Act (ACA), largely because of its free market approach and focus on price transparency.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Advocates say the direct primary care movement highlights the need to keep the doctor-patient relationship up front in any discussion of the future of the U.S. healthcare system.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Insurance does not equate to care,” said Gold. “It’s all well and good to have Medicaid or any other subsidized health plan, but if you can’t get access to a doctor who knows you and cares about you, a lot of good that [insurance] card does.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Downsides to cash only&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;While advocates of direct primary care feel strongly about the ability of this approach to produce better care for patients, there are some downsides.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For doctors, switching to a direct primary care model is a big step. And like any business, they may have to invest heavily up front before their practices have enough patients to be sustainable.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They may also need to spend more time on the business side of their practices — marketing their practices, negotiating prices on lab tests and radiology services and medications.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They may even have to educate communities about the benefits of letting go of insurance for primary care.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I knew this was the right thing for me, and I knew it was the right thing for patients,” said Gold. “But I also knew that 99 percent of the patients were also going to think it was bad for them.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Many new primary care doctors are trained to assess quickly and refer to specialists. So they may not have a broad enough medical background to handle patient care with the intensity required for a direct primary care practice.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And when doctors switch to direct primary care, it can affect their current patients and their communities.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If current patients choose not to follow a doctor into the new direct primary care practice, they may lose a long-standing relationship with their physician.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Not every community has enough primary care doctors to go around, which can be exacerbated when doctors cut their patient lists in half.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cost is also an issue. Even at the lower membership fees, not everyone will be able to pay this out-of-pocket expense, particularly those on Medicaid. Some practices offer “charity care” to those in need, but this may not meet the demand.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Qliance, a larger direct primary care business shows that this may be &lt;a href=&quot;http://californiahealthline.org/news/new-program-in-coachella-valley-seeks-affordability-in-personalized-primary-care/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;less of a concern&lt;/a&gt;. The company has roughly 35,000 patients, about half are enrolled in Medicaid.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some doctors have raised concerns about the lack of oversight offered by insurance companies, which monitor doctors to make sure they are following clinical care guidelines and practicing evidence-based medicine.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>

<dc:creator>Shawn Radcliffe</dc:creator>

<item>
<title>Is Vitamin D a Wonder Supplement?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/is-vitamin-d-a-wonder-supplement
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/030217_vitamind_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;You may
]]>
<![CDATA[
think vitamin D is little more than a component in your daily multivitamin.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But the so-called “sunshine vitamin” is more complicated — and potentially more beneficial — than you might have imagined.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s long been known that vitamin D helps bone growth and strength by increasing the body’s absorption of calcium, magnesium, iron, and other beneficial minerals. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Absorbing sunlight and eating fatty fish are two simple ways to boost vitamin D levels.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But some of vitamin D’s unique characteristics — and its lesser-known benefits — may make it worth talking to your doctor about.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A unique vitamin&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Unlike other members of the vitamin alphabet, vitamin D defies easy classification.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s because it could actually be considered a hormone, since it’s synthesized in the liver and kidneys. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another unique aspect of vitamin D is the fact that, apart from fatty fish oil, vitamin D is rarely found in food.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The essential nutrient is dependent on body chemistry — and because everybody is different — it’s worth getting an expert opinion.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I always measure vitamin D,” Dr. Jenny Goodman, Nutritional and Environmental Medicine specialist from the British Society for Ecological Medicine (BSEM), told Healthline. “It’s very important because you can theoretically overdose — it’s very unlikely, but still technically a risk. You could never overdose on vitamin C or the B vitamins, because they’re water-soluble and you just pee out whatever you don’t need.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Any B or C vitamins will be gone from your system within a few hours, Goodman noted. But, that’s not the case with vitamin D.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s why she tends to measure patients’ levels before suggesting they take it. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Goodman said that humans once got enough sunlight to produce sufficient vitamin D, but times have changed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We all evolved from Africa, we didn’t evolve with clothes on, and we didn’t evolve indoors. So our basic natural state is to be running around under an African sun with very little covering on,” she explained. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Even in the Northern Hemisphere, until the Industrial Revolution, most people worked outside all the time, and they got by.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After the industrial revolution, people began spending more time indoors, in offices, and at home. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Goodman said that unless you happen to have a job as a gardener or a landscape designer, you likely won’t get enough sun, even through the summer, because you’re just not outdoors enough. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“People’s requirements vary, which is why levels should be measured,” she added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Old benefits, new benefits&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The link between healthy vitamin D levels and healthy bones is well-known.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But more recent research sheds light on a wider range of possible benefits.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers at the Harvard School of Public Health (HSPH) found that low levels of vitamin D could &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/vitamin-d-may-help-prevent-treat-multiple-sclerosis&quot;&gt;accelerate the progression&lt;/a&gt; of multiple sclerosis (MS) for people in the early stages of the disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Getting enough vitamin D may protect against this.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Recent research out of the University of Birmingham, published in PLOS ONE, suggests that increased levels of vitamin D in the blood can help &lt;a href=&quot;http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0170665&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;optimize muscle strength&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lead study author, and Clinical Lecturer at the Institute of Metabolism and Systems Research at the University of Birmingham, Zaki Hassan-Smith, PhD, told Healthline in an email that researchers hope to learn more about this connection in future studies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We found that the receptor which vitamin D is known to act through was present in muscle from our research volunteers,” he wrote. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We also observed associations between serum vitamin D levels and a number of genes that are involved in muscle function,” he added. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hassan-Smith says that his team is seeking funding for trials of vitamin D in different groups, including the elderly and high-performance athletes, in order to better understand optimum doses of vitamin D. He also points to other research into possible health benefits.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“A recent &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.bmj.com/content/356/bmj.i6583&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;BMJ study&lt;/a&gt; has suggested that there may be benefit in [vitamin D] reducing respiratory tract infections, but the jury is still out,” he wrote. “There are large scale randomized controlled trials due to report in a number of health outcomes that should give us a clearer idea in the next two to three years.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Goodman says that this BMJ study, which shows a link between vitamin D levels and immune system health, could be a game-changer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our bodies are producing cancer cells all the time, but what happens is our immune system detects that there’s an alien cell and it destroys it, just as it would destroy a bacterium — and it does not work properly without vitamin D,” she said. “I see particularly low levels of vitamin D in my patients with breast cancer.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She suggests that anyone who has had cancer, particularly breast cancer, should have their levels checked immediately. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Goodman also suggests a link between healthy vitamin D levels and brain function, telling Healthline, “You’ve got to remember that the brain is a fatty organ ... All the nerve cells are basically coated in a myelin sheath, which is basically fat.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She emphasized that people need their fat-soluble vitamins, particularly vitamin D.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Get it checked&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Multivitamin supplements may promise a well-rounded nutritional regimen, but they often don’t deliver, said Goodman.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I definitely do not recommend multivitamins,” she said. “Firstly, they tend to have tiny amounts of everything, and secondly, they tend to have lots of fillers and rubbish in them.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some options may have too much vitamin A, and many use a cheap, synthetic form of vitamin D, called vitamin D-2, according to Goodman.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Vitamin D-3 is the real thing. It’s what our body makes from sunshine. Multivitamins really are a cheap substitute for eating properly,” she added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s worth noting that the body cannot create vitamin D if it doesn’t have the necessary components to do so. “One of the causes of vitamin D deficiency, especially in women, is low-fat diets,” said Goodman. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;People who don’t have enough fat in their diets won’t get enough vitamin D because it’s a fat-soluble vitamin, she explained&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Goodman closed with this advice for keeping your vitamin D levels up during the winter months: “Eat oily fish — that is, salmon, trout, mackerel, sardines, and so on — through the winter, make sure you’re getting as much sunshine exposure as you can, and if you’re poorly, get your vitamin D levels tested.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Food and Nutrition</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-01T11:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-01T11:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/is-vitamin-d-a-wonder-supplement
</guid>
<dc:creator>Dan Gray</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-01T19:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
A High-Tech Blood Test That May Detect Cancer Early
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/a-high-tech-blood-test-that-may-detect-cancer-early
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/cancer/030117_bloodchip_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Monitoring cancer patients and assessing their response to treatment can sometimes involve invasive procedures, including surgery. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A new experimental technique may help change that. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers from Cedars-Sinai Medical Center&amp;nbsp;and the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA), are using a small device to help predict which cancers are likely to spread. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The experimental device is about the size of a postage stamp. The NanoVelcro Chip has nanowires 1,000 times thinner than a human hair. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The chip is coated with proteins that recognize circulating tumor cells. These are cells that have broken off from tumors and entered the bloodstream.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;From there, cancer cells can travel throughout the body and spread to other tissues and organs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers run the blood sample through the chip. The proteins recognize and capture circulating tumor cells, which can then be identified and analyzed. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s a technique that could make monitoring cancer treatment easier.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s far better to draw a tube of blood once a month to monitor cancer than to make patients undergo repeated surgical procedures,”&amp;nbsp;Dr. Edwin Posadas said in a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cedars-sinai.edu/About-Us/News/News-Releases-2017/Cedars-Sinai-UCLA-Scientists-Use-New-Blood-Biopsies-With-Experimental-Device-to-Speed-Cancer-Diagnosis-and-Predict-Disease-Spread.aspx&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;press release&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Posadas is medical director of the Urologic Oncology Program at&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cedars-sinai.edu/Patients/Programs-and-Services/Cancer-Institute/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Cedars-Sinai Samuel Oschin Comprehensive Cancer Institute&lt;/a&gt;, and one of the lead investigators of the research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The power of this technology lies in its capacity to provide information that is equal to, or even superior to, traditional tumor sampling by invasive procedures,” he continued.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Blood biopsies for prostate cancer&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The research focused on prostate cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s an important area of study because prostate cancer can be slow growing or super aggressive.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Slow-growing types may never become an issue and don’t necessarily need treatment. Other types spread quickly and are potentially fatal.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cancer.org/cancer/prostate-cancer/about/key-statistics.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;American Cancer Society&lt;/a&gt;, prostate cancer is the third leading cause of cancer death in men in the United States.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Knowing the difference as early as possible can save many men from treatment they don’t need. For others, it means getting the most effective treatment as quickly as possible.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This research showed that some cancer cells contain a smaller nucleus than others. Men with the most aggressive type of prostate cancer have cells with these small nuclei. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The scientists found that the smaller nuclei are associated with cancer spreading to the liver and lungs. And it happened before the metastases were found.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s a discovery that could help identify those patients who are at high risk of metastatic prostate cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Circulating tumor technology &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Liquid biopsies have been around for some time.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So has the concept of circulating tumor cells, according to urologist Dr. Timothy Wilson.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“All solid tumors release circulation tumor cells. Some science suggests even early cancer, or small cancers, release cells into the bloodstream,” he told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Wilson is director of the Urologic Oncology Research Program, and professor and chair of urology at the &lt;a href=&quot;http://california.providence.org/john-wayne/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;John Wayne Cancer Institute&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;at Providence Saint John’s Health Center in California.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Wilson said that for men with a metastatic prostate cancer, who have a high tumor burden, the biopsies are a valuable tool for tracking how well treatment is working.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Getting the tissue for a tumor biopsy involves an invasive procedure, which often means surgery. The location of the tumor and health status of the patient can sometimes make that risky.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Liquid biopsies are convenient and noninvasive, so they’re easier on patients. And they help doctors choose the treatments with the most potential to work.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Right now, blood biopsies are not used to detect, but to monitor mostly metastatic cancers. If you’re not getting a good response to treatment, and there’s an increase in cancer cells, you can switch gears and try another treatment,” said Wilson.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Blood biopsies as a screening tool&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;When doctors want to know if suspicious tissue is cancerous, they generally perform a biopsy of the tumor.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If a tissue biopsy could be replaced with a blood biopsy, it could usher in a new age of diagnosis and treatment for cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;We’re not there yet, but Wilson has high hopes for the future.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The value is exciting if we have good detection for finding evidence in cancer in the bloodstream,” he said. “It would have a huge impact. Imagine what it would mean for screening.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Wilson said that current screening and monitoring tests are relatively ineffective in finding small amounts of cancer. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Finding cancer in its early phase through these new modalities could eliminate the need for all these other tests.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Theoretically, a blood sample could tell you if you’re cancer free or not. Then you could isolate and identify circulation tumor cells and analyze the DNA to learn where it came from (prostate, breast, etc.). &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“That’s where the science is going, but we’re several years away from that,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It would amount to a lot less testing and big cost savings, said Wilson.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He believes the small chip used by the Cedars-Sinai/UCLA researchers adds to the field of precision medicine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Wilson said one of the important next steps will be increasing the likelihood of finding smaller numbers of cancer cells when the concentration is less.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This is the wave of the future. Over time, it will get us away from looking at these cancers by the organ from which they came. We’ll be more precise in delivering treatment based on the characteristics of the cancer found as a result of liquid biopsy. We’ll be able to spare more radical surgery, treat earlier, and prevent more aggressive therapies and side effects,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Posadas and the other lead investigator, Hsian-Rong Tseng, PhD, professor at the Department of Molecular and Medical Pharmacology in the &lt;a href=&quot;http://medschool.ucla.edu&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;David Geffen School of Medicine&lt;/a&gt; at UCLA, are now part of the Blood Profiling Atlas in Cancer (BloodPAC) Project, a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cancer.gov/research/key-initiatives/moonshot-cancer-initiative&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Cancer Moonshot program&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Program participants will share data collected from circulating tumor cells. Posadas and Tseng have been collecting samples from circulating tumor cells for five years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The hope is that the research will lead to effective, targeted treatments for many types of cancer.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Cancer</category>
<pubdate>2017-03-01T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-03-01T10:00:00</updateddate>

</guid>
<dc:creator>Ann Pietrangelo</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-03-01T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>How Same-Sex Marriage Laws Help LGBTQ Teens</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/how-same-sex-marriage-laws-help-lgbtq-teens
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/022717_teensuicide_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Suicide is the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/injury/images/lc-charts/leading_causes_of_death_age_group_2014_1050w760h.gif&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;second leading cause of death&lt;/a&gt; for people between the ages of 15 and 24 in the United States.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, adolescents who identify as gay, lesbian, bisexual, or transgender are at even greater risk of self-harm.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;National &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/healthyyouth/data/yrbs/results.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;data from 2015&lt;/a&gt; compiled by the Youth Risk Behavior Surveillance System (YRBSS) reveal that more than 29 percent of gay, lesbian, bisexual, and transgender high school students reported attempting suicide in the previous 12 months. That compared with only 6 percent of heterosexual students.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But there’s hope, at least on one horizon.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to a &lt;a href=&quot;http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamapediatrics/fullarticle/2604258?utm_source=Silverchair_Information_Systems&amp;amp;utm_campaign=FTM_02162017&amp;amp;utm_content=news_rele&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;new study&lt;/a&gt; published in JAMA Pediatrics, same-sex marriage legalization leads to an overall decrease in adolescent suicide attempts.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What the study concluded&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers used YRBSS data from 1999 through 2015 of more than 750,000 students to identify how suicide statistics in states that legalized gay marriage compared with those that didn’t. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“After same-sex marriage laws were implemented,” the researchers wrote, “the proportion of high school students reporting suicide attempts in the past year decreased by 0.6 percentage points, equivalent to a 7 percent decline.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Adolescents who identified as gay, lesbian, bisexual, or transgender had an even more precipitous drop in reported suicide attempts of 4 percentage points. That was equivalent to a 14 percent decline compared with heterosexual students.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study estimates that, following this trend, “same-sex marriage policies would be associated with more than 134,000 fewer adolescents attempting suicide” every year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Julia Raifman, ScD, the study’s lead author, and a postdoctoral fellow at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health, told Healthline that they believe that same-sex marriage policies may have effectively reduced stigma toward LGBTQ youth by peers, teachers, and parents.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Stigma based on sexual orientation can broadly mean an array of behaviors, but tends to include labeling, prejudice, and stereotyping. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It can have a whole range of negative effects on LGBTQ individuals, including distress, anxiety, depression, and increased suicide risk.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The correlation between same-sex marriage legalization and reduced suicide attempts in adolescents isn’t crystal clear, but study authors say it does make a compelling argument for the benefits of such legislation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Additionally, Raifman explains that studies can also offer insights into other facets of public health concerning the LGBTQ community, including how gay marriage policies affect disparities in HIV among men who have sex with men.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The study’s importance&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;LGBTQ rights advocates say the study is incredibly important.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Suicide is a public health issue. This piece of research is a very positive tool in our toolkit that will support future efforts to link the legislation of positive regard and equality to the improvement of the lives and health of LGBTQ people,” said David W. Bond, vice president of programs at &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.thetrevorproject.org&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;The Trevor Project&lt;/a&gt;, a nationwide crisis intervention and suicide prevention service for LGBTQ youth.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He also echoes Raifman’s conclusion about the results of the research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Marriage equality can likely be seen as an indicator of acceptance, replacing the rejection that very significantly contributes to suicidality,” he told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Same-sex marriage in the United States has been legal on a federal level since 2015. In the landmark case &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/14pdf/14-556_3204.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Obergefell v. Hodges&lt;/a&gt;, the Supreme Court voted in a 5-4 decision that same-sex couples had the fundamental right to marry and required all states to begin issuing marriage licenses to same-sex couples.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, the issue remains contentious. With a Republican administration in office, the question of LGBTQ — particularly transgender rights — has become more visible.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This week, President Trump reversed an initiative set forth under President Obama that allowed students in public schools to &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/23/us/gavin-grimm-transgender-rights-bathroom.html?_r=0&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;use bathrooms of their choice&lt;/a&gt; — not based on their sex.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Meanwhile, North Carolina’s now infamous “bathroom bill,” which also designates bathrooms only be used by people based on their “biological sex,” is still &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.newsobserver.com/news/politics-government/state-politics/article134476919.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;being debated&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Numerous outlets reported a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.newsobserver.com/news/politics-government/politics-columns-blogs/under-the-dome/article72879582.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;dramatic spike in calls&lt;/a&gt; to transgender suicide hotlines, following the passing of the bill in March 2016.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Janson Wu, executive director of GLAD, a legal advocacy group for the LGBTQ community, says that directives like this can be harmful, particularly to adolescents.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When we ask lawmakers to pass a law, we not only explain why it is necessary to fix a concrete problem, such as discrimination,” he told Healthline, “we also impress upon them the critical importance of sending a message of inclusion and support to young people.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Wu also stressed the importance of the recent research, saying that it underscores the “impact of laws that protect and affirm the equality [and] dignity of LGBT people.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<updateddate>2017-02-28T11:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/how-same-sex-marriage-laws-help-lgbtq-teens
</guid>
<dc:creator>Gigen Mammoser</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-28T19:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>
NASCAR Driver Getting the Word Out on Colorectal Cancer
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/nascar-driver-getting-word-out-on-colorectal-cancer
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/cancer/022817_nascarcolorectal_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&l
]]>
<![CDATA[
t;p&gt;Scott Lagasse Jr. admits he wasn’t the kind of guy who went in for regular checkups.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I don’t do doctors very well,” he says.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But the reason the NASCAR driver is still alive today is because of a visit to his physician in 2015.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It was a day out of my life that saved my life,” Lagasse told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Florida native had gone in because he felt pain in his lower abdominal area while bicycling.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;His doctor told him he had colorectal cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Fortunately for Lagasse, it was stage 1, and it was caught early enough that he only needed surgery to fix what could have been a life-threatening problem.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I was 100 percent lucky. I’m normally a very stubborn person,” Lagasse said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The race car driver also doesn’t usually talk about his personal life, but he is making an exception in the coming weeks.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He plans to speak out during &lt;a href=&quot;https://healthfinder.gov/nho/MarchToolkit.aspx&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Colorectal Cancer Awareness Month&lt;/a&gt; in March.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The 35-year-old husband and father is hoping to convince other people in his age group to get screened for a disease that is becoming more common in his generation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Incidence in millennials, Generation Xers&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;A report published today in the Journal of the National Cancer Institute states that people born in 1990 have double the risk of colon cancer compared with people born in 1950.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That younger age group also has quadruple the risk of rectal cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As a result, 3 in 10 rectal cancer cases in this country are now in people younger than 55.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study, led by American Cancer Society scientists, reports that colon cancer incidence rates increased between 1 percent and 2 percent per year from the mid-1980s until 2013 in adults 20 to 39 years of age. That compares with 0.5 percent to 1 percent per year for people from 40 to 54 years of age.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For rectal cancer, the incidence rate has been rising about 3 percent a year for the past three to four decades for adults ages 20 to 39. That compares with 2 percent a year the past two decades for people 40 to 54.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study authors note that the biggest difference between the younger and older age groups is screening.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Currently, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends that people start getting &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/cancer/colorectal/basic_info/screening/guidelines.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;screened for colorectal cancer&lt;/a&gt; at age 50.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study authors say that minimum screening age may need to be reconsidered.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our finding that colorectal cancer risk for millennials has escalated back to the level of those born in the late 1800s is very sobering,” Rebecca Siegel, MPH, director of surveillance information for the American Cancer Society, said in a statement. “Educational campaigns are needed to alert clinicians and the general public about this increase to help reduce delays in diagnosis, which are so prevalent in young people, but also to encourage healthier eating and more active lifestyles to try to reverse this trend.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Getting the word out&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Anjelica Davis, president of Fight Colorectal Cancer &lt;a href=&quot;http://fightcolorectalcancer.org/&quot;&gt;(Fight CRC)&lt;/a&gt;, told Healthline her organization is getting the word out on screening during this awareness month.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She said people should get a checkup and use whatever screening exam they are most comfortable with.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We don’t want you to not get tested,” she said. “The take-home tests are an option. Do the right test for you.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Davis said people should consider getting screened before age 50 if they have a family history of colorectal cancer or if they experience rectal bleeding or pain in the lower abdominal area.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Don’t ignore these symptoms,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Davis noted that colorectal cancer has a 90 percent cure rate if it is caught early. She said 60 percent of the annual &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/cancer/colorectal/statistics/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;50,000 cancer-related deaths&lt;/a&gt; in the United States caused by colorectal cancer could be prevented if people go in for regular screenings.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Screening is a lot easier than managing a treatment schedule,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lagasse knows this all too well.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He had no family history of colon cancer, but he went in when he developed pain.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lagasse said the fact his wife was pregnant at that time was a primary reason.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“That started to weigh on me,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At first, Lagasse kept his diagnosis and treatment secret.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But then one of his cousins called and talked to him about his screening because he was experiencing pain. It turned out his cousin did not have cancer, but he did go in and get checked.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I came to the realization that this was a lot more important than just me,” said Lagasse.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I didn’t do the doctor routine before,” he added. “I felt like it wasn’t the manly thing to do. I had this invincible mentality.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That has all changed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lagasse now goes in for screening every year. So far, there’s no sign of the cancer coming back.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-02-28T09:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-28T09:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/nascar-driver-getting-word-out-on-colorectal-cancer
</guid>
<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-28T17:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Cancer Patients Anxiously Await Decision on Obamacare
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/cancer-patients-worried-about-obamacare-repeal
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/ACA/022717_cancerACArepeal_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&
]]>
<![CDATA[
gt;Bonnie Makkinjie, a teacher from Florida, was diagnosed last year with triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She was told she’d need surgery as soon as possible. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Fortunately, she said, in 2014 she signed up for healthcare coverage through the ACA health insurance marketplace.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Obamacare absolutely saved my life,” Makkinjie, 51, a mother and grandmother who teaches art to children with autism and other developmental disabilities, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“None of my previous jobs offered insurance, and the premiums and deductibles were just too high to make it feasible,” she said. “I was fortunate to fall into the right income bracket for ACA insurance.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But if the ACA is repealed, Makkinjie fears she may soon be without health insurance once again.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I’ll need future MRIs and scans to be sure the cancer has not returned,” she said. “I doubt I’ll be able to afford them without affordable insurance. It’s a scary thought.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;‘I’m a dead woman walking’&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Tina Camino Smith, a small business owner from Ohio, who’s been battling MALT lymphoma for nearly a decade, has the same fears.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Without the Affordable Care Act, I’m a dead woman walking,” said Smith, who was also diagnosed last year with myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS), which, most experts agree, is a form of blood and bone marrow cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If the ACA is repealed and there isn’t an adequate replacement, Smith told Healthline she will forego treatment and “pursue doctor-assisted suicide, when the time comes.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I cannot add the financial burden to an already difficult time to my family. Both my therapist and husband understand this,” she explained.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Obamacare repeal &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;President Donald Trump and members of Congress continue to discuss the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.wsj.com/articles/gops-new-plan-to-repeal-obamacare-dare-fellow-republicans-to-block-effort-1488154291&quot;&gt;possible repeal&lt;/a&gt; of the ACA, which was signed into law in March 2010.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Meanwhile, the anxiety and anger is palpable among people with cancer and cancer survivors who have insurance because of Obamacare.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Tony Glavan, 60, a retired analysis technician from Minnesota, went through several clinical trials before going into lasting remission.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He purchased health insurance through the ACA after he retired. The policy gave him the peace of mind that, even if his cancer recurs, he is covered. But now he doesn’t know what to think.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If my cancer comes back, what does the insurance market hold for me?” he told Healthline. “Will I be allowed to participate in clinical trials as easily as I did before?”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Glavan said the Republicans want to “cherry pick the good parts about ACA, but I don’t think they have any idea how that will be economically feasible if they don’t force the healthy younger people to buy insurance.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Is Obamacare a disaster?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Scrapping the healthcare law was one of the primary tenets of Trump’s campaign.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While supporters agree the ACA is not perfect, they note it provides multiple positive provisions and benefits and have added more than 20 million Americans to the ranks of the insured.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The President continues to call it a “disaster,” and the most conservative members of Congress agree the law should be gutted. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But there is growing dissent in the GOP ranks over repealing Obamacare. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;During an interview Sunday on CBS News’ “Face the Nation,” Ohio Republican Gov. John Kasich, who had just met with Trump in the White House on Friday, said the hard-line conservatives in his party want to get rid of the entire healthcare law, “and that’s not acceptable.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Putting people over party, Kasich said he would “stand up” for the folks who will lose coverage if they don't get this right.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“What's at stake here are 20 million Americans,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Former House Speaker John Boehner also &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.politico.com/story/2017/02/john-boehner-obamacare-republicans-235303&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;said last week&lt;/a&gt; that he doesn't believe Republican legislators will repeal the law, Politico reported. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;People with cancer speaking out&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;At town hall meetings even in red states such as Arkansas and Georgia, members of Congress are being met with hostile crowds, including many people with cancer. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/12/politics/audience-member-paul-ryan-town-hall-obamacare/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;CNN&lt;em&gt; &lt;/em&gt;town hall&lt;/a&gt; with House Speaker Paul Ryan of Wisconsin a few weeks ago, Jeff Jeans, a cancer survivor, and “lifelong Republican” from Arizona, told Ryan that President Obama saved his life.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Thanks to the Affordable Care Act, I’m standing here today alive,” said Jeans, a small business owner who worked on the Reagan and Bush campaigns.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He was told at age 49 that he had cancer and had just six weeks to live.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I rely on the Affordable Care Act to be able to purchase my own insurance,” he said. “Why would you repeal the Affordable Care Act without a replacement?”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ryan responded, “Oh, we wouldn’t do that. We want to replace it with something better.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Approval ratings&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The popularity of the ACA nationwide is in fact ascending to new heights, just as Trump’s approval rating sinks to new lows. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2017/02/23/support-for-2010-health-care-law-reaches-new-high/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;national Pew Research Center survey&lt;/a&gt; released last week, public support for Obamacare has reached its highest level on record, with 54 percent approving and 43 percent disapproving. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;https://poll.qu.edu/national/release-detail?ReleaseID=2432&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;new poll from Quinnipiac&lt;/a&gt; found 54 percent oppose the repeal of Obamacare, while 43 percent support it. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At the same time, &lt;a href=&quot;https://poll.qu.edu/national/release-detail?ReleaseID=2431&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;another Quinnipiac poll&lt;/a&gt; last week found Trump’s approval rating at just 38 percent, while a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cbsnews.com/news/poll-immigration-is-most-important-problem-for-trump-and-congress/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;CBS News poll&lt;/a&gt; last week had the president’s approval rating at 39 percent. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Trump voters who want Obamacare&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kathy Watson, a Trump voter and cancer survivor from Lake City, Fla., told the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.latimes.com/politics/la-na-pol-obamacare-trump-voter-20170224-story.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Los Angeles Times&lt;/a&gt; last week that she would have “lost everything” without Obamacare.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Watson said she didn’t think Trump would follow through on his promise to get rid of the ACA. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I’ll give it a little more time,” she said, “but I’m not really sure about Trump anymore.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Watson’s story is not unique. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To the surprise of even some politicians, a significant crop of Trump voters across the nation want to keep their Obamacare and their Obamacare-backed Medicaid expansion.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While some Trump voters who have Obamacare complain that it’s too expensive and too complicated, evidently few people who have it want to lose it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In Grant County, Neb., Trump received more than 93 percent of the vote. But Grant also happens to be the county with the nation’s highest percentage of Obamacare enrollees.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One in three Grant County residents, or 33 percent of the under-65 population, bought insurance on Obamacare exchanges, according to a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/24/health/nebraska-trump-obamacare-aca-eprise/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;CNN report&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In Whitley County, Ky., where 82 percent of voters supported Trump in the presidential election, the uninsured rate has dropped from 25 percent in 2013 to 10 percent today because of Obamacare, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.vox.com/science-and-health/2016/12/13/13848794/kentucky-obamacare-trump&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Vox reported&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A new survey by the &lt;a href=&quot;http://kff.org/health-reform/issue-brief/listening-to-trump-voters-with-aca-coverage-what-they-want-in-a-health-care-plan/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Kaiser Family Foundation&lt;/a&gt; asked Trump voters who relied on Obamacare or Obamacare-backed Medicaid why they voted for Trump.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The answers varied.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some were simply not aware that their coverage through Medicaid expansion was the result of the ACA.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Others said they signed up for Obamacare because it was the best option available but were hoping Trump would reduce the costs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;People with cancer play the waiting game&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Meanwhile, people with cancer and cancer survivors nationwide, of all political persuasions, continue to watch the news and wait. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In Healthline interviews with more than two dozen people with cancer who are insured through Obamacare, the three most popular provisions in the law that they said any replacement plan should include are:&lt;/p&gt; &lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;the guarantee that coverage not be denied to people with preexisting conditions&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;the assurance that the lifetime dollar amount of an insurer’s coverage cannot be limited&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;the provision that it pays for preventative care such as mammograms, colonoscopies, and other tests &lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lisa Swanson, 58, a graphic designer from New Hampshire, wonders what the future has in store for her and her fellow cancer survivors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Swanson had a rare type of tumor called a pheochromocytoma on her right adrenal gland. She had the tumor surgically removed, along with the adrenal gland, in 2013. She now has insurance thanks to the ACA. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But if the law is repealed, she may lose coverage.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I dread finding out what the Republicans will decide is ‘good enough’ for those of us with preexisting conditions,” she said. “I’ve done everything I can to stay healthy. Now I just have to trust that the Republican Party will not pull the rug out from under my life.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Repeal would hit Hispanic-Americans hard &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The nation’s Hispanic cancer patient community is among the most vulnerable to a repeal or replacement of Obamacare, according to healthcare and insurance industry experts.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Department of Health and Human Services reports that the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cnbc.com/2016/05/17/obamacare-brings-record-low-for-us-health-uninsured-rate.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;uninsured rate among Hispanics&lt;/a&gt; has dropped by more than 25 percent since 2010, in large part because of the ACA.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Glenn Llopis of Healthy Hispanic Living, the first online preventive care educational platform targeted to U.S. Hispanics, told Healthline that prior to the ACA’s demands for patient satisfaction, there was no incentive for Hispanics to pay attention to their health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Hispanics do not always feel welcomed by the healthcare industry, they tend to associate doctors with hospitals and hospitals with a place to die, not get better.” said Llopis, who is author of the new book, “The Innovation Mentality.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Many first-generation Hispanics would rather have a major surgical procedure performed in their native countries than in the United States, Llopis said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He added that Hispanics are “often not proactive with their preventive care and thus disproportionately experience major health problems later in their lives. Without the ACA incentive, the threat to the U.S. economy and impact on global competitiveness will be catastrophic.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Exact national figures for Hispanic patients are not available, but, Llopis noted, “You don’t need to be a statistician to realize that if the Hispanic population increased by 243 percent between the 1980 and 2010 censuses, the number of Hispanic patients nationwide has only grown.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;‘The president is used to his lifestyle’&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Amelia Tena, 56, a Hispanic-American from Southern California, was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2004 and signed up for the ACA last month. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She was laid off from work last year and ended up with COBRA (Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1985), which she could not afford. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I don't know what kind of plan will be next, or if I will even be able to have health coverage,” she told Healthline. “My concerns are stressing me out. How will it be for cancer patients? Right now my copay is $75, and for me this is already high.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Tena doesn’t believe Trump or Congress have a plan that will help her the way the ACA has.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think the president is used to his lifestyle,” she said. “He's not thinking of the middle-class population. In reality, he wants to get all Mexicans out of the U.S.A.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;City of Hope offering advice&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mayra Serrano is the manager of the Center of Community Alliance for Research &amp;amp; Education (CCARE) at the City of Hope, a comprehensive cancer center in the Los Angeles area.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She said Obamacare’s provisions — including its preventative medicine provisions — have demonstrably improved the lives of Hispanic people with cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One of the best features of the ACA, Serrano said, is that it typically pays for screenings, scans, mammograms, Pap smears, colonoscopies, and other things people with cancer need but often can’t afford when there is a copay, or when they have no insurance. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“For people making minimum wage, $20 is a lot of money. It could come down to a choice between food and medicine,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If there is a repeal, Serrano said it is most likely that many Hispanic-Americans with lower incomes will no longer get screenings.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Colon cancer, cervical cancer, and other cancer diagnoses will then rise in these populations. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“A repeal could push public health back decades,” said Serrano.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She notes there is great fear in the Hispanic community over what Trump will do for Hispanics who signed up for Obamacare because many are in “mixed families” — meaning that some members of a family are undocumented while others are not.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But Serrano remains cautiously optimistic that Obamacare will be saved.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Cancer patients and others are telling their stories now, across the country,” she said. “It is making me more optimistic that it will not be repealed. But at this point, we just don’t know what will happen.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<updateddate>2017-02-27T15:00:00</updateddate>

<dc:creator>Jamie Reno</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-27T23:00:00</dc:date>
