<item>
<title>Pediatricians Issue Warning on Marijuana</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/pediatricians-issue-warning-on-marijuana
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/childrens-health/022717_pediatricianweed_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&
]]>
<![CDATA[
lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Marijuana is legal in some states, but it may be harmful to children.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s the message delivered in a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.aappublications.org/news/2017/02/27/Marijuana022717&quot;&gt;report&lt;/a&gt; released today by the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The organization urged doctors to warn parents that the drug may be harmful to children, even though it might seem acceptable, safe, and therapeutic. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Marijuana is not a benign drug, especially for teens. Their brains are still developing, and marijuana can cause abnormal and unhealthy changes,” Dr. Seth D. Ammerman, FAAP, co-author of the AAP report, said in a statement.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As it stands, 29 states have legalized some form of marijuana use. Eight states, along with the District of Columbia, have made recreational marijuana legal for adults over the age of 21. The other states have legalized medical marijuana. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Young people using marijuana regularly can experience decreased sensory awareness, weakened motor skill control and memory function, and impaired lung function. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The drug is also tied to mental disorders including psychosis, depression, and addiction, the AAP report states.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Specific concerns&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Much of the concern about marijuana’s harmfulness is due to the increase in the concentration of tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), which is a psychoactive substance in the plant.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the United States, the amount of THC found in marijuana surged from 4 percent in 1995, to &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.biologicalpsychiatryjournal.com/article/S0006-3223(16)00045-7/fulltext&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;12 percent in 2014&lt;/a&gt;. Some strains have as much as 20 percent THC.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This chemical is the same one that can lower pain and ease chemotherapy side effects. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The AAP is urging doctors to talk about using marijuana as well as screening kids for substance abuse. Parents who use it may not know about the impacts it can have on children, they say. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Seeing parents use marijuana makes kids more likely to use it themselves, whether or not their parents tell them not to, because actions speak louder than words,” Dr. Sheryl A. Ryan, lead author of the report, said in a statement. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How kids perceive marijuana&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2015, &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.samhsa.gov/data/hlcmsresource/NSDUH-FFR1-2015/NSDUH-FFR1-2015/NSDUH-FFR1-2015.htm#illicit02&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;7 percent&lt;/a&gt; of children aged 12 to 17 used marijuana.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The percentage of adolescent marijuana users was similar to percentages between 2004 and 2014. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Studies have shown that 9 percent of people who try marijuana become addicted to it. That number rises to 17 percent when the user starts during adolescence. It goes up to 50 percent among teens that consume marijuana on a daily basis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Correlating usage to confirm whether or not there has been an increase in use after a state legalizes the drug is where experts seem to disagree.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The AAP cited a National Survey on Drug Use and Health report that found the percentage of 12- to 17-year-olds who said there was a great risk to using marijuana decreased from 55 percent in 2007 to 41 percent in 2015.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/65/ss/ss6511a1.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;report&lt;/a&gt; of National Survey on Drug Use and Health (NSDUH) data states that the percentage of kids 12 to 17 who perceived the greatest risk from using it declined from 34 percent in 2006 to 24 percent in 2013.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;More legalization, more use?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Natalie Lyla Ginsberg, the policy and advocacy manager of the Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic Studies (MAPS), told Healthline that she was disappointed in the AAP’s “alarmist warning and avoidance of research.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ginsberg cited a National Academy of Medicine &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nap.edu/catalog/24625/the-health-effects-of-cannabis-and-cannabinoids-the-current-state&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;report&lt;/a&gt; that found heavy cannabis use among 12- to 17-year-olds was at 7 percent. A &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24223560&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2013 study&lt;/a&gt; mentioned in that report states that users were declining compared with older adults.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/65/ss/ss6511a1.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2016 CDC report&lt;/a&gt; stated that that cannabis use has declined among 12- to 17-year-olds since 2002. The report cites that kids 12 to 17 who used marijuana in the past month went up from 6.7 percent in 2006 to 7.1 percent in 2013. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ginsberg noted that Colorado’s data indicates that &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/colorado-s-teen-marijuana-usage-dips-after-legalization/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;teen marijuana use&lt;/a&gt; went down in the state since legalization.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kyle Sherman, chief executive officer of the point-of-sale tool Flowhub, told Healthline that his platform is geared at keeping minors out of dispensaries. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Here in Colorado we've seen &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/colorado-s-teen-marijuana-usage-dips-after-legalization/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;no increase&lt;/a&gt; in teen use since legalization,” Sherman said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He believes regulating cannabis will help get it off the streets and out of children’s hands.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There is no convincing evidence that cannabis use alone is harmful for children, but we also do not have enough research to assert that that means it is therefore safe,” Ginsberg added. “However, we do have research that medical cannabis is far safer than many less effective and more dangerous pharmaceuticals often prescribed for children.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She also noted that many of the AAP’s assertions about health impacts of marijuana on children do not take into account the whole picture. The AAP should focus screening on trauma and other stressors to children, instead of solely focusing on symptoms of trauma such as substance abuse, Ginsberg said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Guohua Li, a professor of epidemiology at Columbia University, said the AAP’s concerns and warning are justified. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“As a parent, I'm grateful to AAP for safeguarding the safety, health, and well-being of our children,” Li told Healthline. “There is an urgent need for federal, state, and local government agencies to monitor marijuana use and related consequences in children.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Li notes that the jury is still out as to whether legalization has caused an increase in marijuana use among kids, but there is mounting evidence that access to edibles has increased in children. A 2016 &lt;a href=&quot;http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamapediatrics/fullarticle/2534480&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; in JAMA Pediatrics&lt;em&gt; &lt;/em&gt;found an increase in children being exposed to the drug in Colorado, where edibles are legal.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What’s next?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Marcus Bachhuber, an assistant professor of medicine at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York, said that because legalization is a reality, it’s time to focus on how to regulate marijuana programs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“How best can we allow access for patients who could benefit while protecting kids and promoting public health?” he told Healthline. “Physicians have a key role to play in shaping policy and the overall debate, but all too often, we have decided to watch from the sidelines.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The AAP’s report comes about a week after President Donald Trump’s press secretary &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cbsnews.com/news/trump-administration-threat-recreational-marijuana-industry-colorado/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Sean Spicer&lt;/a&gt; spoke about cracking down on marijuana regulations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While the president has said he approves of medicinal uses, federal laws still consider marijuana use to be illegal.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Children's Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-02-27T15:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-27T15:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/pediatricians-issue-warning-on-marijuana
</guid>
<dc:creator>Kristen Fischer</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-27T23:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Randy Travis’ Long Road Back</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/randy-travis-long-road-back
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/022717_randytravis_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For a few minutes, it seemed like it was the last night of country western singer Randy Travis’ life.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Suffocating from his fluid-filled lungs while his heart was failing, Travis flatlined.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He was put on life support and into an induced coma.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When he was conscious again, doctors found that sometime between dying and waking he suffered a stroke.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;His wife was told he probably wouldn’t survive and if he did he’d be bedridden as well as in and out of hospitals for what was left of his life.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Honey, you have to let me know you want to keep fighting,” Mary said at his bedside.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She saw a tear slide down his face and he squeezed her hand. She knew then that Randy would battle back. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“He and God had other plans,” she said. “His faith got him through what he got through. When a lot of people gave up on him he didn’t give up on himself.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Long road back&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Now Travis, 57, is on a marathon road to recovery that has lasted nearly four years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He struggled to relearn how to walk and to partially regain use of the right side of his body. The blood clot had lodged in the part of his brain that controls those muscles and dominates the use of language.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The words he’d strung into song — resulting in 25 million records sold, 22 number one hits, and eight Grammy Awards — no longer can make it from his brain to his lips because of a disorder called aphasia. It’s caused by brain trauma and it makes using words a struggle.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If he could just talk to me one more time and tell me the stories that must be going through his mind,” said Mary.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While Travis understands what he hears, his own voice has been more difficult to find. Usually he speaks singular words or a simple “yup” and “nope.” He is skilled enough with one-word conversations that he can tell jokes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The disorder also impacts the written word, although just recently, he read “Nashville” off a road sign as he and his wife drove into town for a tribute concert in his honor.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Music has come back to him more easily.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While he can’t strum the notes on his guitar with his weaker right hand, the music is so ingrained in him that Travis can chord every song on his guitar.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And although he can’t speak in a full sentence, he can mouth every single word to thousands of songs. “Amazing Grace” has become his personal anthem, and he can sing those verses despite the aphasia.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Travis sang it publicly for the first time in October when he accepted his induction into the Country Music Hall of Fame, stunning the audience and his fellow artists.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Surviving infections, surgery&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;That evening was a bright moment among many struggles since that fateful day on July 7, 2013.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Travis’ fight to survive included three tracheotomies, collapsed lungs, numerous intubations and IVs until his veins collapsed. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He was fed through a tube and dropped to less than 100 pounds. He had emergency brain surgery. Half of his scalp was removed and stored in his abdomen to keep the skin alive.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And there were infections, including staph, pseudomonas, serratia, and three bouts of pneumonia.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It was just one thing after another that you never thought you’d live through or learn about,” said Mary. “It was a crash course for me. We were going through life at 100 miles per hour and hit a brick wall.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Travis was listed for a heart transplant, but his heart healed “by the grace of God,” Mary said. Doctors told the couple that it had likely failed because of a virus that caused&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2770911/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;dilated cardiomyopathy&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Piecing together how that could have happened, the doctors told Mary that it likely&amp;nbsp;occurred during filming of the movie “Christmas on the Bayou” a few weeks earlier.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Travis had filmed during hot, humid days in an old feed store in Opelousas, La., possibly breathing in molds and spores.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With his heart back, Travis did rehabilitation more than four hours a day in a blur of setbacks and successes. A fear of immediate death was replaced by a fear of a slower one over the six months he spent in the hospital.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Giant baby steps” punctuated his recovery, said Mary.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Raising awareness&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Today, Travis is taking a break from the relentlessness of therapy and is spending his days at his ranch with his wife, dogs, horses, and cattle. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He and Mary attend fellow artists’ concerts so he can hear the music he loves and encourage&amp;nbsp;his contemporaries.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He’s also now using his energy and fame for raising awareness and money for stroke research. He’s “passing out hope” by showing what is possible to other stroke patients, said Mary.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He’s appeared before Tennessee legislators and at a recent tribute concert in Nashville given in his honor.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And on Mar. 25, Travis will make a guest appearance at a&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href=&quot;http://attstadium.com/events/beauty-kind&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;BeautyKind Unites Concert for a Cause&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;at AT&amp;amp;T Stadium near Dallas, where the Cowboys play. The event will help raise money for the American Heart Association, River Ranch Randy Travis Fund, and other charitable organizations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Travis, who once was given no hope and no chance of survival, wants people to know that there is still life after stroke.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The point is to show “stroke victims they don’t have to be victims,” said Mary.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;The &lt;/em&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/after-flatlining-and-years-of-therapy-country-music-star-randy-travis-is-passing-out-hope/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;original story&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;em&gt; was published on &lt;/em&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;American Heart Association News&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;em&gt;.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<item>
<title>‘Fake News’ Is Also Plaguing the World of Science</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/fake-news-plaguing-world-of-science
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/022417_fakenews_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The political arena isn’t the only place where “fake news” is being debated.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Scientists are now speaking out about false information and “alternative facts” that they say are diluting and harming legitimate research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To be sure, there has always been phony scientific material from snake oil salesmen to industry-sponsored research to tabloid headlines.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, experts interviewed by Healthline say the advent of the internet and the popularity of social media have made it easier for fraudulent information to spread.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The topic is worrisome enough that the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.aaas.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS)&lt;/a&gt; made it part of their agenda at their annual meeting last weekend in Boston.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The new media environment has allowed this type of information to be disseminated,” Dominique Brossard, PhD, a life sciences communication professor at the University of Wisconsin-Madison who spoke at the conference, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Types of bad information&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are several packages in which false information is delivered.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some are simply outright lies promulgated by people with an agenda.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Others are part of research funded by industry to skew results and opinions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And yet another segment is questionable research that receives widespread attention.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some are a combination of these factors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One of the best examples from the past is the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ucdmc.ucdavis.edu/welcome/features/20071114_cardio-tobacco/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;tobacco industry&lt;/a&gt;, which for decades funded research that cast doubt on whether cigarette smoking and secondhand smoke were bad for your health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;/health/sugar/big-fat-lies-sugar-propaganda&quot;&gt;sugar industry&lt;/a&gt; has also been accused of propping up studies that downplayed the health hazards of consuming sweetened foods and beverages.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“All an industry needs to do is create some uncertainty,” Kevin Elliott, PhD, an associate professor at Michigan State University, who also spoke at the AAAS meeting, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sometimes the tainted research isn’t easy to spot.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Earlier this month, a &lt;a href=&quot;http://online.liebertpub.com/doi/full/10.1089/aivt.2016.0024&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; was released that concluded lung inflammation was far less serious in e-cigarette smokers than it was in people who smoked regular cigarettes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The research was funded by British American Tobacco.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Why would this organization fund a study that had negative results for regular cigarettes? Turns out the &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/tobacco-companies-taking-over-e-cigarette&quot;&gt;tobacco industry worldwide&lt;/a&gt; is getting into the e-cigarette market.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Faulty research can also receive widespread attention.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 1998, a British doctor named Andrew Wakefield published a study in The Lancet that linked autism to the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, that study only included a small sample size of 12 individuals, and a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3136032/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;number of conflicts&lt;/a&gt; were eventually uncovered involving Wakefield and his colleagues.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Lancet retracted the study in 2010, but it still is quoted by some anti-vaccination organizations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In September 2012, a study was widely publicized that linked genetically modified corn and the herbicide Roundup to tumor growth.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study was retracted in 2013 but then &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cbsnews.com/news/study-on-genetically-modified-corn-herbicide-and-tumors-reignites-controversy/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;republished in another journal&lt;/a&gt; in 2014.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Brossard said these types of studies have led to the creation of a blog called &lt;a href=&quot;http://retractionwatch.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Retraction Watch&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She said the online column reports on 500 to 600 retractions a year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Spreading the word&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The problem isn’t just the questionable research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s also how quickly and widely the information can spread.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Elliott and Brossard note that anyone can have a website in today’s world, and even former Playboy playmates like &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.buzzfeed.com/ellievhall/11-things-that-jenny-mccarthy-has-said-about-vaccines?utm_term=.tbzMbe2Ao#.nrw9j6QbG&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Jenny McCarthy&lt;/a&gt; can become experts on vaccines and autism.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On those sites, people can post and share whatever material they deem to be worthy and accurate.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, sites such as Facebook can add to the problem.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Those social media sites track what information a person is interested in and feeds them more of the same. So, someone who thinks the coal industry doesn’t pollute the air will see more material along those same lines.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Laura Boxley, PhD, director of clinical neuropsychology training, and assistant professor-clinical in the&amp;nbsp;Departments of&amp;nbsp;Psychiatry and Behavioral Health, Neurology, and Psychology at The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center, said this type of information can be more appealing to those reading it than accurate information.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Real science is not sexy and fancy. It’s slow and steady,” she told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This “confirmation bias” can produce and validate a person’s one-sided view.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There is a lot of danger in accepting only one scientist’s opinion,” said Elliott.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Beyond hardening an individual’s belief, scientific “fake news” can also affect government policy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Climate change is one high-profile example with a new president who, in the past, has proclaimed that the scientifically proven phenomenon is really just a “&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2016/jun/03/hillary-clinton/yes-donald-trump-did-call-climate-change-chinese-h/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;hoax&lt;/a&gt;.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The consequences are important,” said Brossard.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Alternative facts in science,” added Elliott, “facilitate alternate facts in politics.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What can be done?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Experts are urging several courses of action to stop or slow the spread of false scientific information.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;First, they say scientists need to do a better job of communicating their research to the public.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Spouting off data and technical terms isn’t going to get it done.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They add society should start teaching teenagers in middle school and high school how real science works. That way they’ll be able to spot phony research when they’re adults.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Teaching this early builds lifelong skills,” said Boxley.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This highlights the importance of developing a sophisticated citizenry,” added Elliott.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The experts also urge the country to better fund and better respect places where real scientific work is done.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We need to double down on our institutions,” said Boxley.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Finally, they urge the public to avoid the temptation to share dubious information on social media.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s really hard to break that echo chamber,” said Brossard.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, she said, search engines such as Google should eliminate research that has been debunked from its system.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She pointed out that Wakefield’s vaccine study can still be called up.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Institutions, she added, can also monitor the internet and then perform “damage control” if they see incorrect information out there.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Strange Science</category>
<pubdate>2017-02-26T09:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-26T09:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/fake-news-plaguing-world-of-science
</guid>
<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-26T17:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Loving Yourself Can Help You Battle MS</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/loving-yourself-helps-battle-ms
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/022517_loveMS_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Have you loved yourself today?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Because now there is scientific proof that loving yourself may actually help your multiple sclerosis (MS).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/13548506.2016.1238492?scroll=top&amp;amp;needAccess=true&amp;amp;&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2016 study&lt;/a&gt;, researchers concluded that the quality of intimate relationships was strongly associated with self-concept and illness acceptance.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This, they said, suggested that self-concept could be used to contribute to better outcomes for those with MS.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While self-concept, the knowledge one has about themselves, is &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.qub.ac.uk/sites/media/Media,366009,en.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;different&lt;/a&gt; than self-esteem, the overall attitude one takes toward themselves can benefit those with MS.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Using self-love&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;One way to improve both self-esteem and self-concept is to shower yourself with love.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Literally tell yourself how awesome you are, over and over, in a loving, positive way.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.jbiomeds.com/biomedical-sciences/new-frontiers-in-the-treatment-of-mentalwar-disorders-and-posttraumatic-disorder-by-repeating-phrases-of-positive-thoughts-trppt-o.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; that covered post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and Syrian refugees, patients with MS saw that self-esteem and satisfaction with life were &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/13548506.2016.1238492?scroll=top&amp;amp;needAccess=true&amp;amp;&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;significantly improved&lt;/a&gt; after the use of repetitive positive reinforcement.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In general, researchers in the PTSD study said Treatment by Repeating Phrases of Positive Thought, or TRPPT, had a positive effect on people with MS with life factors such as stress and anxiety. TRPPT also shows significant success in helping decrease depressive symptoms. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;By thinking positively, people who perceive stress as less threatening are able to cope with it more effectively, while people who think negatively do not expect things to go as planned and tend to anticipate bad outcomes. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, TRPPT is free, has no side effects or limits, and is even accessible in places like war-torn Syria.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Helping people with MS&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Strategies like TRPPT could benefit people with MS in particular because studies indicate there are high levels of depression among people with the disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One study looked at the first year after an MS diagnosis and the associated &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/13548506.2016.1274043&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;psychological impact&lt;/a&gt;. Many people with MS chose to avoid the illness, pretending they were not sick.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, the study showed a high prevalence of depression. It also showed a reduction in quality of life as a result of lower self-concept and psychological well-being.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to one &lt;a href=&quot;http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/pdf/10.1177/1352458506070926&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt;, there are two questions you need to ask to determine if you need a hug. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;ol&gt;&lt;li&gt;During the past two weeks, have you often been bothered by feeling down, depressed, or hopeless?&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;During the past two weeks, have you often been bothered by little interest or pleasure in doing things?&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ol&gt; &lt;p&gt;Answering “Yes” to one or both of these questions could signify some depression, a common and serious emotion that should be discussed with your doctor.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When people struggle with physical discomfort, it’s not uncommon to experience feeling depressed or a lack of motivation. Especially with MS, when you don’t know exactly when the next flare-up will occur, it can be hard to keep your head up.” &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.drjenniferjones.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Jennifer Johnston-Jones&lt;/a&gt;, PhD, a psychologist in Southern California, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Often people turn toward Band-Aid treatments such as medication or distractions such as overuse of television, social media, or not committing to the work they are meant to do. Instead, one can focus their efforts on strategies that increase their self-concept and self-worth which will naturally decrease depression.” Jones added. “Some of these strategies include: doing a daily gratitude journal, doing things a little out of your comfort zone, and sharing your vulnerability with others.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Stress on relationships&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Having MS can also affect your relationships — creating situations that may require people to seek professional help.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One program based in Colorado, &lt;a href=&quot;http://ijmsc.org/doi/abs/10.7224/1537-2073.2012-002?code=cmsc-site&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Relationship Matters (RM)&lt;/a&gt;, is a relationship enrichment program that integrates information and resources of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society with marriage education.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The National MS Society has a variety of &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nationalmssociety.org/Resources-Support/Library-Education-Programs/You-CAN/Fan-the-Flame&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;tips&lt;/a&gt; to help flame the romance.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One is to create rituals and traditions. Make it a habit to acknowledge and celebrate your relationship.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another is to find ways to express caring and appreciation in your relationship every day. It could be as simple as a gentle stroke on the cheek.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Loving yourself can also help. Being positive can help traditional medicines &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5221550/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;work better&lt;/a&gt; due primarily to better adherence, while depression was associated with a lower likelihood of adherence.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;MS takes a lot of &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3883007/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;self-management&lt;/a&gt;, according to a study at the University of Washington, and part of this is the ability to love oneself and to love others.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Editor’s Note: Caroline Craven is a patient expert living with MS. Her award winning blog is GirlwithMS.com, and she can be found @thegirlwithms.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Multiple Sclerosis</category>
<pubdate>2017-02-25T09:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-25T09:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/loving-yourself-helps-battle-ms
</guid>
<dc:creator>Caroline Craven</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-25T17:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Exercising in Your 40s, 50s, 60s, and Beyond</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/exercising-in-40s-50s-60s-beyond
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/022417_exerciseolder_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;You
]]>
<![CDATA[
’re getting older.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And with aging comes a certain amount of change, especially when it comes to your body.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Activities that you could easily do in your 20s now require a bit of caution — if not a note of permission from your primary care physician.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Luckily, you can continue to be physically active well into your golden years, provided you’ve established a good foundation early on.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And even if you haven’t, it’s never too late to get (back) into shape. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Exercise is the ultimate anti-aging treatment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers are emphatic about the &lt;a href=&quot;https://uic.pure.elsevier.com/en/publications/exercise-and-physical-activity-for-older-adults&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;correlation&lt;/a&gt; between exercising and fitness and the body and mind, contributing to a decreased prevalence of injury, illness, and other negative aspects of getting older.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Here’s how to combat the effects of growing older and achieve peak performance condition no matter what your age. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Exercising in your 30s&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;With your &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.lung.org/lung-health-and-diseases/how-lungs-work/lung-capacity-and-aging.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;stamina and bone densities&lt;/a&gt; at their peaks, now is the perfect time to lay the foundation for a long-term relationship with fitness.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Your league sports games and pickup matches may be less frequent, but that should allow you the time and energy for other activities.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;High intensity cross training or circuit training with cardio and resistance (i.e., weights) will help you develop overall fitness, which may be lacking if you have always participated in just one or two sports.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It will also help prevent injuries.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Exercise in &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.fitday.com/fitness-articles/fitness/strength-training/how-endurance-strength-training-can-benefit-your-health.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;intense bursts&lt;/a&gt; at 80 to 95 percent of your max, interspersed with recovery pauses to allow your heart rate to return to normal.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;High intensity interval training (HIIT) has been shown to be &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/how-long-to-get-in-shape&quot;&gt;more effective than prolonged&lt;/a&gt; cardio-only training. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Women, in particular, should start prioritizing intense strength training as &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nytimes.com/1999/01/19/health/law-of-diminishing-returns-for-athletes.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;marathon treadmill sessions&lt;/a&gt; won’t be as effective as they once were.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Aim to exercise five times a week with one day reserved for high intensity cardio (at least 45 minutes). Switch your routine up often to avoid diminishing returns, and plan for a once-a-week rest day.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Your exercise regimen should also include balance and flexibility training. This will become more important as you age. Low-impact activities like yoga, tai chi, and dancing integrate stretching and breath work into movement. (Bonus: yoga, for one, has been proven to &lt;a href=&quot;http://online.liebertpub.com/doi/abs/10.1089/acm.2007.6338&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;stave off depression&lt;/a&gt; by increasing your brain’s GABA levels.)&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Just don’t let up&lt;/strong&gt;: Your metabolism has already begun &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/wellness/basal-metabolic-rate-changes-as-you-age/2013/03/05/d26b1c18-80f1-11e2-a350-49866afab584_story.html?utm_term=.12591abea599&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;slowing down&lt;/a&gt;, requiring doing more exercise and taking in fewer calories to avoid putting on fat.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Don’t leave proper form at the gym&lt;/strong&gt;: Walk upright, focusing on keeping your abs activated to avoid hunching later in life. And &lt;em&gt;always&lt;/em&gt; take the stairs. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Featured exercise: Burpees&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These full-body exercises will quickly and efficiently wear you out (in a good way). They require no special equipment — all you need is a timer — and can be done just about anywhere. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Get into a squat and position your hands on the floor in front of you.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kick your feet straight back while lowering yourself into the “down” part of a pushup, arms bent at 90 degrees.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Jump your feet back to their original position while pushing your torso up with your arms.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;From the squat, jump straight up, as high as possible, reaching your arms toward the ceiling or sky.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Come back down into a squat and repeat the series of movements, moving from one position to the next as quickly as possible. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Start by doing 20 seconds of burpees, resting for 10 seconds, and repeating eight times, for a total of four minutes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Extend the amount of time you spend moving between rest periods or increase the total amount of time you spend doing the exercises.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Exercising in your 40s&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Welcome to the official start of middle age.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A combination of more time sitting at a desk job, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.today.com/health/confronting-between-decade-2D&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;hormonal changes&lt;/a&gt;, and a naturally occurring muscle mass loss — with men dropping &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3940510/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;5 to 8 percent&lt;/a&gt; of their muscle mass every decade after they turn 40 — makes for a slower metabolism and the seemingly inevitable middle-aged paunch, increasing the chances for a bad lower back.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On top of that, your fat distribution will change internally, putting additional weight on and around your organs and increasing the risks of heart disease, diabetes, and cancer. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The good news?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;You still have great potential to reverse decades of aging and improve your body shape while upping your energy levels.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In fact, &lt;a href=&quot;http://jap.physiology.org/content/98/4/1154.short&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;regular exercise&lt;/a&gt; will ward off cardiovascular disease and diabetes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Keep up a consistent exercise regimen to preserve lean muscle mass and keep fat gains minimal. Even 10 minutes of activity is better than none.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Continue training with weights three to four times a week, and up the cardio to five times a week, reserving one day for rest.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In terms of strength training, remember quality over quantity. Focus on doing the movements slowly and with control.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Now is the time to make stretching a priority. Invest a few bucks in a foam roller. It will help with your flexibility by loosening and relaxing muscles.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Maintaining or improving flexibility will be crucial in the years ahead.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Featured exercise: Squat&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A staple of most gym workouts, the squat directly affects the large muscles of your legs — quads, hamstrings, and calves — and also promotes overall muscle gain which in turn helps burn fat. Squats also help improve your balance and mobility. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lower yourself down by bending your knees, pushing your hips back, until your thighs are at least perpendicular with the floor.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Keep your back flat and avoid allowing your knees to move forward beyond the length of your feet.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Pause at the bottom, then activate your leg muscles to raise yourself back up. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Initially, your bodyweight will be sufficient as you learn to perform the movements with proper form and control. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With time you can add intensity by positioning a barbell across your shoulders or holding dumbbells in both hands.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Exercising in your 50s&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;You are likely experiencing more drooping as you lose muscle tone and your shoulders start to &lt;a href=&quot;http://medical-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;hunch forward&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Focus on saving your back by strengthening your core muscles and keeping good posture. Yoga and Pilates are helpful for both.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;You may also discover that the soreness and fatigue the day after a workout is becoming more than occasional.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some activities may exacerbate pain, so alter your exercise routine accordingly rather than letting it discourage you from exercising at all.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If your knees are bothering you from running, try riding a bike or swimming instead. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;You will also need additional recovery time after a hard workout, so go easy — aim to exercise more frequently but with a moderate level of intensity. Ideally, get in a half-hour of cardio every day. Studies show that regular exercise will &lt;a href=&quot;http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamainternalmedicine/article-abstract/607859&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;increase your aerobic capacity&lt;/a&gt;, keeping your muscles and lungs healthy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Train with weights twice a week and develop an affinity for the kettlebell as it is good for complex exercises.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Be fanatical about stretching hard after every workout. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Featured exercise: Sun Salutations&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A Sun Salutation — Surya Namaskar, in Sanskrit — is a specific series of yoga poses that flow from one to the next. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Typically used as a warmup in yoga classes, Sun Salutations stretch and strengthen all the major muscle groups. Linking movements to breathing also helps reduce stress.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Stand with your feet hip-width apart.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Press your palms together in front of your chest.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sweep your arms out and overhead while inhaling.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Exhale as you fold forward at your hips, reaching your hands toward the floor and bending your knees as necessary.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Inhale as you lift your torso up halfway, bringing your back to parallel with the floor, open palms pointed toward your shins.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Exhale as you step your feet back one at a time or jump both feet back together to come to a plank pose, continuing to exhale as you lower your body to the floor by bending your elbows.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Inhale as you straighten your arms, extending your chest forward, and drawing your shoulders back.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Exhale as you lift your hips, pushing down with your hands and feet to lengthen your spine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Take five breaths.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On your last exhalation, bend your knees and look forward between your hands. Inhale as you step or jump your feet in between your hands and again lift your back halfway, bringing your back parallel with the floor and pointing your fingers toward your shins.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Exhale as you fold forward at your hips, again reaching your hands towards the floor and bending your knees as necessary.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Inhale as you sweep your arms out and overhead. Exhale as you bring your palms together in front of your chest. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Repeat.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Exercising in your 60s&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Although you may still be planning to become a world-class bodybuilder or swimsuit model at 65, your goal should now be prevention — preventing disease, such as diabetes and heart disease, falling, and frailty.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Regular exercise is still the way to go, with emphasis on maintaining balance and strength.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Weight training is a must, ideally three times a week, alternating between upper and lower body muscle groups and using light weights. Your bones are a bit &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK45503/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;more fragile&lt;/a&gt; and the tendons and ligaments holding you together aren’t as supple as they once were, so be careful. Better yet, work with a professional trainer to avoid injury. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Low-impact group exercise classes like Zumba and water aerobics will get your blood flowing without adding strain. And working out with others should make for comradery and accountability around working out.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Group walks, for instance, have been shown to have &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.uea.ac.uk/about/media-room/press-release-archive/-/asset_publisher/a2jEGMiFHPhv/content/uea-research-shows-group-walking-cuts-risk-of-life-threatening-conditions&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;additional health benefits&lt;/a&gt; when compared with solo walking. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Aim for three days a week of moderately intense cardio.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If you run, take heart: an hour-and-a-half of slow to moderately paced jogging over the course of the week could &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2012-05/esoc-rjs050212.php&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;increase your life expectancy&lt;/a&gt; by as much as five years, according to research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Incorporate balance exercises and stretch, stretch, stretch. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Featured exercise: Single-leg deadlift&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Isolateral exercises like the single-leg deadlift work one side of the body at a time, as opposed to training both sides at once.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This allows training to continue around an injury and also corrects strength asymmetries. Most importantly, they improve general balance and equilibrium. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Stand on one leg, firmly planting your toes and heel into the floor.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Slightly bend your standing leg as you extend your free leg behind you, leaning forward with your torso and reaching your arms towards the floor.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Continue to lower yourself until your torso is parallel to the floor. Lift yourself back up slowly and with control. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Increase intensity by adding a weight — a kettlebell is ideal. Hold the weight in the hand on the same side as your standing leg, lowering it in front of you as you bend down.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Return the weight to your side as you return to the upright position.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Exercising past age 70&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Exercise is beneficial at every age. Continuing to work on your strength, flexibility, and balance will keep you spry and independent long past 70.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt; It will also help you &lt;a href=&quot;http://newsroom.cumc.columbia.edu/blog/2007/03/12/new-reason-to-hit-the-gym-fighting-memory-loss-3/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;retain your memories&lt;/a&gt;, according to a recent study. And though your morning constitutional walk is a perfectly fine starting point, don’t stop there.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Incorporate stretching and working light weights and resistance bands into your regimen. Staying strong will increase your chances of surviving a fall; women in their 60s and 70s have a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3048257/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;five-fold chance&lt;/a&gt; of dying within a year of suffering a hip fracture.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When working out, be sure to check in with yourself when you experience pain as it may necessitate changing up your exercises. If the pain continues, visit your doctor.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Featured exercise: Heal-to-toe walk&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Improving your balance and stability will decrease your chances of falling and make going up and down steps easier.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If you feel unsteady on your feet, do this exercise alongside a wall so you can steady yourself as necessary. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Position the heel of one foot directly in front of the toes of the other foot so your feet are nearly touching.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Focus on a spot ahead of you and take a step, placing your moving foot’s heel directly in front of the toes of your stationary foot.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Repeat.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<dc:creator>Matt Schneiderman</dc:creator>

<item>
<title>Stimulant Drugs Can Prematurely Age the Heart</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/stimulant-drugs-prematurely-age-heart
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/heart-health/022317_amphetamine_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In a well-known Oscar Wilde novel, Dorian Gray retains his youthful good looks while his portrait progressively shows the hideous effects of a wantonly dissolute lifestyle.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Abusers of “speed,” “ice,” or other amphetamines might take note: Their outsides might look fine, but their cardiovascular systems show greater aging than the arteries of those smoking tobacco or using the heroin substitute methadone, according to a new study.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;An investigative team led by Dr. Stuart Reece, a clinical associate professor at the University of Western Australia, published their findings February 9 in the online journal Heart Asia.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study included more than 700 Australian participants in their 30s and 40s.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Using radial arterial pulse tonometry, researchers measured the stiffness of participants’ arteries, which is a sign of aging. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers compared 55 amphetamine-exposed patients with 107 tobacco smokers, 483 nonsmokers, and 68 methadone patients who visited a substance misuse clinic from 2006 to 2011. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For each participant, they determined a cardiovascular-biological age (VA).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The research team said the findings demonstrate that “recurrent habitual amphetamine abuse ages the cardiovasculature, and likely the whole organism generally,” according to a news release.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They added that the new study is further evidence of the importance of tackling the “global stimulant epidemic.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Unclear if damage is reversible&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We were expecting these results,” Reece said in an interview with Healthline. “Amphetamines are known to damage the cardiovascular system in both short- and long-term ways.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Stimulant abuse is associated with stroke, aneurysms, and cardiac arrhythmias, among other problems.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Reece said this was the first time hardening of the arteries was measured.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Cardiovascular aging is a surrogate measure for the whole organism,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers could not say if this damage is reversible.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Clinicians out in the field look at this issue up close. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Amphetamines “are both prescribed and abused,” said Dr. Christopher Bull Granger, professor of medicine, professor in the school of nursing, and member of the Duke Clinical Research Institute in North Carolina. “This is a real issue,” he told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These drugs “may be good for [students’] academic performance, but there are real risks,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Amphetamines are stimulants, hence their popularity as study aids. They can cause effects such as elevated heart rate and blood pressure, and increased risk of heart attack, stroke, and aneurysm rupture.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Since the new study was observational, it didn’t establish a direct cause-and-effect relationship between amphetamine use and cardiovascular aging. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It also didn’t provide information on the dose of amphetamines that may prematurely age the heart. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ninety-four percent of the study participants who used amphetamines had done so in the week prior to testing. The effects of amphetamine exposure persisted after adjustment for all known cardiovascular risk factors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For Reece, the study is one part of a larger picture: The quest to understand — and reverse — aging.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We’ve measured arterial stiffness,” he said. “We need to look at molecular levels of aging.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Reversing aging is one of the Holy Grails of modern medicine, and each new discovery is important.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Granger, who is also a spokesman for the American Heart Association, paints a picture of stimulant drug use. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Amphetamine use can be harmful to the heart, particularly for patients who have underlying risk factors,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Generally drugs that stimulate the nervous system, including the adrenal glands, can be harmful. They directly administer a toxin to the heart, they overstimulate it, and wear it out.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“What’s more,” he added, “they contribute to risk factors like high blood pressure.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“As a person gets older, overstimulation is bad for the heart,” Granger explained. “Some drugs, like cocaine, can cause a heart attack or increase other risk factors and contribute to cardiac arrhythmia.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Risks of other stimulant drugs&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other drugs such as Adderall also present a potential danger. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Adderall contains a combination of amphetamine and dextroamphetamine, which are central nervous system stimulants that affect chemicals in the brain and nerves that contribute to hyperactivity and impulse control.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It can cause side effects other than withdrawal or crashing. Taking Adderall in high doses is called chronic intoxication and can cause feelings of euphoria and excitement. This can lead to addiction.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other side effects of taking the drug at a high dosage include a skin condition, insomnia, hyperactivity, irritability, and changes in personality.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Granger notes that clinicians don’t have measurable proof that Adderall is harmful. “It’s relatively safe,” he said, “but there’s still some risk.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Those risks increase when the drug is overused, he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other drugs, like asthma drugs used as inhalers, are stimulants as well, Granger said. “There have been reports that asthma drugs may increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmia. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Drugs that stimulate the adrenals are a big public health issue,” he said, urging caution and awareness of risks.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But the picture is not entirely bleak. There are some ways “we can reverse aging,” Reece said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The most significant and meaningful way of undoing arterial damage is with plenty of exercise — better than any pill, according to Reece.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Research shows that drugs make people old [and] fat,&quot; he said.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Sort of like Dorian Gray.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-02-23T11:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-23T11:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/stimulant-drugs-prematurely-age-heart
</guid>
<dc:creator>Roberta Alexander</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-23T19:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Adult RA and Juvenile Arthritis May Be More Similar Than Once Thought
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/adult-ra-juvenile-arthritis-similar
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/arthritis/022317_adultpediatricRA_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Are rheumatoid arthritis and juvenile rheumatoid arthritis simply the same illness diagnosed at different life stages?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The answer isn’t as clear-cut as rheumatologists, patients, and researchers might think.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Juvenile arthritis (JA) — also known as juvenile rheumatoid arthritis, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.arthritis.org/about-arthritis/types/pediatric-rheumatic-diseases/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;pediatric arthritis&lt;/a&gt;, and juvenile idiopathic arthritis — is the sixth most common childhood disease, but it’s often misdiagnosed or undiagnosed. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One reason for this is due to the misconception that “arthritis” only affects an older portion of the population. Another problem is the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.arthritis.org/advocate/our-policy-priorities/access-to-care/increase-access-to-pediatric-rheumatologists/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;national shortage&lt;/a&gt; of pediatric rheumatology specialists.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There is also the issue that the umbrella term “juvenile arthritis” actually encompasses several unique childhood rheumatologic diseases. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Furthering the confusion surrounding JA is whether or not it is actually a separate and distinct disease from rheumatoid arthritis (RA) or if it is simply early-onset or pediatric RA, meaning, the same disease diagnosed at a younger age.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Researchers may have found link&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://ard.bmj.com/content/early/2016/12/20/annrheumdis-2016-210025&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;new study&lt;/a&gt; may provide some clarity and guidance about the JA vs. RA conundrum.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In it, researchers say a genetic link has been found between JA and RA. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It was already known among pediatric rheumatologists that some kinds of juvenile idiopathic arthritis have adult counterparts.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Past research also showed that there was a genetic link between juvenile idiopathic arthritis and a chromosomal abnormality, but the sample sizes were weak. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the new study, genetic associations within juvenile idiopathic arthritis categories were compared with adult inflammatory arthritis. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to a press release about the study, “A major finding was that there were within-category associations for juvenile idiopathic arthritis. Specifically, the study team found that rheumatoid factor (RF)-negative polyarticular and oligoarticular were genetically similar. Comparisons with adult disease showed a shared association of human leucocyte antigen-DRB1 amino acid at position 13 for both child-onset and adult diseases. Moreover, researchers found that associations from a combined dataset for juvenile idiopathic arthritis types oligoarthritis and RF-negative polyarthritis were the same associations seen in adult seronegative rheumatoid arthritis.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The authors of the study added, “The results of this study have important implications for understanding disease pathogenesis, aetiology, and potential future therapeutic strategies for JIA categories,” but they note that more genetic research will need to be done into JA.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Could research lead to treatments?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;But it is possible that these findings may eventually provide better, more targeted novel treatment therapies for JA and RA patients alike.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Or at least may open up treatment options to JA patients who have been limited by the “juvenile” component of their diagnosis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The report states that, “There are no specific therapeutic strategies for seronegative RA at this time, but given the rarity of this subphenotype of RA and the JIA categories individually, this study suggests that further comparisons of genetic studies for these diseases could help identify novel pathways and targets for therapy for both adult-onset and childhood-onset forms of inflammatory arthritis.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to an &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.hss.edu/conditions_arthritis-children-adolescents.asp&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;article&lt;/a&gt; in The Hospital for Special Surgery, “For more than 95 percent of the children with arthritis, we don't need new drugs or miraculous inventions, we just need proper application of the resources we already have.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But a missed JA diagnosis or delayed treatment can be catastrophic, as evidenced by &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/2801846/five-year-old-boy-died-crippling-arthritis/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;recent reports&lt;/a&gt; out of the United Kingdom.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The same can be said for adult-onset RA.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Whether they share these genetic commonalities or not, both diseases are among the most disabling in their respective age demographic — and both can affect more than bones and joints.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Arthritis</category>
<pubdate>2017-02-23T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-23T10:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/adult-ra-juvenile-arthritis-similar
</guid>
<dc:creator>Ashley Boynes-Shuck</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-23T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Donate an Egg, Become Infertile</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/donate-egg-become-infertile
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/womens-health/022317_eggdonors_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&l
]]>
<![CDATA[
t;p&gt;I was 24 years old when I donated my eggs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The first time was in June 2007. The second was January 2008.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I’d seen fliers across my college campus for years soliciting egg donors, but it wasn’t until a friend of mine went through the process herself that I became interested.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I liked the idea of helping an infertile couple build the family they yearned for. I was about to graduate college, so the money attached to egg donation seemed like a good way to start tackling my student loan debt. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Perhaps most importantly, I believed agency officials when they told me that egg donation was a simple and safe process.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I was deemed a “perfect” donor. All my tests came back great. I was young, healthy, fit, and college educated.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Which apparently also made me easily marketable in their database.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Prior to donating, I was informed of the potential risks.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A nurse gave me a sheet of paper that listed &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/ovarian-hyperstimulation-syndrome-ohss/home/ovc-20263580&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS)&lt;/a&gt; and infection from surgery as the most likely risks, although she told me those were pretty rare.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Possible infertility was also listed as a much less common risk, but she patted me on the back and said, “There are no studies showing that’s a real risk. We just have to put it there, just in case. You’re young and healthy. You have nothing to worry about.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And so, I signed on the dotted line. And I began injecting myself with high dose hormones to produce eggs for two families who were desperate to conceive.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A painful reaction&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Both of my donations went smoothly, with 14 eggs retrieved each time.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I felt fully recovered within days of retrieval. It wasn’t until six months after my second donation that I began to experience complications. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The first sign that something was wrong came when my period just stopped. Months went by with no sign of my cycle. Then when it did return, it was with excruciating pain.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I began running fevers every time I got my period, doubling over in such pain that I couldn’t walk and often vomited because I was hurting so badly. That pain began to extend into my day-to-day life, even when I wasn’t on my period.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;An ultrasound showed my ovaries were covered in tumorlike growths. I had surgery shortly after that, and those growths were found to be endometriomas, or blood-filled cysts.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I was diagnosed with stage 4 endometriosis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I’d never experienced any problems with my period prior to donating. There had never been any reason to believe I had endometriosis before.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But endometriosis is an estrogen-driven condition.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After looking at my before and after records, several doctors have told me they believe I likely had an underlying case of endometriosis that flared and became extremely aggressive as a result of the hormones involved in donating.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Egg donation did not give me endometriosis. But it did cause my condition to become unmanageable, which ultimately led to my swift diagnosis of infertility.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Facing the fertility facts&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;At 27 years old, I pursued two rounds of in vitro fertilization (IVF) myself.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;My egg quality had diminished greatly in just the few years since I had donated.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Both rounds failed, and I had to come to terms with the fact that while my egg donations had produced two children, I would never be pregnant myself. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the three years following the donation of my eggs, I required five major surgeries and several expensive drug therapies to treat endometriosis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This wasn’t just about infertility. It was about quality of life.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In total, I spent about $60,000 out of pocket in medical expenses. None of this was covered by my donations, from which I had earned about $12,000.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In fact, the agency I donated through simply stopped returning my calls and emails upon learning how aggressive my condition had become. They didn’t even help me to obtain my donation medical records. I eventually had to pay the clinics I donated at for access to those records. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Every specialist who has seen my before and after records has agreed there is no denying my donations likely played some role in my condition.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The progression was just too fast, too aggressive, to not be linked.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But plenty in the industry continue to claim that egg donation is completely safe, even though there is no actual research to back up that claim.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;No research on risks&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The nurse who told me there was no research showing egg donation might cause infertility wasn’t lying.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She was simply playing on the fact that there was no research at all. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There has never been a long-term study into the health risks of egg donation. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Plenty of doctors will point to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK327768/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;research&lt;/a&gt; that exists about the safety of IVF and other fertility treatments. They say the same drugs are used for egg donation, and so the same safety conclusions can be drawn.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But StatNews recently published an article on this subject, confronting that very conclusion by pointing out that the women followed in that &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.statnews.com/2017/01/28/egg-donors-risks/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;research&lt;/a&gt; have been primarily women with infertility. These women are often over the age of 35 and already struggling with infertility, which can be a symptom of other health problems.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Meanwhile, egg donors are typically under the age of 25 with no such health concerns. Yet they are being given the same drugs and dosages as women with very different health profiles.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s fair to say they’re not the same population,” Dr. Richard J. Paulson, president of the American Society for Reproductive Medicine, told StatNews. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While egg donation has existed for 30 years, we simply don’t have any definitive research about the safety to donors or the long-term risks.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Assessing the risks&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Diane Tober, PhD, an anthropologist, and assistant adjunct professor at the University of California, San Francisco, School of Nursing, has been trying to change all this.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She has obtained a pilot grant and is spearheading a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.weareeggdonors.com/blog/2016/1/8/diane-tober&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;comprehensive study&lt;/a&gt; on international egg donation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;What she’s found so far does raise some red flags. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“One thing doctors and agencies should really be doing is looking first at preventable risks,” Tober told Healthline. “We know that one risk that can be controlled is OHSS. There is a very clear cause and effect, and it is absolutely preventable. But one of the things I’m seeing is that, especially in the U.S., many donors are producing really high quantities of eggs. In many of my interviews internationally, they are producing between 10 and 12 eggs each cycle. Eighteen is considered high risk for OHSS. But here in the U.S., so many of the donors I’ve spoken to have produced 30, 40, 50 eggs. They are being told by doctors and agencies that they are superdonors, ‘fertile Myrtles.’ But the reality is, these superproducing cycles put them at much higher risk for OHSS, which could be prevented if doctors were monitoring their progress throughout the cycle and adjusting their meds so that they didn’t overproduce.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Many of the conditions that donors do experience,” she added, “can be linked to excess estrogen [endometriosis and certain types of cancer, for instance]. I believe that when screening donors, we absolutely need to screen out carriers of the BRCA gene. Women who do carry the BRCA gene aren’t even supposed to use hormone-based contraceptives.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Yet we’re allowing donors to pump themselves full of hormones without first confirming whether or not they may be at greater risk.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://draimee.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Dr. Aimee Eyvazzadeh&lt;/a&gt;, a Harvard-educated, board certified OB-GYN specializing in reproductive endocrinology and infertility, agrees with the need to better screen donors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Every donor should have an inherited cancer test,” Eyvazzadeh told Healthline. “They should have a fertility gene test. If you have endometriosis, you should not donate.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While Eyvazzadeh believes that egg donation is generally safe for most women, she concedes, “There are women for whom it is dangerous to donate, without a doubt.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What can be done&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;So why aren’t more agencies and clinics pushing for this testing? Why aren’t they taking steps to better screen and protect potential donors?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to Eyvazzadeh, it’s about money.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Donors think the agencies actually care about them. But those agencies are making more than double what the donors are making, without taking any of the risk on themselves, she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Eyvazzadeh is trying to change that.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She wants to see research done into the long-term emotional implications of egg donation for donors. And she wants to see financial compensation removed from the egg donation process.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Instead, she’d like to see donors compensated with shared cycles, where some of their eggs could be frozen and stored for their own future use, should they ever face infertility themselves.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She wants to put the power back into donors’ hands, effectively cutting out agencies and allowing donors to be their own brokers — where they own their eggs, and can freeze and share on their own terms.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Also choosing who they donate to and operating with total transparency, where donors are given just as much information about their recipient families as recipient families are given about donors. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s been nearly 10 years since I first donated, and in that time I’ve heard a lot of horror stories of donors being taken advantage of and mistreated by the agencies they have donated through.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Removing the financial compensation and cutting out agencies reduces those risks. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But I also still firmly believe that the one thing donors need, and deserve the most, is long-term research into the potential health effects of donating, so that they can give truly informed consent. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Tober agrees.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“From an anecdotal perspective, in my study so far out of 100 women, there are about five that did experience infertility not long after egg donation,” she said. “Some of those cases were endometriosis or cancer, and for one woman, her hormones never returned to normal after donating. We don’t know for sure if there is a causal connection. I can’t say it’s definitely linked. But there is enough reason for concern to warrant a push for more information.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The only question is how many cases like mine will it take before more doctors and agencies will join the push for that research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Or is it possible that with so much money on the line, that push will never come?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<updateddate>2017-02-23T10:00:00</updateddate>
