</guid>
<dc:creator>Leah Campbell</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-23T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Can an App Help You Avoid Getting Pregnant?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/app-helps-avoid-getting-pregnant
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/womens-health/022217_pregnancyapp_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt
]]>
<![CDATA[
;&lt;p&gt;A new app approved in Europe claims to defy the old joke “What do you call a couple who uses the rhythm method?”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;(Answer: Parents)&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Natural Cycles is the world’s first regulatory approved app for contraception, offering couples an option besides condoms, the pill, and IUDs. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It received &lt;a href=&quot;http://venturebeat.com/2017/02/09/natural-cycles-is-first-contraceptive-app-to-get-eu-approval/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;class IIb medical device status&lt;/a&gt; from a German inspection firm employed by the United Kingdom’s regulatory agency for healthcare products.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Now, women across the world can access the app. More than 150,000 users in 161 countries currently use it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I love that the hormones are gone and that I get to know my own body in a different way. I am more aware of my cycle and my own natural hormones,” Sara Flyckt, a London resident, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Flyckt used the app for two years to prevent pregnancy after using both contraception injections and several types of contraceptive pills.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I never really felt that they agreed with me and the hormones made me very unstable,” she says.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Avoiding hormone therapy for contraception is exactly why Elina Berglund Scherwitzl and Raoul Scherwitzl, husband and wife creators of Natural Cycles, developed the app.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I didn’t want to use hormones anymore, and I wasn’t exactly excited to use a condom every time, having been in a relationship,” Elina Scherwitzl, PhD, told Healthline. “We looked into natural family planning solutions, but there was nothing out there that made it easy and reliable to use.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Scherwitzls, who both have doctorates in physics, applied their math skills to the natural family planning method, developed an algorithm, and created the app they believe is safe and easy to use. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We packaged it into a mobile app to make it user-friendly and scalable at the same time,” Scherwitzl says.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How it works&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Users who sign up for the app for a year receive a free basal thermometer to track their temperature.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The yearly subscription costs $4.99 per month. Access to the app is also available for $8.99 per month, but this plan doesn’t include a thermometer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Anyone can have a free trial for one month.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Each morning, you take your temperature and enter it into the app. An algorithm then determines your fertility that day.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;div class=&quot;hl-poll&quot; style=&quot;float:right; margin:10px;&quot;&gt;&lt;script type=&quot;text/javascript&quot; charset=&quot;utf-8&quot; src=&quot;http://static.polldaddy.com/p/9671710.js&quot;&gt;&lt;/script&gt; &lt;noscript&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://polldaddy.com/poll/9671710/&quot;&gt;Would you be comfortable using a temperature app for birth control?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/noscript&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;p&gt;If the app determines it’s a green day, then you can have unprotected intercourse. If it informs you that it’s a red day, then you should use protection. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I’ve heard and read a few comments that people seem to think that it’s tricky to have to take your temperature every morning, but it really couldn’t be easier,” Flyckt says. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She puts her thermometer on top of her phone since it’s the first thing she usually reaches for when she wakes up.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“That helps you to remember,” she notes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Scherwitzl says the app’s method differs from traditional fertility awareness methods because the rhythm method leaves assumptions about when a woman ovulates, or requires her to analyze her body temperature on her own. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This is very error prone as you don’t only have the human error at play, but also you have to use very simplified statistical methods as well as only analyze one cycle at the time,” Scherwitzl says. “Our algorithm takes all this away by doing more advanced calculations and simply returning red or green, thus removing the human error, and it is always extra cautious in the first months before it has enough data from this person to be able to safely give green days, without making any assumptions about the unique user’s cycle or ovulation date.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;As effective as the pill?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmedhealth/behindtheheadlines/news/2016-04-15-would-you-trust-a-smartphone-app-as-a-contraceptive/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2016 clinical study&lt;/a&gt; of women using Natural Cycles to prevent pregnancy, performed by the Scherwitzls along with the Karolinska Institute, showed the app was as effective as birth control pills. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The results reported a perfect use Pearl Index of 0.5 (99.5 percent effective) and a typical use Pearl Index of 7.0 (93 percent effective). This means five women per 1,000 would become pregnant per year due to the Natural Cycles app giving the wrong green day. Seven out of 100 women would become pregnant due to any reason. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Other contraceptives, such as the hormonal contraceptive pill, are in similar ranges, while contraceptive methods that are inside your body such as the hormonal implant or the IUD have higher typical use Pearl Index rates as the human error is minimal,” Scherwitzl says.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Still, Dr. Jane Oh, an OB-GYN in Illinois, says a Pearl Index of 7 sounds unrealistic. She states that most OB-GYN textbooks suggest that the natural rhythm method has a Pearl Index of about 20. This means 20 per 100 women will get pregnant in a year when using that method.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In real life, I would expect it to be much less effective in terms of preventing pregnancy. Especially if you have highly irregular cycles,” Oh told Healthline. “In the best case scenario, natural family planning with or without the app should work pretty well, but specific criteria must be met.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Oh says the criteria includes a woman who has regular periods, and two disciplined adults with excellent self-control who are not devastated if they do become pregnant.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In other words, a highly organized and motivated couple,” says Oh. “This is not the real world. That’s why the best forms of birth control to date are ones that do not depend on the person doing anything for years and years, like IUDs, sterilization, and Nexplanon implants.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Scherwitzl agrees that the app is for couples in stable relationships who are willing to use protection on red days. Since the study was performed on women above the age of 18, she does not recommend anyone younger using the app. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Because Natural Cycles does not protect against sexually transmitted infections (STIs), Scherwitzl stresses that it “Should therefore only be used by stable couples when the woman knows and trusts her partner.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Can it help you &lt;em&gt;get&lt;/em&gt; pregnant?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Oh says the natural rhythm method is effective in helping women become pregnant. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When Flyckt wanted to become pregnant, she used Natural Cycles to help plan her pregnancy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I did this for about one year and I am now pregnant in week 30,” she says.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Scherwitzl is currently conducting a third clinical study on the app’s effectiveness in helping women become pregnant by investigating what variables impact time for pregnancy and infertility. These include age, BMI, previous contraception, intercourse rate, and cycle regularity. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While the results have not been published yet, Scherwitzl says she can share some insight.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“What is clear is that we help users plan the most when they are less likely to have intercourse on the most fertile day by chance. This is especially users that have irregular cycles, early or late ovulation, or intercourse less frequently,” Scherwitzl says. “Previous contraception is also very important. If they used Natural Cycles to prevent pregnancy before, they usually get pregnant very fast once they switch to plan, as both the app and the woman have a good understanding of her cycle already.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>

<category>Technology</category>
<category>Women's Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-02-22T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-22T12:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/app-helps-avoid-getting-pregnant
</guid>
<dc:creator>Cathy Cassata</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-22T20:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Will Men Ever Embrace Male Birth Control?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/male-birth-control
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/mens-health/022217_malebirthcontrol_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It’s said you can lead a horse to water, but you can’t make it drink.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The same might be true when it comes to men and birth control.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A new form of male birth control — an injectable gel that blocks sperm flow — has cleared its latest round of clinical trials.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Vasalgel, an experimental contraceptive developed by researchers at the Parsemus Foundation, was found to be a safe and successful form of birth control in male monkeys.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers published their findings in &lt;a href=&quot;https://bacandrology.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12610-017-0048-9&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Basic and Clinical Andrology&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers believe that the gel injection will be more easily reversible than a vasectomy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Experts and advocacy groups welcome new methods of family planning, but they say there are more hurdles to clear — both scientific and cultural — before Vasalgel or other forms of male contraceptives are widely embraced.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A survey of Healthline readers indicates the resistance of men to birth control may be quite real.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A crucial function&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Just about any couple can attest to the importance of birth control.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And while modern couples have several options — whether condoms, vasectomy, or the female birth control pill — it’s always good to have other alternatives.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Raegan McDonald-Mosley, chief medical officer at Planned Parenthood Federation of America, outlined in an email to Healthline some of the reasons it’s important to have options.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s important to note that birth control methods are not one-size-fits-all, so a method that’s perfect for one person may not be right for another,” she wrote. “In addition to health and the likelihood of side effects, some of the most common factors that people consider when weighing birth control methods are effectiveness at preventing pregnancy, ease of use, future childbearing plans, cost, privacy, and partner acceptance. Age and the permanence of the method are also factors to consider.“&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Terry O’Neill, president of the National Association for Women (NOW), says the development of male contraceptives is great news.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think the more that people are able to control their own bodies, the better off we are,” she told Healthline. “Male birth control doesn’t mean that women won’t be utilizing birth control. Clearly, women will continue to use birth control because every woman has the right to decide for herself when she will have children, if ever. But what’s good, I think, about the development of male birth control is that men should have control over their own bodies.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;McDonald-Mosley says the research and development of male contraceptives should “absolutely” be a public health priority.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It would provide couples with more options for preventing unintended pregnancies,” she said. “Providing men with better and greater contraceptive options would also enable men to play a more active role in the mutual planning and pregnancy and the prevention of unintended pregnancies — a role that Planned Parenthood greatly encourages and supports.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Changing norms&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;One of the biggest question marks surrounding the development of male contraceptives is whether or not men will actually embrace the new methods.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In order to understand the likelihood of whether or not men will use contraceptives, you have to understand that probably the most unfair aspect of human evolution is that women evolved in a way that makes sex a much higher cost,” Dr. Wendy Walsh, a relationship expert, told Healthline. “Because of their unique biology, women are much more susceptible to contracting an STI, much more susceptible to bonding and falling in love with a jerk because women’s bodies emit oxytocin, the bonding hormone, during orgasm. And, of course, women are much more likely to contract an 18-year case of parenthood because our culture is not one where men are doing the bulk of the child care.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A 2015 &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/womens-health/11693404/Male-Pill-More-than-half-of-men-cant-wait-to-take-it.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Telegraph poll&lt;/a&gt; showed that slightly more than half of men surveyed would definitely take a male birth control pill if it became widely available, while about a quarter said they weren’t sure, and another quarter said they wouldn’t.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In an online survey that 570 Healthline readers answered, 34 percent of men said they’d be willing to get an injection that blocks the flow of sperm for several months while 66 percent said they wouldn’t.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When asked if they’d be willing to receive a series of shots that blocked sperm production, 27 percent said “Yes” while 73 percent said “No.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Despite these survey results, some experts see change down the road.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Urologist Dr. Jamin Brahmbhatt, co-director of the Personalized Urology &amp;amp; Robotics Clinic at South Lake Hospital in Clermont, Fla., in partnership with Orlando Health, says he’s hopeful that men will embrace new methods as they become available.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I deal with men on a daily basis and there definitely is an interest,” he told Healthline. “But right now, I have very little to offer. I can tell them to use a condom or have a vasectomy. But condoms have a 10 percent failure rate. Withdrawal, where they pull out, has a 20 percent failure rate. And with vasectomies, they get worried that they’ll want to have kids in the future. But if there is something out there, I think a lot of guys will do it — especially younger men. With the millennial generation becoming very tech savvy and proactive when it comes to overall health, I think guys, even knowing their female partner is on birth control, will get this as well, just to be doubly sure.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Walsh also says she sees a generational shift happening.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think men are evolving, especially with the millennial generation,” she told Healthline. “I feel optimistic about the future, especially with the younger generation and the amount of child care that this generation of men is doing or thinking of doing. I feel optimistic that it’s changing, I really do.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Looking ahead&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;While Vasalgel shows promise, it’s just one of several proposed methods of male contraception.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A different &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-37790450&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;injection method&lt;/a&gt; — this one involving hormones — was explored but halted because of unwanted side effects.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers at the University of Minnesota are looking into the possibility of a &lt;a href=&quot;http://license.umn.edu/technologies/z09075_reversible-non-hormonal-male-contraceptive&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;non-hormonal birth control pill&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There’s also the future possibility of a literal &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.livescience.com/54105-which-male-birth-control-works.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;on/off switch&lt;/a&gt; implanted under the skin.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Brahmbhatt says he thinks the pill is still years away from becoming viable.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I would say it’s decades away from becoming a reality,” he said. “Right now it’s just a concept, and they haven’t really done any studies on the actual switch part, or how they’re going to be putting it inside humans.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Healthline readers seem a bit reluctant about this option at the moment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the online survey, 31 percent of respondents said they would be willing to take a daily pill to stop sperm production while 69 percent said they wouldn’t.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When asked if a risk of side effects, such as acne or depression were involved, 61 percent said they’d be less likely to try this birth control option.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Tough times ahead&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The future of male contraceptives is fraught with both medical and cultural challenges, the future of family planning in general seems poised to face significant political problems.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We know the transformative effect birth control has on people’s lives. We see it every day in our patients and supporters,” wrote McDonald-Mosley of Planned Parenthood’s mission. “There’s a lot to celebrate around birth control: the ability to plan, prevent, and space pregnancies is directly linked to benefits to women, men, children, and society, including more educational and economic opportunities, healthier babies, and more stable families. It can also enhance people’s sex lives, helping them feel less stressed about getting pregnant.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Despite the benefits that contraceptives provide, there’s a battle looming between groups like Planned Parenthood and the newly inaugurated administration of President Donald Trump.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“On reproductive rights, we know that the administration is going to try to systematically block people from access to basic reproductive healthcare,” O’Neill said. “The defunding of Planned Parenthood is actually a bit of a smokescreen for defunding Title X family planning clinics generally. They’re not just going after Planned Parenthood — if they did, that would be unconstitutional. The only way to do it constitutionally is to cut off all funding for federal family planning clinic programs. Of course, that will be devastating.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<dc:creator>Dan Gray</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-22T19:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>More Hispanic, Latino Cardiologists Needed</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/hispanic-and-latino-cardiologists-needed
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/heart-health/022117_hispaniccardiologists_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Dr. Tony Urey went into medicine for the same reason many of his medical school friends did.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He wanted to give low-income Hispanic and Latino communities better healthcare.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Many of his fellow students became family doctors, but Urey decided to specialize in the heart.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Most Hispanic and Latino doctors are internists or general practitioners, according to data from the Association of American Medical Colleges.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As of 2013, there were 1,044 U.S.-trained Hispanic and Latino cardiologists practicing in the United States — less than the number who went into surgery, psychiatry, or emergency medicine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As a cardiology fellow, Urey is specializing in advanced heart failure and transplantation at UT Southwestern Medical Center in Dallas.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In medical school, Urey said he and his classmates had little exposure to cardiology in their training.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think that the exposure or the opportunities to serve the community in other areas [besides primary care] are not really well-explored by a lot of undergrads and medical students,” said Urey, a Los Angeles native who wanted to become a doctor because his mother struggled to get good care in the county health system.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Looking for cardiologists&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Experts say they wish more medical students in general chose to specialize in cardiology.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But getting more racially and ethnically diverse cardiologists to treat patients in their respective communities is especially important.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Research shows minority patients, when given a choice, often seek out doctors from their same race or heritage.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Urey decided to go into cardiology during his residency.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, medical school programs and practicing cardiologists should start engaging children in elementary school, said Chicago cardiologist Dr. Kim A. Williams, Sr., chief of cardiology at Rush Medical College, and a past president of the American College of Cardiology (ACC).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The first task is to get them interested in science, he said, and as they get older, to talk about medical school and cardiology.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It really has to do with the [education] pipeline,” said Williams.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The African-American physician often talks to high school students about going into medicine, but said he and his peers should do more to work with school districts.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Williams is the head of cardiology at Rush University Medical Center, and co-chair of ACC’s new initiative to encourage more women and ethnic and racial minority physicians to pursue a career in cardiology.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Available U.S. demographic data from the ACC show about 7 percent of its physician members identify as Hispanic or Latino.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Targeted efforts&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Medical schools are also targeting their efforts.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Duke University School of Medicine has come a long way in changing the makeup of its student body since pediatric cardiologist Dr. Brenda Armstrong was a resident there in the mid-1970s.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Armstrong was among faculty members in the 1990s who pushed to increase the number of minority medical students.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We have built — and it's taken time — an understanding that this is a place where diversity is valued,” said Armstrong, the medical school's associate dean of medical education, and director of admissions for more than 20 years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ohio State University’s medical school made it a priority more than a decade ago to recruit minority candidates for its cardiology fellowship program.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Before 2007, the program hadn’t had an African-American or Hispanic trainee since it started in 1967.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Alex J. Auseon, DO, was the Ohio State program’s director from 2010 to 2015.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We knew we couldn’t just do it at the end of the line,” he said. “We had to [get them interested in cardiology] early.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Lack of graduates&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Auseon, who now oversees the cardiology fellowship program at the University of Illinois at Chicago, said another challenge is that there simply aren’t a lot of minority medical school graduates.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And among that graduate pool, he wonders whether some may not apply because cardiology training is among the most challenging and demanding in medicine, or they don’t want to deal with the life-or-death situations linked to heart disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Having more Hispanic and Latino cardiology students isn’t just good for their future patients, it’s also good for medical programs, said Urey, who is of Guatemalan and Bolivian heritage.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Training with people from different ethnic, racial, and socioeconomic backgrounds better prepares doctors to care for a more diverse group of patients and better understand the health issues and cardiovascular disease risk factors that are unique to a particular ethnic group, he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s especially important considering the growth of the U.S. Hispanic and Latino population, which rose from &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.census.gov/prod/cen2010/briefs/c2010br-04.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;50 million&lt;/a&gt; in 2010 to &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.census.gov/newsroom/facts-for-features/2016/cb16-ff16.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;56 million&lt;/a&gt; in 2015, according to the U.S. Census Bureau.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), heart disease is the second-leading cause of death among Hispanics and Latinos, who are more likely than whites to be obese, have diabetes, and be physically inactive — all risk factors for heart disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Some of these [Hispanic and Latino] communities have been largely underserved for decades,” said Urey. “Having someone that understands the culture, speaks the language, and has gone through some of the challenges the patients face is, I think, something that will benefit patient care — but also training of non-Latino physicians.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Editor’s Note: The &lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/wanted-more-hispanic-and-latino-heart-doctors/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;original story&lt;/a&gt; was published on American Heart Association News.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Heart Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-02-22T09:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-22T09:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/hispanic-and-latino-cardiologists-needed
</guid>
<dc:creator>American Heart Association News</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-22T17:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Experts Still Urge Americans to Get Flu Shots. Here’s Why
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/experts-urge-americans-to-get-flu-shots
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/flu/022117_fluseason_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As flu season continues experts say it’s still not too late to get a vaccine. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has released a new report saying that the current vaccine is 48 percent effective.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Does that mean it’s worth it to get a flu shot?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If so, why do we keep hearing &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.foxnews.com/health/2017/02/17/flu-vaccine-is-only-moderately-protective-this-year-cdc-says.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;negative reports&lt;/a&gt; about the flu vaccine this season?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This year, the most common virus is the influenza A (H3N2) strain. The vaccine was estimated to be 43 percent effective against that strain, and 73 percent effective against the influenza B strain.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;CDC officials say they define the vaccine as 48 percent effective because it’s used more often against the H3N2 strain. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A “bad” season?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;A report published in the New England Journal of Medicine Journal Watch cited CDC data from Feb. 4 that said flu activity is widespread in &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.jwatch.org/fw112543/2017/02/13/much-country-seeing-high-flu-activity?query=pfw&amp;amp;jwd=000020000592&amp;amp;jspc&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;43 states&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This is much higher than average, the report added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another CDC report, published by the Associated Press (AP), called the season &lt;a href=&quot;https://apnews.com/01f125e2b43c429695f9b68adfffde66/US-flu-vaccine-a-good-match;-season-moderate-so-far&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;moderate&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Elodie Ghedin, PhD, a biology professor at New York University, said the season hasn’t been particularly bad despite some of the hype in reports. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The vaccine is well-matched compared to two years ago when it wasn't. And people are getting vaccinated at relatively the same rate as previous years,” she told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Vaccination rates aren’t too different this year compared with others, Akiko Iwasaki, PhD, an immunobiology professor at Yale University, told Healthline&lt;em&gt;.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Experts say you still need a flu shot&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s a good but not great vaccine,” Dr. William Schaffner, an infectious disease specialist at the Vanderbilt Medical Center in Tennessee, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Schaffner said the 48 percent efficacy figure is pretty normal.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Flu shot effectiveness can range from 35 percent to 65 percent, he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That said, people should still get vaccinated, Schaffner said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The current strain disproportionally affects older adults and &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&amp;amp;rct=j&amp;amp;q=&amp;amp;esrc=s&amp;amp;source=newssearch&amp;amp;cd=3&amp;amp;cad=rja&amp;amp;uact=8&amp;amp;ved=0ahUKEwj0lMmwrZ_SAhXJ1IMKHfUDDTwQqQIIMSgAMAI&amp;amp;url=http%3A%2F%2Fnbc4i.com%2F2017%2F02%2F14%2Fofficials-fourth-ohio-child-dies-from-flu-related-illnesses%2F&amp;amp;usg=AFQjCNEp-X1ZYNskbzI7l4mLNRXcMQPwow&amp;amp;sig2=f1REnMGilv1apUSzRdvzWA&amp;amp;bvm=bv.147448319,d.amc&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;children&lt;/a&gt;. It is also more likely to cause severe illness. Recent reports of child deaths from the flu have been prominent.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Every year we have children who are hospitalized with the flu. Most of those children are not vaccinated,” Schaffner noted.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He added that kids usually respond well to the vaccine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another reason to “run, do not walk” and get the vaccine: Those who get the vaccine may still experience the flu, but it will be much less severe.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That is something Schaffner said is not represented in the statistics.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Also, getting the vaccine helps cut down on the spread of the virus overall. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It has a dual effect,” he explained.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While it’s not too late to get a shot, Schaffner said people should get vaccinated in September or October so it covers the whole season.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It is very important that people get the flu shot,” Iwasaki added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She noted that a nasal swab is the only way to tell if you have the flu.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Symptoms include fever, chills, sore throat, aches, and fatigue that last for one to two weeks.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Stomach bugs such as rotavirus or norovirus are technically not caused by flu strains though some people refer to them by that name.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If you do not get the flu shot and catch the flu, then you are suffering needlessly,” Iwasaki said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Cold and Flu</category>
<pubdate>2017-02-21T13:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-21T13:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/experts-urge-americans-to-get-flu-shots
</guid>
<dc:creator>Kristen Fischer</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-21T21:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Impending Water Crisis Could Affect Your Health</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/water-crisis-could-affect-your-health
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/022117_waterpollution_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Most Americans take clean water for granted.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;We turn on the tap and safe water to drink, bathe in, and cook and clean with comes out of the faucet. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But according to a &lt;a href=&quot;http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0169488&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;new study&lt;/a&gt;, there’s a growing water affordability problem on the horizon that could soon make water scarcer and more costly.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The fallout has the potential to be devastating to public health in the United States.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The true cost of water&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Utility companies actually take a loss on the cost of water.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, between individual households’ water bills and government subsidies, they have historically made enough money to keep operating their businesses while also tackling long-term, fixed-cost infrastructure projects.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But these infrastructure projects are increasingly eating up an unduly large part of most water and sewer companies’ costs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As much as 80 percent of the agencies’ budgets go to replacing outdated infrastructure that was built around World War II.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Elizabeth Mack, PhD, an assistant professor at Michigan State University, and co-author of the study, says that replacing aging infrastructure in the United States is projected to cost at least $1 trillion over the next 25 years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But that’s not the only factor driving up the cost of water.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Slow or even declining population growth, which reduces the customer base over which the high fixed costs of water services are distributed,” is also affecting costs, according to Mack’s research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The system works better the more people there are in the system because the more people there are in the system, the lower the per-unit cost of supplying water, which reduces people’s bills,” Mack stated.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In other words, the inability to pay for water has a cascading effect.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Those who can’t afford to keep water flowing through their pipes cause utility companies to charge more to those who can, creating a larger population that can’t afford water. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This, combined with an exodus of city dwellers in favor of the suburbs, and an urgent need to update infrastructure, “present a perilous future for water utilities and their customers,” according to Mack’s study.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Increasingly unaffordable water&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mack’s study estimates that “over the next few decades, water prices are anticipated to increase to four times current levels.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mack and another Michigan State professor found that water is currently unaffordable for about 12 percent of U.S. households, and this number could rise to 35 percent within the next five years. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mack says the study started with “a simple question: ‘Can households afford their water and sewer bills?’”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She says the answer is mostly yes, but maybe not for long, and certainly not for everyone.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study found that those living in poverty can’t always pay their water bills. And though that’s not expected to change anytime soon, “I think what’s more interesting,” Mack says, “is that people who make below median income” — that is, around $51,000 per year — “are also going to be facing some sort of affordability concerns.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That means the problem is likely to affect millions of Americans — many of whom aren’t expecting it and can’t afford it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The case of Flint&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;To combat the rising cost of providing water to its residents, officials in Flint, Mich. — a city where 40 percent of the population lives in poverty — switched the town’s water provider from the Detroit Water and Sewerage Department to the Flint River in 2014.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Soon after, residents began complaining about the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/04/20/465545378/lead-laced-water-in-flint-a-step-by-step-look-at-the-makings-of-a-crisis&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;quality of the water&lt;/a&gt;, in particular its smell and color. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Tests showed that the water had elevated levels of lead and trihalomethanes, cancer-causing disinfection byproducts.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In short, the Flint River water made pipes &lt;a href=&quot;http://pubs.acs.org/doi/full/10.1021/acs.est.6b04034&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;corrode&lt;/a&gt;, exposing the people of Flint to harmful chemicals. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Three years later, Flint residents are still &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.helpforflint.com/residentresources/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;drinking and cooking with filtered or bottled water&lt;/a&gt; as their water supply continues to be tested for lead, copper, and chlorine. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But the very solution of bottled and filtered water also exacerbates the problem.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There’s not as much water flowing through the pipes, which makes them corrode faster,” says Mack. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Potentially deadly health impact&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), “&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/nceh/lead/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;lead exposure&lt;/a&gt; can affect nearly every system in the body.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lead-filled water affects everyone exposed to it, but the effects are exacerbated in children, the elderly, and pregnant women.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.niehs.nih.gov/health/materials/lead_and_your_health_508.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;National Institutes of Environmental Health Sciences&lt;/a&gt;, the effects of lead in children can include behavioral and attention-related issues, delayed puberty, impaired hearing, stunted growth, and decreased cognitive ability, IQ, and academic achievement.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In adults, health effects can include hypertension, nerve disorders including tremors and other disorders of the central nervous system, decreased kidney function, and fertility problems.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Additionally, Legionnaires’ disease, a form of pneumonia caused by &lt;em&gt;Legionella&lt;/em&gt; bacteria, has so far caused the deaths of &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.freep.com/story/news/local/michigan/2016/01/13/snyder-flint-area-has-seen-spike-legionnaires/78750610/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;10 people&lt;/a&gt; in Flint. Between June 2014 and November 2015, 87 cases of the disease were reported to the county medical examiner’s office.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Jonathan Yoder, who works for the waterborne disease prevention branch of the CDC, says that Flint demonstrates the importance of water quality for communities.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If your water is of poor quality, it impacts every part of your community,” he told Healthline. “We have to ensure our water is safe, because it touches every part of our lives, in our homes and in our businesses, so it’s important that we can trust it to be supportive, not detrimental, to our health.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Yoder points out that water is used not only for drinking but also for “handwashing, bathing, and recreational uses, not to mention the way it’s used in industry and agriculture.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It must therefore “be safe and clean and free from disease-causing organisms.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A broad spectrum of disease&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;We’re used to hearing stories about water and sanitation issues in other countries, including China, India, Haiti, and Nigeria.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/06/health/cholera-vaccine-bangladesh.html?_r=0&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;recent article&lt;/a&gt; in The New York Times, cholera, a bacterial disease that “spurs the intestines to violently flush themselves” is “a continuing threat in nearly 70 countries, where more than 1 billion people are at risk.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cholera is a particularly serious effect of poor sanitation. Could an outbreak happen here?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Most water bills — the ones an increasing number of people will not be able to afford in the near future — usually include water &lt;em&gt;and&lt;/em&gt; sewage.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If a significant number of people have their water shut off for nonpayment, it could lead to a dangerous hygiene situation in the cities and towns where water is unaffordable. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And even in towns where residents can afford the increasing costs of water bills, they must still deal with outdated infrastructure.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We’ve not continued to invest in system upgrades and pipe replacements. As a result, we have an estimated 240,000 water main breaks a year that could potentially expose users to sewage, pathogens, and other contaminants,” says Michael Beach, PhD, the chief of the waterborne disease prevention branch at the CDC, in a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/healthywater/materials.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;video&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As of now, cholera isn’t a primary concern for America’s water supply, according to CDC statistics. But that doesn’t mean there aren’t concerns at all.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the United States, the top five causes of drinking water outbreaks are giardia, &lt;em&gt;Legionella&lt;/em&gt;, &lt;em&gt;Shigella&lt;/em&gt;, norovirus, and &lt;em&gt;Campylobacter&lt;/em&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Clean running water is critical for preventing disease outbreaks, but it’s also dangerous and inconvenient not to have it for everyday tasks such as hand-washing, teeth-brushing, cooking, and cleaning. Anyone who has traveled internationally — or, indeed, has visited Flint recently — can tell you how critical it is.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It doesn’t take you very long to really miss the convenience of a faucet and being able to do things that were so easy and that we take for granted,” says Yoder. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Beyond Flint&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Flint has brought home the issue of water quality to the 286 million Americans who get their water from public utilities that are regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). An additional 45 million, or 15 percent to 20 percent, use private wells that &lt;a href=&quot;http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/123/6/1599&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;aren’t regulated&lt;/a&gt; at all.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But “America's water issues extend far beyond Flint,” according to a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cnbc.com/2016/03/24/americas-water-crisis-goes-beyond-flint-michigan.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;story on CNBC&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The outlet obtained data from the EPA that show only nine U.S. states have safe levels of lead in their water supply. Put another way, 41 states have reported “higher than acceptable levels of lead in drinking water.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If nothing else, the water troubles in Flint have shined a light on the problem of poor water quality and lead exposure nationwide.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;New York recently &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/03/nyregion/new-york-dept-education-lead-water.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;changed its water-testing protocol&lt;/a&gt; for schools and found levels of lead above the EPA’s recommended limits.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cities across New Jersey, Pennsylvania, and Ohio that have long battled &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2016/02/04/untold-cities-across-america-have-higher-rates-of-lead-poisoning-than-flint/?utm_term=.b480169337ea&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;higher lead levels in children&lt;/a&gt;, primarily from lead-based paint, have new ammunition in advocating for more oversight.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mack predicts confidently that the underlying reasons that Flint’s water was contaminated with chemicals and bacteria “will repeat elsewhere.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In most places, water infrastructure is old, and they have to go in and replace and update it,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Yoder concurs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“More than 100 years ago we began this process of separating our wastewater from our drinking water, and in general, we have really good water quality in the U.S.,” he says. “We’ve invested in having clean, safe water, and developing public water systems, and it’s made a huge impact on the health of our citizens. Whatever we can do to maintain and improve that infrastructure is really important.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The crisis continues&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Meanwhile, there’s no end in sight to Flint’s water crisis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Earlier this month, Smithsonian magazine &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/chemical-study-ground-zero-house-flint-water-crisis-180962030/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;reported&lt;/a&gt; that Flint is “now in the midst of an effort to replace the city's thousands of lead pipes, but it’s unclear how long it will take or how much it will end up costing.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Compounding the situation, the Trump administration recently placed a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/energy-environment/wp/2017/01/23/trump-administration-tells-epa-to-freeze-all-grants-contracts/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;freeze on grants and contracts&lt;/a&gt; from the EPA.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Flint and cities with similar poor water quality depend on such grants for money to help fix their water supply. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Simultaneously, Republicans in the House of Representatives recently &lt;a href=&quot;http://time.com/4657438/congressional-republicans-environmental-regulations-coal-streams/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;reversed a rule&lt;/a&gt; that prevented coal mines from dumping their debris into nearby streams.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Time magazine quoted Republican Paul Ryan of Wisconsin as saying, “The stream protection rule is really just a thinly veiled attempt to wipe out coal mining jobs.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Be prepared and get educated&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Perhaps surprisingly, there is no federal law ensuring the right to water for all people.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The EPA regulations can’t entirely prevent old, outdated pipes from introducing toxic chemicals and pathogens into the water supply in an increasing number of cities with infrastructure dating back to World War II.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Fixing the problem will require nothing less than a nationwide overhaul of our water and wastewater infrastructure. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the meantime, both Yoder and Mack recommend getting educated about your water bill.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Yoder acknowledges that the future of water affordability and its impact on health “are the kinds of things that you could lie awake and worry about at night,” but says people’s energy is better spent learning about their water systems.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Where does their water come from? How do they know it’s safe? What are the systems in place to acquire that water: to treat it, to make sure it’s safe both at the treatment plant and all the way to their house? Are there things they can do to conserve water?” he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mack advises people to “find out how much water you use every month, who your provider is, what your billing structure is, and whether you can install water-saving fixtures.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If you’re having an affordability issue,” she says, “contact your provider and see if you can’t renegotiate payment of your bill.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“For people who are in economic hardship, [water affordability] is a really challenging situation,” says Yoder. “But from a planning standpoint, it’s really important that we get involved and we understand water and value it as a common resource that we all need to survive.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;From Flint to Philadelphia and Santa Fe to Seattle, clean, affordable water is an increasingly precious resource.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Knowing why that is and what you can do about it could save your life.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>General Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-02-21T09:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-21T09:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/water-crisis-could-affect-your-health
</guid>
<dc:creator>Anna Wahrman</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-21T17:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Are Expensive Fitness Classes Worth It?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/expensive-fitness-classes
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/021717_bestexercise_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;When
]]>
<![CDATA[
Adam Barker first walked into a boutique fitness studio, he immediately noticed the difference from a public or big-box gym.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Everything is catered for you,” he said. “You're guaranteed quality in everything from the workout, to the equipment, to the amenities and facilities available to you — it’s like a nirvana for your fitness.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Like others who frequent trendy studios with an “exclusive club” feel — mood lighting, banging beats, and mirrors everywhere — Barker is more than willing to pay $30 or more for a single fitness class.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I’m happy to spend a little bit more on the best quality experiences with extra personalized and tailored routines, and extras that make it special,” said Barker, chief executive officer and co-founder of &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.magnapass.co.uk&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;MagnaPass&lt;/a&gt;, a U.K.-based company that lets people book local fitness classes online.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Selling an experience&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Expensive fitness classes are not a new phenomenon, but right now they seem to be hot — hot enough to burn a hole in your wallet.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In New York, for $34 a class you can experience the spin classes of SoulCycle or its competitor FlyWheel, or try out strength and interval training on a treadmill at Barry’s Bootcamp.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If you want to shell out $37, you can take a drop-in “Pilates-meets-ballet” class at The Bar Method or get pumped and stretchy at Exhale’s CoreFusion yoga classes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But the boutique fitness ceiling goes even higher.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;SLT offers a Pilates and cardio mix done on M3 Megaformer machines, and Aqua takes spin classes into the pool. Both for $40 per class.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Of course, rates vary from city to city. And some studios offer deals or cheaper rates if you pay for more classes up front.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But compare this to regular gyms and you’ll see how quickly the cost of boutique fitness classes can add up.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Planet Fitness and World Gym also offer fitness classes — plus a wide range of treadmills and strength training equipment — for membership fees of $10 to $20 a month.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At the higher end of the scale, the New York Health &amp;amp; Racquet Club — with weights, treadmills, swimming pool, basketball and racquetball courts, sauna, steam room, and more — charges up to $135 a month, plus a $300 initiation fee.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For the racquet club, that comes out to less than $2,000 a year — for unlimited access. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Taking three underwater spin classes a week at Aqua — to hit the recommended 150 minutes of cardio a week — would cost more than $6,000 a year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Still, working with a personal trainer once a week for $100 or $150 each session would run up to $7,800 a year — and that’s not counting any gym fees.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Hidden costs of fitness&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;There’s no doubt that part of what you’re paying for at boutique fitness studios is what Barker calls the “good atmosphere and those touches that give a studio that extra personality.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Aryn Forman, owner of the small online boutique &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.arynpayne.com&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Aryn Payne&lt;/a&gt;, noticed this when she attended a SoulCycle class in the Boston area.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It is clean and has a very nice atmosphere,” she said. “They are selling fancy clothes and everything looks brand new.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some boutique fitness studios sell clothing and other merchandise embossed with their logos — sometimes funneling members through the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.thestar.com/life/health_wellness/2017/01/23/how-much-would-you-pay-to-work-out-at-an-instagram-worthy-gym.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;gift shop&lt;/a&gt; after class to pick up some trendy supplies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And there are the free amenities like complimentary towels, deodorant, shampoo, hair ties, and earplugs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But market forces also drive the higher class prices.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“People don’t realize what it costs for me to run Rise Nation,” Jason Walsh, founder of Rise Nation, a California-based studio that offers fitness classes on climber machines.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“You have to pay your people and hopefully pay them well,” added Walsh. “You’ve got overhead. And for real estate in West Hollywood — prime real estate — it’s thousands of dollars per month.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As expected from their image, many expensive boutique fitness studios are in trendy neighborhoods — with high rent costs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Like Rise Nation, they may also have high equipment costs just because of the classes they offer — like the stationary bicycles immersed in a pool at Aqua or the $7,000 &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/21/fashion/sebastien-lagrees-megaformer-machines-put-the-sweat-in-pilates.html?_r=0&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;M3 Megaformer machines&lt;/a&gt; at SLT and Studio Lagree. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And paying instructors to run each class is not cheap, especially when you want the best. Which is a big part of the experience.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“People get to know the instructor — who often teaches a lot of classes at the boutique studio — and they learn to like that person's teaching style and crave it,” said Ashley Pitt, a San Francisco-based personal trainer and author of the blog &lt;a href=&quot;http://aladygoeswest.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;A Lady Goes West&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Most bang for the buck&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;No matter how many cold eucalyptus towels you get for free at a fitness studio, though, paying more for a class doesn’t always mean a better workout.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So how do you find something that gives you the most bang for your buck?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“To get the best results,” said Justin Fauci, a certified personal trainer, and co-founder of &lt;a href=&quot;http://leanmuscleproject.com&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Lean Muscle Project&lt;/a&gt;, “choose classes that focus on one primary goal — such as maximizing strength via weight training, or maximizing calorie burn via high-intensity spinning.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Variety is good, too, so you don’t hit a fitness plateau or get bored.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Pitt recommends finding classes “that have a different focus each day, in order to work new muscles. Orangetheory Fitness and Barry's Bootcamp are great at this because they keep the participant guessing so that you have to keep working harder and differently each time.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Also, watch out for classes that try to cram everything into one workout.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Doing cardio alongside strength training tends to dilute the effectiveness of the strength training by draining your energy and limiting the amount of weight you can lift,” said Fauci.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These types of classes are common among fitness studios chasing the latest craze.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Unfortunately what you’re seeing in these ‘hybrid classes’ — where there’s two or three different aspects to the workout — is just somebody putting their hand in a grab bag, throwing it against the wall, and seeing what sticks,” said Walsh.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Find a class that fits your goals&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Whether a fitness class works for you also depends on your goals.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With spin classes, you can always pedal faster or harder than those around you for a more intense workout.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But Fauci said some group classes may take a one-size-fits-all approach to strength training, where you work with the same weight the entire time, or do low weights and high reps.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This may help build endurance, but not size or strength.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If building muscle and strength is one of your primary fitness goals,” said Fauci, “then I believe that most fitness classes are going to be a waste of your money — and your time.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The importance of matching the workout to your goals is true for other areas.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“For clients focused on weight loss, TRX, kettlebell, HIIT [high-intensity interval training], and boot camp style classes are the biggest bang for your buck,” said New York-based certified personal trainer Lisa Snow, president of &lt;a href=&quot;http://onthemendfitness.com&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;On the Mend Customized Fitness and Massage&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But if you need to let go of some stress or improve your mobility, she added, yoga, stretching, or MELT foam roller classes would be a better use of your time and money.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Balance is good, too — not just the kind you get from standing on one leg in yoga class.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.acsm.org/about-acsm/media-room/news-releases/2011/08/01/acsm-issues-new-recommendations-on-quantity-and-quality-of-exercise&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;American College of Sports Medicine&lt;/a&gt; recommends that in addition to at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise each week, most adults should also include strength training and flexibility exercises.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If you are just starting out, though, do whatever it takes to make exercise a regular part of your life.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Once the foundation is there, it’s time to balance your workouts, rather than wasting money by focusing only on your strengths — and ignoring your weaknesses.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If you're already running outside every day, do you really need a spin class?” said Snow. “You've already got so much cardio under your belt. Pilates or yoga might be a better investment.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For stress-free and flexible yoga fans, said Snow, a dumbbell or kettlebell class might be a good option.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Put the workout first&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;With the lighting and music, Rise Nation still has a bit of a trendy club feel, but all that, said Walsh, is secondary to helping people get great results.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I came up with a really efficient and effective and safe workout. That was it,” he said. “That was the seed that started this whole thing. It wasn’t the other way around.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said he spent a couple of years in the studio, where he does personal training, coming up with the workout before even opening up shop.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And with only 31 climbers in the room, Rise Nation classes are smaller than some packed stadium fitness classes. This helps instructors keep an eye on students.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I want people to have great form,” said Walsh. “That’s really important to me.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Snow sets the bar even higher — or lower — for class size.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Skip the expensive classes with 20, 30, or 40 people in the room,” she said. “While they may have better music or decor than a chain gym, it's hard to see how these classes are really better than free classes that come with a gym membership.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;What’s the ideal boutique class size to justify the higher price and allow the instructor the focus on you? Snow puts it at 12 or fewer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Finding an instructor that you connect with is also essential if you plan on returning.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“A great instructor is one who can help you push past comfort in a motivating and supportive environment,” said Donnie Stutland, co-owner of &lt;a href=&quot;http://wheelpowerstudio.com/&quot;&gt;WheelPower Studio&lt;/a&gt; in Illinois. “It's easy to have an easy workout at home and not realize how little we have truly pushed ourselves.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Don’t ignore cheaper options &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Expensive boutique fitness studios don’t have a monopoly on good workouts.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Rise Nation’s classes are $26. In New York, on average, Bikram yoga classes are $25, and Jivamukti yoga classes are $22.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;WheelPower Studio charges $23 for a class. But like many studios, they also offer monthly pricing to keep the cost lower. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And they have two studios under the same roof for more workout options.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“People can take a cycle class one day, a bootcamp or rhythmic sculpt class the next, and yoga to round out the week, as opposed to getting the exact same workout in every class as at many boutiques,” said Stutland.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Now we’re approaching big-box gym territory. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Which is not necessarily a bad thing.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The great thing is that I pay one month and I'm able to take as many classes as I want,” said New York-based comedian Dan Nainan, who is a member of the New York Health &amp;amp; Racquet Club.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“You certainly can't beat that. Studio classes in New York are really expensive,” he added. “So to me, it's a no-brainer.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cheaper fitness options can also help people exercise regularly — not just when they can afford it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If someone is struggling to afford boutique classes,” said Pitt. “I think they would be well served to see what is available at the big-box gym near them.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As surprising as it may seem to diehard fans of boutique fitness classes, not everyone who tries them is rushing back.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“SoulCycle was a good experience. It was definitely fun but super hard,” said Forman. “But I didn't feel like it was a superior experience to other fitness classes I have taken.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Others even swear by the variety offered at large gyms.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With his monthly membership, Nainan has taken kickboxing, trampoline, yoga, and core strength classes — and has hardly noticed any difference from what’s offered at boutique studios.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I took karate classes for years and essentially it's a bunch of people in a room along with an instructor,” said Nainan. “I don't really know how many ways there are to do that.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<updateddate>2017-02-17T13:00:00</updateddate>

http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/expensive-fitness-classes

<dc:creator>Shawn Radcliffe</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-17T21:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>
The Jury is Still Out on Benefits of Moderate Drinking
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/jury-out-on-moderate-drinking
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/021717_moderatedrinking_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Is a glass of red wine every night really beneficial for your health?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Maybe. Maybe not. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the ever-raging debate over alcohol consumption, many experts cite the supposed benefits moderate drinking can have on cardiovascular health. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Tim Stockwell, PhD, director of the Centre for Addictions Research of British Columbia, in Canada, used to be one of those experts.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Many years ago he wrote a commentary in which he suggested it would be ridiculous to doubt that alcohol in moderation was cardioprotective. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Now, however, Stockwell considers his prior assertions embarrassing and is unconvinced that alcohol is beneficial to cardiovascular health. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I’m skeptical as to whether there are any benefits,” Stockwell told Healthline. “I’m now not at all sure there is any cardioprotection, so I believe such advice would be potentially dangerous.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Office of Disease Prevention and Health Promotion (ODPHP) &lt;a href=&quot;https://health.gov/dietaryguidelines/2015/guidelines/appendix-9/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Dietary Guidelines for Americans&lt;/a&gt; defines moderate drinking as up to one drink per day for women and two for men. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the United States, a standard drink is considered to contain 14 grams of ethanol, the amount found in 12 ounces of 5 percent alcohol by volume (ABV) beer, or 5 ounces of 12 percent ABV wine. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Short-term and long-term risk&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://circ.ahajournals.org/content/early/2016/02/29/CIRCULATIONAHA.115.019743&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; by researchers at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health showed that there was an immediate cardiovascular risk after drinking, but researchers noted moderate consumption may not have a long-term risk. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There appears to be a consistent finding of an immediately higher risk of heart attacks and strokes following any alcohol consumption, but by 24 hours only heavy alcohol intake conferred a continued heightened risk,” Elizabeth Mostofsky, ScD, instructor at Harvard, and lead researcher of the study, told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In other words, heavy drinking increases risk both in the short term and the long term, but drinking smaller amounts has different effects in the subsequent hours than it does in the subsequent days and weeks. It seems possible that the transiently higher cardiovascular risk in the hours after drinking small amounts of alcohol may be outweighed by the longer-term health benefits or regular drinking,” she said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;George F. Koob, PhD, director of the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, says there have been studies that suggest a potential health benefit to alcohol in moderate amounts. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Animal and human laboratory studies suggest that alcohol increases HDL [“good” cholesterol], lowers LDL [“bad” cholesterol], decreases blood pressure, decreases inflammation, decreases &lt;a href=&quot;/health/atherosclerosis&quot;&gt;atherosclerosis&lt;/a&gt;, decreases diabetic vasculopathy [disease of blood vessels], and increases protective signaling against I/R induced tissue damage [involved in ischemic stroke], among others,” Koob told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Other methods&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, Koob suggests that the possible health benefits of alcohol could be obtained through other means. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Many of the potential benefits of alcohol can be achieved through a healthy diet and exercise. And low-risk drinking doesn’t mean no-risk drinking. So it’s really a personal choice,” he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As for the red wine, Stockwell says there is no known health benefit to having a glass every night. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Wine drinkers sometimes look better than other people in these kinds of studies, but that appears most likely to be due to a range of confounders,” he told Healthline. “People who like wine tend to have a whole host of other lifestyle characteristics compared with those who drink beer, for example, which generally mean they have more protective factors unrelated to their drinking, e.g., being relatively wealthy.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;So, what should you do?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;So where does this leave people unsure about whether or not alcohol is good for them in moderate amounts? &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to Koob, one should consider whether the benefits of drinking outweigh the risks. Are they taking medications that interact with alcohol? Are they pregnant, planning to be pregnant, or breastfeeding? Is there is a history of alcohol dependence in the family? Are they able to keep their drinking within the low-risk guidelines? &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It is important to consider carefully any risks, if possible, in concert with your physician, when deciding whether or not to consume alcohol,” he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Koob notes that a person may choose to drink in moderation for a social benefit. However, there are no definitive answers regarding possible health benefits of moderate consumption.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For those unsure if they should introduce alcohol into their diet, the American Dietary Guidelines do not recommend that individuals who do not drink alcohol start drinking.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As with many matters relating to health, the risks and benefits of alcohol are largely dependent on the individual and as such it is hard for experts to make a broad recommendation. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The blanket statement I’m comfortable with is that alcohol presents a risk to the health of everyone who drinks it, but in proportion to how much they drink, and starting at a very low level,” Stockwell said. “Enjoy moderate drinking if you are a moderate drinker, but don’t kid yourself it’s doing any good healthwise. Be aware of the risks and try to limit the number of days you drink and stick within the drinking guidelines.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-02-17T11:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-17T11:00:00</updateddate>

</guid>
<dc:creator>Elizabeth Pratt</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-17T19:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>
Is Swimming the Best Exercise for Children with Asthma?
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/swimming-for-children-with-asthma
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/childrens-health/021717_asthmaswim_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It’s cold outside, which means it can be difficult to get anyone, let alone kids, up off the couch to exercise.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And if your child has asthma that can present concerns.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the United States, asthma affects 1 in 11 children, according to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/asthma/impacts_nation/asthmafactsheet.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Center for Disease Control (CDC)&lt;/a&gt;. And a cold, dry winter can make these youngsters even more susceptible to the condition.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Asthma is a chronic inflammation of the airways — or bronchial tubes — inside the lungs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;What can be problematic for children with asthma is how exercise, or any kind of strenuous activity — games of tag or school soccer matches — can affect the disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With asthma a person’s airways are always inflamed to some degree, so exercise can lead to a more acute and serious condition known as exercise-induced asthma (EID) or exercise-induced bronchospasm (EIB).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Tod Olin, a pediatric pulmonary specialist at &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nationaljewish.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;National Jewish Health&lt;/a&gt;, explains: “[As] you exercise, you breathe more, as you breathe more the air in the airways is moving back and forth and it evaporates some of the water that is naturally lining your airways. This process of drying leads to the muscle squeezing down and causing the airflow limitation.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Indoor pools an option&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;So what, if anything, can a parent do to keep a child with asthma up and active?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Olin and others say swimming at an indoor pool can be a great physical activity for children with asthma.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Among other things, the presence of humidity is helpful for alleviating the dryness in the airways typically associated with cardiovascular exercise.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If you can prevent the water loss, by being in a really humid environment, the chances of having a problem go down,” Olin told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Tonya Winders, president and chief executive officer of the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.allergyasthmanetwork.org&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Allergy &amp;amp; Asthma Network&lt;/a&gt;, echoes that sentiment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She told Healthline that humid environments such as steam rooms are commonly used to help people with bronchoconstriction to relax and open up the airways.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Swimming also holds additional benefits for kids with asthma, due to the nature of the exercise itself.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;By holding their breath, children not only help to expand their lung capacity, but also gain a greater &lt;a href=&quot;http://njhealth.multimedia-newsroom.com/index.php/2017/02/07/why-you-should-enroll-your-child-with-asthma-in-swimming-classes/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;ability to control their breathing&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Though, as with any other exercise, some preventative measures should be taken to minimize the possibility of an asthma attack.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Both Winders and Olin suggest that children pretreat with a few puffs of their short-acting asthma medication before beginning their exercise.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ultimately though, swimming is just another option for kids to get out and move their bodies. It certainly isn’t the only activity for children with asthma.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Anything every other healthy child can do, a child with asthma should be able to do if their symptoms are well-controlled,” says Winders.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Olin agrees.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We definitely don’t want to give the message, ‘Don’t do something because you have asthma,’ because something like 30 percent of Olympic athletes have asthma,” he said. “You can do anything you want with asthma, for the most part.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What about the chlorine?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Chlorine doesn’t have a significant impact on asthma symptoms.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It is true that when chlorine comes in contact with human waste — be it sweat or urine — it can form chemicals known as &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/healthywater/swimming/aquatics-professionals/chloramines.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;chloramines&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s those chloramines, not the chlorine itself, responsible for causing irritation in the eyes and respiratory tract.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“[The] relative risk that we can attribute to [chlorine] in 2017 is really, really low,” said Olin. “So, the benefit of getting someone out and exercising, especially if they like to swim, outweighs the theoretic risk of the chlorine.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, Winders does caution that asthma and potential interactions with irritants such as chlorine must be treated on a case-by-case basis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It really depends on the person and their individual triggers as to what makes their asthma worse,” she said.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
