<category>Children's Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-02-15T09:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-15T09:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/parents-pay-to-keep-children-with-allergies-safe
</guid>
<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-15T17:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Americans Still Skipping Out on Helpful Vaccines</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/americans-skipping-helpful-vaccines
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/021417_vaccinations_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Nobody likes getting stuck by a needle, but the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) says we should get used to it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Agency officials recently unveiled an &lt;a href=&quot;http://annals.org/aim/article/2601209/recommended-immunization-schedule-adults-aged-19-years-older-united-states&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;advisory&lt;/a&gt; for adult vaccinations, published in the Annals of Internal Medicine. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The new guidance eliminates the nasal flu shot due to inefficacy, but recommends most other flu vaccines as they’re effective in people with egg allergies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The CDC has also revised its recommendations for hepatitis B, HIV, and meningococcal disease vaccinations — as well as 10 other conditions. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another significant update: Children who receive their first human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine before they turn 15, and get the second dose within five months, only need those two doses instead of three. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Why don’t we get our shots?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;On the whole, adults in the United States are not getting vaccinated as much as they should, according to the CDC Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP), which wrote the report.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Only 20 percent of adults over the age of 19 have had an updated Tdap vaccine, which guards against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis (whooping cough).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;About 44 percent of adults the same age has had a flu shot.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And 20 percent of those ages 19 to 64 who were at risk for pneumonia had the pneumococcal vaccine, while 60 percent of those over the age of 65 had gotten it, the report stated.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One barrier to getting vaccinated is insurance, Dr. Sandra Fryhofer, a general internist in Atlanta and American College of Physicians’ liaison to the ACIP, who served with the vaccine work group, told &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cbsnews.com/news/cdc-updated-vaccine-guidelines-what-you-need-to-know-flu-shot-hpv/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;CBS&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She said that insured Americans are two to five times more likely to receive their vaccines. Misconceptions about vaccines can also cause people — especially parents — to question or avoid them.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Michael Brady, the associate medical director at Nationwide Children’s Hospital, and member of the hospital’s Division of Infectious Diseases, told Healthline that many parents &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2017/02/06/parents-of-young-children-are-more-vaccine-hesitant/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;avoid&lt;/a&gt; having their children vaccinated because they hear inaccurate reports about side effects. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The common theme is that ‘someone’ has told them about their child or even a friend or relative’s child that had a terrible response after getting a vaccine. Then if they go to the internet, there is so much inaccurate information, that it compounds the problem,” Brady explained.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Flu season significant&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;One vaccine parents may have their families skip is the flu shot.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In past years, reports have emerged that the shots weren’t effective, or even caused the flu. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Most of the time, the illness that they got was not influenza but rather a different, but less serious, respiratory or gastrointestinal virus,” Brady noted.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Although some people get the flu after getting the vaccine, it reduces overall numbers and makes the virus less severe, he added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;We are in the midst of a &lt;a href=&quot;http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2017/02/07/flu-prevention-children/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;significant flu season&lt;/a&gt; where pediatric hospitalizations and deaths are mounting. In New York, &lt;a href=&quot;http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2017/02/07/flu-prevention-children/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;CBS&lt;/a&gt; reported there were four child deaths from the flu this year — the same number as reported in &lt;a href=&quot;http://abc6onyourside.com/news/local/child-flu-deaths-in-ohio-on-the-rise&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Ohio&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;From Jan. 29 to Feb. 4 of this year, the CDC reports that five children died from the flu. As of earlier this week, 20 children had died nationally according to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/index.htm#S3&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;CDC&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Brady believes that pediatricians do a good job of promoting vaccines, but adult providers are “not quite as used to incorporating vaccine recommendations into their general adult well-patient visits” though they are getting better. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>General Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-02-14T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-14T12:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/americans-skipping-helpful-vaccines
</guid>
<dc:creator>Kristen Fischer</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-14T20:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>GMO Apples, Potatoes Hitting Store Shelves</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/gmo-apples-potatoes-hitting-shelves
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/021417_gmofood_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Genetically modified organisms (GMOs) are back in the news.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s because some genetically modified produce is heading for store shelves.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;GMO apples and potatoes will be in Midwest produce departments this month.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s the start of a 2017 rollout of these types of items. And should provide some food for grocery aisle debate. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;GMOs are created in a laboratory when genes from the DNA of one species are extracted and artificially forced into the genes of an unrelated plant or animal.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The foreign genes may come from bacteria, viruses, insects, animals, or even humans. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;To eat or not to eat?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;If you don’t want to eat GMO food, said Alexis Baden-Mayer, political director of the Organic Consumers Association, you have one clear option.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Organic is one’s only defense,” she told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Food that is certified non-GMO is actually another option for concerned shoppers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Until recently no fresh produce were GMOs. It was mainly soybeans and corn, which was not available as fresh products,” Jaydee Hanson, senior policy analyst of the Center for Food Safety, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The vast majority of corn, soy, canola, and sugar beets grown in the United States is now genetically engineered.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These items are often used as ingredients in processed foods. Tests have shown that GMOs are present in many packaged foods, such as breakfast cereals, chips, baking mixes, and protein bars.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Does that present a health danger?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The contention that GMOs pose no risks to human health can’t be supported by studies that have measured a time frame that is too short to determine the effects of exposure over a lifetime,” said Dr. Robert Gould, president of the board of Physicians for Social Responsibility, in a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.consumerreports.org/cro/magazine/2015/02/gmo-foods-what-you-need-to-know/index.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2015 interview&lt;/a&gt; with Consumer Reports.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Coming to a store near you&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Now GMO apples and potatoes will be in grocery store produce bins.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A GMO apple looks like any other except for one salient feature. It won’t turn brown. The company has turned off some of the genes that make them change color.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Here’s the catch, according to Hanson, “The apples are sitting in the store looking white [inside], but may be covered with microbes not covered by genetic engineering.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He cited food industry arguments that a lot of fruit goes to waste because it turns brown.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Maybe that’s a good thing because of those other microbes,” Hanson said. “Does it still taste fresh? I don’t know. It’s not that difficult to cut up an apple.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Potatoes are on their way as well, probably in the form of chips or other processed food, Hanson noted.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Traditionally, apples were preserved by being sprayed with something acidic, such as lemon juice.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hanson doesn’t know what is done to the Arctic Apples, the name of the supplier. It’s a division of Intrexon, which describes itself as designing biologically-based consumer solutions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Look for the label&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Labeling of GMO food remains a hot-button issue.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Not surprisingly, the food industry doesn’t like labels.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When Vermont passed a labeling law last year, the industry responded by backing what they considered to be a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2016/aug/2/obama-signs-bill-overturning-vermonts-gmo-labeling/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;weaker national law&lt;/a&gt;. Hanson noted that law precluded states such as Vermont from legislating on their own.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, that action has led to an unexpected consequence.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The new labeling law will require regulations to determine how these rules will work, who will provide oversight, and so on.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But the Trump administration has &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2017/01/30/trump-orders-two--one-repeal-all-new-regulations/97237870/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;announced&lt;/a&gt; that for every new regulation produced, two old ones must be tossed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Where that leaves them, nobody knows, Hanson said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dealing with the climate in Washington presents a real challenge now, he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Nothing will change immediately. We may have a new law on the kind of labeling, or it may be put on hold,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It may be labeling lite,” he added, half joking. “I’d prefer to see something straightforward, like you have on a Snickers bar. But we’re not going to get that from most food companies.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hanson said good labeling might be something small printed on the package that a consumer could scan with a phone, “while they’re shepherding three kids through the supermarket.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Baden-Mayer takes it a step further, noting that the administration will be limited on what regulations it wants on GMO crops.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think these extreme tactics would probably hurt farmers who would benefit from FDA rules,” she said. “The whole process may become unbearable … maybe grind to a halt.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Going organic&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Baden-Mayer acknowledges that eating organic takes more work.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Don’t buy prepared food. Live near an organic market,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One thing that drives consumers to an organic approach is children with health problems, including behavioral issues, digestive problems, being on the autism spectrum, allergies, and even cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When children have health problems, the parents are interested in what can be done to help them,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That may mean eliminating a food or two or restricting the diet and then adding foods as health improves.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Lots of parents find organic foods reduce the intensity of their child’s symptoms,” Baden-Mayer said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She added that it helps to have a holistic physician, someone interested in diet issues.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Unresolved issues&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;All in all, the GMO issue remains in flux.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s not known whether new products will be introduced with new regulations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s also not known whether these products will have consumer-friendly labeling or whether they’ll be considered a health risk.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Consider Polly’s plight.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A cartoon from 2014 by Ann Tenae shows a parrot on a perch saying, “Polly wants a gluten-free, low sodium, non-GMO cracker.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Good luck with that, Polly.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Food and Nutrition</category>
<pubdate>2017-02-14T11:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-14T11:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/gmo-apples-potatoes-hitting-shelves
</guid>
<dc:creator>Roberta Alexander</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-14T19:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Ingestible Capsule Powers Itself Using Gastric Acid
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/capsule-powers-itself-using-gastric-acid
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/tech/021417_stomachacid_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Researchers in Boston have come up with a novel new way of powering ingestible capsules.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A team at Brigham and Women’s Hospital has developed a capsule that can be powered by a galvanic cell battery that draws its juice from stomach acid.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The team demonstrated this by having their battery successfully power an ingestible thermometer. It took measurements every 12 seconds inside a pig’s stomach for six days.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Experts in the field say that while there’s still a lot of work to be done, the research could be an important step to improving the long-term utility of ingestible devices.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The team was led by Phillip Nadeau, Ph.D., study author, and postdoctoral researcher at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They announced their findings in Prolonged Energy Harvesting for Ingestible Devices, published in the journal &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nature.com/articles/s41551-016-0022&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Nature Research&lt;/a&gt; earlier this month.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Useful ... until the battery dies&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ingestible devices are useful tools for doctors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They are utilized in a variety of applications from simple vital sign measurement, to dispensing medication, to “pill cams,” which provide video feedback as an alternative to more invasive means of diagnosis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These devices, particularly the more energy-intensive pill cams, are limited by a lack of power. While simpler devices use minimal power, a pill cam tends to drain its battery quickly, with no means of recharging while it’s inside the body.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In an effort to develop a device that could provide continuous power on a long-term basis, the research team turned to an old science class standby.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“One of the things we started contemplating with our collaborators in the Department of Electrical Engineering at MIT was looking at a galvanic cell, basically a takeoff of the lemon battery that’s often explored in school,” Giovanni Traverso, Ph.D., senior co-author, and instructor at Harvard Medical School, told Healthline. “And that’s exactly what we did. We used the gastric fluid as the electrolyte, and we used the copper and zinc as the cathode and anode, respectively, to generate that current.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think the researchers put forth some interesting demonstrations of a zinc-copper type electrolytic cell for power,” John Rogers, Ph.D., physical chemist, and chair of the Rogers Research Group at the University of Illinois, told Healthline. “By comparison to more widely used magnesium-based systems, the appeal of zinc is that it can offer long-term operation — several days, as opposed to one or two. So I think that’s an important advance. There’s an electrical engineering team involved in that work that put together some pretty interesting low-power electronics. They had some pretty clever ways to optimize the power utilization and accommodate for the fluctuations in the power that were coming from the battery.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Drew Higgins, Ph.D., Banting Postdoctoral Fellow at Stanford University, told Healthline in an email, “The authors took fundamental electrochemistry concepts that many of us would have applied through lemon battery or penny battery experiments in school. While this battery chemistry may not be practical for your cell phone or laptop, the authors recognized some key features of these systems. Primarily, they are inexpensive, biocompatible, and capable of producing enough energy to power microdevices assembled in their laboratory.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A variety of skills&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The technology, which couples electrochemistry with biomedical engineering, required researchers with varied skillsets. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We did have a diverse group with expertise ranging from electronics design to packaging, chemistry, and medicine,” wrote Nadeau. “Having such a diverse team was a tremendous asset to this work. Working at the interface of these different areas helped us find and try something that was broadly interesting.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There are electrical engineering challenges here, there are materials challenges, and then there are animal model challenges,” acknowledged Traverso. “So you really need a broad expertise to come together, collaborate, and execute. And that’s reflected in the manuscript when you look at the authors and where they come from. They come from departments in electrical engineering, chemical engineering, from hospitals, and I think it really takes that kind of collaboration to address some of the major challenges.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Higgins says this multidisciplinary approach is crucial — not just in this research, but in other scientific endeavors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“As scientists and engineers, we consistently talk about the fact that interdisciplinary collaborations underpin some of the most high impact research,” he wrote, “And this study exemplifies this perfectly.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Big possibilities, big challenges&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;This technology could underpin the way ingestible devices operate in the future.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The research, however, is still in its infancy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nadeau says that miniaturizing the device and using more advanced circuit design is a priority.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He’d also like to explore more advanced sensors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Ultimately, it would be neat if five or 10 years down the road, we could power a long-term ingestible vital signs monitor with this technology,” Nadeau said. “Essentially, a pill that could monitor your breathing and heart rate from inside the stomach and transmit it wirelessly for up to a week using the harvested energy from the cell.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“You can just let your imagination run wild with things you’d like to measure, sense, capture, store, sample, or even deliver therapy. Kind of the whole gamut,” said Rogers. “But I think the menu of options is going to be limited by the range of functionality you can pack into a relatively small footprint. But then, the overarching concern is going to be how to power it. I think going forward, there will probably be a lot of optimization you can do. But it’s a good starting point for sure.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“With respect to where we could be in five or 10 years, I think that depending on further interest — and that means collaboration with potential sponsors and also further funding — I think we could be in humans fairly quickly,” said Traverso.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Technology</category>
<pubdate>2017-02-14T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-14T10:00:00</updateddate>

<dc:creator>Dan Gray</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-14T18:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>
A New Possibility: Women with Heart Defects Having Babies
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/women-with-heart-defects-having-babies
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/womens-health/020917_heartbabies_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Erica Thomas was born with several heart defects. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At birth her outlook was poor, and her early years were focused on staying alive. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We had to move to low altitude away from family and friends. I didn't play competitive sports as a kid and often would require a modified version of P.E. in school and sometimes even academic assistance,” Thomas told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The 37-year-old has undergone three major heart surgeries as well as a pacemaker implantation for her four heart defects — a trial septal defect (ASD), single ventricle defect, pulmonary atresia, and tricuspid atresia. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She is one of 2.5 million people in the United States living with congenital heart defects. About 1.4 million are adults.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Since 2000, the number of people with heart defects who are living into adulthood has increased by 63 percent. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Pressure on the heart&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;A growing number of women with congenital heart defects are now hoping to become pregnant.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Under &lt;a href=&quot;http://circ.ahajournals.org/content/early/2017/01/12/CIR.0000000000000458&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;new guidelines&lt;/a&gt; from the American Heart Association (AHA) this may now be possible for some of them. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Traditionally, doctors have advised women with complex congenital heart conditions not to get pregnant, due to the pressure both pregnancy and childbirth place on the heart. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the &lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/successful-pregnancy-possible-for-some-women-with-high-risk-congenital-heart-disease-2/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;AHA&lt;/a&gt;, “changes from pregnancy tax the heart and circulatory system. Blood volume increases by about 40 percent, cardiac output increases 30 percent to 50 percent, and heart rate rises 10 to 20 beats per minute.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Such changes dramatically impact the cardiovascular system, and in women with congenital heart defects this poses a particular risk. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“A major concern is whether the heart muscle is strong enough to sustain the physiological changes of normal pregnancy,” Mary Canobbio, R.N., chair of the statement-writing group for the new guidelines, and lecturer at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA), School of Nursing, told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If the muscle is already weak by the cardiac condition, the extra burden can cause further weakening,” she added. “Other changes, primarily hormonal can lead to irregular heart rhythms (arrhythmias) ... especially in those women who have had arrhythmias before conception. Some of these are quite serious and can be fatal.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Canobbio notes another concern is the changes in pregnancy that can increase the risk of developing clots. Some heart conditions are prone to clot formation before conception, and pregnancy may increase the risk of thrombosis (a clot), embolism (a clot that travels), and stroke. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Pregnancy a possibility&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The new set of recommendations from the AHA is providing the medical community with the guidance to help women with congenital heart defects have successful pregnancies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This really represents a shift in thinking and offers new hope for a growing segment of our society,” said Canobbio in a &lt;a href=&quot;http://ucla.multimedia-newsroom.com/index.php/2017/02/06/growing-group-of-women-take-heart-in-pregnancy-recommendations/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;press release&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Among the recommendations, the AHA suggests women undertake extensive preconception testing and counseling, to determine if they can safely deliver a baby. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If the woman is deemed able to safely have a baby she should then work alongside a team of specialists including an OB-GYN trained in high-risk pregnancies, as well as a cardiologist. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The good news is that for the majority of women with congenital heart disease, the risk of pregnancy is small. But for a number of defects, especially those considered complex, the risk is much higher and it is this group of women who must have not only preconceptional counseling but need to undergo full diagnostic evaluation to determine her risk before becoming pregnant,” Canobbio told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Canobbio says tools now available to manage high-risk pregnancies are instrumental in ensuring a successful pregnancy for women with congenital heart defects.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, there will still be some women for whom pregnancy is deemed too high risk. In these cases, such women will be discouraged from becoming pregnant. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For those that are given the “all clear” to deliver a baby, the recommendations suggest that women deliver at a large medical facility that has sufficient resources to respond to any medical emergencies. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After delivery, doctors should carefully monitor the woman’s heart function for at least six weeks and in some cases up to six months. This is to check for any long-term damage that may have occurred due to the pregnancy. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In both of Thomas’ pregnancies, her team of cardiologists closely monitored her. She was given regular echocardiograms, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.mayoclinic.org/tests-procedures/stress-test/basics/definition/prc-20019801&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;stress tests&lt;/a&gt;, electrocardiograms, and blood pressure tests. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Regular ultrasounds from her obstetrician as well as echocardiograms for the fetus were also undertaken. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A personal tale of precaution&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Before both of her deliveries, Thomas was transferred via ambulance from her local medical facility to UCLA with a specialized nurse on board.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Despite her water breaking early in both of her pregnancies and a 74-day stay in the hospital prior to a cesarean delivery for her second baby, both Thomas and her two children are healthy. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“One of my first questions to my cardiology team regarding family planning was, ‘Have there been other patients who have done this and what were the outcomes?’” Thomas said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our decision to go forward was primarily based on my health and the recommendations of my medical team. We would not have moved forward if there were any major concerns about my well-being and my heart's ability to handle pregnancy,” she told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If there are tools and resources out there to increase our vitality and longevity, and the ability to possibly bear children, then let’s make them available to everyone everywhere,” she added. “The best way to make an informed decision is to be informed.” &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

</guid>
<dc:creator>Elizabeth Pratt</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-13T21:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Why Don’t Girls Pursue Science-Related Jobs?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/why-dont-girls-pursue-science-jobs
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/womens-health/020717_girlssmart_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Girls get better grades than boys in school.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are also more female college graduates than males.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So, why is there a much smaller number of women in science and technology fields than men?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It could be related to something that happens to girls as early as first grade.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a recent study, researchers concluded that girls as young as age 6 start to think they aren’t as smart as boys.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Why this happens is still a mystery.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What the researchers found&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Findings of the study were first reported in the journal &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2017/01/young-girls-are-less-likely-believe-their-gender-brilliant-they-age&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Science&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the authors, the premise for the study was that men, more often than women, are associated with intellect.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This assumption or stereotype is what discourages women from holding successful careers in fields that “cherish brilliance,” such as science, technology, engineering, and math (S.T.E.M.).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Because of this stereotype, are women less likely to be successful [in the workplace]?” Lin Bian, Ph.D. candidate in psychology at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, and lead author of the study, told Healthline. “It’s important to know if young girls are being held back because of these stereotypes.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;About 400 children participated in the study, Bian said. About 75 percent of the kids were white.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To conduct the research, Bian and her team put the young students into groups and presented a few different scenarios about gender and intellect.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One of scenarios had the children listen to a story about a “really, really smart person,” Bian said. The researchers never disclosed if the person in the story was male or female.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When the story was finished, they showed the kids pictures of two women and two men, and then asked the kids to identify who they thought the story was about.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At age 5, the children usually selected their own gender. But at age 6 that changed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Boys were 70 percent more likely to pick a man, but girls were only 50 percent more likely to pick a woman.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Bain said that response was consistent across all races.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In another setting, the researchers showed the children a game and said only “really, really smart people could play,” Bain said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They then asked the kids if they wanted to play. At age 5, both boys and girls showed equal interest. But at age 6, more girls showed less interest.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Why the research is important&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Matthew C. Makel, Ph.D., director of research at Duke University Talent Identification Program, told Healthline that it’s rare to find researchers focusing on such young children with regard to perception of gender intelligence.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He found the age of participants coupled with the line of inquiry especially insightful because the research is trying to get at the larger implications about the role of women in the workplace.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think the questions they are asking are great,” he said. “They should be applauded.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But he also cautioned against jumping to conclusions so quickly. The particular focus group was only from one community, he added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We as consumers of the research need to be careful of the findings,” Makel said. “It’s still an awfully small sample.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He believes that in order for researchers to make definitive declarations about how young girls view the intelligence capacity of their gender, a bigger, more broadly based study is warranted.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He’d like to see the study replicated in different communities within the United States and around the world. Even better would be to follow a group of children, starting at age 5, and continue to assess their views on intelligence and gender each year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“To see how individual perspectives change,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Still wondering why&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Bian and her team didn't ask the kids the reasons behind their choices. That’s for another study currently under way.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But the researchers did discover that the children’s assumptions about their gender had nothing to do with academic ability.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They asked the kids who did better in school. Both genders said girls.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Makel said the children's perspectives about academics are backed up by data.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Girls in general do better than boys in school. Females also consistently graduate from college at a higher rate than males. They now account for 60 percent of all college graduates.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“So they can succeed and excel,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But good grades and academic achievement don’t always translate into positions of power.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Particularly in work settings where intelligence or brilliance is revered — even demanded — such as S.T.E.M. related careers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Females make up half of the work force in the United States, but they hold less than 25 percent of S.T.E.M. related jobs, according to a report from the Department of Commerce.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;What’s more, women who hold S.T.E.M. degrees are less likely to work in these fields. Instead, they pursue careers in education or health-related industries.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Makel said the answers as to why are complex.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some studies have shown that women and men choose careers based on different values, Makel added. Men appear to be drawn to jobs or careers that allow them to work with things, he said. Women often lean toward careers that place a high value on building relationships.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“What’s the cause of that?” he said. “Is it biological factors or is it society?”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These are the kinds of questions that this study is ultimately trying to get at, Makel added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Bain suspects there will be multiple reasons, including influence from parents, peers, and the media.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We want to find out the reasons,” she said. “The answer won’t be a single reason.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-02-13T13:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-13T13:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/why-dont-girls-pursue-science-jobs
</guid>
<dc:creator>Carolyn Abate</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-13T21:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>President Trump’s Policies Could Harm Your Health</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/trump-policies-could-harm-your-health
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/020917_healthbudget_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt
]]>
<![CDATA[
;&lt;p&gt;President Donald Trump considers himself an environmentalist.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He told &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/23/us/politics/trump-new-york-times-interview-transcript.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;The New York Times&lt;/a&gt; in late November, “Clean air is vitally important. Clean water, crystal clean water, is vitally important.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Then in a meeting three weeks ago with several auto industry chief executives, &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/innovations/wp/2017/01/24/donald-trump-tells-detroit-auto-ceos-environmental-regulations-are-out-of-control/?utm_term=.787daceba397&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;he reiterated&lt;/a&gt;, “I am, to a large extent, an environmentalist.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But the president’s actions speak much louder than his words.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In early December, he &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/02/us/politics/scott-pruitt-epa-senate.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;nominated&lt;/a&gt; former Oklahoma Attorney General Scott Pruitt to lead the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For years, Pruitt has tried to undermine the agency’s regulations on clean water, air pollution, and other issues, even suing the EPA more than a dozen times. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Pruitt has opposed EPA efforts to reduce power plant pollution. He has also tried to block such things as the Cross-State Air Pollution Rule, which limits power plant emissions like sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides are in &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.lung.org/our-initiatives/healthy-air/sota/health-risks/?referrer=https://www.google.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;soot and smog pollution&lt;/a&gt;, which can cause bronchitis, cardiovascular disease, and premature death.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Trump appears to share Pruitt’s opinion of the EPA and environmental regulations in general. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The president has vowed to cut the EPA budget by as much as $1 billion, which, officials tell Healthline, will likely lead to a national public health crisis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The EPA, courtesy of Richard Nixon&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The EPA, which was established by former President Richard Nixon in 1970, has been largely responsible for reducing human exposure to toxins and making America’s air and water cleaner.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The national demand for a governmental body to address pollution was prompted by two events in 1969.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The first was the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-santa-barbara-oil-spill-1969-20150520-htmlstory.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;oil rig blowout&lt;/a&gt; that spilled 100,000 barrels of oil off the coast of Santa Barbara, Calif.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The second was the &lt;a href=&quot;https://clevelandhistorical.org/items/show/63#.WJ4M1xIrJo4&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;raging fire&lt;/a&gt; on Cleveland’s Cuyahoga River, which was filled with toxic, untreated industrial waste.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Both environmental disasters led to the first &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.earthday.org/about/the-history-of-earth-day/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Earth Day&lt;/a&gt; in 1970, when 20 million demonstrators nationwide pushed the nation in a new, more environment-friendly direction.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The EPA was established that same year, as was an updated version of the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.epa.gov/laws-regulations/summary-clean-air-act&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Clean Air Act&lt;/a&gt;. The &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.epa.gov/laws-regulations/summary-clean-water-act&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Clean Water Act&lt;/a&gt; came two years later.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The EPA has been at the forefront of air and water pollution control ever since.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Former President Barack Obama used the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.edf.org/blog/2017/01/12/ready-defend-obamas-environmental-legacy-top-10-accomplishments-focus&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;agency&lt;/a&gt;, despite a generally unsupportive Congress, to protect the environment and improve public health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Among other things, Obama set new pollution limits for power plant smokestacks, placed the first ever limit on carbon pollution, preserved 260 million acres by designating 19 national monuments, and, in a move just before his tenure expired, banned oil drilling in large parts of the Arctic and Atlantic oceans.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Obama also set standards for fuel efficiency for cars and trucks, signed the largest ever commitment to protect the Gulf Coast, and signed the first major environmental law in two decades to fix the broken chemical safety landscape.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/meet-4-republican-lawmakers-who-want-abolish-epa-n717061&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;many Republicans&lt;/a&gt; think the EPA has too much power and is a bureaucratic waste of taxpayer money.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Trump’s plan to cut the agency’s budget by $1 billion, along with more expected &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.vox.com/energy-and-environment/2017/1/23/14356652/trump-epa-regulations&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;executive orders and new legislation&lt;/a&gt;, will reverse most, if not all, of Obama’s momentum on protections against water and air pollution, toxic waste sites, and a host of other things.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But the cuts, orders, and policies, which Trump says are necessary to &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.npr.org/2017/01/24/511341779/president-trump-to-cut-regulations-by-75-percent-how-real-is-that&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;generate the country’s business machine&lt;/a&gt;, will have a devastating impact on American health, officials tell Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The environment and our health&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;David Helvarg, executive director of Blue Frontier, an ocean conservation and policy group, said that environmental issues and health are inextricably linked.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It has been demonstrated over and over in this country that when we improve environmental quality, we also improve overall public health,” said Helvarg, an author whose books include “The War Against the Greens and the Golden Shore: California’s Love Affair with the Sea.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Trump’s policies will have a hazardous effect on the health of Americans,” Helvarg told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The activist noted that last year, “somewhat miraculously,” a bipartisan &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.congress.gov/bill/114th-congress/house-bill/2576&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;environmental bill&lt;/a&gt; made its way through both houses of Congress. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The bill, which reformed the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA), broke a logjam in place for 20-plus years, Helvarg said, in terms of how the EPA evaluates chemicals based on the health risk they pose to the public.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The bill compelled the agency to get back to the job of protecting all Americans against dangerous chemicals, explained Helvarg. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The EPA was not doing a great job on this,” he said. “Both sides agreed this was in the public interest. It takes an enormous amount of work to do it well, but thanks to the bill this is a new responsibility of EPA.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But it seems inevitable that the new administration will revisit and possibly reverse this legislation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In fact, one of Trump’s first acts as president was imposing a freeze on EPA grants and contracts.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.propublica.org/article/trump-administration-imposes-freeze-on-epa-grants-and-contracts&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;ProPublica report&lt;/a&gt;, that restriction could affect everything from water quality testing to toxic cleanups.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The new EPA director&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;When Trump nominated Pruitt to run the EPA, public health advocates and environmentalists were &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.colorlines.com/articles/former-and-current-epa-employees-denounce-trumps-pick-top-administrator&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;critical&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When he was attorney general in Oklahoma, Pruitt &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/01/14/us/politics/document-Pruitt-v-EPA-a-Compilation-of-Oklahoma-14.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;sued the EPA 14 times&lt;/a&gt;. He told &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.thewhim.com/trump-puts-hold-epa-grant-bars-social-media-updates/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Fox News&lt;/a&gt; two years ago that the environment would be “fine” without the EPA.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Pruitt also went after such things as ozone protection and air pollution standards. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Pruitt sued the EPA over the requirement that technology be added on to cut mercury emissions from coal-burning power plants. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ken Kimmell, president of the Union of Concerned Scientists, and a former commissioner of the Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection, told Healthline that power plant smokestacks are the largest source of mercury emissions in the country.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Mercury is one of most potent neurotoxins there is; as it is emitted into the atmosphere, it drifts and deposits on water bodies, and people eating big fish like tuna and swordfish are in danger of mercury ingestion,” Kimmell said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Approximately 60 percent of coal-burning power plants have adopted the technology to cut these emissions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It can be done. Technology exists, but for the 40 percent who have not, there is no reason for it,” said Kimmell.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another issue that Pruitt went after when he was in Oklahoma is the complicated one of interstate air pollution. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kimmell explained that pollution goes from state A to state B, and state B doesn’t have much ability to stop this pollution. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The EPA’s purpose is to have federal regulations to police the problem of interstate air pollution,” he said. “Obama came up with a workable plan to address this problem. Pruitt sued to have it overturned. He was unsuccessful, but it is something he could choose to resurrect.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The effects in your town&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Trump’s EPA cuts are expected to trickle down into private, state, and municipal level entities, which receive some of their funding from the federal agency. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The important point that many people don’t realize is that a lot of the day-to-day enforcement of our environmental laws that protect our air, water, landfills, etc., are done at the state level, but funded through the federal EPA,” Kimmell said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The states agree to take on those things, he said, under the theory that they are closer to the ground and have a better understanding of what is going on in their own communities. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Cuts of this magnitude won’t just take away bureaucrats’ jobs in Washington,” he said. “They will mean major cuts to state enforcement of environmental laws as well.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As a result, Kimmell said fewer rivers and streams will get tested for such things as &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.water-research.net/index.php/fecal-coliform-bacteria-in-water&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;fecal bacteria&lt;/a&gt;, which can cause such pathogenic diseases such as dysentery, typhoid fever, viral and bacterial gastroenteritis, and hepatitis A.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In this administration, there will be far less protection of America’s rivers and streams that are used for swimming and fishing, and that puts us all at greater health risk,” he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This administration’s actions will also lead to dirtier air, he added. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There will be less ability to enforce the laws that put caps on pollutants that come out of smoke stacks, for example,” he said. “Fewer hazardous waste sites will be cleaned up, and more toxins will get into our water supplies.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Looking at the bigger picture, Kimmell said, “You will see a reversal of 50 years of progress we’ve made in providing clean air and water and providing a healthy environment, even while we have grown the economy.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The changes have already begun&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Last week, House Republicans voted to dismiss a rule that prohibits the dumping of toxic coal mining debris into streams.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As &lt;a href=&quot;http://time.com/4657438/congressional-republicans-environmental-regulations-coal-streams/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Time magazine&lt;/a&gt; reported, Rep. Bill Johnson, the Ohio Republican who sponsored the dismissal, said the Obama administration rule was not designed to protect streams but was “an effort to regulate the coal mining industry right out of business.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But Arizona Rep. Raul Grijalva, senior Democrat on the House Natural Resources Committee, strongly disagreed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He told Time that repealing the stream protection rule would “sicken and kill the very people Donald Trump falsely promised to help,” including coal miners in West Virginia and other states.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Rep. John Yarmuth, a Kentucky Democrat, reportedly displayed a bottle of brownish water he said came from a constituent's well near a surface coal mine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He challenged legislators to drink from it and said the stream rule was one of the only safety measures protecting people living in coal country.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Republicans in Congress later said that ending this rule was just the beginning of what will be many actions that reverse eight years of Obama’s regulations that they insist are excessive.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Is regulation getting a bum rap?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kimmell said that the Trump administration is doing its best to tarnish the word “regulation.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Regulation is just a synonym for protections that all of us enjoy. It’s about government setting clear rules and enforcing those rules, and not allowing a corporation to get away with putting us all at risk,” Kimmell said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He acknowledges there is a cost to having those rules in place, but says, “There is also tremendous benefit. If you don’t agree, go visit New Delhi or Beijing and try to take a jog around those cities.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Trump has stated repeatedly that environmental regulations are bad for business and that renewables are a “&lt;a href=&quot;http://fortune.com/2017/01/27/solar-wind-renewable-jobs/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;bad investment&lt;/a&gt;.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, the findings of a&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href=&quot;http://edfclimatecorps.org/sites/edfclimatecorps.org/files/the_growth_of_americas_clean_energy_and_sustainability_jobs.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;major study&lt;/a&gt; published by the Environmental Defense Fund's (EDF) Climate Corps program dispute that.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It shows that the solar and wind industries are each creating jobs at a rate 12 times faster than that of the rest of the U.S. economy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;EDF is one of the world’s largest environmental nonprofit organizations with more than 2 million members and a staff of more than 500 scientists, economists, policy experts, and other professionals around the world.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In its report, the organization concluded that solar and wind jobs have grown at rates of about 20 percent annually in recent years and collectively represent at least 4 million jobs in the United States, up from 3.4 million in 2011.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The renewable energy boom has been driven in part by state and local building efficiency policies and incentives and was supported by Obama.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Liz Delaney, program director at EDF Climate Corps, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.businessinsider.com/solar-energy-job-growth-2017-1&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;told Business Insider&lt;/a&gt; that Trump's current approach “is basically ignoring an entire industry that has grown up over the last 10 years or so and is quite robust.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kimmell said the irony of this is that while Trump touts himself as a job creator above all else, many of his anti-environment policies will be job killers. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The U.S. can afford to have a growing economy and have clean air and water,” he said. “That choice is presented to us over and over, and it is a false choice.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kimmell said Congress for a long time has been “aching” to roll back these regulations. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The only thing stopping them was President Obama, who vetoed those efforts,” he said. “We now have a Congress partial to industry and a president believing that regulations are bad for the economy. That will result in a lot of serious public health consequences.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Minority health at particular risk?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The health of minorities living in America’s inner cities could be especially threatened by Trump’s cuts and orders, a number of officials told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Jose Calderon, executive director of the Hispanic Federation, wrote in an &lt;a href=&quot;http://thehill.com/blogs/pundits-blog/energy-environment/318637-we-must-reject-scott-pruitt-he-doesnt-car-about&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;opinion piece&lt;/a&gt; published in The Hill last week that the “EPA’s mission of protecting our health, including promoting clean air and clean water, is particularly important for Hispanic Americans, as many of us are at heightened risk from pollution and degradation because of where we live and work.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2017, he added, 24 million Latinos lived in the country’s top 15 cities for smog pollution, and Latinos are also “overrepresented in outdoor jobs in industries like construction and agriculture, which place us on the front lines of air pollution and extreme weather.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Calderon concluded that, like all Americans, Latinos care about their health and the health of our communities. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We expect the administrator of EPA to also care about us, and to align with these values.” he wrote. “Scott Pruitt, however, has built his professional career suing EPA to block or rollback measures that protect Americans from harmful pollution and its negative health effects.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Other impacts on public health&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are other decisions President Trump is likely to make that will affect America’s health, including the impending &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/obamacare-being-dismantled-now-what&quot;&gt;repeal of the Affordable Care Act&lt;/a&gt;, the defunding of &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/what-if-planned-parenthood-went-out-of-business&quot;&gt;Planned Parenthood&lt;/a&gt;, and the &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/will-healthcare-for-veterans-improve-under-trump&quot;&gt;possible privatization&lt;/a&gt; of the Department of Veterans Affairs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are also new fears that Trump could try “to open up additional areas &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.politifact.com/florida/statements/2016/nov/22/bill-nelson/bill-nelson-says-donald-trump-intends-expand-oil-d/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;off the coast&lt;/a&gt; to oil drilling.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Californians will fight any such effort. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;California State Lands Commissioner Betty Yee &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.independent.com/news/2017/feb/01/state-lands-commissioner-opposes-venoco-applicatio/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;announced last week&lt;/a&gt; she is opposing Venoco Oil’s application to expand its lease in California waters off the coast of the University of California Santa Barbara, which would be the first new or expanded lease in state waters since the 1969 spill in Santa Barbara. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Oil drilling must not be expanded,” Yee said in a statement. “The Santa Barbara Channel is a world-renowned habitat that hosts vast terrestrial and marine diversity that deserves protection from the adverse environmental impacts of further oil drilling.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The fight between California’s environmental interests and Trump’s energy policy will be one to watch. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Helvarg said citizens not just in Santa Barbara but from coast to coast are preparing to resist many of this administration’s actions. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“No one wants dirty air or dirty water,” Helvarg said. “Look at California, the sixth largest economy in the world. Gov. Jerry Brown has said they will stand for climate change and for the environment. There is already widespread resistance to Trump’s extreme agenda.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Officials at the U.S. Health and Human Services Department and at the White House declined requests to be interviewed for this story.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>

<dc:creator>Jamie Reno</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-13T20:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>
Would You Know What to Do If You Saw Someone Having a Severe Allergy Attack?
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/what-to-do-for-someone-having-severe-allergy-attack
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/020917_allergyattack_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In 1980, at the age of 7, I became a near expert in the most unexpected topic. Food allergies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While most of my childhood friends were out perfecting their roller-skating moves, I was home memorizing a list of allergens our family must keep away from my younger sibling in order to keep her alive.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Before I dive deeper into this topic, it’s important to take a slight pause.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Remember, this was 1980. At this time food allergies were not a “trending topic” in the media.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There were no food allergy blogs. No “safe cupcakes” for school parties. No allergy alert sticky labels for kids’ lunchboxes. No storybooks for children with food allergies and their parents to read at night, reassuring them everything was going to be OK.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At the time, food allergies were unknown to most people.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Not a typical family&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Growing up I knew no other families with food allergies much less those allergic to peanuts, tree nuts, dairy, eggs, sesame, wheat, fruits, shellfish, and more.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;We were not like other families. And that was super clear.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;We quickly became a band of warriors on a mission to protect one of our own tribe.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Birthday parties were now dairy danger zones — ice cream, cakes, and other delights.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A night out at a restaurant was met with concern as we doubted our teenage waitress and if she heard our “no butter” request.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As it goes however, some crazy good often emerges when things get bad. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;We learned clever solutions and life hacks in which to make our way. And years later when I went on to have children who had food allergies, I felt slightly more prepared.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Two kids with combined allergies to peanuts, tree nuts, dairy, soy, sesame, shellfish, mango, and strawberries? No problem. I got this.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A different era now&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Being a parent to a child with allergies in 2017, however, is far different than being one in 1980.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;I’ve adopted many of my mother’s smart survival techniques while adhering to new study findings and important information out these days. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Today, we write Food Allergy &amp;amp; Anaphylaxis Emergency Care Plans, which we share with schools and others to help with positive outcomes in the event of a severe allergic reaction.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;We share “signs to look for” with babysitters, teachers, and grandparents for an allergic reaction. These include tightness of throat, struggling to breathe, wheezing, and loss of consciousness.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;We share tips on ways kids describe allergic reactions that might be confusing but are crucial to listen for. These include phrases such as “my throat tickles.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, it’s still difficult in today’s modern world to keep your child with food allergies safe as they travel through their busy lives from home, school, after school, bus, playdate, soccer practice, and so on.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Communication on how to keep kids with allergies safe can be lost and potentially lead to confusion in the event of a food allergy related emergency.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;New guidelines released&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Today, the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) released a &lt;a href=&quot;http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/early/2017/02/09/peds.2016-4005&quot;&gt;written action plan&lt;/a&gt; to help families, schools, and communities with ways to respond to life-threatening allergic reactions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The plan is featured in the AAP clinical report, Guidance on Completing a Written Allergy and Anaphylaxis Emergency Plan.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This plan reaffirms the importance of giving epinephrine in first aid treatment for anaphylaxis-related reactions and includes written plans for when and how to use it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The report is customizable and provides guidance for use.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Also included with the article is a second AAP clinical report called, Epinephrine for First-Aid Management of Anaphylaxis, which helps stress that administering an EpiPen is the first line of treatment for anaphylaxis episodes rather than other medications such as antihistamines.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Tonya Winders, the president and chief executive officer of the Allergy and Asthma Network, is excited to see the new guidance.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It is critically important to educate the public,” she told Healthline. “Every person can play an important role in recognizing the signs and symptoms of anaphylaxis and in being prepared to respond with epinephrine to save a life. The guidelines also can empower families to have a more productive dialogue with their child's pediatrician based on the best scientific evidence.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For now, it’s a group effort to keep our two young children safe.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, I’m prepping myself for the teenage years ahead. Teens today face higher rates of anaphylaxis episodes because they are often careless with carrying their EpiPens and more casual with avoiding food allergy triggers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While other parents will be battling their teens not to text and drive I’ll do the same but while also yelling out the door, “And don’t forget your EpiPen!”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Kristen Duncan Williams is the Founder of FAKS: Families of Allergic Kids at School. FAKS is an organization devoted to spreading more allergy awareness in a public school setting. For more information contact: faksbrooklyn@gmail.com.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Allergies</category>
<pubdate>2017-02-13T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-13T10:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/what-to-do-for-someone-having-severe-allergy-attack
</guid>
<dc:creator>Kristen Duncan Williams</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-13T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Why We Are So Emotionally Connected to Our Pets</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/why-we-emotionally-connect-to-pets
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/mental-health/020917_pets_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&g
]]>
<![CDATA[
t;We love our pets, and we feel like we understand them.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But is that true?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;How could it be, when we are two species separated by millions of years of evolution?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to a Finnish &lt;a href=&quot;http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0170730&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; published last month, people are actually about as good at interpreting the expressions on a dog’s face as they are another person’s with the most sensitive readings divined by the most empathetic people.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That makes sense, says the study’s lead author, Miiamaaria Kujala, Ph.D.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Empathetic people have already been shown to make quicker, better assessments of facial expressions in other people.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In our study, we wondered if this ability extends to perception of dogs, since dogs and humans share much of the common mammalian facial musculature, and dogs are overall quite expressive,” Kujala told Healthline in an email. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Expressive photos&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;To test this theory, Kujala and her colleagues showed 30 volunteers close-up photos of dogs and humans, along with pictures of objects and blurry images.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;About a third of the faces were meant to look happy, a third neutral, and a third threatening.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After rating and describing the emotional state of the subject in each picture, volunteers were given a personality test and asked to describe their experience with dogs. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In general, the volunteers agreed that happy faces were happy, neutral faces were unemotional or a little sad, and threatening faces were angry and aggressive — no matter whether the face was human or dog, and no matter the person’s prior experience with dogs. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“So even without training, we may understand some of the dogs' emotional gestures if [they are] similar enough to the human respective gestures,” Kujala said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A long history together&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s probably not a coincidence.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Humans and dogs go way back and we’ve influenced each other in major ways.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some studies suggest that humans bred dogs to be less aggressive and more puppylike. In fact, a recent &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cnn.com/2016/08/11/health/dogs-humans-language-faces/index.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; found that dogs in shelters that made “puppy eyes” found homes faster than other dogs. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dogs and humans are so tied to each other that we share some of the same genetic characteristics, as though we’ve evolved in tandem.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers at the University of Chicago &lt;a href=&quot;http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2013/13/130514-dogs-domestication-humans-genome-science/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;estimate&lt;/a&gt; that dogs were domesticated as long as 32,000 years ago, and in that time the two species have developed similar genetic markers for diet, neural processing, and disease. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Animal-human connections&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;With findings like that, perhaps it’s not surprising that scientists are increasingly trying to understand how we connect with other animals.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kujala is part of a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.helsinki.fi/en/researchgroups/animal-mind&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;research group&lt;/a&gt; in Helsinki that explores the connection between animals and people using noninvasive methods like tracking eye movements and measuring brain activity with electrodes placed on the scalp. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This study relied, in part, on a new coding system known as Dog Facial Action Coding System, or &lt;a href=&quot;http://dogfacs.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;DogFACS&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The original FACS was first developed as a way to deconstruct the expressions on human faces in the 1970s, and since then spinoffs have been created for chimpanzees, monkeys, horses, and even cats. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sometimes things get lost in translation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One expression that seems prone to misinterpretation is the smile — or at least, the tendency to pull back one’s lips and show one’s teeth.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In wolves and rhesus monkeys, that look is thought to be a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2555422/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;sign of submission&lt;/a&gt; used when greeting a superior. In chimpanzees, a beaming face might actually indicate &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.chimpsanctuarynw.org/blog/2013/09/chimpanzee-smiles/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;fear&lt;/a&gt;, not happiness. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Reading the face&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The current study showed that people do indeed have some biases when they look at dogs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Volunteers rated pleasant human faces as happier than pleasant dog faces and threatening dog faces as more aggressive than threatening human faces. People also described the pleasant human faces as more intense than pleasant dog faces, as if gauging happiness is easier in people than in dogs. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Those results “may reflect the biological and ecological importance of our own species to us, and that the potential threat from other species is commonly estimated as higher,” Kujala said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She added there’s no way to know for sure that the faces in the photos didn’t actually differ in intensity in some unmeasurable way.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Her lab’s previous work found that people who were more experienced with dogs were more adept at reading their body language.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But in this study, where only a dog’s face could be seen, experience didn’t matter as much. The ability to read a dog’s face seems to be more or less intuitive.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As expected, that proved to be especially true in volunteers who scored high in emotional empathy. They were particularly quick in their assessments and rated the dog expressions as more intense.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When it came to cognitive empathy, though — the ability to share someone else’s perspective — there was no such link.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In other words, we can’t quite put ourselves in a dog’s place, but we may be able to tell from its face how it feels.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<dc:creator>Rose Rimler</dc:creator>
