<item>
<title>Regenerative Medicine Has a Bright Future</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/regenerative-medicine-has-bright-future
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/tech/012017_regenerativemed_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;U.S. Army scientists, working with medical technology companies, have successfully tested and used products and techniques that have enabled Army surgeons to replace the severely burned skin of soldiers as well as transplant new hands and even faces.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At Duke University, researchers are studying zebra fish to learn how science and medicine might someday be able to regenerate severed human spinal cords. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These examples — one already in practice and the other in the early research stages — illustrate the potential that regenerative medicine offers for the future of medical care.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This research aims to go beyond easing the pain of life-threatening illnesses by changing the way diseases affect the body and then eradicating them. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The vast majority of currently available treatments for chronic and/or life-threatening diseases are palliative,” Morrie Ruffin, managing director of the Alliance for Regenerative Medicine (ARM), told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;ARM, based in Washington, D.C., is considered the preeminent global advocate for regenerative and advanced therapies. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Other treatments delay disease progression and the onset of complications associated with the underlying illness,” he said. “Very few therapies in use today are capable of curing or significantly changing the course of disease. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Regenerative medicine has the unique ability to alter the fundamental mechanisms of disease, and thereby offer treatment options to patients where there is significant unmet medical need.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And it has the potential to address the underlying causes of disease, Ruffin said, representing “a new and growing paradigm” in human health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The field encompasses a number of different technologies, including cell, gene, and tissue-based therapies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Helping with the wounds of war&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;With the Army breakthroughs, government investment was key.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The U.S. Department of Defense (DOD) has invested more than $250 million in regenerative medicine research over the past decade in an effort to make promising technologies available to wounded service members.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Wendy Dean is medical officer for the Tissue Injury and Regenerative Medicine Project Management Office at the U.S. Army Medical Materiel Development Activity at Fort Detrick, Md., home to the Army’s Medical Research and Materiel Command.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Those investments have yielded a stress-shielding surgical bandage, Embrace, to reduce scarring after surgery,” Dean told Healthline. “The research has also enabled tremendous progress in burn care, allowing surgeons to improve recovery from severe burns with the use of novel skin replacement strategies, such as ReCell ‘spray-on’ skin, or skin substitutes such as StrataGraft. These skin replacement methods reduce or eliminate the need for donor sites, a frequent request of burn patients.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These revolutionary products were not developed by the Army, Dean said, but were supported with research funding, initially through the Armed Forces Institute of Regenerative Medicine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The DOD also has invested in hand and face transplantation efforts for service members and civilians whose injuries are so severe that conventional reconstruction is insufficient,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dean noted that DOD funding has supported 13 hand transplants to date, including a transplant for retired Sgt. Brendan Marrocco in 2012. He was the first service member to survive quadrilateral amputations sustained in combat. The funding also supported eight face transplants.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Army’s goal is to heal those injured in battle.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Regenerative medicine is still young, but it has shown tremendous progress over the last decade,” Dean said. “Our mission is to make wounded warriors whole by restoring form, function, and appearance. This field offers the best hope to someday fully restore lost tissue with tissue that is structurally, functionally, and aesthetically a perfect match. It may be years before the vision is a widespread reality, but the field is well on its way.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Helping with spinal injuries&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;At Duke University, Kenneth Poss, professor of cell biology, and director of the Regeneration Next initiative, was the senior investigator for a study of spinal cord regeneration in zebra fish.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Those &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2016/11/161103142321.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;findings&lt;/a&gt; were published in November in the journal ScienceDaily. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In my lab, we are researching genetic factors that enable regeneration of tissues such as heart and spinal in nonmammalian animals like zebra fish,” Poss told Healthline. “A scientist in my lab, Mayssa Mokalled, led a study finding that a gene called connective tissue growth factor [CTGF] is important for spinal cord regeneration in zebra fish after an injury that completely severs the cord.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;CTGF is necessary to stimulate cells called glia to form a tissue bridge across the severed parts of the spinal cord — an early step in spinal cord regeneration.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Within eight weeks, the scientists found that zebra fish regenerate a severed spinal cord, including nerve cells, and fully reverse their paralysis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Developing techniques to treat and reverse spinal cord damage, a paralyzing and often fatal injury, is a pressing need in regenerative medicine, Poss said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our findings present a step toward understanding which glial cells can be encouraged to help heal the spinal cord, and how to stimulate this activity,” he said. “This is just the first step in many before the findings could be applied to humans.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Poss is already planning trials with mice that he hopes to start in the next few months. Mice represent an important stage in applying his latest findings, he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Why this field is needed&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;So, why is regenerative medicine important?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Regenerative medicine seeks ways to re-grow or engineer healthy tissue without the need for transplants,” Poss said. “On a global scale, there’s a tremendous organ shortage, and transplantation is an expensive and nonpermanent solution. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Imagine the number of lives that could be improved if, for example, we could find ways to use the body’s innate healing mechanisms to regenerate heart muscle in patients that are spiraling toward heart failure after a heart attack.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Imagine how many lives could be improved if we could find interventions that restore functional spinal cord tissue and reverse paralysis.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ruffin of ARM sees a promising future for regenerative medicine. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We will continue to see the development of additional regenerative medicine therapies for a broad number of acute and chronic, inherited and acquired diseases and disorders,” he said. “Therapies in this area will continue to advance along the regulatory pathway, many of which are entering phase III clinical trials this year.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In fact, in the next two years, we are anticipating a number of U.S. and E.U. approvals in the cell and gene therapy sector, including therapies that address certain types of cancers, debilitating retinal disorders, rare genetic diseases, and autoimmune conditions. We also expect to see sustained investment, which will help fuel growth and product development within this sector.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A number of cell and gene therapies and technology platforms are demonstrating real potential to address areas of significant unmet medical need, Ruffin said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These include cell therapies for blood cancers and solid tumors; gene therapies for rare genetic diseases as well as chronic conditions; and gene editing for the precise targeting and modification of genetic material of a patient’s cells to cure a broad range of diseases with a single treatment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Poss at Duke talked about the ultimate quest.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Regenerative medicine has been most successful in restoring or replacing the hematopoietic tissue that creates blood, he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We still lack successful regenerative therapies for most tissues,” Poss said. “The future of regenerative medicine — the holy grail — will be stimulating the regeneration of healthy tissue in patients without adding cells or manufactured tissue.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Working out the details of innate mechanisms of regeneration in animals like salamanders, zebra fish, and mice, can inform this approach, he said. So can improvement in factor delivery and genome editing applications to encourage the regeneration of healthy tissue.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Ultimately,” Poss said, “regenerative medicine will change the toolbox of physicians and surgeons, with major impact on outcomes of diabetes, spinal cord injuries, neurodegenerative disease, and heart failure.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;ARM says the public does not realize how far the field has progressed in recent years. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Currently, there are more than 20 regenerative medicine products on the market,” Ruffin said, primarily in the therapeutic areas of oncology, musculoskeletal and cardiovascular repair, and wound healing. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;More than 800 clinical trials are now underway to evaluate regenerative advanced therapies in a vast array of therapeutic categories, he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We’re seeing a significant focus on oncology, cardiovascular disease, and neurodegenerative diseases, with more than 60 percent of trials falling into one of these three categories,” he added. “Even though the majority of people perceive regenerative medicine as something of the future, it’s actually here and now.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>

<dc:creator>Patrick Keeffe</dc:creator>

<item>
<title>Do You Have Relationship OCD?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/do-you-have-relationship-ocd
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/mental-health/020917_relationshipocd_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Everyone has doubts about their relationship from time to time.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But usually they’re fleeting thoughts, not prominent enough to take seriously.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, for people with relationship obsessive compulsive disorder (ROCD), their doubts and fears blur reality, causing them to obsess about whether they’re happy with their partner.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I was with my ex-wife for 12 years. Through that entire time, I was constantly checking to see if my love for her was as founded as I believed it was,” Aaron Harvey, founder of the OCD resource &lt;a href=&quot;http://intrusivethoughts.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Intrusivethoughts.org&lt;/a&gt;, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Every single time another woman was in the room, I would test my level of attraction to them compared to my attraction to my partner,” he said. “It was so distracting. I couldn’t engage in conversations. I also spent years and years evaluating one small curve or line on my wife’s face to determine whether or not I found that attractive. It became an endless cycle of doubting thoughts and I felt a slave to it.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Harvey also obsessed about intellectual standards, wondering if his partner was smart enough for him or smarter than other people around them.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Ultimately what is happening is that you really love the person and you’re trying to prove to yourself that you actually do or that they’re enough for you. This constant obsession causes major anxiety. That in itself is the essence of OCD,” Harvey said, who struggled with various symptoms of OCD his entire life.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;More than vanity&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Could Harvey’s behavior be chalked up to superficiality? &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Not quite, says Jonathan S. Abramowitz, Ph.D., clinical psychologist, and professor of psychology at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“People with OCD have obsessional thoughts about things that are most important to them. This means that normal everyday doubts end up escalating into clinical obsessions in the context of that need for certainty and intolerance of uncertainty,” Abramowitz told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Relationship obsessions are just one of many presentations of OCD, he notes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For some people cleanliness is important to them, so they worry about contamination and germs. For others, it may be safety, so they worry about being harmed or harming others.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In terms of relationships, Abramowitz says, a person with OCD can be in a relationship and it’s clear that the relationship is going well, yet the person obsesses about knowing for sure that they’re in love with their partner, they’re doing this because the relationship is so important to them that even thinking about ending it is incredibly distressing.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The senseless thoughts and doubts about the relationship don’t make sense to the person and they get upset that they’re thinking them. They might say, ‘if I love my partner, why would I have these thoughts? Maybe I don’t love them,’” Abramowitz explained.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;People with these thoughts start to resist them and begin to seek out a guarantee that they really are in love. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This makes them engage in all sorts of compulsive behaviors to try to put things right or reduce their stress. Just like other manifestations of OCD, this is what drives people to do rituals and seek reassurance that their doubts are wrong,” Abramowitz said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For instance, if cleanliness is a concern for a person with OCD, they may wash their hands hundreds of times a day.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If harm is their concern, they may constantly check that their door is locked.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If they’re worried about their relationship, they may ask their partner if everything is OK, again and again.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“However, those behaviors make the person focus on the fears and doubts, and the person gets themselves into a vicious cycle. Trying to wiggle out of these doubts by performing rituals actually makes them intensify,” said Abramowitz.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How is ROCD treated?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Abramowitz says that the biggest sign of ROCD is having senseless worries and doubts about whether you love your partner, despite being happy in the relationship. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He says some people with ROCD may only obsess about their relationships, while others may obsess about more than just their relationships.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The thing is that the stuff that people with OCD have an obsession about you can’t have a guarantee about. You can’t see germs. You can’t see love. Love is something that you just know when you’re in love,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Still, treatment for all presentations of OCD is similar. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s a very treatable problem that takes hard work because you have to face your fears, but people can and do overcome it,” Abramowitz said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While a class of drugs called selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors can be used to treat OCD, Abramowitz says the most effective form of treatment is cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), a type of psychotherapy that focuses on understanding the relationship between a person's thoughts, feelings, and behaviors. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The type of CBT that Abramowitz says works best with OCD is called exposure and response prevention (ERP).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;During therapy, one is exposed to thoughts, images, objects, and situations that make them anxious and initiate their obsessions. The response prevention teaches the person how not to engage in a compulsive behavior or ritual when they are exposed to what makes them feel anxious. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“So you’re teaching the person how to lean into their doubt and anxiety and see that they can go on with life even if they don’t know for sure that they, say, really love the person,” Abramowitz said. “They learn that they are not allowed to ask for reassurance from their partner since doing so amplifies the doubts.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One exercise Abramowitz asks a person to do who questions if they’re in love or if they’ll leave their family, is to write down the scenario. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For instance, they may write down that they come home from work, have doubts, and tell their family they’re leaving. Then drive away, and the family is heartbroken.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Then, Abramowitz asks the patient to read what they wrote down to themselves several times in the day so they can feel their fears. They are not allowed to ask their family for reassurance, however.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Everyone in a relationship gets frustrated with their partner. That’s normal. We can all relate to thoughts of what if I just ran away from my family? A person with OCD has to learn that it’s OK to think that, and it doesn’t mean that they are a bad person or that they are going to actually do it,” Abramowitz said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;ERP is exactly what Harvey practiced to face his fears.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After years of struggling with OCD symptoms, he was finally diagnosed with the condition in his early 30s. He went on to try half a dozen medications over a period of a year and a half. He chose to stop medication and focus on therapy and mindfulness strategies. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“ERP helps me not worry about how many thoughts I’m having or the nature of them and helps me pass the thoughts. So when the thoughts come up instead of letting them overwhelm me, and think that they represent my true beliefs or character, I learn to say ‘that was a weird thought’ and move on. More like the general population behaves when they have weird thoughts,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When it comes to Harvey’s relationships, he says mindfulness also helps. When thoughts about whether he should leave his partner arise, he asks himself if he’s willing to leave them today.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s powerful because you’re not asking yourself to answer questions like do you love them or if they’re good enough,” Harvey said. “It helps to calm my mind and perspective and reduce my expectations of what it means to be in a relationship. When thoughts pop up and I begin to judge my attractiveness to them or whether I love them or not, I let them pass, and try to be mindful by telling myself to revisit the thoughts a week from now. OCD is a chronic condition I’ll always have, but I’ve learned to live with it.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Mental Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-02-10T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-10T10:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/do-you-have-relationship-ocd
</guid>
<dc:creator>Cathy Cassata</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-10T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Limiting Tumors and Infections Instead of Killing Them
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/limiting-tumors-and-infections
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/020917_fightingtumors_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Wh
]]>
<![CDATA[
en you have a serious infection or cancer, it’s natural to want it destroyed as quickly as possible. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Aggressive treatment, however, may not always be for the best.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Even when it initially works, antimicrobial medicines and chemotherapy can suddenly become ineffective.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Research suggests that in some cases where drug resistance can lead to treatment failure, containing an infection or a tumor at a tolerable level can improve patient outcomes. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In other cases, the traditional approach of elimination might be better.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The problem is in determining which option is likely to be successful.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers at Penn State University and the University of Michigan developed a mathematical analysis to identify factors that can help in that determination.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Their paper was published in &lt;a href=&quot;http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pbio.2001110&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;PLOS Biology&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Acceptable disease burden&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers compared containment to eradication.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Their goal was to lengthen the amount of time until drug resistance developed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;You can have a certain amount of infection or tumor without being sick. It’s called an “acceptable burden.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In their paper, the researchers wrote that the concept of an acceptable burden is their core premise.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They acknowledge this is likely to make clinicians uneasy. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They recognize situations, such as bacterial meningitis, where there’s no acceptable burden. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Identifying the maximum acceptable burden is a complex problem.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To determine if an infection or tumor would develop drug resistance, the researchers looked at two key things.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One was the rate at which cells become resistant.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The other was “competitive suppression.” In cells that are responding to treatment, there’s a competition for resources. More competition can slow the spread of resistant cells. However, there’s a risk that the sensitive cells will also develop resistance.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The infection or tumor was considered to be managed if it was maintained at or below the level of acceptable burden. The treatment was considered a failure if a pathogen rose above that level.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers found that containment can sometimes double a patient’s survival time.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There are situations where we can be relatively sure that treatment will completely eliminate the infection or tumor, so aggressive treatment is the obvious choice,” Elsa Hansen, a research associate at Penn State, and an author of the paper, said in a press release. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“On the opposite end of the spectrum, there are low-level situations like urinary tract or ear infections where a doctor may decide not to treat at all,” she continued. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The majority of cases, however, are somewhere in between,” she added, “and require hard choices that balance the damage caused by the infection or tumor and the risk of mutation with the damage caused by the treatment itself and the risk of developing uncontrollable resistance. Our analysis provides guidance for making these decisions from a standpoint of maximizing patient well-being.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;How long treatment can continue before failing depends on the disease and the person. There won’t be a single solution that applies to everyone.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers' goal is to provide a basic outline so doctors and patients can make informed choices.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The growing problem of resistance &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;There’s no doubt that antimicrobial drugs have saved a lot of lives.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But the more we use them, the more resistant infectious organisms become. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/drugresistance/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)&lt;/a&gt;, 2 million people are infected with antibiotic-resistant organisms every year, causing 23,000 deaths.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Drug resistance is a major problem in cancer and infection,” said Dr. Timothy Byun, medical oncologist at the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sjo.org/Our-Services/The-Center-for-Cancer-Prevention-and-Treatment.aspx&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Center for Cancer Prevention and Treatment&lt;/a&gt; at St. Joseph Hospital in California.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Antimicrobial drug resistance is a major public health crisis. According to WHO [World Health Organization], it is a major global health threat,” Byun wrote in an email to Healthline. “Many cancers are incurable because chemotherapy may not completely eradicate cancer cells.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Antibiotic resistance is a consequence of evolution, said Dr. Santosh Kesari. “We’ve had various stages of health crises over the years. Flesh-eating bacteria, for example, is very resistant.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kesari is a board-certified neurologist and neuro-oncologist, and current chair of the Department of Translational Neuro-Oncology and Neurotherapeutics at the &lt;a href=&quot;http://california.providence.org/john-wayne/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;John Wayne Cancer Institute&lt;/a&gt; at Providence Saint John’s Health Center in California.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In an interview with Healthline, Kesari said that antibiotic resistance is obvious right away when a patient doesn’t respond. Sometimes that’s the case with chemotherapy as well.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“But here we’re talking about getting an initial response to treatment. Then resistance develops. This can take weeks or months,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Stabilizing cancer&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are several reasons cancer cells become resistant to treatment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cells mutate.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sometimes the cancer is heterogeneous to begin with.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;You might wipe out one type, but a different type of cell starts to grow. It takes over and creates a resistant tumor.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kesari explained that sometimes killing a tumor with drugs can actually promote regrowth. It may be better to just keep it stable.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The question is, can we do better in preventing resistance by understanding the tumor better in the beginning? Maybe giving multiple drugs rather than one could resolve this at the start,” said Kesari.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“What you’re doing in the short term may, in the long run, be bad because of the emergence of resistance. Rather than aggressive treatment up front, containment might have a better long-term effect,” he continued.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“For infection, we use multiple antibiotics right away. This is to prevent resistance from happening. In cancer, combination therapy rather than a single agent is more complicated. It takes time to study each drug and combine them safely.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s a significant problem,” said Kesari. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We need to think about this more carefully. This paper describes an approach of containment rather than elimination. That’s interesting. But it needs to be proven in a clinical setting that this concept works using drugs that don’t necessarily kill 100 percent of cells, but contain the tumor, and with the same outcome. That includes different cancer types and types of infection. That’s what ultimately needs to be proven,” said Kesari.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<category>Technology</category>
<pubdate>2017-02-09T13:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-09T13:00:00</updateddate>

http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/limiting-tumors-and-infections
</guid>
<dc:creator>Ann Pietrangelo</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-09T21:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
How Immigration Restrictions Are Hurting People's Health
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/immigration-restrictions-hurting-peoples-health
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/020917_immigrationhealth_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt
]]>
<![CDATA[
;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Trump administration’s travel ban on people from seven Muslim-majority countries is likely to have far-reaching and unintended effects on the health of refugees, immigrants, and the American people.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Children needing lifesaving surgeries have already been affected.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, the policies could affect researchers as well as thousands of foreign-born doctors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That means people living in rural and low-income areas of the United States, where many foreign medical graduates provide care, may be particularly affected.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Shortly after the ban went into effect, shockwaves quickly spread throughout the healthcare system.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A 4-month-old &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/iranian-baby-previously-banned-u-s-receive-treatment-soon-n716881&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Iranian girl&lt;/a&gt; traveling to the United States for lifesaving care for a congenital heart defect was among those prohibited from entering the country. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The girl and her mother eventually received special permission from the Department of Homeland Security to fly to Oregon, but the delay in undergoing surgery means she will face a much longer recovery.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A 1-year-old &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/01/world/europe/trump-travel-ban-syria-refugees.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Syrian girl&lt;/a&gt; born without an eye and a seriously disfigured face was blocked, along with her family, from coming to the United States.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The girl had undergone two complex operations in Spain. The family had planned to resettle in the United States, and had already undergone all required security checks and interviews. Now they will need to find another country to take them in.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Experts are worried, in particular, about the fate of refugee children.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to a recent &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/31/world/middleeast/trump-immigration-ban-children.html?_r=0&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;United Nations report&lt;/a&gt;, children most in need of international emergency assistance come from five of the seven countries affected by the executive order — Iraq, Somalia, Sudan, Syria, and Yemen.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Adults were affected, too.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At San Francisco International Airport, an Iranian-born permanent &lt;a href=&quot;http://abc7news.com/politics/bay-area-doctor-helps-pregnant-detainee-after-travel-ban/1728892/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;resident&lt;/a&gt; of the United States — six months pregnant — was taken into custody by federal officials. She was held for hours before a judge ruled that green card holders were exempt from the executive order.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As the ban went into effect, hospitals around the country scrambled to &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.statnews.com/2017/01/30/trump-immigration-order-hospitals/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;help patients&lt;/a&gt; who had already planned to travel to the United States to receive care for serious medical conditions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Ethnicity and health&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Experts worry that the nature of the ban, which affects only Muslim-majority countries, increases the health risks for people of certain ethnicities.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It puts immigrants, refugees, and basically anyone who may be perceived as being an immigrant or a refugee — including U.S. citizens — at risk of being perceived as a threat,” Jhumka Gupta, Sc.D., a public health professor at George Mason University, told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These groups may be targeted with harassment or &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/30/us/islamerica-excerpt-hate-crimes/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;hate crimes&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But, said Gupta, just living in constant fear of being targeted or being perceived by others as a threat is associated with poor health outcomes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2804633/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;research&lt;/a&gt; found that after the 9/11 terrorist attacks, Arab American adults who reported being abused or discriminated against because of their ethnicity showed increased psychological distress and poorer health status.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A 2006 &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.rwj.harvard.edu/papers/Lauderdale.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; published in the journal Demography, found that women with Arabic-sounding names who gave birth in California during the six months after 9/11 had a higher risk of having a low birth weight or preterm baby, compared with women who delivered a year earlier.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“That shows how discrimination and the stress associated with it, as well as other mechanisms, can impact not only the individuals, but also future generations such as babies,” said Gupta.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The fate of the ban — which affects people from Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria, and Yemen — awaits a decision from the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in San Francisco, which heard &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-immigration-idUSKBN15L0GC&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;arguments&lt;/a&gt; for the case on Tuesday.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But damage to people’s health may have already been done.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Even if the ban is lifted,” said Gupta, “the societal stigma is still there. So we have to deal with the health fallout of that.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Doctors, other medical professionals impacted&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Patients were not the only ones affected by the travel ban.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On Jan. 28, a Cleveland Clinic &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.crainscleveland.com/article/20170207/NEWS/170209856/cleveland-clinic-doctor-suha-abushamma-returns-home&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;internal medicine resident&lt;/a&gt; from Sudan, on the way back to the United States, was deported from an airport in New York and sent to Saudi Arabia.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The doctor was in the United States on an H-1B visa for workers in &quot;specialty occupations.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some doctors who are &lt;a href=&quot;http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2017/01/30/president-donald-trump-travel-immigration-ban-abdollah-mostafavi-sfo/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;permanent residents&lt;/a&gt; of the United States were also detained as they tried to reenter the country.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These stories hint at one fact that many people may not realize — the United States is heavily dependent on foreign-born healthcare workers, including doctors, nurses, and home care aides.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;About &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4370780/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;one quarter&lt;/a&gt; of the more than 800,000 physicians practicing in the United States are graduates of medical schools outside the country — as are 10 to 15 percent of trainees in doctor residency programs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to Andrea Clement Santiago, director of communications and media relations of The Medicus Firm, which recruits and places doctors in the United States, about 15,000 of those doctors are from the seven countries targeted in the travel ban.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That amounts to less than 2 percent of all doctors in the United States, but many foreign-trained doctors practice in &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27119328&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;rural and underserved areas&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;More than one-quarter of the international medical graduates placed by The Medicus Firm practice in rural areas. Another quarter care for patients in large cities.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;International medical graduates also account for a large proportion of those that practice certain &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.vox.com/2017/2/1/14470746/trumps-immigration-ban-healthcare-doctors&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;specialties&lt;/a&gt;, including geriatric medicine and family medicine. And they &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20679648&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;provide care&lt;/a&gt; on par with graduates of American medical schools.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The executive order has created a great deal of uncertainty for foreign-trained medical personnel, which could harm the U.S. healthcare system well into the future.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If the immigration policy is perceived to be unfair, or too tough,” said Santiago, “it may deter all international physicians, even those not from the targeted countries, from coming to the U.S. to practice.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Big impact of immigration policies&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other experts are concerned that the travel ban will harm &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.statnews.com/2017/02/06/travel-ban-trump-medicine-science/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;medicine and science&lt;/a&gt;, including &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/trump-immigration-ban-may-threaten-international-work-on-disease/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;international work on diseases&lt;/a&gt; like Ebola.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.fiercehealthcare.com/it/exclusive-trump-immigration-ban-could-stifle-health-it-workforce&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;health IT industry&lt;/a&gt;, which draws heavily on highly skilled workers from outside the United States, could also be affected. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ama-assn.org/ama-urges-trump-administration-clarify-immigration-executive-order&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;American Medical Association (AMA)&lt;/a&gt; expressed concern about the impact of the immigration executive order on the nation’s healthcare system, in particular in rural and low-income areas.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The AMA has also shown &lt;a href=&quot;https://searchlf.ama-assn.org/letter/documentDownload?uri=%2Funstructured%2Fbinary%2Fletter%2FLETTERS%2F2017-2-6-Letter-of-Support-to-Coffman-HR-496-Bridge-Act.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;support&lt;/a&gt; for a bipartisan bill that would protect young undocumented immigrants — often called “dreamers” — with Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA). The bill would prevent them from deportation if they are doctors, medical students, or considering a career in medicine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These immigrants are not affected by the current travel ban, but they could be deported later if the country tightens its immigration policies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As the United States shuts its doors to refugees, immigrants, and other people in need of urgent medical care, other countries are opening theirs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Last week in Ontario, Canada, Health Minister Eric Hoskins offered to provide healthcare for foreign-born children whose lifesaving surgeries have been cancelled in the United States due to the travel ban.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This is a particular subset of children who require lifesaving surgery, so, absent that surgery, they will certainly die,” Hoskins told reporters at a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.thestar.com/news/queenspark/2017/02/03/ontario-to-help-young-patients-affected-by-trump-travel-ban.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;press conference&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>

<dc:creator>Shawn Radcliffe</dc:creator>
