<item>
<title>32 Heart Surgeries … and She’s Only 19</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/32-heart-surgeries-shes-only-19
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/heart-health/020817_aha_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;Courtesy of Elizabeth Argo&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Courtesy of Elizabeth Argo&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Bethany Gooch was a fussy newborn.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She was born in Memphis, Tenn., in October 1997.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Her initial pediatrician’s visits didn’t reveal anything wrong.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But just days before Bethany’s first Christmas, her color seemed off.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Her parents took Bethany to the hospital, where she was diagnosed with a pair of serious heart defects — &lt;a href=&quot;/health/tetralogy-of-fallot&quot;&gt;Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)&lt;/a&gt; and pulmonary atresia.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We were just so grateful to have caught it,” said her mother, Serena LaGesse.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A complicated condition&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Bethany was born years before pulse oximetry screening became routine in most hospitals across the country.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With no sure way to detect them, Bethany’s heart ailments could have resulted in tragedy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;TOF changes the flow of blood through the heart. The condition occurs in about 1 in 2,500 babies born in the United States each year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, Bethany had the rarest form of the condition, and doctors weren’t sure how best to treat it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Surgery kept her alive, but it was still touch and go for months, as it is for thousands of babies born each year with critical congenital heart defects.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I had surgery about every six months,” said Bethany, now 19. “It was pretty much just a part of my life. I couldn’t do what other kids do because I’d get so tired.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At the time, doctors didn’t know how to treat such a complicated condition, in part because the research and experience weren’t there.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In that regard, she truly is an example of how you keep someone alive until new research shows a new technique or a new treatment,” LaGesse said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A life different from other children&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;And so a couple times a year Bethany would go into the hospital for surgery to help keep her heart pumping.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When Bethany got to first grade, she realized that what for her was a normal life was different from other kids’ lives.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I’d sit down and watch the other kids run,” she said. “Whenever there was recess, I had to take naps.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When she was 8, a new surgical procedure allowed doctors to close a hole in her heart.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“My skin turned from bluish to pink, and I could breathe so much better,” Bethany said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another turning point came when she could go to Eva, Tenn., to a camp for kids with heart disease. It made Bethany feel like she wasn’t alone.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I made really good friends,” said Bethany.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One new friend was a girl named Sarah Theobald, who had the same conditions as Bethany. When Sarah passed away it made Bethany even more determined to fight.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“She taught me to never give up, and she told me she’d be chasing purple butterflies,” Bethany said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It was a phrase Sarah used a lot as they dealt with the deaths of friends over the years, said Bethany.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“To help me deal with the grief, she’d say they were chasing purple butterflies,” she remembered.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Bethany said the memory of her friend helped see her through several more surgeries, including a heart valve replacement in 2015.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Congenital Heart Defect Awareness Week began Tuesday. As with many other survivors, each new development has led to a new surgery that improves Bethany’s life.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She has found reason to believe she can live a normal life and now plans to work in the medical field.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I always wanted to [be a nurse], but I just didn’t think I could,” she said. “Now I know I can.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Editor’s Note: This &lt;/em&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/32-heart-surgeries-and-shes-only-19/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;story&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;em&gt; was originally published on the American Heart &lt;/em&gt;&lt;em&gt;Association’s &lt;a href=&quot;http://news.heart.org/&quot;&gt;news website&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;em&gt;.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Heart Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-02-08T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-08T12:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/32-heart-surgeries-shes-only-19
</guid>
<dc:creator>American Heart Association News</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-08T20:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Procedure May Provide Map for AFib Treatment</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/map-for-afib-treatment
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/heart-health/020817_afib_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;There’s new hope for the millions of Americans that have &lt;a href=&quot;/health/atrial-fibrillation-natural-alternative-treatments&quot;&gt;atrial fibrillation (AFib)&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A team at The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center, using hearts from organ donors, were able to devise a method to clearly map the heart, and ultimately interrupt its ability to produce irregular heartbeats.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The clear mapping of the heart allows experts to find new areas to perform helpful ablations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;During an ablation, tiny cuts or burns are made to form scar tissue that can disrupt the heart’s electrical circuitry and stop irregular beats.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What is AFib?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;AFib is an abnormal heart rhythm or arrhythmia that occurs when disordered or rapid electrical signals cause the upper chambers (atria) of the heart to contract too quickly and chaotically (fibrillate).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When fibrillation occurs, it causes blood flow to become irregular and blood can collect in the atria without being pumped into the lower chambers of the heart, which is what happens in a healthy heart.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), someone goes to the hospital every 42 seconds due to AFib.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;AFib can lead to blood clots, heart failure, stroke, and chronic fatigue.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;About 2 percent of Americans under age 65 have AFib, while about &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/dhdsp/data_statistics/fact_sheets/fs_atrial_fibrillation.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;9 percent&lt;/a&gt; of those 65 and older have the condition.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Michael Miller, a cardiologist at the University of Maryland Medical Center, told Healthline that traditional treatments for AFib include low-voltage shocks (electrical cardioversion) and medications to convert the abnormal heart rhythm or reduce an excessively fast heart rate.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Despite the treatments, symptoms can persist.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In these cases, the abnormal electrical activity is mapped out and the affected region is ablated or destroyed,” he said. “Catheter relation is successful in approximately 75 percent of cases but up to 10 percent may experience complications.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;An AFib breakthrough?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Typically, it is difficult for doctors to know where to ablate the heart as it beats erratically 24 hours a day. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Vadim Fedorov, Ph.D., an associate professor who studies anti-arrhythmic treatments, and his team, devised a way to better image the heart.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The organ is injected with dye and placed in a dish with four high-speed optical cameras around it. A camera normally can capture about 200 recordings, but this technology records 40,000 images in 3-D.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The improved imaging lets doctors find ideal areas for ablations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“While this technique may pave the way for more precise ablation procedures for atrial fibrillation, and improve their success rates, [currently at about 70 percent] the approach has not been validated in real-life humans with atrial fibrillation,” Dr. Regina Druz, a cardiac imaging doctor from New York, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She noted that the hearts used in the study were donated by patients that received transplants, and they probably had structural issues that come with cardiac disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She says that Fedorov’s technique may find fewer clinical applications in actual patients with AFib because their hearts are not structurally damaged.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Fedorov could not be reached for comment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Druz also notes that recent evidence has indicated that AFib is an inflammatory disease that can be modified with lifestyle interventions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Over the years, we saw a drastic reduction in atrial fibrillation caused by rheumatic heart disease, as antibiotics and vaccinations took care of that,” Druz added. “However, atrial fibrillation burden remains high due to explosion of obesity, diabetes, and sedentary lifestyle.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Patients need to be provided with comprehensive lifestyle counseling, and helped to lose weight, reduce their blood pressure, normalize their cholesterol and blood sugar, as all those are triggers and risk factors for cardiac disease, including atrial fibrillation,” she said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While the imaging tools developed at Ohio State may add great precision to mapping out regions for ablation, it’s important to recognize that ablation is used to treat persistent symptoms only, Miller noted. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Patients who have risk factors for stroke should remain on anticoagulant therapy [blood thinners] because the risk of stroke has not been shown to be reduced following ablation therapy,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Heart Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-02-08T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-08T12:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/map-for-afib-treatment
</guid>
<dc:creator>Kristen Fischer</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-08T20:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Using ‘Brute Force’ to Beat Antibiotic Resistance</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/brute-force-to-beat-antibiotic-resistance
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/020717_antibiotics_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A team from University College London has demonstrated that it’s possible for antibiotics to effectively kill resistant bacteria through sheer “brute force.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s a promising step forward in counteracting antibiotic resistance, which is a growing problem worldwide.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Antibiotics work in different ways, but they need to bind to bacterial cells in order to kill them,” Joseph Ndieyira, lead study author, and senior research associate at University College London (UCL) Medicine, said in a release. “Antibiotics have ‘keys’ that fit ‘locks’ on bacterial cell surfaces, allowing them to latch on. When a bacterium becomes resistant to a drug, it effectively changes the lock so the key won’t fit anymore. Incredibly, we found that certain antibiotics can still ‘force’ the lock, allowing them to bind and kill resistant bacteria because they are able to push hard enough. In fact, some of them were so strong they tore the door off its hinges, killing the bacteria instantly.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The team published their &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2017/02/170203085156.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;findings&lt;/a&gt; in the journal Scientific Reports.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Experts say the research is welcome, but there’s still a lot of work to be done.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A growing problem&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Antibiotics can be extremely useful, but overuse has led to a rise of antibiotic resistant bacteria.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The medical community has been sounding the alarm on the rise of antibiotic resistant bacteria for years. In 2014 then-President Barack Obama signed an &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/obama-declares-war-on-superbugs-091814&quot;&gt;executive order&lt;/a&gt; acknowledging the threat.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ndieyira outlined some other ways the international health community is working to combat the issue, noting that a 2016 United Nations &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.un.org/pga/71/2016/09/21/press-release-hl-meeting-on-antimicrobial-resistance/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;conference&lt;/a&gt; called for a coordinated plan of action. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In an email to Healthline, he added, “The World Health Organization, together with partners, has developed a global action plan to mitigate the problem of drug resistant bacteria by strengthening surveillance to better inform strategies on health interventions and detection of new trend resistance evolution, as well as the threat posed by the new strains of bacteria.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Others also see the threat.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Antibiotic resistant bacteria are a worldwide threat,” Daniel Wozniak, Ph.D., professor in the department of microbial infection and immunity at The Ohio State University College of Medicine, told Heathline in an email. “There are some infections caused by these bacteria that simply cannot be treated with conventional antibiotics, putting us in a position where we were almost 75 years ago. Without effective antibiotics, people can succumb to infections during routine surgery or chemotherapy. Unfortunately, new resistance strategies are emerging and spreading at a pace faster than we are developing means to combat infection.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;David S. Weiss, Ph.D., director of the Emory University Antibiotic Resistance Center, acknowledged the issue in an email to Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Carefully studying the characteristics of known antibiotics is of great interest as it may broadly guide the enhancement of antibiotic activity and efficacy,” he wrote. “This would likely be a faster process than the development of new antibiotics. Given the dire situation we currently face, it is critical to explore all paths and leave no stone unturned.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Forcing the lock&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ndieyira’s team at UCL studied the effects of two antibiotics.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One was vancomycin, a powerful antibiotic typically used to treat MRSA and other dangerous infections.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The other was oritavancin, a modified version of vancomycin that can be used to treat skin infections.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition to working more quickly — oritavancin begins killing bacteria in 15 minutes, while vancomycin takes hours — oritavancin has some properties that could make it a game-changer when it comes to killing powerful antibiotic resistant bacteria.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There are three properties that make oritavancin unique,” wrote Ndieyira. “First, its molecules are good at sticking together at the surface of bacteria to form clusters. Second, its clusters bind very strongly to the surface of bacteria, and third, the clusters consequently generate the largest mechanical forces against drug resistant and drug-susceptible bacteria, which can lead to bacteria cells being killed more rapidly compared to vancomycin.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In short, these unique clusters literally tear the surface of the bacteria apart.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Wozniak applauded the research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I found the work quite compelling and interesting,” he wrote. “The multidisciplinary approach involving biological, physical, and mathematical sciences to tackle this problem was impressive. The authors bring a new perspective on drug-bacteria interactions by studying mechanobiology, the forces at play during antibiotic-target binding. For me, the most important advance was the premise to utilize mathematical modelling prior to, or integrated with, the synthesis of new antibiotics to help ensure potent activity of drugs. This work also has implications outside of antibiotic development, since the concept applies potentially to any drug-target interaction.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A fine balance&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Medical experts acknowledge that combating antibiotic resistant bacteria can create an “arms race” when bacteria grows stronger and more resistant as the medication used to combat it becomes more effective.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There has to be a balance between the need and usage, so as to avoid a future arms race,” acknowledged Ndieyira. “For example, overuse of oritavancin when it is not absolutely necessary, or using it in agriculture, might lead to the evolution of antibiotic resistant bacteria.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We frankly have been in an arms race with microorganisms throughout history,” wrote Wozniak. “Because bacteria can grow to such high numbers, and because they grow much faster than our cells, acquisition of resistance is an evolutionary inevitable outcome, I’m afraid. The trick is to use antibiotics prudently and often in combination with other drugs that target different bacterial processes, and for us to remain healthy so that our immune systems can fight infections during antibiotic treatment.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ndieyira says his team will continue their research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our next step is to use these findings to develop new antibiotics, and modify existing antibiotics, so that they are effective against multi-drug resistant bacteria,” he wrote.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>General Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-02-07T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-07T10:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/brute-force-to-beat-antibiotic-resistance
</guid>
<dc:creator>Dan Gray</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-07T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
What Would Happen If Planned Parenthood Went Out of Business?
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/what-if-planned-parenthood-went-out-of-business
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/020617_plannedparenthood_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt
]]>
<![CDATA[
;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;What would happen if the doors suddenly closed on the 650 health centers across the United States operated by Planned Parenthood?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s certainly a topical question with the introduction of a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ernst.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/075cd2c9-efc7-412a-afba-66fcbcb72cb7/C4E3F05D9D425CB3F92CD8663ECCE920.1.30.17-protect-funding-for-women-s-health-care-act.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;bill&lt;/a&gt; in Congress last week by two female Republican legislators.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The legislation would take away the $500 million a year the federal government provides for Planned Parenthood.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It would also repeal a law that prohibits states from defunding the nonprofit organization.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Those tax dollars represent about 40 percent of Planned Parenthood’s &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.plannedparenthood.org/files/2114/5089/0863/2014-2015_PPFA_Annual_Report_.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;operating budget&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Even if that money wasn’t recouped, Planned Parenthood would probably still operate, albeit with fewer centers and a lower capacity.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, what if opponents did achieve their ultimate goal of putting Planned Parenthood out of business?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Those opponents say women would be able to get services such as cancer screenings, Pap smears, and counseling by going to other community health centers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Perhaps more importantly to them, women would have trouble finding a facility that performs abortions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“They would have a difficult time getting an abortion and I would celebrate that,” Eric Scheidler, executive director of the Pro-Life Action League, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, supporters of Planned Parenthood say hundreds of thousands of women would lose access to important reproductive and other health services. Even more would face reduced services.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, they say, abortions would actually increase because the number of unwanted pregnancies would go up.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These cuts, they add, would come on top of the changes being sought by &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/paul-ryan-republicans-still-committed-repeal-replace-obamacare-strategy-n716986&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Republican leaders&lt;/a&gt; in the Affordable Care Act (ACA).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The primary goal is to block all women from reproductive health services,” Terry O’Neill, president of the National Organization for Women (NOW), told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What Planned Parenthood provides&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;When it comes to Planned Parenthood, opponents focus on the abortion services the organization provides.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Anti-abortion groups say Planned Parenthood performed &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.lifenews.com/2016/01/28/planned-parenthood-made-1-3-billion-killing-324000-babies-in-abortions/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;324,000 abortions&lt;/a&gt; in 2014.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Scheidler calls the organization “the nation’s largest abortion chain.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He notes its clinics perform 35 percent of abortions done in the United States compared to 1 percent of all Pap smears and 2 percent of all breast exams.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s what they specialize in,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Supporters of Planned Parenthood take a different view of the figures.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Overall, Planned Parenthood’s clinics see 2.5 million patients a year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They note the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.plannedparenthood.org/about-us/who-we-are/planned-parenthood-at-a-glance&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;organization’s clinics&lt;/a&gt; provide 360,000 breast exams and 270,000 Pap smears annually.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The clinics also perform 4.2 million tests and treatments for sexually transmitted diseases (STDs). That includes 650,000 HIV tests.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, it provides 2 million people with birth control information and supplies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They estimate Planned Parenthood helps prevent 579,000 unwanted pregnancies every year, and only 3 percent of its health services involve abortion.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It is a vital and valuable resource for our adolescents,” Dr. Cora Breuner, a Seattle pediatrician, and chair of the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) Committee on Adolescence, told Healthline. “There’s quite a bit that they do that is not contraceptive.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The question of federal funds&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Planned Parenthood has been around for 100 years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It began receiving federal funds in 1970. In 1976, federal funds were limited to services that are not abortion-related.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Scheidler said although the $500 million in annual federal funds aren’t directly used for abortions they keep Planned Parenthood in business.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It helps keep the lights on,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Scheidler also believes Planned Parenthood is a corrupt organization, noting a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.justice.gov/usao-edtx/pr/planned-parenthood-pays-43-million-settle-allegations-unnecessary-medical-care&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Medicare fraud case&lt;/a&gt; in Texas the group settled in 2013, as well as the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cnn.com/2015/07/15/health/planned-parenthood-undercover-video/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2015 controversy&lt;/a&gt; involving undercover videos taken at a Planned Parenthood clinic.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He says the organization doesn’t deserve taxpayer money.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Supporters wholeheartedly disagree.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They say Planned Parenthood provides vital healthcare services and helps lower the cost of other tax-funded programs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Public opinion appears to be on their side.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a &lt;a href=&quot;https://poll.qu.edu/national/release-detail?ReleaseID=2421&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Quinnipiac Poll&lt;/a&gt; taken in late January, 62 percent of respondents opposed cutting off federal funds for Planned Parenthood. That rose to 80 percent when those questioned were told federal funds aren’t used for abortions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Supporters say Planned Parenthood could operate without federal funds but not in the way they currently do.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In the short term, it would be extremely damaging,” said O’Neill.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Amy Friedrich-Karnik, senior federal policy advisor for the Center for Reproductive Rights, told &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cbsnews.com/news/can-planned-parenthood-survive-without-federal-funds/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;CBS News&lt;/a&gt; it would be difficult for an organization as large as Planned Parenthood to continue operating without that federal money.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There would be a shift in how Planned Parenthood operates,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A world without Planned Parenthood&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Scheidler and other abortion opponents reject the notion that women would have no other place to go for healthcare services without Planned Parenthood.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/marking-a-new-era-committed-to-protecting-our-most-vulnerable/article/2613098&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;blog&lt;/a&gt; in the Washington Examiner, Sen. Joni Ernst (R-Iowa) and Rep. Diane Black (R-Tennessee), the co-sponsors of the bill to defund Planned Parenthood, said there are 14 federally qualified health centers (FQHC) for every one Planned Parenthood facility.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Scheidler said those and other centers can be found on the website &lt;a href=&quot;http://getyourcare.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;GetYourCare.org&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said his group supports giving every dollar taken away from Planned Parenthood to other healthcare providers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We don’t want to cut off one single woman from getting the services she has been getting from Planned Parenthood,” Scheidler said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Officials at Planned Parenthood declined a request from Healthline for an interview, but their supporters say there is no way these other organizations could pick up the slack.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They note that &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.plannedparenthood.org/files/4314/8183/5009/20161207_Defunding_fs_d01_1.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;54 percent&lt;/a&gt; of Planned Parenthood clinics are in rural or underserved areas.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They add Planned Parenthood is the only safety-net family provider in 21 percent of counties where it operates.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;About 65 percent of Planned Parenthood patients are 150 percent or below the federal poverty line.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;About 60 percent are recipients of Medicaid or Title X programs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, they say, Planned Parenthood clinics have extended hours, same-day appointments, and shorter waits than other publically funded healthcare providers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://healthaffairs.org/blog/2015/09/08/quantifying-planned-parenthoods-critical-role-in-meeting-the-need-for-publicly-supported-contraceptive-care/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;report&lt;/a&gt; commissioned by the Congressional Budget Office estimated 390,000 women would lose access to services and another 650,000 would have reduced access within a year if Congress blocked Medicaid patients from Planned Parenthood.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;O’Neill said some women would go elsewhere without Planned Parenthood but others wouldn’t. Some women would also forego preventative healthcare services such as cancer screenings.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Many women would die unnecessarily,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, O’Neill predicted there would be an increase in sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), maternal mortality, and infant mortality, as well as a decrease in “well woman” visits.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She added there would also be an uptick in unwanted pregnancies, leading to more abortions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Women aren’t going to stop having abortions,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She called anti-abortion groups’ claims that women would find care elsewhere as “alternative facts,” noting that dentist’s offices are listed on GetYourCare.org as healthcare providers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some women have been going public recently with their stories on how Planned Parenthood helped them in times of need.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Several &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/opinion/columnists/rekha-basu/2017/01/27/basu-defunding-planned-parenthood-could-increase-abortions/97137524/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;testified&lt;/a&gt; late last month before Iowa legislators.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One woman said her doctor refused to prescribe birth control pills that could have helped her with an ovarian cyst, saying it was his religious belief that an unmarried woman shouldn’t have contraception.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a &lt;a href=&quot;http://thehill.com/blogs/pundits-blog/healthcare/316469-planned-parenthood-is-essential-to-me-and-millions-more&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;blog&lt;/a&gt; on The Hill website, Jen. D. Rafanan, a board member of the Feminist Women’s Health Center in Atlanta, wrote about an “urgent reproductive health issue” she experienced in 2012 when her menstrual period wouldn’t stop.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The county health center didn’t have an available appointment for three months, so Rafanan went to Planned Parenthood.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Before I went to Planned Parenthood, I felt helpless. Afterward, I felt like I had someone on my side,” she wrote.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another woman posted a note on a Healthline social media page saying it was Planned Parenthood that helped to switch her from the pill to an IUD to alleviate chronic headache symptoms.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I so appreciate their care and availability,” the woman wrote.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;O’Neill said there are thousands of other stories like these.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As an example, she said a 16-year-old girl who wants to become sexually active can go to Planned Parenthood without worrying her confidentiality will be breached.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Breuner, of the AAP, said relationship counseling is one of the most important services Planned Parenthood offers to teenage girls.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She said girls, especially those from low-income households, can learn how a healthy relationship should function.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The counseling can teach her how to say “No,” and how she should expect to be treated,” Breuner said.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Public Policy</category>
<pubdate>2017-02-06T14:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-06T14:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/what-if-planned-parenthood-went-out-of-business
</guid>
<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-06T22:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
How to Avoid Calling in Sick the Monday After the Super Bowl
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/avoid-calling-in-sick-after-super-bowl
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/Hike_0.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Perhaps it was those extra beers you drank during the post-game festivities.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Or maybe it was those half-dozen chicken wings you gnawed on during crunch time in the fourth quarter.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Or it could have been all those salty snacks you munched on during the entire four-hour football game.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Whatever the cause, it’s now Monday morning and your head is pounding from a hangover.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Or your stomach is doing somersaults from all that food you ate.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;div class=&quot;hl-poll&quot; style=&quot;float:right; margin:10px;&quot;&gt;&lt;script type=&quot;text/javascript&quot; charset=&quot;utf-8&quot; src=&quot;http://static.polldaddy.com/p/9655252.js&quot;&gt;&lt;/script&gt; &lt;noscript&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://polldaddy.com/poll/9655252/&quot;&gt;Do you think you'll eat and drink too much on Super Bowl Sunday?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/noscript&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;p&gt;There is no way you can make it into work.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If you call in sick this Monday, you won’t be alone.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.workforceinstitute.org/blog/super-bowl-workplace-impact/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2016 Workforce Institute report&lt;/a&gt; estimated that 16 million Americans miss work the day after the Super Bowl, both from planned days off and sick days.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s in addition to the 7 million employees who will come in late.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Many of these absences will be due to simple overindulgence during Super Bowl festivities.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The key operative here is moderation, which is not synonymous with this particular Sunday,” Dr. Anthony A. Starpoli, a gastroenterologist, and associate director of esophageal endotherapy at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Common mistakes&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are a lot of ways people sabotage their health while enjoying themselves during the Super Bowl.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Number one on the list is alcohol consumption.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nutrition experts told Healthline there are several ways people abuse this privilege.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The most obvious is the amount. Drinking throughout the Super Bowl is a sure path to Hangover Highway.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another is downing alcoholic drinks before you eat. Taking in liquor on an empty stomach allows alcohol to course even more quickly into your bloodstream.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ingrainhealth.com/about-katie.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Katie Ferraro&lt;/a&gt;, a registered dietitian, and assistant clinical professor at the University of San Diego and the University of California, San Francisco, says the majority of sick calls on Monday will be from drinking too much.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“You don’t want to focus on the wrong thing,” she told Healthline. “In the end, it’s probably the alcohol that is going to do you in.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s not to say food consumption won’t be a problem.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ferraro says there is not only a lot of food at Super Bowl parties, there’s also a lot of unhealthy snacks that are high in sodium, fat, and calories.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The typical Super Bowl cuisine isn’t focused on health,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://susanweinernutrition.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Susan Weiner&lt;/a&gt;, a registered dietitian and nutritionist, says there are foods served at Super Bowl parties that people don’t normally consume.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think quantity is really the problem, but it’s especially true with foods you don’t typically eat,” she told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And it’s not just upset stomachs that are the result.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Starpoli said people can also have acid reflux-related problems. The most common is heartburn.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said this is a particularly serious problem for people prone to gastroesophagael reflux disease (GERD), but it can affect anybody who is overindulging.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It can create a perfect storm,” he said. “People aren’t used to consuming these types of things in such a short period of time.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Time is also a factor.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ferraro points out that the Super Bowl is longer than most regular season football games, giving people more opportunity to abuse their bodies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition to the game, the post-game celebration doesn’t end until around 11 p.m. EST. Even on the West Coast, that’s 8 p.m.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In either case, it doesn’t give people a lot of time to settle down before they go to bed and then wake up the next morning to go to work.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Super Sunday advice&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;So, how do you avoid Super Sick Monday?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Let’s start with the alcohol.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ferraro recommends beginning your party with a glass or two of water before you take that first sip of liquor.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After that, drink some water in between each of your alcoholic beverages.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Starpoli agrees.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Staying hydrated is incredibly important,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As for the food, Weiner suggests having some alternative dishes to the bacon-cheese snacks and beefy sandwiches.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Perhaps one or two party-goers can be assigned to bring vegetable and fruit dishes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“At least give yourself a fighting chance,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Weiner also suggests not standing next to the food table while you watch the game or talk with other guests.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Put some food on a napkin or plate and walk to the other side of the room.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If you’re standing next to it, you’re more likely to eat it,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, stop eating and drinking as the end of the game draws near. That’ll provide you with a better chance of getting adequate rest.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are also things you can do on Monday to help yourself.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;First, make sure you toss out any leftover food from the party. If you don’t, you’re likely to snack on those unhealthy items.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Second, drink a lot of water on Monday. It’ll help re-hydrate you.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And do your regular exercise for that day.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Super Bowl Sunday can set up some not-so-good habits for the next few days,” Weiner said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>General Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-02-03T13:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-03T13:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/avoid-calling-in-sick-after-super-bowl
</guid>
<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-03T21:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>How Long Does It Take to Get in Shape?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/how-long-to-get-in-shape
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/heart-health/102516_paidexercise_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;
]]>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;If you’ve ever stayed up watching late night movies, you’ve probably seen commercials promising miracle total body makeovers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;You know the kind. “Just 30 minutes of exercise a day, three times a week, and you could have a totally ripped body in as little as six weeks.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It sounds good, but the truth is, there’s no quick way to get fit.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If a gym, trainer, or class promises to make all your dreams come true in six weeks, run — don't walk — in the other direction,” New York-based certified personal trainer Lisa Snow, president of &lt;a href=&quot;http://onthemendfitness.com&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;On the Mend Customized Fitness and Massage&lt;/a&gt;, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Even “natural” exercisers won’t see fitness miracles any time soon. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Some people seem to put on muscle at a much quicker pace than others — although nobody is going to look like Vin Diesel overnight,” said Justin Fauci, a certified personal trainer and co-founder of &lt;a href=&quot;http://leanmuscleproject.com&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Lean Muscle Project&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If you doubt that six weeks isn’t enough time to get fit, take a look at a &lt;a href=&quot;http://journals.lww.com/nsca-jscr/Abstract/2004/05000/Training_Vs__Body_Image__Does_Training_Improve.9.aspx&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2004 study&lt;/a&gt; by researchers at the University of Wisconsin, La Crosse, which was published in The Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers put a group of 25 sedentary men through a six-week exercise program — either three 20-minute cardiovascular sessions each week, or three 30-minute high-intensity, total-body strength training sessions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Yes, it sounds a lot like those miracle fitness commercials.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A group of panelists rated the men’s appearance at the start and end of the study based on photos. After six weeks, the ratings were unchanged. Even the men’s ratings of their own appearances were pretty much the same after six weeks.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Also, objective signs of fitness — like percent body fat, number of pushups, and oxygen efficiency — didn’t improve over the course of the study.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So if six weeks isn’t enough time to get in shape, how long does it take?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Time depends on goals&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The answer to this fitness question depends, in part, on what you mean by “in shape.&quot;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“How long it takes to see fitness results will vary depending on what your goals are,” Eliza Kingsford, director of &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.wellspringcamps.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Wellspring Camps&lt;/a&gt;, and author of “Brain-Powered Weight Loss,” told Healthline. “Are you looking to improve time? Get stronger? Lose weight? Lose body fat? The answer to how long it will take to get fit will vary for each one of those goals.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A beginner wanting to run a 5K race will take less time to get in shape than someone training for their first marathon or triathlon. And they will need a different training program than someone getting ready for a weeklong backpacking trip.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In general, though, you will start to “feel” better long before you see major fitness results.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“For someone starting out, I notice that within two weeks they can start feeling the benefits of exercise,” Jamie Logie, a personal trainer who runs &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.regainedwellness.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Wellness Regained&lt;/a&gt;, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This might mean being less out of breath when you climb stairs or run to catch the subway. Or being able to play with your grandchildren in the back yard without getting tired.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Although you might not have a “ripped body” yet, these small changes shouldn’t be dismissed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The mental benefits of getting active are even more important than the external changes we are all so concerned about seeing,” Samantha Clayton, senior director of Worldwide Fitness Education at &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.herbalife.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Herbalife&lt;/a&gt;, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This includes increased motivation and confidence to keep coming back to your workout until you start seeing physical benefits.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If you have been out of shape, or not working out for 10 years — or forever — it will generally take about two months of working out most days of the week to get to a moderate level,” New York-based Nikki Glor, creator of &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nikkifitness.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;NikkiFitness&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;videos, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And if you exercise regularly, over time you will gain even more fitness benefits.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“At six to eight weeks you can definitely notice some changes,” said Logie, “and in three to four months you can do a pretty good overhaul to your health and fitness.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Strength-specific results take about the same amount of time.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“For a client who is already in good cardio shape but just wants to learn how to lift weights safely, three months is usually a reasonable timeframe,” said Snow.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So, how long until you are sporting a “ripped body”?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If you're consistent about working out and dieting properly for a full year, and you weren't significantly overweight to begin with,” said Fauci, “then after one year you can expect to sport a lean, muscular physique with a visible six pack.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Getting fit to compete&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Not everyone likes getting fit just for the sake of getting fit.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For them, there are any number of outdoor races to choose from — 5K or 10K running races, marathons, half marathons, or 100-mile bicycle rides. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are also triathlons, Tough Mudders, Super Spartans, and other obstacle races for people who like variety.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With this kind of specific fitness goal, it’s even more important to not rush getting in shape.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If you are preparing for an event or race, please be over-prepared,” James Shapiro, a certified personal trainer with New York-based &lt;a href=&quot;http://primalpower-fitness.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Primal Power&lt;/a&gt;, told Healthline. “If you plan to participate in an endurance event like the Spartan race and have never jogged five miles, it's time to start three to four months before. Our bodies do get stronger, but you want to run past the finish line, not crawl to get there.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are many training programs to help you get in shape for these races, but expect to spend at least two months on pre-race training, clocking miles three to six days each week.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That extra time will be worth it, especially for beginners.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17186304&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2007 study&lt;/a&gt; in the European Journal of Applied Physiology, researchers put a group of untrained adults through a nine-month half-length and full-length marathon training program.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;By the end of the study, people in the program had increased their cardiovascular fitness — VO2 max — by 24 percent, and their running speed by 29 percent.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Even if you prefer noncompetitive outdoor activities like backpacking, kayaking, or mountain biking, expect to put in solid miles to get in shape.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We find that it takes about four to five full days of backpacking to get into hiking shape,” Steve Silberberg, owner of Massachusetts-based &lt;a href=&quot;http://fitpacking.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Fitpacking Weight Loss Backpacking Adventure Vacations&lt;/a&gt;, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These are full eight-hour days, back-to-back, with a fully loaded pack. It may sound daunting, but lots of beginners have walked this path before.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Many people can get right off the couch and start backpacking,” said Silberberg. “The second day is the toughest because the first day’s enthusiasm has waned and you already have sore feet and muscles.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Factors that affect fitness&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;These, of course, are general guidelines. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Many things along the way can speed up or slow down your progress.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“How fit you are when you get started is one factor that I’ve personally seen affect people’s individual results timeline,” said Clayton.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The type of exercise you choose also matters and it will affect you differently if you are a beginner or coming off an illness or injury.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If you’re not comfortable with exercise, or perhaps are being cautious because of an injury, you are going to get different results from walking for 90 minutes per day than someone who is already used to exercise and decided to try a HIIT [high intensity interval training] program,” said Kingsford.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Beginners, though, may progress faster simply because they are starting lower down the fitness ladder and require less exercise to challenge their body.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Beginners see huge jumps in strength across the board every week with proper training,” said Fauci.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Of course, what you put into an exercise program also determines what you get out of it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On a perceived exertion scale of one to 10, “if you only feel comfortable exercising at a level six, you are going to get different results than someone who is comfortable exercising at a level nine,” said Kingsford.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a &lt;a href=&quot;http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/1108370&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2007 study&lt;/a&gt; in the Journal of the American Medical Association, researchers placed sedentary, overweight, or obese women into three groups — exercising at 50 percent, 100 percent, or 150 percent of the recommended energy expenditure level.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Women who worked out at the highest intensity level saw an 8 percent improvement in their cardiovascular fitness after six months. Those at the lowest intensity level saw a 4 percent increase in fitness.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;An 8 percent increase in fitness doesn’t seem like a lot, but if you’ve been inactive for a long time, it can be huge.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If you crank up the intensity even more, you’ll get faster results.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We see fitness results from our students within about two weeks,” Tina Angelotti, fitness director of &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.kravmaga.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Krav Maga Worldwide&lt;/a&gt;, told Healthline. “Our students work at very high levels of intensity in our Krav Maga self-defense, fitness, and fight classes.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If you are a beginner, or new to higher-intensity workouts, you might need to work up to this level.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If you work too hard too soon, you risk injury or quitting from the stress,” said Clayton. “But if you don’t work hard enough, you won’t see results. So find your balance and know that healthy and fit is not a race nor a destination.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Getting out of shape&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Once your exercise routine becomes a habit, you’ll probably find that it’s easier to stick with it. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But an injury, illness, or even life can easily derail your workouts.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Life circumstances will always throw you off your plan at some point,” Rob Williams, performance coach and trainer for &lt;a href=&quot;https://eas.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;EAS Sports Nutrition&lt;/a&gt;, “but the more important thing is to get back to your program and be in it for the long run.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Often, cardiovascular fitness is the first to go.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If you're highly trained and decide to take a break from exercise, your cardio is going to be the first and fastest to decline. It will drop significantly after only a few weeks of inactivity,” Tyler Spraul, a certified strength and conditioning specialist and the head trainer at &lt;a href=&quot;http://exercise.com&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Exercise.com&lt;/a&gt;, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the &lt;a href=&quot;http://journals.lww.com/acsm-msse/Fulltext/2011/07000/Quantity_and_Quality_of_Exercise_for_Developing.26.aspx&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;American College of Sports Medicine&lt;/a&gt;, physiological changes — like blood lipoproteins, ability to use glucose for energy and body composition — can occur one or two weeks after you stop exercising.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/6511559&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;1984 study&lt;/a&gt; in the Journal of Applied Physiology: Respiratory, Environmental and Exercise Physiology also found that when endurance athletes stopped training, their VO2 max dropped by 7 percent within the first 21 days of inactivity.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This stabilized after 56 days of no exercise. And after 84 days of inactivity, the athletes still had a higher VO2 max than people who had never trained.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Muscle strength may last longer during a break.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10949019&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2000 study&lt;/a&gt; in Medicine and Science in Sports and Exercise found that young people lost just 8 percent of their strength after 31 weeks of inactivity. Older people lost 14 percent of their strength during that time.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Most of the loss of strength occurred between 12 and 31 weeks.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Even small breaks may not affect your overall strength progress.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21771261&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2011 study&lt;/a&gt; in Clinical Physiology and Functional Imaging, beginners who took a three-week break in the middle of a 15-week bench press program achieved similar results by the end of the study as beginners who worked out the entire way through.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So once you build a foundation of strength, it stays with you.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When you undergo resistance training, you permanently change the physiology of your muscle cells — even if you stop training for long periods of time,” said Fauci. “This makes the process of regaining strength and size after a long break from the gym much quicker.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This is just as true for overall fitness.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Everyone is going to be different when it comes to seeing results after a break from working out,” said Williams, “But the longer and more consistent you’ve been working out and training, the less of an impact a break will have on you.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Minimizing losses during breaks&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The good news is you can minimize fitness losses during a break by continuing to exercise at some level, even if it’s less than what you were doing before.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the ACSM, you can maintain your current level of strength, performance, and health benefits with “as little as a single session per week of moderate- to hard-intensity exercise.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;What you choose to get you through a break depends on your circumstances.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If you stopped exercising because life got in the way, you might need to squeeze in physical activity wherever you can — do bodyweight resistance exercises throughout the day, take the stairs instead of the elevator, or bike to work.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If you are injured, you may have to modify your workouts significantly.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I encourage students dealing with an injury — depending on the severity of the injury — to continue to come and train, but we obviously modify their workout around the injured body part,” said Angelotti. “For example, a student with a shoulder injury can still come and work out their lower body so that they don't get completely deconditioned.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s also important to work with a doctor or physical therapist to develop a program that will keep you active, but still let your body heal.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;People who are coming back from an injury also “need to learn to trust the injured joint again,” said Snow. “Favoring the uninjured side for months or years after graduating from therapy only increases the risk of a new injury somewhere else in the body.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If you have been inactive for several weeks, it is often safest to start fresh — working with your current level of fitness and health, not where you were before the break.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And for that, you’ll need lots of patience, the kind that got you in shape in the first place.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“After giving birth to my first son it took me four months to get back to fit and after triplets it took me 18 months,” said Clayton. “It’s all about one step at a time and allowing your body to adapt slowly — this is often the best and most sustainable approach.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Fitness and Exercise</category>

<updateddate>2017-02-03T13:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/how-long-to-get-in-shape
</guid>
<dc:creator>Shawn Radcliffe</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-03T21:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Marijuana Component Might Be an Effective Tool in Opioid Epidemic
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/marijuana-component-tool-in-opioid-epidemic
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/childrens-health/072616_childrenmarijuana_BODY.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Is marijuana a safer drug to use for some people than an opioid painkiller?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cell.com/trends/neurosciences/fulltext/S0166-2236(17)30001-2&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; published today in the journal Trends in Neurosciences is bringing that issue and related topics to the forefront.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study was narrowly focused, looking at the potential use of an extract of cannabis found in medical marijuana to reduce the symptoms and cravings of people who use heroin.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But the study author, Yasmin Hurd, professor of neuroscience, psychiatry, and pharmacology and systems therapeutics at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai in New York, and other experts, say the findings do highlight a need for the scientific community to further investigate the potential therapeutic uses of marijuana components.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This line of thinking, Hurd notes, is particularly critical now because of the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/drugoverdose/epidemic/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;opioid epidemic&lt;/a&gt; sweeping the United States.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She notes that 2.5 million people in the United States have opioid use disorder and more than 80 people die every day from opioid overuse.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She adds that 200 million opioid painkiller prescriptions are written in the United States every year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We have to do something urgently,” Hurd told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What the study showed&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;For her research, Hurd used information from a small human trial as well as a number of animal studies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She focused on cannabinoids, an extract of cannabis legally sold as medical marijuana.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hurd said both cannabinoids and opioids regulate the perception of pain.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, she concluded, the two drugs affect different parts of the brain as well as how the sensation of pain is communicated from neuron to neuron.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cannabinoids tend to have a stronger effect on inflammation-based chronic pain.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Opioids, such as painkillers like hydrocodone, are better at relieving acute pain. That’s why they are used in situations such as post-surgery recovery.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hurd said the downside to opioids is they are more addictive than cannabinoids. In addition, it is nearly impossible to overdose on cannabinoids, while it is possible to overdose on opioids.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If you look at both drugs and where their receptors are, opioids are much more dangerous, in part because of the potential for overdose — the opioid receptors are very abundant in the brainstem area that regulates our respiration, so they shut down the breathing center if opioid doses are high,” Hurd said in a statement. “Cannabinoids don't do that. They have a much wider window of therapeutic benefit without causing an overdose in adults.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She noted that younger people can overdose from consuming too much edible medical marijuana.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hurd said that some people addicted to heroin might be better off using cannabinoids.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She said cannabinoids have the potential to reduce the users’ cravings and symptoms with less chance for addiction.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hurd noted that states that have passed medical marijuana laws have noticed a decrease in opioid prescriptions and opioid overdoses since legalization.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The experts weigh in&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Several experts interviewed by Healthline found merit in Hurd’s findings.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Thomas Strouse, medical director of the Stewart and Lynda Resnick Neuropsychiatric Hospital at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA), said the study brings up some “very interesting” points and issues.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Strouse, who also oversees a palliative care program, said some of his patients who experience acute pain from surgery or chemotherapy need to stay on opioids.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, some patients who experience long-term chronic pain might be better served using components of marijuana.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He agreed that the effects from cannabinoids are not as serious as they are from prescription painkillers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Marijuana dependency is milder compared to opioids,” Strouse told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He and Hurd did agree that people under the age of 25 whose brains are still developing should avoid marijuana-based treatments.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Officials at the National Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA) also saw promise in Hurd’s research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s important to note that the focus of this paper is on cannabidiol (CBD) — a nonpsychoactive component of the marijuana plant — and that preclinical and preliminary evidence in human trials suggest that it may have therapeutic potential for treating some components of an opioid (and other) addictions,” Dr. Susan Weiss, NIDA’s director of the Division of Extramural Research, said in an email to Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Weiss added that the best way to administer such treatment is through “purified extracts of the plant or synthetic formulations of cannabinoids that can be reliably produced and administered through nonsmoking routes.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Paul Armentano, deputy director of the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws (NORML), also agreed with the study’s basic findings.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He told Healthline that cannabinoids have been proven to be less addictive than opioids, tobacco, and alcohol.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said people who use marijuana products rather than opioids usually came out ahead.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When you weigh the ‘pot positives’ against the ‘pot negatives,’ you come out with a net positive,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The experts also urged the scientific community to continue researching marijuana’s therapeutic advantages.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hurd noted that so far the policy on marijuana laws has been made at the ballot box, not in the nation’s laboratories and university halls.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Strouse had the same concern.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I hope we are guided by science on this issue,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Addiction</category>
<pubdate>2017-02-02T14:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-02T14:00:00</updateddate>

</guid>
<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-02T22:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Do Wearable Devices for Babies Cause Anxiety for Parents?
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/wearable-devices-for-babies
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/childrens-health/021816_vitamindbaby_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;When Mary O’Connell Ripley and her husband, John, brought home their newborn daughter slightly more than a year ago, the couple was undoubtedly nervous.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Like many first-time parents, their anxieties were relieved a bit when they decided to invest in a baby video monitor so they could easily check on their infant while she slept.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It definitely brought me piece of mind,” O’Connell Ripley told Healthline. “We could just look at the monitor and see how she was doing.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Peace of mind isn’t an unreasonable aspiration for any parent with regard to their child’s safety. Baby monitors are often considered the first line of defense in that quest.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As O’Connell Ripley mentioned, they allow parents to easily keep tabs on their child — when they sleep, when they wake up, and when they cry.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But a &lt;a href=&quot;http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/article-abstract/2598780&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;recent review&lt;/a&gt;, published in the Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA), cautioned parents about turning to a specific type of monitoring device as the be-all and end-all of keeping track of your child.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Concerns over constant monitoring&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;These so-called smart devices, or wearable devices, are designed to monitor your baby’s movements at night, analyze your baby’s sleep, and keep you constantly updated on your baby’s heart rate and oxygen levels.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These devices are usually linked to apps on smart phones that send alarms to parents when a condition, such as the position, breathing, or temperature of the baby, changes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The JAMA authors say many parents appear to be using these devices as a means to prevent sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS). But in the end they are only subjecting themselves and their babies to unwarranted health scares.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Despite the lack of publicly available evidence, supporting the safety, accuracy, and effectiveness, or the role of the monitors in the care of well infants, sales of the products are brisk and the market is expanding,” JAMA stated.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Jesspreet Gowan of the Stanford Children’s Health Pediatric Associates, told Healthline that she agrees with the concerns of the JAMA review.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She said that wearable devices for infants may sound like a great idea, in theory. But unless your child has a serious medical condition that warrants constant monitoring, parents are only setting themselves up for more stress.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“You have alarms going off and parents rushing to the ER,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Any parent who enters an emergency room and reports that their baby isn’t breathing properly will have to watch their child undergo a number of tests that can range from chest X-rays to a hospital stay, Gowan added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She said the fear of SIDS is real, so she understands why parents would turn to a wearable device to help alleviate that worry. But they need to understand that healthy babies, just like adults, don’t always sleep soundly.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“What these monitors are really looking at is sleep apnea,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But apnea is not correlated with an increased risk of SIDS, Gowan added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“These monitors have not been shown to decrease risk of SIDS,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The evolution of baby monitors&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;First generation baby monitors took hold in the 1980s and looked like walkie-talkies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They broadcasted through short wave radio.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;By the early 2000s, video monitors came into favor, giving parents a bird’s-eye view of their child.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Today, parents and caregivers can choose from a veritable smorgasbord of baby monitoring devices. &lt;a href=&quot;http://amazon.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Amazon.com&lt;/a&gt; boasts dozens of devices. A quick search for “baby monitoring devices” on Google produces a seemingly endless list of page results.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are only a handful of the more sophisticated smart devices on the market.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Owlet gives parents real-time feedback on heart rates and oxygen levels. It looks like a little sock that parents slip on their baby’s foot.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The website promotes the idea of “peace of mind” for parents, but it also lists a disclaimer that “this device is not intended to cure, treat, or prevent any disease or health condition, including, but not limited to, sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS).”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Mimo Smart Baby Breathing and Activity Monitor is best described as onesies with the device attached near the belly.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It monitors “real-time breathing” and alerts parent of any changes in breathing and activity, such as body position and temperature through a connected app.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;MonBaby calls itself a breathing and rollover monitor.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It snaps onto your baby’s clothes, similar to antitheft devices used on clothes in department stories. Parents can set up their desired alerts on the accompanying app.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Parental anxiety &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s important to note the American Academy of Pediatrics is not in favor of parents using smart monitoring devices. These products are also not approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Gowan said infants with chronic lung disease or bronchopulmonary dysplasia, or infants who require ventilation at night, would likely benefit from a smart monitoring device.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“But then the pulmonologist is prescribing it and parents are instructed on what to do,” she said. “In this case it’s very controlled.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Parents who have healthy babies and are using a smart device are essentially on their own, she added, with no one to help them interpret the alarms.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This leads to the anxiety,” Gowan said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;O’Connell Ripley said that was the reason she and her husband made the conscious choice to not purchase a smart monitoring device.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Unless there was a known medical issue,” she said, “I think it would increase your anxiety.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Gowan said she has no issue with parents employing a video monitor. She also hasn’t had any parents ask her about wearable devices for their child.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But she expects that to change.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When that happens Gowan said she plans to educate parents on the JAMA findings and strongly encourage parents to employ the tactics that are known to prevent SIDS.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Safe sleep, that has been known to reduce SIDS. Back sleep, no blankets, no toys in the crib, all of those things,” she said. “It’s important for us to emphasize those are the things to do to protect your baby.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<category>Technology</category>

<dc:creator>Carolyn Abate</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-02T20:00:00</dc:date>
