<item>
<title>
OK, So What Else Don’t We Know About the Human Body?
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/what-dont-we-know-about-the-human-body
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/topic_centers/osteoarthritis/642x361-3-Thumb_Bend.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt
]]>
<![CDATA[
;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For years, medical students were taught there are 78 organs in the human body. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In January, that number was revised with the announcement of a &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/new-organ-in-human-body#1&quot;&gt;new organ&lt;/a&gt; called the mesentery. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Part of the digestive tract, the mesentery transports blood and lymphatic fluid between the intestine and the rest of the body.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Until recently, it was believed to be made of up separate structures.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But researchers in Ireland have revealed the mesentery is in fact one continuous structure, bringing the organ count for the human body up to 79. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So, what else don’t we know about the human body? &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Healthline asked a few experts to share their theories on some long-held questions about our complicated machinery. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Why do we have different blood types? &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The major blood types are A, B, and O.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Type O is the most common blood type, and type AB is the least common. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Blood type can be determined by the types of sugars that stick to blood cells. Each individual has enzymes that are particular and will only add certain types of sugar to the blood cell.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Blood types can also be determined by the presence or absence of antigens and antibodies in blood and blood plasma. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But the reason why humans have different blood types in the first place remains a mystery.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Les E Silberstein, a spokesperson for the American Society of Hematology, and a hematologist at Boston Children’s Hospital and Harvard Medical School, describes it as an “enigma.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It is speculated that specific blood types and blood type antigens have evolved to fulfill a particular function,” Silberstein told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“One theory is that people who evolved in a specific location may develop a specific blood type to protect them against diseases common in that area,” he added. “For example, the majority of African-Americans are group O, which is considered to be more resistant to certain forms of malaria.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Why do we have fingerprints? &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Fingerprints have long been used as markers of human identity.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Fingerprint analysis forms an important part of forensic science and criminal investigation. Among other things, they can be used to identify individuals who are deceased. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The exact reason we have fingerprints has puzzled researchers for decades. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Roland Ennos, Ph.D., a professor of biological sciences at the University of Hull in England, says there are three potential reasons humans have fingerprints. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The first is that fingerprints help with touch sensitivity. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Touch receptors are found in the ridges [of fingerprints] and these can amplify strains in the skin, so increasing sensitivity. But this could be a secondary use. Many other areas of our hands and feet, the palms and soles also have similar ridges, and we don't use them for sensitive touch,” he told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The second possibility is that fingerprints help improve grip, though Ennos is unconvinced this is the case. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The problem with this is that the friction of soft, rubbery materials such as skin rises with the area of contact. Fingerprints will reduce contact area, so should actually reduce friction on smooth surfaces. However, they could increase friction on rougher surfaces by getting into the troughs of the surface,” he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The third possibility is that the ridges on fingerprints could help prevent blisters. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Blisters tend to occur when shoes rub on areas of the feet which don't have ridges, such as the heel and tips of the toes, but it's hard to prove,” Ennos said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Why do we yawn? &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Have you ever found yourself needing to yawn directly after someone else has? &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Robert Provine, a neuroscientist, and professor of psychology at the University of Maryland, and author of the book “&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.hup.harvard.edu/catalog.php?isbn=9780674048515&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Curious Behavior: Yawning, Laughing, Hiccupping, and Beyond&lt;/a&gt;,” says contagious yawning is a basic, neurologically programmed social behavior. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Yawning may be a primitive form of empathy that binds tribal members together and coordinates their physiology, such as synchronizing arousal and bedtimes. Diminished contagion, whether from yawning or laughing, may be a novel measure of social disorders as in autism or schizophrenia,” he told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But why do we yawn in the first place? &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The best starting point to this question is considering when we yawn,” Provine said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We yawn most just before bedtime, after waking, and when becoming bored. All of these situations involve ‘state change’ — shifting from one condition to another, whether from sleep to wakefulness, wakefulness to sleep, or alertness to boredom. Also, it has been suggested that yawning may cool the brain. Yawning is a vigorous, body-wide act that is ideal for stirring up our physiology and facilitating these shifts.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s not just humans that yawn.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For most vertebrates (animals with backbones) yawning starts near the end of the first trimester of prenatal development.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Contagious yawns also occur in highly social animals such as chimpanzees and animals that travel in packs, like dogs. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What causes us to laugh? &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;If you’ve ever heard someone laugh so hard they begin to sound like a chimpanzee, you have evolution to thank for it. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If you tickle a chimpanzee, its laughter sounds like panting. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The sound of laughter came to symbolize the physical play that triggered it,” Provine explains. “Laughter indicates, ‘This is play, I'm not attacking you.’ The ancestral primate ‘pant-pant’ evolved into the human ‘ha-ha’ that involves a chopped exhalation, as in speech.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The idea of “play” has evolved for humans from rough play of the chimpanzees to conversation and other high-order cognitive stimuli.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But laughter still remains highly social.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We laugh thirty times more often in social than solitary situations. When alone, without the vicarious social stimuli of media and our imagination, laughter almost disappears,” Provine said. “Want more laughter in your life? Spend more time in playful encounters with friends, family, and lovers.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<category>Strange Science</category>
<pubdate>2017-02-02T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-02T10:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/what-dont-we-know-about-the-human-body
</guid>
<dc:creator>Elizabeth Pratt</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-02T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
'Baby Boxes' Show the Importance of Helping New Parents
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/baby-boxes-helping-new-parents
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/childrens-health/021816_vitamindbaby_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Taking a page from Finland’s baby care book, New Jersey will soon begin offering “baby boxes” to parents of all newborns in the state.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These cardboard boxes are large enough — and come with a tight-fitting sheet and hard mattress — to provide a safe sleep space for the baby’s first couple of months.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The boxes are also filled with essential items for newborns — a onesie, diapers, baby wipes, and nipple cream and breast pads for breast-feeding mothers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The program is a partnership between the state's Child Fatality and Near Fatality Review Board and manufacturer The Baby Box Company. They expect to hand out about 105,000 baby boxes this year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Funding is provided by a grant from the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.phillyvoice.com/new-jersey-become-first-state-send-new-parents-home-baby-boxes/&quot;&gt;Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This is the first statewide baby box program in the United States. But similar efforts have been undertaken in other cities, including one started last year at &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.phillymag.com/be-well-philly/2016/05/06/baby-boxes-temple-university-hospital/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Temple University Hospital&lt;/a&gt; in Philadelphia.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These programs attempt to reduce the risk of accidental suffocation and strangulation — which account for 25 percent of the approximately 3,500 cases of &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/sids/data.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Sudden Unexpected Infant Death (SUID)&lt;/a&gt; in the United States each year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) accounts for 44 percent of the SUID cases. The rest have unknown causes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/sudden-infant-death-syndrome/basics/risk-factors/con-20020269&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Risk factors for SIDS&lt;/a&gt; include infant sex and age, secondhand smoke, and premature birth.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;SIDS, though, is not related to unsafe sleep.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“SIDS deaths are deaths where we have no explanation for why this previously healthy baby died,” Dr. Elizabeth Murray, a pediatrician at University of Rochester Medical Center’s Golisano Children’s Hospital, told Healthline. “But unsafe sleep deaths are 100 percent preventable.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Creating a safe sleep space&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;These “preventable deaths” occur in communities across the country.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I work in a pediatric intensive care unit and unfortunately we still see this happen,” Dr. Shoba Srikantan, a pediatrician and critical care specialist for Arnold Palmer Hospital for Children in Florida, told Healthline. “We have a few cases every year of a child who died while sleeping in a bed with a parent. A child, whose parent put them to sleep on a pillow, who suffocated on the pillow. A child who fell asleep breast-feeding on their mom and suffocated that way.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If parents and doctors keep in mind the dangers of unsafe sleeping conditions, said Murray, it “will help to make it very real for the families that are learning this information.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With baby boxes and other sleep devices, parents also need to keep in mind other safety tips, like “making sure that there’s nothing in the crib — that there are no baby bumpers, that there are no blankets — that the baby is on their back,” said Murray, “and no co-sleeping in an adult bed.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Toys, pillows, and pets should also be kept out of the baby’s sleep area.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And if parents are using gadgets to keep track of their baby, they shouldn’t get lulled into a false sense of safety.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If you still don’t have a safe sleep environment, and you put your baby on a pillow — even with a baby monitor … I’ve seen children suffocate and die that way,” said Srikantan. “I can’t emphasize how it’s so important that safety is paramount.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Educating parents&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In countries like Finland, which has been handing out baby boxes to parents since the 1930s, “it’s considered a rite of passage and a very proud thing that the parents engage in,” said Murray.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But this is not the only safe sleep option.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Other communities have other projects to get Pack 'n Plays or actual cribs to families in need if they don’t have it,” said Murray.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These resources, though, can only do so much for the safety of infants.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The one thing we’ve definitely seen in our community is that it’s not a lack of access to a safe sleep device,” said Murray. “It’s a choice to not use it. So you have to overcome that barrier.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Which is why the New Jersey program also tries to educate parents about newborn care through an online curriculum and quiz.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These messages are especially important for new parents, who may feel overwhelmed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Parents are focused on so many things when they have a baby,” said Srikantan. “How’s my baby going to feed, how do I give a bath, how much is too much? There’s so much that you’re trying to absorb at once.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The baby box program is part of a larger conversation about newborn health, one that parents can start long before their baby arrives.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Srikantan suggests that expectant parents “find a pediatrician that you can really partner with,” and remember that “no question is a silly question to ask your pediatrician.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-02-01T14:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-01T14:00:00</updateddate>

http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/baby-boxes-helping-new-parents
</guid>
<dc:creator>Shawn Radcliffe</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-01T22:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Celebrity Health Advice: The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/celebrity-health-advice
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/topic_centers/Depresion/400x400_Famous_Faces_of_Depression-8-Gwyneth_Paltrow.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It only takes one glance at the tabloid rack to realize that when famous people talk, people listen.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Celebrities often use their platform to discuss personal health and well-being.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Much of their health advice is considered questionable, from putting a jade egg in a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.health.com/sexual-health/jade-egg-goop&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;private area&lt;/a&gt;, to espousing the belief that &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/children-still-no-evidence-vaccines-cause-autism-032913&quot;&gt;vaccines cause autism&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nonetheless, these comments tend to gain traction.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To be sure, not all celebrity health advice is bad, but experts say the comments of the rich and famous should be taken with a grain of salt.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;They’re not doctors&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;A celebrity’s fame can provide a big platform.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Because celebrities have a big audience, they can have a big effect on people’s behavior,” Steven Salzberg, Ph.D., Bloomberg Distinguished Professor of biomedical engineering, computer science, and biostatistics at Johns Hopkins University, told Healthline. “And if they give out bad advice, that can be very dangerous.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;To find bad celebrity health advice, one doesn’t have to look far.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Jenny McCarthy is as well-known for her &lt;a href=&quot;http://content.time.com/time/health/article/0,8599,1888718,00.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;anti-vaccine activism&lt;/a&gt; as she is for her Playboy pictorials.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ben Stiller gave well-meaning — but what some experts called flawed — advice regarding &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/men-to-get-prostate-cancer-screening-but-should-they&quot;&gt;prostate cancer screenings&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When it comes to Gwyneth Paltrow, it’s hard to know where to start.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the past, the Oscar-winning actress has &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.businessinsider.com/gwyneth-paltrow-goop-bad-health-advice-2015-10&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;posted tips&lt;/a&gt; on her website about health-related topics from sunscreen to cleanses.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Last week, Paltrow recommended that women put &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cbsnews.com/news/gwyneth-paltrow-goop-advice-vaginal-jade-eggs-doctors-warning/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;jade eggs&lt;/a&gt; in their vaginas to improve their health and sex life. That advice was criticized by a number of medical professionals.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Add to all this the dozens of celebs, including &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cosmopolitan.com/health-fitness/news/a63124/kardashian-weight-loss-tips-you-should-never-follow/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Kim and Kourtney Kardashian&lt;/a&gt;, who offer weight-loss tips.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Georges Benjamin, executive director of the American Public Health Association, says it’s risky for the general public to put their trust in celebrities.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Celebrities are seen through the lens of their fans as trusted messengers,” Benjamin told Healthline. “The challenge we have is making sure that those messages are correct and that those celebrities are well-informed. Frankly, sometimes, they’re simply wrong.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When it comes to the anti-vaccine movement, Salzberg says that anti-vaxxers like McCarthy tend to see a conspiracy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Vaccines are one of the most effective treatments we have to prevent disease and save people’s lives, and that’s why people go into medicine. They don’t go into it because they want to hurt people. That’s just a crazy and nutty kind of suggestion, but that’s exactly what Jenny McCarthy and other anti-vaxxers like Robert F. Kennedy Jr. are promoting now,” Salzberg told Healthline. “So there’s no evidence that there’s any conspiracy, but they state it and assert it, and people listen because they have a big platform. It’s frustrating. I’m not going to have the kind of audience that R.F.K., Jr. has. He had a meeting with Donald Trump.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Benjamin points out that sometimes it isn’t an individual celebrity, but rather an entire industry, that spreads a harmful message.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The tobacco industry, for many, many years, encouraged and even paid studios and others in the entertainment industry to promote tobacco, which is, of course, a harmful product,” he said. “So the medical community has worked very hard with the TV and film industry to try and get them to remove the use of tobacco products from movies, where role models are seen smoking.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Good advice, education&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Despite some of the more dubious health claims celebrities have made over the years, there are precedents for famous people using their platforms to advocate for responsible health decisions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Benjamin cites actor Michael J. Fox’s battle with Parkinson’s disease, and his subsequent advocacy for research into the disorder, as a particularly noteworthy example.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He also brings up some other examples, noting, “Katie Couric, whose husband had colon cancer, had her own colonoscopy on TV. The Marlboro Man, Wayne McLaren, became an anti-tobacco advocate after being diagnosed with lung cancer. Angelina Jolie, whose genetic makeup included a strong possibility of breast cancer, had a preventive double mastectomy. A celebrity can have a positive impact.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Salzberg says education is the key.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think that the only real solution is a long-term one, to educate people better starting in grade school. They need to pay attention to science and evidence-based medicine,” says Salzberg. “The other thing that I’ve been blogging about for years — and other people, too — is that I think we need to train individuals, starting as early as elementary school, to be skeptical about claims they hear on TV or on their computer screen. They don’t have to become experts on science and medicine — they just can’t, it requires too much background training. But they can be skeptical.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Benjamin says that individuals can make informed choices by making sure their health advice is coming from a reputable source.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In this era, what often happens is a celebrity will bring something up, and people will begin googling it. It can begin a national conversation. Now, some of that conversation is informed and some of that information isn’t informed,” he said. “And so what has to happen is that health organizations need to weigh in and become part of that conversation so people can find trusted information from organizations like the Red Cross, American Heart Association, American Cancer Society, and I’d like to say us at the American Public Health Association. There are also federal agencies like the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Salzberg points out that the scientific community has made significant headway in educating the public, particularly when it comes to anti-vaccine rhetoric.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think the momentum has flagged,” he said. “The current anti-vaccine movement was at its peak in the early and mid-2000s, but in the scientific community we’ve been working very hard to counter that, because it’s very harmful to public health. So I think it’s losing momentum. But it’s a constant fight.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<dc:creator>Dan Gray</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-01T21:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>The Skinny on Coconut Oil: It May Be Fattening</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/coconut-oil-may-be-fattening
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/topic_centers/Food-Nutrition/766x415_thumbnail_coconut_oil_vs_coconut_butter.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Over the past few years, consumers have been bombarded with information about the health benefits of coconut oil.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It can slow the aging process.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It can help your heart and thyroid.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It can protect you from illnesses such as Alzheimer’s, arthritis, and diabetes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It can even help you lose weight!&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Bah humbug, says Dr. Andrew Freeman, director of cardiovascular prevention and wellness at National Jewish Health in Denver.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He says coconut oil is not just another fad that comes and goes, it’s also dangerous.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There’s very little data showing health benefits,” Freeman told Healthline. “It’s not in one’s best interest.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Adding fat to your meals&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;There’s no question that coconut oil is popular.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Freeman, who is co-chair of the American College of Cardiology’s lifestyle and nutrition group, notes it’s possible to buy the oil by the tub at Costco.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, Freeman says, coconut oil is high in fat, so it’s about the worst thing to add to a typical American diet already rich in processed meat and cheese.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lauren Blake, a registered dietitian at The Ohio State University’s Wexner Medical Center, says some of her clients love coconut oil and think it has healing properties.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I always advise them to be careful,” she told Healthline. “I don’t recommend one specific type of oil. I suggest they switch them around. Include olive oil or avocado oil.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She noted that &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.todaysdietitian.com/newarchives/1016p32.shtml&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Today’s Dietitian magazine&lt;/a&gt; investigated some of claims attributed to coconut oil. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“While there's a possibility that MCFAs [medium-chain fatty acids] may behave differently in the body than longer-chain saturated fats, there's no direct evidence that coconut oil increases insulin sensitivity or can be helpful in the prevention or treatment of diabetes in humans. The American Diabetes Association considers coconut oil a saturated fat to be limited,” the magazine reported.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Can it really clean teeth?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Wall Street Journal reported last spring that &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.wsj.com/articles/coconuts-go-upscale-boosting-price-of-conventional-coconut-oil-1460017362&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;coconut oil prices&lt;/a&gt; had risen nearly 20 percent in a month, largely due to the growing popularity of specialty products such as coconut water. Coconut water is being marketed as a replacement for sports drinks like Gatorade. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The result is a shake-up in supply chains from farms to store shelves.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In some supermarkets, coconuts are being sold with pull tabs to be drunk like beer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Among the celebrities touting the benefits of coconut oil is actress &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.glamourmagazine.co.uk/article/gwyneth-paltrow-oil-pulling-to-make-your-teeth-white-using-coconut-oil&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Gwyneth Paltrow&lt;/a&gt;, who has said it whitens teeth and improves the complexion.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.dailymail.co.uk/health/article-3137807/Would-clean-teeth-coconut-oil-Study-finds-ancient-Indian-technique-really-DOES-benefit-mouth-health.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Daily Mail&lt;/a&gt; in England consulted a dentist about claims for assorted alternative methods of cleaning teeth, including the following:&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A 3,000-year-old Ayurvedic way to clean teeth is to swish a tablespoon of oil (usually coconut, sesame, or olive oil) around your mouth for 20 minutes every morning. The coconut oil is said to stick to the oil in the cell membranes of any bacteria in your mouth, so when you spit it out, you are ridding your mouth of unwanted microorganisms.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Turns out there is no scientific evidence at all that “oil pulling,” as it’s called, will remove bacteria or whiten teeth.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The science of saturated fats&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;True believers, however, say there’s science to back up their claims.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Coconut oil is made by pressing the fat from the white “meat” inside the giant nut. About 84 percent of its calories come from saturated fat. Compare that to 14 percent of olive oil’s calories from saturated fat, and 63 percent of butter.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This explains why, like butter and lard, coconut oil is solid at room temperature with a long shelf life and the ability to withstand high cooking temperatures,” says registered dietitian Lisa Young, Ph.D.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Despite the fact that coconut oil is high in saturated fats, it’s made up mostly of medium-chain triglycerides, or MCTs, which some say the body handles differently than other fats.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;MCFAs, which always are saturated, are defined as having six to 12 carbons. Long-chain fatty acids (LCFAs) have more than 12 carbons and can be saturated or unsaturated.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The two behave differently in the body. Short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) and MCFAs are more easily absorbed than LCFAs because they're more water soluble.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When I was in school, coconut oil was big no-no because it was a saturated fat,” Blake recalled. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Now it’s popular again, although most professionals in the field don’t think much of it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Fans of coconut oil point to studies that suggest the MCT saturated fat in coconut could boost HDL (“good”) cholesterol. This, they claim, makes it not as bad for heart health than the saturated fat in foods like cheese and steak or products containing trans fats.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But it also raises your LDL (“bad”) cholesterol.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“But just because coconut oil can raise HDL cholesterol doesn't mean that it’s great for your heart,” Young said. “It’s not known if the rise in beneficial cholesterol outweighs any rise in harmful cholesterol.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s Freeman’s point.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He says there is no proof coconut oil does anything other than clog arteries.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He points to the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.heart.org/HEARTORG/HealthyLiving/HealthyEating/Nutrition/Saturated-Fats_UCM_301110_Article.jsp#.WJEuOUUrKlM&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;guidelines&lt;/a&gt; from the American Heart Association, which recommend saturated fat be limited to no more than 13 grams a day. That’s the amount found in about one tablespoon of coconut oil.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s not a recommended oil by any of the guidelines that I know of. In general, it can contribute to cardiovascular disease risk because of its very high saturated fat content,” Freeman said.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>

<pubdate>2017-02-01T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-02-01T10:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/coconut-oil-may-be-fattening
</guid>
<dc:creator>Roberta Alexander</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-02-01T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Can President Trump Really Reduce Prescription Drug Prices?
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/can-trump-reduce-drug-prices
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/011317_vatrump_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;
]]>
<![CDATA[
p&gt;Negotiating drug prices under the Medicare program.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Allowing more medications to be imported from other countries.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Speeding up the drug approval process.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Those are the basic tenets of President Donald Trump’s plan to reduce prescription drug prices in the United States.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The president reiterated some of those positions as well as unveiling a proposal to “streamline” the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) when he &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.politico.com/story/2017/01/trump-drug-pharmaceutical-manufacturing-234423&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;met Tuesday morning&lt;/a&gt; with pharmaceutical executives and lobbyists.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Trump took a more conciliatory tone with the pharmaceutical leaders than he did a couple weeks ago when he accused the industry of “&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-drugpricing-idUSKBN14V24J&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;getting away with murder&lt;/a&gt;.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After today’s meeting, both sides said they would work together to try to make drugs more affordable for consumers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For that to happen, there are two big questions facing the White House.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One is will Congress approve the president’s plans.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The second is will the plans work.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What the president proposes&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;During the 2016 presidential campaign, Trump advocated a plan to allow officials in the Medicare health program to negotiate drug prices with the pharmaceutical industry.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Current U.S. law prohibits such talks. Other countries, including Canada, France, and the United Kingdom, allow government officials to &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.huffingtonpost.com/socheata-poeuv/america-does-not-negotiat_b_5516353.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;negotiate drug prices&lt;/a&gt;. Some experts say that has kept prescription prices down in those countries.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Medicare covers more than 55 million older Americans. The Medicare and Medicaid systems spent &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cms.gov/research-statistics-data-and-systems/statistics-trends-and-reports/nationalhealthexpenddata/nhe-fact-sheet.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;$325 billion&lt;/a&gt; on prescription medicine in 2015.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Trump mentioned this proposal again during Tuesday’s meeting.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kurt Mosley, vice president of strategic alliances for Merritt Hawkins consultants, said this strategy could be an effective one.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It could bring pharmaceutical companies back to the table,” he told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;During the campaign, Trump also floated a plan to make it easier to import prescription drugs from other countries.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said this would increase competition and lower drug prices.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The president didn’t mention this plan specifically during Tuesday’s meeting, but he expressed interest in global trade and tax policy that he said could benefit U.S. drug manufacturers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We’re gonna be changing a lot of the rules. We’re going to be ending global freeloading,” Trump was quoted as saying by &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.politico.com/story/2017/01/trump-drug-pharmaceutical-manufacturing-234423&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Politico&lt;/a&gt;. “Foreign price controls reduce the resources of American drug companies to finance drug and R&amp;amp;D innovation.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;At least &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2017/1/31/14453740/trump-medicare-prescription-drugs&quot;&gt;one critic &lt;/a&gt;said the president had caved in to the pharmaceutical industry by backing off price negotiations and instead promising less regulation and lower taxes.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Others were more optimistic.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After the meeting, The Campaign for Sustainable Rx Pricing (CSRxP) &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.csrxp.org/csrxp-applauds-trump-administrations-focus-on-lowering-prescription-drug-prices/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;applauded&lt;/a&gt; the president’s focus on reducing drug prices.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Rodney Whitlock, vice president of health policy at ML Strategies, and a consultant to CSRxP, told Healthline this week that changes such as the Medicare negotiations and the import rules could have an impact.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The ones on the table are very significant steps,” Whitlock said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On Tuesday, the president also discussed an overhaul of the FDA drug approval process.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said he’ll be naming an FDA commissioner soon who will streamline the agency.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Trump also expressed an interest in possibly allowing some drugs to be approved before they’ve been proven safe, according to Politico.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We're gonna be getting rid of regulations that are unnecessary, big league,” the president said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The FDA recorded &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.fda.gov/Drugs/DevelopmentApprovalProcess/DrugInnovation/ucm483775.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;22 “novel drug” approvals&lt;/a&gt; in 2016, down from &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.fda.gov/Drugs/DevelopmentApprovalProcess/DrugInnovation/ucm430302.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;45 approvals&lt;/a&gt; in 2015.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mosley told Healthline last week that quicker approvals, especially for generic drugs, could boost the free market.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The president can do a lot of things,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What else can be done&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Whitlock said CSRxP would like to see the president and Congress go even further.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;His organization calls for &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.csrxp.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;transparency, competition, and value&lt;/a&gt; in the pharmaceutical industry.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Whitlock said one of the key ways to boost transparency is for drug companies to disclose how much they have spent on research and development for specific medications.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said that would let the public know when these companies have recouped their costs on drug development.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said that could prevent hikes such as last year’s increase in &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/cost-of-epipens-forcing-allergy-sufferers-to-syringes&quot;&gt;EpiPen prices&lt;/a&gt; or the 2014 leap for the hepatitis C drug &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/new-hepatitis-c-drug-stirs-controversy-041114&quot;&gt;Solvadi&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It could produce some self-moderating of prices,” Whitlock said. “We want to try to create market-based solutions.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another tactic CSRxP is pushing involves hearings later this year on user fees the pharmaceutical company pays the FDA to review their drugs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Whitlock said Congress could use this reauthorization as leverage to force the pharmaceutical industry to make changes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Officials at the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America (PhRMA) think the solutions lie in ensuring patients have access to medications and instituting more “patient-centered care.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In an email to Healthline, officials at PhRMA noted their industry spends more than $70 billion a year in research and development of drugs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Breakthrough medicines are revolutionizing how we treat disease, saving patient lives, reducing healthcare costs, and improving public health,” the statement read. “Today, medicines are purchased in a competitive marketplace where large, sophisticated purchasers aggressively negotiate lower prices.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The industry association said it intends to work with the federal government in the coming years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We look forward to working with the administration and Congress to advance proactive, practical solutions to improve the marketplace and make it more responsive to the needs of patients,” the association stated.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The organization has launched a $100 million multiyear advertising campaign called &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.phrma.org/press-release/america-s-biopharmaceutical-companies-launch-groundbreaking-multi-year-initiative-heralding-new-era-of-medicine&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;GO&lt;strong&gt;BOLDLY&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/a&gt; to showcase what it calls “the industry’s unsung heroes driving cutting-edge advances in science.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, CSRxP officials see this as nothing more than a distraction from the industry’s price gouging.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“No amount of advertising will make hardworking families forget the consequences of their out-of-control drug costs,” a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.csrxp.org/csrxp-on-phrmas-multimillion-dollar-pr-campaign/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;statement&lt;/a&gt; on the group’s website says.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Whitlock added that getting changes through Congress could be difficult given that the pharmaceutical industry has one of the top three largest lobbying groups in Washington.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s an uphill battle, but it’s a battle worth fighting,” he said.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Public Policy</category>
<pubdate>2017-01-31T15:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-01-31T15:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/can-trump-reduce-drug-prices
</guid>
<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-01-31T23:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Experimental Treatment Provides Hope for Infants with Cancer
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/hope-for-infants-with-cancer
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/childrens-health/092016_childrencancer_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;An experimental treatment has saved the lives of two infants with difficult to treat leukemia.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The two children, 11 and 16 months old, each experienced complete cancer remission within 28 days of receiving treatment. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Diagnosed with B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), both infants had exhausted all other treatment options.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;ALL is an aggressive type of cancer that begins in immature white blood cells called lymphocytes. Without treatment, ALL can be fatal within months.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cancer.org/cancer/leukemia-in-children/detection-diagnosis-staging/prognostic-factors.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;American Cancer Society&lt;/a&gt;, children with B-cell ALL who are between the ages of 1 and 9 have better cure rates. Infants under 1 year old tend to have a poorer outlook.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The two infants given the experimental treatment have both been cancer-free for more than a year. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The research was published in &lt;a href=&quot;http://stm.sciencemag.org/content/9/374/eaaj2013.full&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Science Translational Medicine&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;How T cell treatment works&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;When other methods such as chemotherapy don’t work, there’s a newer leukemia treatment that involves using a patient’s own T cells. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The T cells are removed and manipulated with chimeric antigen receptors (CARs) that instruct them to attack ALL cells. Then they’re returned to the patient’s blood. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, most infants during their first year haven’t developed enough healthy T cells.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Waseem Qasim, professor of cell and gene therapy at Great Ormond Street Institute of Child Health, University College in London, and his colleagues, wanted to find a solution to this problem.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Unable to get enough T cells from the infants, they decided to use donor blood.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Through gene editing, they created functional T cells that could evade immune system attacks in unmatched recipients. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The T cells were then infused into the infants’ blood.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Two months after the procedure, one infant developed mild graft-versus-host disease in the skin. It cleared up following a bone marrow transplant and steroid treatment. The other infant had no complications.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s the first time doctors have ever treated cancer with altered T cells from a donor. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The doctors showed it’s possible to create universal, or “off-the-shelf,” therapies from altered donor T cells. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The experiment could lead to big advances in hard to treat ALL.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The promise of off-the-shelf T cells &lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;With no need to match patients with donors, patients could be treated more quickly and more efficiently. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Engineered T cells are the most important story in difficult to treat leukemias and lymphomas,” said medical oncologist Dr. Jack Jacoub in an interview with Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“A lot of progress has been made in this type of treatment. It’s an area that has excellent promise and definitely needs to be considered,” said Jacoub, the director of thoracic oncology at &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.memorialcare.org/services/cancer-care/cancer-care-orange-coast-memorial&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;MemorialCare Cancer Institute&lt;/a&gt; at Orange Coast Memorial Medical Center in California.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This type of lymphoblastic leukemia is a very bad disease,” he added. “There’s often little to be lost. This is the case with these two infants. They were provided therapy on a compassionate basis. All other therapies failed, so there was nothing to lose. They would have succumbed to this illness.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The paper’s authors suggest there are limitations in getting lymphocytes in young patients. They have a less mature immune system. They don’t have enough T cells, and that’s a problem,” said Jacoub.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The authors are implying we don’t need to go to the patient or have a donor. We don’t need either route,” he explained.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Next steps for researchers&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;“In these two infants, they’ve showed they can do it,” said Jacoub. “It’s only two [patients] and they tried it because there was nothing else. But it’s not even a phase I trial structure.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Jacoub notes that the paper was published in a small journal that may not be widely received throughout the field of hematology. He’s fairly certain, however, that this paper is on the radar of scientists involved in the field.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Also worthy of note is the small sample size. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We don’t know how the next patients will do. This is just an observation, but an exciting one that must be expanded,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Jacoub suggests the need for more collaboration with larger institutions with research infrastructure, more of these types of patients, and the expertise to manage this disease. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Whether it will go to phase I trial is a big leap. It will have to involve more than one institution. Right now, it’s just an observation of two patients. We won’t be rushing out to try to do this now, but this is how things start,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Jacoub sees a lot of potential in this type of treatment. But there’s a long way to go.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The U.K. trial would have to be reproducible in the United States to see if this is feasible. With more scientific scrutiny and oversight — if we can reproduce it — it could be enormous. Barriers would be overcome,” he said. “They’re taking available technology a few extra steps. The technology is there. If it really was a true effect and can be reproduced in different settings and countries, it could lead to widely available therapeutic options. If this observation could be accurately reproduced, we’ll probably know in the next year or two. That’s how fast this field moves.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Jacoub said this is exciting news for patients and their families. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s not widely available or the current standard of care. But families of these patients are usually medically savvy,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He’s all for families bringing it up with their physicians.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s OK if their doctor hasn’t seen this published report. Copies of this journal may not go everywhere. Usually these things happen in collaboration. Emails to scientists and institutions start discussions. So they should definitely bring it up.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Cancer</category>
<pubdate>2017-01-31T13:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-01-31T13:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/hope-for-infants-with-cancer
</guid>
<dc:creator>Ann Pietrangelo</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-01-31T21:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Is There a Gender Bias Against Female Pain Patients?
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/gender-bias-against-female-pain-patients
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/womens-health/012017_girlsheart_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&
]]>
<![CDATA[
lt;p&gt;Do medical professionals treat women differently when it comes to painful ailments?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some people sure think so.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Others aren’t convinced.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Although there is evidence to support an unconscious gender bias against women — especially in emergency room or pain management settings — there are also many people who say that such a bias doesn’t exist. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;An October 2015 article in &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2015/10/emergency-room-wait-times-sexism/410515/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;The Atlantic&lt;/a&gt; gained a lot of traction in the discussion surrounding gender bias in healthcare.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It was titled “How Doctors Take Women’s Pain Less Seriously.” The article provided a first-person account from a husband who observed the way his wife was being treated in a hospital setting.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The op-ed essay stated, “Women are likely to be treated less aggressively until they prove that they are as sick as male patients.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another article titled &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/17/opinion/sunday/women-and-the-treatment-of-pain.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;The Gender Gap in Pain&lt;/a&gt; was also widely circulated.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It was originally published in 2013 in the New York Times, and concluded that “pain conditions are a particularly good example of the interplay between sex (our biological and chromosomal differences) and gender (the cultural roles and expectations attributed to a person).”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Sexism in medicine?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Beyond individual stories, there are also studies that conclude the possibility that this gender bias does exist.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the early 2000s, a study by the University of Maryland Francis King Carey School of Law was published in &lt;a href=&quot;https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=383803&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;SSRN&lt;/a&gt;. The study, called “The Girl Who Cried Pain: A Bias Against Women in the Treatment of Pain,” attempted to identify why it was that women seemed to “report more severe levels of pain, more frequent incidences of pain, and pain of longer duration than men, but are nonetheless treated for pain less aggressively.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study stated, “… not only that men and women communicate differently to healthcare providers about their pain, but that healthcare providers may respond differently to them.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This study found that female patients more likely to have their pain described as emotional or psychogenic.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;div class=&quot;hl-poll&quot; style=&quot;float:right; margin:10px;&quot;&gt;&lt;script type=&quot;text/javascript&quot; charset=&quot;utf-8&quot; src=&quot;http://static.polldaddy.com/p/9652131.js&quot;&gt;&lt;/script&gt; &lt;noscript&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://polldaddy.com/poll/9652131/&quot;&gt;Do you think medical professionals treat women differently?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/noscript&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;p&gt;The bias — although it may be an implicit or unintentional one — seems to be particularly pronounced in emergency settings.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Heart disease is the number one killer of women in the United States. In addition, experts say that many times women experience &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/heart-disease/in-depth/heart-disease/art-20046167&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;different symptoms&lt;/a&gt; of a heart attack than men. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In general, the consensus among documented patient experiences and the studies presented, is that often women, while more likely to report symptoms to a doctor, are often viewed as more emotional than men.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Avoiding the pain&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;This isn’t to diminish men’s experience with pain.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One rheumatologist, who didn’t want his name used, told Healthline that most doctors don’t like treating people with chronic pain at all, regardless of sex.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Pain is complex, hard to treat, and there aren’t a lot of good answers on how to best manage pain in people with chronic pain.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Still, taking the general stigma against people with chronic pain out of consideration, women seem to face &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/opioids-problems-for-chronic-pain-patients&quot;&gt;more skepticism or indifference&lt;/a&gt; when it comes to their symptoms than men do given the same circumstances.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Women report doctors being condescending or &lt;a href=&quot;https://psmag.com/is-medicine-s-gender-bias-killing-young-women-4cab6946ab5c#.irqdgft58&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;not taking symptoms seriously&lt;/a&gt;. Sometimes women say they are told their symptoms are all in their heads — a refrain that doesn’t seem to always translate to men’s healthcare experiences.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92516/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2011 Institute of Medicine report&lt;/a&gt; on the public health impact of chronic pain found that not only did women seem to suffer more often from pain, but they also had a higher pain tolerance. Nonetheless, the study concluded that women’s reports of pain were more likely to be dismissed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This can be problematic, since pain is self-reported and is relatively subjective. To properly treat and control pain, doctors have to trust that the person is describing pain accurately and in a trustworthy manner.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Gender bias against women is not solely an American phenomenon nor is it only “sexist” male doctors. This is bias that may potentially exist on a global scale, coming from both male and female healthcare providers. It can play a role in many situations from emergency care to &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.huffingtonpost.com/soraya-chemaly/how-sexism-and-implicit-bias-hurt-girls-and-womens-health_b_7736866.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;childbirth&lt;/a&gt; and OB-GYN care to chronic pain management. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Simply put, according to Dr. Mary O’Connor of the Mayo Clinic in a 2015 &lt;a href=&quot;https://myheartsisters.org/2013/08/27/unconscious-bias/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;blog post&lt;/a&gt;, “Women do not always receive the same medical care as men.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This “built-in bias” can create more serious problems in an emergency room.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What do patients think?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;A survey of 2,400 women conducted by the &lt;a href=&quot;http://nationalpainreport.com/women-in-pain-report-significant-gender-bias-8824696.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;National Pain Report&lt;/a&gt; concluded that 90 percent of women with chronic pain feel the healthcare system discriminates against women.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;About 65 percent of respondents felt that doctors of either gender took their pain less seriously simply because they were women. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Amiee Lesko of Pennsylvania, told Healthline, “My PCP is a woman, been seeing her for 10ish years. She's younger and the absolute best. She takes time to listen and never discounts any of my thoughts, feelings, or complaints. I totally trust her opinion. When I had a health scare in 2015, I had seen a handful of physicians, all male. They all brushed my complaints off as ‘mental’ since they couldn't see anything. I basically felt like brushed off as a ‘silly girl.’ Now when I'm looking for a specialist, I always try to find a female provider first.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lauren Karcher, another Pennsylvania resident, had similar experiences but noted not all doctors treat young women this way.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It depends on the doctor I think ... but I have been treated by specific ones in a manner that they felt I had no idea what I was talking about and refused to listen to me,” she told Healthline. “My mom went with me to an appointment and even said to the doctor, ‘I don't feel like you are taking her very seriously.’ He said, ‘Look at her, she is smiling and bubbly, how could she be in so much pain?’… I am always smiling and bubbly, even when I'm pain, that’s just me.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Tami H., who lives with rheumatoid arthritis, told Healthline, “I'm not able to speak for others. However, I have felt and seen the discrimination in doctors’ offices and the work force. My personal experiences have made me leery of new doctors and nurses … and God forbid I have to go to the ER! That’s more frustrating than just putting up with whatever is wrong with me.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These women aren’t alone.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Alice Sparks of Florida is living with psoriatic arthritis. She told Healthline, “There is absolutely a gender bias. The typical stereotype is that women overreact to pain and symptoms while men do not seek medical care until it is absolutely the final measure. I can look back, prior to my diagnosis, when I presented with classic symptoms and was told that it was ‘stress’ or ‘depression.’” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lucy Bowen of Texas said that in her situations, going with a female doctor helped. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I purposely chose a female rheumatologist to treat my pain to bypass this issue,” Bowen told Healthline. “It has made a world of difference. I used to feel like I had to justify what I was feeling but now there is so much less pressure.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This feeling of being judged or talked down to can leave some women feeling mistrustful of, or intimidated, by their doctors. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some male patients say they have noticed a bias against women.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I can't tell you that I know this to be true. However, I have listened to many ladies talk about how their doctor doesn't seem to believe the intensity of their pain,” Jose Velarde, an advocate living with rheumatoid arthritis, told Healthline. “I have seen three rheumatologists, a pain specialist, and my GP. Not once has anyone suggested I wasn't in the pain I say I'm in. Not once have they questioned my need for the pain meds.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But some people say they don’t see any discrimination or differences in treatment or care.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Tavie George, who has juvenile rheumatoid arthritis, told Healthline, “This question of gender bias against women kind of made me laugh because I always think female doctors are way more rude than male doctors … I think being young has been more of a discrimination against me than being a female. I also have received discrimination over having Medicare and Medicaid at such a young age.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I do think,” she added, “women in general have an emotional habit of getting their feelings hurt in unneeded situations when they are in pain, emotional or physical.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Lindsay Paige Tonner, who has rheumatoid arthritis, told Healthline, “Bias hasn't been the case for me. I've been treated with care and respect throughout from both male and female doctors. Having said that I have been told that if I say I'm in a lot of pain then I really must be as I have had a baby so know what I'm talking about.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What do professionals think?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Women are seen as less pain tolerant, but actually I see the opposite in prehospital medicine. Men always ask for pain meds while women seem to wait to ask. Maybe women have the general thought process that we will think they are whiners or med seekers and abusers,” DeNell S., a healthcare worker, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Brenda Unhajer, a nurse from Pennsylvania, told Healthline, “From the other side of the bed, I can tell you there is a gender bias in healthcare. In an acute versus chronic situation, many women having acute chest pain are often overlooked and given anti-anxiety medications before receiving treatment, or in addition to, being worked up for a cardiac problem.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She continued, “One of the biggest frustrations I face as a provider [non-physician] is the ‘golden standard.’ While we promote individualized care, it's far from that. Evidence-based practice has changed a lot of things for the good, but treatment-wise, I think it's hindered a lot from the physicians' standpoint.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Carrie Wood of Pennsylvania disagreed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I’ve worked in the ER for six years and I can say I never treated or saw a patient treated differently for their gender,” she told Healthline. “We treated based on facts, tests, and symptoms, and there were at least 10 different providers. Nor have I ever been treated differently in my healthcare field because I am a woman.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But she added that this may vary from person to person or institution to institution.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As cultural norms shift and gender identities and values are challenged, this may continue to be a topic of conversation. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Medical schools are beginning to address the nuances of gender in healthcare and also teach med students about &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.jointcommission.org/assets/1/23/Quick_Safety_Issue_23_Apr_2016.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;implicit bias&lt;/a&gt;, whether against women, people of color, or the LGBTQ community.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
