<pubdate>2017-01-31T11:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-01-31T11:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/gender-bias-against-female-pain-patients
</guid>
<dc:creator>Ashley Boynes-Shuck</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-01-31T19:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Insecticides Can Increase Your Risk for Diabetes and Other Ailments
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/insecticides-increase-diabetes-and-other-ailments
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/010715_dietguidelines_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Gardening may not be on the minds of most Americans as cold temperatures continue to persist across much of the country.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But when the warmer temperatures move in and everyone wants to get outside, making sure to use safe lawn and garden products is important. The chemicals found in some of those products can be harmful to your health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acs.chemrestox.6b00301&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; published last month in Chemical Research in Toxicology&lt;em&gt; &lt;/em&gt;found that chemicals in some gardening products and insecticides can affect melatonin receptors and put humans at a higher risk for metabolic diseases, including diabetes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Exposure to these chemicals could put people at higher risk for diabetes and also affect circadian rhythms,” Rajendram Rajnarayanan, Ph.D., an assistant professor at the University at Buffalo in New York who served on the research team, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This is the first report demonstrating how environmental chemicals found in household products interact with human melatonin receptors,” Margarita L. Dubocovich, Ph.D., a professor at the University at Buffalo in New York, said in a statement.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dubocovich is a renowned authority on melatonin receptor regulation. Her work has expanded the understanding of how melatonin affects human health, including sleep disorders, metabolic disease, and drug addiction.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Looking at toxic chemicals&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Carbaryl, a popular insecticide used in the United States, but banned in several countries, is one of the chemicals in the study. It has been linked to &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/wide-range-of-pesticides-contribute-to-dwindling-bee-population-101315#2&quot;&gt;declining bee populations&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The study’s other chemical, carbofuran, is a toxic carbamate insecticide that has been banned for use on food crops in the United States since 2009, but is still used in many countries, including Mexico.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We found that both insecticides are structurally similar to melatonin and that both showed affinity for the melatonin MT2 receptors that can potentially affect glucose homeostasis and insulin secretion,” said Marina Popovska-Gorevski, who co-authored the study while a student at the University at Buffalo. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“That means that exposure to them could put people at higher risk for diabetes and also affect sleeping patterns,” Popovska-Gorevski said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As of now, federal agencies do not assess environmental chemicals for their ability to disrupt circadian activity — something highlighting the importance of this study, Rajnarayanan added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Other disrupters lurk&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;These aren’t the only chemicals that can affect the human body, though.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Rajnarayanan said Bisphenol A (BPA) and DDT are known to disrupt the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.niehs.nih.gov/health/topics/agents/endocrine/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;endocrine system&lt;/a&gt; and even cause cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Some of the insecticides do tend to persist in the environment and have the potential to bypass metabolism and chemical breakdown,” he said. “Exposure to these chemicals does more harm than those that are broken down chemically or by our body rapidly.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0269749114002802&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2014 study&lt;/a&gt; in Environmental Pollution&lt;em&gt; &lt;/em&gt;found insecticides known as neonicotinoids (similar to nicotine) that were used on soy and corn crops were commonly found in streams throughout the Midwest.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That same year, a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.neurology.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;paper&lt;/a&gt; published in Neurology reported on &lt;a href=&quot;/aging-pesticide-exposure-tied-to-parkinsons-risk-020314#2&quot;&gt;11 pesticides&lt;/a&gt; that increase a person’s likelihood of developing Parkinson’s disease by up to six times.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another article in &lt;a href=&quot;http://archneur.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1816015&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Neurology&lt;/a&gt; linked DDT exposure to an increased risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease. A year earlier, an Environmental Health Perspectives report linked the chemical to &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/women-exposure-to-pesticides-increases-endometriosis-risk-110513&quot;&gt;endometriosis&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2015, more research tied these chemicals to &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/long-banned-pesticides-still-causing-men-to-produce-mutant-sperm-110415#2&quot;&gt;infertility&lt;/a&gt; and low sperm count.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Pinpointing pesticides&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Rajnarayanan said his team is developing a test that could detect environmental toxicity and circadian disruption activity to establish potential health risks of other chemicals they have compiled into a database.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;His study was funded to pinpoint new environmental diabetogens (chemicals that can cause diabetes) and obesogens (chemicals that can cause obesity). Research on them is “a relatively new research area,” he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Don’t be afraid to tend to your garden, but do keep an eye on labels. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Not all insecticides are bad for us,” Rajnarayanan said. “However it is imperative to study the chemicals that are extensively in use, especially the ones that can get into our air, food, and water.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Using organic products could be an alternative to harmful chemicals, but they may not be as effective for extensive farming practices.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;John F. Tooker, Ph.D., an associate professor at Penn State College of Agricultural Sciences, said some data show things like spiders can do a good job controlling pest insects in crop fields. This is part of the practice known as integrated pest management.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The main way to do that is to avoid unnecessary insecticide applications,” he told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Rajnarayanan said that scientists can provide data and examine risks, but regulators and policy makers will need to get involved to advise people on risk factors.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Food and Nutrition</category>
<pubdate>2017-01-30T15:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-01-30T15:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/insecticides-increase-diabetes-and-other-ailments
</guid>
<dc:creator>Kristen Fischer</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-01-30T23:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Cancer Clinical Trial Does Wonders for Ground Zero Rescue Worker
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/cancer-trial-does-wonders-for-ground-zero-worker
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/cancer/Bart_Zagami_with_grandkids.jpeg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;
]]>
<![CDATA[
p&gt;In the days following the terrorist attack in New York on Sept. 11, 2001, Bart Zagami spent his time at Ground Zero helping with the task of rescue and recovery.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Zagami, 61, a New York State Supreme Court sergeant at the time, was in his office just blocks from the World Trade Center in lower Manhattan when the terrorists struck. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The next few days were something he will never forget.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The whole area was covered in debris,&quot; he told Healthline. &quot;Gigantic piles of dust and rebar was what we were on, passing buckets. Please don't make it sound heroic. We did what we did.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nine years after the attacks, as he was about to retire, Zagami was diagnosed with stage 4 marginal zone lymphoma, a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma for which there were few effective treatments.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Zagami didn’t know it at the time, but his cancer was likely caused by his exposure to the enormous amount of toxins that filled the air at Ground Zero for weeks and months after the terrorist attacks.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;A rough treatment road&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cancer was a difficult thing to face as he began his retirement. But Zagami, a New York native who still lives around the corner from the Brooklyn house where he was born, was ready for the fight.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But in 2014, he learned that he was allergic to Rituxan, the successful monoclonal antibody drug used to treat lymphoma.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It was his only remaining treatment option approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), other than chemotherapy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;About six months after his last Rituxan treatment, Zagami had an MRI that showed his spleen was getting larger.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It continued to grow, to the point where it took up his entire midsection and weighed more than 8 pounds. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;After having his spleen surgically removed, Zagami recovered again, started exercising, and began feeling better. But within a year, his blood levels were unhealthy again.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Taking a chance with a clinical trial&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Zagami’s future was uncertain. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But then his doctors at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York told him about an experimental treatment with a drug called ibrutinib.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They said it held great promise for his type of cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ibrutinib, the generic name for the drug Imbruvica, is an oral therapy that inhibits the function of Bruton's tyrosine kinase (BTK), a target for therapy of B cell diseases that includes several types of lymphoma. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The drug, which was developed by Pharmacyclics LLC, an AbbVie company, and Janssen Biotech Inc., causes fewer side effects than traditional chemo because fewer healthy cells are damaged.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When Zagami’s doctors told him about the treatment, it had not yet been approved by the FDA for his type of cancer. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Doctors couldn’t offer Zagami any guarantees that the drug would work on him. But they showed him the positive early data. And he embraced the opportunity. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Enrolling in the clinical trial was an easy decision for Zagami to make. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“My doctors were confident that this drug could help me,” he said. “There was no nervousness. It sounded better than the alternative.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Better results than anticipated&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;During the trial, which consisted of a daily dose of four pills, Zagami had few side effects.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Just some blistering on his skin and minor bone and body aches, both of which were temporary. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Blood tests showed his body was responding positively to the medication.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Today, more than two years later, Zagami is doing well.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He continues to take the drug every day — three pills now instead of four.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While he may never be in complete remission due to his type of cancer, he has what is referred to as a partial but durable remission. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;His blood counts remain normal. He’s back to working out with weights and walking five miles a day.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I’m not sick anymore. I feel terrific,” Zagami said. “I get up in the morning and work out with weights every day, then I read the newspapers online, go for five-mile walk, and go shopping. My wife still works. Three days a week I watch my two granddaughters.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;More clinic trial options available&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;While clinical trials like the one Zagami opted for have always been an important part of cancer care in America, they’ve become an option for more people than ever before.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There are so many new treatments now in the pipeline, everything from targeted therapies like ibrutinib to immunotherapies. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And the risk factors that once scared patients away from clinical trials seem to be diminishing.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Patients are becoming increasingly aware that this new generation of cancer treatments is moving away from the traditional chemotherapy model, and they are often more effective than anything patients have seen in the past.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They are generally safer than drugs of the previous generation, although some are still accompanied by serious but typically short-lived side effects.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Last week, the FDA &lt;a href=&quot;https://news.abbvie.com/news/us-fda-approves-imbruvica-ibrutinib-as-first-treatment-specifically-indicated-for-relapsedrefractory-marginal-zone-lymphoma-mzl--rare-type-non-hodgkins-lymphoma.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;announced&lt;/a&gt; that because of the positive responses to ibrutinib in people with MZL, like Zagami and others in the Sloan Kettering trial, the agency has granted “accelerated approval” for the drug for this type of cancer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Ariela Noy, a hematologic oncologist at Sloan Kettering, and lead investigator of the study, told Healthline that “Imbruvica’s approval helps fill a significant treatment gap for previously treated MZL patients who will benefit from a targeted therapy rather than a traditional chemotherapy.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Darrin Beaupre, head of early development and immunotherapy at Pharmacyclics LLC, added, “Imbruvica’s approval for patients with MZL is significant. Now patients have the option of a well-tolerated, effective treatment in a disease that had no prior approved therapies.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Ground Zero cancer legacy&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;For Zagami, who’ll be allowed to continue the clinical trial for two more years despite the fact that the drug has now been approved for MZL, his cancer has taken on an even deeper meaning. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The thick dust that covered Zagami and tens of thousands of others who worked at Ground Zero in the days after 9/11 held a mixture of toxins and irritants.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These include asbestos, polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), benzene, dioxin, glass fibers, gypsum, cement particles, heavy metals such as lead, and more.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In January 2011, less than a year after Zagami was diagnosed with lymphoma, President Barack Obama signed into law the James Zadroga 9/11 Health and Compensation Act of 2010.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Zadroga Act created the World Trade Center Health Program, which covers medical expenses for a list of more than 90 conditions linked to exposure at Ground Zero, including multiple types of lymphoma and leukemia.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As of June 2016, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the WTC Health Program reported an enrollment of more than 5,400 people who have been diagnosed with cancers linked to the 9/11 attacks.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While his cancer was probably caused by the exposure, Zagami didn’t initially file a claim.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In fact, he’s been private about his cancer diagnosis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I didn’t tell anyone anything, I kept it a secret,” said Zagami, who has two children and two grandchildren. “Only my wife and kids knew, but the rest of my family didn’t. Both of my parents are still alive and they’re elderly. I didn’t want them to worry about me. I was doing well. But now they know.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Zagami said he finally decided recently to file a claim with the WTC Health Program.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Some people I worked with got sick. I didn’t want to, but people told me to do it, so I filed a claim,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But Zagami added that if he could go back in time and was given the option of not volunteering at Ground Zero, he would still do it again.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Treating other cancers&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Meanwhile, people with a number of different cancers have benefitted from ibrutinib.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Its approval last week for MZL is just the latest breakthrough for this drug.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition to MZL, ibrutinib has also been approved to treat people with:&lt;/p&gt; &lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL), including people with 17p deletion.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) in people who have received at least one prior therapy&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia (WM), another type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt; &lt;p&gt;Janssen, which has the rights to the drug outside the United States, is also expanding its use in Europe.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Janssen announced last May that the European Commission (EC) approved the drug for all patients with CLL, expanding the number of people who may benefit from this treatment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Janssen also expects to introduce the drug to people with lymphoma sometime later this year in &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/campaign-launches-to-battle-cancer-crisis-in-china-012516&quot;&gt;China&lt;/a&gt;, where lymphoma is on the rise.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Marginal zone lymphoma is China’s second most common type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, following diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL), multiple cancer researchers and industry observers in China told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There is currently no standard treatment in China for these people. But sources tell Healthline that physicians in China took notice of the news that ibrutinib was approved by the FDA for people in the United States with MZL.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Janssen has submitted ibrutinib for approval in China and asked that the drug get priority review due to better efficacy than what is currently available. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The company is working with the national cancer community in China and patient advocates to inform people with lymphoma about their treatment options. The national cancer community is waiting until the drug is officially approved by China authorities.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Meanwhile, Zagami said the drug was a lifesaver for him.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think with ibrutinib, it just made my cancer a manageable disease,” he said. “The same way people take blood pressure medication to make that manageable.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Cancer</category>
<pubdate>2017-01-30T11:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-01-30T11:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/cancer-trial-does-wonders-for-ground-zero-worker
</guid>
<dc:creator>Jamie Reno</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-01-30T19:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Can We Make Food Truck Menus Healthier?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/can-we-make-food-trucks-healthier
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/766x415_food_truck.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p
]]>
<![CDATA[
&gt;Maybe you prefer a food truck classic like a Philly cheesesteak.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Or something a little southern, like brown sugar marinated fried chicken drowning in bacon gravy.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Whatever your tastes, you’re sure to find something to thrill your palate at one of the thousands of food trucks across the country.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While you’re reveling in spicy sauces and meaty juices, though, consider the finer details of your on-the-go meal.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Most foods you’re getting when you go out to eat are not going to have the right balance of nutrients,” Dr. Deborah Cohen, physician scientist at RAND Corporation, told Healthline. “They are going to have too many calories, too much salt, too much sugar, and too much fat.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This is as true for food trucks as it is for restaurants.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With some exceptions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At Matcha Konomi, a food truck in Corpus Christi, Texas, customers line up for healthy favorites like matcha green tea latte and avocado toast.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Owner Michelle Fraedrick started the business when she realized most fast food options around town didn’t match her dietary preferences.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Eating healthy and eating ‘real food’ is something I am very passionate about,” Fraedrick told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Many public health officials would no doubt love to see a few more Matcha Konomis around the country. But they’d probably settle for food trucks offering one or two healthy meals alongside their best sellers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Which is what Cohen and her colleagues attempted in Los Angeles, where thousands of licensed and unlicensed food trucks — known as “loncheras” — serve up tasty meals to hungry customers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The big question is: Would food truck operators bite?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Study encourages healthier meals&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the end, Cohen’s team found 11 food trucks willing to participate in the study.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These few were “a forward-looking group, a progressive group of loncheras,” said Cohen. “They agreed that the customers they serve need to eat healthier.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Food truck operators worked with nutritionists to create meals that met &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.choosemyplate.gov/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;MyPlate&lt;/a&gt; guidelines for recommended amounts of protein, vegetables, and fruit. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Study workers helped the food trucks market these meals to customers, using the name “La Comida Perfecta” — the perfect meal.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Fraedrick thinks there is untapped need for nutritious fast food.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;div class=&quot;hl-poll&quot; style=&quot;float:right; margin:10px;&quot;&gt;&lt;script type=&quot;text/javascript&quot; charset=&quot;utf-8&quot; src=&quot;http://static.polldaddy.com/p/9649285.js&quot;&gt;&lt;/script&gt; &lt;noscript&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://polldaddy.com/poll/9649285/&quot;&gt;How often do you eat at a food truck?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/noscript&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I truly believe people are trying to move away from unhealthy foods — or at least eating them daily — and trying to find healthy alternatives,” she said. “More food trucks should have at least one healthy option on the menu for those looking to stick to their health goals.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Food truck operators also received a small subsidy for participating in the study as well as $2 coupons to encourage customers to buy these healthier meals.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Although the healthier meals accounted for only 2 percent of the trucks’ overall sales by the end of the study, they were still a hit.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When people tried these new dishes, they liked them,” said Cohen. “The majority really liked them.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Still, even with the extra marketing of the healthy meals, customers tended to stick with “the usual.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We found the majority of people were following their habits, and ordering the same thing all the time,” said Cohen. “So if we want people to make changes, sometimes they need to be nudged to try something new.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Given the low number of food truck operators who volunteered for the study, this may require cities and towns to motivate food trucks to offer healthier meals.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Communities that are concerned about the health of their residents should take steps to make sure that when people go out to eat, they’re not being put at risk of chronic disease,” said Cohen.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/public-health-nutrition/article/div-classtitlecan-latino-food-trucks-loncheras-serve-healthy-meals-a-feasibility-studydiv/4B5B118023A3C0A791B7F731CBC7E102&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; was published online this month in the journal Public Health Nutrition.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Shaping eating habits&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other research shows the potential of using food trucks to steer people toward healthier eating habits.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/Pcd/issues/2012/11_0222.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Researchers&lt;/a&gt; in Oakland, Calif., brought a food truck that sells fresh, precut, and bagged fruit — known as a “frutero” — to an elementary school campus.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Local regulations sometimes prohibit mobile food vendors — even those offering only healthy foods — from selling near schools and parks.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The frutero outside the school — which competed with nearby ice cream and cotton candy vendors — did a brisk business. The truck sold almost 18 bags of fruits and vegetables each afternoon in about half an hour.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A similar effort in &lt;a href=&quot;http://amarillo.com/news/latest-news/2016-08-31/big-mac-hits-road&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Texas&lt;/a&gt;, spearheaded by the Amarillo Independent School District, provides high school students with healthy food truck meals, at the same cost as meals in the school cafeteria.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Other programs use food trucks to bring healthy food to where it’s most needed.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.timesherald.com/article/JR/20170103/BUSINESS/170109973&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Philadelphia&lt;/a&gt;, food trucks visit local schools with bins filled with growing vegetables that students can try.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One goal of the program, which is sponsored by nonprofit Greener Partners, is to teach children about growing and cooking healthy fruits and vegetables. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.wlwt.com/article/truck-loaded-with-fresh-produce-rolls-into-cincinnati-s-food-deserts/3567529 target=&quot;&gt;Cincinnati&lt;/a&gt;, a “grocery store produce section on wheels” visits “food deserts” in the city — areas that lack fresh fruit, vegetables, and other healthy whole foods.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The program is sponsored by health system TriHealth. Its goal is to feed 250 families each week in 10 neighborhoods.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Whether food trucks are selling to eager customers or building an oasis of fresh fruit and vegetables in a food desert, there’s potential for them to transform the country’s food environment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This matters, because healthy eating is not just about willpower.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If we want people to be healthier, we have to stop wagging our fingers at individuals,” said Cohen, “and look at the environment, look at what people are faced with, and do something about that before we start blaming people.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Tell us in the comments what your favorite food truck meals are.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Food and Nutrition</category>
<pubdate>2017-01-27T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-01-27T12:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/can-we-make-food-trucks-healthier
</guid>
<dc:creator>Shawn Radcliffe</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-01-27T20:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Researchers Say They May Have a New Way to Attack Alzheimer’s
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/new-way-to-attack-alzheimers
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/080816_alzheimers_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Scientists at a prominent research facility say they have uncovered a new way of attacking Alzheimer’s disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The process, they say, may someday lead to the development of drugs that could prevent, and even reverse, the effects of the deadly brain disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The research was funded by the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.alzinfo.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Fisher Center for Alzheimer’s Research Foundation&lt;/a&gt; and was conducted by the organization’s scientists at &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.rockefeller.edu/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;The Rockefeller University&lt;/a&gt; in New York.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2017/01/17/1620963114.abstract&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;findings&lt;/a&gt; were published this week in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Scientists were quick to point out the research is in its early stages, and the development of an effective drug could be years away.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If this is successful, this would be a huge advancement,” Dr. Victor Bustos, senior research associate at the Fisher Center, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;James A. Hendrix, Ph.D., the director of global science initiatives, medical and scientific relations, at the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.alz.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Alzheimer’s Association&lt;/a&gt;, also sees promise.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hendrix told Healthline the research was an “interesting look” at a “different way of intervening” in Alzheimer’s disease progression.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It introduces a new mechanism for attacking Alzheimer’s,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What researchers found&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Fisher Center scientists focused on a mutation that protects older adults from developing Alzheimer’s.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers said they discovered that Gleevec, a cancer-fighting drug, and another compound, can mimic the effects of that protective mutation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Bustos said researchers did discover that Gleevec did not stay in the brain that long after it entered, so the focus during the studies shifted to the other compound.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, the scientists identified the cellular process responsible for the mutation’s protection effect.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;All this, the scientists say, can act as a model for effective drugs to battle Alzheimer’s.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This new finding opens the doors for new treatments that may actually prevent Alzheimer’s disease from developing, which would drastically decrease the number of people affected by the disease,” Paul Greengard, Ph.D., director of the Fisher Center, said in a statement.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Bustos said the drugs currently used to treat Alzheimer’s are only able to reduce symptoms and slow the disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“They don’t really attack the source of the problem,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Drugs using this newly discovered process would target the cause of Alzheimer’s.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Bustos said the drugs could be given to people when they first start developing signs of Alzheimer’s such as amyloid plaques or tau tangles.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The next steps&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Bustos said scientists will next test compounds with different types of Alzheimer’s in animals.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They will also try to determine any toxicity or side effects.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;From there, human clinical trials can be conducted.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Bustos and Hendrix both said there is a long road ahead for this research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hendrix did note that experimental treatments have been successful in curing Alzheimer’s in rats and mice for decades.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“You have to remember that animals aren’t humans,” he said. “Human biology is complicated.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He noted this latest research can advance along with other treatments being studied such as immunotherapies and enzyme inhibitors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Hendrix said the key will be funding for organizations like the Alzheimer’s Association and the Fisher Center.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We need to do good research and do good science,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Bustos agreed, noting there is slow, yet steady progress in this field.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“What I can say is today we know more than we did yesterday, and today we are closer to a cure than we were yesterday,” he said.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<pubdate>2017-01-27T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-01-27T10:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/new-way-to-attack-alzheimers
</guid>
<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-01-27T18:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>
Movie ‘Split’ Does Harm to People with Dissociative Identity Disorder, Experts Say
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/movie-split-harms-people-with-dissociative-identity-disorder
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/Split-620.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;M. Night Shyamalan is typically praised as a filmmaker who creates unusual stories, but his new movie “Split” has come under fire.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the movie, a man with dissociative identity disorder (DID) kidnaps three girls, frightening and harming them.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While the star, James McAvoy, gives a dramatic performance as the villain, the movie has irked some medical professionals.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They say the film stigmatizes the disorder and may have a negative impact on people who have the condition.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Elizabeth Howell, a psychotherapist from New York, said the film raises the potential for dangerous attitudes to emerge and for people with the illness to be damaged.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Colleagues who have seen the film said it is not an accurate portrayal of someone with DID, she told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It is a disservice,” Howell said. “This is a common plot device. The serial murderer turns out to have DID. Why not have the plot be about a sociopath like Ted Bundy? Much more plausible.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Between 1 and 3 percent of people in the world have DID.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The movie may imply that someone with DID could be violent, but experts say those people are more likely to hurt themselves than others.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.isst-d.org/downloads/Statement%20on%20Split-final.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;statement&lt;/a&gt; about the movie, the International Society for the Study of Trauma and Dissociation (ISSTD) cited a soon-to-be-released study of 173 people with DID.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The researchers found that only 3 percent were charged with an offense, 1.8 percent were fined, and less than 1 percent were in jail over a six-month span. No convictions or probations were reported in that time period.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What is DID?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;DID used to be referred to as multiple personality disorder.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It is described by the National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI) as a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nami.org/Learn-More/Mental-Health-Conditions/Dissociative-Disorders&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;disorder&lt;/a&gt; that forms when someone is trying to escape reality — often because they experience a traumatic situation such as abuse.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As a result, the people with DID shift between separate identities they form inside themselves to escape the trauma.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These personalities may have names, traits, mannerisms, and distinctive voices. When the person switches between personas, they experience memory gaps.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;People with DID have out-of-body-like experiences. They may feel like voices are trying to control or possess them.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And they may also experience anxiety and depression.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Peter Barach, a clinical psychologist in Cleveland, told Healthline that most people are not diagnosed with DID right away because most mental health professionals are not trained to recognize the disorder.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Most adults with DID have been in the mental health system for several years. They may have received six or seven other diagnoses before DID is accurately identified. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Long-term therapy and medication are used to treat the disorder. Sometimes hospitalization is needed to stabilize a person with DID and ensure their safety. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The psychotherapy helps the person to stabilize their symptoms and improve their ability to function in daily life,” Barach said. “Once the person is stabilized, the treatment works on processing the traumatic memories that interfere with daily functioning, self-esteem, relationships, and personal safety.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“A large percentage of people with DID have made potentially lethal attempts to kill themselves,” he added. “The last part of treatment involves helping the ‘alters’ [parts of the self that experience themselves as separate people] to function in a more integrated and consistent way.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Making the movie&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;McAvoy told the &quot;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hcjxvx9_2F0&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Today Show&lt;/a&gt;” that he watched video diaries made by people with DID and inquired about it with medical professionals.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, he did not sit down with a DID patient while preparing for the role.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The ISSTD statement criticized those involved in the movie, in particular the filmmaker.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“With respect to Mr. Shyamalan’s ability to write and direct truly frightening movies, depicting individuals with this, or any other mental disorder, does a disservice to his artistic ability and to the over 20 percent of the population who, at some time or another, struggle with some form of mental illness,” the ISSTD statement said. “It acts to further marginalize those who already struggle on a daily basis with the weight of stigma.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Impacts of the film&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Sheldon Itzkowitz, a New York-based psychologist and psychoanalyst, said he had not seen the movie — and doesn’t plan to.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“What concerns me is how the film may inadvertently demonize people who are truly suffering. DID is a disorder that has its etiology in the worst form of human suffering — the abuse of innocent children,” Itzkowitz told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said many of his patients with DID are highly functioning people whose friends and co-workers don’t know how much the person may be affected by their condition.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When films and stories “vilify and demonize mental illness in general, and DID in particular,” the viewer does not understand how hard it can be for that person to survive, he added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As such, one of his colleagues views DID as a form of resilience. It is the “mind's effort at trying to cope with overwhelming and terrifying trauma, often at the hands of people who were supposed to care for and protect the child,” Itzkowitz said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Barach, who also had not seen the movie when he was interviewed by Healthline, said that the media is fascinated with mental illness as a cause of violence.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Unfortunately, nearly all of the media depictions of DID are sensationalized. They sometimes depict treatment that would be considered unethical,” he added. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Barach said the movie reviews have led him to believe that the movie will not help society better understand DID. It will only add to the stigma of mental illness in our society. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I wish the media would understand that people with DID suffer greatly and do everything they can to hide or ‘cover’ their symptoms, which they find embarrassing and often disabling,” he said.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<updateddate>2017-01-26T11:00:00</updateddate>

<dc:creator>Kristen Fischer</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-01-26T19:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>Temporary Doctors on the Rise</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/temporary-doctors-on-the-rise
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/070615_sickdoctors_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Everyone gets burned out. Even doctors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In fact, half of practicing physicians reported feeling burned out, according to a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.mayoclinicproceedings.org/article/S0025-6196(15)00716-8/abstract&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2015 report&lt;/a&gt; in the journal Mayo Clinic Proceedings. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This is the exact reason Dr. Louise Henson, a family practice physician in Texas, has been working as a locum tenens (temporary doctor) for the past 10 years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“For years, I worked with the underserved in a typical medical setting, putting in long hours and taking my turn on call,” Henson told Healthline. “As a locum, I can pretty much set my schedule and work 40-hour weeks. I do my job when I’m on the job without having to worry about if I’m going to be able to take off time for my family or other personal commitments.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Doctors like Henson are in demand. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A recent &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.staffcare.com/uploadedFiles/2015-survey-temporary-physician-staffing-trends.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;survey&lt;/a&gt; from the locum tenens staffing agency Staff Care reports that the use of temporary physicians is growing, with primary care physicians cited as the most in-demand locum specialty. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, 94 percent of healthcare facility managers surveyed indicated they had used locum tenens doctors sometime over the past 12 months, a 74 percent increase since 2012.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The top reasons facilities hired temporary doctors were to:&lt;/p&gt; &lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;fill in until a permanent doctor is found&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;fill in for staff who have left&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;fill in for doctors on vacation or receiving continuing education &lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;meet rising patient demand&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The practice of medicine requires working more than 40 hours a week, being on call, and working on weekends,” Dr. Janis M. Orlowski, chief healthcare officer of the Association of American Medical Colleges (AAMC), told Healthline. “We see the younger generation of physicians in the beginning of their career looking for a lifestyle change, as well as those at the end of their career who want to work some to stay in the field.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Physician shortage in play&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;A shortage of physicians may largely be driving the need for locums. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The AAMC released a &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/doctor-shortage-we-may-need-an-additional-90000-physicians-by-2025-092715&quot;&gt;report&lt;/a&gt; in 2015 that projected a physician shortage ranging between 46,000 and 90,000 over the next decade.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The shortage is growing, and needs to be addressed,” said Orlowski. “We are asking for support in increasing the number of residency slots we have because of the shortage.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Aging patients with increasing healthcare demands and aging physicians who soon will retire are some of the reasons for the shortage.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A difficult time filling physician needs in smaller regions of the country also contributes to the shortage, said Dr. Peter Angood, chief executive officer of the American Association for Physician Leadership.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The public should be aware that there are distribution issues within the physician workforce, and there’s data that the shortage is gradually building,” Angood told Healthline. “Therefore the combination of the two will make it such that whatever community you live in you should not be surprised to come across a locum tenens or transient physician for your care.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Should patients be concerned?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Locum tenens are required to have the same licensure and training as other physicians. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“These are highly qualified individuals. However, the institutions who hire them need to do the due diligence to make sure they are qualified,” says Orlowski. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She points out that safety procedures can vary between healthcare facilities. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s how quickly the doctors can adapt to that and work. Medicine is a team sport so you’re working with nurses and pharmacists, and if the physician is new, care needs to be taken so that communication is clear and that the team works smoothly together under a new physician,” Orlowski says.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Angood agrees, noting that doctors who are used to working together get to know and understand each other’s strengths and weaknesses.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When you have a more transient workforce coming through there’s a basic level of knowledge of skill, but the institution and doctors that are in the community have to be mindful that the person who’s coming through on a temporary basis may not have the same skill set as what they’re used to,” he says.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, this is not unique only to locums, adds Angood. So is the case with medical personnel who work in emergency medicine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Any time there’s a shift change this happens. The locum tenens is just a different form of a handoff for a period of time,” says Angood.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As far as what settings are most suited for locums, Angood points to procedural-based settings that don’t require any type of follow-up since patients who need to follow up with a doctor after a procedure might prefer the same doctor.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The same goes for those who see a doctor for a chronic condition.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Those practices will do better with a stable physician workforce because the patients rely on connecting with the same group of doctors,” says Angood. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Henson admits that there’s some truth to that notion in her work setting.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I may not see you as often as I would if I were in a typical clinical setting. That personal and deep relationship is not going to happen,” she says.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, patients’ medical needs will be taken care of, she adds.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Even if you don’t see me every time, the doctors communicate with each other, and your medical care is priority,” Henson says, noting that having a physician who isn’t burned out has benefits.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think it makes us better physicians when we’re not stressed out, and we’re there because we want to be,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<updateddate>2017-01-26T10:00:00</updateddate>

</guid>
<dc:creator>Cathy Cassata</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-01-26T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Regenerative Medicine: Re-growing Teeth and Healing Wounds Without Scars
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/re-growing-teeth-and-healing-wounds-without-scars
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/012017_regenerativemed_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;
]]>
<![CDATA[
p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Medical science may be about to achieve two things once thought impossible.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One is re-growing teeth, something that would eliminate the need for dental fillings.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The other is healing surgical wounds without leaving scars, a process that involves using a drug designed to treat Alzheimer’s disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Teams of scientists in England and the United States, following years of research with mice, announced these discoveries this month.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They hope to begin clinical trials soon.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;No more scars?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers at the University of Pennsylvania’s Perelman School of Medicine say they have discovered a way to &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.pennmedicine.org/news/news-releases/2017/january/using-fat-to-help-wounds-heal-without-scars&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;manipulate wounds&lt;/a&gt; to heal as regenerated, normal skin rather than as unsightly scar tissue.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The scientists transformed the most common type of cells found in wounds into fat cells. This had been considered impossible to accomplish in humans.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The research team conducted a large, multiyear study in collaboration with the Plikus Laboratory for Developmental and Regenerative Biology at the University of California, Irvine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They published their &lt;a href=&quot;http://science.sciencemag.org/content/early/2017/01/04/science.aai8792&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;findings&lt;/a&gt; in early January in the journal Science.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We can manipulate wound healing so that it leads to the regeneration of normal skin without scars,” said Dr. George Cotsarelis, who chairs the Department of Dermatology at Penn, and is the Milton Bixler Hartzell Professor of Dermatology, and principal investigator of the project.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The secret is to regenerate hair follicles first,” he told Healthline. “Then the fat will regenerate in response to the signals from those follicles.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Fat cells called adipocytes are normally found in the skin, Cotsarelis said, but they are lost when wounds heal as scars. Myofibroblasts, the most common cells found in healing wounds, were thought to form only scars. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Scar tissue does not have hair follicles associated with it, which gives it an abnormal appearance from the rest of the skin,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cotsarelis and his colleagues used these characteristics as the basis for their work. Their goal was to change the already present myofibroblasts into fat cells, which do not cause scarring.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Our study showed hair and fat develop separately but not independently,” he said. “Hair follicles form first, and we previously discovered factors necessary for their formation.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While Cotsarelis and his colleagues tried to determine what was sending the signal from the hair to the fat cells, they identified a factor called bone morphogenetic protein, which instructs the myofibroblasts to become fat.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This signaling was groundbreaking on its own, he said, as it changed what was previously known about myofibroblasts.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Now his team has discovered additional factors produced by the regenerating hair follicles that convert the surrounding myofibroblasts to regenerate as fat instead of forming a scar, he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“That fat will not form without the new hairs,” he said. “But once it does, the new cells are indistinguishable from the preexisting fat cells, giving the healed wound a natural look instead of leaving a scar.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The potential for applying his research goes beyond preventing scars.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cotsarelis said their discoveries also could make it possible to regenerate adipocytes in wrinkled skin, especially in the face, leading to new anti-aging treatments.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cotsarelis is also co-founder of Follica, Inc., a Boston-based company that is developing a system to treat hair loss and to stimulate the growth of new hair follicles. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He has filed for a patent and said clinical trials may be eventually conducted at Penn.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We looked at isolated molecules from keloids, which are very big benign tumors that form on pierced ears, and are sometimes the size of golf balls,” Cotsarelis said. “If we can convert those cells to fat, it will be easier to treat scarring, including cancer surgery scars.&quot;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;No more dental fillings?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In England, scientists at King’s College London have discovered a new method to stimulate the renewal of living stem cells in tooth pulp by using an Alzheimer’s drug.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nature.com/articles/srep39654&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;paper&lt;/a&gt; published this month in Scientific Reports, the researchers detailed their method to stimulate the stem cells inside tooth pulp to generate new dentine — the mineralized material that protects the tooth — in large cavities.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This could potentially reduce the need for fillings or cements. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Professor Paul Sharpe, Ph.D., lead author of the ongoing three-year study, specializes in molecular control of tooth development, tissue engineering, and dental stem cells in the college’s Department of Craniofacial Development and Stem Cell Biology.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When a tooth suffers trauma or infection, the soft, inner pulp can become exposed and infected,” Sharpe told Healthline. “The body reacts to protect the tooth and produces a thin band of dentine that seals the tooth pulp. This natural process, however, is insufficient to repair large cavities effectively.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dentists use man-made cements or fillings to treat larger cavities and fill holes in teeth, he said. But the cement remains in the tooth and does not disintegrate, so the tooth’s normal mineral level is never completely restored.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sharpe and his colleagues found that teeth could use their natural ability to repair large cavities without cements or fillings, which are prone to infections and often need to be replaced a number of times.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When fillings fail or infection occurs, dentists have to remove and fill an area that is larger than what is affected, and after multiple treatments the tooth may eventually need to be extracted,” Sharpe said. “As this new method encourages natural tooth repair, it could eliminate all of these issues, and provide a more natural solution for patients.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;How did an Alzheimer’s drug, tideglusib, become a candidate for dentine regeneration?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One of the small molecules the team used to stimulate the renewal of the stem cells included tideglusib, which has been used in clinical trials to treat neurological disorders such as Alzheimer’s disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This presents an opportunity to fast track the treatment into practice, Sharpe said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The scientists used biodegradable collagen sponges to apply low doses of small-molecule glycogen synthase kinase inhibitors to the tooth. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We found that the sponge degraded over time and that new dentine replaced it, leading to complete, natural repair,” Sharpe said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Collagen sponges are commercially available and clinically approved. These factors, he said, add to the potential for this treatment to be adopted quickly and used in dental clinics.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sharpe plans to seek funding for a clinical trial from the United Kingdom’s Medical Research Council, and will seek commercial partners to move the project forward.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sharpe is optimistic about his discovery.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The simplicity of our approach makes it ideal as a clinical dental product for the natural treatment of large cavities, by providing both pulp protection and restoring dentine,” he said. “It brings stem cell biology into clinical dentistry for the very first time, and will hopefully make the clinical dental community aware that biological-based treatments are the future.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<category>Technology</category>

<updateddate>2017-01-25T12:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/re-growing-teeth-and-healing-wounds-without-scars
</guid>
<dc:creator>Patrick Keeffe</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-01-25T20:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Annual Tobacco Report Highlights Anti-Smoking Measures
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/tobacco-report-highlights-anti-smoking-measures
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/012517_tobaccoreport_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The tobacco industry spends $23 million a day advertising its products.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Tobacco now kills 480,000 Americans a year, with another 16 million living with diseases caused by tobacco. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Those numbers are no surprise to Thomas Carr, director of national policy for the American Lung Association (ALA).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nor is the fact that a lot of that industry money pays for advertising to young people.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The ALA makes keeping children from using tobacco a top priority, but it’s an uphill battle.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s not just cigarettes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The tobacco industry is creative in introducing new products like e-cigarettes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That is the climate in which the ALA released the results of its 15th annual State of Tobacco Control &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.lung.org/our-initiatives/tobacco/reports-resources/sotc/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;report&lt;/a&gt; today.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The report evaluates key tobacco control policies at the federal and state levels. Grades are assigned based on how well laws and policies protect residents from death and disease caused by tobacco. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The report is not light reading.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It is lengthy and detailed, showing what the federal government, and each state and municipality is doing to eliminate or reduce tobacco use.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The report also covers trends, including which communities are doing better and which are falling behind.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Keeping an eye on legislation&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Carr keeps an eye on what is happening in the halls of Congress each year as well as the executive branch.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A program the association was backing may find more, or less, support depending on who chairs the relevant committee or how the rules of enforcement are written.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One of the issues closest to his heart is getting the legal age for smoking raised to 21, as was done last year in &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.latimes.com/politics/la-pol-sac-jerry-brown-smoking-bills-20160504-story.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;California&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We’ve seen a lot of bills [on this issue] in state legislatures,” Carr told Healthline. “It’s an issue we’ve been pushing.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He explains it as a simple matter of math. If you increase the age to 21, 223,000 premature deaths can be prevented.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The largest effect can be seen in the number of 15- to 17-year-olds taking up the habit. The reason, according to Carr, is that those teens usually get their cigarettes or other tobacco products from older teens, who would no longer have easy access themselves.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Marketing starts in childhood, he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Cigarettes are as addictive as heroin,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition to a higher legal smoking age, Carr would like to see that basic services, such as counseling and workshops on quitting, are available to everyone.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some health plans offer such coverage. Others don’t.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Looking ahead, Carr said, they don’t know what is going to happen with the change of administrations in Washington.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We’re eager for housing rules preventing smoking in all public housing,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Carr noted that some places have implemented such a policy with voluntary compliance.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Evictions are rare,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s an important policy to protect people exposed to secondhand smoke, especially children. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Carr said there are 760,000 children in public housing. Smoke seeping through the walls and outlets could make them sick.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s a more popular policy than you would think,” Carr said. “It’s the number one complaint the lung association gets, about smoke in housing.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Grades and laws&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;California got mixed reviews in the report.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The state was graded as follows: smoke-free air, A; tobacco taxes, B; and access to cessation services, F.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Vanessa Marvin, vice president of public policy and advocacy for the ALA in California, emphasized the need for improvement at the local level.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Last year a lot was accomplished in the [state] legislature,” she told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;California recaptured some of its national leadership in fighting tobacco use following the successful passage of laws and the approval of Proposition 56 in November. That measure will increase the state’s cigarette tax by $2 per pack as well as increase other tobacco product taxes. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2016, California also increased its minimum age of sale for tobacco products to 21 as well as passed a comprehensive quit-smoking benefit for Medicaid recipients.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The state also closed loopholes and added e-cigarettes to its smoke-free workplace law.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As a result of Prop. 56, the state will also significantly increase funding for its tobacco prevention and cessation program.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While pleased with this progress, Marvin noted that some communities were left behind.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Big Tobacco gives a lot of money to legislators,” she said. “We have trouble getting bills through the legislature.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This year she’s hoping for more action by local leadership. “More than 50 percent of the population doesn’t have protection from tobacco,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The picture is also mixed across the nation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Raising the minimum age of sale for all tobacco products to 21 emerged in 2016 as an effective strategy to keep kids from using tobacco products.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2015, Hawaii became the first state in the nation to pass that law. Many other states considered &lt;a href=&quot;http://tobacco21.org/state-by-state/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Tobacco 21 laws&lt;/a&gt; in 2016. In addition to California, the District of Columbia also passed that law.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Taxes were another hot issue.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The year 2016 marked the return of states using the ballot to increase tobacco taxes. Not since 2006 had there been as many tobacco tax initiatives on the ballot. Only California’s was approved by voters, however.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Funding for state tobacco prevention and cessation, or quit-smoking programs for 2017 generally remained consistent with 2016.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There were notable exceptions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Connecticut provided no new state funding for tobacco prevention and cessation programs for 2017. It joins New Jersey as one of only two states that provide no state funding to combat tobacco use.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Tennessee cut funding for tobacco prevention programs by several million dollars.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Louisiana, Pennsylvania, and West Virginia passed cigarette tax increases through their state legislatures in 2016, but only in Pennsylvania ($1 per pack increase) and West Virginia (65 cents per pack increase) were the increases significant enough to affect smoking rates.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Louisiana’s cigarette tax increased by 22 cents per pack.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2016, California joined Pennsylvania and West Virginia in establishing new taxes on e-cigarettes or the liquid used in them. Five other states and the District of Columbia already have established taxes on these products.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;California, along with Maine, Missouri, North Dakota, and Ohio, has implemented policies to offer a comprehensive tobacco cessation benefit to all Medicaid enrollees. Missouri became the first state Medicaid program to have no barriers to accessing cessation coverage.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So far, no state has passed a comprehensive statewide smoke-free law, but some progress continued at the local level. California also became the first state to close loopholes in its existing smoke-free law and add e-cigarettes to the law.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Vermont and the District of Columbia passed legislation in 2016 adding e-cigarettes to their smoke-free laws. Nine states with comprehensive smoke-free laws as well as the District of Columbia now prohibit the use of e-cigarettes in all public places and workplaces.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<category>Public Policy</category>

<updateddate>2017-01-25T10:00:00</updateddate>

http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/tobacco-report-highlights-anti-smoking-measures
</guid>
<dc:creator>Roberta Alexander</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-01-25T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Sophie the Giraffe Has Mold? Should Parents Worry?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/mold-should-parents-worry
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/childrens-health/012517_sophiegiraffe_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For the second time in about as many years, a product made for young children has been shown to breed mold.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sophie the Giraffe, a teething toy designed for children 18 months and under, is the latest item geared toward babies that is under fire by parents who discovered mold inside the toy’s cavity.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Last year, &lt;a href=&quot;/health-news/mold-inside-childs-sippy-cup&quot;&gt;sippy cups&lt;/a&gt; made by Tommee Tippee were in the spotlight when some parents uncovered mold growing in the cup’s valve.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The issue of mold involving Sophie the Giraffe was first reported in Good Housekeeping. Pediatric dentist Dana Chianese was washing her child’s toy when she noticed an odd smell coming from the hole at the bottom.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I decided to cut into Sophie out of curiosity and discovered a science experiment living inside,” Chianese told the magazine. “Smelly, ugly mold living in my infant's favorite chew toy.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Pediatricians weigh in&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Healthline turned to pediatricians at two of the country’s top children's hospitals to get their take on the issue of mold growing inside toys.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One was Dr. Sheela Sathyanarayana, M.P.H., environmental health specialist at Seattle Children's Research Institute and an associate professor of pediatrics at the University of Washington’s School of Public Health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The other was Nicholas Newman, D.O., M.S., F.A.A.P., assistant professor of pediatrics and environmental health at the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;We asked them what makes mold grow on the inside of toys, why the issue continues to pop up, and what parents can and should do about it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The good news, the pediatricians said, is occasional exposure to mold isn’t as harmful as parents may think.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The bad news is some toys and products designed for kids are a perfect breeding ground for the organism to grow.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Mold grows anywhere there is moisture and a carbon source,” Newman said. “It doesn’t surprise me that it would grow inside a kid’s toy.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sathyanarayana said this isn’t the first time mold has been known to grow inside a toy, and it likely won’t be the last.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This is not new,” she said. “There are probably other toys that have the same problem, but we just don’t know about them.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As with Tommee Tippee sippy cups, parents who discovered mold inside Sophie the Giraffe have turned to social media to express their dismay.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Good Housekeeping said other parents have posted concerns about the toy on Amazon and other websites.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sophie the Giraffe has been around for decades.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The toy, made from natural rubber and decorated with plant-based paint, is manufactured by the French company Vulli.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A spokesperson for the company told Good Housekeeping in a statement that the package instructions state that Sophie the Giraffe should only be cleaned on the surface with a damp cloth.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It should not be immersed in the water nor rinsed off, to prevent water from getting inside, as she may become damaged,” the statement read.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Mold is a natural thing&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mold, while unpleasant to look at and smell, is everywhere, according to Newman.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Any attempt to fully eradicate it from our children’s toys, let alone our lives, is futile.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Mold is how nature tries to recycle everything,” he said. “It’s the normal recycling process.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;What’s more, mold thrives in damp environments.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Children’s toys, particularly those that are hollow and have the capacity for moisture to collect on the inside through tiny vents or holes, set up the perfect conditions for mold to grow.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, most people don’t become sick if they accidentally ingest mold, Newman said. Although people with comprised immune systems such as people with cancer or HIV may show signs of gastrointestinal issues once they consume mold.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The bigger concern, when it comes to children and mold, is not ingestion but inhalation, said Sathyanarayana.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Mold reacts with cells in the lungs and can lead to issues,” she said. “Runny nose, cough, things like that.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sathyanarayana noted that a “child that has asthma, allergies, or eczema,” may have some risks if mold is inhaled.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Those are the kids most likely to be affected,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Preventative measures&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The best defense against the development of mold inside your child’s favorite toy is to follow use and cleaning instructions, Sathyanarayana noted.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Really pay attention to instructions,” she said. “Use [toys] only as indicated.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sathyanarayana suspects that some parents are bringing the toy into the tub.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But Newman said even if that isn’t the case, cleaning the product with soap and water sets up the right chemistry for mold to grow.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Soap is a carbon source,” he said. “The mold sees that and goes, ‘Oh good, yum.’”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sathyanarayana noted that if parents do discover mold inside any of their child’s toys, they should make an effort to clear it out.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If you see mold, a little bleach and water can help remove some of it,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nikki Fleming, spokesperson from the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cpsc.gov/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Consumer Product Safety Commission&lt;/a&gt; said parents are welcome to report safety concerns about any toys at saferproducts.gov, or call the toll free hotline at &lt;a href=&quot;file://localhost/tel/(800)%2520638-2772&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;800-638-2772&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We want to hear from consumers,” she told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Vulli has not made any further announcements regarding its toy. Tommee Tippee voluntarily recalled six of its cups on January 10 because of the faulty valve.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While moldy toys are of great concern for parents, Sathyanarayana said people should be just as vigilant when looking for mold in their homes or offices. Particularly if you live in damp cities, such as Seattle.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I’d actually be more concerned about proper ventilation in homes — bathrooms and basements,” she said, “than Sophie the Giraffe.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<updateddate>2017-01-25T09:00:00</updateddate>

<dc:creator>Carolyn Abate</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-01-25T17:00:00</dc:date>
