<item>
<title>
Trump’s Health Secretary Nominee: Anti-Abortion, Against Stem Cell Research, Thinks Tobacco Isn’t a Drug
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/trumps-health-secretary-nominee
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/012417_tomprice_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;He’s a
]]>
<![CDATA[
gainst abortion rights and would like to cut off federal funding for Planned Parenthood.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He’s against human embryonic stem cell research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He doesn’t think tobacco should be regulated as a drug.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He has voted against the expansion of the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But he did support a bill that would have limited monetary damages in malpractice lawsuits.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Those are some of the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ontheissues.org/GA/Tom_Price.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;positions&lt;/a&gt; taken by Dr. Tom Price, the Republican congressman from Georgia who President Donald Trump has nominated to be secretary of the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.hhs.gov/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Health and Human Services Department (HHS)&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At confirmation hearings last week, Price was &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.politico.com/story/2017/01/tom-price-hhs-confirmation-hearing-233755&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;questioned&lt;/a&gt; by members of the Senate Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee about some of those views, as well as his support for President Trump’s plans to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (ACA).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Also last week a &lt;a href=&quot;http://big.assets.huffingtonpost.com/letterPriceNominationfinal.ECBT.01.17.17.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;letter&lt;/a&gt;, signed by the American Academy of Pediatrics and dozens of other health-related groups, was sent to key senators asking that they get Price on the record about whether he supports mandatory vaccinations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Then, there’s the question of some of Price’s stock purchases in recent years. Those activities have led some Democratic leaders to &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/congress/schumer-calls-ethics-probe-trump-s-hhs-nominee-n703511&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;call for a delay&lt;/a&gt; in Price’s confirmation proceedings while these deals are investigated to see if any ethics rules were broken.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The process, however, is still pressing forward.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Senate Finance Committee went ahead with its confirmation hearing today for Price, an orthopedic surgeon whose father and grandfather were also doctors.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;At the hearing, Price once again &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/24/us/politics/trump-cabinet-hearing-confirmation.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;defended his stock dealings&lt;/a&gt; and answered new questions about some of his tax deductions in recent years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Those who support Price&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Officials in the Trump administration did not respond to several requests from Healthline for an interview on Price’s positions on issues.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The congressman also has a number of supporters.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The American Medical Association (AMA) is one of more than a half-dozen physician groups that have endorsed Price’s nomination.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In an &lt;a href=&quot;https://wire.ama-assn.org/ama-news/why-we-support-dr-price-lead-hhs&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;opinion column&lt;/a&gt;, Dr. Patrice A. Harris, the AMA’s board chairwoman, said Price understands the challenges facing patients and is willing to listen directly to concerns expressed by the AMA and other organizations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She did point out her group doesn’t agree with Price on all issues. That includes his support for dismantling the ACA.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, the AMA feels Price’s background is a major plus for the HHS secretary position.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“[His] physician background will provide important perspective within the president’s cabinet,” wrote Harris. “Too often, health policy makers and regulators give short shrift to the real-world impact their plans and decisions can have on how patient care is delivered.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a column on &lt;a href=&quot;http://thehill.com/blogs/pundits-blog/healthcare/314495-hhs-needs-a-doctor-like-tom-price-as-secretary&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;The Hill website&lt;/a&gt;, Dr. J. Phillip Gingrey, a former Republican congressman from Georgia, called Price “the doctor HHS needs.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“He is a compassionate, competent, and smart man who will help steer the nation's largest healthcare agency through a period of change with a steady hand on the rudder,” wrote Gingrey.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When he nominated Price in late November, Trump heaped praised on his choice.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&quot;[Dr.] Price, a renowned physician, has earned a reputation for being a tireless problem solver and the go-to expert on healthcare policy, making him the ideal choice to serve in this capacity,” Trump said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Abortion rights&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Democrats haven’t challenged Price’s medical knowledge or leadership skills.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They do, however, have concerns over some of the six-term congressman’s &lt;a href=&quot;http://edition.cnn.com/2017/01/18/health/tom-price-hhs-on-the-issues-profile-aca/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;political views&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The biggest might be on abortion rights.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2011, Price voted against federal health coverage that included abortion services.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2010 and 2011, he voted to prohibit funding for abortion services and organizations like Planned Parenthood.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2007, he voted in favor of granting the “preborn” equal protection under the Fourteenth Amendment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And in 2005 and 2007, he voted against programs for human embryonic stem cell research.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For his &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ontheissues.org/GA/Tom_Price_Abortion.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;anti-abortion stance&lt;/a&gt;, Price has been given a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ontheissues.org/GA/Tom_Price_Abortion.htm#06n-NRLC&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;100 percent grade&lt;/a&gt; by the National Right to Life Committee.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Ross Baker, Ph.D., a political science professor at Rutgers University, said Price would be able to lobby congressional representatives as HHS secretary on abortion issues, but “his hands are tied” on taking action within his department because of the 1973 &lt;a href=&quot;http://landmarkcases.org/en/landmark/cases/roe_v_wade&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Roe v. Wade&lt;/a&gt; decision that legalized the procedure.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Baker said Price would face the same situation with Planned Parenthood funding, although he could encourage states to pass new laws.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Obamacare, tobacco, drugs&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Price has been a consistent, ardent foe of the ACA.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He voted against the landmark legislation in 2010 and in favor of the various repeal efforts in the following years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He also supported a move to defund the ACA in 2010.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2015, he introduced the &lt;a href=&quot;https://tomprice.house.gov/HR2300&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Empowering Patients First Act&lt;/a&gt; as a “patient-centered” solution to the ACA.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That bill did not become law, but it might be used as a guidepost for Republican proposals this year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Baker said Price is a “man with a plan” when it comes to new healthcare laws. It’s also one of the congressman’s passions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“He really wants to get the federal government out of the [healthcare] business entirely,” Baker told Healthline. “It’s a calling for him.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2007, Price voted against legalization that requires negotiated prescription drug prices for Medicare Part D.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2006, he voted in favor of a law that would deny nonemergency treatment to people who couldn’t afford the copayment under Medicare.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the past, he has voted in favor of proposals to limit malpractice awards in lawsuits.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2009, Price voted against a bill to regulate tobacco as a drug.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And, as a congressman, Price, reportedly a cigar smoker, tried to &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.statnews.com/2017/01/17/tom-price-questions/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;exempt the cigar industry&lt;/a&gt; from Food and Drug Administration (FDA) regulations that require premium, hand-rolled cigars to comply with the same testing and labeling that smokeless tobacco products follow.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As HHS secretary, Price would oversee the FDA, but Baker says the new HHS secretary probably won’t push too hard on the tobacco rules.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He said Price’s time will be taken up by the ACA replacement plans.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“He’s going to have to pick his targets,” Baker said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The questions over stock purchases&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Price has faced some fire during his confirmation hearings on a total of $300,000 worth of health-related stock he has purchased the past four years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Democrats say some of those &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2017/01/18/why-one-expert-says-tom-prices-stock-deals-may-very-well-have-broken-the-law/?utm_term=.b4969e64ddd7&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;purchases and sales&lt;/a&gt; came while Price was dealing with healthcare legislation.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One of the most scrutinized purchases was a so-called “&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-care/trump-s-hhs-nominee-got-sweetheart-drug-stock-deal-n706576&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;sweetheart deal&lt;/a&gt;” offered to Price and another congressional representative as well as other U.S. investors last year by the small Australian biotech firm Innate Immunotherapies.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another deal that is under the microscope involved shares Price purchased last spring from Zimmer Biomet, a medical device manufacturer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/16/politics/tom-price-bill-aiding-company/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;report on CNN&lt;/a&gt; last week stated that Price invested in the company, then introduced legislation to help it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Price has said his broker purchases stock without his prior knowledge, although he does approve the sales on a quarterly and annual basis.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Price hasn’t answered the question of why he didn’t tell his broker to avoid any health-related stocks.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Price denies any wrongdoing and has stated he will divest himself from 43 companies he has an interest in 90 days after he is confirmed as HHS secretary.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The Democrats’ charges of improper behavior produced a flurry of statements last week from Trump administration officials.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In those emails sent to Healthline and other news organization, Trump officials asked CNN to retract its Zimmer Biomet story, which they called “junk reporting.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They also sent out a release detailing stock holdings from some of the Democrats who criticized Price.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Baker said “it would have been prudent” for Price to advise his broker to avoid health-related stocks.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He added that Price and other Trump nominees are facing new scrutiny because of the 2012 &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.congress.gov/bill/112th-congress/senate-bill/2038&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;STOCK Act&lt;/a&gt;, which cracks down on the financial dealings involving members of Congress.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It gives more ammunition for the interrogations,” Baker said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Nonetheless, Baker expects Price to be confirmed as the HHS secretary. He said it’s “very rare” for a president’s cabinet choices to be denied.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, that might not dissuade Democrats from some political theater at Price’s hearings.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Democrats are out for blood,” said Baker. “They know they’re not going to win, but they want to cut him up a bit.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-01-24T23:00:00</dc:date>

<item>
<title>
Alzheimer’s Documentary: Epidemic Could Bankrupt Medicare and Medicaid
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/alzheimers-epidemic-could-bankrupt-medicare-medicaid
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/mental-health/012417_alzheimersdoc_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Each year Alzheimer’s disease can cause financial hardships for families with loved ones that are affected by the condition.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the United States, millions of baby boomers are becoming at risk for the disease. And the financial impact on the country will be astronomical, experts warn.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“All the Medicare, Medicaid, and healthcare costs are going to devastate us financially, and we’re just not going to be able to handle it,” Rudolph Tanzi, Ph.D., a professor of neurology at Harvard Medical School, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.alz.org/facts/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Alzheimer’s Association&lt;/a&gt;, in 2016 the country spent $236 billion caring for people with Alzheimer’s and other types of dementia. Over two-thirds of these costs were borne by Medicare and Medicaid.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Total healthcare spending in the United States for this incurable disease is projected to jump to $1 trillion per year by mid-century.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some fear that, unless the government greatly increases Alzheimer’s research funding — and quickly — the disease will overwhelm the healthcare system much sooner.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If you start trying to calculate when we’re going to hit that tipping point where Medicare and Medicaid are going to be overtaken by Alzheimer’s, it’s not so far away,” said Tanzi. “It could be within five to 10 years, depending upon how many of these baby boomers start showing symptoms.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Even if a treatment is found soon, people who have already started down the path of this progressive brain disorder may not benefit.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“For people who are in their 70s or 80s now, and on their way to Alzheimer’s, even if [scientists] came up with a treatment tomorrow, it’s probably not going to really help those people. It’s a little bit too late for them,” Elizabeth Arledge, award-winning director of the new documentary “Alzheimer’s: Every Minute Counts,” told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These patients will need intensive, and expensive, care for years to come — adding to the impact on Medicare and Medicaid.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.pbs.org/tpt/alzheimers-every-minute-counts/home/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;PBS documentary&lt;/a&gt; will air at 10 p.m. (ET) on Wednesday.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Burden on healthcare system&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Like Arledge’s 2004 film about Alzheimer’s, “The Forgetting: A Portrait of Alzheimer's,” her new film, for which she also wrote and serves as producer, weaves together expert commentary with personal stories from around the country — but with a different focus and a bigger sense of urgency.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We tell these stories through the experiences of families and through individuals,” said Arledge, “but we wanted to focus a little less on that and a little more on the public policy disaster that is looming if we don’t change the trajectory of the epidemic.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Right now, that trajectory looks like a public health “tidal wave” about to hit the country.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“By mid-century there could be as many as 16 million people living with this disease in the United States,” Matthew Baumgart, senior director of public policy for the Alzheimer's Association, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These are just the people with visible symptoms of the disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If you start to calculate how many have Alzheimer’s pathology on their way to symptoms,” said Tanzi, “Ten or 15 years from now, the number [of people affected] probably goes up to at least 25 or 30 million.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The length of time people live with Alzheimer’s, and the intensity of the care needed later on, makes this one of the costliest diseases in the country — and one that could bankrupt Medicare and Medicaid.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;More research funding needed&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Experts say the key to getting a handle on the Alzheimer’s epidemic is to find new ways to treat and prevent it.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Addressing the future solvency of Medicare and Medicaid is going to require addressing Alzheimer’s disease,” said Baumgart. “That’s why research is so important because we can actually save Medicare and Medicaid money by investing in research today.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Government funding for Alzheimer’s disease research, though, has lagged far behind what is spent on other diseases, although there have been signs of progress in recent years.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The government has largely been asleep at the wheel about this,” said Tanzi. “They’re starting to wake up, you know. They raised our paltry half a billion dollars of funding up to about a billion now.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In comparison, in 2017 the &lt;a href=&quot;https://report.nih.gov/categorical_spending.aspx&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;NIH allocated&lt;/a&gt; $6 billion for cancer research and $3 billion for HIV and AIDS.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Tanzi, though, estimates that heading off the Alzheimer’s epidemic would require much more — along the lines of $10 billion in research funding.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some might balk at that kind of up-front investment, but this approach has helped with other diseases.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Government — whatever people think about it — has actually worked in the area of medical research,” said Baumgart. “Because of the research funding that has been given over the years to cancer, cardiovascular disease, and HIV and AIDS, you see demonstrable progress. Deaths from those diseases have dropped in the last 15 years — and in some cases, dropped significantly.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Tanzi also says that tackling Alzheimer’s will mean stopping it earlier.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This has worked for heart disease, where doctors screen people early for risk factors — like high cholesterol — and treat those before someone has a heart attack or congestive heart failure.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s also worked with early screening and treatment of cancer — rather than waiting for a person to develop a large tumor or organ failure.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If you want to stop this disease — eradicate this disease — you have to take the same approach we take in cancer and heart disease,” said Tanzi. “Which is detect early on that the pathology has begun and then stave it off so you never get symptoms.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<category>Senior Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-01-24T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-01-24T12:00:00</updateddate>

http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/alzheimers-epidemic-could-bankrupt-medicare-medicaid
</guid>
<dc:creator>Shawn Radcliffe</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-01-24T20:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Are We Headed Toward a World Without Antibiotics?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/headed-toward-a-world-without-antibiotics
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/012417_antibiotics_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;What would a world without antibiotics be like?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Here’s what David Weiss, Ph.D., director of the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.antibiotics.emory.edu/index.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Emory Antibiotic Resistance Center&lt;/a&gt;, thinks.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“A world without effective antibiotics would be terrible, an 80-year trip backward in time,” he told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Weiss notes that many great achievements of modern medicine would be reversed if antibiotics ceased to exist.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Transplants would no longer be possible, many cancer treatments would be too dangerous, and very premature babies would have greatly reduced survival rates,” Weiss said. “Routine surgeries would carry great risk. Even seemingly harmless cuts and scrapes could prove deadly. The way we go through life would be fundamentally changed.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Although Weiss notes a world without antibiotics is far from a certainty, and perhaps not even likely, he also suggests that for patients with drug resistant infections, his hypothetical scenario has already become a reality. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That was the case for a woman in Reno, Nev., who died last year from an incurable infection that was &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/woman-killed-by-a-superbug-resistant-to-every-available-antibiotic/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;resistant to all 26 antibiotics&lt;/a&gt; available in the United States. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;She had spent a significant amount of time in India, and had contracted a bone infection after breaking her right femur (thigh bone). &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;When she was hospitalized in Reno last August doctors found she was infected with carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;CRE are a class of bacteria that are resistant to a number of antibiotics, including carbapenems, drugs that are considered the last resort when all other antibiotics have failed. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Tom Frieden, the director of the U. S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), has described CREs as “nightmare bacteria” due to their ability to spread their resistance to other bacteria. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Typically, CRE spreads in hospitals and care facilities. It causes an estimated &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/drugresistance/pdf/ar-threats-2013-508.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;9,300 infections&lt;/a&gt; and 610 deaths in the United States each year. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Spreading more than anticipated&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2017/01/10/1616248114.full?sid=51df8b41-148a-42aa-99e8-ec642e8b5224&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; published this month from researchers at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, and the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, found that CRE may be spreading more widely than previously thought.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It may also be passing between people asymptomatically, meaning it does so without showing any obvious symptoms. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We need to look harder for this unobserved transmission within our communities and healthcare facilities if we want to stamp it out,” William Hanage, Ph.D., associate professor of epidemiology at the Harvard T.H Chan School, and senior author of the study, said in a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/news/press-releases/drug-resistant-nightmare-bacteria-diversify-spread/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;press release&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Lee Riley, head of the infectious diseases department at the University of California, Berkeley, says antibiotic resistance poses a significant threat to public health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“People should recognize that antibiotic-resistant bacterial infections are an epidemic of worldwide proportions, and they kill more people each year than Ebola or Zika virus, which gain more attention in the lay media. This silent epidemic needs to be better recognized,” he told Healthline. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/drugresistance/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;CDC&lt;/a&gt;, every year at least 2 million people in the United States become infected with bacteria that are resistant to antibiotics. Of those at least 23,000 die as a result of these infections. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Many factors led us to this point,” Weiss said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Pharmaceutical companies stopped developing new antibiotics in part because they have not been as profitable as other drugs. The use of antibiotics for growth promotion in farming [nonmedical uses] is another factor. Complacency in thinking that things wouldn't get this bad was a big factor as well,” Weiss added.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Riley also emphasizes the need for reducing use of antibiotics in farming, arguing if nothing is done to address this it may be too late to fix. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“At this time, there is very little emphasis on addressing the problem of antibiotic use as a growth promoter in animal husbandry … More than 70 percent of all antimicrobial agents manufactured are used in animal husbandry. This is a huge source of drug-resistant pathogens and needs to be recognized,” he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What can be done&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Developing new antibiotics and diagnostic tests, using antibiotics more sparingly, and reducing their use in agriculture are some of the ways experts suggest antibiotic resistance could be combatted, but it will require a significant global investment.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, Weiss says there are ways the general public can do their part to help stop the increase in antibiotic resistance.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Urge your lawmakers to support increased funding for research and regulations that limit the overuse of antibiotics. Purchase antibiotic-free products [soap, meats, etc.] to incentivize producers to stop using unnecessary antibiotics. If you or your loved ones are in the hospitals, insist that care providers wash their hands each time they enter the room,” he said. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Most importantly, Weiss says, both the medical community and the general public should avoid becoming complacent. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“As we would, bacteria will always try to survive,” he said. “They evolve rapidly, and are under great pressure to find ways to resist antibiotics. They have had decades to become as resistant as they are today. We should not think that if we simply develop new drugs, we will be past this problem. We will also have to remain vigilant and not let our guard down.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>

<updateddate>2017-01-24T12:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/headed-toward-a-world-without-antibiotics
</guid>
<dc:creator>Elizabeth Pratt</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-01-24T20:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>Obamacare Being Dismantled: Now What?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/obamacare-being-dismantled-now-what
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/public-policy/012017_obamacarerepeal_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Affordable Care Act’s days are numbered.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Congress has already started efforts to repeal the 2010 legislation and come up with an alternative. On Monday, two Republican senators &lt;a href=&quot;http://edition.cnn.com/2017/01/23/politics/collins-cassidy-obamacare-repeal/index.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;introduced a proposal&lt;/a&gt; they called an “Obamacare replacement plan.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On Sunday, one of President Trump’s advisors said the administration &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/01/22/510984148/republican-plan-to-replace-obamacare-would-turn-medicaid-over-to-states&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;plans to turn control&lt;/a&gt; of the federal Medicaid program to the states.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This all followed President Donald Trump’s signing of an &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/inauguration-2017/trump-signs-executive-action-obamacare-inauguration-day-n710116&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;executive order&lt;/a&gt; on Friday, directing federal agencies to “minimize the economic burden” of the Obamacare health law.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So, what will happen when the dust clears?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Experts say it depends on what Congress and the president come up with as a replacement.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The predictions range from chaos as tens of millions of people lose their insurance coverage, to an efficient, affordable healthcare system that’s overseen at the state level.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Dire predictions&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Last week, the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) released a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cbo.gov/publication/52371&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;report&lt;/a&gt; that stated what their analysts believe could happen in the next decade.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;For the study, the CBO researchers went on the assumption the Affordable Care Act (ACA) would be completely repealed and replaced with something similar to &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.congress.gov/bill/114th-congress/house-bill/3762&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;H.R.3762&lt;/a&gt;, a Republican-sponsored bill that was approved by Congress in 2015 but vetoed by then-President Barack Obama.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The CBO report predicts that 18 million people would lose insurance coverage. Of that group, they said 10 million would be people who bought insurance though the ACA marketplace. Another 5 million would be Medicaid recipients, and the final 3 million would be people who would lose employer-based insurance.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The analysts added that once government and Medicaid subsidies were eliminated, 27 million would become uninsured.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They predicted that 32 million people who now have insurance would lose their coverage by 2026.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The CBO report also predicted insurance premiums would rise initially by 25 percent for policies purchased by individuals.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That would increase to a 50 percent hike once subsidies are eliminated and a 100 percent jump by 2026.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They also forecast that half of the U.S. population will live in areas without a marketplace insurance setup. That will increase to 75 percent by 2026.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Many Democratic leaders have made similar predictions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On Monday, House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-San Francisco) released a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.democraticleader.gov/newsroom/12317/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;statement&lt;/a&gt;, saying the Republican actions will take seniors and working families “from affordable care to chaos.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Others aren’t as sure.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kurt Mosley, vice president of strategic alliances for Merritt Hawkins healthcare consultants, said the CBO is less bipartisan than it used to be.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He noted the agency made some rosy predictions about the success of Obamacare that didn’t quite come true.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Lately, they’ve been more wrong than right,” he told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What to look for&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Experts like Mosley said there are several key components that will determine whether the nation’s healthcare system succeeds or not.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The first is the ACA provision of requiring insurance companies to provide coverage for people with preexisting medical conditions.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;President Trump and other Republicans leaders have said they want to keep that requirement.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That may end up creating &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/22/business/president-donald-trump-health-insurance-high-risk-pool.html?rref=collection%2Fsectioncollection%2Fh&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;high-risk pools&lt;/a&gt; where people with preexisting conditions can get insurance, but at higher costs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On the other hand, the ACA’s mandate that people must have insurance coverage or face financial penalties appears to be headed for the scrap heap.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some experts say that provision could actually be &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-care/five-obamacare-provisions-trump-could-change-right-away-n709771&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;done away with&lt;/a&gt; under the executive order President Trump signed on Friday.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;There’s also the “employer mandate” that requires companies to provide certain minimum healthcare coverage. That also seems unlikely to survive.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Mosley added it will be important for new healthcare laws to retain the provision that allows young adults between the ages of 18 and 25 to stay on their parents’ healthcare plans.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He noted that without the individual mandate it will be important to have incentives for younger, healthier people to buy insurance.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;He also thinks it’s crucial that insurance companies be allowed to sell policies across state lines, something they can’t do in ACA marketplaces.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We need to get insurance companies to play ball,” Mosley said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;What may eventually happen is what happened last year in &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-01-23/why-kentucky-couldn-t-kill-obamacare-a-lesson-for-congress&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Kentucky&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That state elected a governor who promised to get rid of Obamacare. When it was all said and done, Kentucky crafted a healthcare program with a new name that had most of the provisions of the ACA.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Public Policy</category>
<pubdate>2017-01-23T14:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-01-23T14:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/obamacare-being-dismantled-now-what
</guid>
<dc:creator>David Mills</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-01-23T22:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>
Women Need to Get Heart Checkups in Their 20s, Experts Say
</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/women-need-heart-checkups-in-their-20s
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/womens-health/012017_girlsheart_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Sooner rather than later.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s the general advice given by medical professionals to women for having their heart health checked.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Plaque buildup in the arteries and other problems that lead to heart disease can begin manifesting when people are in their teens and early 20s.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, most women in the United States don’t think they should begin getting heart screenings until much later.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A national online survey commissioned by Orlando Health polled 2,054 U.S. adults, including 1,062 women. A majority of women — 60 percent — believe that heart screenings aren’t recommended until people are in their 30s.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Just 8 percent of women thought heart screenings should start in their 20s.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;On average, women think a seemingly healthy person should begin getting heart screenings at the age of 41.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A cardiologist who spoke to Healthline said awareness of heart disease has come a long way, but there are still significant gaps in education and perception.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Not just a problem for men&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cardiovascular diseases are the number one cause of death worldwide.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;They’re the number one killer of women in the United States.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Maria Carolina Demori, a cardiologist who leads the Women’s Cardiac Center at Orlando Health Heart Institute, says women traditionally haven’t been aware of the risks of heart disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We used to think that heart disease was more of a men’s problem,” she told Healthline. “However, women were dying of heart disease more than men for many years — for decades. Now, women are dying less of heart disease than men, but it’s still the number one killer of women. There’s a significant lack of awareness of heart disease in women, and only about 50 percent of women know that the number one killer of women is heart disease.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Demori says that men are more likely than women to recognize heart attack symptoms such as chest pains and shortness of breath.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s better now, but in the past, doctors would often diagnose these symptoms in women as anxiety or indigestion, rather than something more serious,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“One fact for sure is that many cardiovascular trials, in the past, were for men. For some reason, more men got enrolled in these trials than women,” says Demori. “Women, I think, sometimes seek medical care less often because they’re busy. This is harmful because we know that women do poorly when they have a heart attack. They’re more likely than men to die after experiencing a heart attack.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Another possible reason for the perception of cardiovascular disease as a problem for men is the different physiology between the sexes.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Women sometimes don’t have the significant obstructions in the coronary artery that would lead to a positive stress test,” says Demori. “In men, there are more obstructions, so a stress test is more likely to turn up positive. Now, we have better techniques, so it’s easier to determine when arteries are not dilating and working properly.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Demori says there’s reason for optimism as awareness increases.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think now, women are more aware of the symptoms of heart disease and, therefore, they’re now looking for help, while in the past they may not have,” she said. “Many of the risk factors for heart disease were tailored more toward men than women in the past, while now they’re tailored for women as well.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Early education crucial&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Despite advancements in diagnosing cardiovascular diseases, the survey indicates that most women don’t think screening is necessary for an otherwise healthy person until later in life.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The American Heart Association &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.heart.org/HEARTORG/Conditions/Heart-Health-Screenings_UCM_428687_Article.jsp#.WIOH5bYrK1u&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;recommends&lt;/a&gt; men and women begin regular checkups for blood pressure, cholesterol, and body mass index when they’re 20.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Demori agrees, saying people should begin seeing their doctor for heart screenings right after their teen years, pointing out that undiagnosed heart problems only get worse with time. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think education at a very early age is important,” she says. “I don’t think we should wait until people are in their 20s, 30s, or 40s to educate people. Education can start very early, at school. We can teach kids that they can prevent and reduce their risk of heart disease by helping them understand that they can start developing that plaque in their arteries as early as their teen years.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It is something that can progress and get really bad, depending on risk factors,” Demori added. “So I think educating kids at a young age, telling them that this is something they can prevent, would be a big step in the right direction.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>Heart Health</category>
<category>Women's Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-01-23T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-01-23T10:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/women-need-heart-checkups-in-their-20s
</guid>
<dc:creator>Dan Gray</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-01-23T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>What Really Happens When You Come to Work Sick</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/when-you-come-to-work-sick
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/sick-employee-thumbnail-766x415.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&
]]>
<![CDATA[
lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The scratchy throat. The achy joints. The stuffy nose.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;It’s hard to ignore the symptoms of cold and flu — but that doesn’t stop us from trying. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;We show up to work and nurse a headache all day. We cough until, at last, we’re begged by our coworkers to take our germs home already.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Whether sick workers show up because there’s a crucial meeting, they fear being punished, replaced, or fired, or because they’re hourly workers who need the money, they do real harm by spreading their illnesses to everyone else in their vicinity. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Dr. Lee Norman, the chief medical officer at the University of Kansas Hospital, acknowledges that people “want to demonstrate to their bosses and coworkers that they have a strong work ethic, so a lot of them suck it up and go to work.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It might be a noble idea,” Norman told Healthline, but “it doesn’t work well for containing the spread of diseases.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In fact, Norman says, there may be no place worse than an office environment for containing germs. There’s little air circulation and, in most cases, outside windows can’t be opened.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“People are in close proximity, and it’s just kind of a perfect setup for the spread of disease,” he says. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What’s so bad about offices?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Norman says that this time of year is ripe for respiratory viruses like cold and flu, which are spread primarily via coughing and sneezing.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But even if a sneeze from Mary in Accounting doesn’t land right in your face, “it’ll settle down on to a surface and be contagious from that perspective. Viruses live on the surface of things for a long time, and it’s easy to pick something up,” says Norman. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Anything people are touching presents the greatest danger of virus transfer, Norman says, but in office settings it seems the number of such items is a lot.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Copy machines, door handles, keyboards, phones, light switches, elevator buttons, vending machines, microwaves, and conference room tables are all breeding grounds for germs. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Says Norman, “Hands are the things that carry from one person to the next. People mop up their runny nose, then don’t wash their hands. Then they take the half-and-half out of the refrigerator,” and the next thing you know, half the office has been felled by the same lingering cough. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A poll of Healthline readers showed people are split over whether to come to work when they're sick.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In the online survey of 119 people done last week, about a third said they always come to work sick.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Almost half said they sometimes come in, while slightly more than 20 percent said they never come in.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;’Tis the season&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;January through March are typically the prime months for cold and flu.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;That’s because the cold weather forces people indoors, and the period following the holiday season is notorious for creating illness in children (and, in turn, the parents of those children).&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This year’s strain of flu is set to be a doozy, according to the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/flu-season-getting-worse-cdc-says-n704061&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)&lt;/a&gt;. Ten states — in particular, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2017/01/06/flu-cases-hit-us-coastal-cities-hard-particularly-nyc/96249856/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;those on both coasts&lt;/a&gt; — have already seen spikes, and the CDC predicts it will only get worse. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The observations and data collected so far this year by Lisa-Marie Gustafson, a human resources manager at aerospace company Hexcel, certainly backs the claim that this time of year is ripe for employee illnesses.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“We are definitely seeing that our delivery is well below where it should be,” she told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Speaking on behalf of the Society of Human Resource Management, Gustafson says, “It’s not just loss of employees’ time, it absolutely is loss of real dollars.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Gustafson says that in order to stem the tide of sick workers, she’s had to have “some hard conversations” with employees who insist on coming to work while ill, because those who haven’t stayed home have affected those around them.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Especially those who work in close team environments, it’s more than just one person that’s going out on illness,” she says.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Remote possibility&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Like many employers, Hexcel offers working from home as an option for office-based employees who are feeling unwell.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Technology like email, video conferencing, and messaging apps have expanded the ability of workers to keep their germs at home. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But what about those in the manufacturing and retail sectors? Most part-time and hourly employees don’t have the option of working from home when they’re not feeling well, because not showing up means not making money. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Current U.S. law does not require employers to provide paid sick days. In fact, the law does not even protect workers from being fired when they miss work due to health reasons, as viral star &lt;a href=&quot;http://people.com/human-interest/new-hampshire-man-fired-for-attending-sons-birth/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Lamar Austin&lt;/a&gt; proved earlier this month. He was sacked for choosing to stay with his wife — instead of working at his security guard job — while she gave birth to their fourth child. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;President Obama proposed a law in 2015 that called for mandating seven days of paid sick time a year for all workers, but Congress declined to pursue the legislation. However, 23 cities and states have passed laws requiring paid sick time for part-time workers, according to the nonprofit organization &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.workplacefairness.org/paid-sick-leave&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Workplace Fairness&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;San Francisco passed a paid sick leave law in 2007. Since then, Portland, Ore.; Seattle; Washington; New York, and the state of Connecticut, among others, have followed suit. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Businesses have argued that these types of laws could lead to price hikes or negatively impact their overall hiring, but the New York law was studied last year by the Center for Economic and Policy Research (CEPR), which found it to be a “nonevent.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The authors of the report, economist Eileen Appelbaum, Ph.D., and sociologist Ruth Milkman, Ph.D., reported that the law had little business impact, saying, “The vast majority of employers were able to adjust quite easily,” and “85 percent reported that the new law had no effect on their overall business costs.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Staying home (or, if possible, working from home) while under the weather benefits not only workers’ health, the health of their fellow employees, and the overall productivity of employers, it also benefits all the people with whom the sick worker would be interacting. That includes customers, clients, and the already immune deficient.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There’s a whole frail segment of the population: older people, babies, people with immune deficiencies or underlying chronic illnesses, people with acute leukemia, people who are going through or just coming off of chemotherapy,” said Norman. “What might be a minor illness to you and me can be a life-threatening illness to somebody like that.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Sucking it up&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to Norman, “A cornerstone of public health is to voluntarily sequester oneself away so as to protect those around them.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s a blinding flash of the obvious,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So why do people persist in coming into work when they’re ill?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nsf.org/consumer-resources/studies-articles/surveys/workplace-flu-survey&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;recent study&lt;/a&gt; from global public health and safety organization NSF reveals that 25 percent of the U.S. workers the group surveyed said their boss expects them to come in no matter what.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The survey also found that 42 percent of workers “have deadlines or are afraid they will have too much work to make up if they take a sick day,” and 37 percent said they can’t afford to take the time off.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The survey also showed that men are twice as likely as women to tough it out when they’re not feeling well.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, two-thirds of those surveyed by NSF considered sick coworkers to be hard workers, while 16 percent reported they felt their ill colleagues didn’t care about their coworkers’ well-being.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;CEPR conducted a &lt;a href=&quot;http://cepr.net/documents/publications/paid-sick-days-2009-05.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; of 22 other countries’ sick leave policies and found that in Europe, most workers are guaranteed days off for illness, paid for either by employers (Netherlands, Switzerland, and United Kingdom), the government (France, Ireland, and Italy), or a combination of both (Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Germany, Greece, Iceland, Luxembourg, Norway, Spain, and Sweden). &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Gustafson, whose company has offices throughout Europe, describes that continent’s sick-time policies as “far more robust,” but says about U.S. sick policies, “We’re getting there.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Flu shots and common sense&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;If human resources departments, and public health advocates can’t convince workers to stay at home or work from home while sick, what are the other options? &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;One way Gustafson’s company is trying to combat the spread of flu is by offering free flu shots to all employees.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;So far, she says, “It seems like in those who got the flu shot, we’re not seeing the same amount of illness.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Her company doesn’t mandate flu shots, but the University of Kansas does. It’s a requirement for the hospital’s 10,000 employees.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There’s no question that the best way to reduce the burden of influenza is by influenza vaccine, and I’m very much a proponent,” Norman said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;No one is truly immune from flu or other viruses, but getting a flu shot can shorten the course of flu as well, says Norman.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In fact, the doctor says that he’s been immunized for 43 years running and has never had the flu. And according to the CDC, &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/flu/pdf/matte/nivw-vaccination.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;it's not too late&lt;/a&gt; to get a flu shot this year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The best defense&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition to preventive measures like getting a flu shot, the NSF says to take defensive steps such as eating healthily and taking vitamins.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Norman recommends humidifying the air and getting a good night’s rest. He also recommends frequent hand washing or hand sanitizing.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“If I’ve been exposed to something, I should not assume I don’t have it on me. I should wash my hands,&quot; he says.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If you suspect you're coming down with something but you absolutely must report to work, make sure you’re doing all you can to avoid spreading your germs to others.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cough and sneeze into a tissue, or at least into the crook of your arm instead of your hands.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Wash your hands frequently.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Don’t go into communal areas, and, if necessary, wear a mask. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;As for employers who expect their employees to show up no matter what, they’re only hurting themselves in the long run.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Your employees are your greatest competitive advantage,” Gustafson says. “If they are ill, or if they feel like, ‘I’m just another person,’ that hurts your bottom line. We want you to stay home and take care of yourself.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>General Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-01-23T10:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-01-23T10:00:00</updateddate>
<guid>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/when-you-come-to-work-sick
</guid>
<dc:creator>Anna Wahrman</dc:creator>
<dc:date>2017-01-23T18:00:00</dc:date>
</item>
<item>
<title>If You Want to Die Young, Move to Rural America</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/die-young-move-to-rural-america
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/general-health/012017_ruralhealth_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Fresh air. Wide open spaces. Starry skies above.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Rural America has long claimed a reputation as a healthy place to live.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But the truth is that rural areas in the United States generally lag behind urban areas in many aspects of health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/66/ss/ss6601a1.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;new study&lt;/a&gt; released this month by researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) highlights the health situation for those living the country life.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Americans living in rural areas face a higher risk of dying from the five leading causes of death in the United States — heart disease, cancer, lower respiratory disease, stroke, and unintentional injuries — compared with their urban counterparts.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“This report confirms the findings that we’ve seen in previous studies about rural populations tending to be older, poorer, and sicker,” Dr. Daniel Derksen, director of the Arizona Center for Rural Health, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Using mortality data from the National Vital Statistics System, CDC researchers determined that these five leading causes accounted for almost 62 percent of all deaths in the country.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Between 1999 and 2014, death rates for heart disease and cancer dropped across the country, but both fell more slowly in nonmetropolitan, or rural, areas.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Urban and rural areas saw similar drops in the death rates for stroke.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Death rates for chronic lower respiratory disease — which includes chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) — decreased in urban areas, but increased in rural areas.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers also estimated the percentages of “potentially excess deaths” by comparing the death rates in counties in states with the lowest rates. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These excesses for heart disease, unintentional injury, and chronic lower respiratory disease were higher in rural areas. They also are potential targets “for public health prevention efforts focused on rural populations,” the study authors wrote.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The rural-urban health gap, though, extends beyond disease mortality.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s not just the increased death rate, which is concerning and unacceptable enough,” said Derksen, “It’s also the collateral damage that these diseases cause.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Accidents and chronic diseases can lead to disability, which makes it harder for people to work. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;This can snowball, with people not being able to afford doctor visits, lab tests, prescription medications, or even a car to get to their appointments.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Lifestyles are a factor&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In 2014, approximately &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ers.usda.gov/topics/rural-economy-population/population-migration/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;15 percent of Americans&lt;/a&gt; — or 46 million people — lived in nonmetropolitan counties, spread across 72 percent of the country’s land area. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Overall life expectancy in the United States has increased over the past decades, but more slowly in rural areas. One &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cfah.org/hbns/2014/gap-in-life-expectancy-between-rural-and-urban-residents-is-growing&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;study&lt;/a&gt; found that the life expectancy gap between urban and rural areas has grown from 0.4 years in 1971 to 2.0 years in 2009.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Unhealthy behaviors may be dragging down the life expectancy and health of Americans living in rural areas.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ruralhealthinfo.org/topics/rural-health-disparities#mortality-rates&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;South Carolina Rural Health Research Center&lt;/a&gt;, Americans in rural areas are more likely to smoke, use alcohol or other substances, be physically inactive or overweight, or have poor access to healthy foods. They are also more likely to not wear car seat belts, a factor in motor vehicle deaths.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18257870&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Childhood obesity&lt;/a&gt; is also a particular problem in rural areas, with 25 percent of children overweight in 2008, compared with 19 percent of urban children.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Certain types of substance abuse affect rural areas more than urban ones, as well.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The opioid epidemic has been getting much attention in the press, and it’s certainly one that’s affecting rural areas more than urban areas, and rural areas have fewer resources to address it,” Carrie Henning-Smith, Ph.D., M.P.H., M.S.W., a research associate at the University of Minnesota Rural Health Research Center, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ruralhealthinfo.org/topics/substance-abuse#drinking&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2012 study&lt;/a&gt; by the Maine Rural Health Research Center concluded that alcohol use and binge drinking were more common among 12- to 13-year-olds in rural areas, compared with youth of the same ages in urban areas.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ruralhealthinfo.org/topics/substance-abuse&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Rural Health Information Hub&lt;/a&gt;, abuse of prescription opioids in the past year was more common in adults in urban areas than those in rural area. But rates of deaths and injuries from misuse of these drugs was higher in states with high rural populations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;What’s behind the health gap?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition to the unhealthy behaviors identified by the authors of the CDC report, other factors lie behind the rural-urban health gap.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“A lot of rural health disparities are driven not by one particular health issue, but by differences in the social determinants of health,” said Henning-Smith.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Those include unequal access to jobs or education, transportation, social activities, recreational facilities, and even whether there are sidewalks to encourage people to walk more.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“All of those things that we think of as going with health and being part of this healthy lifestyle aren’t necessarily embedded into the fabric of rural communities in the way they are in urban communities,” added Henning-Smith.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Economic factors, in particular, drain the health of rural America.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the &lt;a href=&quot;http://kff.org/uninsured/issue-brief/the-affordable-care-act-and-insurance-coverage-in-rural-areas/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Kaiser Commission on Medicaid and the Uninsured&lt;/a&gt;, rural areas have higher rates of poverty and unemployment as well as lower household incomes compared with urban areas. They also have lower rates of college or university education.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These are &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/minorityhealth/chdir/2011/factsheets/educationincome.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;all linked&lt;/a&gt; to an increased risk of death, unhealthy behaviors, poor access to healthcare, and inadequate quality of care.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Specific populations in rural areas may face their own unique problems.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Along the U.S.-Mexico border in Arizona, “there are not enough health providers that speak Spanish,” said Derksen. “Being able to communicate effectively in the language which they’re most comfortable with is an important factor” in accessing medical care.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In addition, Derksen added, “some chronic diseases tend to be more prevalent in certain populations,” including higher rates of type 2 diabetes in Hispanic adults.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Older people in rural areas — because of the larger distance from family and neighbors — are especially at risk of social isolation. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“A person might go longer without someone noticing that they’re not doing well,” said Henning-Smith. “So they might go longer without screening or treatment than someone who is in really close contact with people.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Then there are the wide open spaces to contend with.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some of the counties in Arizona are bigger than many New England states. And New England’s population is more than double that of Arizona.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;People may have to travel hours to get to the doctor or hospital. Without a car — or services like Uber or Lyft, which are not common in rural areas — this can be daunting.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ers.usda.gov/webdocs/publications/aib795/30150_aib795_lowres_002.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2005 USDA Information Bulletin&lt;/a&gt;, Americans living in rural areas without cars are more dependent on public transportation. But only 60 percent of rural counties offer any services.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s not as though people in urban areas don’t also live in poverty or struggle to afford a car,” said Henning-Smith. “But there’s the infrastructure to get to the doctor if they need to. There are public transportation options — albeit not perfect — but they exist. In a lot of rural communities, they don’t exist at all.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;And when older adults are placed in long-term care facilities, they may end up far from home.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“That’s really disruptive for someone who’s lived their whole life, or a good portion of their life, in a community,” said Henning-Smith, “to suddenly find themselves somewhere else just to get the care that they need.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Boosting rural health&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;Some of these issues may be easier to address than others.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;In a &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/66/ss/ss6602a1.htm&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;related commentary&lt;/a&gt;, CDC authors call for improved public health prevention efforts focused on rural populations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These would target risk factors for the leading causes of death through increased screenings for high blood pressure, cholesterol, and cancer, as well as smoking cessation programs. It would also include educating people about eating better, exercising more, and motor vehicle safety.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Others see a need for a broader approach.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“How do we really transform lives and communities, not only within the doctor’s office, but throughout every aspect of their lives?” said Henning-Smith. “We know this impacts health much more than what happens just in the doctor’s office.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Part of the challenge again is the fabric of rural America.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“These are very large areas, often considered frontier in terms of population density,” said Derksen. “How do you get the information out to those folks who really need it?”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Public health and education efforts alone will not reduce rural health disparities. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Compared to cities, rural areas suffer from two factors that continue to widen the health gap.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“The combination of not enough providers, not enough clinics, not enough hospitals — along with a high rate of uninsured — is a kind of a recipe for health system failure,” said Derksen.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These issues can limit people’s access to healthcare — and to the screenings, vaccinations, and treatments that can improve a person’s health or reduce the severity of a disease.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;According to the &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ruralhealthinfo.org/topics/rural-health-disparities&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Rural Health Information Hub&lt;/a&gt;, less than 10 percent of doctors set up practice in rural areas.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There are often not the number or array of specialty physicians, clinics, and hospitals readily available for people to access primary care, preventive, and specialty services,” said Derksen.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Rural demographics play a role, too, as seen with a shortage of caregivers for older adults.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“There’s not the same workforce, partly because the population structure is different,” said Henning-Smith “You don’t have the same number, or proportion, of younger folks there to help take care of older folks.” &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Programs like the National Health Service Corps, which offers loan forgiveness to providers who practice in rural areas, take a financial incentive approach to luring providers to these more remote locations.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;But sometimes exposing people to the best of rural America is enough to keep them there.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“When we educate our health professionals in these types of areas,” said Derksen, “they tend to go into those areas to practice more often.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Tackling the health insurance beast&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;One of the biggest successes for rural America in recent years was the Affordable Care Act (ACA) — in particular, provisions for the expansion of Medicaid in states, and subsidies to offset the cost of health insurance for many people. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Those two factors halved our uninsured [in Arizona],” said Derksen. “Before these coverage provisions of the Affordable Care Act went into place, of our 6.5 million total population, 1.2 million were uninsured. We halved that.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;These factors also revitalized small, rural hospitals — known as Critical Access Hospitals. These hospitals, which have 25 beds or less and are 35 miles or more from another facility, serve a sparse population.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;If someone without insurance shows up at a hospital needing care, most hospitals will treat them. This “charity care” is a drain on all hospitals, but more so on small ones that you find in rural areas.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Increased insurance coverage through Medicaid and federal insurance subsidies relieved some of this burden.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Rural and critical access hospitals across the country have been closing at a very disturbing rate,” said Derksen. “That decline was certainly stabilized with the sharp reduction in uncompensated care, as more people were covered.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;With the Republican-controlled Congress already dismantling the ACA, the future health of people living in rural areas — like the healthcare system itself — remains uncertain.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“A lot of us in public health are apprehensive,” said Derksen. “I think ‘repeal and replace’ is a catchy phrase. It has a nice alliteration, but it’s not a health plan. It’s not a public health intervention in itself.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;However, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.npr.org/2016/11/14/501737150/rural-voters-played-a-big-part-in-helping-trump-defeat-clinton&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;rural voters&lt;/a&gt; played a big part in President Donald Trump’s election in November.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Any politician would be prudent to pay attention to the constituents that got them into office,” said Derksen. “What I’m hopeful for is that there will be more health policy attention paid to rural populations.”&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
]]>
</description>
<category>General Health</category>
<pubdate>2017-01-20T12:00:00</pubdate>
<updateddate>2017-01-20T12:00:00</updateddate>

<dc:creator>Shawn Radcliffe</dc:creator>

<item>
<title>Is Sweat the New Blood?</title>
<link>
http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/health-news/is-sweat-the-new-blood
</link>
<description>
<![CDATA[
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://shonnavalli-dev.healthline.com/hlcmsresource/images/News/011917_sweat_THUMB.jpg&quot; width=&quot;&quot; height=&quot;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; image-copyright=&quot;&quot; image-has-syndication-rights=&quot;1&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Kenzen, a S
]]>
<![CDATA[
an Francisco-based startup that creates wearable diagnostics, is developing a product that promises to provide real-time feedback on the wearer’s health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The only thing it needs to measure this data is sweat.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The company’s &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.kenzen.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;ECHO Smart Patch&lt;/a&gt; is a small, flexible, adhesive patch that connects wirelessly to a monitor to measure the wearer’s vital signs.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kenzen executives hopes the device will become available online to consumers by the end of the year.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It continuously measures a wide range of biometrics and gathers reliable data to monitor health, and predict and prevent injuries and avoidable health conditions,” Dr. Sonia Sousa, chief executive officer and co-founder of Kenzen, told Healthline in an email. “Individual physiology varies, but most users begin sweating after approximately 15 to 20 minutes of heavy exertion. The sweat is transported across the ECHO Smart Patch to its sensors, which immediately begin analyzing various biomarker concentrations.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Experts interviewed by Healthline say the device shows promise, but it will take time for medical professionals to properly apply the data it measures to individuals.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;Sweat provides insights&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;While not as common as blood tests, sweat tests can provide valuable information on a person’s health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Lots of things can be measured in sweat and the new technology to do so is interesting,” Dr. Benjamin D. Levine, director of the Institute for Exercise and Environmental Medicine, told Healthline.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Cystic fibrosis, for instance, is generally diagnosed using a simple test that measures salt levels in a patient’s sweat.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Performance labs will also swab athletes before and after a workout session in order to gather data.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Sousa says that sweat contains several biomarkers that can help assess an individual’s health.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Minerals such as sodium and potassium can be detected, but surprisingly, sweat also holds proteins, hormones, and larger molecules like glucose, lactate, and cortisol, which can be used to measure calorie intake and output, muscle fatigue, and even stress levels,” she said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“It’s really a way to look at electrolyte balance,” Dr. James Borchers, head team physician for athletics, and director of medical services for The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center, told Healthline. “Performance and biomarkers and athletes’ health are definitely areas where a lot of people are looking to the future because they don’t want to be invasive and do a blood draw, a finger stick, or something like that, in order to get this information.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Blood panels are, and will likely continue to be, the gold standard for full clinical assessment,” notes Sousa. “We believe, however, that people need continuous measurements, in context, in order to get ahead of injuries and adverse health conditions. Drawing blood just isn’t easy, affordable, or convenient. And although not a direct correlation to blood, sweat provides a wealth of information about an individual’s health, is readily available, and can be collected and measured painlessly.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;h2&gt;The next generation in fitness tracking?&lt;/h2&gt; &lt;p&gt;The wearable technology industry has been projected to be worth &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.forbes.com/sites/paullamkin/2016/02/17/wearable-tech-market-to-be-worth-34-billion-by-2020/#388c93f03fe3&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;$34 billion&lt;/a&gt; by 2020.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Most fitness trackers use relatively simple technology to measure step counts, heart rate, and little else — but that is poised to change.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://journals.plos.org/plosbiology/article?id=10.1371/journal.pbio.2001402&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Stanford University study&lt;/a&gt;, released this month, concluded that wearable biosensors can provide useful health data and “might be used as a diagnostic tool to spot disease early.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Researchers added that it will take some time before this technology finds its way into the hands of consumers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kenzen’s patch, assuming it’s released on schedule, is poised to become one of the first advanced wearable biosensors to become widely available. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Borchers says a sweat-monitoring patch could be useful in a sports context.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“I think it could be applied to, for example, endurance athletes, to look at their performance and their health. Same thing for football players. I do think it could give athletic trainers, coaching staffs, and physicians a lot of information about athletes and their training, and what their needs could be moving forward,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;Kenzen’s team echoes this, focusing on professional and elite-level athletes as an initial go-to-market strategy before trickling down to other athletes and consumers.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The company has partnered with two professional sports team — the National Football League’s San Francisco 49ers as well as FC Dallas of Major League Soccer.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;The technology shows promise, but Levine cautions that it will take some time for the health community to properly apply the data.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Right now, the technology appears to be ahead of the knowledge required to use the information appropriately in making decisions about individual patients or athletes,” he said.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;While the technology is still in its infancy, Kenzen has big plans.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;“Imagine that you get a notification before you get hurt, sick, or develop a more serious medical condition. Would your behavior change? How much could we save on expensive medical treatments if chronic conditions could be detected earlier? Could coaches and trainers preempt costly injuries by pulling players off the field before they cramp up? Would you have more peace of mind if you could remotely monitor your kids’ or mother’s hydration level?” asks Sousa. “We believe all of these things could soon be a reality, and we’re committed to keeping our users safe. Kenzen’s mission is to predict and prevent avoidable injuries and adverse health conditions — and we plan to do this using a simple little patch.”&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
]]>
